HEADLINE: Why South Africa Has to Privatize Now

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A great disservice to public understanding of South Africa's economic situation is done by Adam Hochschild's article on privatization in South Africa ("A Fire Sale in South Africa," Op-Ed, Nov. 2).
The motive behind privatization, be it in England, the Soviet Union or South Africa, is to encourage efficiency and economic growth, and to disengage the state from activities not central to government's essential responsibilities, i.e., administration of justice, public safety, foreign affairs. Mr. Hochschild would keep these enterprises in the hands of the state to facilitate affirmative action four or five years from now. He ignores that the South African economy desperately needs the revitalization privatization can assist. Even more disturbing, he forgets that the economy is the economy that will serve all South Africans, black or white. It will serve them well if it is healthy and growing, badly if it stagnates.
The South African economy has been stagnant for years and will probably grow less than .5 percent this year, while population growth continues at 2.4 percent and unemployment is at 15 percent. As the country looks forward to majority rule, it will need not only to create employment, but also to equalize per capita expenditures in health, education, welfare and housing. It also needs to begin land redistribution with fair compensation, and with financing for the purchasers. Both programs involve massive funds. The only significant budgetary offset will be a reduction in military expenditures. Increased taxation will be a very limited source of funds for a country seeking a dramatic increase in economic growth.
President F. W. de Klerk's mandate expires in 1994, when a majority elected government is expected to come in. South Africa cannot wait four years to liberalize an economy that has nearly stopped growing. Liberalization must go ahead full speed. Also, the world's economic powers should study massive economic aid for South Africa, because in the short run the country cannot generate the wealth to meet the growing but reasonable expectations of its population. Mr. Hochschild's assumptions obscure this, and so does the equally incorrect assumption that removing sanctions will revitalize the South African economy.
 
JOHN E. PURCELL
Buenos Aires, Nov. 12, 1990
 
The writer was a consultant to the Rev. Dr. Leon Sullivan in writing the Sullivan Principles for United States companies in South Africa.

HEADLINE: Albanian Exile Writer Sees Reform

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Ismail Kadare, the pre-eminent writer of Albania, says he sought refuge in France a month ago because of "the conviction that more than any action I could take in Albania, my defection would help the democratization of my country."
Albania is Europe's last Communist-ruled country, and Mr. Kadare, whose novels and poems have been published in about a million copies, has been a national figure there comparable in popularity perhaps to Mark Twain in the United States. His works have been translated into 15 languages. 
 In response to written questions, the 54-year-old author, in his first interview since defecting, said he had been subjected to "threats from the Sigurimi," Albania's ubiquitous secret police. This, together with his disappointment over the Government's rough handling of some 5,000 asylum seekers at foreign embassies in Tirana last summer, prompted him to leave, he said.
"In the case of democratic processes in Albania, the pace of change is a matter of life and death," he said, referring to President Ramiz Alia's seventh-month-old program of cautious political and economic change. "If I had any doubt that accelerating such processes would cause unrest and anarchy and thus hurt the Albanian nation, I would never raise this issue. But I am convinced the contrary is true. I am convinced that a delay in this direction will be fatal."
 
Sees End of Dictatorship
 He also said he was "deeply convinced" that despite more than four decades of Stalinist rule, the 3.3 million people of Albania would be able to shake off dictatorship.
"This is a people with a rich internal resource," he said, "a strong tradition and a great sense of justice. The Albanian people will be able to take the right step in these difficult times. The evil has not penetrated this country to the extent it is commonly thought."
Like other literary works created under a Communist dictatorship, Mr. Kadare's writing may be read in different ways and on different levels. He has, in the words of Arshi Pipa, an Albanian-American critic, "a double-entendre way of writing, allusive and analogical and often allegoric, punctuated by insinuating hints."
Mr. Kadare has been as much a source of controversy at home as he is in literary circles abroad. His novels and verses both criticized and praised the regime of Enver Hoxha, the Communist tyrant who died in 1985. For instance, his "Chronicle in Stone," published in 1971, portrays life in Gjirokaster, where both he and Mr. Hoxha were born, in a series of sketches. Some of these obliquely cast Mr. Hoxha in a lurid light.
But in "The Great Winter," a novel about Albania's break with the Soviet Union in 1960, Mr. Kadare depicts Mr. Hoxha as a national hero for defying Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader at the time, as he had also done in a long poem called "The Sixties."
 
No Repudiation
 Asked whether he might revise his views of the Hoxha era, which lasted 40 years, Mr. Kadare replied: "There is no need for me to change. Moreover, I will never repudiate what I have written. I have no intention of throwing mud on some 50 years in the life of my people."
He denied that he had enjoyed the protection of Mr. Hoxha, saying: "For 20 years they have attacked me continually. Do you believe that someone in Albania could have been attacked especially in such a harsh manner, if he had the real protection of Enver Hoxha?"
The writer said that if anyone had protected him, it was "the entire Albanian nation" by its overwhelming approval of his works. Indeed, there is hardly an Albanian household without a Kadare book, and even foreign visitors are presented with volumes of his verse as souvenirs. "Had it been up to dogmatic officials, my work would have been buried a long time ago," he said.
He mentioned an incident in 1975 when he had submitted a poem called "Red Pashas" attacking the Communist bureaucracy. Saying the poem amounted to a call for an uprising, the party bureaucracy prevented its publication, forced Mr. Kadare to express self-criticism and barred him from publishing for a time. "No one came to my defense," he said.
Earlier this year, he said, the secret police had fabricated statements charging that he had condemned the Tirana asylum-seekers. He called this "a cynical lie."
"The final thrust," he continued, "was the direct or indirect threats from the Sigurimi, which wanted to settle old scores. The Sigurimi would have used the first signs of unrest to settle those scores."
 
Police Arrest List Reported
 Mr. Kadare was alluding here to a purported list of about 100 Albanian intellectuals to be arrested by the security police. The existence of the list was rumored in Tirana last spring and summer as an apparent attempt to intimidate the intellectuals. The author was reportedly on this list.
Mr. Kadare acknowledged that he had met and discussed his views on Albania's future with President Alia -- most recently in August -- and that, "although my dialogue with him has been interrupted, I still believe one can talk to and have a dialogue with him."
He also said it was evident that the Alia regime was not as harsh as that of Mr. Hoxha's. "The regime in the current phase is much less dictatorial," he said.
The author had already been in France for several weeks when he announced that he was seeking political asylum on Oct. 25. Some 28 hours passed before the official Albanian press agency issued a brief statement on "this ugly act," saying Mr. Kadare had placed himself "in the services of the enemies of Albania."
In the interview, Mr. Kadare said: "Dogmatic officials have always done things like this. Those who are so vigilant to protect a criminal and enemy of Albania, like Stalin, are ready to reject, even with pleasure, national values. But it is now too late. Their time is running out."
 
Other Writers React
 The immediate reactions from leading Tirana writers mixed regret with friendship and admiration for Mr. Kadare. "I continue to have great respect for his work," said Dritero Agolli, a poet who heads the Albanian Writers' Union.
"I feel abandoned." Nezhat Tozaj, a novelist, commented. "I am still his friend."
Since his defection, Mr. Kadare has remained in seclusion, his whereabouts kept confidential by his Paris publisher. The interview questions were transmitted to him in French through the publisher. His responses were provided in Albanian two weeks later.
He said his defection was "inadvertently" prefigured last spring in a poem titled "Insufficient Time," his last to be published in Albania. In it he speaks of approaching his grave, and he said in the interview, "Departure from this world has been identified with fleeing the motherland."
The final stanza is:
Tormented until the last moment
By the silence and by being a tragic hostage
Perhaps with an incomprehensible signal
I will take leave of all and escape.

HEADLINE: William Hall Wendel Dies at 76; Former Head of Kennecott Copper

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ

 BODY:
William Hall Wendel, the retired president of the Carborundum Company and the Kennecott Copper Corporation, died on Monday at his winter home in Savannah, Ga. He was 76 years old and lived in Savannah and Buffalo.
He died of a heart attack, a spokesman for the family said.
Mr. Wendel joined Carborundum as an assistant to the president in 1947 after serving with the Army and Navy Munitions Board, the War Productions Board and as an assistant to the president of United Engineering Company. 
 In 1948 he was promoted to manager of the coated products division. He was named executive vice president in 1959 and president in 1962, and directed the company through its greatest period of growth, including 10 major acquisitions.
In 1977 Carborundum was sold to the Kennecott Copper Corporation for about $560 million, and Mr. Wendel became president of Kennecott, which has since been acquired by Standard Oil (Ohio). He stepped down in 1980. In retirement, he served for five years as chairman of Polaris Industries, a Minneapolis company he and others acquired. It manufactures all-terrain vehicles and other transportation equipment.
 
Promoted Niagara Area
 Mr. Wendel was a leading spokesman for the economic, cultural and social concerns in the Buffalo-Niagara Falls area. He helped found the Society for the Promotion, Unification and Redevelopment of Niagara, an organization to spur business development in the area.
He worked to rebuild the city of Niagara Falls and was responsible for the construction of a $4.5 million downtown headquarters for Carborundum. He also served on the board of the Roger Tory Peterson Institute, which preserves bird sanctuaries, and on the boards of Allegheny International, the Dunlop Tire & Rubber Corporation, the Energy Reserves Group, the New York Telephone Company and the Norfolk & Western Railway Company.
Mr. Wendel graduated from the United States Naval Academy in 1936 and the Harvard Business School in 1940. He was a member of the American Society of Corporate Executives, a commissioner of the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority, and chairman of the State University of New York College of Environmental Sciences and Forestry at Syracuse.
He is survived by his wife, Louise; two sons, William Jr. and Jeffrey, both of Minneapolis; a daughter, Christine Longyear of Baltimore, and three grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Hall Wendel (The New York Times, 1977)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Australian to Become Head of BTR of Britain

BYLINE: By Marion Underhill

 BODY:
BTR P.L.C., the British conglomerate, has named Alan Jackson as managing director and chief executive, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Jackson, a 54-year-old Australian, succeeds John C. Cahill, who steps down at the company's retirement age of 60.
Mr. Jackson joined the BTR group in 1977 as managing director of what became BTR Nylex Ltd., one of Australia's most dynamic international companies, which is 62 percent owned by BTR. After a period of development and local acquisitions, BTR Nylex expanded in the 1980's by acquiring large international enterprises, including the China General Plastics Corporation of Taiwan, ACI International Ltd. of Australia and Feltrax of New Zealand. 
 BTR P.L.C. is a London-based global corporation comprising more than 500 companies operating in five business sectors: industrial, control systems and electrical, construction, transportation and consumer.
In April, the company began a $1.64 billion hostile bid for the Norton Company, the abrasives group in Worcester, Mass., but lost out to Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, the French glass manufacturer, which topped the offer at almost $2 billion. A month later, BTR said its wholly owned subsidiary, the Schlegel Corporation in Rochester, had agreed to buy the United Technologies Corporation's Global Automotive Sealing Systems group for approximately $200 million cash.
Commenting on the appointment, Sir Owen Green, BTR's chairman, said: "Alan Jackson has an outstanding record, evidenced by the dramatic growth of BTR Nylex over the past 13 years. He now takes on the most challenging role within our group, following the sterling achievements of John Cahill."
Mr. Jackson is married with four daughters. He is a member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia and an active contributor to the Economic Planning Advisory Council of Australia. He was voted Australia's Businessman of the Year in 1985 and 1989.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
New York State Offering Pollution-Control Bonds

 BODY:
The New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation is offering $68.1 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds to finance water-pollution-control projects. The offering is through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The maximum yield is 7.20 percent for an issue due 2011. Shorter maturities offer yields ranging from 5.45 percent for securities due in 1991 to 6.05 percent in 1995, 6.55 percent in 2000 and 6.90 percent in 2004.
Underwriters said the financing was rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Money from the bonds will provide low-interest loans to eight municipalities in the state to finance pollution-control projects through the state revolving-fund program.
Three of the loans will finance new construction, four will refinance continuing projects and one will be used for both new construction and refinancing. The Governor's office said the loans would save the municipalities more than $15 million in interest costs, helping to hold down their charges for sewer service.
The state agency selects the municipalities based on a rating system that gives priority to projects that address the most pressing needs.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Indications That War Tension Is Easing

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell on world currency markets yesterday as the prospects for war dimmed after the offer by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to release all foreigners detained in Iraq and Kuwait.
The market interpreted his offer "as a sign war tensions were easing, and the dollar fell sharply," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the firm IDEA. The dollar is typically viewed as an investment haven during world turmoil. 
 But as the session wore on, Mr. Chandler said it became clearer to traders that Saddam Hussein was actually prepared for war and made the offer because his troops were now fully deployed in Kuwait. That assessment helped the dollar firm a bit around midday, but it then languished for the remainder of the session.
"The market was supporting the dollar on a war premium and took it down on a peace premium," said Michael Malpede, a senior analyst at Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago.
Also putting pressure on the dollar was anticipation over the release today of November unemployment data. Analysts expect the Labor Department report will show an increase in initial jobless claims and a higher overall unemployment rate for the month.
"That will further confirm the slowdown of the U.S. economy and add pressure on the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates," Mr. Chandler said. Lower interest rates erode the value of dollar-denominated securities and therefore decrease investors' need for the United States currency.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 134.05 Japanese yen, from 133.42 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, it fell to 132.35 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 132.14 yen, down from 133.63 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9390, from $1.9225 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.9400 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.9260.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.4885 marks, from 1.4993 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.2710 Swiss francs, down from 1.2795; 5.0510 French francs, down from 5.0770; 1,122.25 Italian lire, down from 1,127.68, and 1.1621 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1630.
Silver prices showed a decline. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.121 a troy ounce, down from $4.148 on Wednesday. In London silver was unchanged at a late bid price of $4.16 a troy ounce.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
'Phantom Income' Created by Swaps

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
JUST when "junk bond" investors might have thought things could get no worse, Congress has voted to raise taxes on companies that issue such high-yield bonds and get into trouble.
The new law threatens to force companies, and in some cases bondholders, to pay taxes on "phantom income" created when troubled companies restructure their debt to survive. 
 Depending on how the Internal Revenue Service interprets the law, it could mean the death of the public junk bond market by offering companies a big tax advantage if they keep their bonds out of the public market.
The law will be most severe on companies that try to restructure their bonds without going into bankruptcy court. Those that seek Chapter 11 protection from their creditors can escape the law's most severe restrictions, but they face a provision that reduces the flexibility of choosing bankruptcy.
In essence, the law changes the tax treatment when companies swap new securities for old bonds. Those swaps are typically made by companies that are in financial distress and cannot meet the terms of their old obligations. Under the old law, it was easy for the company in question to avoid paying tax on the phantom income that was, in effect, generated when a loan was forgiven. Under the new law, that will remain the case only if the bonds in question are not publicly traded; if they are, much harsher rules will apply.
"Congress has imposed a tax on the theoretical income of companies which have fallen on hard times," said Joni L. Nelson, a partner in the New York law firm of Rogers & Wells. "This blow to restructuring seems particularly inappropriate foran economy on the precipice of recession."
The new law "really is biased in favor of non-publicly traded situations," said Robert Willens, an accountant and tax analyst at Lehman Brothers. He said many on Wall Street hoped the I.R.S. would impose a strict and restrictive definition of publicly traded, confining the category to bonds traded on an exchange, not to bonds traded over the counter with prices quoted on what are known in the trade as yellow sheets.
But if a broader definition is established, the result could be to force many companies to remove the bonds from the public market altogether by no longer filing information with the Securities and Exchange Commission. That step could save taxes, but at the cost of depriving investors information and possibly making it harder for current bondholders to find buyers for their bonds.
The new law, which took effect on Oct. 7 but did not cover exchange offers under way then, can be most easily viewed through an example of a troubled company that originally sold a publicly traded $1,000 bond at face value, with a coupon of perhaps 16 percent. Suppose the company reaches an agreement with bondholders to exchange that bond for a similar one with an interest rate of 12 percent, and with most of those interest payments deferred. The new bond begins trading at $700.
Under the old law, there would have been no tax effect. But under the new law, Mr. Willens said, the company would owe tax immediately on the $300 "profit." If the company has sufficient losses tooffset that gain, it will not have any immediate tax to pay, but that phantom profit will effectively reduce the operating earnings that can be sheltered from taxes by loss carry-forwards.
Over the life of the bonds, the company may be able to recoup that $300 through deductions from taxable income, but those tax effects will be delayed. And to add insult to injury, the holder of the bonds, like an individual or a junk bond mutual fund, will have to report phantom income each year totaling $300 over the life of the bond.
That is the treatment if the company's bonds are publicly traded. But if they are not, and there is no trading price, the I.R.S. will assume the bond is worth face value, so long as the new bond has an interest rate at least as high as Treasury rates, now below 9 percent. The result is that a company with publicly traded bonds would pay taxes on phantom income, whereas an identical company with bonds that are not publicly traded would not.
Bond swaps in bankruptcy proceedings have always been exempt from taxation, so long as a significant amount of stock was included in the package. The new law changes that by saying that certain types of preferred stock -- those with a specified maturity price and a required redemption date -- do not qualify as stock for that purpose. The result is likely to be that different kinds of stock will be used in restructurings, with more reliance on common stock.
Nonetheless, the bankruptcy exception will remain. In the earlier example, where a bond worth $700 was issued in exchange for a bond that had cost $1,000, there would be no tax penalty for the company if stock that had more than a "nominal" value was included in the package. That term has never been exactly defined, but the I.R.S. said yesterday that it was considering a rule that would require the stock to be worth at least one-tenth of the value of the debt being canceled.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A 'Happy Ending' In Gulf Is Doubted

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE greatest uncertainty hanging over the economy and the financial markets is whether the confrontation in the Persian Gulf will end in war or peace. Markets got a shot in the arm this week when President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accepted President Bush's proposal for discussions in Washington and Baghdad with their respective chief foreign officers. And yesterday word came that Mr. Hussein said he would allow all hostages to leave Iraq and Kuwait.
However, the end game of this affair is tricky -- and could take a lot longer than the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations resolutions calling for full Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, restoration of the Kuwaiti Government and release of all hostages. President Hussein will doubtless seek to escape from some of those terms. 
 President Bush said he was not convinced that Mr. Hussein had yet got the message from the U.N. that "all means" would be used against him if he did not get out. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said that as a "reward" for full Iraqi withdrawal and release of all hostages, the United States was prepared to offer assurances that it would not take military action.
Does all this mean that peace is about to break out? Not necessarily. A high-ranking Western diplomat, just back from discussions in Iraq, said in a not-for-attribution interview this week that he still thought the resolution of the crisis would be by war. He said President Hussein, in his talks with Mr. Baker, might agree to full withdrawal from Kuwait and release of all the hostages -- but that he would delay and delay, offering one pretext after another, while holding on to parts of Kuwait and to some hostages. In the end, he said, warwould come. Similarly, Robert D. Hormats, a former State Department official and now vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, said this week that "the probability of war is increasing" because "Saddam Hussein thinks President Bush does not have the support of the United States people on a commitment to war." Mr. Hussein's belief in American irresolution could force the United States into war.
What Mr. Hormats fears most is the so-called 80 percent solution, with Mr. Hussein giving up 80 percent of Kuwait and keeping the other 20 percent -- including oilfields, two islands, and "the knowledge that he had stood the United States down." Such a "solution," Mr. Hormats said, "could be worse than war," since it would cause the coalition to fragment and would leave Iraq in a position to earn enormous profits from oil, which it would use to buy advanced military technology, dominate the gulf and become a far more dangerous enemy. With Mr. Hussein's instructions to his parliament to release all hostages, the 80 percent solution looks even more probable as his basic ploy.
If war comes, will it be quick or protracted?Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist of the Midland Bank in New York, said the Bush Administration was counting on a quick solution that would bring oil prices back to pre-crisis levels, raise consumer confidence and stimulate economic recovery.
"They have blamed the Middle East situation as the key factor causing the present economic downturn and are stressing that the resolution of the Middle East crisis will be the principal salvation for the economy," he said. Mr. Fabbri considers this a falsely optimistic view and contends that "the massive financial problems of the economy must be worked out before a meaningful expansion can emerge."
Most oil experts believe, as Charles L. Schultze of the Brookings Institution said this week, that if war broke out and ended quickly it would temporarily raise oil prices sharply and depress financial markets, but "sustained disruptions to oil supplies would not occur."
Oil prices would then fall back below today's levels, and financial markets would soon recover, Mr. Schultze said. But two "low probability" outcomes, he added, might confound the experts and disrupt this rather optimistic assessment: first, a long-lasting, high-intensity war and, second, substantial damage by the Iraqis of oil installations in the gulf.
The talks with Iraq may well give a lift to spirits, and markets, in coming weeks. But a true resolution of the conflict may remain out of reach. The tougher the United States stance, the greater the hope of a lasting settlement. But the chances of miscalculation are great.
At this point, as Prof. M. A. Adelman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology observes, it is hard to envision a "happy ending," for if President Hussein goes before his people as a "discredited C.E.O. with two big, failed investments, Iran and Kuwait," he himself may be liquidated. But if he escapes with some gains in the gulf, he will live to make even bigger trouble another day.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Ease

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly, and interest rates moved up a bit in light trading yesterday, as dealers awaited this morning's release of November employment data.
"It's a very quiet market," said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. "Caution and profit taking are the watchwords of the day. The market has come a long way, and there is a big number on Friday. At this point people are unwilling to make purchases." 
 Most economists are expecting the employment numbers will show that economic conditions deteriorated further last month. A sharp decline in non-farm payroll employment and a fairly sizable increase in the unemployment rate are anticipated.
A survey of economists about the employment report by MMS International, an economic information service company, shows that most are projecting a decline of 75,000 in nonfarm payroll employment and a rise in the unemployment rate to 5.9 percent, from 5.7 percent in October.
"The employment numbers will be important," said Michael R. Englund, a vice president and director of research at MMS, "but a lot will hinge on what happens in the Middle East. If there was a significant move in Iraq, that would likely overshadow the employment report."
Mr. Englund and others said that a news report stating that a news conference had been scheduled by Iraq for early this morning accentuated the possibility that additional important news might be forthcoming.
 
Gulf Report Affects Oil
 Reports that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq may release the remaining hostages held in Iraq helped push oil prices lower yesterday, sending prices of fixed-income securities up at first. But later in the session prices in the credit markets fell back.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered in late trading at a price of 104 19/32, down 6/32, to yield 8.32 percent, compared with 8.31 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 7/ 32, down 1/8 point, to yield 8.16 percent. And the 7 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 26/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.47 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.99 percent, up one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point. And six-month bill rates rose by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.87 percent.
New issuance remained strong in the investment-grade corporate bond market yesterday, as five companies offered a total of $875 million worth of securities.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade bonds said that the heavy flow of new securities over the last few weeks was having a salutary effect on the overall market.
"We are getting a reprieve from all the nervousness that has been in the market," one corporate bond trader said.
He said that prices of a General Motors 10-year issue that was priced on Wednesday at $100, or par, improved by about half a point yesterday. Bonds issued by major commercial banks also rose in price.
In general, traders said that prices of most intermediate-term corporate issues rose by about1/8 point, while longer-dated securities slipped by about 1/4 point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues fell by 1/4 point to 1/2 point, dealers said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Nov. 26.
The money report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Gephardt Says G.O.P. Trades on Racial Divisions

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, accused Republican strategists today of "following a new trail of racial resentment" and seeking political gain by dividing whites and blacks over the issue of affirmative action.
In a strikingly partisan speech that set out lines of attack for the new Democratic Congress, Mr. Gephardt also scoffed at the notion, advanced by some Republicans, of a "new paradigm" for Federal programs. Advocates of the "new paradigm" describe it as a new approach to government that emphasizes less bureaucracy, more individual choice and the operation of free market forces. 
 Mr. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat, suggested that it was simply a Republican dodge. "David Stockman admitted that the supply-side economics of the 1980's was nothing more than a Trojan Horse for the old, discredited trickle-down theory," Mr. Gephardt said, alluding to President Ronald Reagan's first budget director.
 
'A Trojan Polo Pony'
 "By that standard, the New Paradigm may be nothing more than a Trojan polo pony, providing attractive cover for yet another assault on working families and another giveaway for the privileged," he asserted in an address before the Center for National Policy, a Democratic-oriented policy group in Washington.
Mr. Gephardt, who sought the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988 and who is mentioned as a potential future contender, has often helped frame the Democratic debate in recent months and notably in last fall's budget negotiations.
He delivered a biting counterattack on quotas, an issue that many Democrats assert is being used by Republicans to polarize the races and peel white voters away from the Democrats. The next chairman of the Republican National Committee, William J. Bennett, has said that quotas were worthy of debate and he has defended the use of the issue by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina in his successful campaign against Harvey Gantt, a Democrat who was the first black mayor of Charlotte.
In that race, a Helms campaign advertisement showed white hands crumpling a rejection letter while an announcer declared, "You needed that job, and you were the best qualified. But they had to give it to a minority because of a racial quota." The commercial echoed a charge by Republicans that the civil rights bill vetoed by President Bush this year would have led to the adoption of quotas by employers.
"The ideologues on the right are following a new trail of racial resentment and recrimination blazed by David Duke, then trod successfully by Jesse Helms, and now given a tarnished patina of intellectual respectability by William Bennett," Mr. Gephardt said, alluding to the politics of Mr. Duke, the Louisiana State Representative who is a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan.
 
Some Are Said to Seek Divisions
 Mr. Gephardt, noting that many "conscientious Republicans" supported the civil rights bill, asserted that "certain Republican strategists seek to divide white working people from black working people, and thereby distract them from their common interests and concerns: that under Republican rule, the system works for the rich, but not for them."
Mr. Gephardt repeated the Democrats' stated intent to move quickly on the civil rights bill when the 102d Congress convenes in January.
Charles Black, chief spokesman for the Republican National Committee, today countered, "The whole theme he's representing is nonsense, and it's a cheap shot to inject David Duke into this debate since David Duke is out of the mainstream and has been vigorously opposed by Republicans and Democrats."
Mr. Black added, "It's obvious that Congressman Gephardt is hiding from discussing the merits of this issue. The President wants a civil rights bill. The Democrats want a quota bill."

HEADLINE: Slow Start For Holiday Retail Sales

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
The Christmas shopping season that began last month started off more slowly than last year's, bearing out pessimistic forecasts for the holiday period as a whole, according to reports yesterday from a number of the nation's leading retailers.
The downtrend is most evident at stores that have been open at least a year, a measure considered more important than sales including new stores. 
 Retailers with a wide variety of merchandise and price levels generally reported declines in November from the level a year earlier by the "same store" measure. Among them were Sears, J. C. Penney, May Department Stores, Neiman Marcus, Venture, Carter Hawley Hale and Mercantile Stores.
 
An Important Month
 November is an important month in retailers' calendars, traditionally ranking second only to December. In women's apparel, for example, December's share of yearly sales is 13.9 percent and November's is 9.3 percent, according to the National Retail Federation.
The disappointing sales results added another indication that the nation was in a recession.
"The overriding issue in the retail business is the economy," said Janet Mangano, research director at Jesup, Josephthal & Company in New York. "People's jobs are less secure and income isn't rising as much."
The buying malaise seemed to spread across department stores, specialty stores and discounters. Even Wal-Mart Stores, the Sun Belt discounter that is the country's fastest-growing retailer, registered only a 7 percent rise in same-store sales in November, smaller than its normal double-digit gain.
 
Delays in Purchasing
 Both retailers and analysts said yesterday that it appears that the last, frantic days will make or break the season. One reason for the delay in buying is the public's perception that shoppers can get lower prices if they wait, they said.
"It is clearly a more competitive and more promotional holiday season," said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, in Minneapolis.
In many cases, the reporting companies gave two sets of figures for the month the ended Dec. 1. This was because the retail accounting calendar adds an extra week every few years. This year, the Christmas selling season contains the extra week, so that the monthly sales figures reported yesterday were arbitrarily higher than in the period last year. For this reason, the retailers also reported sales figures that were adjusted as if the number of weeks were equal in both the 1990 and 1989 periods.
Other than Dayton Hudson, which operates not only department stores but promotional apparel and discount stores, the industry's department store segment was battered in the month, according to results computed on the adjusted basis.
Dayton Hudson had a 15.1 percent rise in November sales over all, to $1.55 billion, and a rise of 3.4 percent in same-store sales. But May Department Stores' sales slipped two-tenths of 1 percent in November, to $964.5 million, with a 5 percent drop in same-store sales in the month. Carter Hawley Hale's sales in November dropped 5.4 percent, to $272.7 million, and same-store sales fell 7.4 percent.
 
Discounters Fared Better
 As a group, discounters like Hills Department Stores and Jamesway Stores fared better in the month than traditional department stores or large, mass-volume retailers like Sears.
Some retailers, including R. H. Macy & Company and Montgomery Ward & Company, do not report their sales on a monthly basis. Reporting periods vary slightly and not all retailers have the same fiscal year.
Here are the domestic sales reports for November and for the 10 months from Feb. 1 to Dec. 1, 1990, released yesterday by some of the nation's largest retailers. Figures, except for those of Dayton Hudson, are adjusted so that this year's selling period contains the same number of weeks as last year's.
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.: Down 5.4 percent for four weeks ended Dec. 1, to $272.7 million; down one-tenth of 1 percent for first 10 months, to $2.2 billion.
Dayton Hudson Corp.: Up 37.4 percent for four weeks ended Dec. 1, to $1.55 billion; up 16.5 percent for first 10 months, to $11.25 billion. (If results were adjusted, sales would have risen 15.1 percent in November.)
J. C. Penney Co.: Down 3.1 percent for four weeks ended Dec. 1, to $1.51 billion; up nine- tenths of 1 percent for first 10 months, to $11.98 billion.
K Mart Corp.: Up 5.1 percent for four weeks ended Nov. 28, to $2.87 billion; up 11 percent for first 10 months, to $25.2 billion.
Limited Inc.: Up 24 percent for four weeks ended Dec. 1, to $508.5 million; up 15.6 percent for first 10 months, to $4.02 billion. (1989 includes results of the Lerner Woman division, which has been sold.)
May Department Stores Co.: Down two- tenths of 1 percent for four weeks ended Dec. 1, to $964.5 million; up 6.3 percent for first 10 months, to $7.72 billion.
Melville Corp.: Up 17.1 percent for four weeks ended Dec. 1, to $886.3 million; up 13.2 percent for first 11 months, to $7.34 billion.
Sears, Roebuck & Co.: Down 1.6 percent for four weeks ended Dec. 1, to $3.1 billion (comparing continuing lines only); up 2.1 percent for first 10 months, to $27.48 billion.
TJX Cos.: Up 10.4 percent for four weeks ended Dec. 1, to $247.5 million; up 12.8 percent for first 10 months, to $2 billion.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc.: Up 22 percent for November, to $3.22 billion; up 25 percent for first 10 months, to $25.46 billion.
Woolworth Corp.: Up 4.9 percent for four weeks ended Dec. 1, to $476 million; up 7.4 percent for first 10 months, to $4.33 billion.

HEADLINE: After Brief Hope, New Trade Snag

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Another crisis erupted in the 107-nation trade talks late tonight, dashing hope that had been raised earlier in the day when both the United States and the European Community made concessions that allowed the deadlocked negotiations to continue. The talks are aimed at lowering barriers on the nearly $4 trillion of annual world trade.
The latest crisis resulted from a continuing failure to resolve farm trade issues. The new trouble revived earlier fears of a conference collapse that could bring trade wars and a general worldwide economic decline.
"It's back to ground zero," said John C. Crosbie, Canada's Trade Minister.
 
'Brutally Torpedoed'
 Australia's Minister for Trade Negotiations, Neal Blewett, said he had "never before been in a meeting in which there was a promise of getting a breakthrough and it was so brutally torpedoed." 
 Charges and countercharges have dominated the four days of this conference that aims both to free trade and write rules to govern trade relations into the 21st century.
What caused tonight's breakdown of the agricultural talks was the community's unwillingness -- at the insistence of France -- to negotiate on the basis of a working paper prepared by the community's agricultural negotiating group.
The paper proposed that the community nations make 30 percent cuts in their direct subsidy payments to farmers, their subsidies to promote farm exports and their border protection over five years beginning Jan. 1, 1991. The community had orignally proposed 30 percent cuts in the direct subsidies going back to 1986 and continuing to 1996.
The United States has offered to cut its protection and direct subsidies by 75 percent over the 10 years beginning in January and wants subsidies on exports slashed by 90 percent.
Japan and South Korea, which want to protect their farmers, joined France, the community's principal farm exporter, in vigorously objecting to the compromise formulations, and the meeting broke up in discord.
It was unclear how the crisis would be resolved. Senior ministers are to meet on the agriculture issue Friday morning. One possibility -- suggested by the chief American trade negotiator, Carla A. Hills -- would be to suspend the conference for three to four weeks to give time for political leaders of the United States, Europe and other regions to try to revive the momentum for a trade agreement.
Mrs. Hills called for such a cooling-off period to give the Europeans time to rethink their policies on trade protection for farm products.
 Britain's new Prime Minister, John Major, offered today in London to mediate the agricultural dispute.
Julius L. Katz, the deputy United States trade representative, told reporters that "unless there is a miracle overnight, which doesn't seem likely," the talks would be suspended.
But the European position could be modified Friday at a meeting of the community's Council of Ministers, its highest decision-making authority. The European side in the talks is being led by Frans Andriessen of the Netherlands and Ray MacSharry of Ireland, both Executive Commissioners of the community.
Wednesday night the talks also seemed on the verge of breakdown. The mood shifted after a council meeting today that the Europeans said allowed for greater negotiating flexibility. That was viewed as the community's first expression of willingness to negotiate limitations on farm export subsidies.
The United States showed a more conciliatory approach on the market access it would offer countries willing to cut barriers in tourism, financial services, accounting and other services.
The community is a relatively new food exporter, and the longtime food exporters here have been sharply critical of Europe's subsidies. European producers get billions of dollars of subsidies for dairy, wheat, beef and other products, enabling them to sell below cost in world markets.
The practice affects the trade of many nations, including the United States, Australia, New Zealand, Canada and many countries in Latin America and the Pacific Basin.
"If this conference fails," said Owen Jennings, president of the Federated Farms of New Zealand, "my message to New Zealand farmers is: 'Batten down the hatches. There are going to be trade wars, and we're going to get trampled.' "
Commenting on the community's earlier show of flexibility, Mats Hellstrom, Sweden's farm minister and the chairman of a negotiating group on agriculture, said this was "the first real negotiation in agriculture" in the four years of the current trade liberalization effort, known as the Uruguay Round because it started in that nation.
The Europeans' refusal to ease protection for their 10 million farmers, 30,000 of whom demonstrated here Monday, has created most of the problems for the conference. But in the end the community may be less intransigent than it now seems to non-Europeans.
Ministers from its 12 member nations meet frequently to reconcile conflicts. Indeed, the community's usual negotiating pattern is crisis followed by small concessions to keep people at the bargaining table until there is a resolution.
 
Source of Frustration
 When other countries negotiate with the community, they often become frustrated by such tactics, which create tensions and sometimes ill-will, both of which have been volubly expressed at this conference.
For example, a high-level negotiating session that started at midnight Wednesday was cut off after about 90 minutes by the chairman, Hector Gros Espiell, Uruguay's Foreign Minister, after some sharp exchanges between the American and European sides.
The community's position has been that it would not move in agriculture until the United States backed off the position on trade in services that it adopted shortly before the conference began. Washington said it would refuse to allow nondiscriminatory access to the United States market to be the starting point for an agreement on services.
The American proposal, strongly backed by the private sector, stunned most other countries. Nondiscriminatory access, otherwise known as "most favored nation" treatment, is one of the hallowed principles of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 43-year-old international trade charter. The Uruguay Round is being held under the aegis of GATT.
American officials contend that the United States has the most open services market in the world and that by granting most favored nation status as a general principle it would be giving access to foreigners without getting any concessions in return.
But the United States modified that position today, after a strong attack from the Europeans and other negotiators.
"We will work on the basis of unrestricted M.F.N., on condition that all countries make commitments, and we adopt formulas to secure those commitments," a senior American trade official said.
The Uruguay Round seeks to bring agriculture under the GATT trade rules for the first time. The sector was originally excluded at the insistance of the United States.
Although the conference may break up without the political agreements that had been sought, it is likely that officials will search for a way to preserve some of the considerable gains in the other sectors and try later at resolving the farm trade imbroglio.
Many of the American executives and trade group representatives who have accompanied the delegation from Washington said these gains are of real substance for the United States.
For example, many developing countries, eager to attract investment from industrialized countries, made commitments to accept new rules on services and intellectual property.
Brazil, for one, has accepted the principle of equivalent competitive opportunities in financial services that could mean new foreign licenses for insurance companies.
"The key is to cement the gains that have been made here and create a more constructive climate to finish the job," said a former United States trade representative, William Brock, who is here representing a coalition of companies supporting the liberalization effort.

HEADLINE: Transit Cuts Called First Of Many Painful Moves

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
New York City transit officials said yesterday that service cuts proposed on Wednesday are part of a new budget-driven strategy of tailoring service more closely to the fluctuations in ridership.
For decades, the Transit Authority has provided subway and bus service to all New Yorkers, at all hours of the day and night, including weekends, without regard to their destinations or the number of riders on any one line. 
 But now the Transit Authority must operate more like a private business, the officials said, cutting service where riders are scarce. That is because the agency faces record revenue shortages of $272 million for 1991 and about $500 million for 1992.
 
Half-Mile Walks
 "In the past, we have operated under the philosophy that all subway stations on all lines would be served all the time," said Millard Seay, the authority's senior director of scheduling for bus and rail service. "But given the bad economic times and the drop in ridership, we are changing the way we do business."
The cuts proposed Wednesday would save $38 million a year by elminating or shortening bus and subway routes and cutting token-booth service after midnight. Fares would be collected on some trains and a few riders would have to leave trains at elevated stations and wait at the curb for buses to finish the route.
Transit officials said yesterday that the majority of the proposed cuts, which must go through a public hearing process, are expected to go into effect starting in July.
Officials said the cuts would inconvenience riders to an extent unseen since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. And they acknowledged that, barring unforseen increases in state or Federal subsidies, more service reductions would be necessary.
Under the agency's new strategy, New Yorkers who now use subway and bus lines that have low ridership, particularly in the early-morning hours, could see service on those lines cut drastically or eliminated altogether, transit officials said. In some corners of the city at some hours, people will have to walk as much as a half-mile to find a subway station or a bus stop, Mr. Seay said.
Consumer advocates criticized the agency's new approach, predicting it would alienate customers and reduce ridership at a time when new riders are needed to persuade state legislators to approve a much-needed $12 billion rebuilding plan.
While the agency has not decided where all the service cuts will be made, certain subway and bus lines are particularly vulnerable. Service on the F line, for example, has been scheduled for elimination from midnight to 5 A.M. between Church Avenue and Coney Island in Brooklyn. But parts of other lines have even lower ridership. The Belle Harbor end of the C line in the Rockaways carries only an average of 200 riders from 11 P.M. to 6 A.M. And the No. 3 line along Lenox Avenue in Harlem carries 325 riders in the same period from 145th Street to 148th Street.
 
'Government by Press Release'
 The Transit Authority's new strategy comes as the regional economy is slumping and transit officials are considering raising the $1.15 subway and bus fare for the second time in less than a year and are seeking legislative approval for new operating subsidies and the rebuilding plan.
Some state legislators said yesterday that transit officials are using the proposed service cuts to help make the case for larger subsidies, a fare increase and a new capital budget. The legislators said, though, that if the proposed cuts are put into effect, the transit agency will face an uphill battle in obtaining any increase in financing.
"It's government by press release," said Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan, a Democrat of Queens. "It makes me think that this is all a posture to shake the Legislature down for more subsidies. But the authority should realize that this is the kind of thing that doesn't generate a lot of support for them statewide."
Half of the Transit Authority's $2.5 billion-a-year operating budget comes from fare revenues and the other half from government subsidies. About 6 percent of its subsidies come from the Federal Government, 13.9 percent from the state, 13.9 percent from the city, 55.6 percent from taxes on real estate, telephone service and corporate profits, and 10.5 percent from the operating surplus of certain bridges and tunnels.
Gene Russianoff, a lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a consumer group representing New York subway riders, said, "The enactment of this strategy would be the most radical change in subway service since World War II."
Mr. Russianoff predicted that there would be strong opposition from the public and politicians to the Transit Authority's plans to eliminate some subway service altogether. "It's one thing to reduce the frequency of trains to every eight minutes from every six minutes," he said. "But it's quite another to make people get off a train and wait 40 minutes in the cold for a bus."

HEADLINE: American General Halts Auction of Unit

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The American General Corporation said today that it had rejected two offers for its insurance subsidiary, which specializes in marketing policies door to door, and that it would halt its attempt to auction the unit.
The company, the nation's fourth-largest publicly owned insurer, with $34 billion in assets, said it would resume a stock buyback program begun three years ago. It also reduced the annual dividend to $2; it had been increased to $3 a share from $1.58 a share last May. 
 With more than one million shares traded, American General stock fell by $1.50 today, to $28.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
American General's full retreat from the decision last May 2 to auction the entire company underscores the troubles investment bankers are facing in their attempts to raise money to finance large takeovers.
When American General's directors voted to auction the company, Harold S. Hook, chairman and chief executive, forecast offers of more than $7 billion, or $59 a share. The Houston-based company had turned down a stock-and cash offer from the Torchmark Corporation valued at $50 a share.
Torchmark, a smaller insurer based in Birmingham, Ala., said today that it had offered $3.65 billion for American General's home-service unit, which markets life and health insurance policies primarily among middle- and low-income customers in the Southeast.
The deal included $1.05 billion in Torchmark shares and $800 million in cash, and Torchmark would have taken on $1.8 billion of debt in the American General unit. In a brief statement, Torchmark said it was disappointed, but still regarded American General's home service unit a good match for it.
Torchmark's shares rose by $1.375 today, to $48.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Other companies rumored to have made competing bids for the American General unit were the Capital Holding Corporation, based in Louisville, Ky. and Nationale-Nederlanden, a large Dutch insurer, analysts said.
American General narrowed the auction to its home service unit in late summer, as the weakening economy and weakening stock markets in Europe, Japan and the United States made it unlikely that a bidder could meet American General's price.

HEADLINE: '91 BUDGET DEFICIT WILL SET A RECORD, CONGRESS IS TOLD

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Driven by the weakening economy and the savings and loan bailout, the Federal budget deficit will set a record this year and be even higher the next, despite the budget agreement reached in October, the Congressional Budget Office said today.
Among members of Congress, the mood ranged from sober to grim as Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, reported that the deficit, $220 billion in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, would increase to at least $253 billion in the current fiscal year, 1991, and $262 billion in 1992. 
 Those estimates assume that Congress takes further action to keep military and domestic spending within the limits set in October.
 
Persian Gulf Costs Excluded
 The estimates presented today at a hearing of the House Budget Committee do not incorporate the costs of United States military operations in the Persian Gulf, which some economists say could increase spending by as much as $1 billion a month.
Moreover, these estimates of the deficit include Social Security. If the surplus in the Social Security trust fund is excluded from the calculations, as many people say it should be, the budget deficit would exceed $300 billion this year and next, the budget office said. In theory, money in the trust fund can be used only to pay Social Security benefits and related administrative costs. But the surplus is invested in Treasury securities, which help finance all operations of the Government.
Without the savings achieved in the budget agreement six weeks ago, the deficit would be $35 billion higher in the current fiscal year, Mr. Reischauer said.
 
Difficult Choices Ahead
 The combination of a weak economy and the need for "massive spending to resolve insolvent savings and loan institutions" will push the deficit to record levels, Mr. Reischauer said.
The new numbers strongly suggest that the political and fiscal choices facing Congress and President Bush will be just as difficult in 1991 as they were in the struggle to reach the budget deal this year. The largest deficit to date was $221 billion, in 1986.
The giant budget measure passed in October was widely described as a "deficit-reduction bill." Sponsors were successful in selling it partly because of their determined effort to focus attention on its savings, rather than on the bottom line.
 
Playing Down the Deficit
 Congressional leaders and Administration officials who negotiated the deal talked of the savings in terms of what the deficit would have been in the absence of an agreement. They did not emphasize that the amount of the deficit, in absolute terms, would increase, although that fact could have been inferred from a close reading of the deficit targets set by the legislation.
Realizing that earlier deficit-reduction goals in the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law would be impossible to meet, the negotiators proposed goals for savings. They originally sought $50 billion in savings in 1991 and said later they would accept $40 billion, a figure now reduced to $35 billion. Estimates of the deficit varied in that period.
Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, chairman of the Budget Committee, said at the hearing: "We have completed a major landmark agreement, the largest deficit-reduction package in the history of the budget process. It was by no means the solution to the problem, but at least it was the beginning of an effort to try to find an answer and to get some control, some discipline over the deficit."
 
'The Deficit Is Growing'
 Now, he said, with the nation apparently at the beginning of a mild recession, people ask, "Was the agreement too little too late?" Despite the agony of this year's budget negotiations between Congress and the White House, "the fact is that the deficit is growing," Mr. Panetta said.
Representative Jerry Huckaby, Democrat of Louisiana, sounded frustrated as he said, "Even with so much political capital put into the budget agreement, the deficits are increasing rather than decreasing."
No one at today's hearing suggested that the savings envisioned in the budget deal were a sham. Indeed, Mr. Reischauer said they were genuine and would total $496 billion over five years. The savings result from tax increases and from Congressional action to reduce military spending and slow the growth of domestic spending compared with what they otherwise would have been.
Mr. Panetta said that the Pentagon and the State Department were asked and refused to provide testimony at today's hearing about the costs of United States military operations in the Persian Gulf. Mr. Reischauer said Defense Department officials were "having a difficult time" calculating the costs. "We have tried to extract the information from them," he testified. "We have not received what we wanted."
Mr. Reischauer said the spending limits in the new budget law "do not allow appropriations to grow as fast as inflation." If the Government continued services and operations at current levels, he said, military spending would exceed its limit by $9.4 billion in the fiscal year 1992 and domestic spending would run $4.3 billion over the limit. The domestic category includes many popular health and education programs, public works and scientific research.
 
Officials Project Trims
 To comply with the limits, Mr. Reischauer said, Congress would need to trim projected Federal spending by $14 billion in 1992 and by $23 billion in 1993.
The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the cost of Federal deposit insurance, for savings and loan associations, banks and credit unions, would rise to $91 billion in 1991 and $107 billion in 1992 from $58 billion in the last fiscal year. "Most of this spending is required to close or subsidize the sale of hundreds of insolvent thrift institutions," Mr. Reischauer said.
In 1994 and 1995, he said, the sale of real estate and other savings and loan assets should bring the Government more than the Treasury would spend on insolvent institutions in those years. But Mr. Reischauer said those estimates were not firm. Asked how confident he was about those estimates, he said, "I can assure you they won't change for a month."
The economy was deteriorating even as Congress passed the budget bill in October. Estimates of savings at that time were based on economic assumptions made by the Congressional Budget Office in June. The new estimates are based on assumptions adopted by the budget office in October.
The changes, reflecting sharp increases in oil prices after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, "increase the projected deficit by $41 billion in 1991 and by about $60 billion per year thereafter," Mr. Reischauer said.
A partisan dispute broke into the open at the start of today's hearing. Republicans and Democrats clashed over who should be designated as the official scorekeeper in computing the cost of new legislation: the Congressional Budget Office or the President's Office of Management and Budget. Such calculations may sometimes lead to automatic cuts in Federal benefit programs.
Republicans charged that the Democrats were reneging on an agreement reached in October to expand the role of the Office of Management and Budget. However, Democrats said the Congressional Budget Office had been more reliable and less partisan over the years.
The hearing today was an educational session to lay the groundwork for the next Congress, which convenes in January.

HEADLINE: Japan Import: School Blends Two Cultures

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PURCHASE, N.Y.

 BODY:
Junko Yamamoto's social studies class at Keio High School looks and sounds as if it had been packed in a massive crate and shipped from home: all of her students are of Japanese descent, they study a Japanese textbook, and Ms. Yamamoto lectures in rapid Japanese
But in the cafeteria after class, the same students eat clam chowder and ham on rye and watch MTV on a big television set. Of course, on each table there is a bottle of soy sauce next to the salt and pepper. 
 These conflicting scenes are integral to the daily routine at Keio (pronounced KAY-oh), an experimental private high school where a prominent Japanese university is trying to educate the children of Japanese executives living abroad in a way that will serve them as well in Cambridge, Mass., as it would in Tokyo.
School officials hope to combine the basic elements of two very different high schools -- one Japanese, the other American -- under the same roof in this Westchester County village. But the mix is delicate.
Though all of the school's 120 students are of Japanese descent, they hail from 10 countries and at least 25 percent need tutoring in Japanese. Most of the 16 teachers are from Japan and lecture only in Japanese.
 
Hampered on Examinations
 Some students fear they are being pushed too hard in two very different directions, and worry about preserving their identities. The high school is the first international venture by Tokyo's Keio University, which also runs schools in Japan.
Most of the students are here because they hope to return to Japan for university study but fear that their years away might hamper them on the rigorous entrance examinations to Japanese universities. Keio High School eases those fears by guaranteeing admission to Keio University -- without the examinations -- as long as they keep their grades up.
They will have another edge many of their fellow students will not. "By the time they graduate, I hope all of them are reasonably bilingual and correspondingly bicultural," said Dr. Yasumitsu Nihei, the school's 57-year-old headmaster.
But some of his students worry that, by being both, they will be neither.
Over lunch with friends a week ago, Yumi Terahata, a 14-year-old whose arents live in Seattle, said the workload is frustrating.
"We're going to be half and half, and that's too much of a balance," she said. "I want to be in broadcasting in America. If my English goes down, I won't be able to compete."
Keio University spent $40 million over the last year building the school on 27 acres bought from neighboring Manhattanville College. In September, it opened its doors to 120 10th graders, each paying $12,000 tuition. Eighty-five pay an additional $5,000 to board.
Most of their fathers are businessmen working overseas for up to five years. Sixty percent of the students live in the New York aread.
 
'No Spoonies and Milksops'
 In one classroom a week ago, about 20 students were watching a tape of a Japanese news program describing the nation's failure to cope with overpopulation and provide decent pensions. In another, they were reading: "Here in this young, vigorous country we want no spoonies and milksops . . . ." -- Walt Whitman's reluctant paean to boxing when he was writing editorials.
As Ms. Yamamoto, book in hand, lectured her social studies class on the mechanics of commodities pricing, her students repeatedly nodded their understanding but remained generally quiet. They were not rigid, though: two girls ventured a brief moment of gossip, one boy twirled a pen aimlessly.
They were even more respectful -- and, to judge by the nods, just as comprehending -- in the algebra class of Richard Marx, one of the three American teachers, who scribbled furiously on the blackboard, unlocking the mysteries of rational equations.
All told, the students must sit through a dizzying array of classes: mathematics, science, social studies, music, art and home economics, high-level Japanese and English and a comparative culture course.
To get into Keio, according to the guidebook, they will be judged on their "hope and aptitude," grades, extracurricular activities, community service, American SAT tests, attendance, "reward and punishment," and recommendations.
"The students are complaining that they are suffering from a heavy load of studying," Dr. Nihei said sympathetically. "Maybe some of the teachers are asking too much."

HEADLINE: In Florida, a Private Company Will Operate a Public School

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, DEC. 6

 BODY:
The half-finished construction project a few blocks from the Art Deco hotels and restaurants at the south end of Miami Beach gives little hint of the educational gamble that will occur there next year.
But when 550 students enter the gates of the South Pointe Elementary School in September they will become subjects of a bold experiment in which the local school board will virtually turn over control of the school to a private, for-profit company. 
 For five years, beginning next fall, the company, Education Alternatives Inc., will help select and train the teachers, design the curriculum and provide educational materials. Teachers will use the same expensive techniques and equipment used at two private academies the company operates in affluent suburbs of Minneapolis and Phoenix -- where the annual tuition runs from $5,000 to $6,000.
The idea of hiring a private company to help run South Pointe began percolating two years ago, when some Dade County schools were filled to twice their capacity and the dropout rate was nearly 30 percent. Heeding the pleas of Superintendent Joseph A. Fernandez, county voters approved a $980 million bond referendum to build 49 schools and renovate 250 existing ones. Mr. Fernandez, who became School Chancellor for New York City this year, then advertised in national newspapers and education magazines for ideas on how the new schools should be run.
 
A School for the Future
 "Rather than having schools designed and operated in same way schools have in the past, we invited proposals from anyone in country who is interested in education on how they would design, plan and operate a 21st century school," said Dr. Frank Petruzielo, an associate superintendent who heads the school system's Bureau of Professionalization. The invitation drew dozens of responses, among them Educational Alternatives.
The school will get about the same financing from Dade County as any other new elementary school, around $1.1 million for salaries and $500,000 for materials and supplies. Extra costs will be borne by the company.
Officials with the Dade County Public Schools say they hope the experiment will not only boost the performance of children at South Pointe but also produce a prototype that could be used in other schools. And if that model is expensive, school officials say, that could provide a lesson to the public in what a good education costs.
"We might be able to come forth with a specific model that will require people to make choices," said Dr. Petruzielo. "We might be able to say, 'This works. You want it? Pay for it.' "
 
Hoping to Breed Success
 Education experts say they believe this is the first time a public school district has hired a private, for-profit company to run a school and the first time a private-school company has tried to duplicate its methods at a public school. Even if the experiment succeeds, it is unclear whether the method would work in other school districts, since it can only be tried in a system that gives much autonomy to individual schools and works with flexible unions.
The performance of Education Alternatives is to be reviewed each year, and the district can choose not to renew the contract if it is dissatisfied.
The methods of the company's private schools, called Tesseract Schools, include extensive use of computers, telephones in every classroom and a ratio of 12 students to every teacher. To replicate them, Education Alternatives has pledged to raise $2.2 million over a five-year period to supplement South Pointe's budget, which has not yet been determined by the school district. The money will be contributed by private foundations and corporations, and part of it will be used to pay the company's annual fee, from $200,000 to $275,000 a year.
"We have gotten several verbal commitments and expect to have hard dollars in before the year is out," said John T. Golle, chairman and chief executive officer of the company. "But we are looking for more."
He added that he does not expect to turn a profit from the Miami venture. He said he wants to use South Pointe as a marketing tool to demonstrate that his company can produce quantifiable improvement in academic performance regardless of the students' educational or economic background.
 
Using Graduate Students
 "I'm not ashamed to admit that if our system works, the world is going to beat a path to our door," he said by telephone from the company's headquarters in Minneapolis.
To achieve the desired student-teacher ratio while keeping costs down, the school will employ first-year graduate students from the University of Miami as part-time teachers. The aides will be paid $7 an hour and will get credits towards a master's degree in education. This use of graduate students required a waiver of a provision in the contract between the school board and the teachers union. Other exemptions from the labor agreement are anticipated before the school opens.
"The union's commitment and the school board's are identical: quality education and improved education," said Yvonne Burkholz, director of labor for The United Teachers of Dade, explaining why the union agreed to change aspects of its contract. "We thrive when the public perceives that we are willing to take risks."
Officials at Education Alternatives caution that their methods are not a panacea for all public schools.
 
Some Districts Too Daunting
 "We're not looking to do an impossible task," Mr. Golle said. "There are some districts in the country we won't go in, because the challenges are too great."
The task facing Mr. Golle is daunting. South Pointe will draw its students from two overcrowded elementary schools; new zoning lines will be drawn so that its students will come from a geographic area, and not from families applying to send children there. More than 85 percent of the students at one school and 79 percent of those at the other are eligible under Federal law for free or reduced-cost lunches. Reading scores at both schools are well below the national average. More than 80 percent of the children are Hispanic, many of them recent immigrants from Central America who speak little or no English.
Moreover, the neighborhood is known as a temporary way station that many families leave when they can afford higher rents. "That's what scares me the most," said Linda Lentin, who will be South Pointe's lead teacher, supervising other teachers in lieu of an assistant principal. "We have a transient population there. I hope we will have enough time to make a difference in their lives and prove what Tesseract can do."
Tesseract is named after an imaginary corridor through which the main characters travel in the children's book, "A Wrinkle in Time," by Madeline L'Engle. The concept was developed by a subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation, which designed an education model that could be used in a chain of private, for-profit elementary schools. Mr. Golle formed Education Alternatives and bought the subsidiary for $10 million in 1986.
 
A Plan for Each Student
 Dade County school officials also hope South Pointe will attract children of the growing number of middle class residents who have moved to the southern end of Miami Beach in the last few years, but who have placed their children in private schools.
"This excites me, because I think private schools get better attention than do public schools -- more money, newer equipment, computers," said Jana DiConstanzo, the office manager of a restaurant, who plans to send her son, Francis, 5, to South Pointe next year. Francis currently attends a parochial school in downtown Miami.
South Pointe will be divided into four mini-schools of 125 to 150 students, and the pupils and teachers will remain together from kindergarten through sixth grade. Mr. Golle said this encourages a sense of community and belonging among pupils, which he feels is necessary for children to be successful in school.
Instruction is to be tailored for each student. Each year teachers, in consultation with parents, will draw up a "personal education plan" setting goals for individual students. Students will work at their own pace and will be encouraged to help each other. There will be no grades, although the students will take the same standardized tests other Dade County pupils take.
Teachers will not lecture in front of a classroom; they will move about, helping students as they work individually or in small groups. Computers will be used not only as learning aids but also to allow teachers to track a student's progress.
 
Calling Parents From Class
 Periodically, an audio tape in the student's native language will be sent home so parents can keep up with their child's progress. To reinforce a feeling of accomplishment and to involve parents, students will be encouraged to telephone their parents from the classroom after successfully completing a task, to share the experience with them.
"We try to avoid the situation where a parent asks his kid what did you do in school today, and the answer is, nothing, or I forgot," Mr. Golle said.
Those who have been pressing for reform of the nation's school system will be watching the South Pointe experiment closely.
"I think it's a terrific innovation, well worth trying, and I'm glad they're doing it," said Chester E. Finn Jr., professor of education and public policy at Vanderbilt University. "Will it work? Who knows."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John T. Golle, chairman and chief executive officer of Education Alternatives, in a class at the Tesseract Academy in Eagan, Minn. For the first time the private company has been hired to operate a publicschool in Dade County, Fla., the new South Pointe Elementary School. With him were Patricia Parham, left, and Linda Lentin, teachers at South Pointe, who were observing the program. (Steve Woit for The New York Times)
