HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Deal Reported on Settlement Payments in Collusion Case

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROSEMONT, Ill., Dec. 6

 BODY:
Major league club owners will pay the players' union $120 million Jan. 2, then complete their $280 million collusion settlement payment in four installments of $40 million each over the next 15 months.
Under terms of the settlement, details of which were disclosed today by a lawyer familiar with the negotiations, the $40 million payments, plus accrued interest, will be made next July 15, Sept. 15, Nov. 15, and April 15, 1992. The owners will invest the money in Federal Government-backed securities until the payments are made. 
 The payment schedule is a chief feature of the terms of the settlement. Another is the granting of free-look free agency for 15 players from the 1987 group of free agents. Those players could be free as early as Friday to seek contracts with other teams.
Some details remain to be worked out before the settlement is completed, but the owners, at their meeting here Wednesday, and the players' executive board, at its meeting in Orlando, Fla., today, adopted similar resolutions authorizing their negotiators to agree on a settlement that included terms stipulated in the resolutions.
 
Competition May Be Spirited
 The resolutions noted that "both parties will make their best effort to get a comprehensive settlement by Dec. 13."
Some of the new free agents could command immediate and heavy attention. The Atlanta Braves, for example, can hardly wait until they can legally approach Brett Butler, then make him a large offer to become their center fielder. Butler, who began his career with the Braves, lives in the Atlanta area and is a favorite of Ted Turner, the Braves' owner.
But the Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Diego Padres are also interested in the leadoff hitter, and the competition could become spirited and expensive.
Butler is certain to command the kind of contract (four years, $13 million) that the San Francisco Giants gave Willie McGee, leaving Butler with no alternative but to leave them. Butler, as an initial approach, asked the Giants for $15 million, but that was because Will Clark and Kevin Mitchell had $15 million contracts.
 
Attention Likely for Clark
 Jack Clark, who has been bumped from first base in San Diego by Fred McGriff, is another impending free agent who will attract instant attention. The suddenly active Toronto Blue Jays and the Boston Red Sox are prepared to compete, among others, for his services as a power-hitting designated hitter. Several teams need a third baseman, which should make Gary Gaetti a popular free agent.
While the 15 players seek to improve the economic status that an arbitrator said was damaged by the owners' collusive practices, the Players Association will attend to more general matters.
The union, according to the terms, will have the "sole and exclusive responsibility" of developing a plan for the allocation and distribution of players' individual claims on loss of salary. The union must recommend the plan to the two arbitrators who decided the collusion cases, and the arbitrators have to approve it.
When other arbitrators hear salary arbitration cases in the first three weeks in February, they will be given statements regarding the amounts by which aggregate player salaries were reduced in five seasons, 1986 through 1990, because of club violations.
 
May Affect Arbitration
 The arbitrators will also receive a statement regarding the amount by which average salaries in service groups were reduced in 1989 and 1990 because of the collusion.
Armed with those figures, the arbitrators may award higher salaries than they might have the past several years. Players would certainly be expected to seek higher salaries, arguing that their previous salaries had been depressed under the weight of collusion.
The settlement also addresses major league service time. Thirteen free agents who missed the early parts of seasons because they had not signed with anyone will be given credit for full seasons of service.
The union can also ask the arbitrators to award additional service for other players who missed time, but the Player Relations Committee can take the opposite position, leaving it for the arbitrators to decide.

HEADLINE: How to Choke Iraq

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein certainly seems to be budging. Last week, in a trivial gesture, he sent a few cases of food to the embattled American Embassy in Kuwait. Now he offers a noteworthy gesture: release of all the foreign hostages Iraq has held since the Persian Gulf crisis began in August.
These steps, immediately following a forceful United Nations Security Council resolution, suggest that he has come to appreciate just how unified the world is in its outrage at his aggression. Now the coalition arrayed against him can turn its full attention to larger purposes -- getting Iraq out of Kuwait and assuring stability for the nations around the Persian Gulf. 
 It is conceivable that President Bush's recent bellicosity has speeded things along, but that's speculative. What has all along seemed certain is that the best way to squeeze Iraq is by economic pressure and diplomacy.
In Senate testimony, William Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, has given new support for that posture. He said what the Administration must have known all along but has refused to concede: that the economic embargo is quietly but surely strangling Iraq's economy and will soon start sapping its military strength.
The embargo has shut off more than 90 percent of President Hussein's imports and 97 percent of his petroleum export revenues. He has been forced to forfeit $1.5 billion in foreign exchange earnings every month for four months now. And his hard currency reserves, essential to pay for smuggling, are running out.
Denied critical inputs like fuel additives, Iraq's economy is slowing down -- and much sooner than anticipated. Well-informed experts like James Schlesinger estimate civilian production declined some 40 percent in three months. Soon the embargo will hurt where it counts, in military capacity. Already the army and air force have curtailed training and reconnaissance to reduce wear and tear on equipment and conserve on fuel.
The longer the embargo lasts, the less able Iraq will be to defend its army in Kuwait. That's an important counterpoint to those who say that time is on Iraq's side, and that the allies must strike soon.
The Administration worries about the coalition's willingness to sustain the embargo over the long haul. But that strain cannot compare to the strains war would impose.
It's also true that some holes may open in the embargo. But they won't be large enough to satisfy Iraq's growing needs. Indeed, the siege can be tightened. Air traffic through Jordan can be curtailed. Shipping can be subject to more intrusive inspection. Smuggling via Jordan, Iran and Turkey can be interdicted more effectively.
Granted, economic embargo can't guarantee Saddam Hussein's departure from Kuwait. But neither can a limited war, certainly not the friction-free air strike dear to so many armchair strategists.
War is as likely to erode as restore security and stability in the region. Indeed, in the long run only economic and diplomatic means can check Mr. Hussein's expansionist ambitions and keep him from getting his hands on critical materials for manufacturing chemical and nuclear weapons.
President Bush quickly, wisely and boldly put a firm chokehold on Iraq. It remains a shrewder policy than impatiently grabbing for his gun.

HEADLINE: Agreement, at Last, on Police

 BODY:
This autumn's financial crisis followed last summer's crime crisis, forcing New York City officials to decide just how much more they are prepared to pay to improve public confidence and public safety.
The criminal justice program emerging from negotiations between the Mayor and City Council gives an answer: $450 million a year. Some aspects of timing and financing remain dubious, but on the whole, the plan deserves support. 
 Mayor Dinkins came down from a $650 million proposal while the City Council Speaker, Peter Vallone, came up from $300 million. The compromise calls for 5,797 new police officers on patrol duty -- 743 fewer than in the original Dinkins plan. There is also money for courts, jails and schools.
An increase in the property tax would pay for $150 million of the program. Extension of an income tax surcharge set to expire in 1992 would eventually add $184 million more. The balance would come from a new city lottery.
Because the Council balked at even higher property taxes before the 1992 election, only a third of the new police would be hired before 1993. And another regressive lottery is hardly an attractive financing source.
But the plan at least establishes a firm schedule for bringing the police force up to adequate strength. The lottery and the income tax surcharge extension require Albany's approval, and city officials are lobbying hard for it during the current special session.
New Yorkers need to know that fiscal austerity hasn't paralyzed government. Swift approval of the Dinkins-Vallone compromise would provide that reassurance.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
'A Broken Dream'

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Yuval Neria looks like a romantic vision of an Israeli poet: dark eyes, curly black-and-gray hair. In fact he is a war hero. As a 21-year-old lieutenant in the 1973 Middle East war, he twice jumped to another tank when his was destroyed. He won Israel's highest decoration, the Medal of Valor. "I was quite meshuginah," he says -- crazy.
Now he is a clinical psychologist and the author of a best seller on the 1973 war, "Fire," something between autobiography and fiction. He also helped to found the organization Peace Now, and he is in the United States at the moment conveying its message. 
 But what is Peace Now's message at such a time? The organization has favored Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories and negotiations with the Palestinians. But the Persian Gulf crisis and Palestinian support for Saddam Hussein have made the prospects for Israeli-Palestinian peace even more remote than they were.
"Separation," Mr. Neria said when we met the other day. By that he meant physically separating Israel within its 1967 borders, to the extent possible, from the Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza.
"We are flooded with traumatic events," he said: "the murder of three Israelis in Jerusalem a month ago, this week the Palestinians attacking with knives on a bus, the incidents on the borders. The people are so angry. There is no negotiation, no hope -- none for us, none for the Palestinians.
"We need some time to let us regain a little quiet, to reduce the anxiety. It's an immediate necessity. I don't want to enter into a paranoiac state where everyone is suspicious of everyone, and we are very close to it now."
If the 1967 border were actually closed, I asked, how would the Palestinians in the occupied territories survive? They are heavily dependent, especially in Gaza, on work in Israel. Mr. Neria said international economic aid would be necessary, but he confessed that he had no detailed solutions. He only wanted to prevent the situation from getting worse.
The official position of Peace Now is more complex. It still calls for negotiations and a political settlement with the Palestinians. But a statement last month called for "gradual economic separation between Israel and the territories," by promoting economic self-sufficiency in the West Bank and Gaza.
Prime Minister Shamir and his Likud bloc have always favored a Greater Israel including the West Bank and Gaza. But curiously, events seem to be pushing them toward increasing emphasis on the 1967 borders. Events are confirming Peace Now's view that holding onto the occupied territories harms Israel's security.
The events are violent attacks by Palestinians, especially since the police killing of 17 Palestinians in Jerusalem on Oct. 8. In the last two months more than 20 Israelis have been stabbed by Arabs; 5 died of their wounds. Some of the incidents have occurred far from the borders, one in Tel Aviv, and many more Israelis have taken to carrying weapons.
To try to prevent such attacks, the army and the police have sharply restricted Palestinian entry into Israel across what had been an open border. This week a new network of roadblocks was set up along the border, and the police were ordered to check Palestinians closely, including the use of metal detectors.
"Shamir cannot admit the end of Greater Israel," Mr. Neria said. "But those who advise him -- the army and so on -- know it is a myth, a broken dream.
"I'm not in politics, I can't say. But the younger people in the Likud must not be able to deny reality."
Mr. Neria's parents were both professional soldiers: his father a colonel, his mother "a lieutenant colonel like me," Mr. Neria said. (That is his rank in the reserves.) His parents were in the Palmach, the elite unit of the Haganah, the Jewish underground army before the state was born in 1948. They fought in the War of Independence that year, then in the wars of 1956 and 1967.
"They had the dream that after 1948 their world would change," Mr. Neria said. "I remember my mother telling me that the War of Independence would be the last war; after that nothing would happen to the Jewish people.
"I think the only hope for them is that there are still young people who have enough energy to fight for peace. They are very supportive of Peace Now, which is important for me."

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
The Planes of Change

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

DATELINE: TEL AVIV

 BODY:
The plane landed at 4 in the morning. Ten minutes later, the passengers walked eagerly down the ramp to begin a new life in a country that exists perpetually in condition of war, siege or danger.
A small crowd of Israeli youngsters waited to deliver huge hugs, homemade sponge cake, coffee, plastic flags and the national anthem, in that appropriate order. Other planes came in later and for every one the kisses and the cakes were fresh. 
 Every day about 1,000 Soviet Jews land in Israel. In a few years, at least a million immigrants will arrive, one-quarter of Israel's present Jewish population. It is something like trying to fit all the people of France into the United States -- and make them happy, too.
The threat of war in the Persian Gulf, which could bring bombs on Israel, has frightened tourists off -- but not the immigrants from the Soviet Union. More and more of them, instead of fewer and fewer, line up in Moscow for visas, preferring the risks of the Middle East to life in any Soviet Union they can conceive.
They will change the face and future of Israel, change its economy, its politics, the way it thinks and acts. Israelis are sure of this: absorbing these many new citizens will be one of the most difficult jobs Israel has ever faced, and the migration will be the best thing that has happened to this country since independence -- if. If the voters force Israeli leaders to reform their country's political and economic systems.
The people who come off the plane every day are a gold mine of talent, energy and desire. It is a migration proportionally richer in skills than the existing Israeli population. Richer in university graduates, engineers, physicians, scientists and musicians. Right now they will do anything at all -- carpentry, street cleaning, construction work, anything. That startles some Israelis who see "menial" work as not quite fitting for the intelligentsia. But one day not too far away, Israel will have to create enough new enterprises to find enough new jobs to make the newcomers feel fufilled professionally and economically.
For the next year or so, many of the new Israelis are doubling up with relatives or friends who were able to get out of the Soviet Union a few years ago. But the supply of cousins is running out. With every planeload, the pressure for homes increases on a Government already a year behind in building them.
The pressure to absorb Soviet Jews quickly and decently may finally force Israeli politicians to cut apart the net of government ownership and control, an outdated legacy from Israel's early days. It discourages foreign investment, and is a leg iron on Israeli domestic enterprise and initiative.
These immigrants become citizens the moment they land. They will vote. Logically, the newcomers' rich, full detestation of anything that smacks of socialism should bring them to the conservative Likud rather than Labor. But the chances are that like a lot of other Israelis, they will vote in the next national election for the party that will actually do what Israeli politicians keep promising and keep failing to deliver.
That is to reform an election system that makes electing a strong majority government almost impossible. The system hands tiny extremist or splinter parties a blackmail role -- give us ministerial jobs or we swing to the other side. It guarantees confusion, corruption and weakness in any government that manages to put together a patchwork majority.
Without government reform and economic modernization, the absorption will falter. The treasure of talent will lie untapped. The pressure for change is the biggest gift the new Israelis are bringing to this country.
At the airport, strange thoughts crossed my mind. Could it be that these people, these doctors, engineers and architects so full of life's juices that they accept privation and danger for the chance to work, will one day be allowed to make the rest of the Middle East a better place to live?
Enough doctors will be coming to Israel over the next few years to give succor to the sick of the whole Middle East. Will the day ever come when a Jewish doctor from Israel can tend the Muslim sick as immigrant Muslim doctors make the rounds in New York hospitals, caring for Jew or non-Jew without question from physician or patient?
Is it a useless dream to think of this? Or is it a nightmare not to think of it? I take a piece of cake while I examine that thought. Both are delicious.

HEADLINE: Israel Frays Its Tie With America

BYLINE: By Harold H. Saunders; Harold H. Saunders, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs from 1978 to 1981, is a Brookings Institution fellow.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Israelis fear that because of the Persian Gulf crisis America is moving away from Israel and toward the Arabs. But they are wrong. The U.S. commitment to Israel is not that shallow.
The Israelis' concern should form the starting point of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's meeting with President Bush in coming days. Mr. Shamir should appreciate that the real danger to the U.S.-Israeli relationship is political, not strategic. Israel, by its hardline control over all Palestine, has been heightening that danger. 
 Responding to violence, the Israelis have considered greater separation between themselves and Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza. Such permanent action could lead to apartheid, which would shake the foundations of the U.S.-Israeli relationship.
The U.S. remains committed to a Jewish state -- but to one sharing Palestine with its Arab neighbors, not dominating all of it.
Will Israel address the violence by further control, repression, separatism? Or, more sensibly, will it talk with the Palestinians about how they could, in freedom, run their own body politic? The choice is Israel's, although the Palestinians must demonstrate that Israel can make that choice without jeopardizing its security.
Some Israelis say the unprecedented U.S. security collaboration with Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria to counter Iraq's seizure of Kuwait is undermining the strategic foundations of the Israel-U.S. relationship. In addition, Israelis have interpreted U.S. support for sharp U.N. resolutions voted after Israeli police killed at least 17 Palestinians at the Temple Mount in Jerusalem as placating the new strategic partners.
Israel should not forget America's consistent support since Israel's founding in 1948. Nor should both sides misread the human and political foundations of that commitment: No President could sit still while Israel suffered serious harm.
Israel's desire to be described as a U.S. strategic asset against the spread of Communism was an argument of convenience that served Israel. Today, the Soviet-U.S. relationship is changing, and Israel is improving its relations with the Soviet Union.
But the human commitment endures and transcends strategic concerns -- so long as both sides remain committed to the deepest values of our common tradition, among them human rights principles. Israeli acts that erode that compact threaten the relationship.
That compact was forged at the U.N. when the U.S. voted on Nov. 29, 1947, to partition Palestine between a Jewish and an Arab state. Concern for fairness in an unfair situation made the U.S. reject a solution in which one people might annex or suppress the other. Even the Balfour Declaration in 1917 spoke of establishing a national home for the Jewish people, while doing nothing "which may prejudice the civil and religious rights and existing non-Jewish communities in Palestine."
The U.S. has faithfully kept its commitment, from Security Council Resolution 242 in 1967 through the Camp David Accords and Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. That commitment has always been to an Israel sharing the land fairly with its Arab neighbors.
While the U.S. position has remained solid, since 1977 Israel has sought permanent control of all the land west of the Jordan River. All these years, even after 1977, the U.S. has protected Israel from a hostile world at the U.N., and through large-scale aid it has helped Israel defend itself and buttress its economy. The U.S. designed the peace process of the 70's to move one careful step at a time so that Israel could test its neighbors' readiness for new relationships.
Just yesterday, Secretary of State James Baker reiterated opposition to a premature Middle East peace conference by rejecting an effort by a group of neutral nations to persuade the Security Council to approve a resolution calling for such a conference to discuss Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
In promoting its interest in protecting global access to Middle East oil and resisting Iraqi aggression, the U.S. has consulted with Israel even has it has cooperated with key Arab countries. Similarly, for years the U.S. has walked a fine line between its Arab and Israeli interests without damaging Israel, despite Israeli alarms.
In the gulf crisis, the U.S. is hotly debating a delicate balance between political and military pressure on Saddam Hussein. Foreign Minister David Levy has entered that debate, apparently advocating U.S. military action, by warning against "a situation in which all the Western armies will leave the gulf and Saddam Hussein will emerge with certain advantages." If Israel, by so intruding itself in the debate, undercuts the U.S. effort to contain Iraq, it will harm the mutual relationship.
After the gulf crisis subsides, an effort to reconstitute the peace process -- involving honest attempts at reconciliation in a shared land -- will be essential. This should not be linked to a solution to the Kuwait problem. But it will be necessary because it will be right, vital to Israel's survival, critical to sustaining a strong U.S. position in the Middle East (which serves Israel's interests) and essential to the health of the Israeli-U.S. relationship. Until the crisis is over, Israel's treatment of the Palestinians could open - or close - doors to the peace process.

HEADLINE: When It's a Recession

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Greenspan Says Nation's Economy Is in a Downturn," (front page, Nov. 29), on the Congressional testimony of the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, asserts that the "official definition of a recession is a decline in the gross national product for two consecutive quarters." That is just one popular definition of a recession.
As I understand it, the Business Cycle Dating Committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research, whose recognition of a recession is what makes it official, looks not just at the duration of a downturn, but also at its depth and diffusion, and the committee looks at output, income, employment and trade, in making that determination.
Thus, two successive quarters of decline in G.N.P. are neither necessary nor sufficient for a recession to occur.
 
ANIRVAN BANERJI
Economist and Research Associate
Center for International Business
Cycle Research, Columbia U.
New York, Nov. 29, 1990

HEADLINE: Daily News Fights for Present and Future Economic Survival;
Management's Weapon

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Striking Out at Public Order," on The Daily News strike (editorial, Nov. 2), ignores fundamental facts about labor relations in the United States. When Congress passed the Wagner Act, giving workers the right to form unions and protection for concerted action, the country was on the verge of industrial warfare. The act established a peaceful process for workers and employers to solve disputes by negotiation. The process worked with Government support. 
 In 1981, Government support was withdrawn when the Reagan Administration fired striking air traffic controllers and dissolved the workers' voluntary organization. This told management it was acceptable to wage warfare on employees and unions. Employers permanently replaced workers striking over economic issues.
The law says you cannot be fired for striking, but you can be permanently replaced. The effect is the same. Many employers started to see the strike as their weapon, not the unions'. They learned that by forcing workers to strike, they could replace them forever with nonunion employees and eliminate having to negotiate wages, hours and working conditions with employees.
Violence cannot be condoned in a strike, but the sword cuts both ways. Is it not a violent act to deprive a worker of a job forever for exercising the right to strike?
As a union organizer I have worked with employees throughout the country seeking to form unions. Their frustration is real. It is, I am sorry to say, reaching the point where if Congress does not act to reform labor law, and prevent striking workers from being permanently replaced, the violence occurring today in New York will be repeated across the country.
 
LEONARD SMITH
Seattle, Nov. 10, 1990

HEADLINE: Oil Price Down Again on Hostage Decision

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The decision by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to free all hostages helped send oil prices plummeting at the opening yesterday, adding to the sharp drop the day before on hopes for peace. But the market began rising later in the day, as traders wondered exactly how far the crisis stands from peaceful resolution.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for delivery next month fell 89 cents a barrel, to $26.40, the lowest close since Aug. 29. The price of oil has dropped $4.26 a barrel over the last two days. 
 At one point in the morning yesterday, oil was trading as low as $25.25 a barrel. On Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait, the similar contract closed at $21.54. Analysts differ on exactly how low the price would be without the threat of war but agree that most of the "war premium" is gone.
In a separate action, the New York Mercantile Exchange said yesterday that it had formulated new rules to deal with extreme volatility in prices. Under the proposal, trading would cease for the day if the price of oil moved $15 a barrel in either direction on the contracts for the nearest two months, and it would close for one hour if the price moved $7.50.
The change must be approved by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and market experts pointed out that both of the new proposed limits were far larger than even the biggest move this year, which was a $5.41-a-barrel decline, on Oct. 19.
Analysts attributed the move over the last two days to the perception of a sharply lower risk of war.
"People have been taken to the brink of peace and looked in -- and it's concentrated their minds," said Michael C. Lynch, a senior research associate at the Washington International Energy Group.
But referring to a possible visit to Washington by the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, Mr. Lynch warned that the price could shoot up again. "If Aziz comes to Washington and says, 'If the Israelis get out of the West Bank we'll be happy,' and then Bush says, 'Go home,' then the war premium goes back up to $10," he said.
Some people noted that Mr. Hussein had not said exactly how and when the hostages would be leaving. "One has to give a lot of credit to Saddam Hussein for his deft manipulation of our psyches," said Peter C. Beutel of Pegasus Econometrics in Hoboken, N.J.
 
'All the Good News Is Out'
 Shahrokh Nikkhah, vice president for futures at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the market had descended a little too low this morning in its expectation of peace. Explaining the turn back up in price he said, "I think today people looked at the substance of the differences between Iraq and the United States and realized there is still a big difference."
Of the price between now and Jan. 15, the deadline set by the United Nations Security Council resolution for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, he said unhappy surprises were possible.
"All the good news is out now," he said. "Any news that could come up now, unfortunately, is that there are differences between the United States and Iraq."
Another trader, Tom Bentz of United Energy Inc., said: "People are reading a lot in between the lines of what's actually being said. I personally don't think we're that close to a peaceful solution." He said that the market could turn around and move up today.
 
The Merc's Proposal
 Under the details of the rules announced today by the Mercantile Exchange to curb price volatility, if the price moved $7.50 a barrel, or 20 cents a gallon for oil products, and trading was halted, then when it resumed, movement would be limited to another $7.50 a barrel in the same direction. There would be no time out, however, if the limit was reached in the last two minutes of a trading session. There would also be no limits in the last half-hour of the day of the contract's expiration.
A pause, said Z. Lou Guttman, chairman of the exchange, would allow opportunity "for additional information dissemination, the review of margins and other financial considerations, consultation between Government officials and the exchange board and staff," and for consultation by traders with customers.
The most prominent of the exchange's critics, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, said yesterday in a statement that "a $15-per-barrel increase in one day is still huge and unacceptable." He pointed out that some analysts had predicted a price of $100 a barrel in case of war. "Still," he added, "I appreciate the fact that Nymex has the foresight to announce its plans, however modest they are, in advance."
Mr. Bentz of United Energy praised the proposed rules. "Markets sometimes have a way in panic situations of overdoing things," he said. A break in trading, he added, would be a chance to pause "until the market can get ahold of what's really going on and people can calm themselves."
But Mr. Beutel said the limit was unlikely to be reached in all but the most extreme circumstances.
"You'd have to catch everybody by surprise with something humongous in terms of news," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 20, 1990, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Dec.7 about a rule change proposed by the New York Mercantile Exchange to curb volatility in oil trading misstated what would happen if the price moved by the daily limit, $15 a barrel up or down, on the contracts for the nearest two months. If that limit was reached, trading could continue, but only at prices within the $15 limit. It would not be halted.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Vice Chairman Named At Salomon Brothers

BYLINE: By H. J. Maidenberg

 BODY:
Salomon Brothers Inc. yesterday announced the appointment of Deryck C. Maughan as its fifth vice chairman, effective Jan. 1. The 43-year-old British-born executive is chairman of Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd.
Mr. Maughan will also become the seventh member of the office of chairman, which is the investment banking firm's management group. 
 Mr. Maughan joined Salomon in 1983 and became a managing director in 1986. Shortly after joining Salomon, he went to the firm's Tokyo office where, a company spokesman said, he developed an expertise in Japanese economic and financial affairs.
That interest in Japan's economic development led him to become a founding member of the Tokyo International Financial Futures Exchange. He is also active in the America-Japan Society.
After his position in Japan, Mr. Maughan became Salomon's corporate and international fixed-income product manager in New York.
Before joining Salomon Brothers, Mr. Maughan worked in the London office of Goldman, Sachs & Company for four years. Before that, he served with the British Treasury as an adviser on global economic and financial affairs for 10 years after graduating from King's College at the University of London in 1969. He also earned a master's degree from the Graduate School of Business at Stanford University.
In addition to Mr. Maughan's appointment, Salomon announced it had added 14 new managing directors, also effective Jan. 1. The new appointments will raise the number of Salomon's managing directors to 164.
The new managing directors are: Joseph Anastasio, domestic support-operations; Christopher Baine, Tokyo sales management; Victor Haghani, domestic fixed-income arbitrage; Gregory Hawkins, domestic fixed-income arbitrage; Robert Huffman, domestic fixed-income sales; Toshiharu Kido, Tokyo fixed-income sales; Richard Lampen, domestic investment banking; William McDonald, domestic investment banking; David Shulman, domestic research/real estate; Rick Singer, domestic investment banking; Robert Smith, domestic investment banking; Richard Stuckey, domestic hedge management; Scott Wilson, domestic investment banking, and Gary Wolens, European equities.

HEADLINE: Matthew D. Edel, 49, Professor and Author

 BODY:
Matthew D. Edel, professor of urban studies at Queens College and an author, died on Wednesday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 49 years old and lived in Sunnyside, Queens.
He died of septic shock after being treated for cancer, the college said. 
 Dr. Edel, a specialist in urban economics and Latin American development, joined the Queens faculty in 1972 and was chairman of the urban studies department from 1983 to 1987. Since 1984 he served on the economics faculty at the City University of New York Graduate School and was a senior associate of the Bildner Center for Western Hemisphere Studies in Manhattan.
He wrote several books on urban affairs, including "Food Supply and Inflation in Latin America," published in 1969; "Economies and the Environment" (1973) and "Shaky Palaces: Homeownership and Social Mobility in Boston's Suburbanization" (1984).
Dr. Edel, a native of Brooklyn, was a graduate of Harvard and held a master's degree from Columbia and a doctorate from Yale. He taught at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for five years before joining the Queens faculty.
His uncle, Leon Edel, is the biographer of Henry James and other literary figures. Dr. Edel is survived by his wife, the former Kim Dye; his father, Abraham, of Philadelphia; three sons, Keir, Stephen and Gareth, all of Queens, and a sister, Deborah, of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Saudis and U.S. Aides Wary Over Iraqi Move

BYLINE: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Saudi and American officials here are reacting with some wariness and concern to the generally welcome news that Iraq will release its Western hostages.
While the release of the hostages was a major objective, both Saudi and American officials here have long worried that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would release hostages not as a prelude to a complete withdrawal from Kuwait but as a shrewd gambit to weaken the international coalition against him. 
 A senior American military commander said this idea raises the prospect of a prolonged Iraqi presence in Kuwait, continued American deployment in Saudi Arabia, declining support for war and a long, exasperating political confrontation with Iraq in which Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations would probably feel increasingly vulnerable.
"This means the war is over," said a worried Saudi official who deals in foreign affairs. "It's going to be almost impossible to keep the pressure up if Saddam releases the hostages."
 
Saudis to Redouble Efforts
 The official said Saudi Arabia feared that it would eventually be left to face a still armed and agressive Iraq. He added that Saudi Arabia would redouble efforts to keep the United Nations embargo against Iraq as severe as possible and to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and pay to rebuild what it has destroyed.
Senior American officials here have long expressed concern that Iraq would use the hostages as part of an extended confrontation aimed at breaking up the embargo.
American officials often seem torn between a desire to avoid war and a desire to seize the moment to destroy Iraq's military might.
Speaking a few days before the surprise announcement that Iraq would release its hostages, a senior American commander here said American military planners had visualized what they call a nightmare scenario in which Mr. Hussein avoids war, maintains his military strength and keeps part of Kuwait.
The scenario, the commander said, begins with the Iraqi release of all hostages, a move aimed at calming passions. Then Mr. Hussein begins a gradual withdrawal from Kuwait, while opening negotiations.
 
Sagging of Will Feared
 As talks drag on, and international and American will sags, and Mr. Hussein announces that he will give up all of Kuwait except perhaps a few islands in the Persian Gulf and a major oil field next to the Iraqi border.
American military and political strategists say they fear that such a series of steps will make it impossible to force Mr. Hussein to leave Kuwait entirely, or to pay for the damage and death he has caused. It will also be difficult to strip his army of chemical and biological weapons, and perhaps the nuclear ability that he appears to be trying to build, the senior American commander said.
Saudi officials fear a similar outcome at a moment when a quiet debate here has brought contradictory statements from influential Saudis. There is a fear that the United States will lose resolve, and there is equal concern that the costs of war will destabilize the region and make Saudi Arabia a sort of pariah in the eyes of other Arabs.
The two views share a profound sense of vulnerability that many Saudis seem to feel at a moment of crisis.
"We're completely exposed," a well-connected Saudi businessman said. "Other Arabs are going to blame us for years for bringing in the Americans and attacking Iraq. It's a bad feeling for us."
 
'We Aren't Safe' From Iraq
 But in the next breath, the same businessman said he hoped the United States would attack immediately because, "we know we aren't safe so long as Saddam has these big weapons and his army."
Other influential Saudis are more cautious.
An influential Government administrator who is a private adviser to the royal family said in an interview this week that he and several of his closest friends were counseling against war for as long as a year, to see if economic sanctions will cripple Iraq.
"War is easy to start, but few can know how it will end," the administrator said. "I think war will destabilize the region for years at endless cost."
"Why is it necessary to rush to war so quickly?" the official continued. "The embargo has cut off Iraq's income. I think within a year, Saddam will be severely weakened and his military will be out of parts. If he still won't withdraw from Kuwait, attack him then."
 
Worried About Support
 Both American and Saudi officials said, however, that they are deeply worried by the difficulty of maintaining international support and the embargo against Iraq, while winning political backing from several countries for a continuing military buildup here to be ready to wage war if necessary.
Saudi and American officials said the hostage release would force them to reconsider previous assumptions on the duration and nature of the military deployment under way against Iraq.
A central consideration, they said, will be the question of a long confrontation that never quite reaches the point of war, but that lasts for another year or more.
"All kinds of things are possible, but I don't think anyone came here thinking they were going to spend a year in the desert," an American military commander said. "It's very hard to predict the outcome of that sort of standoff."

HEADLINE: Waiting for the Zapping of Nintendo

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Will Nintendo, the world's biggest maker of computer games, be zapped this increasingly bleak Christmas? Many stock analysts think so. Nintendo competitors hope so.
Nintendo says, dream on. 
 More than the dominance of games like Super Mario Brothers 3 and the Legend of Zelda is at stake. Nintendo, the toy sensation of the last three Christmases, remains the best-selling toy in the industry, and its fate may signal whether consumers will continue to pay high prices for toys.
Of every dollar Americans spent on toys last year, 16 cents went to Nintendo. That was $2.7 billion out of a total $16.8 billion that Mom and Dad did not spend on Barbie dolls, Hulk Hogan "action figures," licensed merchandise like Batman soap or Scattergories board games.
While Nintendo's rivals, like Sega of America and NEC Technologies , say their sales are better than expected, they remain tiny blips on the radar screen of Nintendo, which has more than 90 percent of the game market.
Even so, Nintendo has had to scale back its sales projections. Looking at a looming recession and continued tensions in the Middle East, some toy industry experts are predicting that consumers will cut back on expensive Christmas toys like Nintendo. But even with slow third-quarter sales, Nintendo and its licensees will see a sharp sales rise this year, said Peter Main, vice president for marketing for Nintendo of America, the subsidiary of the Japanese company that is based in Redmond, Wash.
Retailers love Nintendo because it is a large profit sitting on a little shelf space. Nintendo's dictionary-sized plastic game console, which hooks up to a television set, sells for $99. Its hundreds of microchip-stuffed game cartridges, the size of a slice of bread, sell for up to $50. Game Boy, the hand-held Nintendo game console the size of a Sony Walkman, sells for $89.95; its tiny game cartridges cost a hefty $29.99.
If Nintendo slips, said Paul Valentine, a toy-industry analyst for Standard & Poor's, then makers of more traditional toys and board games will benefit. "We can put our hands on hard evidence that Nintendo is faltering," he said. Toy retailers are already sharply discounting Nintendo games. And 70 percent of American households with children 8 to 15 already have Nintendo, signaling market saturation.
Mr. Valentine estimates that when sales of Atari video games, Nintendo's predecessor, collapsed, traditional toy sales rose 50 percent in 1984 alone.
Despite such strong sellers as Playmate Toys' Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles, Hasbro's World Wrestling Federation action figures and Tyco's My Pretty Ballerina, many traditional-toy companies have reported earnings declines or losses in recent quarters. Cautious ordering and financial weakness at highly leveraged retailers exacerbated problems for the Nintendo wallflowers.
 
Aiming for Adults
 But Nintendo is not dying, according to Mr. Main. "There is a sense of whipping boy when people talk about Nintendo," he said. "Are we old news? Yes, we are. Are we continuing to show strength? Yes, we are."
Just about every youngster does have Nintendo, Mr. Main said, but that is why the company's new marketing pitch is aimed at adults, who already make up a third of Nintendo players. Even with its lower sales expectations and marked-down software, Nintendo will still sell significantly more units than last year. Mario, the little Italian plumber who stars in the most popular line of Nintendo games, gives the company a brand-name recognition that competitors like Sega and NEC do not have, he said.
If Nintendo seems to be everywhere, it is because about 29 million American homes are now noisy video arcades filled with Nintendo invalids. Five of the top 10 toys, according to the latest survey of Toy & Hobby World magazine, are Nintendo. The game console is still the nation's best-selling plaything.
But Atari had also emptied the wallets of millions of parents only to become a kind of metaphor for disaster gone ballistic. Immensely popular in the early 1980's, Atari reported huge losses in 1983 when a nation of temperamental tykes said suddenly, "Masters of the Universe, please." This year, several analysts see Nintendo but think Atari.
Nintendo's direct competitors are making headway with technologically advanced games and equipment. But Nintendo says it has a 93 percent share of the game market, Sega 3.8 percent, NEC 1.3 percent and Atari Games, 1.1 percent. Nintendo's rivals acknowledge that Nintendo has more than 90 percent of the software market. But they say Nintendo underestimates their shares and overestimates how many Nintendo games and consoles that retailers, heavy with inventory, will actually sell.
Nintendo has prospered, in part, by keeping tight control over its game software by manufacturing its own cartridges. In a move interpreted by some analysts as a response to slowing sales, Nintendo earlier this year said it would allow some licensees -- the scores of independent companies that write the hundreds of Nintendo game titles -- to make their own cartridges. Talks are still under way with licensees, and Nintendo has not cleared any cartridges in what it calls an "experimental" program.
Using the lowest of Nintendo of America's unit sales projections, the company and its licensees could post 1990 retail sales of $3.8 billion, up 40 percent from the level a year ago. That compares with perhaps a 47 percent rise projected earlier this year.
Nintendo of America did reduce its sales projections for its Nintendo game cartridges, which bring in about two-thirds of the company's revenue. But it raised projections for the Nintendo Entertainment System, the video game console, signaling more game cartridge sales in the future. Nintendo expects to sell 8.2 million consoles, up from its earlier estimate of 6 million, but down 11 percent from the 9.2 million a year earlier.
The company had expected to sell 70 million game cartridges, but revised that estimate to between 59 million and 65 million. That compares with 53 million unit sales in 1989.
The wide range for cartridges is due in part to uncertainty over old inventory, which has led to widespread discounting of Nintendo games. Like day-old bread, slower-selling Nintendo games have accumulated on store shelves. But that does not mean, Mr. Main argues, that customers are rejecting Nintendo, just as supermarket shoppers are not rejecting bread as a category when they pass over day-old loaves.
Since Nintendo's introduction in the United States in 1985, dozens of slower-selling titles have accumulated every year. There are now nearly 300 Nintendo video game titles but just 30 of those account for 50 percent of sales.
Even so, big chain stores, like Toys "R" Us, the world's largest toy store, have bought many slow-selling titles from distributors and smaller retailers. Nintendo studies, perhaps self-servingly, show that the more titles a store carries, the more it will sell for every game console.
Much of Nintendo's expected 1990 increase results from surging sales of Game Boy and its software. Nintendo expects to sell 4.4 million Game Boys, down from 5 million, projected earlier, but quadruple the level of a million last year, when it was introduced.
 
'You Could Get Old'
 Although Nintendo has reached market saturation among youngsters, especially boys aged 8 to 12, it finds that girls and young adults are becoming fans. From small percentages in the late 1980's, women and girls now make up 25 percent of all players. Even more striking is the percentage of players over 18, more than 32 percent.
Nintendo hopes to capture adults, both men and women. Game Boy's television commercials aim directly at this market. A recent commercial, by Foote Cone & Belding, San Francisco, shows suspendered professionals in their 30's playing Game Boy in their offices while vaguely classical music plays in the background. The tagline is: "You don't stop playing because you get old. But you could get old, if you stop playing."
As Game Boy this year stimulated lagging sales of its previous years' products, Nintendo hopes new machines from its Kyoto-based parent will raiset 1991 sales. Nintendo game consoles are 8-bit machines, a measure of computer memory and power, while new consoles recently introduced in Japan are 16-bit computers, with improved graphics and sound but at a hefty $169 price tag.
Whatever happens this year, Mr. Main said, Nintendo will live up to its name, which in Japanese means "Good things come from hard effort." Perhaps more appropriately, in view of this uncertain season, Nintendo can also be translated as "Leave it to heaven."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Steep Decline; Interests Rates Are a Factor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar registered a sharp decline yesterday, shaken by an unemployment report from the United States that was worse than expected and by falling interest rates.
The dollar declined overseas and opened on a very weak note when trading shifted to domestic markets. The report that unemployment jumped two-tenths of a percentage point in November, to 5.9 percent, "got the market moving," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.
The report offered virtually indisputable evidence that a recession has begun and prompted the Federal Reserve and a handful of banks to act to ease interest rates.
Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable and therefore reduce investors' need for dollars.
There were unconfirmed reports that the Federal Reserve had stepped in to support the dollar against the German mark, Mr. Flanagan said, adding that the dollar did move up after the rumors of intervention.
Traders are expecting interest rate differentials to become more unfavorable for the dollar, as United States rates decline while some important foreign rates hold steady. That would put further pressure on the dollar.
Also pushing the dollar down was an easing of tensions in the Persian Gulf conflict after the offer Thursday by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to release all hostages.
"The war premium was wiped out this week," said Kevin Lawrie, a vice president at the Bank of Boston in New York.
In New York, the dollar closed at 130.70 yen, down from 132.14 yen on Thursday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 132.17 yen, from 134.05 yen at Thursday's close. In London, it fell to 131.05 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.9510 in London, up from $1.9390 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.9535 to buy a pound, up from Thursday's $1.9400.
In New York trading against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.4720 marks, down from 1.4885 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.2532 Swiss francs, down from 1.2710; 4.9975 French francs, down from 5.0510; 1,110.00 Italian lire, down from 1,122.25, and 1.1580 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1621.

HEADLINE: U.S. Needs More Help in Gulf, Cheney Tells NATO.

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that he had told the NATO allies that the United States would welcome more troops, supplies and help in transporting American forces to the Persian Gulf.
In response, NATO defense ministers meeting here made no promises to send more forces to the region, but agreed to continue giving the assistance they were already providing. 
Mr. Cheney said he had told the allies that the United States would welcome additional assistance, including heavy combat units, materiel and help in transportation. He said he had made no specific requests and received no specific promises.
"I made a general statement that we would be happy to have additional support," he said. "I did not come with specific requests and I am not now in a position of waiting for a response.
 
Deployment to Continue
 "I would expect that some governments would go back and say we'll reconsider."
Mr. Cheney also said that the news that Iraq might soon release all its foreign hostages would not hold up the deployment of 200,000 more American troops to the gulf by the end of January, or lead to any lessening of American resolve.
And, he said, even if the allies sent no more forces to the gulf, the United States would have enough to drive Iraq out of Kuwait if the decision was made to go to war.
NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner, said the response to the American invitation to continue or increase help was "basically favorable."
 
'Self-Sustaining' Combat Units
 The heavy combat units the United States would welcome are "units that are self-sustaining, and would add ground combat power, or additional air defense, or artillery," Mr. Cheney said. They would have to be prepared to operate under American command in the event of a decision to use force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait if it has not pulled out by the United Nations deadline of Jan. 15.
Mr. Cheney said he had not made any additional requests for money from the allies to help the United States meet the costs of the planned deployment of a force of over 400,000 Americans by the end of January.
Asked specifically if the Administration was satisfied with the contribution of Germany, which has sent no ground forces to the gulf, Mr. Cheney said:
"The United States clearly is playing the lead role, because we're able to. We have been very pleased with the support we've received from other countries. In particular, Germany has been very helpful in providing equipment, and is now helping to transport additional equipment and troops to the gulf."
 
New Kinds of Threats Seen
 Britain, which last month announced plans to bring its total deployment to the gulf to more than 30,000 troops by the end of January, and France, which has about 15,000 troops in the area, are the only NATO countries besides the United States to have sent significant numbers of combat soldiers.
The NATO communique after the two-day defense ministers' meeting acknowledged that, with the cold war over and the Warsaw Pact dying, the alliance had to be prepared to respond to new kinds of threats.
"The risks that allies now face in Europe arise principally not from the likelihood of deliberate aggression against allied territory, but rather as unforeseeable consequences of instabilities that might emerge in a period of rapid and widespread political, social and economic transformation," it said.
"Risks to alliance security can also arise from instability in East and Central Europe and from elsewhere," it said. NATO has not acted as a unit in the gulf crisis because its original charter, the Treaty of Washington, defined its area as the North Atlantic and Mediterranean.
 
Drafting a New Strategy
 The defense ministers discussed the progress of their alliance's attempt to draft a new strategy and design new tactics and force structures to preserve itself now that it has lost its traditional enemy, the Soviet Union, which no longer poses a threat of direct aggression. It is expected that the new strategy will be approved at a NATO summit late next spring.
As Mr. Worner put it, "NATO doesn't need a counterpart, or a foe, or an enemy. There are risks, there are instabilities, so you need insurance."
After the signature of the treaty on reduction of conventional arms in Europe in Paris last month, and despite plans to make "dramatic" reductions in the number of NATO nuclear warheads in Europe, the allied defense ministers still insisted today that they needed to maintain "for the foreseeable future an appropriate mix of nuclear and conventional forces, based in Europe, and kept up to date where necessary."
President Bush bowed to German wishes earlier this year and canceled the planned modernization of American short-range Lance nuclear missiles based in Germany. Gerhard Stoltenberg, the German Defense Minister, said at the meetings that he expected the alliance to give negotiators a mandate to eliminate all land-based nuclear missiles and nuclear artillery weapons in Europe in talks with the Soviet Union that are to start next year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a news conference yesterday in Brussels, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said he told NATO defense ministers that the United States "would be happy to have additional support" in the form of troops, supplies and help in transporting American forces to the Persian Gulf. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Growth Rate Of Consumer Debt Slows

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Growth in consumer credit slowed to a seasonally adjusted $1.47 billion in October, the Federal Reserve reported today. Analysts said it was another sign of a weakening economy.
"That is minuscule, a very, very small increase," said Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group, a Washington management consulting firm. "It mostly reflects that we have a real softening in the kinds of purchases that people usually use credit for -- cars, furniture, appliances." 
 "Consumer spending is weak, and it's not surprising that consumer credit is weak," she said. "Consumers are much more leery about using credit given the business and economic environment."
The Federal Reserve said consumer credit grew at an annual rate of 2.4 percent, down from a revised 4.6 percent rate posted for September. The September rate was even slower than the 4.9 percent advance originally reported.
"Growth in revolving credit slowed in October from September," the central bank said. "Auto loans outstanding declined further in October as did loans for mobile homes."
Revolving, or credit card, debt increased $1.56 billion, at an annual rate of 8.6 percent. That was down from a 12.9 percent gain in September and a 13.3 percent advance a month earlier.
Automobile loans declined $785 million, at a 3.3 percent annual rate. Auto loans, which fell one-tenth of a percent in September, have declined every month this year except for January and March.
Ms. Shaber said the auto loan component provided more evidence that relatively strong car sales in October were attributable more to fleet sales than purchases by ordinary consumers.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose $880 million, a 5 percent rate, which was up slightly from 4.9 percent the previous month.
Borrowing for mobile homes fell $188 million, or a 10 percent rate, after declining 15.8 percent in September.
The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of October at $736.7 billion.

HEADLINE: New Zealand Media Move

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The New Zealand Government said on Thursday that it would allow foreign companies to increase their holdings in radio and television companies.
The Communications Minister, Maurice Williamson, said legislation providing for up to 49.9 percent ownership by foreign companies in New Zealand broadcasters would be introduced in Parliament before the end of the month. The current ratios are a maximum of 15 percent foreign ownership in television companies and up to 25 percent in radio concerns. 
 The primary beneficiary of the move is expected to be the financially troubled TV3 network, a private company now in receivership. The network, begun a year ago as the first private competition to the two stations run by the state-owned Television New Zealand, attracts 15 percent of the viewing audience.
NBC of the United States owns 7.5 percent of TV3. It had reduced its stake from 15 percent. TV3 reported a $28 million loss for the year ended on March 31.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Fleet-Norstar To Cut 500 Jobs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 7

 BODY:
Fleet-Norstar Financial Group plans to cut about 500 jobs by the end of the year, an official of the banking company said today.
The layoffs will be scattered among Fleet's 1,000 offices in 40 states but will primarily affect workers in New England and New York, a bank spokesman, Robert W. Lougee Jr., said.
The cutbacks "range from the top to the bottom of the organization," he said. Some workers have already been notified.
Fleet posted a small profit in the third quarter and has been profitable for the first nine months of the year. The Providence-based bank-holding company attributed most of the layoffs to the recession in the the Northeast.
Other reductions were part of a continuing consolidation since Fleet Financial Group merged with Norstar Bankcorp of Albany in 1988. Shortly after the merger, Fleet-Norstar employed 19,500 people. Today, it employs 18,000, Mr. Lougee said. The work force reduction was expected to save the company about $25 million.

HEADLINE: Crude Up 18 Cents, to $26.58, But Is Down $2.27 for Week

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices showed little change yesterday as traders paused to wonder what crude might do next, after a dramatic weeklong slide based on hopes for peace in the Persian Gulf.
"When the market moves like this one has, it tends to get a little bit overdone and then moves back," said Brian Tagler, an oil broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. 
 Crude for January delivery rose 18 cents, to $26.58 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
For the week, oil was down $2.27 a barrel for next-month delivery. After a big fall of $4.06 a barrel on Nov. 30, this week's losses dropped oil into a price range it had not seen since August, the month Iraq invaded Kuwait.
Crude's fall also brought unleaded gasoline futures down to August levels. The dive began last week when President Bush offered to hold top-level diplomatic sessions with the Iraqis.
Oil kept falling this week, first when Iraq accepted the offer, and later when President Saddam Hussein of Iraq announced plans to free all his hostages.
 
A Little Correction
 Oil traders said the market seemed due for its its slight bounce up yesterday, and some were surprised it did not rise even more.
"We came down awfully fast over the past couple of days and this is a little bit of a correction," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. "Even though there's new peace hopes, you have to look at them with a grain of salt."
Futures contracts for home heating oil and unleaded gasoline were mixed, though none of them moved by as much as a cent a gallon. Some traders were selling heating oil contracts and buying unleaded gasoline contracts just because gasoline seemed like a relative bargain at about 12 cents a gallon cheaper than the heating oil, Mr. Blakeslee said.
Heating oil closed down 0.54 cent at 79.17 cents a gallon for January delivery. Unleaded gasoline was down 0.13 cent at 66.47 cents a gallon for January delivery.
For the week, unleaded gasoline fell 11.11 cents a gallon for next-month delivery, while home heating oil fell 6.70 cents a gallon.
Natural gas, which is not directly affected by fears of war in the Persian Gulf, also showed little direction yesterday. The January delivery contract fell 0.1 cent, to $2.350 per 1,000 cubic feet. For the week, gas dropped 9.5 cents for January delivery.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum Prices Off Sharply After Unemployment Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metals continued their slide on the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday, paced by a sharp drop in platinum prices that was caused by a jump in United States unemployment.
Silver prices were also hard hit, at one point tumbling to contract lows. Both platinum and silver are heavily used in industry. 
 The selloff in platinum came after the release of unemployment figures by the United States Labor Department showing joblessness in November reached a three-year high of 5.9 percent.
 
January Platinum at $413.40
 Platinum settled $7.90 to $8.50 lower, with the contract for delivery in January at $413.40 an ounce.
Peter Cardillo, an analyst with Jesup, Josephthal & Company in New York, said the silver market was also sharply affected by the decline in employment.
Platinum is used in the catalytic converters of automobiles and in jewelry. Silver is a luxury item and is used in the photography industry.
"If you have a recessionary atmosphere, it dampens the future prospects of the metal," Mr. Cardillo said.
The unemployment figures gave some support to the gold market. Gold is usually an investment haven in times of economic uncertainty. But the imminent release of hostages in Iraq and the resulting perceptions of peace weighed on gold futures, analysts said.
Gold was $1.10 to $1.90 lower, with the active February contract at $372.10 an ounce. The near-month December contract fell $1.40 an ounce, to $370.30. Silver was 6.2 to 7.8 cents lower, with December at $4.055 an ounce.
Recessionary fears also forced copper prices lower on the Comex.
Copper was 1.45 to 3.10 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in December at $1.1015 a pound.
Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as a lack of news on United States aid to the Soviet Union took its toll on the market.
The market has been awaiting an announcement that the United States will extend about $1.2 billion in export credits to the Soviet Union so that nation can buy United States farm products. But nothing has come of talks between Soviet officials and the United States Agriculture Department.
Analysts also noted that the market was hurt by the failure of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks in Brussels.
Wheat futures showed gains on aggressive buying by commercial houses and by Egypt's purchase of 200,000 metric tons of soft white wheat under the export bonus program, said Paul Sylvester, an analyst with Gerald Inc. in Chicago.

HEADLINE: 1-900-I-LOVE/I-HATE-FLORIO-MAKE-ME-RICH

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNION CITY, N.J.

 BODY:
A 16-year-old high school student has found a way to channel some of the heated public debate over Gov. Jim Florio and his $2.8 billion tax program into a money maker: a 900 telephone number for people who want to say whether Mr. Florio should be recalled, or given a chance.
The $2 it costs each caller to dial the number and select one of two extensions that registers the votes for or against the Governor's program pays for the call and yields about $1 to Lorraine Buschhoff, a junior at St. Aloysius Academy in Jersey City. 
 "I'm going to save some of the money for college, and donate the rest to a local homeless charity," she said. "I haven't figured out how much will go to each."
More than 200 callers have registered votes in the 10 days the number has been available. "So far, the sentiment is running 3 to 1 for a recall," Miss Buschhoff said.
 
Clothing for Homeless
 In June Miss Buschhoff was among 324 young people across the state to receive a Young Citizen's Award from Senator Bill Bradley for making "significant contributions to their communities."
Miss Buschhoff and her parents collected clothing three years ago from the more than 400 families who live in their apartment building in Union City and given it to the homeless at the Journal Square PATH Station in Jersey City and at Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan. She has also sold candy and stuffed animals to raise pocket money and funds for organizations for the homeless and the blind.
"I don't get an allowance, so I had to find ways to raise money," she said. "The clothing distribution and the donations also give me a warm feeling because I am able to do something for others."
Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's communications director, said he was glad she had found a way to raise money from the debate.
 
We Said It Would Help
 "We said our program would be good for the economy," he said. "But from the consumer's standpoint, it would make more sense to spend 25 cents for a stamp and write to the governor directly."
He also said 900-number telephone surveys do not really measure public sentiment on important issues. "People who are against it are much more likely to spend the $2," he said.
Using 900 numbers to tap the emotion generated by taxes appears to have become almost a cottage industry.
Last month, after a complaint by Mr. Florio's office, a number run by a Cranford resident was shut off. Mr. Shure said the call cost $6 and callers "were told the money would help impeach Mr. Florio, when it can't, and the message contained gross misinformation that approached fraud."
 
Father's First Customer
 The message said Mr. Florio was planning to raise the current 7 percent sales tax to 10 percent and to disarm police departments.
Miss Buschhoff got the idea to start the telephone poll when her father started a new business leasing 900 numbers.
The phone number, (900) 321-0001 (she was her father's first customer), is available 24 hours a day. Callers are told to press one extension if they agree that "Governor Florio should be recalled for his tax increase," and another extension if they believe "Governor Florio had no choice in raising taxes and should be given a chance."
Sister Joan Repka, principal of St. Aloysius, said Miss Buschhoff's latest venture has brought reporters and a cable television crew to the school. "Everyone is aware of the telephone poll," she said, "although the students ask her, 'Why are you doing this?' and 'Who's Florio?' -- as sophisticated as high school students are."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Democrats Say Iraqi Move Won't Turn Debate

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Congressional Democrats who have been critical of President Bush's Persian Gulf policy said today that their views had not been altered by President Saddam Hussein's decision to release the foreign hostages in Iraq and Kuwait.
"It doesn't affect the debate," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, a senior member of the Foreign Relations Committee. "Democrats like me are not going to stop questioning the soundness of his policy." 
 Mr. Biden and other prominent Democrats in both the House and the Senate have argued that economic sanctions imposed on Iraq after Mr. Hussein's invasion of Kuwait in August should be given more time to work before any resort to military force.
Both Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d insisted on Thursday that the Iraqi decision to free the hostages proved that the threat of imminent war was finally beginning to produce concessions from Mr. Hussein.
 
Hostages 'Becoming a Liability'
 But many Democrats said today that the decision was more likely the result of a combination of factors, including the sanctions, and that in terms of the future course of gulf policy, it probably did not matter much any way.
"I think it became clear to Saddam Hussein that there was no more mileage in having hostages and that they were becoming a liability," Mr. Biden said. "I think he became convinced that they would not slow the momentum for a siege against him, whether it was military or economic."
Senator Sam Nunn f Georgia, who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, echoed that view, saying, "To me, it doesn't matter why he's done it."
Mr. Nunn, who has been critical of the President's decision to send additional American forces to the gulf, said the military option has been credible since October, when the initial contingent of 230,000 American troops sent to Saudi Arabia reached full strength.
He said that while it was impossible to determine Mr. Hussein's motivations for deciding to free the foreigners, the most important factor may have been Mr. Baker's statement that there would be no war if the Iraqi leader complied fully with a resolution adopted last week by the United Nations Security Council. That resolution authorizes the use of force after Jan. 15 if Iraq does not leave Kuwait.
"I at some point will support the use of military force in Kuwait," Mr. Nunn said. "I have said that all along. The question is whether that is wise at this time. I don't think it's vital that Kuwait be liberated with 95 percent American forces and 95 percent American casualties between now and February."
"If there is a war, we ought to be able to look at the family member of somebody who gets killed and say it was worth it, and we exhausted all the other options," he said.
The split over gulf policy has taken on an increasingly partisan tone in Congress over the last several weeks, highlighted by the angry exchanges between liberal Democrats and Administration officials during hearings conducted by Mr. Nunn's panel and the Foreign Relations Committee. But there are also divisions within Democratic ranks.
Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat who serves on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said that while party colleagues who are critical of the President's policies had received most of the attention, he and at least half a dozen other House Democrats had serious doubts about the effect of economic sanctions on Iraq or their utility in dislodging Mr. Hussein from Kuwait.

HEADLINE: Prime Rate Is Cut to 9 3/4% By a Few Regional Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
A few regional banks cut their prime lending rates yesterday to 9 3/4 percent from 10 percent, a move that is expected to spread to other banks, although analysts are not sure when.
The cuts are a sign that the Federal Reserve's recent moves to ease monetary policy and reduce short-term interest rates in the financial markets are beginning to spread through the economy. 
 The prime rate, which has been stable at 10 percent since January, when it fell from 10 1/2 percent, is a benchmark for rates charged on loans to small and medium-sized businesses. It is also used at some banks to determine rates on home equity and credit card loans.
 
'Little Beneficial Impact'
 "So far the Fed's moves to lower rates have had a relatively little beneficial impact on rates at which individuals and smaller businesess can borrow, which is one reason why I expect further easing by the Fed," said Dana Johnson, an economist at the First National Bank of Chicago.
To stimulate the economy, and encourage further cuts in the prime rate, Mr. Johnson expects the Fed to reduce the interest rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market to 7 percent by the year's end, and that it might also cut the discount rate it charges on loans made to banks. Since July, the Fed has reduced the overnight loan rate in the Federal funds market from 8 1/4 percent to 7 1/4 percent but has left the discount rate unchanged at 7 percent since February 1989, when it was raised from 6 1/2 percent.
 
 Move by New Jersey Bank
 The largest bank to reduce the prime was the First Fidelity Bancorporation, Lawrenceville, N.J., the 23d-largest banking company in the country. Officials at First Fidelity declined to comment, but analysts noted that the lower rate would surely be noticed by large New York banks that compete with the New Jersey bank for loans to midsized businesses in the New York area.
Robert G. Wilmers, chairman of the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company, a Buffalo bank that also reduced its rate, said the lower rate was justified "by growing indications that the economy is soft, and the continued moves by the Fed to push rates down."
Large banks have been slower than normal to reduce the prime rate because they are trying to earn as much interest as possible to compensate for heavy losses on bad real estate loans and a need to pay higher than normal interest rates to large depositors who are worried about the health of the banking system.
