HEADLINE: The Talk of Albany;
Government's Their Job; Business Is Lousy

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The holiday season has arrived in Albany, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo wants to give everyone in the state work force some extra time off. But little joy has greeted the news: These vacation days would be mandatory furloughs, without pay, a move proposed by the Governor to help close a $1 billion state budget deficit for the current year.
 Legislative leaders, meanwhile, are promoting an alternative plan under which many workers would still work, but not collect some of their pay until the 21st century. Under this plan, known as a lag payroll, state employees would be required to defer a week's worth of their wages until they retire.
Either way, state workers are feeling squeezed. 
 "People are in an uproar," Richard Waterhouse, a keypunch operator for the Department of Taxation and Finance, said on his lunch hour recently outside the department's sprawling headquarters. "They can call it whatever they want, but this thing basically amounts to a pay cut."
Some state workers are getting even worse news. Pink slips have already been sent to about 700 Department of Correctional Services employees, and the Governor plans to lay off up to 10,000 people within the next year and a half and eliminate thousands of other jobs through attrition.
Beyond the people most immediately affected, the budget plan has set off alarms throughout Albany, which so far has been spared the worst effects of the Northeast's economic downturn. That insulation has stemmed in large part from the state government's steadiness as an employer; but now there is wide concern here that layoffs of thousands of people in the Albany area could throw the city into an economic tailspin.
"The city of Albany has been about as recession-proof as you could get," said Albany's Mayor, Thomas M. Whalen 3d. But Albany is still something of a company town, the Mayor noted, "and the company is in trouble."
 
 The Mood at Ground Zero
 The various budget cuts proposed by Mr. Cuomo recently would affect every level of state government, and have stirred wide resentment.
"We're the backbone of the state," Roger Stevens, a 50-year-old highway equipment operator for the Department of Transportation, said as he helped ready a snowplow for winter duty the other day at a maintenance shop in an Albany suburb. "They should cut at the fat cats, not at us -- but this plan goes after everybody."
But while the cuts will be felt across the state, ground zero for any attempt to pare the state bureaucracy may well be the Gov. W. Averell Harriman State Office Campus, a huge cluster of squat office buildings a few miles west of the Capitol that houses everything from the State Troopers' Academy to the Department of Civil Service.
Governor Cuomo has repeatedly emphasized that the furloughs are the best possible way to "share the pain" of tough fiscal times and that the alternative would be even more layoffs.
But some state workers at the complex see other factors at work.
"Who's kidding who?" said 61-year-old John Birnbach, who has worked in the state printing plant for 23 years. "The Governor's doing this because he's running for President of the United States. He's trying to show he can be a big tough guy."
Others acknowledge that the state is in fact facing dire fiscal problems, but they are resisting the furloughs and the deferred-pay plans anyway. "There's a feeling that by going along you will just be setting yourself up for a sucker punch," said Isaac Bracey, a compensation analyst for the Department of Civil Service. "First they furlough you, then they'll lay you off anyway."
 
 No Laughing Matter
 Bob Mason has started going easy on his state-worker jokes, a sure sign of the sensitivity of the budget cuts.
Mr. Mason, a WPYX-FM radio announcer who hosts the Albany area's most popular morning show, usually peppers his program with skits and jokes that poke fun at the state work force. One long-running segment features a "900" party line for fictitious state workers, who spend much of the day calling in to complain that they were stumped by the day's "Jumble" puzzle or a crosssword.
The jokes (What's yellow and blue and sleeps six? A Department of Transportation truck. What did the state unions use for a float in this year's Thanksgiving Day parade? A giant loafer.) are largely gone these days, replaced instead by skits that liken Mario Cuomo to a George Steinbrenner figure, blaming the players for his team's problems.
"We've been giving state workers the business for years," Mr. Mason said in an interview. "Usually people just take it all in fun. But it's a tough time right now."
 
 Less Cheer for Holidays
 The Governor and legislative leaders are still huddling over the budget-cutting proposals, but officials here say that either the furloughs or the lag payroll will almost surely wind up as part of the final package. Sensing the inevitability of losing a week's pay this year, and knowing that banks and utility companies are not in the habit of letting their own bills "lag," many state workers said they were already holding back on holiday gifts.
"There's a lot of window-shopping going on this year," said Rick Eaglestone, the manager of the Northway Mall in the Albany suburb of Colonie. "What we're seeing is people coming in and looking at something, then coming back and looking again, then coming back and looking some more. It seems like last year, they'd just come in and buy."
State workers aren't the only ones caught in a budget crunch here. The gleaming 15,000-seat Knickerbocker Arena, built by Albany County to help revitalize the downtown area and perhaps even lure a major-league sports franchise someday, recently got stuck with a $250,000 bill from the state for chilled water that it uses for air conditioning and icemaking. That figure, included as part of the Governor's deficit-cutting plan, is about three times what the arena managers said they had agreed to pay. State officials said the initial cost estimate the state provided had simply been too low.
The higher bill adds to the county's anticipated debt payment for the arena, known as the Knick, of about $5.3 million this year, or $1 million more than anticipated revenues.

He walked across the State Office Campus with Larry Mauldin of the Department of Transportation. (Photographs by David Jennings for The New York Times) (pg. 28)

HEADLINE: Sears Reduces Prices Amid Lagging Sales

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Two weeks into a disappointing holiday season and two years after introducing a discount pricing policy, Sears, Roebuck & Company is cutting prices again, starting its after-Christmas clearance sale now.
Reacting to sales chilled by a possible recession and tensions in the Middle East, the nation's largest retailer is slashing prices on apparel and durable goods like washers and offering zero percent financing on some product lines including home electronics and furniture. 
 The latest Sears sales strategy follows by nearly two years the introduction by the company of a brand-name "everyday low price" strategy to compete with large discounters like K Mart and Wal-Mart. That strategy, of course, implied that there would be no sales.
Some analysts have said the move confused consumers and did nothing to address a more fundamental Sears problem: that it is a high-cost retailer that tries to sell too many product lines to too many kinds of customers.
"We are moving as quickly as we can to deal with conditions right now," Perry D. Chlan, a Sears spokesman, said about the pre-Christmas sale.
Some marketing consultants expressed doubt about the move, saying it would further cloud the Sears image and would not help in the retailer's struggle to regain customers.
"They are undermining their image for quality," said John Morton, senior vice president of the Total Research Corporation, a market research firm that analyzes consumer perceptions of brand names.
"Oh boy, it tends to communicate that they're in a lot of trouble," said Jack Trout, president of Trout & Ries, marketing consultants in Greenwich, Conn. "Every other retailer has a pencil and they can mark down stuff, too, if they have to."
Securities analysts, quickly revising their earnings estimates for Sears, project that 1990 profit may be off by as much as two-thirds from last year's $1.45 billion, or $4.12 a share. Sears said earlier this week that store sales dropped 1.6 percent in the four weeks ended Dec. 1. Other large retailers like Carter Hawley Hale, J. C. Penney and May Department Stores also reported sales declines in November.
At all its 850 stores, Sears is moving up its traditional after-Christmas sale on apparel to the period between now and Christmas Eve, reducing prices 20 percent to 40 percent.
On certain days, Sears will reduce from $5 to $500 the prices on brand-name merchandise like washers and driers, vacuum cleaners and microwave ovens. On Dec. 11-12, the company will offer zero percent financing on goods like home electronics, furniture and jewelry.
To encourage early shopping, Sears today will begin to offer 10 percent discount coupons to shoppers who buy between 8 and 10 A.M. as well as other "bonus bucks" coupons at other times.
The new sales strategy will be heavily promoted in print and on broadcasts with the slogan "After-Christmas prices just in time for Christmas." But Mr. Chlan, the Sears spokesman, said the company would not increase ad spending.
When Sears initiated discount pricing two years ago, it also switched from emphasizing its private-label brands like Craftsman hardware and Kenmore appliances to a "Brand Central" theme with national brand-name merchandise.
Some analysts say that for years Sears confused consumers by being a full-price merchandiser of unglamorous goods like refrigerators and children's clothes. Then it switched to being more of a discount merchandiser of prestige goods from Sony, RCA and General Electric.
Mr. Morton of Total Research said his consumer surveys indicated shoppers ranked Sears with Goodyear tires and Holiday Inn hotels. They did not associate Sears with names like Sony or Cuisinart. "Those images are just not compatible," he said.
Like other department stores, Sears was hurt by being a high-cost general merchandiser at a time when specialty retailers, like the Limited apparel stores and Circuit City consumer electronics stores, offered more variety at lower prices.
In addition, the modern shopping mall became another Sears competitor. With its range of specialty stores, it became a kind of extended department store.
Securities analysts, who have been slashing Sears earnings estimates throughout a weak retailing year, were quick yesterday to cut their projections further.
William N. Smith of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company reduced his estimate to $3 a share for the year, down from a November estimate of $3.25. He said profits could go as low as $2.80 if real estate profits from the Coldwell Banker unit did not materialize.

HEADLINE: Rates Fall After Move By the Fed

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Interest rates plunged yesterday after the Federal Reserve loosened credit by injecting funds into the banking system. The central bank's action came a few hours after the Government reported that unemployment in November had surged to a three-year high of 5.9 percent.
The yield on the Government's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue due August 2020, plunged to 8.17 percent in response. This was the lowest yield on the long bonds since mid-January of this year, and compared with the 8.32 percent of the day before and 8.39 percent of a week ago. The bonds, which are the most sensitive to inflation, were offered late in the day at at 106 10/32, up an extraordinary 1 21/32.
A few regional banks reduced their prime lending rates to 9.75 percent from 10 percent, a move that is expected to spread to other banks, although analysts are not sure when. The largest bank to act was the First Fidelity Bancorporation in Lawrenceville, N.J. [Page 37.] 
 Credit market analysts said they did not expect bigger banks to fall into line anytime soon. Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo, the world's largest bank, said, "The bigger banks are hurting too much to do anything that would reduce their profit margins, certainly not before they are to issue their year-end reports in a few weeks."
 
Effect on T-Bills
 Changes in Fed policy have their most immediate impact on 90-day Treasury bills, and by late in the day the discount rate on those bills had dropped 11 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.90 percent, its lowest level since early August 1988. The rate on six-month bills fell 12 basis points, to 6.79 percent, and the one-year bills lost 12 basis points, at 6.69 percent.
Because any economic developments that reduce the likelihood of a rise in interest rates and inflation benefit the fixed-income market, prices of all Treasury debt issues began to advance soon after the Government reported the unemployment data at 8:30 A.M. Three hours later the Fed added $1.5 billion of reserves to the banking system.
This caused the bedrock cost of credit, the funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans, to fall to 7 1/16 percent, from 7 1/4 percent at the time of the Fed's action. The funds had traded at 7 3/8 percent the day before. It was the third time the Fed had intervened to reduce this key interest rate since late October, when the funds traded between 7.75 percent and 8 percent.
"What provoked the Fed to act was the November numbers were far worse than they appear at first glance," Mr. Braverman of DKB Securities said. "A truer and sadder picture emerges when one looks at the household tally of jobless and not just the non-farm payroll numbers."
The payroll data showed that 267,000 non-farm jobs were lost in November, worse than the drop of 178,000 in October. These figures include those holding one or more part-time jobs, Mr. Braverman noted. The household tally put the loss of jobs last month at 405,000, almost double the 218,000 jobs lost in October.
 
 Doubt on Major Banks
 Although Mr. Braverman expects the Fed to ease credit further this month, probably after the central bank's policy-making Open Market Committee meets on Dec. 17, he said that he doubted that the major banks would cut their prime rates in the foreseeable future.
Eugene J. Sherman, senior vice president and chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, said: "There will only be a cut in the prime at the majors after the Fed cuts its discount rate, which is now 7 percent. Even then, most banks will be reluctant to cut their prime because so much of their consumer lending, including home equity loans and credit cards, are linked to their prime. And consumer lending is the brightest area of the banking business today."
Mr. Sherman noted that the Fed's discount rate to member banks was no longer the powerful tool it was a decade or so ago because banks have developed other sources of funds. Still, he pointed out, "the Fed has to make a bold statement to revive both consumer and business confidence, and cutting the discount rate would be a good way to do this."
William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, said: "The Fed usually prefers its discount rate to be at least 50 basis points below the funds rate. Regardless of what one may think of the discount rate in today's environment, the Street still thinks the Fed would like it that way. But it is doubtful a discount rate cut would affect the prime. The major banks have too much riding on their prime's linkage to consumer credit, including mortgages, to want to lower it."
 
Another Move Discounted
 As for the current consensus in the credit markets, Mr. Sullivan said that "the Street has already discounted another Fed easing in the next few days, largely because of the Fed's dramatic reversal in posture between Thursday and today."
Among domestic issues competitive with those of Japan and Germany, the yield on the Treasury's 8.5 percent long notes of November 2000 rose a full point, or $10 for each $1,000 of face value, to 103 8/32, while the yield dropped to 8.01 percent, from 8.23 percent a week ago. The yield on Japan's 10-year long bonds fell to 7.21 percent, from 7.43 percent a week ago, and the yield on Germany's comparable long bonds slipped to 8.77 percent from 8.82 percent.
The Treasury announced that its regular monthly auction of one-year bills would be held next Thursday. The amount offered was set at $11.75 billion.

HEADLINE: A Ford-VW Mini-Van for Europe

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company and Volkswagen A. G. of Germany are nearing agreement on a joint venture for European production of mini-vans. The vehicles' popularity is growing rapidly in Western Europe.
Volkswagen's supervisory board approved plans for the factory on Nov. 16, and the tentative agreement will go to Ford's board of directors next week. The British newspaper The Financial Times said the plant was expected to have a production capacity of 150,000 to 200,000 vehicles a year and could involve an investment of $2.5 billion to $3 billion. Ford and Volkswagen would not comment on those figures. 
 A leading choice for the plant's site is Portugal. Its Government has promised to provide financial support for the project, but such assistance would require the approval of the European Community.
 
 Earlier Latin Venture
 In 1987, Ford and Volkswagen merged their operations in Brazil and Argentina to form Autolatina, 51 percent of which is owned by Volkswagen and 49 percent by Ford.
About 82,000 mini-vans -- small vans that handle like cars -- are expected to be sold in Western Europe this year, or 18.8 percent more than were sold in 1989, according to DRI/ McGraw-Hill. The economics forecasting firm said annual sales could increase to 320,000 in 1995.
Ford predicts that the market could grow to 475,000 by 1998. It currently sells about 1,000 Aerostar mini-van imports a year in Europe.
Mini-vans were introduced in the United States by the Chrysler Corporation in 1983. This year industry sales in the United States will total about 800,000, predicted David B. Healy, a New York-based analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities, the British brokerage.
In a telephone interview from Wolfsburg, Germany, Ortwin Witzel, a Volkswagen spokesman, said: "We saw what happened in the United States. It gives you an idea of what could happen in Europe." Although Volkswagen does not currently sell a mini-van, it does sell a passenger version of its Transporter commercial van. Known as the Caravelle, it is being introduced in Europe.
 
 Production Limits
 Carol Thomas, an analyst at DRI/ McGraw-Hill, said current industry sales of mini-vans would probably be larger in Europe if more were available. She noted that there was limited production capacity in Western Europe, and several countries have quotas on Japanese imports, which hold 29 percent of the mini-van market.
Renault, the French company, has been the pioneer in mini-vans in Western Europe, and its Espace mini-van is the market leader with a 43 percent share. Factory expansions this year increased its production capability to 55,000 units a year.
Other companies are following suit. Earlier this year, Chrysler formed a joint venture with Steyr-Daimler-Puch Fahrzeugtechnik, an Austrian company, to build mini-vans in Austria. The plant is to go into operation next spring, with an initial annual output of 25,000 vehicles. That is eventually expected to rise to 125,000. Chrysler expects to sell 15,000 Voyager mini-vans imports in Europe this year, up from 8,800 last year.
 
 Peugeot-Fiat Venture
 France's Peugeot and Italy's Fiat have a joint venture and hope to begin mini-van production in their countries by late 1993. They expect to make 50,000 to 60,000 units a year by the mid-1990's.
The General Motors Corporation is considering plans for mini-van production in Europe, where it now has no mini-van sales, a spokesman said.
Ford has no joint ventures in European car manufacturing, although Nissan has agreed to produce a four-wheel-drive vehicle for Ford at the Japanese company's plant in Spain beginning in the spring of 1993.
Ford and Mazda, the Japanese company in which Ford has a 25 percent stake, had been talking about a European joint venture in compact cars. But in an interview in October, L. Lindsey Halstead, chairman of Ford of Europe, said, "We aren't at the stage where we've got any kind of firm proposal or even a glimmer of one." Analysts believe that Ford is not eager to help Mazda establish a manufacturing presence in Europe.
 
 VW Is Market Leader
 In the first 10 months of 1990 Ford of Europe sold 1.3 million cars in Western Europe and had 11.6 percent of the market, ranking fifth, just behind General Motors, whose share was 11.9 percent. The market leader was Volkswagen, with 15.2 percent, followed by Fiat and Peugeot.
Last year, Ford's European automotive operations had a net income of $1.19 billion on sales of $21.23 billion. They accounted for 37.5 percent of the company's worldwide automotive earnings and 25.6 percent of revenues.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Returning to Cash In Uncertain Time

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
For uneasy investors, it may make sense to lighten up on portfolio holdings before the end of the year, combining tax and market strategies.
"With the continued uncertainties over war and recession and job stability, a lot of people are interested in cash right now," said George E. L. Barbee, executive director of personal financial services for Price Waterhouse. "We're finding that mindset." And comments from market professionals show there is good reason for that view. 
 Edward A. Taber 3d, director of T. Rowe Price's taxable bond division, said at his firm's briefing this week on the 1991 investment and economic outlook, "The more risk you took, the less reward you got" in 1990, and that could continue early next year. So far this year money market funds have had a 6.5 percent return, he noted, while high-yield funds have lost 11.5 percent, and long Treasury funds have returned only 1.3 percent.
Paul W. Boltz, the firm's economist, saw a mild recession, beginning in this quarter and lasting two or three quarters, with a slight drop in short-term interest rates. He expects the Fed to tighten credit as recovery sets in, but he sees an outside possibility of a severe recession, should war break out in the Persian Gulf or a major bank fail.
John H. Laporte, president of Price's New Horizons and New America Growth funds, concurred, saying, "We think the bear market has farther to go." But he added, "The stock market as usual will begin to recover well before the economy." He added that small growth stocks, which have been battered this year, could lead a cyclical recovery in 1991, so he advised investors to focus on growth companies with high financial returns and assured earnings growth.
Investors should inventory their portfolios,determining paper losses and gains, and identify candidates for sale, Mr. Barbee said, and then decide whether to move into a cash position like a Treasury bill or C.D. or to reinvest in the market.
If a portfolio has both losses and gains, an investor can use the losses to offset the gains, so that cash is raised without incurring tax liability on the gains. Also, net capital losses of up to $3,000 can offset ordinary income, so from a tax standpoint, he said, "it makes sense to admit to yourself you were wrong and sell."
"It is paramount to run some calculations before the end of the year and see if there is an A.M.T. situation," Mr. Barbee added, referring to the alternative minimum tax, which is intended to make sure that no taxpayer with substantial income avoids taxation.
The rate is 21 percent, compared with a normal 28 percent or 33 percent, but a number of tax breaks that are allowed in regular tax calculations are taken away. As a result, those who are snared have a larger taxable income and fewer deductions than they would have under regular rules.
The reason to see if there is an alternative tax liability is that the three things most likely to subject a taxpayer to it are commonly considered inyear-end planning. They are: sizable state and local taxes, the exercise of incentive stock options and the donation of appreciated property to charity. The timing of these items is often the opposite for regular taxpayers and those subject to the alternative tax.
For regular taxpayers, appreciated securities, for example, may be deducted at market value -- and making such a contribution at year-end can be an effective way to help a favorite charity and lower one's tax bill. But for those subject to the alternative tax, the deduction is based on the original cost. Therefore, if a taxpayer were to be subject to the alternative tax this year but not next year, it might be a good idea to delay the donation until January.
As for gifts of valuable artwork, the new tax law provides a one-year window in 1991 in which donors will not be subject to the alternative tax.
Sam Radin, president of the National Madison Group, which advises lawyers on tax and estate planning, noted that for regular high-income taxpayers it might be advisable to wait until early January to fulfill a 1990 charitable pledge because the deduction will be worth more in 1991, when it will be taxed at 31.93 percent after the phase-out of all exemptions, compared with 28 percent in 1990.
"The value of a $100,000 charitable deduction in 1990 is $28,000; in 1991 it is $31,930," he said. The difference "represents a 14.04 percent net after-tax return -- with no risk."
 
'What If' Tax Strategies
 Probably the fastest way to try "what if" tax strategies is to use income tax software in a personal computer. Turbo Tax from Chip Soft, which has been the best-selling program for I.B.M. and compatible machines in recent years, has also introduced a Macintosh version this year.
Headstart versions are now on retail shelves. A big plus for this program is that it has 1991 tax rates as well as 1990's, so that in the planning mode users can see what the effect would be of recognizing income or taking a deduction this year versus next year, for example.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Bed-Stuy, Do or Die. For Real. 911.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
The Bedford-Stuyvesant Volunteer Ambulance Corps officially began on Feb. 23, 1989. Within 24 hours, its president, James Robinson, and a colleague spotted a fire in an abandoned building and saved 10 people. Within 48 hours, volunteers had delivered a baby.
The pace never slackened. Drug-related violence devastates this poor Brooklyn neighborhood. People living here are particularly susceptible to hypertension and resultant heart problems. Medical care, at best, is patchy. 
 "We're like an oasis in the middle of the desert," said Mr. Robinson, a gruff, bearlike man known to one and all as Rocky. Like all volunteers, Mr. Robinson, 50 years old, wears a beret decorated with the corps patch of red, green and black, the colors of black liberation.
He tells astonishing stories in the tone of a jaded veteran chronicling a ruthless war. Once he intercepted a man running wildly down a sidewalk. His carotid artery had been cut and blood spurted out. Mr. Robinson applied pressure and the bleeding abated.
Just then, the man who had cut him walked brazenly past. The wounded man jerked away and charged the attacker. He beat him soundly, then turned to Mr. Robinson. "Please finish saving me," he said.
Mr. Robinson thinks the man lived only because his blood pressure remained strong because he was so agitated and high on crack. "Me and you would have been dead," he said.
In a city where services have so deteriorated, citizens feel compelled to take matters into their own hands. Volunteer ambulance corps are a case in point: there are now 32. The idea is to augment, not replace Emergency Medical Services.
 The Bedford-Stuy vesant effort began because the need was so immense. Re search by Mr. Robin son and Joe Perez, vice president and co-founder of the corps, had shown that three-quarters of all emergency calls for medi cal assistance in New York City came from predominantly minority communities.
 But an overburdened Emergency Medical Services was taking as long as 15 minutes to arrive. The corps has cut its own response time to an average of four minutes. It answers an average of 350 calls a month. Mr. Robinson, who like Mr. Perez is an E.M.S. supervisor, said a salutary spinoff is that city ambulances, sparked by competition, now arrive almost as fast.
In a community where unemployment is vast, another benefit is that scores have been trained as emergency medical technicians and found jobs with the E.M.S. or private ambulance services. This has begun to solve a problem that began in the mid-1970's when E.M.S. made service in a volunteer corps a hiring requirement. There were none in minority neighborhoods until the Bedford-Stuyvesant corps.
Mr. Robinson recoiled at the inequity, but knew the time for self-help had come. "We should stop blaming the other guy for our problems," he said. "A lot are self-inflicted."
An uphill fight. The corps began in an abandoned apartment building without electricity or running water. It didn't even have an ambulance. Members listened to the police, fire and E.M.S. radio bands and raced to respond first in a car carrying first-aid equipment.
The original ambulance was a gift from the Williamsburg Volunteer Ambulance Corps, which also sold the corps a 55-foot trailer for $2,500. The new corps placed it on an abandoned lot and made it their headquarters. On the lot were two shacks from which crack was sold. Gunfire sometimes shattered the trailer's windows.
The crack dealers and their lines of clients have left. A local businessman is paying to renovate the trailer. It will have an enormous sign on top: "The Pride of Bed-Stuy." Three shiny ambulances are parked beside it.
The group established a corps for youths between 12 and 17. They learn basic medical skills and are given a chance to help heal the ravages of drugs and violence that are decimating a generation.
"The average kid wants to be a hero," Mr. Robinson declared. "We teach them how to be a hero and get a job at the same time."
Money for the corps has always been hand-to-mouth. A basketball team, the Shockers, plays benefit games. There have been bake sales and dances. A New Jersey businessman donated $15,000. A private ambulance company came up with a $1,500 insurance payment in February, when the end appeared near.
Foundations have pitched in, particularly the Robin Hood Foundation, headed by Rolling Stone's publisher, Jann S. Wenner. Next Tuesday, he will present Mr. Robinson and Mr. Perez with a check for $25,000.
Mr. Robinson, in turn, plans to donate an ambulance to a new corps forming in Brownsville, East New York and Flatbush.
"We're going to help them like somebody helped us," he said. "That's what it's all about, right?"

LENGTH: 1039 words

HEADLINE: In California, Era of Plenty Fades to Fear

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Standing in the unemployment line today, a cross section of Americans, from a beautician to a film editor to a sales manager to a corporate vice president, voiced a shared sense of insecurity about the future as jobs disappear and companies close.
They said their hunt for work had taken on new urgency as they watched the economy worsen and opportunites dry up. Gathered at an unemployment office in West Los Angeles, they listened with a very personal concern to the news that the unemployment rate in California had climbed today to its highest point in four years. 
 "The hardest thing is to see how panicked people are," said Bill Williams, a part owner of a small marketing company in Huntington Beach that recently went out of business. "Right now, I don't have a dime. I'm worried about buying things like sugar. I'm that close to losing my home. Now is when the nerve systems are really going."
 
A New Line of Work
 Mr. Williams, a 43-year-old man in a worn leather jacket, set down his briefcase and held out his hands, roughened by his new line of work.
"After being an executive," he said, "I'm cleaning toilets now. See my hands? I'm glad to have a $5 job."
Grace Clayton, a 56-year-old hairstylist and home-health aide from Santa Monica, said she had lost clients during a nine-month illness and was finding now that "the competition has gotten so much greater and I just wasn't able to bounce back."
"People are cutting back," she said. "They aren't spending money anymore. They are doing their own hair."
In California, a state that had come to believe in its own economic myth of boundless growth, unemployment jumped last month to 6.7 percent, from 6 percent in October and 5.1 percent in November 1989. California was among the states with the biggest jumps in unemployment.
The aerospace and military contracting industries have already laid off thousands of workers in Southern California, reflecting cuts in Pentagon spending. The real estate market has cooled off dramatically, eliminating construction jobs.
Tax revenue for the first four months of this fiscal year, which began July 1, fell $400 million below previous estimates, contributing to predictions of a $4.3 billion imbalance in the state's budget next year unless strong measures are taken.
"In the longer term, California will continue to outpace the nation" in economic growth, Robert K. Arnold, chairman of the Center for Continuing Study of the California Economy, a research organization in Palo Alto, said in a telephone interview. "But as far as short-term cyclical economic fluctuations, California flows with the national economy. As goes the nation, so goes California when it comes to recession."
 
'It's a Depression'
 That analysis was echoed today by a corporate vice president in bow tie and tasseled loafers who sat at the unemployment office filling out an application for the first time.
"Recession -- I think it's a depression," snapped the executive, who spoke on condition that his name not be used because he was actively searching for a new corporate job. "The R word: What a joke that is."
He said California's economy had been in a slump for months and that the entire region had been affected by layoffs in the aerospace industry.
"I'm working with a head hunter now and he tells me that the hunting process is taking two to three times longer than it used to," he said.
"I think people are scared here, actually," he went on. "I'm very highly thought of in my field. Normally I wouldn't even bother applying for unemployment insurance. But I need every penny I can get now."
The unemployment line is not new for John Ganem, a 30-year-old assistant film editor in Hollywood.
"Lately I've been working on some really big movies," he said. "I just got done working on 'Godfather.' "In my line of work, it's usual to come down here between jobs."
But he said he was beginning to feel a new uneasiness. He said some friends were finding that the gaps between jobs were growing.
"There is a pretty prevailing air of uncertainty, and I'm not so content to live on my savings now," he said. "I'm not so sure about the future, and that's why I'm much more actively pursuing my next film."
That feeling of uncertainty was also affecting Mary Cibic, 32, who recently lost her job as an account sales manager for an international video company. It was only a few years ago that the concern expanded from Chicago to Los Angeles to take advantage of the growing economy. Now, because of competition from a Taiwanese firm, she said, her company was cutting back again. "Everyone's going now," she said, "the sales manager, the vice president, the president." 
When she looks for work, she said, "it's the old story: either you're overqualified or you're underqualified."
"There's so much competition out there," she said.
What might seem a truism was a deeply felt statement for her, as for the other people waiting on the unemployment line: "I'd rather be working. I love to work. Being unemployed is not advantageous to me."
She said her unemployment benefit of $200 a week was not enough to cover her monthly rent and car payments. The average weekly benefit in California is $120, lasting an average of 14 weeks.
 
Similar Mood in San Francisco
 A similar unsettled mood was evident today in an unemployment line in the Mission District of San Francisco, where Esther Rossen said she was going to have to depend on her savings to support herself and her child. Mrs. Rossen, who recently lost her job when the art gallery where she was working closed, said, "It's going to make it very tough."
Manuel Lago, a 48-year-old immigrant from Cuba, has faced the problem from the opposite perspective. As the manager of a small restaurant that closed three weeks ago, it was part of his job to interview applicants.
"As a manager I saw so many resumes, it was almost pitiful," he said. "I saw so many people who were qualified, who could have done a good job, but I had no openings."
He said the unemployment line set the tone of the holiday spirit of 1990. "Christmas is a headache," he said. "You have to put up the decorations whether you're in the mood or not."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Relief, Tears and Hope At the Hostages' Hotel

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 7

 BODY:
First the armed guards disappeared from the lobby. Then the plainclothes secret policemen abandoned their checkpoint in front of the elevators.
Baghdad's hostage hotel, the transit camp for the human shields President Saddam Hussein sought to place between his military-industrial installations and the threat from America's strategic bomber force, was suddenly transformed this week into an emancipation hall after Mr. Hussein announced on Thursday that he had decided to set all foreign hostages free. 
 For some of those gathered at the Melia Al-Mansour Hotel, joy over their anticipated freedom was tempered with doubts about the Iraqi Government's promises.
"No Iraqi official has said anything to me," said Charles P. Keegan, 57 years old, an American who was the chief investment strategist for the Kuwait Investment Company when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. "I'm very vague on just exactly how this is going to unfold," he added.
For months, Iraqi security forces had used the hotel, a well-known downtown landmark, as the way station where some hostages got a few days' access to diplomats from their home country before heading to detention at Iraqi military and economic installations.
 
Slightly Surreal Scene
 The hostages were confined to the hulking, brown concrete structure that overlooks the Tigris River. Foreign reporters were barred from entering.
But this week, with the arrival of dozens of hostages' relatives invited by the Iraqi Government for holiday visits, and then Mr. Hussein's surprise announcement on Thursday, the hotel became a scene of poignant relief, tearful reunions and the expectation that a long and frightening captivity was coming to an end.
In this slightly surreal scene, where journalists freely circulated today with hostages and relatives in the lounges and restaurants and corridors of the hotel, there was still an eerie lack of clarity about the status of those who had been held, their schedule for leaving and the intentions of the faceless security officials who were controlling their lives.
This morning, Joseph C. Wilson 4th, deputy chief of mission at the United States Embassy in Baghdad, met with Mr. Keegan and a large group of hostages to tell them that the embassy was seeking to bring a charter flight into Baghdad to evacuate them as soon as possible.
 
Looking Back at the Ordeal
 In this pause before freedom, and with the anticipation that they will soon return to careers and the normal rhythms of life, many of the hostages spoke about their ordeal.
Mr. Keegan, who is from Des Moines and was reunited with one of his daughters and a son-in-law on Thursday, was arrested on Sept. 19 at the apartment complex where he lived in Kuwait and was held for more than two months near a munitions plant 60 miles southwest of Baghdad.
"At first, I thought about hiding in the air-conditioning ducts like some people," he said. "Ironically, it was a relief to be picked up because while no Iraqi ever threatened me, I would get warning calls from friends in the middle of the night -- that was the most frightening thing, the anticipation of what it might be to be caught."
"I had my bag packed by the door, ready to go" when the Iraqi military police came on Sept. 19, he said.
 
'We Waited Too Long'
 Mr. Keegan also said that he and several other Americans had laid careful plans to escape Kuwait by driving a four-wheel-drive vehicle through the desert to Saudi Arabia with the help of a Bedouin guide. But that the plan faltered as the occupation forces clamped down on escape routes.
"I think the biggest thing is that we waited too long," said Mr. Keegan, who said that upon reflection, the psychology of the unfolding crisis led to procrastination and misjudgments.
"Your mentality is not prepared to cope," he said, "you have a myopic view of your circumstances, and your decision making is clouded by personal wishes." He said he remembered thinking that he would not escape in one car because it was a company vehicle. "That seems ridiculous now in hindsight," he said.
Mr. Keegan related the tale of a Kuwaiti friend who said he was tortured by Iraqi officials who found a pistol in his possession. The man showed Mr. Keegan burn marks on the soles of his feet, which he said were received from Iraqi interrogators who also pushed his head into a toilet and placed a gun to his head and pulled the trigger while the chamber was empty to frighten the man into disclosing whether he was a member of the Kuwaiti resistance.
 
Betrayed by Manager
 Mr. Keegan's whereabouts in Kuwait were betrayed by a Palestinian manager of the apartment complex, but he said he harbored no resentment because he was sure the manager had been threatened with death.
"When the Iraqis came through, they scared the living daylights out of them," he said, "I would not have expected them to lie for me -- I would have done the same thing."
Passing by Mr. Keegan's lunch table today was Hamid el-Hiloudi, 46, an air-conditioning contractor from Chatanooga, Tenn., who took refuge in the American Embassy in Kuwait on Aug. 18 and remained there until Nov. 21.
Mr. Hiloudi, who was born in Morocco, became the "Mr. Green Jeans" of the embassy compound when he decided in October to plant a large vegetable garden to help sustain the 6 or 7 diplomats and 19 others who remain there. The title was bestowed on him by Barbara Bodine, the embassy's deputy chief of mission.
 
Food for About 60 Days
 He estimated that when he left the embassy had enough food to sustain its refugee population for about 60 days, with about 3,000 cans of tuna fish and mackerel remaining, along with supplies of rice and sugar.
In November, Ambassador Nathaniel Howell was forced to cut back his communications to Washington to three scheduled sessions a week, Mr. Hiloudi said, to conserve fuel that powers the embassy's satellite communications link.
Mr. Hiloudi spoke with pride about his association with the effort to keep the American flag flying over the compound and said he now regretted leaving his comrades in November, when Iraqi officials promised him a safe exit because of his Arab origins, then reneged.
"With all the beans and peas I planted, they'll make it," he said, before American officials announced in Washington that Ambassdor Howell, his staff and the refugees there would abandon the mission.
 
'Created Our Own World'
 Joining Mr. Keegan at the lunch table today were Stuart Williams, 58; his wife, Charlene Coutre, and Mr. Williams's daughter, Jennifer, 21, a student at Southern Methodist University in Dallas.
Mr. Williams and his wife, who have a home in New York, took an assignment last summer to manage Gulf Bank's operations in Kuwait. They were taken captive when the Iraqis invaded and held along with dozens of British nationals at the Mina Al-Ahmadi oil refinery just south of Kuwait City.
"We created our own world where we shut out what was around us," Mr. Williams said. When Iraq announced in September that it would allow women and children to leave, Mrs. Coutre refused to abandon her husband. She was the only woman among the 64 hostages brought by bus from the Kuwait refinery two weeks ago.
Mr. Williams's daughter said she traveled to Baghdad this week over the objection of Bush Administration officials, thinking she had a slim chance to help free her father by making a special appeal to Mr. Hussein during the holiday season. She was surprised by the sudden turn of events that freed him.
"I hated waiting, being passive," she said. "My life had come to a stop."
Mr. Williams said: "Men are brought up learning how to be in control, how to manage things, but in this situation I was totally helpless and I had to look to the women in my family to bail me out. When they did, it felt marvelous."

HEADLINE: TRADE TALKS END WITHOUT MENDING RIFT OVER FARMING

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 7

 BODY:
A four-year round of talks to establish new rules for world trade broke off in disarray today as the United States and the European Community remained deadlocked over the issue of reducing subsidies to farmers.
Trade ministers had set today as a deadline to reach an agreement to liberalize rules governing $4 trillion in annual world trade. The goal was an accord that could increase economic growth and living standards worldwide by removing government rules that restrict trade not only in agriculture but also in a wide range of manufactured goods, financial services and technological expertise. 
 But instead, after marathon negotiations throughout the week, the trade officials gave up, disbanded and suspended the talks after failing to overcome their impasse on farm trade.
 
Some Talk of Resuming
 Trade officials tried to put the best face on the failure. The chairman of the 107-nation talks, Hector Gros Espiell, the Foreign Minister of Uruguay, expressed confidence that the ministers, after additional reflection and consultation with the heads of their governments, would resume the talks in Geneva in a month or two.
John Crosbie, the Trade Minister of Canada, said, "It's a failure that leaves a ray of hope."
But many officials said that unless the wide gulf between the American and European positions on farm trade could be bridged, the breakup in Brussels might signal that the talks had collapsed permanently, ending the effort to set international trading rules for the 21st century.
American officials say the lack of success in the talks could have significant effects on American consumers, farmers, workers and businesses. For example, with many countries subsidizing exports of their grain, a failure to reduce agricultural protection could make it harder for American farmers to export wheat. For American pharmaceutical companies, the deadlock means they will have to wait longer to get third world nations to agree to respect their patents.
For American consumers, a trade agreement could mean lower prices for many goods, from peanuts to pants, since an agreement could result in lower tariffs and import barriers. At the same time, an agreement might bode ill for the jobs of American textile workers because an accord would probably reduce quotas on clothing imports from the developing world.
Conversely, many governments in the third world hope for an agreement because it would probably mean new markets and more jobs for their textile industries.
'We Have Failed'
"We have tried to improve the economic situation in the world, but we have failed," Helmut Haussmann, the Economics Minister of Germany, said today.
The round of talks, known as the Uruguay Round because it began in that country in 1986, aims to set liberal new rules in 15 broad areas of trade, including farming, patents, financial services, telecommunications and textiles.
This week's talks were dominated by a bitter clash between the European Community on one side, and the United States, Canada, Argentina and more than a dozen other nations on the other. The community was reluctant to move nearly as far as the other side wanted in slashing farm subsidies. The Europeans, who pay the most generous farm subsidies, said the opposing side was asking for cuts that were too deep to be politically acceptable in Europe. The French, in particular, resisted big reductions in payments to farmers.
Business representatives attending the talks were alarmed by the suspension of the negotiations.
 
A Businessman Reacts
 "The astounding failure of political will has not only risked throwing away the progress made during four years of hard work, it has placed a major question mark over the future of the existing multilateral trading system," said Peter Wallenberg, a Swedish businessman who heads the Paris-based International Chamber of Commerce.
Trade officials fear that without an agreement trade wars could erupt as nations erect barriers to protect domestic businesses and farmers from imported goods. Such beggar-thy-neighbor policies are economically counterproductive, eventually hurting industries, farmers and consumers throughout the world, trade officials say.
Many officials predicted that without an overall agreement there would be more and more bilateral and regional pacts in which the most powerful countries or blocs, like the United States or the European Community, would have the upper hand.
After two nights of attending negotiations and meetings until 4 A.M., Carla A. Hills, the chief American trade negotiator, was dismayed today. Nonetheless, she said it was better to have the talks suspended than to accept an agreement that would make only minor changes in the international trading system.
 
Disappointment and Optimism
 "I am very disappointed, but I think it's much more important that we stand on our position of opening markets," she said. Nonetheless, she was optimistic that all sides would make the necessary compromises to reach an agreement because they recognize the importance of liberalizing and modernizing world trade rules.
Agriculture has become the key to success of the Uruguay Round because the United States and a group of 14 food-exporting countries, known as the Cairns Group, have said they would not accept an overall pact unless it included large cuts in farm protection.
Washington and the Cairns Group -- which includes Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia -- say paying subsidies to farmers results in overproduction that drives down prices, while paying special subsidies to promote food exports robs the most efficient producers of markets.
 
Payments to Farmers
 Agricultural subsidies come in many shapes and sizes, and one of the most common is government payments to farmers when the price of their crop falls below a certain target price.
The United States and the Cairns Group, named for the Australian town where the group was formed in 1986, proposed a 75 percent cut in such internal supports over 10 years and a 90 percent cut in export subsidies. In contrast, the European Community proposed reducing internal supports by 30 percent over 10 years retroactive to 1986, when the community made some subsidy cuts. At the same time, the community refused to make specific commitments on reducing export subsidies and barriers to farm imports.
Negotiators said that on Thursday morning it seemed that a longstanding logjam in the talks had finally become unblocked, when the European Community indicated it would offer to reduce export subsidies and import barriers. The talks became deadlocked again late Thursday night, however, when American and Cairns Group officials concluded that the community's offer was too imprecise and inconsequential.
"There was no official offer from them," Mrs. Hills said. "They don't have anything on the table."
To push the talks along, the Agriculture Minister of Sweden, Mats Hellstrom, who led the agricultural negotiations, had offered a compromise proposal for discussion, suggesting 30 percent cuts in internal supports, import barriers and export subsidies from 1991 to 1996. Although Britain and the Netherlands found the proposal interesting and worth discussion, the community negotiators, bowing to France's insistence, refused to negotiate on the basis of the Hellstrom proposal.
 
The Europeans' Defense
 Community officials denied that they were inflexible, saying they had agreed, for example, not to raise soybean tariffs as part of a much-criticized proposal under which they would increase import barriers in some areas as they lowered them in others.
Speaking about Washington and some of its allies, Raymond MacSharry, the community's Agriculture Commissioner, said, "Unless and until they reduce the expectations they have had for quite some time now, there will not be an agreement on agriculture."
In the view of some American officials, the key to breaking the deadlock is to get agreement to concessions from President Francois Mitterrand of France, the community's leading food-exporting nation. That is not expected to be easy, however, because French farmers, who staged several large demonstrations last summer, are already suffering severely from drought and falling prices for beef and lamb. The French Government, which barely survived a no-confidence motion last month, is not eager to offend the two million French farmers.
 
Consultations Planned
 Under the terms of the meeting's suspension, Arthur Dunkel, the Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based organization sponsoring the talks, is to consult with leaders from different nations over the next few weeks. If he concludes that they will be flexible enough to make it possible to reach a final agreement, then he can summon back the negotiators.
One GATT official suggested that Mr. Dunkel might reconvene the negotiations in late February. American negotiators must submit a fiinished agreement to Congress by March 1 if Congress is to give it "fast track" consideration. This means Congress would have to vote the whole agreement up or down, rather than examine it line by line, which might allow the lawmakers to pick apart a carefully balanced agreement.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER, 8, 1990

 BODY:

International
A four-year round of trade talks broke off in disarray as the U.S. and the European Community remained deadlocked over the issue of reducing subsidies to farmers. [Page 1.]
Ford and Volkswagen are nearing agreement on a joint venture for European production of mini-vans. [33.]
 
The Economy
 In a report of almost unrelieved gloom, the Government said the economy lost more than a quarter of a million jobs in November. The unemployment rate climbed 0.2 points, to 5.9 percent, the highest since October 1987. The number of factory jobs skidded by 200,000, far more than expected. [1.]
 The New York Stock Exchange reported that the earnings of a broad sector of its membership collapsed in the first nine months of this year, falling by 98 percent. [34.]
Banking industry profits were down 20 to 25 percent from the second quarter, the F.D.I.C. chairman said. [34.]
A few regional banks cut their prime rates to 9.75 percent from 10 percent, a move expected to spread eventually. [37.]
Growth in consumer credit slowed to a seasonally adjusted $1.47 billion in October, the Federal Reserve reported. [37.]
The Senate Ethics Committee had a change of pace when Arizona's Governor, Rose Mofford, testified for DeConcini. [14.]
Companies
Sears is cutting prices again, starting its after-Christmas clearance sale now. [33.]
Meshulam Riklis is stepping down from all executive positions with E-II. McCrory, an E-II subsidiary, is to be sold to another company controlled by Riklis. [33.]
Citicorp expects to cut at least 4,250 employees from its corporate lending business in North America, Europe and Japan. [33.]
NCR took its case for independence to Washington, but Wall Street professionals said such efforts would be unlikely to help it ward off A.T.& T. [35.]
The Dec. 17 issue of Channels magazine will be its last, making it the latest victim of changes at Act III Publishing. [35.]
A judge rejected a request by Eastern Air Lines to keep under seal a document that an Eastern lawyer calls damaging. [35.]
At the request of The Daily News, a Federal-New York City task force is investigating bombings and possible arson. [28.]
LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton said it had agreed to pay $618 million to acquire Pommery and Lanson from BSN. [35.]
The invasion of Manhattan by two huge toy chains is, to some, a mournful sign of the times. [27.]
 
Markets
Interest rates plunged after the Fed loosened credit by injecting funds into the banking system. [33.]
The stock market focused on a worsening economy, and the Dow fell 12.38, to 2,590.10. The week's gain was 30.45. [36.]
Crude oil rose 18 cents, to $26.58 a barrel. [39.] Energy Secretary Watkins said a gulf war would not significantly disrupt the flow of oil. [39.]
The dollar registered a sharp decline. [42.] Precious metals continued their slide. [42.]
 
Today's Columns
For uneasy investors, it may make sense to lighten up on portfolio holdings before the end of the year. Your Money. [34.]
A patent on a fountain that makes "real" rainbows has been granted to a landscape designer and a meteorologist. Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: Buenos Aires Journal;
An Army Revolt One Day, an Invasion the Next

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7

 BODY:
On the morning this week that President Bush awoke in Buenos Aires, a local newspaper carried a front-page cartoon showing a crowd of tall men in dark glasses surrounding an almost invisible Mr. Bush, protecting him from the slight figure of President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina.
The dialogue went this way: "Mr. President, there's a guy here who says he's the President of the natives. Has a Latin aspect, is between five and six feet tall and weighs about 130 pounds." 
 "Does he have sideburns?"
"Yes, sir."
"What's his name?"
"He says it's Menem."
"Let him through."
For a people who had experienced the rise and collapse of an army rebellion on their way to and from work on Monday, Mr. Bush's visit on Wednesday sometimes gave them the sensation that they had subsequently fallen victim to foreign occupation.
 
Menem's New Book Released
 But if Argentine journalists and spectators were a bit put off at being ordered around in English by hundreds of big, blunt-spoken men, Mr. Menem and his aides appeared to think the payoff in backing for their embattled policies and Government had been more than worth it.
Mr. Menem, in fact, in the glow of the aftermath, today introduced his new book, "The United States, Argentina and Carlos Menem." It details how he has brought about a 180-degree shift in Argentine relations with the United States in his 17 months in the presidency.
In countries of the region where a warm embrace and endorsement from President Bush were less crucial than they were for Mr. Menem at this particular time, the sheer might and seeming arrogance of the traveling American Presidency made the visit a mixed blessing. Mr. Bush's five-nation South American tour continued today in Venezuela.
Hundreds of advance people showed up in each country several weeks ahead of Mr. Bush. Giant C-5 Galaxy aircraft landed and unloaded fleets of sophisticated helicopters and unknown quantities of marines. And hundreds of telephone lines were installed in each country, including one for each of the more than 200 White House correspondents.
 
Great Mobile Phone Service
 This meant, for example, that you could call a direct number at the Hotel Sheraton in Buenos Aires and hear an American voice respond "Buenos Aires White House," explain that he was manning the A.T.&T. telephone system brought intact from the United States and ask if you were calling "from Stateside."
Cultural and linguistic sensitivities were reflected in many of the reactions that people expressed to all of this.
"I wouldn't say there was a reaction against Bush, but the extent of the security certainly drew people's attention," said Danilo Arbilla, a newspaper editor in Uruguay, where Mr. Bush stopped the day before he came to Buenos Aires.
Mr. Arbilla said irritated members of the Uruguayan Parliament had refused instructions from the White House security people to wear the lapel insignia issued to the legislators for the Mr. Bush's speech. And he said the security people had ordered President Luis Alberto Lacalle's press secretary, who has an office next to his, to leave the area before Mr. Bush arrived. She resisted and was waiting at the door when the meeting began.
 
English Is Irritating
 Further, said Mr. Arbilla, the efforts of the multi-lingual Mr. Lacalle to accommodate the visiting White House press corps by answering their questions in English drew criticism from some listeners in Uruguay, who thought he should have responded in Spanish and left the English to the interpreter.
"It wasn't so much the security that bothered people here as the White House press corps," said Maria Elena Ipinza, who works with the foreign press in Chile, where Mr. Bush stopped after leaving Buenos Aires on Thursday morning.
She said that while President Patricio Aylwin of Chile, who stands six feet tall, is up in Mr. Bush's stratosphere enough so as not to be lost standing beside him at a news conference, the White House press corps dismayed Chileans by asking all their questions of Mr. Bush and by focusing them on the expected release of hostages in Iraq and Kuwait.
To top that, she added, none of the White House press corps attended a news conference offered by Alejandro Foxley, Chile's English-speaking Finance Minister and the Government's point man in the dynamic, free-market economy that Mr. Bush himself said had made Chile "the center of economic activity in Latin America," even if it is "at the end of the world."
 
Visited Despite Rebellion
 Aides to Mr. Menem, in their morning-after assessment of the visit to Argentina, were convinced that nothing but good had come with it because of the strong backing and praise Mr. Bush gave to the Argentine leader for his efforts to rebuild the economy along free-market lines and his success at controlling the rebellion by some 300 army dissidents.
They said that while Mr. Bush gave a "slap" to the Brazilians on his first stop for their failure to reach agreement with foreign creditors, there had been no similar "scolding" here -- maybe because of the trauma Mr. Menem had undergone with the rebellion.
They were especially grateful for the fact that Mr. Bush had declared his willingness to come even while the bullets were still flying here.
Neverthless, Pagina 12, the irreverent but respected newspaper that carried the cartoon about the Bush security, gave its own opinion in a banner headline on his departure: "Alone at Last."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush with President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela yesterday after arriving in Caracas. Mr. Bush is there for a two-day official visit, which is the last stop on his South American trip. (Agence France-Presse)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1626 words

HEADLINE: JOBLESSNESS RISES TO A 3-YEAR HIGH; FED EASES CREDIT

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
In a report of almost unrelieved gloom, the Government said today that the economy lost more than a quarter of a million jobs in November. The unemployment rate climbed two-tenths of a point to 5.9 percent, the highest since October 1987.
The number of goods-producing jobs skidded by 255,000, far more than expected, with downturns in every durable-goods industry. Factory jobs accounted for 200,000 of the loss. Almost 800,000 factory jobs have disappeared since the beginning of 1989. 
 Service employment, which has been sputtering after a long expansion, fell by 12,000 last month.
 
Action on Interest Rates
 Today's report, which seemed to remove any remaining doubt among most economists that the economy had slipped into recession, clearly worried the Federal Reserve Board. Shortly after the report was released, the Federal Reserve moved for the second time this week to make money more available. To stimulate the economy, it injected money into the banking system, pushing down by about a quarter point the rate banks charge each other for temporary loans. [Page 33.]
A few regional banks cut their prime lending rates to 9 3/4 percent from 10 percent, the first drop in nearly a year. But credit market analysts said large banks would be reluctant to follow the lead because it would reduce their depressed profit margins. The analysts suggested that the Federal Reserve would have to loosen credit further before most borrowers would see lower interest rates on home mortgages and home equity and other consumer and business loans. [Page 37.]
 
'Unambiguous' Figures
 The unemployment figures released today are "unambiguous," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. "Now the question is how are you going to get out" of the downturn.
Today's figures painted "a dismal picture" of the job market, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood, said during her monthly appearance before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. She said they warranted "an extremely pessimistic view" of business activity in general.
The committee chairman, Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, asked Dr. Norwood whether the economy was now in a stage of "cumulative unwinding," using the phrase Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has adopted as his shorthand definition of recession. She replied, "We are certainly beginning to see signs of that."
As a rule of thumb, the economy is considered to be in recession after two consecutive quarters of declining national output of goods and services, adjusted for inflation. But the economists who make the official determination scrutinize a downturn for severity and breadth as well as duration. A recession could, in fact, be confined to a single quarter.
The President's chief economic adviser, Michael J. Boskin, was clearly disappointed with the figures reported today. "While the modest rise in the unemployment rate was expected because of the recent sluggishness in the economy," he said, "the reduction in employment, especially including the October revision, was larger than expected."
He acknowledged that the economy was now almost certain to contract during the fourth quarter but said "it's too early to tell" whether it would continue to decline into the new year.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat who is the House majority leader, issued a statement asserting that since the middle of the year the "army of the unemployed has swollen by nearly a million unwilling enlistees." He urged President Bush to shift his attention to dealing with "the recession which is now surely upon us."
Recessions can have major political consequences, affecting voters nationwide. The Federal budget deficit has already worsened because of the economy as well as the rising cost of bailing out savings and loan institutions, and a continuing economic downturn would cut tax receipts and increase Government expenses in relief efforts like unemployment compensation.
 
Grim Nature of Report
 There was virtually nothing to soften the grim nature of the first comprehensive report on the November economy apart from a new increase in jobs in health services and a small gain in oil drilling jobs, In addition, the call-up of military reserves may have exaggerated the severity of job losses.
One particularly sobering note was the fact that practically all the people added to the ranks of the unemployed were dismissed or laid off rather than people who quit their last jobs or who were entering or re-entering the labor force.
The number of jobs, as determined by the Labor Department's survey of business payrolls, tumbled 267,000, a fall that was more than triple many private estimates. Furthermore, the decline for October was revised to show a loss of 178,000 jobs instead of the 68,000 initially reported.
This was the worst two-month decline since late 1982, when the latest declared recession was ending.
The automobile industry, which had announced production cutbacks in the face of slumping sales, shed 55,000 jobs, and many other jobs were lost in industries that supply auto plants, with fabricated metal products and rubber and plastics products each down about 15,000, and apparel and other textile products down 10,000.
But there were also large declines last month in the number of jobs producing industrial machinery, equipment, lumber and furniture.
Moreover, people who kept their factory jobs worked fewer hours: The average workweek fell by 12 minutes, to 40 1/2 hours. Factory hours had fallen by 18 minutes in October.
The construction industry lost 60,000 more jobs last month, bringing the total to 250,000 over the past six months.
 
In Retail, Below Expectations
 In the service sector, the figures were also bad. For the retail trade, seasonal hiring for Christmas meant a gain of more than 200,000 jobs, but after allowing for statistical expectations, there was a decline of 70,000. Employment in wholesale trade fell by 10,000, and job losses continued in the finance and real estate industries. Business services lost 20,000 jobs.
These losses overwhelmed the growth in jobs in health care. Health care employment rose by about 60,000, while another small gain in oil drilling jobs brought the two-month total to almost 10,000.
The unemployment rate in the oil-producing state of Texas, however, surged to 7 percent from 5.7 percent, the biggest change by far among the 11 biggest industrial states. The jobless rates in California and Massachusetts each rose seven-tenths of a point, to 6.7 percent and 7 percent, respectively.
In New York, however, the rate dropped two-tenths of a point, to 5.4 percent, while the jobless rate in New York City fell to 7.4 percent from 7.7 percent, the department reported. New Jersey's jobless rate was unchanged at 5.5 percent.
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that while New York and New Jersey had avoided an upswing in the unemployment rate, "Basically, there's very little cheer in the November numbers." He attributed the figures partly to a lack of growth in the labor force. "People are just not entering the labor market," he said.
Because of smaller samples, changes for individual states of less than half a point are considered statistically insignificant. But the state figures do give a general indication of how state economies are faring.
According to the Government's separate survey of households, the number of civilians employed dropped by 450,000 last month, while the number of civilians working or actively looking for work fell 168,000. As a result, the ranks of the unemployed jumped by 282,000, to a total of 7,355,000, for an unemployment rate of 5.9 percent.
The overall jobless rate, which includes about 1,615,000 military personnel stationed in the United States, rose two-tenths of a point in November, to 5.8 percent.
Most of the increased joblessness occurred among adult men, whose rate of unemployment rose by three-tenths of a point, to 5.4 percent, up from 4.7 percent in June. This population group tends to be hit hard in a recession since men dominate factory jobs, which are most susceptible to contraction.
The unemployment rate for all factory workers climbed nearly a full point last month, to 6.6 percent, while the rate for those in durable-goods manufacturing soared to 7.1 percent from 5.8 percent. For construction, the jobless rate rose to 13.6 percent from 13.2 percent.
 
Rise in Job Losers
 The number of job losers, including those who expect to be recalled from layoff, rose nearly 300,000 last month, bringing the total to nearly 700,000 since June. Last month 3.1 percent of the labor force had either been dismissed or laid off, up from 2.8 percent in October and 2.5 percent in July. Re-entrants who could not find jobs represented 1.5 percent of the work force, those who quit their latest jobs accounted for eight-tenths of a point and new entrants accounted for five-tenths of a point.
The ranks of both the newly unemployed -- those jobless for less than five weeks -- and those out of work for 27 weeks or more, a group whose basic unemployment compensation had run out, both swelled last month.
And the number of people who wanted to work full time but were employed only part time because of slack work rose by 170,000, the department reported.
The proportion of the working-age population with jobs fell to 62.1 last month from 62.4 in October, and that was down from about the 63 percent level during 1989 and the first half of 1990. The ratio for adult women, at 54.5 percent, is now a full point below its June peak.

HEADLINE: Regional Defense Plan Urged for Europe

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Backing plans to turn the European Community into a powerful political bloc, France and Germany proposed today that the 12-nation group develop a regional foreign and security policy with a view toward adopting a common defense policy.
Debate about the need for the community to take an independent security role has intensified over the last four months since the Persian Gulf crisis exposed Western Europe's continued reliance on the United States to protect its vital economic interests. 
 The two countries nonetheless stressed that a common defense policy would not affect the region's commitments to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and they argued that a "European pillar" would serve to strengthen the 16-nation NATO alliance.
Coming just one week before an important summit of community leaders in Rome, however, the move today by France and Germany seemed principally inspired by a desire to set the agenda for coming negotiations on what is described as the future "political union" of Western Europe.
 
New European Powers Proposed
 Urging the community to act increasingly as a bloc in international affairs, President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl also proposed giving new powers to the European Parliament, creating a common European citizenship and expanding areas subject to community control.
They said the community's authority should eventually embrace the environment, health, social policy, energy and consumer protection, while the entire question of border controls, including immigration, drug trafficking and terrorism, should be handled by a new 12-nation body.
Political experts said that by going public with their ideas now, Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl appeared anxious to forestall any efforts by Britain's new Prime Minister, John Major, to limit the scope of the debate on political union, above all as it relates to foreign, defense and security questions.
Final decisions on further European integration will be made by two inter-governmental conferences on economic and monetary union and on political union that are to be inaugurated in Rome after next week's summit, but community leaders will instruct negotiators on what they should discuss.
 
Major Eager to Break Pattern
 At their last summit in late October, issuing guidelines on economic and monetary union, European Community leaders overrode the objections of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and called for the creation of a regional central bank and adoption of a single European currency after 1994.
British officials have said that, when taking part in his first European summit next week, Mr. Major is anxious to break the pattern of British isolation, but they said he was determined not to be rushed into surrendering any additional British sovereignty before the intergovernmental conferences.
The political experts said that the initiative today by Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl was of special significance to France because it signaled that longstanding cooperation between Paris and Bonn on European affairs had survived the test of German unification.
