HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Far From Mudville

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
Recession? What recession?
 The Boston Red Sox have agreed to pay Matt Young, a pitcher, $6.35 million for the next three baseball seasons. 
 Down the pay scale a notch, Rob Deer, who used to play the outfield for the Milwaukee Brewers, has agreed to accept $6.05 million for working three seasons with the Detroit Tigers.
 In letting Mr. Deer go to Detroit for his multimillion-dollar payday, the Milwaukee Brewers were not tightening their belts, however, or whatever baseball people tighten now that their pants are already so tight that belts are unnecessary.
 To the contrary, as the players' agents say when a team owner says $2 million is too much for a catcher who can't hit .225, to the contrary -- are you ready for this?
The Milwaukee Brewers have agreed to pay $6 million to Franklin Stubbs, a hitter formerly employed by the Houston Astros, to do his hitting in Milwaukee for the next three years.
 The Brewers have also contracted with a pitcher named Edwin Nunez, to pitch two seasons for them at a salary of $1.9 million.
 Even this didn't deplete the Brewers' bank vat, so they were also able to persuade Ted Higuera, a left-handed pitcher, to continue working in Milwaukee for four more years.
 Remember days and days of everybody shouting "Four more years! Four more years!" when the Republican Convention re-nominated Richard Nixon in 1972? Nixon lasted only two more years until Watergate got him. Watergate for baseball pitchers is torn rotator cuff, or bone chips in the subcutaneous fat, or something equally incomprehensible to everybody but sportswriters, yet terribly common.
 Nevertheless, the Brewers have put up a $13 million contract that says left-handed-pitcher Higuera can give them four more years. As Gordon Gekko might have said, "Eat your heart out, Carl Hubbell."
 You don't know who Gordon Gekko is? Don't worry. It speaks well of you. It proves you had the good taste to pass up the 1980's.
 Everybody, though, surely knows who Carl Hubbell was. Just about the best left-handed pitcher ever to have a sportswriter refer to his business arm as "the old soupbone," that's who Carl Hubbell was. And what was his salary? About $35 a week probably.
 The Kansas City Royals have agreed to pay Mike Boddicker, a pitcher, $9.25 million to leave Boston and play three years in Kansas City.
 They have also agreed to pay Kirk Gibson, who used to play the outfield in Detroit, and then in Los Angeles, $3.4 million to come work two seasons in Kansas City.
 What about New York, the home office of big bucks? The Yankees have snared a pitcher, name of Steve Farr, at $6.3 million for three years' work in pinstripes. They have also persuaded one of their not-so-terrible pitchers, Tim Leary, to continue to be a Yankee three more years for a consideration of $5.95 million.
 Not to be outdone in the competition to prove that New York is a jock's bonanza, the Mets have persuaded Vince Coleman (base stealer, infielder) to leave St. Louis and spend the next four years in Queens. The persuader: $11.95 million.
 This sum may make you goggle if your sport is chess hustling in Times Square, but it's not in the same league with the five-year, $20.25 million contract the Los Angeles Dodgers gave Darryl Strawberry after he lost his zest for playing in Queens. There's something possible here about Queens gambit declined being the road to checkmate, but you'd have to be named Karpov or Kasparov to get it, so let's move on to Atlanta.
 That's where Terry Pendleton, formerly of the St. Louis Cardinals, has agreed to move on to, and you probably would, too, if the Atlanta Braves offered to treat you the way they promise to treat Pendleton: namely, by paying him $10.2 million over four years for playing third base.
 Atlanta is also bringing in Sid Bream, a pitcher, to work three years for $5 million.
 Fort Knox, however, is not in Atlanta but in San Francisco, and the Giants -- those same cheapskates who once paid Carl Hubbell no more than $35 a week probably -- have the keys to the treasure and a generous heart for wandering ballplayers.
 The wanderers who will be walking in the great Hubbell's footprints -- and with sufficient taste, one hopes, to feel just a little inadequate -- include:
 Bud Black, pitcher, at $10 million for four years; Willie McGee, outfielder, at $13 million for four years, and Dave Righetti, pitcher, at $10 million for four years.
 Boys, you've come a long way from Mudville.

HEADLINE: Hortense W. Gabel, 77, Ex-Judge And New York City Official, Dies

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ

 BODY:
Hortense W. Gabel, a former New York State Supreme Court justice who was a longtime advocate for housing and civil rights and whose career was shattered when she was accused in the Bess Myerson case, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.
She died of heart failure, her daughter, Sukhreet, said. 
 Mrs. Gabel served on the Civil Court and State Supreme Court for 17 years. In December 1988 she was acquitted of charges that she had abused her powers by improperly reducing the alimony payments of Ms. Myerson's companion, Carl A. Capasso, in exchange for a job for her daughter in the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, which Ms. Myerson headed.
Mrs. Gabel had a long and distinguished career in government before assuming the Civil Court bench in 1970. That career began after Mrs. Gabel, already active as a reform Democrat, attended a dinner party in 1948 given by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, the founder of the American Jewish Congress; discussion at the party centered on the formation of a group that would champion the cause of blacks discriminated against in housing.
 
Enforced Rent Laws
 By the mid-1950's, as a director of the Committee on Discrimination in Housing, she was involved in trying to expose abuses in the urban renewal program in New York City and helped draft a report that was highly critical of Robert Moses, the builder who reshaped much of the city.
As head of New York City's Rent and Rehabilitation Administration, she dreamed of a slumless New York, and her enforcement of the rent-control laws uncovered overcharges and conspiracies, saving tenants millions of dollars. She also developed rehabilitation programs for sections of Harlem, the Lower East Side and Brooklyn.
Later, as a consultant to and vice president of the Center for Community Change, Mrs. Gabel helped develop housing programs in cities and states across the country.
In her several decades of public service, she served as an assistant New York City corporation counsel, general counsel and first deputy administrator of the New York State Temporary Housing Rent Commission and assistant to the mayor for housing and New York City Rent and Rehabilitation Commissioner, a position she held from 1962 to 1965. Mrs. Gabel was also a consultant to the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency and to the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
She served as an acting justice of the State Supreme Court in 1973 and as an acting Family Court judge in 1974. She was appointed to fill a vacancy on the State Supreme Court by Gov. Hugh L. Carey in 1975. She was known as a compassionate judge who supported civil rights and women's causes. In 1986, she was named judge of the year by the National Association of Women Judges, an organization she helped found in 1979.
The organization's president, Justice Christine Durham of the Utah Supreme Court, said in a 1987 interview that Justice Gabel was revered as "one of the grand dames of the New York legal community, who has been a mentor and supporter of women in the profession for decades."
Justice Gabel resigned in 1987 under the cloud of criminal and misconduct investigations that led to the Myerson indictments.
A jury in Federal District Court in Manhattan found Mrs. Gabel, Ms. Myerson and Mr. Capasso not guilty of charges of conspiracy, fraud and bribery. The central issue in the case was whether Mrs. Gabel, who was the judge handling preliminary motions in Mr. Capasso's divorce case in 1983, had received a bribe from Ms. Myerson, then New York City's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, in the form of a job for Sukhreet Gabel as a special assistant to Ms. Myerson.
The hiring, the prosecution said, was an inducement to reduce Mr. Capasso's weekly support payments to his wife to $500 from $1,500. Mrs. Gabel had been seeking a job for her daughter.
 
Family Drama
 The case was full of bizarre twists and personal dramas. The two-month trial was dominated by the nine days of testimony against her mother by Sukhreet Gabel, the prosecution's star witness, who also taped two telephone conversations with her mother without her knowledge and provided prosecutors with some of her mother's documents.
Mrs. Gabel and her husband, Dr. Milton Gabel, were portrayed during the trial as the protective parents of a troubled woman, and seemed torn between wanting to support her in her moment in the spotlight and hoping that her testimony would not sway the jury.
After the verdict, an exuberant Mrs. Gabel held hands with her daughter outside the courthouse and shouted, "Hooray, we won!"
"This is the best judicial experience I have ever had," she said.
Hortense Wittstein Gabel, known as Horty to her friends, was born Dec. 16, 1912, in the Bronx. She attended public schools in the city and graduated from Hunter College in 1934. Three years later she graduated from Columbia University Law School and worked in her father's law firm. She left in 1944 to marry Dr. Gabel, then an army dentist, and in the war years was a reporter at Fort Hood, Tex., before returning to New York.
In addition to her daughter, she is survived by a sister, Sybil Phillips. They both live in Manhattan. Dr. Gabel died in July.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hortense W. Gabel (The New York Times, 1988)

HEADLINE: Heinlein Gets the Last Word

BYLINE: By Kurt Vonnegut; Kurt Vonnegut's most recent book is his novel "Hocus Pocus."

 BODY:

STRANGER IN A STRANGE LAND
By Robert A. Heinlein.
525 pp. New York:
Ace/G.P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95. 
 IN London in October, at a dinner party in the home of the publisher Tom Maschler, head of Jonathan Cape, our host asked a question that was primitive but deep. "What is the best novel ever written?" I nominated "Madame Bovary." A majority went for "Anna Karenina." Anna had glamour, Emma didn't. That was that. We hastened on to gossip about Salman Rushdie and so forth.
Afterward, though, as I sat alone in my room at Brown's Hotel, I marveled that none of us had celebrated a story that took place in the world at large rather than in a stratified and codified little society. And Tom Wolfe a few months earlier had told the rest of us in the fiction trade to either do deep-dish reportage on members of little groups, right down to the name of the manufacturers of the shoes they wore, or take up macrame.
Yes, and now Putnam has published for the first time the full text of "Stranger in a Strange Land," by Robert A. Heinlein (1907-88), an abridged version of which has sold 100,000 copies in hard cover and nearly five million in paper since its debut in 1961. An enormous number of readers have found this book a brilliant mind-bender, and yet I doubt that Heinlein's name was ever uttered at a meeting of PEN or in the halls of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. Despite his having written this book and about 40 others ("The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress," "I Will Fear No Evil," "Methuselah's Children," "The Puppet Masters" and on and on), this remarkable man, whom I never met, was included only in "Who's Who in Science Fiction," and died without having been considered worthy of an entry in the more inclusive annual "Who's Who." The president of the American Poultry Association is sure as heck in the big 'Who's Who" somewhere.
How could this have happened? My goodness, the name of the leading character in "Stranger in a Strange Land" is as familiar to millions of literate persons as Oliver Twist or Holden Caulfield. He is Valentine Michael Smith. But he was raised by Martians on Mars, without ever having seen another human being. And to those who get to say which novels are serious and which are not, professional critics and teachers of literature in the company of authors of novels about the rise or fall of ordinary people in provincial societies, he is absolutely intolerable. He is far more dismaying to them, say, than a character found when an infant in an overnight bag in Victoria Station. And I say that their rejection of not only Valentine Michael Smith, but his creator, too, is an act based on social prejudices, and that intellectual and esthetic standards have nothing to do with it.
The great critic H. L. Mencken confessed as much without shame, saying that he could not appreciate the works of Willa Cather since he simply wasn't interested in people from Nebraska. That isn't criticism. That is snobbery. In the Soviet Union before glasnost the Writers' Union regularly said that some writers weren't really writers, no matter how much and how well they had written, since they were politically incorrect. In this country the same thing is done to writers like Robert A. Heinlein because they are socially incorrect, because their stories are about places members of the literary establishment do not care to visit and about characters, many of them not even human or humanoid, they simply do not care to befriend.
Truth be told, the establishment, on the same grounds, isn't all that fond of "Candide" or "Gulliver's Travels," either, both of which I should have championed at Tom Maschler's house. I should have at least mentioned "Stranger in a Strange Land" as well, a wonderfully humanizing artifact for those who can enjoy thinking about the place of human beings not at a dinner table but in the universe.
We are approaching the 30th birthday of "Stranger in a Strange Land." Valentine Michael Smith is the stranger. Raised by Martians on Mars, he is brought to Earth where he must adapt not only to our social prejudices, but to our strong gravitational field and rich atmosphere. Some 60,000 words that were cut from Heinlein's manuscript for reasons of economy back in 1961 are at last taking their rightful place in the body of world literature. There is a preface by the author's widow, Virginia Heinlein, which speaks not at all of the neglect of her husband's work by the establishment. It tells the history of the uncut manuscript, which, if it weren't for her, might have remained in total darkness forever in a vault in the library of the University of California at Santa Cruz.
Is the story much improved by the restored passages? I leave it to someone else to compare the two versions line by line. The thought-provoking premise is unchanged and could scarcely be enriched. Nor did the consequences of that premise as extrapolated by Heinlein seem to me garbled or anemic or whatever in the abridged edition I read years ago. So I say of the restorations, "Icing on a cake which for people who like that kind of cake was already quite satisfactory."
Am I arguing that "Stranger in a Strange Land" is anywhere near as good as "Madame Bovary"? Good heavens no! No novel has come within a kilometer of the greatness of Flaubert's masterpiece. Not even "Anna Karenina." Not even "The Bonfire of the Vanities."

 
 
THE BIGGEST, FATTEST SACRED COWS

"I believe that I have dreamed up a really new S-F idea, a hard thing to do these days," Robert Heinlein confided to his agent, Lurton Blassingame, in 1952. His idea (which had emerged in a discussion with his wife, Virginia) used the picaresque adventures of a young human, brought to Earth after having been raised from infancy by Martians, to probe human prejudices and foibles. "Absolutely everything about Earth is strange to him . . . its orientations, motives, pleasures, evaluations. On the other hand, he himself has received the education of a wise and subtle and very advanced -- but completely nonhuman -- race." No stranger to controversy, Heinlein saw the novel as an opportunity to launch frontal assaults on "the two biggest, fattest sacred cows" of Western society, "monotheism and monogamy."
The book had a long, uncertain evolution. There were many drafts. The final version, 220,000 words long (down from the 600,000 he had once envisioned), was finished in two feverish months and submitted in 1960 to G. P. Putnam's Sons. Putnam accepted the book but requested that it be trimmed. Heinlein reluctantly complied, deleting 60,000 words and, in the process, some of the more provocative passages lampooning American attitudes toward sex and religion.
Even in its pared-down form, the book was intensely controversial. Some reviews were descriptive rather than judgmental. Others shared the ire expressed by Orville Prescott in the pages of The New York Times. The reviewer described the novel as a "disastrous mishmash of science fiction, laborious humor, dreary social satire and cheap eroticism."
Despite such responses the book sold well. It quickly went into a book club edition, appeared in paperback, and eventually became the first science-fiction title to appear on The New York Times Book Review's best-seller list. In 1989 Virginia Heinlein approached Putnam with the suggestion that the complete work, based on Heinlein's working manuscript, should be published. While the restored version does not present a radically new work, it does offer readers a chance to watch Heinlein working out his ideas at greater length, and challenging society's "sacred cows" with unexpurgated zest.
Heinlein was bemused by those who claimed that the work provided a blueprint for a new society. The novel was not written, he explained to one fan, to promulgate any set of beliefs. "I was not giving answers. I was trying to shake the reader loose from some preconceptions and induce him to think for himself, along new and fresh lines. In consequence, each reader gets something different out of that book because he himself supplies the answers. . . . It is an invitation to think -- not to believe." -- RICHARD E. NICHOLLS

HEADLINE: The Stuff That Makes the World Go Round

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb; Leslie H. Gelb will become the foreign affairs columnist of The New York Times in January. He has been the deputy editor of The Times's editorial page and the editor of its Op-Ed page.

 BODY:

THE PRIZE
The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power.
By Daniel Yergin.
Illustrated. 910 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $24.95. 
 IN 1891, Abdul Rahman, the nominal governor of Riyadh, fled with his family from the city, then under the control of a hated rival. His son, the future King of Saudi Arabia, Abdul Aziz ibn Saud, made part of that journey in a bag hung on a camel. The Saud family wandered in exile until invited to the city-state of Kuwait, ruled by the Sabah family.
A hundred years later, the Sabahs fled across the same desert in their helicopters and Mercedes-Benzes just ahead of Saddam Hussein's Iraqi hordes. And the Sabahs, not reputed for their largeness of spirit, do not hesitate to remind their hosts of the old debt.
It would be totally out of character for the low-key present Saudi rulers, however, to say they expect assistance of a similar kind from their current American protectors. Yet as we learn in "The Prize," Daniel Yergin's timely book, long before the assurances of the Carter and Reagan Administrations, President Harry S. Truman virtually committed the United States to the defense of the Saudi realm. In 1950, he wrote to King Ibn Saud that Washington "is interested in the preservation of the independence and territorial integrity of Saudi Arabia," and that threats to the kingdom would be "a matter of immediate concern to the United States."
These are among the roots and cycles recaptured by Mr. Yergin in a work that deserves to become the standard text on the history of oil. Half historian and half energy expert, Mr. Yergin, the president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates and the author of "Shattered Peace," is almost uniquely qualified for the task. "The Prize" exceeds in comprehensiveness and care the only comparable effort, a study (and a good one) about the major oil companies entitled "The Seven Sisters," by Anthony Sampson.
Historians will point out that Mr. Yergin essentially retells familiar stories. Economists will quibble about his failure to provide a theoretical apparatus to guide the reader through the various rounds of expansion and consolidation in the oil industry. Partisans will lament his avoidance of the charged debate over whether the oil barons and their political allies have been greedy devils or mostly instruments of market forces.
But Mr. Yergin's clear aim is not to break new ground, to theorize or to blame. It is to pull together a heretofore indigestible mass of information and provide a much-needed historical map. And he has done so with an eye toward the colossal personalities and forces that have drawn and redrawn that map.
There are, of course, the familiar figures, like John D. Rockefeller, the founder of Standard Oil, and J. Paul Getty and Armand Hammer, the famous independent oil tycoons. Very early in the tale of oil, a critical role is played by the Nobel brothers, Robert and Ludwig. Robert turned out to be instrumental in the development of the Baku oil fields in the Russian Caucasus, long before his guilt over being the dynamite king inspired his Nobel Prizes.
Not the least of the characters was Mohammed Mossadegh, chosen as Prime Minister of Iran in 1951, when the Shah was pushed aside and the oil fields nationalized. Truman dispatched Averell Harriman to explain to Mossadegh that he couldn't expect more for a barrel of oil than the oil companies earned. When told by Mr. Harriman that nothing can be larger than the sum of its parts, the Prime Minister responded, "That is false." Consider the fox, he continued. "His tail is often much longer than he is." And the Prime Minister laughed uproariously. He later explained to the American envoy that he could not survive if he compromised on oil pricing because of the power of the Ayatollah Seyed Kashani. Harriman, ever determined, visited the Ayatollah, who told him all foreigners were evil, and that those who interested themselves in oil could find themselves butchered.
Perhaps the most colorful of all the oil lions was Calouste Gulbenkian, a financier and deal-maker from Istanbul who played a pivotal role in bringing together money and oil before the turn of the century in Russia, and thereafter in the Middle East. His shrewdness earned him the sobriquet Mr. Five Percent. But for Mr. Yergin, his most endearing quality was his reputation for being "totally and completely untrusting."
Untrusting and, Mr. Yergin could have added, with a clearsighted understanding of the power of oil. Some of our most untrusting leaders never seemed to have grasped the point. After the outbreak of war between Israel and the Arabs in 1973, President Richard Nixon warned Arab oil producers that they wouldn't be able to sell their black gold at exorbitant rates. "We and Europe are the market," he said, and "if they continue to up the price they will lose the markets." A month later, the Arabs initiated their oil embargo and prices jumped to a historical high.
THE point was, and remains, that oil and not man has been in the saddle -- ever since man discovered it could be used to make light and fuel modern society. The point was, and is, that oil has meant more than fabulous wealth and power; it has created an umbilical dependency. Modern transportation, factories and food production feed on oil. Almost nothing that makes modern man and society go round can work without oil. In this way, it surpasses gold and coal and all the other precious resources that have driven history.
From this central insight, Mr. Yergin constructs his three themes. First, oil has been at the heart of "the rise and development of capitalism and modern business." Seven of the top 20 companies in the Fortune 500 are oil conglomerates. Since 1973, Saudi Arabia alone has earned over a trillion dollars from oil.
Yet Mr. Yergin does not say enough about why a nation like the Soviet Union has failed economically, though it remains the single largest oil producing country. Nor does he take full note of why Germany and Japan have thrived despite their enormous dependence on oil imports. The most disciplined nations manage quite well regardless.
The second theme of "The Prize" is the intimate relationship of oil with "national strategies and global politics and power." Here again, Mr. Yergin fails to explore how Germany and Japan were able to make themselves mighty militarily without oil. But the fact remains that the Allies defeated Germany in both world wars in no small measure because of German oil shortages. Japan went to war against the United States in 1941 in good part to establish secure oil supplies in Southeast Asia, and failed when Allied naval power cut off those supplies. And oil is so potent that a nation of 17 million like Iraq can support a force of a million men and the fourth most powerful military establishment in the world. Still, a much smaller country and one without oil, Israel, has been able to withstand the forces of the oil-rich Arab nations, including Iraq. Nonetheless, the theme generally holds.
It holds because of the truth of the third theme, that we have become a "Hydrocarbon Society," peopled by "Hydrocarbon Man." It is so in almost all things material. The interminable gas lines for autos during shortages, and the spiraling inflation and insuperable poverty of developing nations as oil prices rise, testify to the all-pervasive dominance of oil.
Mr. Yergin worries about this terrible dependency that so distorts our foreign policies and destroys our environment in an all-too-cursory concluding chapter. To the end, he does not want to step out of his role as historian and undermine the balance and integrity of his work. But he has left the reader with enough to take the next step.
There is the matter of the oil mentality and the matter of choice. The oil mind, with rare exceptions, has been marked with arrogance. It has taken the gift of the modern gods and turned it to power -- for windfall profits, against most kinds of government regulation and against the causes of conservation and environmentalism. It has inspired demons in the forms of the deposed and dead Shah of Iran, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya and Saddam Hussein.
For the United States and other nations to have mortgaged their environmental heritage to oil has been inexcusable. For the United States and others to have grown so dependent for their well-being on a part of the world that is politically unstable and enthralled by religious fanatics and terrorists has been an act of gargantuan irresponsibility. The very telling of the oil story as well as Mr. Yergin does it creates a sense of inevitability. But there have been alternatives, and there are alternatives -- nuclear power, solar power -- even now, especially now.
 
THE LONG ARM OF SADDAM HUSSEIN
 Daniel Yergin wrote out every word of "The Prize" in longhand. When typed, the first draft ran more than 2,500 pages (eventually cut by half), and Mr. Yergin read every chapter aloud to himself twice. Then, three days after he finished the epilogue, Saddam Hussein reached out for a prize of his own -- Kuwait.
For Mr. Yergin, Iraq's invasion four months before his book's publication meant a hectic end to a project that had consumed more than seven years and had become, in its author's eyes, a "narrative history of the 20th century."
"Oil and energy excite passions and animosity in our society like no other commodity," Mr. Yergin said during an interview over lunch in midtown Manhattan.
Despite the promise of alternative technologies that would decrease dependence on oil, Mr. Yergin predicts that "we will be an oil society much longer than we thought. If we weren't, we wouldn't have 400,000 troops in Saudi Arabia."
Mr. Yergin is the author of "Shattered Peace," a history of the origins of the cold war, and the co-author, with Robert Stobaugh, of the best seller "Energy Future." As an undergraduate at Yale, he studied English literature, with particular attention to the 19th-century novel, an influence that is apparent in "The Prize." But Mr. Yergin also flirted with new forms, and in 1967 he founded The New Journal in the wake of the New Journalism championed by Tom Wolfe and others. Later, he found himself sharing pages with Mr. Wolfe as a contributing editor at New York magazine.
Torn between journalism, business and the academic life, Mr. Yergin chose the academy when he won a Marshall Scholarship to Cambridge University, where he received his Ph.D. He has been a lecturer at the Harvard Business School and the John F. Kennedy School of Government. He has since returned to the business world, as president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, an international consulting company that he started in 1982.
Mr. Yergin, whose two children were born during the writing of "The Prize," is now searching for a subject for his next book, about which he makes this promise, only half in jest: "It will be short." -- JOSEPH A. CINCOTTI

HEADLINE: Four Married Couples in Space

BYLINE: By Robert Bazell; Robert Bazell is the science correspondent for NBC News.

 BODY:

MISSION TO MARS
By Michael Collins.
Illustrated. 307 pp. New York:
Grove Weidenfeld. $22.50. 
 THE mission to Mars that Michael Collins foresees in his latest book would last almost two years: a two-month visit on the red planet would be sandwiched between an 11-month voyage there (via Venus) and a nine-month return. Mr. Collins, the Apollo 11 astronaut who orbited the moon while Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on it, reminds us that a trip to Mars "won't be the same as a lunar voyage, where home is still large enough and beautiful enough to act as a strong magnet for the eye and the mind." For months the crew would see "the same black velvet dotted with unblinking stars." And such isolation could "create frustration and hostility, perhaps followed by incapacitation, violence, or even insanity."
How should planners select people for such an ordeal? Should the crew include both sexes? Married couples? How can the spacecraft transport 65,000 pounds of food, drinking water and oxygen for the crew? Mr. Collins offers possible solutions to these and other problems that face humans bound for Mars. He does this by detailing a hypothetical mission, complete with a fictional international crew, that would take off in less than 14 years. His narrative allows even those who are not so interested in space travel to appreciate the complexity and the grandeur of the undertaking.
Mr. Collins has long been the articulate astronaut. In two previous books, "Carrying the Fire" and "Lift off," he described space flight in an energetic style that contrasted sharply with the monosyllabic utterances of many of his colleagues. Similarly, "Mission to Mars" is evocative of a real mission because he incorporates not only his own past but also the experiences of American and Russian astronauts, sailors on nuclear submarines and residents of Antarctica.
Unfortunately, this imaginary voyage takes up only half the book. The rest is a tepid polemic on why the great nations of the world should send people to Mars. It includes a brief summary of the scientific arguments for such a trip. (Anyone interested in a full account should read John Noble Wilford's recent book, "Mars Beckons.") But Mr. Collins's obsession with Mars stems less from an interest in science than from a desire to see the National Aeronautics and Space Administration win back the prestige it enjoyed when he himself played a starring role. A Mars trip, he writes, would be "the salvation of the agency."
Mr. Collins understands that "the decision to go to Mars will be made for political reasons," not economic ones. But he doubts politicians will back such a mission. He remembers attending a picnic on the White House lawn after listening to a speech by President Bush commemorating the 20th anniversary of Apollo 11: "Munching on a hot dog, I tried to digest what the president had said -- and not said." President Bush had endorsed NASA's plans to return to the moon and go on to Mars. "But what was missing," Mr. Collins says, "might be even more important: some indication of how high a priority his administration would put on space when the inevitable budget crunch came."
After offering that insight, which has been borne out by the recent budget decisions of Congress and the Administration, Mr. Collins returns to his hypothetical journey to Mars. As he sees it, twin spacecraft built by the United States and the Soviet Union would be flown by four married couples -- American, Soviet, French and Japanese. He explains that "an element of stability, of old-shoe comfort, would be introduced by having one's husband or wife to fall back on. Certainly a singles-bar atmosphere, a charged mixture of sexually unattached competitors, would be a disaster." (By contrast, the crew chosen to spend two years in Biosphere II, a closed ecological system in Arizona that, in many ways, is a model for a Mars mission, is four men and four women, all single.) As for the issue of command, Mr. Collins's desire to keep NASA in charge is so strong that he even allows a Soviet commander in exchange for keeping mission control in Houston.
On the oh-so-long voyage to Mars and back, Vladimir, Elena, Henri, Marina, Wesley, Heather, Sachi and Mariko encounter problems ranging from the deaths of loved ones back home to backups in the sewage and water-recycling systems. The intended high point, of course, is the landing on and exploration of Mars. But it struck me as ho-hum -- more people bounding around in a desolate environment with about one-third of Earth's gravity, another Apollo in a more distant place. Nonetheless, even a space cynic like me found Mr. Collins's descriptions of the challenges of a Mars mission fascinating.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1311 words

HEADLINE: SCIENCE FICTION

BYLINE: By Gerald Jonas

 BODY:
Early on, one of the central characters in Kim Stanley Robinson's PACIFIC EDGE (Tor/Tom Doherty Associates, $18.95) declares, "There is no such thing as a pocket utopia." What he means is that an elitist paradise cannot survive for long as an island of perfection in an imperfect world. This sounds like a truism, yet Mr. Robinson spends the rest of the book bringing to life an appealing and perversely believable pocket paradise.
Most utopian visions make boring reading. Despite some attempt (typically in the opening chapters) to disguise philosophy as fiction, authors with an ax to grind tend to scant storytelling in favor of polemics. Ursula Le Guin's 1974 novel "The Dispossessed" is a modern exception that speaks to our emotions as well as our intellect. Ms. Le Guin placed her utopian society in jeopardy in a way that challenged the wider applicability of that society's ideals; Mr. Robinson engages our attention by focusing on the day-to-day labor of putting ideals into practice. 
 If the residents of El Modena (in late 21st-century southern California) live in paradise, it is only because they work so hard to defend their way of life. Like all Californians, Kevin and Doris and Hank and Gabriela and Alfredo and Ramona worry about economic development and land use and water rights; they know where their water comes from -- mostly far away -- and they understand the political arts of compromise and give-and-take. Mr. Robinson tells us just enough about their cooperative, town-meeting type of self-government to make it sound plausible without reducing it to a bloodless formula. The issue that splits the town is what to do about Rattlesnake Hill, the last unspoiled hilltop in the area.
What distinguishes Mr. Robinson's treatment of this conflict from dozens of overheated ecological-disaster scenarios is his sense of scale. He never equates the fate of a particular hill with the fate of civilization. Instead, through a blend of dirt-under-the-fingernails naturalism and lyrical magical realism, he invites us to share his characters' intensely personal, intensely local attachment to what they have. The result is a bittersweet utopia that may shame you into entertaining new hope for the future.
The membership of the Science Fiction Writers of America once voted Isaac Asimov's "Nightfall" the best science fiction short story of all time. Now, a half-century after the story's publication, we have the novel NIGHTFALL (Doubleday, $19.95), a collaboration between Mr. Asimov and Robert Silverberg.
The original story, written when Mr. Asimov was 21 years old, took off from a line of Emerson's: "If the stars should appear one night in a thousand years, how would men believe and adore, and preserve for many generations the remembrance of the city of God!" The whole point of the story was to invent a scientifically plausible solar system in which such an event could actually occur, and then turn Emerson's prediction on its head. The inhabitants of the planet Kalgash, whose system is blessed with six suns and who have no way of imagining a dark night, much less a sky emblazoned with stars, react to the periodic "nightfall" with a worldwide panic that all but obliterates civilization.
It was not only Emerson who took it on the chin in the original; the cocky scientists of Kalgash who thought they understood the universe were reduced to whimpering idiots by the immensities of time and space revealed when the last veil of sunlight dropped from their eyes.
Continuing the story into the days and weeks following the terrifying nightfall, Mr. Silverberg and Mr. Asimov have altered the trajectory of the narrative out of all recognition. Instead of a fable about intellectual pride that ends in a thought-provoking blackout, this novel offers a rather pedestrian chronicle of the efforts of the surviving scientists and their religious adversaries to put the eggshell of society back together again. Unfortunately, we have read something like this a hundred times before, in the subgenre of science fiction known as the post-collapse novel. In such novels, which have proliferated in recent years, the collapse of civilization is typically triggered by a nuclear holocaust or some ecological catastrophe like global warming. By a curious alchemy, the new ending has transformed the appearance of the stars that made the original story so memorable into what might be called a retroactive cliche.
WINTERLONG (Bantam Spectra, $4.95) by Elizabeth Hand is a post-collapse novel with a vengeance. The environment is shot to hell. Nuclear explosives and virus bombs have scrambled genes to produce some bizarre variants on the human standard. Remnants of warring governments still duel over the devastated terrain. And in the ruins of the City (Washington) a strange new civilization, cobbled together out of bits and pieces of the old, struggles to survive.
The overgrown Mall is now a "Narrow Forest," haunted by "lazars" and "geneslaves." The cavernous buildings, which have grown "heavy kudzu beards," now house Curators who preserve, with some degree of success, the old scientific knowledge. But the real center of this world, and of Ms. Hand's novel, is the houses of pleasure where all the technology that has not yet been turned into instruments of destruction has been placed in the service of lust.
The plot, which has as many twists as a mutated chromosome, deals with the re-emergence of magic (white and black) in a world familiar with the worst that science can do. The characters include several mad scientists, a military commander of surpassing maleficence, doomed decadents of every stripe, some not-so-innocent innocents and a few enigmas whose true nature may be revealed in the promised sequel.
Ms. Hand's style tends toward the ornate: "At the sound I start to turn, to break the reverie that binds me to this place, this tree stirred by a tainted wind riven from a bleak and noiseless shore." But her vision of children used and abused by malign forces is so strong it keeps bursting through the language to evoke not just horror and disgust but outrage and even -- a word much bandied about by inhabitants of the City -- empathy.
If Rod Serling ever came back from the Twilight Zone to take up his career where he left off, the result might be HER PILGRIM SOUL: And Other Stories (Tor/Tom Doherty Associates, $17.95) by Alan Brennert. Here are all the master's tics, recycled for today's brave new world. The title story (which was in fact adapted from a script for CBS-TV's recent revival of "The Twilight Zone") strikes just the right tone of stylistic and conceptual pretension. A brilliant computer scientist who has trouble connecting with flesh-and-blood people gets a lesson in love (complete with many pregnant ellipses, italicized emphases, stunned dashes and a dynamite tag line by W. B. Yeats) from a long-dead woman who haunts his holograms.
In another retread from "The Twilight Zone," a group of space explorers approaches a "sad, wounded" planet shrouded in pollution. A technician asks, "There was a name for this one, in one of the old languages, wasn't there, Professor?" The professor (quietly): "Earth. They called it Earth." After discovering that the dead world is haunted by its former inhabitants, the explorers somehow trigger a planetary rebirth, which they recognize as scientifically impossible: " 'It's as if something is . . . accelerating evolution, somehow,' Archer said. 'As if -- ' " Two more dashes, one italicized exclamation and an ellipsis later, the truth is suddenly apparent: "The oceans are swarming with . . . cyanobacteria," the precursors of all higher organisms. "For the Earth, the long night was over; and if she knew what strange dawn was about to break, she kept her counsel, and remained silent, silent as the dead."

HEADLINE: Green Streets, Mean Streets

BYLINE: By Tamar Jacoby; Tamar Jacoby has a fellowship from the Alicia Patterson Foundation to write a book about racial integration.

 BODY:

STREETWISE
Race, Class, and Change in an Urban Community.
By Elijah Anderson.
276 pp. Chicago:
The University of Chicago Press. $19.95. 
 IN 1975, Elijah Anderson and his wife moved innocently enough into the gentrifying Philadelphia neighborhood that he calls the Village. The young black sociologist was drawn to the area for personal reasons of an ordinary kind: the attractive houses, central location and rising property values. Only after he moved in did he realize that he was also strangely fascinated by the integrated neighborhood and by its relationship with the nearby ghetto.
He found himself studying the two linked neighborhoods, informally at first and then in a professional way -- photographing, videotaping, frequenting bars and shops and precinct houses. In the 14 years that followed, he conducted scores of interviews -- with cops, drug dealers, street kids, middle-class homeowners and community leaders. He also participated actively in local affairs, giving up any pretense of scientific objectivity. The result is an excellent portrait of two communities. Mr. Anderson, who teaches at the University of Pennsylvania, calls it an ethnographic study -- and he has framed his perceptions with some sociological theory about the "underclass" -- but the sharpness of his observations and the simple clarity of his prose recommend his book far beyond an academic audience. Vivid, unflinching, finely observed, "Streetwise" is a powerful and intensely frightening picture of the inner city.
Mr. Anderson's observational skill serves him well wherever he goes, and his portrait of the gentrifying Village is wonderfully lifelike: one-time hippies turned into landlords, yuppies braving the city streets only when protected by their dogs. But by far the strongest chapters in the book, the newest no doubt for many readers and the most searing, are those set in the black community he names Northton. Mr. Anderson is able to make himself at home on the ghetto street corner, hanging out with a gang or chatting with middle-aged workmen who once served as role models for local youths, but no longer do. He interviews churchgoing ladies who are now afraid whenever they venture out of their apartments. He shows us the thinking of a teen-age mother and explains what it feels like to be an adolescent male on a dark street at night, waiting for a chance to prove one's toughness by assaulting the next passer-by. Most memorable and appalling is the section in which he takes us inside a filthy crack house and talks at length with a pitiful "coke whore."
The neighborhood that emerges from these vignettes is an utterly hellish place. Hemmed in by poverty, unable to find jobs, largely without hope for the future, the inhabitants of Mr. Anderson's inner city have sunk into a desperate and vicious way of life. Northton is a Hobbesian world where the predator is king and the most admired people are those who are most ruthless in exploiting others. Teen-age boys with no other way to prove their manhood pride themselves on how many girls they can impregnate and abandon. Drug dealers live by ensnaring others, enlarging their pool of customers by addicting friends and lovers. Wolf-pack attacks on whites are justified as sport. Common decency seems to have no hold on people; duplicity and trickery are a way of life -- even inside families and young couples.
Mr. Anderson's most telling description is of the typical drug dealer, now the role model for many ghetto teen-agers. He is "making money fast and scorning the law and traditional values. If he works, he does so grudgingly. . . . He is out to beat the next fellow. . . . To his hustling mentality, generosity is a weakness. . . . Self-aggrandizement consumes his whole being."
Mr. Anderson is a scrupulous guide, and he whitewashes nothing in his picture. And yet, for all his honesty, at times he seems to shy away from the moral conclusions indicated by his evidence. His theories about the ghetto poor lean heavily on the sociologist William Julius Wilson. Like Mr. Wilson, Mr. Anderson believes that the root of the problem is largely economic: a lack of dignified, well-paying jobs. This, combined with the weakening of traditional values (caused largely by the black middle class's departure), has so demoralized inner-city blacks that they cannot resist the temptations of the drug culture. Thus, for Mr. Anderson, it is the economy that is to be blamed for teen-age motherhood, crack-addicted babies and the endless crime that ravages both Northton and the Village.
TO a degree, certainly, he is right. Most young people in the ghetto probably cannot help themselves, cannot ignore peer pressure or pass up the crack pipe. Clearly there is little point in blaming them, and society ought to do all it can to help -- both economically and in other ways. But to rule out blame should not mean banishing any hope for choice or personal responsibility. And at times one can't help wondering whether Mr. Anderson does the poor a service by insisting that they have so little choice. In the same way, one asks oneself, is it fair to impute racism to those Village whites who have come to associate young black males with crime? Which side of the problem needs more urgent attention -- the whites' undoubtedly overgeneralized fear or the reality of high crime rates among black youths?
Much of the power of Mr. Anderson's portrait grows from his obvious personal anguish. He paints a tragically dislocated world, poignant above all because of the waste of life. His sympathy is not misplaced, but he sometimes seems distracted from the truth it reveals.

HEADLINE: On Language;
Bespokesman

BYLINE: BY WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
"HE'S REACHING way upscale," wrote Jay Cocks in Time magazine recently about today's fashionable male, "to Armani and Ralph Lauren and the heady heights of bespoke tailoring."
"You have to show up in Bond-age style," Paul Hirshson of The Boston Globe wrote about a promotional party for a James Bond film, "meaning bespoke tailoring for men and something slick and sexy for women." 
 "Times are tougher, flamboyance is out," Newsweek wrote, following the trend toward Duke of Windsor styling. "The suits are available 'off the peg,' but there is even a growing interest in made-to-order, 'bespoke' tailoring."
My interest is growing in whatever happened to cus tom, a word fading from our fashion vocabulary in a blizzard of British usage. Don't give me any of those non-U made-to-order suits; get away from me with that bottom-of-the-line custom blazer; to be suitably trendy, bespeak to me of bespoke tailoring.
No, I may not say "bespeak to me." One old sense of bespeak is "to foreshadow, foretell," as in "The President's move bespeaks action in the gulf." Another sense means "show, indicate." In a New York Times book review, John Maxwell Hamilton notes the paradox of the frequent theft of the Bible, the most stolen book of all: "The Good Book apparently bespeaks a merciful God."
Yet another sense of this offbeat word is "to ask for in advance" ("to bespeak the reader's patience") or the similar "to reserve, or book, seats before a performance." The seats that are taken, like the person betrothed to be wed, are said to be spoken for.
Now we are zeroing in on the meaning of bespoke, an adjective that means "ordered in advance" (I'll hear from the Squad Squad about that).
"The shoemaking trade," Chambers's Encyclopedia wrote in 1866, ". . . is divided into two departments -- the bespoke and the ready-made." A half-century later in London, the bespoke tailor was born (probably on Savile Row, famed home of tailoring establishments; the present Japanese term for a Western-style suit is sebiro).
Why are there so few linguistic customers for cus tom? That word, from the Latin consuescere, "to accustom," is akin to suus, "one's own," as in suicide, a form of which a political candidate wearing a bespoke suit in a working-class district commits.
The Custom Tailors and Designers Association of America claims to be the oldest trade association in the United States, and its executive director, Irma Lipkin, insists that custom is here to stay: "Bespoke is British for what Americans call custom."
But usage by usage, stitch by stitch, the Britishism is patching over our word. We may be left with customized -- "altered to fit" -- or with made to measure -- "tailored to specific measurements but not made on the premises for a specified customer." This bespeaks a victory for the Brits. (Is "Brits" an ethnic slur? I'd like to hear from Britons about that.)
 
Fluffya Slang
 PHILADELPHIANS ARE proud of their regional dialect, which is based on a pronunciation of compression; a "Fluffya Inkwire," for example, is what outlanders call a Philadelphia Inquirer.
A competing publication, The Fluffyadailynooz, has come up with an interesting slang usage unrelated to pronunciation. "Ex-Prosecutor's Plea Stalemated," goes a July headline of an article that was read with dread at the Department of Justice in Washington, where droves of Pennsylvania prosecutors recused themselves in the case. Then followed this subhead: "Won't Dime Drug-Using Pals, Feds Say."
What is the meaning of dime as a verb? "Since pay phones required 10 cents per call for many years," explains Francis J. Hanssens Jr. of that city, "the phrase to drop a dime on came to mean 'to inform on.' The Daily News apparently believes that, even standing alone, dime can be used in that sense."
I salute the headline writer; it's good to see a colorful bit of slang hang in there in the face of inflation. To stop on a dime is still with us, because the 10-cent coin is our smallest, and the phrase means "to stop short"; however, the dime store, or five-and-dime, is Old Slang. So is "Suddenly the dime dropped," said by one who was illuminated by understanding, as if the inserted coin finally operated the pay phone and the dial tone came on. (If anybody calls about this, I'll hit him with Really Old Slang: "It's your nickel.")
 
Rich Soak
 IN OUR ETYMOLOGICAL dig for the coinage of the phrase soak the rich, one member of the Nitpickers' League argued that only words, not phrases, could be the object of etymology.
More helpful were two Lex Irregs who nailed down the coinage. Joe Klein of New York magazine cites Thomas Kessner's book "Fiorello H. La Guardia and the Making of Modern New York," which reports that on March 10, 1932, the fiery Congressman from New York took the floor of the House to blast a tax bill and to add his own formula: "I am simply going to say, 'Soak the rich' "; he was denounced in The New York Times for those "wild and whirling words."
David Shulman, an avid phrasedick, comes up with the earliest known citation of the phrase as the compound adjective that populist politicians came to know and love, with this headline from the April 2, 1932, Literary Digest: "The 'Soak-the-Rich' Drive in Washington."
 
Mickey Mouse
 "THE LINES BETWEEN children's television and the Federal Government are blurred," Anna Quindlen wrote in The New York Times, ". . . and if people get the government they deserve, are we all Mickey Mouse?"
Whence Mickey Mouse as a symbol of childishness, and its use as a slang adjective with a meaning ranging from "cockamamie" to "rudimentary" to "unsophisticated"? The Oxford English Dictionary defines the Americanism as "something small, insignificant or worthless," but that misses the nuance of dismaying oversimplification.
The cartoon character with the alliterative name was created by Walt Disney in the late 1920's, and George Orwell turned the name into an adjective in 1936, writing of "a sort of Mickey Mouse universe where things and people don't have to obey the rules of space and time."
Mickey was a mouse, and mice are small; a Mickey Mouse spot became the smallest spotlight in a motion-picture studio. The phrase was used in World War II British military slang to describe complicated machinery, but this sense soon atrophied; the use of the cartoon character on inexpensive children's wristwatches gave it an added meaning of cheapness.
To go to the mouse's mouth about the source for the current sense of simplism, I shot a query to Dave Smith, the archivist for Disney Studios in Burbank, Calif.
"Carl Nater, who worked on our educational films during World War II, had an explanation," said Mickey's historian. "He said the Government once sent its accountants to the studio, and they were dismayed by the way we kept the books -- they found overhead charges for the office in New York, scribbled notes, that sort of thing. One of the accountants exclaimed, 'What a Mickey Mouse way of bookkeeping!' and that's how that sense of the phrase was born."

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory

 BODY:

Mideast Crisis Makes Cruises Alter Course
Enthusiasm for taking cruises to the eastern Mediterranean has all but disappeared because of tensions in the Middle East. Two deluxe cruise lines, Crystal Cruises and the Seabourn Cruise Line, have responded by canceling their plans to operate ships in the region next year.
Duncan Beardsley, president of Seabourn, said, "People are still interested in the Mediterranean, but not the eastern part."
Seabourn, based in San Francisco, said it had rerouted six cruises of the Seabourn Pride, a 204-passenger ship, which had been scheduled to embark from Venice and make stopovers in Istanbul between May and August. Instead of Istanbul, Seabourn said the ship will make stopovers in Lisbon, Nice and other western Mediterranean ports.
Crystal, based in Los Angeles, said its 960-passenger Crystal Harmony, which was to make seven cruises in the eastern Mediterranean between August and November, would be recalled to the United States. Crystal said the ship would likely operate between New York and Montreal, with stopovers in New England. Before the tensions arising from Iraq's seizure of Kuwait, the ship's destinations were to have included Istanbul, Odessa and Alexandria.
"We are responding to our guests' requests," said Darlene Papalini, a Crystal spokeswoman. "There is just a reluctance to travel to the eastern Mediterranean." Both companies said passengers who had booked passage on the canceled cruises were being offered alternative routes or their money back.
 
Polar Voyage On Soviet Ship
Western passengers can travel aboard a nuclear-powered Soviet icebreaker when she sets off July 26, 1991, from Murmansk to Nome, Alaska, via the North Pole. After the voyage -- said to be the first complete transpolar voyage on any vessel -- the ship, the Sovetsky Soyuz, will depart from Nome (pending United States Government approval) on Aug. 19 and return to Murmansk through the Northeast Passage, bound for remote towns in northern Siberia, offshore islands and the North Cape of Norway.
The two 21-day voyages, offered by Salen Lindblad Cruising, will cost from $25,000 to $32,000 a person, depending on the choice of cabin.
The 500-foot vessel has 48 twin cabins, two lounges, a dining room, pool and sauna and lecture theater. The ship attains a cruising speed of 18.8 knots at sea and 10 knots through ice five feet thick.
The ship has two lounges as well as a dining room, two saunas, gymnasium, indoor pool and a 100-seat tiered lecture theater with stage. Information: Salen Lindblad Cruising, 203-967-2900 or 800-223-5688.
 
Eurailpass for Car and Trains
Eurailpass will introduce three programs for 1991 and expand its destinations. For the first time, the pass -- allowing unlimited train travel in 17 countries -- will be valid throughout unified Germany, including Berlin. Eurailpass also has introduced a EurailDrive Pass, which offers travelers the combined use of rail and rental car in 16 countries.
The program allows four days of rail travel and three days of Hertz car rental within a 21-day period. The per-person rate, when two or more people travel together, is $269 for an economy car, $289 for a small car and $299 for medium size. In this plan, the rental car may be returned to any city in the country where the car was picked up.
Eurailpass has also expanded its Youthpasses for next year. Travelers under the age of 26 may use the rail system for 15 individual days of second-class travel during a three-month period for a cost of $340; 30 days of travel during that period costs $540.
The declining value of the dollar has led to price increases for most other Eurailpasses. In 1991, the consecutive-day price structure will be: $390 for 15 days of first-class travel; $498 for 21 days; $616 for a month; $840 for two months, and $1,042 for three months. Fifteen days of first-class travel between April 1 and Sept. 30 will be $298 a person, for travel by three or more people. Further information may be obtained by writing: Eurailpass, Post Office Box 325, Old Greenwich, Conn. 06870.
 
Club France Offers Benefits
Francophiles can help the new American Center in Paris (opening in 1992) as well as earn benefits related to travel in France by joining the new Club France formed by the French Government Tourist Office. The annual membership of $65 includes a $15 contribution to the American Center. Membership benefits, which the tourist office says begin Jan. 1, include entry in monthly drawings for round-trip air tickets to Paris and for FrenchRail and rail-and-drive passes. Members also receive a subscription to the quarterly France Magazine, a newsletter and a Michelin Red Guide to France. Members also get reductions at certain hotels in France, room upgrades, or free breakfast or dinner at some establishments and shopping and car-rental discounts. To join, send a check for $65 payable to the French Government to the French Government Tourist Office, 610 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10020
 
A $6 Dinner In Prague
 PRAGUE -- The kosher restaurant in Prague's Jewish Town Hall, long a lunchtime haunt of tourists and local people, Jews and non-Jews alike, recently began serving evening meals. The dinnertime ambiance -- tablecloths, low lights and a pianist -- is more sophisticated than the clamor at lunchtime.
One simple set menu, changing daily, is available at lunch, which costs about $3.50. In the evening, there is a more ambitious choice of three set menus ranging from $2 to $6 and, unlike at lunch, alcoholic beverages are served. The $6 dinner, called the supermenu, includes appetizer, soup, fish, vegetables, main meat course, dessert and fruit, coffee or tea.
The restaurant, in a high-ceilinged, ground-floor hall of the bright pink Old Jewish Town Hall on Maiselova Street, is around the corner from the Old-New Synagogue and the various parts of the Jewish Museum, including the Old Cemetery. The Town Hall, originally built in the 16th century and still the headquarters of the Prague Jewish community, is a five-minute walk from the Old Town Square. -- RUTH GRUBER
 
Diversions For Children
For children who ask "Are we there yet?" the American Automobile Association offers a "Travel Activity Book," which includes pictures to color and a variety of puzzles and games. Most items in the 144-page book, which is organized by state, are related to travel and help introduce youngsters to geography, nature and history. The book can be purchased at many bookstores and at most A.A.A. offices. The list price is $4.95.
 
REPAIRING STORM DAMAGE TO VERSAILLES GARDENS
 PARIS -- A stroll through the gardens of Versailles as winter approaches reveals the results of efforts by gardeners who, with the help of volunteers, soldiers and Boy Scouts, have restored some of the beauty after a devastating storm last February. Winds of 100 miles an hour took 1,300 trees, including 39 along the Tapis Vert, the main axis of the garden between the chateau and the canal.
Gaps in the walls of trees that define the major areas of the garden designed by Andre Le Notre, the landscape architect, are to be found throughout the park, but the most serious damage was done to the bosquets, openings in the wooded parts containing fountains, statues and benches. The Room of the Chestnuts was left with no chestnuts at all.
However, the debris has been carried away and 40 new trees planted. A mix of other, faster-growing trees and some hardwood varieties have been set out. These new plantings allow one to feel something of the effect of the young Versailles, evoking the appearance of the garden under Louis XIV. The restoration work on the north side has proceeded more slowly than on the south. A substantial area is still closed to the public, and many fallen trees remain on the ground. Both Trianons also suffered important losses.
An informational exhibit has been set up by the staff of the chateau around the Basin of Apollo near the canal. It points out that this is the third time that Versailles has lost most of its old trees.
 The gardens are open until dusk every day; admission is free. -- GUY WALTON

SECTION: Section 5; Page 14; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SUN;
A Guide to Island Water Sports

BYLINE: By STANLEY CARR

 BODY:
DEMANDS for more active vacations, spurred by the drive for fitness, have encouraged the growth of sports facilities for visitors to the Caribbean. The trend has helped develop water sports on all the islands. Most have dive shops, with beginners' and certification courses, as well as centers that put visitors on rented windsurfing boards and give them lessons, and organize sailing, snorkeling and water skiing.
How busy these enterprises are during the high season, which begins next weekend, will probably reflect the health of tourism generally in the islands this winter. Last season was disrupted by Hurricane Hugo, which caused extensive damage in the eastern Caribbean in September and dissuaded many vacationers from going anywhere in the region. The chilly economy in the United States threatens to discourage visits again, though tourism officials hope that high prices in Europe and the crisis in the Middle East may impel travelers to substitute the Caribbean for a trip across the Atlantic and help produce a good season. "We're safe," said Marcella Martinez, the spokeswoman in New York for the Caribbean Tourism Organization, "and we're nearby." 
 Despite the slower economy, American Airlines and the San Juan Port Authority in Puerto Rico are cooperating on plans to expand American's San Juan hub at the Luis Munoz Marin Airport, which the airline made the focal point of its Caribbean route network, starting in 1986. The hub, established in 1986, has allowed American to add Caribbean flights from cities other than New York and has increased the number of flights from San Juan to many of the islands.
Robert Crandall, president of American, said last month that the hub would be enlarged to about four times its current size. Plans range from a new passenger concourse and more wide-body gates to new customs facilities. The Port Authority has announced it will build a new control tower, a new hotel and a parking lot for 4,000 cars.
Connections from Puerto Rico or from St. Martin are vital to islands like Montserrat, Dominica, St. Eustatius, Martinique and Guadeloupe, which do not have direct service from the United States. Martinique and Guadeloupe will have a direct flight once a week from Kennedy International Airport starting next Saturday, on Minerve Airlines, a French charter company.
The following review of some of the water sports facilities in the Caribbean and the Bahamas ranges from the haunts of dedicated scuba divers on Bonaire in the Netherlands Antilles and windsurfing lessons in Antigua to chartering fishing boats on French St. Martin and sailboats in the British Virgin Islands. The hotels and resorts listed generally have water sports or beaches or both to offer.
Unless otherwise stated, their room rates are for a double room per day. Many hotels also offer M.A.P. (Modified American Plan), providing breakfast and dinner at an additional daily cost.
Throughout the Caribbean room taxes imposed by island governments are added to hotel bills and these vary from 5 to about 12 percent. Many hotels also add a service charge that theoretically absolves the visitor from tipping and is usually around 10 percent. In the Dominican Republic, for example, hotels add a service tax of 10 percent and a Government tax of 11 percent (and restaurants generally charge 10 percent service as well as a 6 percent tax).
But the republic's all-inclusive resorts usually include taxes and service, as the all-inclusive resorts do elsewhere, including Jamaica (where there are 11 of them). Vacationers should check on taxes and service when they make reservations.
 
ANGUILLA
 
ANGUILLA TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
271 MAIN STREET, NORTHPORT, N.Y. 11768
(800-553-4939 and 212-869-0402)
 
Overview
 Three wrecked ships that were aground at Sandy Ground and a fourth that was lying on its side in shallow water -- and obstructing the view -- in Road Bay were refloated and sunk as artificial reefs in the reef system this year. The four vessels, which are now dive sites, were cleaned of oil and other environmentally damaging material and sunk in waters 60 to 110 feet deep. They have already atracted schools of fish. The 35-square-mile island has several other wrecks and walls as well as reefs that serve as dive sites. One site, Prickly Pear, is an underwater canyon with ledges and caverns at from 30 to 70 feet. At Grouper Bowl, at 25 to 50 feet, larger groupers are found among the overhangs and small caverns.
Most of the hotels on this island near St. Martin offer water sports, although the Mariners at Sandy Ground has more equipment and is more water-oriented than most. Meads Bay, site of the Malliouhana and the Carimar Beach Club, is favored by sailors and windsurfers. The Coccoloba Plantation resort's beach is rated excellent for snorkeling, and so is Shoal Bay, home of Shoal Bay Villas and the Fountain Beach Hotel, and Rendezvous Bay, because of its point jutting out to deeper water. The Cinnamon Reef Beach Club is noted for its windsurfing.

Hotels
 The 50-room Mariners provides snorkeling equipment, Sunfish sailboats and Mistral windsurfers for guests, and a Mistral instructor is available. For daytime and sunset sails, the hotel has a 49-foot catamaran, the Princess Soya, which was used recently for a marriage ceremony. Room rates at the Mariners are $215 to $250 a day for a double. Breakfast and dinner costs another $45 a person a day.
Other rates, for two: Malliouhana, from $450; Carimar, $285 for a one-bedroom apartment; Coccoloba, from $360 with full breakfast; Shoal Bay Villas, $195, and Fountain Beach, $210.
 
Transportation
 From New York on American or Pan American to San Juan and St. Maarten (Dutch), then on American Eagle from San Juan and on Windward Island Airways from St. Maarten. From Antigua on L.I.A.T., from St. Thomas with Air B.V.I. and Windward, from St. Kitts on L.I.A.T. Daily boat services from Marigot (St. Martin); $8 one way.
 
ANTIGUA
 
ANTIGUA DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-541-4117)
 
Overview
 Sailing, windsurfing, snorkeling, scuba diving, water skiing and deep-sea fishing are all available on this 108-square-mile island, the largest in the Leeward Islands. The island says it has a beach for every day of the year, and describes itself as the sailing capital of the Caribbean. Antigua Sailing Week, held at English Harbour in late April, is the Caribbean's largest regatta and attracts some of the world's fastest yachts. Several of the island's many hotels offer a variety of craft for rent, with or without crews. The Antigua School of Sailing has lessons for beginners and the experienced; its programs include a six-day course aboard a ship.
A number of cruises, most of which last several hours and include lunch and sightseeing, ply the island's jagged coast. One of the boats is the Falcon, which does sunset and day cruises to Barbuda, Antigua's small sister island.
For windsurfing, the sheltered west coast is right for beginners, while the Atlantic rollers that come in on the east shore challenge advanced surfers. Lessons are available at some hotels, including the Jolly Beach Resort and Lord Nelson's Beach Hotel (Patrick Scales Water Sports).
Scuba diving and snorkeling enthusiasts find accessible shallow reefs as well as deep coral canyons, caves and wrecks. Among the many sites around the coast are Thunderhead, a wreck-strewn site in only 35 feet of water with sloping hard corals, and the Chimney, a small cave 60 feet down with sponge-filled gullies descending to 80 feet. Among several dive shops offering lessons, equipment rental and guided dive trips are the Aquanaut Diving Centers at the Galleon Beach Club, the Ramada Renaissance Royal Antiguan and the St. James Club; Dive Antigua at the Halcyon Cove Hotel, Dive Runaway at the Runaway Beach Club and the Long Bay Dive Shop at the Long Bay Hotel.
Water skiing, jet skiing and parasailing are available at a number of hotels and such sports centers as the Wadadli Watersports Center at Buccaneer Cove and Unlimited Hydro Sports at Dickenson Bay and Jolly Beach. Nicholson Yacht Charters is one of the charter boat companies that arrange deep-sea fishing for grouper, snapper and other fish.
 
Hotels
 Antigua has a large selection of accommodations and most have water sports programs. Some water sports are complimentary at Antigua Village, a Mediterranean-style condominium resort amid palm trees and bougainvillea at Dickenson Bay. One- and two-bedroom villas sleep up to six people. Reservations: R.S.I, 212-661-4540.
The secluded Blue Waters has 47 rooms and 8 villas on 14 acres with 2 beaches. There is indoor and outdoor dining with nightly entertainment. Reservations: David Mitchell, 800-372-1323.
The Jolly Beach is a 475-room resort on a one-mile stretch of beach. It has complimentary water sports. Reservations: 800-321-1055.
Long Bay Hotel consists of 20 rooms and 6 cottages, with a restaurant, on a spit of land with protected bay on one side and beach on the other. Reservations: Resorts Management at 212-696-4566 or 800-225-4255.

Transportation
 From New York on B.W.I.A., American, Continental and Pan Am (via Miami); from Miami on B.W.I.A., Pan Am and American.
 
ARUBA
 
ARUBA TOURIST BUREAU
521 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10175
(212-246-3030)
 
Overview
 This originally Dutch island 15 miles north of Venezuela has increased its number of visitors for five consecutive years. Swimming and sightseeing on foot or with rental scooters are the main daytime activities. At night there are high-rise hotel dinner shows, seven casinos, plays and poetry readings, and on Tuesday from 6:30 P.M., a Bonbini Festival, a Government-underwritten party at which tourists and Arubans can meet. Token admission is $1.15, half price for children.
The newest of the island's 70-odd restaurants is the Waterfront Crabhouse (at the main harbor in Oranjestad, the capital; telephone 35858). Among entrees are live Maine lobsters. A four- or five-course dinners costs a couple about $70.
Aruba offers all water sports the year round, and its annual fishing and windsurfing competitions generally attract professional and amateur participants from six to eight countries, turning the beaches involved into weeklong carnivals, with snack tents and almost endless live entertainment by local bands and dance groups.
 
Hotels
 The Divi Tamarijn Beach Resort, 97 L. G. Smith Boulevard (800 367-3484) is an informal, seaside low-rise hotel with the motto "barefoot elegance." Rates for the 236 rooms, seven nights, no meals, are from $1,575 to $1,750. (A 5 percent Government tax is added to room rates on Aruba.) Two restaurants, bar, pool, shops, tennis, outdoor seafood buffet. A young American windsurfer, Gary Smith, is Tamarijn's resident water pro. Scuba equipment, jet skis, floats, Sunfish boats and catamarans may be rented. Windsurfing enthusiasts cam sail for a week with unlimited use of gear and clinics and lessons for $150.
Hyatt Regency Aruba Resort and Casino, 85 L. G. Smith Boulevard (800-233-1234) is a new nine-story hotel on Palm Beach. There are 360 rooms. Rates, without meals, are from $1,680 to $2,555. Two restaurants, two bars, tennis, casino, triple-level pool complex and freshwater lagoon with tropical fish and wildlife. Water activities are run by Red Sail Sports, which offers scuba diving at $77 a day for beginners and less for accomplished divers. A brief snorkel trip including equipment is $19, Sunfish boat rentals are $22 an hour. Hobie cats are $27.50; advanced surfboards $22. Wet-suit rentals are $9 a day and filled air tanks another $9. Sunset sails with snacks and complimentary bar are $27.50 (half price for children) and three-hour dinner cruises cost $49.50.
 
Transportation
 From New York daily on American, and (from Newark) on Air Aruba and, Thursday through Monday, on Continental. From Miami daily on A.L.M. Antillian Airlines, Air Aruba and B.W.I.A., and American via San Juan.
 
THE BAHAMAS
 
BAHAMAS TOURIST OFFICE
150 EAST 52d STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10022
 (212-758-2777)
 
Overview
 The real beauty of the Bahamas lies not in its history or its mix of island architecture, food and folklore but in its waters. Most of the water is very shallow with a sandy bottom (the word Bahama comes from the Spanish baja mar, meaning shallow waters), making the colors of the sea breathtaking hues of green and blue. In general, the farther north in the chain of 700 islands you go, the deeper the water is, making it safer for charter boat cruising, while the farther south, the more dramatic the colors of the water.
The capital, Nassau, is on the island of New Providence, a major tourism and offshore banking center with three principal resort areas: Cable Beach, known as the Bahamian Riviera, Paradise Island, and on the south side of New Providence, Divi Bahamas, which attracts sports enthusiasts. Visitors who want a quiet vacation might prefer to stay in a smaller resort or inn on one of the Family Islands. They won't find casinos and night life on the Family Islands, but they will discover the fun of trying to catch a slippery bonefish. Almost all the resorts have a variety of water sports activities including snorkeling, water skiing, sailing (most have Sunfish, Hobie cats and sailboards or similar boats for rent). Parasailing, banana boat rides and jet skis are available along the Bahamian Riviera and Paradise Island, where boats, kept at a safe distance from swimmers, pick up visitors who want to venture to a reef or island nearby.
 
Hotels
 New Providence. Each of the hotels along the Bahamian Riviera is quite different, from the razzle-dazzle Carnival's Crystal Palace, home of the world's most expensive hotel suite, a $25,000-a-night fantasy complete with Ursula the robot who passes you a towel as you step out of the bath. Regular room rates are $175 to $315, depending on room and time of week. Two meals are available at $36 a person a day. Crystal Palace has 13 restaurants, fitness center and sports including snorkeling, water skiing, banana boats, jet skis, parasailing and sailing. Nearby, but much quieter, is the Meridien Royal Bahamian Hotel, where tea is served in the lobby of the Manor House at 4 P.M. The hotel has a smallish beach, but a complete water sports program. Room rates range from $165 a day to $380; villas are $500.
Divi Bahamas is a sprawling 220-acre resort with the most complete scuba diving program on New Providence. Rooms are $280 a day. Except for dive trips, water sports are included.
On the Family Islands. On Windermere Island, Eleuthera, a guard raises the gate over the single-lane bridge to admit you to the Windermere Island where the private club awards temporary membership to stay in the hotel. This is where Prince Charles and the Princess of Wales spent their honeymoon. The island is five miles long and no more than a half-mile wide. On one side lies the Atlantic Ocean trimmed in five uninterrupted miles of pinkish-white sand. On the leeward side is another beach, a dock and full water sports facilities. Except for a private bonefishing guide ($40), water sports are included in the room rate. There is sailing, kayaking, canoeing, snorkeling, windsurfing (12 new sailboards), six tennis courts. Direct flights are available from Miami to Governor's Harbor or Rock Sound, Eleuthera, both less than 20 miles away, or you may request the club's private plane to pick you up in Miami, Fort Lauderdale or West Palm Beach, Fla. Round trip is $155. Rooms range from $320 for two, with two meals, to $820 for four in a two-bedroom cottage, with two meals. Villas are available from $450 to $900. Reservations: 800-237-1236.
Cotton Bay Club, Rock Sound, Eleuthera, is on a 450-acre palm grove and has one of the finest beaches in the Bahamas. Water sports, including sailing and fishing. Daily rates are $250 to $310 for two; two meals a day cost $45 per person. Direct flights available to Rock Sound from Miami. Reservations: 800-223-1588 or 212-661-4540.
Stella Maris Resort Club on Long Island -- one of the most unspoiled of all the Bahamian islands -- has a fleet of dive boats. Lessons, training tanks and certification are available. Deep-sea fishing and bonefishing trips. Flights from Fort Lauderdale aboard the resort's plane can be arranged. Rates are $106 to $270 for double rooms and $270 for a villa. Two meals a day are $34 a person. Reservations or flight: 800-426-0466.
 
Transportation
 From New York to Nassau on Pan American, Delta and American. Feeder airlines fly to the Family Islands.
