BARBADOS
 
BARBADOS BOARD OF TOURISM
800 SECOND AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-986-6516 and, outside New York, 800-221-9831)
 
Overview
 The sheltered west coast is ideal for water sports ranging from Hobie Cat and Sunfish sailing, jet skiing, parasailing and scuba diving to riding the banana -- a plastic tube pulled by speedboat -- deep-sea fishing and windsurfing. Windsurfing has really caught on in Barbados because of the constant breezes offshore, although it's necessary to go a good distance out on the west coast to catch a good breeze. The south coast, especially as one moves southeasterly, becomes choppy with a stiff breeze and is also favored by many small-boat sailors and windsurfers. The big waves of the east coast provide good opportunities for wave surfers, many of whom like an area called the Soup Bowl at Cattlewash that's noted for surfing, boogie boarding and body surfing.
Scuba divers examine the marine life in the island's coral reefs and in three sunken wrecks, including the freighter Stavronikita near Folkestone Underwater Park, a marine reserve just off the St. James coast devoted to research and protection of marine life as well as recreation.
Most hotel beaches and other beaches on the west and south coasts -- but not east and north -- offer good swimming. Recommended beaches for picnicking and swimming are: Brandons at Brighton in St. Michael; Rockley Beach, Enterprise (also known as Miami) Beach in Christ Church, and the Crane Beach and Long Bay in St. Philip.
On the south coast at Silver Sands, the Silver Rock Windsurfing Club charges $15 for use of a windsurfer for an hour and also rents wave skis at $5 an hour. Windsurfing lessons -- only in the high-performance category because of the lively waves here -- are $30 an hour; contact Brian Talma (809-428-2866).
Grand Barbados Beach Resort (809-426-9947) runs a scuba diving school where the rates are $50 for a resort class and one dive ($20 for class only), $350 for a certification course, $40 for daily dive trips (or $35 for divers with own equipment), $40 for night dives and $140 for a six-dive package, with all equipment supplied.
The Club Mistral (809-428-7277) is a windsurfing club for intermediate to advanced sailors that also operates at Silver Sands Hotel (809-428-6001). Deep-sea fishing trips are arranged by Jolly Roger Watersport at both the Colony Club, St. James (809-422-2335), and at Sunset Crest (809-432-7090).

Hotels
 The 130-room Grand Barbados at Carlisle Bay on the west coast charges from $220 for a double room. Sailing, scuba instruction and snorkeling equipment are provided. Divi Southwinds has 166 units in St. Lawrence on the southwest shore, from $230. Divi St. James in Vauxhall on the western side, with 130 rooms, is $255 to $305. Heywoods in St. Peter on the west coast has 300 rooms in seven buildings, with rates of $160 to $350.
 
Transportation
 From New York and Miami, American, B.W.I.A. and Pan American.
 
BONAIRE
 
BONAIRE GOVERNMENT TOURIST OFFICE
275 SEVENTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10001
(212-242-7707)
 
Overview
 This reef-ringed Netherlands Antilles island 50 miles north of Venezuela likes to think of itself as child friendly. Vacationing parents and children go to Bonaire for casual snorkeling, cave exploring, swimming, flamingo-watching and bicycling, but the island of just 10,012 people also maintains a reputation as a haven for the world's diving elite. Its remarkable coral passages and large variety of sea life, coupled with availability of equipment, has been attracting experienced divers for four decades. Almost any area of Bonaire is ideal for diving. Three good swimming sites are Pink Beach, Playa Dachi and Dac Bay.
 
Hotels
 Flamingo Beach Hotel and Casino, J. A. Abraham Boulevard (telephone in the United States 800-367-3484) is on its own beach in Kralendijk, the principal town. There are 145 rooms with winter rates for one or two people, seven nights, no meals, from $875 to $1,505. Two restaurants, two pools, shops, lighted tennis, casino. The Dive Bonaire facility at the hotel offers guided snorkeling at $15 a person a day plus equipment rental charges. Water picnics, windsurfing, sailing also available.
Captain Don's Habitat, at the edge of town on one of the world's top-rated diving beaches (8290 and 800-327-6709), was a few years ago a handful of cottages with bare essentials. Now its founder, the diver Don Stewart, has become a sought-after advisor to governments on undersea ecology and Habitat has become a small village with accreditations from the world's diving organizations. A room for two for seven nights is from $637 to $1,236, and villas are $3,012 for four people and $3,900 for six.
Habitat has a restaurant, two bars, nightclub, pool, and underwater photo and video center. Seven licensed divers teach in five languages, earning Habitat accreditations as a "PADI 5-star Center," "S.S.I. Center," and "N.A.U.I. Destination." Windsurfing and blue-water fishing are offered and there are seven dive boats for visits to sunken wrecks and other sites. Beginner courses cost $100 for two days and three dives; PADI Master Scuba Diver instruction is $500. Equipment rentals run $4.50 a day for mask and snorkel to $50 a day for video camera.

Transportation
 From New York daily on American with change of plane at Aruba, connecting with Air Aruba, or at Curacao, connecting with A.L.M. Antillian Airlines. Also from New York on A.L.M. Saturday and Sunday with change of plane in Curacao. From Newark Thursday through Monday on Continental with change at Aruba, connecting with Air Aruba. From Miami daily on A.L.M. with change at Curacao, and on Air Aruba with change of plane at Aruba.
 
CAYMAN ISLANDS
 
CAYMAN ISLANDS TOURIST BOARD
420 LEXINGTON AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10170
(212-682-5582)
 
Overview
 Diving, snorkeling and other water sports are major attractions on the Caymans, a British colony of three islands, which are circled by coral walls and feature a variety of marine life. Shallow water surrounds the islands and the coral walls mark the dropoff into deep water about 500 yards off shore. From the walls, divers can share sightseeing with eagle rays, turtles and other sea creatures.
On the main island, Grand Cayman, Seven Mile Beach is a favorite for water sports and sunbathing. Windsurfers, wave runners, sailboats and other recreational equipment are available for rent at a number of locations. On Seven Mile Beach, Don Foster's Dive at the Radison Resort Grand Cayman (809-949-5679) offers windsurfing lessons for $30 an hour and sailing lessons for $20 a half hour. A variety of equipment is available for rent: wave runners ($35 half hour), Tiki canoes ($15 half hour), Aquafin sailboats ($10 half hour) and Aquacat Hobie boats ($20 half hour, $35 hour). For those who wish to take to the skies, parasailing is $35 a ride.
Don Foster's also offers a number of diving trips, ranging from $35 to $156. Certification is required for diving, and instruction is available for $85 (for basic diving) to $330 (full open-water certification).
One of the best snorkeling and shore diving areas is at Eden's Landing on Grand Cayman. Equipment is available from Eden Rock Diving Center (809-949-7243).
The biggest new attraction this winter is the Cayman Islands National Museum (809-949-8368) in a restored courthouse, one of the oldest buildings on Grand Cayman. The museum, on the waterfront overlooking the bay, will feature historical and cultural artifacts from government and private collections and offers dining at the Jailhouse Cafe. The museum is open Tuesday-Friday 8:30 A.M.-4 P.M.; Saturday 10 to 5, and Sunday 1 to 5. Admission is $5; children 6-17, $2.50.
 
Hotels
 The following hotels are on Grand Cayman and each features affiliated dive shops offering water sports and equipment rentals. Nightly rates are for rooms for two people.
Radison Resort Grand Cayman (809-949-0088), one of the island's newest hotels, has a covered patio and bar that opens onto a pool and a beach known for its snorkeling. From $215.
Hyatt Regency Grand Cayman (809-949-1234) features golf and tennis and has a beach club and three restaurants. A mixture of Mediterranean and Colonial styles, the hotel offers two pools, including one on the beach. $245 to $430.
Holiday Inn Grand Cayman (809-947-4444) on Seven Mile Beach features a free form pool, a comedy club and beachside bar. $128 to $198.
 
Transportation
 Cayman Airways flies from New York, Houston, Atlanta, Miami and Tampa. Pan American, American and Northwest fly from Miami.
 
CURACAO
 
CURACAO TOURIST BOARD
400 MADISON AVENUE, SUITE 311, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-751-8266)
 
Overview
 Windsurfing sailboards, invented in 1969 by two Californians, have given this southern Caribbean island its national sport. Curacao's larger resort hotels offer guests windsurfing along with other water sports and one is host to two annual pro-amateur windsurfing competitions attracting entrants from Europe and Asia as well as the Americas. The best place to windsurf is in the Marie Pompoen area near the Seaquarium.
A Dutchman, Freek Born, who runs Top Water Sports Curacao at Seaquarium Beach (telephone, 617343), teaches windsurfing to beginners at $20 an hour -- and believes the island has become the Caribbean capital of the sport. He rents Sunfish boats at $10 an hour and stocks snorkel gear, Hobie Cat craft, catamarans, paddle boards and floating mats.
The island has eight good beaches for swimming: Santa Marta Bay, Sherami, Kenapa, Caracas Bay, West Punt, Jan Thiel, Rif (Reef) and Spanish Water.
The Curacao Underwater Park, established in 1983 to safeguard hundreds of acres of coral reef and inner bay, includes 16 dive sites.

Hotels
 Lion's Dive Hotel and Marina, Bapor Kibra, Willemstad (611644) is near the Seaquarium complex and has the 30-mile Underwater Park starting almost at its door. Rates for the 77 rooms are $770 for seven nights, breakfast included, as are service charge and government tax. It has a skin-diving school with two boats that make a total of four outings a day. Rates for beginners are $300 a person a week, with about 10 dives. Certification lessons available. Rentals of other water sports gear offered.
Princess Beach Hotel and Casino, Dr. Martin Luther King Boulevard, Willemstad (614944 or 800-223-9815) has 200 rooms and rates of $982 to $1,269 for two, including service tax and tax, for seven nights. The hotel is on the beach in a residential part of town near the Seaquarium. There is a free hourly bus to downtown shops. The Princess is the host of two windsurfing tournaments, and the recreation director says windsurfing is second only to swimming in guest popularity. Water equipment rentals available.
 
Transportation
 From New York daily on American, and Saturday and Sunday on A.L.M. Antillian Airlines. From Miami daily on A.L.M. and American via San Juan.
 
DOMINICA
 
CARIBBEAN TOURISM ORGANIZATION
20 EAST 46TH STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-682-0435)
 
Overview
 The 29-mile-long mountainous island between Guadeloupe and Martinique is very different from the Dominican Republic, with which it is often confused. It attracts nature lovers to its hiking trails, waterfalls, rivers and a 16,000-acre rain forest set aside as a national park. Underwater, it boasts hundreds of varieties of reef fish, masses of black coral, hard and soft corals and deep seafans. Diving must be undertaken through one of the island's registered operators or with written permission from the Fisheries Division. Dive centers are at the Castle Comfort Dive Lodge, Picard Beach Cottage Resort, Portsmouth Beach Hotel, Anchorage Hotel and Castaways Beach Hotel. Most of the diving sites are found on the west coast. Underwater visibility is 80 to 100 feet. Portsmouth, the best harbor, is close to beaches and to Indian River which can be explored by canoe.
 
Hotels
 The casual Castaways Beach Hotel, on a one-mile long gray sand beach 11 miles north of Roseau, the capital, has 27 oceanview units. It includes a new water sports center that arranges snorkeling, windsurfing, water skiing and other sports. There are two boats, holding 10 and 12 divers, two divemasters, 22 dive sites (most are about 20 minutes from the hotel shore). Shore diving available. A one-tank dive will cost about $40. Side trips can be scheduled for the rain forest, the Layou River, bird watching, hiking. Hotel rates are $100 a night for two, $120 for three. Fans or air-conditioning are another $5 a day. Reservations: I.T.R., 212-545-8469 or 800-223-9815.
Picard Beach Cottage Resort on the northwest coast offers all water sports (except scuba diving) free. Along with other hotels, it is served by the Waitikubuli Diver Center (809-44-82638), which has two boats and offers certification courses. Single and double tank dives cost $40 to $60 an hour. The resort has an aerobic center, a freshwater pool, one restaurant and one bar. The 18 wooden cottages all have kitchens and fans. Beachview room, $95; beachfront room, $110. Reservations: Robert Reid, 800-223-6510.
Anchorage Hotel is a 32-room seafront hotel a half-mile south of Roseau. It has squash court, freshwater pool and dive shop on premises. One restaurant and one bar. Snorkeling is $5 an hour; windsurfing and water skiing, $10 an hour; scuba diving, $40 an hour. Reservations: 800-223-6510.
 
Transportation
 Dominica is not served directly from the United States mainland. You can fly L.I.A.T. from San Juan and Antigua, Air Caribe from San Juan and Air Martinique from Martinique and Guadeloupe. The new Nature Island Express, a privately owned Dominica airline, flies from Barbados, St. Maarten and St. Lucia. The Caribbean Express ferryboat provides daily service from Martinique and Guadeloupe.
 
DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
 
DOMINICAN REPUBLIC TOURIST INFORMATION CENTER
485 MADISON AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10022
212-826-0750)
 
Overview
 The United States dollar remains strong against the Dominican peso. Tourists are cautioned, however, not to exchange currency with street hawkers. Tourism is the country's largest industry.
In the capital, Santo Domingo, the most popular beach with local people is Boca Chica, about 30 minutes southwest of the city, and when they want a picnic lunch they buy fresh fried fish, fried plantains and johnny cakes (a fried, thin dough) from the women merchants who cook on the spot. Some Santo Domingo hotels offer transport to Boca Chica Beach.
In the capital area, a group called Actividades Marinas del Caribe (A.M.C.) offers scuba diving packages. You would have to provide your own air travel and hotel. A.M.C. plans dives in the National Marine Park in La Caleta, where visitors explore the coral reef bottom and see two colonial-era wrecks and cannons. A four-day scuba diving package at $400 includes dives at La Caleta, La Romana and Bayahibe. A.M.C. can be reached at Post Office Box 21449, La Caleta National Park, La Caleta, Dominican Republic (809-530-1837).
 
Hotels
 The all-inclusive Boca Chica Beach Resort, with its gardens, rattan and stained wood furnishings, has 209 units in 11 buildings. Buffet meals and all drinks and snacks as well as sailing, windsurfing, snorkeling, scuba clinic and horseback riding are covered by the room rate. Waterskiing is $20 for a half-hour; scuba, $20 the half-hour. Deep-sea fishing available. The dive shop called Dolphin Sub Marino is a three-minute walk from the hotel. Dives cost approximately $45. Two dive boats; reef and wreck diving. Rooms are $200 and one-bedroom suites (with kitchen and living room) $220. Under age 12: $20 a child per two adults. United States representative: I.T.R., 212-545-8469.
The Casa de Campo, in La Romana on the Caribbean, was developed in the early 1970's as a resort area with luxurious homes. Many sports and activities are available in the Casa de Campo complex. Among them are deep-sea fishing (a 31-foot boat for half a day for eight people, $275); scuba diving (dive, equipment and transportation, $60); windsurfing, $12 an hour, and Hobie Cat, $27 an hour. Visitors fish for snook on the Chavon River on half-day trips at $21 a person, all equipment supplied.
To reach Casa de Campo you can fly to Santo Domingo and pay $34 a person (round trip) for the 90-minute ride to La Romana, or you can fly direct to La Romana from San Juan. Daily room rate, $230. Reservations: Premier Resorts, 800-223-6620 or 305-856-5405.
On the north coast, with golden sand beaches on the Atlantic Ocean side of the island, is the Puerto Plata resort area. Puerto Plata is an old colonial town that was a commercial port and fortress in the 16th century.
If you are looking for simple accommodations and arrange your own air travel, you can use the Puerto Plata Diving Club. Five days, four nights, two dives (one boat dive, one shore dive), two meals a day and airport transfers costs $385 a person, double occupancy. If you are not part of the package, you can rent equipment from the club. Mask, snorkel, fins are $7.50 a day; complete Scuba rental package, $29 a day.
The Dorado Naco Resort Hotel offers deep-sea fishing at $90 a person, scuba diving for $65, wall dives $70. Snorkeling, windsurfing, sailing free for one hour a day for hotel guests. Snorkeling classes and scuba diving classes free for guests. If you stay at the hotel, the daily cost of a room, without meals, is $110 for a one-bedroom, $150 for a two-bedroom or a penthouse. Representative in Florida: 305-284-9900.
 
Transportation
 From New York and Miami: American, Pan American, Dominicana and Continental (Newark). From Puerto Rico: American Eagle flies to the Punta Cana and Puerto Plata resort areas.
 
GRENADA
 
GRENADA DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM
820 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 900D, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-687-9554)
 
Overview
 Grand Anse Beach, a mile long, 10 minutes from the capital, St. George's, and heart of the island's hotel development, is the best beach for swimming, snorkeling, water skiing, wind surfing and other water sports. Grand Anse is also ideal for scuba excursions to the wreck of the ocean liner Bianca C one mile offshore in about 100 feet of water.
Several other beaches on the southern tip are within easy reach by car and good for swimming, snorkeling and picnicking. Among them are La Sagesse and the Morne Rouge. The Atlantic beaches on the north and east coasts offer surf bathing and a greater seclusion for picnics. All beaches are open to free use. The sister island of Carriacou, an 18-minute flight away, has unspoiled bgeaches and good opportunities for snorkeling.
Yachts may be chartered from Grenada Yacht Services (809-440-2508), Spice Island Marine Services (809-444-4342) or The Moorings (809-444-4449).
The island's annual international triathlon -- swimming, bicycling and running -- is set for Jan. 19.

Hotels
 Ramada Renaissance Hotel on Grand Anse Beach, with 186 rooms, is Grenada's largest hotel. Daily rates from $183 double. Water sports are arranged through Dive Grenada. Rates for water sports include the following: windsurfing, board rental, $7 per half-hour; instruction $10. Sunfish boat rental, $10 for half-hour; instruction $10. Water skiing, two-mile run, $15; instruction $20. Scuba diving, including equipment, boat trip and dive leader, single dive $37; four dives $140; instruction for one and a half hours, pool and reef dive, $50.
Coyaba Beach Hotel on Grand Anse Beach with 40 rooms is a family-run hotel with daily rates from $125 for two. Water sports arranged through Grenada Aquatics. Windsurfing, board rental, $15 an hour; instruction $15. Sunfish, boat rental $20 an hour; instruction, $15. Scuba diving, including equipment, boat trip and dive leader, single dive $45; five dives, $190. Bianca C wreck dive, $64.
Secret Harbour Hotel on the southeast coast with 20 rooms is the base for the Moorings, the largest charter yacht service in the world. Daily rates from $198 single or double. Water sports are operated through the Club Mariner. Rates: windsurfing, board rental, $10 an hour. Sunfish, boat rental, $10 an hour. Water skiing, two-mile run, $10. Small boat sailing from $15 an hour. Boat trip with snorkeling to Hog Island, $5 a person.

Transportation
 From New York on B.W.I.A. via Antigua, and American, via San Juan.
 
GUADELOUPE
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-757-1125)
 
Overview
 The most popular scuba dives are at Pigeon island off the west coast, which Jacques Cousteau has called "one of the world's 10 best" diving areas. On the beach at Malendure, facing the island are three schools with licensed instructors: Les Heures Saintes (98.86.63), Chez Guy (98.81.72) and the Nautilus Club (98.85.69). Scuba schools are also based at some of the large hotels, including Aqua-Fari at La Creole Beach (84.26.26). The Centre Nautique des Saintes is on the small island of Terre de Haut just off the southern coast of Basse-Terre, one of the two islands making up Guadeloupe; the other is Grande-Terre.
Sailboats, crewed or bareboat, are plentiful. Full-day picnic sails on the trimaran Grande Voile are organized by local tour operators, as are trips on glass-bottom boats, such as the Tamarin, with morning and afternoon departures, and the Papyrus, offering day and moonlight sails. Snorkeling is especially rewarding at St. Francois reef and the Ilet du Gosier, offshore from the Gosier hotels. Glass-bottom boats are used for snorkeling trips to Pigeon Island.
Deep-sea fishing: The season for barracuda and kingfish is January to May; for tuna, dolphin and bonito, it is December to March. Hotel desks will recommend such deep-sea fishing boats as the Thalassa, based in Bas du Fort at the Port de Plaissance Marina (82.74.94). The best spots for surfing are at Moule, Port Louis and Anse Bertrand. Contact: Philip Caze, Comite Guadeloupeen de Surf (91.77.64.).
Three marinas have been added to the facilities already available at Pointe-a-Pitre's Carenage and at Deshaies on Basse-Terre. Largest is the Bas du Port de Plaisance, with 700 berths, 55 of which are available for visiting boats. The winds and currents of Guadeloupe tend to be strong and it's a true sailor who worships these waters.
There are many beaches, from the dark sands of western Basse-Terre to the long white stretches encircling Grande-Terre. Public beaches are generally free, though some may charge for parking. Unlike hotel beaches, they have few facilities. Hotels welcome non-guests but charge for changing facilities.
 
Hotels
 The Hamak Beach Hotel in St. Francois offers free water sports, except water skiing, in a seven-night package that costs from $1,540 to $2,380 for two people (not including air fare) through Caribbean Inns, Box 7411, Hilton Head, S.C. 29938 (803-785-7411). One day's car rental and a lobster dinner with wine are also included. The standard room rate at the Hamak is $280 a day, with Continental breakfast. Water sports are available, too, at the new Canella Beach Residence, scheduled to open this month at Gosier. It will have 148 rooms and suites, with rooms starting at $130. Repairs and renovations following damage by Hurricane Hugo last fall have been completed at the Auberge de la Vieille Tour in Gosier. The hotel, which has a small beach, charges from $204 for two.
 
Transportation
 From New York on American via San Juan; from Miami and San Juan, Air France; from St. Martin on Air Guadeloupe.
 
HAITI
 
HAITI NATIONAL OFFICE OF TOURISM
18 EAST 41st STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
212-779-7177
 
Overview
 A general election in Haiti is scheduled for Dec. 16. Political unrest since 1985 has devastated the tourist industry, but the country's deserted beaches remain beautiful and service continues to be friendly and courteous. Haiti is for the independent, adventurous traveler, not for those who want constant planned activities and entertainment.
The Macaya Beach Hotel has closed; Club Med's 350-room Magic Isle facility has been closed since August 1987. In Port-au-Prince, the famous Hotel Oloffson and the Holiday Inn-Le Plaza have a steady flow of guests. United States dollars are acceptable everywhere, but change will most likely be given in local currency.
Divers find a vast variety of sponges, coral and fish, and there are spectacular wall dives at Amani'y and La Gonave Island.
 
Hotels
 Ibo Beach on Cacique Island is a half-hour drive north of downtown Port-au-Prince. A seven-minute motorboat ride ($3) takes visitors to the island and includes admission to the beach. Pretty, rustic cabins (with modern conveniences) cost $60 a night for two, including breakfast. Prices for water-sports equipment and lessons are negotiable. You can scuba, swim in the ocean or pool, snorkel and sometimes rent jet skis.
Kyona Beach Club Hotel, 37 miles north of Port-au-Prince, has 20 air-conditioned double rooms at $55 for two, including breakfast. Windsurfing equipment rental is $10 an hour, and snorkeling equipment, $6 a day. Instructors areavailable for windsurfing; price negotiable. Two dining rooms, featuring seafood dishes. Bar with guitar player. Beach admission for day visitors, $2.50.
Kaliko Beach Club at Pointe Paturon, La Gonave Bay, is about a one-and-a-half-hour drive north from Port-au-Prince along a tree-lined road (Route Nationale 1). Rooms in 40 native-style bungalows are $89 for two, with two meals. Restaurant, freshwater pool. Beach part sandy, part rocky. Snorkeling is $10 a day, windsurfing $10 an hour, Hobie Cats $30, scuba dive shop on property, $42 a dive. Represented by I.T.R.: 212-545-8469.
Kaliko Dive Center, the only complete dive center and training facility in Haiti, is on the Kaliko Beach Club property, one minute's walk down the beach. The full rental department has 40 tanks, rental dive store, classroom, equipment repair center. The dive packages include room, breakfast and dinner daily, use of tennis courts, airport transfers, mask, fins and snorkel, tanks, air, equipment, unlimited shore diving, one shore check-out dive and one guided shore night dive. For divers, three-night packages with five dives costs $324 a person.
 
Transportation
 Nonstop from New York: American and A.L.M. Nonstop from Miami: Haiti Trans Air, Pan Am, American, A.L.M.
 
JAMAICA
 
JAMAICA TOURIST BOARD
866 SECOND AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-688-7650)
 
Overview
 Jamaica has a wealth of beaches and water sports to match the size of its coastline -- the island is 146 miles long and up to 51 miles across at its widest. Visitors intrigued by fine beaches for swimming and picnicking should spend time at Bloody Bay at Negril on the west coast, the Doctors Cave and Cornwall Beaches in Montego Bay, Mallards Beach in Ocho Rios, Puerto Seco in Discovery Bay, all on the north shore, and San San Beach in Port Antonio in the northeast. Kingston has Hellshire Beach. While no charge is made at Bloody Bay or Hellshire, entrance fees of around 50 cents and 25 cents for children are charged at the others.
The all-inclusive resorts -- those where the rates include all meals and sports -- offer some of the best scuba-diving facilities for beginners or those wishing to experiment for a day. For the experienced, offshore diving is best along the north and west coasts, particularly Negril. The Negril Scuba Center (809-357-4425) at the Negril Beach Club offers a variety of diving packages for the novice and certified diver. Prices, as at most diving centers, include tanks, weights, boat ride and guide, and on average range from $30 to $50 for a single dive to from $95 to $400 for dive packages. The Airport Reef near the Montego Bay airport, with its mass of coral caves, tunnels and canyons, is considered by some divers to be the best site. Port Royal, near Kingston, the capital, has sunken ships that are a haven for tropical fish and an objective for divers. Among other established dive centers are Poseidon Nemrod (809-952-3624) at the Chalet Caribe Hotel in Reading, near Montego Bay; Garfield Dive Station (809-974-5749), Ocho Rios, and Sun Divers (809-973-2346) at the Club Caribbean in Runaway Bay.
Ocho Rios, Port Antonio, Montego Bay and Kingston-Port Royal are the major deep-sea fishing centers, and Port Antonio is the home of an international marlin tournament every fall. Dolphin, kingfish and wahoo as well as blue and white marlin are plentiful. Boats accommodating up to six passengers can be chartered in the resort areas. Rates are generally in the range of $250 to $300 for half-day charters and $400 to $600 for full-day trips.
Renting a Sunfish sailboat at the Half Moon Golf, Tennis and Beach Club, Montego Bay (809-953-2211), costs $12 an hour, a Hobie catamaran, $35 an hour, and a windsurfing board, from $12 an hour. A two-hour snorkel tour to Shell Island, equipment included, costs $25.
On Jamaica's sports calendar is the Miami-Montego Bay Yacht Race for the Pineapple Cup from Feb. 1 to 9.
 
Hotels
 Among resorts noted for their beaches and water sports facilities is Hedonism II, an all-inclusive on a stretch of Negril's seven-mile beach. All meals and bar drinks as well as sports equipment and entertainment are included in the rates, which range from $1,200 to $1,300 a person in double occupancy, for seven nights. Another is Sandals Montego Bay, also all-inclusive, with rates of from about $2,200 to $2,600 for six nights for two.
The Half Moon Golf, Tennis and Beach Club charges from $250 to $320 a day for a double room. At Runaway Bay, Jamaica Jamaica, an all-inclusive, has rates of $1,200 to $1,350 a person for seven nights. In Ocho Rios, the Boscobel Beach Hotel, an all-inclusive for families, has rates of $1,250 to $1,340 a person for seven nights, with children under age 14 free.
Morgan's Harbour Hotel in Port Royal on the south coast is favored by some divers because of its proximity to the site of an old port that was a haunt of buccaneers before its destruction by an earthquake in 1692. Many lives were lost and much of the town disppeared beneath the sea. Today the remains of buildings and other relics can be seen underwater. In addition to diving, snorkeling and other water sports, the hotel has a marina for 85 boats. Room rates are from $90 to $165. A number of packages are available, including a seven-night diver's plan that costs $975 a person, double occupancy, and includes five offshore dives with an instructor as well as three meals daily.
 
Transportation
 From New York, on Air Jamaica, American Airlines and Continental (from Newark). From Miami, Air Jamaica, Pan Am, American.
 
MARTINIQUE
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-757-1125)
 
Overview
 There are scuba facilities with licensed instructors at Bathy's Club in the Meridien, at Oxygene Blue in Le Bakoua, and on the Planete Bleue boat, all in Pointe du Bout. The U.C.P.A. diving operation is installed on the beach behind the Christophe Colombe Hotel and at Club Marouba, both in Carbet on the northwestern coast; and Tropicasub operates out of the Hotel La Bateliere north of Fort-de-France, as well as next to La Guinguette restaurant in St.-Pierre. In the south, there are scuba operations at Club Mediterranee (for guests only) near Ste.-Anne and at the Diamant-Novotel's Sub Diamond Rock.
Memorable dive spots include Ilet la Perle and the shipwrecks off St.-Pierre in the north, Cap Salomon and Anses d'Arlets on the southwest coast, Diamond Rock and Ste.-Anne in the south. Individual dives average about $50 but most places offer full scuba packages.
Sunfish, sailfish or hobie cats can be rented by the hour from hotel beach shacks; yachts that come bareboat or equipped with a full crew can be chartered by the day, week, or month. Daylong sailing excursions set out from the Marina Pointe du Bout, the Meridien, the Hotel La Bateliere, and other spots, for St.-Pierre in the north and Diamond Rock in the south. A sample full-day trip on the catamaran Micaline, the three-masted schooner Toumelin (telephone, 66.02.85 for either) or the schooner Captain Cap (66.00.00) might include a stop for snorkeling or swimming and a beach picnic lunch and cost of $55 to $60 a person. Affaires Maritimes (71.90.05) is a good source for nautical information, including trips on typical Martinique fishing yawls.
Martinique's capital, Fort-de-France, is a favored harbor with yachters and a point of origin for charter yachts sailing to St. Vincent and the Grenadines. Among outfitters with yacht charters and boat rentals are: Avimer, Le Bakoua Hotel, Pointe du Bout, 97229 Trois-Ilets (66.05.45); A.T.M., Port de Plaisance du Marin, 97290 Le Marin (74.98.17), which offers the largest fleet, more than 100 boats, and Caraibes Evasion, Pointe du Bout, 97229 Trois Ilets (66..02.85), with Zodiacs, cabin cruisers and sailboats, crewed or uncrewed for 6 to 60 persons.
The beaches south of Fort-de-France are white, while the northern beaches are grayish. Outstanding in the south is the Plage des Salines, a short drive from Ste.-Anne, with tall coconut palms and miles of white sand. During summer holidays and weekends, the beach is busy with families and children; during the week, even in the height of the winter season, it is quiet and uncrowded.
 
Hotels
 Among hotels with good water-sports facilities are La Bateliere, on the city side of Fort-de-France Bay; Le Bakoua at Pointe du Bout, reopening this month after extensive renovation, and the Diamant-Novotel in the south of the island. At the Bateliere and the Bakoua, double rooms start at $155, with Continental breakfast included at the Bakoua. The Diamant-Novotel charges from $180 with Continental breakfast.

Transportation
 From New York, American via San Juan or on local airlines from St. Martin; from Miami and San Juan, Air France.
 
MONTSERRAT
 
MONTSERRAT TOURIST BOARD
450 PARK AVENUE SOUTH, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10016
(212-752-8660)
 
Overview
 Montserrat lost most of its greenness to the devastation of Hurricane Hugo in September last year. The growth on this mountainous, 39-square-mile island has almost completely recovered, but repairs to smashed homes and tourist accommodations are still going on. Most visitors' rooms -- limited at the best of times -- are expected to be ready this month. Meanwhile, unchanged are the opportunities for windsurfing, sunfish sailing, water skiing, snorkeling, body surfing, board paddling, scuba diving and deep-sea fishing. Rendezvous Bay, with its white sands, Lime Kiln and Woodlands are the best beaches for snorkeling, diving and picnics; Foxes Bay and Little Bay are used for for spearfishing. The most popular beach is the sheltered Old Road Bay, which sports a small jetty, and offers everything from diving lessons to day sails. It has a beach bar, as well as a tennis court and is close to the golf course.
Danny's Watersports (809-491-5645) offers rentals and lessons in windsurfing, snorkeling, sailing and water skiing from $5 to $10 an hour. Its scuba-diving instructor teaches and rents equipment at from $35 to $55 a dive.
Visitors this month can be a part of the island's annual carnival. Throughout December there are calypso contests, pageants, masquerade dancers and parades with floats. The recently opened disco called Uprising presents reggae and calypso artists from other islands.
 
Hotels
 The Vue Pointe overlooking Old Road Bay offers the best opportunities and facilities for those who want to swim, dive, ski, surf, sail and fish. Room rates range from $75 to $200. The more modern Montserrat Springs Hotel on the edge of Emerald Isle Beach and within walking distance of Plymouth lends itself well to picnics and beach parties, has good snorkeling and spearfishing and can arrange windsurfing and water skiing. The hotel added some rooms as it carried out repairs and plans a Dec. 15 opening with 22 rooms. By March it hopes to have 46 rooms. Rates range from $110 to $280 a night.
 
Transportation
 From Antigua, Guadeloupe and St. Kitts on L.I.A.T. and other local airlines.
 
PUERTO RICO
 
COMMONWEALTH OF PUERTO RICO TOURISM COMPANY
575 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-599-6262)
 
Overview
 With the Atlantic on its north coast and the Caribbean on the south coast, Puerto Rico has hundreds of miles of sandy beaches. The surf in the north tends to be rough while the waters in the south are usually smooth. The temperature of the water is normally the same as that of the air, which from November to March varies from about 76 to 85 degrees, making it ideal for water sports.
The island suffered billions of dollars in damage from Hurricane Hugo in September last year, but none of the major hotels were so badly damaged that they had to close. The island is now almost fully recovered. Suffering greater devestation were the little islands of Vieques and Culebra off the east coast, which have miles of beaches for snorkeling, scuba diving, fishing and sunbathing and swimming. The hotels were damaged but are open for business, and the rebuilding of the destroyed and damaged homes is about 80 percent complete.
Puerto Rico has some of the world's best beaches for surfing. Beginners would do well to stick to the beach at the foot of Condado Avenue in the Condado hotel district. More accomplished surfers may want to drive out to Tubos, a beach off Route 685 north of the town of Vega Baja, about an hour's drive from San Juan. Expert surfers might prefer Puntas, called the Hawaii of the east, outside Rincon on the westernmost tip of the island. Surfers go there for months at a time staying in ramshackle rooms rented from families with homes near the beach. Rooms at the nearby Villa Cofresi (809-823-7045) go for $75 in the winter season.
Most visitors to Puerto Rico stay in hotels in the San Juan area which also includes those in the Isla Verde section. All the luxury hotels have water sports concessions offering skin diving and scuba diving lessons that include excursions to diving beaches. Castillo Watersports (809-791-7195), near El San Juan Hotel in Isla Verde, offers a 40-hour scuba course with ocean dives for $275. Castillo also offers a snorkeling picnic, with lunch and drinks, from a native sloop for three costing $60 a person. The same trip for scuba divers costs $85 a person.
At the Condado Plaza Hotel and Casino in the heart of the Condado hotel area, San Juan Watersports rents water scooters for use in the Condado Lagoon for $40 a half-hour and water skis and tow boats for $25 for 15 minutes. Windsurfers are rented for $20 an hour.
Coral Head Divers (809-850-7208), at the sprawling Palmas del Mar resort in the southeast coast town of Humacao, rents Sunfish and windsurfers for $20 and kayaks for $10 an hour. It also offers a variety of scuba and snorkeling trips and an open-water scuba certification course for $375. Coral Head also has a combination snorkeling and fishing trip to the island of Vieques on a cabin cruiser for $79 a person.
At the Hyatt Regency Cerromar, in the town of Dorado about 30 minutes west of San Juan, windsurfers, paddle canoes, ocean kayaks and water trikes are free to guests in season. Lisa Tenfield, a world-champion windsurfer, offers a 90-minute beginner's windsurfing course for $45 and an eight-hour certification program for $139.
Vieques is good for snorkeling and scuba diving but divers have to take their own gear: there are no rental facilities on the island. At Esperanza, a little fishing village on the south coast, you can snorkel for lobster and fish right off the Villa Esperanza Hotel. Windsurfing boards and other gear may be rented at the hotel.
Well known for deep-sea fishing charters is Mike Benitez (809-724-6265), who sails out of the San Juan Yacht Club just off the Condado hotel district. A half day for six on his 45-foot boat costs $366 while a full day is $650. A half day for six on his 61-footer is $625; a full day, $1,200. At Palmas del Mar, Bill Burleson (809-850-7442) can take six passengers on his 48-foot boat for $795 for a full day and $595 for six hours.
In Vieques, the Villa Esperanza Hotel (809-741-8675) arranges for a fisherman to take a party of six out for a half day for $250 and a full day for $350.
 
Hotels
 El San Juan Hotel and Casino (809-791-1000 or 800-468-2818), one of the island's veteran hotels, underwent a major face lift that included gardens designed by Edward Durrel Stone Jr. You don't have to leave the hotel for a varied night life or a far ranging choice of restaurants, of which there are five, the latest being the Don Juan. Rates start at $275 daily.
In addition to their water sports, the Hyatt Regency Cerromar (809-796-1234), in Dorado, and Palmas del Mar (809-852-6000), near the southeast coast town of Humacao, are resorts with several golf courses, tennis courts and horseback riding facilities. The rates at the Hyatt start at $225 and at Palmas del Mar at $120 for a room up to $520 for a villa accommodating six people.
Villa Esperanza Hotel in Vieques charges $96 a day for a room, with two children under 10 permitted in the room at no additional cost.
Transporation
 From New York to San Juan on T.W.A., American, Eastern, Pan Am. Also from New York to Aguadilla and Ponce on Carnival Air Lines and to Ponce on Eastern (from Newark). From Miami to San Juan on Pan Am, American, Eastern and T.W.A..
 
SABA
 
SABA TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
271 MAIN STREET, NORTHPORT, N.Y. 11768
(800-344-4606)
 
Overview
 The five-square-mile island 20 miles south of St. Maarten, having no permanent beaches, draws more than 20,000 tourists a year to its dive sites and mountain hiking trails and simply to the island itself as a day trip from neighboring islands. A marine park was established by the Government of Saba in 1987 to protect a zone along the coast and to regulate its use by fishermen and water-sports lovers. There are 14 designated dive sites. Shallow water near shore mirrors the steep sides of the island above the surface and dropping near vertically into the ocean. Coral reefs, dropoffs, walls and pinnacles are a short boat ride away.
Saba is the only island in the Eastern Caribbean with a recompression chamber, acquired from the Royal Dutch Navy last year. The island has three dive shops and the hotels offer package deals for divers. The dive shops are Wilson's (599-5-22167), Saba Deep (599-4-63347) and Sea Saba (599-4-62246). Single-tank dives are $45. An example of packages available is Sea Saba's six nights and eight dives at $528 a person, double occupancy, including accommodations, guided boat tours, tanks and weight belt, refreshments, hotel service charges, room tax, marine park fees and airport and diving taxi service.
 
Hotels
 Scout's Place (599-4-62205) has 15 units with bathrooms, and arestaurant. Rates including breakfast are $55 to $85 for two in a room. .
Juliana's (599-4-62269) has 10 rooms, each with private bath and balcony. A double is $75, and a two-bedroom apartment, $100.
Captain's Quarters (599-4-62201) has 10 rooms, each with private bath, balcony and sea view. There is a pool and a restaurant. A double is $125, and a triple, $160.
 
Transportation
From St. Maarten on five daily Twin Otters (19 seats) of Windward Island Airways. A ferry between Saba and St. Maarten is scheduled to resume Tuesday to Sunday service this month; it has been operating on Sunday only during boat repairs.
 
ST. BARTHELEMY
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-757-1125)
 
Overview
 St. Bart's popularity in the world of yachting is due in part to its being about midway between Antigua and Virgin Gorda, two major sailing centers. Gustavia's harbor, 13 to 16 feet deep, has mooring and docking facilities for about 40 yachts. There are also fine anchorages at nearby Public, Corossol and Colombier. For anything connected to yachting, Loulou's Marine in Gustavia (27.62.74) is the place. The stock is extensive, the staff speaks English and the bulletin board is a trove of yachting information. Other good sources include the tourist office (27.60.08), La Marine Service (27.70.34) and Yacht Charter Agency (27.62.38).
Deep-sea fishing expeditions are run by Pierrot Choisy on his Bertram, and he can be reached through the College Mireille Choisy in Gustavia (27.61.22). Charter boat possibilities are posted on bulletin boards near the quay in Gustavia or can be arranged through Yacht Charter Agency and La Marine Service.
Suba Diving: Guy Blateau is a licensed, accredited divemaster who operates from La Marine Service. His Diving Center has scuba gear and gives free initiation in hotel pools. There is also a branch at the Hotel Guanahani. Dive trips are priced at about $50 a person, gear included. Night dives are also offered.
Windsurfing is particularly good at the beaches of St. Jean, Grand Cul de Sac, Lorient and Flamands. At St. Jean, rentals and lessons are available at the St. Bart Wind School in front of the Tom Beach Hotel; at Grand Cul de Sac from Wind Wave Power at the St. Bart's Beach Hotel and from Atlantis next to the Gloriette restaurant. Rentals average about $14 an hour. A great spot for windsurfing pros is Washing Machine on the southeast coast between Toiny and Grand Fond. Waterskiing can be arranged with the Marine Service at about $42 an hour.
Few of the 14 beaches are crowded, even in peak season. All are public and free. Nude bathing is prohibited, but topless sunbathing is quite common. For beaches with hotels, restaurants and water sports, Grand Cul de Sac on the northeast shore fits the bill, as does St. Jean, which is actually two beaches divided by the Eden Rock promontory. There are also tiny hotels and restaurants at Flamands to the west, a stretch of white sand fringed with lantana palms.

Hotels
 Among resorts with good beaches are El Sereno, which has bungalows in walled gardens with double rooms starting at $245; Guanahani, where some of the 80 rooms and suites have private pools, from $375; and Manapany, consisting of hillside cottages overlooking the sea, $340. Less expensive and with the best water sports is St. Bart's Beach Hotel and its companion, Grand Cul de Sac. The Wind Wave Power water-sports center lies between the two. At the 36-room St. Bart's, rates are from $211, and at Grand Cul de Sac, from $132.
 
Transportation
 From St. Maarten (Dutch side of the island of St. Martin) on Air St. Barthelemy and Windward and from St. Martin (French side) on Air Guadeloupe; from St. Thomas and San Juan on Virgin Air; from Guadeloupe and Antigua on Air Guadeloupe. Catamarans sail daily from the Dutch side of St. Martin, and a yacht sails from the French side.
 
ST. CROIX
1
U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS DIVISION OF TOURISM
1270 AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
 
Overview
 St. Croix, where damage from Hurricane Hugo was severe, continues to recover. All of its beaches are open for water sports, but some hotels have not been repaired and will not reopen for the season. The Tamarind Reef Beachside Inn and the Divi St. Croix are applying for permits to rebuild. The Holger Danske Hotel is being repaired but no opening date has been set. Officials on the island say it is unlikely that the Grapetree Bay Resort and the Queen's Quarter Hotel will be repaired within the coming year.
Many residents say that Sandy Point is the island's prettiest beach. Cane Bay is excellent for scuba diving and snorkeling. Residents and visitors enjoy lounging and picnicking at Cramer's Park beach.
Mile Mark Charters (809-773-2628 or 800-523-3483) offers full-day and half-day sails to nearby Buck Island and its underwater national park. The cost ranges from $20 to $45; lunch is included on the full-day sail. Windsurfing, parasailing and other activities can be arranged. Dive St. Croix (809-773-3434 or 800-523-3483) offers instruction and a shallow-water scuba dive for $65. A five-day certification course is $330.
St. Croix's Carnival will be held from Dec. 23 through Jan. 6, which includes a costume parade, tentatively scheduled for the weekend of Jan. 4.
 
Hotels
 The Buccaneer Hotel (809-773-2100 or 800-223-1108), which has three beaches, offers many water sports and can arrange others. Day and half-day sails to Buck Island begin at the hotel's dock. Parasailing can be arranged for $45, which includes a boat ride and 12 minutes in the air. The hotel can arrange windsurfing, scuba and snorkel lessons. Also available are kayaks, rafts and aquacycles -- large-wheel tricycles that can be pedaled around the bay. The hotel has an 18-hole golf course, eight tennis courts, a shopping arcade and four restaurants. Winter rates for a double room range from $175 to $310. A 7.5 percent tax is added to all rates on St. Croix.
Carambola Beach Resort and Golf Club (809-773-3800 or 800-447-9503) has a complete dive center with scuba lessons and dives. Complimentary snorkel lessons are available to guests. Other water sports and day sails are available. The hotel has nine tennis courts -- two are lighted, two pools and three restaurants and a deli. Rates for a double room, from $475 to $575 a day, include breakfast, lunch and dinner.

Transportation
 Airlines that serve St. Croix include Pan American, Midway, Eastern, Continental and American.
 
ST. EUSTATIUS
 
ST. EUSTATIUS TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
271 MAIN STREET, NORTHPORT, NEW YORK, N.Y. 11768
(800-344-4606)
 
Overview
 St. Eustatius has three beaches each quite different in character. Oranje Beach has interesting sand colors -- areas of light beige and black. Waves are lower on this leeward side: no strong current, undertow, sea urchins or dangerous fish. The two-mile-long Zeelandia, with black and tan sand, has Atlantic surf, fresh invigorating trade winds and a dangerous undertow. Swimming is not recommended, but it is good for wading with a partner, sunbathing and beach hiking. Lynch Beach, on the Atlantic side, is small with light brown sand. Stay near shore and watch out for undertow. There are no lifeguards at any of these beaches.
Some of the best dive sites on this island of nine square miles are Crook's Reef, Double Wreck, Jenkins Bay Reef, the Wall and Supermarket, where many wrecks lie on the ocean floor about 1,200 yards offshore. There is one dive shop, Dive Statia, in Lower Town Oranjestad (599-3-82435) with rates starting at $35 for a single dive; six dives or more cost $22.50 each.
Walkers come across abandoned forts, old sugar mills and ruins of plantation houses. They can also hike up the mountain to the Quill, the crater of an extinct volcano containing a rain forest.
Expansion of Franklin D. Roosevelt Airport has started and is expected to be completed by September 1991, allowing de Havilland Dash-8, AVRO and Fokker Fairchild aircraft to land.
 
Hotels
 The Old Gin House and Mooshay Bay Public House has 20 rooms built in and around a cotton gin factory dating from the 18th century. Rates with breakfast and dinner are $220 for two, $285 for three. A double room without meals is $150. Golden Era Hotel is a simple modern hotel of 20 rooms in the Lower Town near the sea. Swimming pool. Rates (no meals): double, $88; triple, $104.
La Maison sur la Plage on the beach at Zeelandia has 10 bungalows and charges $75 for two, including Continental breakfast. Talk of the Town Bar and Restaurant has efficiency apartments from $340 to $430 for seven nights.
 
Transportation
 From St. Maarten on Windward Island Airways (seven flights daily) and from St. Kitts on L.I.A.T. (twice weekly). Also small local charter flights available.
 
ST. JOHN
 
U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS DIVISION OF TOURISM
1270 AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-582-4520)
 
Overview
 Much of St. John lies within a national park, and the park includes many of the island's most beautiful beaches. Trunk Bay is among the best. Snorkelers can swim a short distance from shore and explore a small cay. Snorkeling equipment may be rented at Trunk and Cinnamon Bay beaches. Trunk is a favorite for picnicking as are Honeymoon and Hawk's Nest beaches.
Tropical Isles Yacht Charters (809-776-6922) offers just about everything for the vacationing sailor and water sports enthusiast. Day sails on 32-foot to 42-foot boats with six passengers cost $60 to $75 a person, including lunch, beverage and snorkeling gear. A half-day sail is $35 to $40, and a sunset cruise is $30 to $40. Small boats, 17 to 24 feet, are available for charter at $100 to $150 a day.
Sailing instruction is $50 a person for a half-day or $225 for a full day for up to three people. Light-tackle sport fishing is available and deep-sea fishing can be arranged, and so can snuba, a combination of snorkeling and scuba diving. Instead of divers carrying an air tank, the tank floats on a raft while the diver is tethered below. Cost for a three-hour tour is $80 a couple or $50 a person.

Hotels
 St. John did not suffer severe damage from Hurricane Hugo and all hotels are operating. A 7.5 percent room tax is added to all rates on the island.
Caneel Bay (809-776-6111 or 800-223-7637), the beachside resort that incorporates ruins of a 17th-century plantation, includes seven beaches, some secluded as well as some that attract residents. Caneel's divemaster can arrange lessons and tours for those interested in scuba diving and snorkeling. Windsurfing is also available. Also offered is a stay with three nights aboard a Hinckley sailboat and three nights at the resort. Cost is $795 to $968 a person a night and does not include meals. The yacht is provisioned to the passengers' requests. Other charters can be arranged.
Winter rates for a double room range from $310 to $510 a day.
Hyatt Regency St. John (809-776-7171 or 800 233-1234). Hyatt took over management of the former Virgin Grand Beach Resort in April. Complimentary snorkeling gear is offered to guests. The sea can become cloudy near the hotel, so snorkelers are encouraged to visit Trunk Bay or other spots, and the resort provides an ice chest for those excursions. The water is fine for swimming, and the resort provides guests with windsurfers, paddleboats and kayaks. Toobies -- motorized innertubes -- are available at no charge. The divemaster can arrange day charters and fishing trips that leave from the hotel's dock.
Rates for a double room range from $275 to $450 a day.
 
Transportation
 Travelers must fly to St. Thomas before catching one of the many ferries, mostly from Red Hook, to Cruz Bay; $3 one way.
 
ST. LUCIA
 
ST. LUCIA TOURIST BOARD
820 SECOND AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-867-2950)
 
Overview
 St. Lucia's water sports activities are getting a boost this year as close to 130 yachts from all over the world end a 2,700-mile journey across the Atlantic by sailing into the island's Rodney Bay Marina. The winners of the event, the Atlantic Rally for Cruisers, are expected to cross the finish line this week. Most of the yachts are due to arrive by Dec. 23. The rally began last month at Las Palmas in the Canary Islands.
The day after completion of the Atlantic event, the St. Lucia Yachting Association holds its own Christmas yachting regatta, a series of three races along the island's west coast. Several yachts in the rally will also sail in the regatta.
Most of the hotels are virtually on the seashore and place great emphasis on water sports: windsurfing, water skiing, parasailing and others. Dive shops offer snorkeling and scuba diving, and deep-sea fishing can be arranged. Most hotels offer their guests complimentary masks, fins and snorkels. Scuba St. Lucia at the Anse Chastanet Hotel in the town of Soufriere, 26 miles from the capital, Castries, is one of the best bets for water sports, offering beach and boat dives as well as resort courses for beginners and certification courses. Single dives cost $25; packages are available at discounted rates. Here, too, equipment can be rented (mask, fins and snorkel costs $4 daily or $20 weekly), including cameras for underwater photography.
 
Hotels
 There are more than a dozen good hotels on St. Lucia, all of which have direct access to the beach. Anse Chastanet has views of the Pitons, the two conical mountains that rise more than 2,400 feet above sea level. Most of the hillside rooms are octagonal gazebos. Deluxe suites are either hillside or beachside and include outdoor living room and refrigerator. Rates, with two meals a day, range from $240 to $300 for two. Weekly packages with two meals a day start at $2,080 for two. Anse Chastanet offers a seven-night scuba package with room, two meals daily, 12 dives from boat or beach, other water sports and transfers from $1,240 a person.
At Cunard La Toc Hotel and Suites, most suites have their own private plunge pool. Room rates at the hotel range from $230 to $265 nightly and from $375 to $525 for one- and two-bedroom suites, some with private pools. La Toc is offering two additional free nights when five nights are booked -- in the rooms, not suites -- through April 20.
While Le Sport, an all-inclusive resort, concentrates on seawater treatments and aerobics at its spa, called Oasis, it also offers windsurfing and other water sports. Daily rates of $220 to $300 a person in double occupancy include sports facilities, the spa's activities, three meals a day (based on a light style of cooking) and refreshments and bar drinks. Guests who stay at least seven nights get a rebate of $349 on their air fare.
 
Transportation
 Major airlines from New York are American (daily), via San Juan, and B.W.I.A. via Antigua.
 
ST. MAARTEN
 
ST. MAARTEN TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
275 SEVENTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10001
(212-989-0000)
 
Overview
 The Dutch side of the island shared with French St. Martin includes the cruise port of Philipsburg, with its duty-free shopping along Front Street, as well as sizable resorts with casinos and sports facilities. Almost every hotel on or close to the beach is involved with windsurfing, sailing and other water sports. There are many beaches. Some local snorkelers say Dawn Beach is best for exploring the reefs and marine life just offshore. Others generally favored are Maho, Little Bay, Oyster Pond and Mullet Bay.
A number of water-sports centers offer lessons, equipment rental and tours. Among them are Maho Watersports at Mullet Bay Resort, Watersports Unlimited at St. Maarten Beach Club and at Holland House Beach Hotel, Beach Bums on Simpson Bay, Red Ensign Watersports at the Dawn Beach Hotel, Little Bay Watersports at the Divi Little Bay Beach Hotel, Ocean Explorers on Simpson Bay and St. Maarten Divers and Watersports at the Great Bay Hotel.
Ocean Explorers (45252) charges $45 for a scuba diving lesson; a certification course lasting five days costs $318, and there are various other packages. Snorkeling trips lasting two and a half hours are $30. Maho (52801) offers a similar program. A three-hour resort course is $45, separate dives can be had for $45, and the one-week certification course costs $350.
Places for windsurfing include the Little Bay Beach Hotel, Mullet Bay Resort and the Dawn Beach Hotel, where the water-sports centers provide rentals and instruction. Jet skiing, water skiing, parasailing, sailing and deep-sea fgishing are available on St. Maarten and generally can be arranged through hotel activity desks.
 In Philipsburg, a new restaurant with a view of Great Bay Harbor is San Marco on Front Street (22166). Linguini salsa caraibi (lobster and shrimps in red or white sauce) is among the specialties, and there is an Italian wine list.
 
Hotels
 The big Mullet Bay Resort, which has golf course, tennis courts and several restaurants, charges $225 for a twin room with kitchenette; rates rise to $890 for a suite sleeping six people. The hotel also includes a casino, nightclub and shopping arcade. Divi Little Bay Beach Resort has rates of $247 rising to $815 for suites. The Divi has nightly entertainment, shops, tennis and satellite TV in each room. The Maho Beach, where facilities run from a casino to badminton, has rooms starting at $175 and suites at $495. Some rooms have kitchens.
 
Transportation
 From New York on American, Pan American and Continental (from Newark); from Miami on Eastern, American and Pan American.
 
ST. MARTIN
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-757-1125)
 
Overview
 By official count, St. Martin -- the French side of the island shared with Dutch St. Maarten -- has 36 white sand beaches, ranging from the small and secluded to broad expanses of untouched sand. Beaches are seldom crowded, even in peak season; public beaches are reached by tracks off the highway. There is a nudist beach at Orient Bay (and a hotel, the Club Orient Nudist Resort). Ilet Pinel, a tiny offshore island, is a favorite of beach recluses.
All diving -- reef, wreck, night, cave and drift -- is done from boats, since most sites are some distance offshore, and depth of dives is 30 to 60 feet. Off the northeast coast of the French side, dive sites include Ilet Pinel, for good shallow diving; Green Key, a barrier reef, and Flat Island (also known as Ile Tintamarre), for sheltered coves and sub-sea geological faults. The shallow reefs and coves offer some intresting snorkeling; equipment can be rented at hotels, and trips are available to a 15-foot coral reef. The area around Orient Bay, Green Key, Ilet Pinel and Flat Island are recommended.
Moorings favored by sailors include Baie Rouge; Nettle Bay near Marigot; Marigot Bay, for taking on stores from the Port la Royale Marina, and Grand Case Bay, a fishing village with dock, grocery, pharmacy, and an array of restautants. For charters, the Moorings, with 45 yachts, is based at Oyster Pond (Clearwater, Fla. 34624; 800-535-7289), as is Sun Yacht Charters, with 30 Centurions (Camden Me.; 800-772-3500). A.T.M. Yachts, the Newport Beach, Calif., charter company, has 20 yachts at Port Lonvilliers (800-227-5317).
Dynasty Yachts, based in Marigot, has a fleet of Dynamique Yachts, 47 to 80 feet, housed at the Royale Marina (590-87.85.21). Sample weekly rates for a 47-foot yacht sleeping eight, unskippered: $3,800 through April 29, then falling to $2,910. Other yacht charter companies include Caraibes Boat Sport, Star Voyage and Sun Ride Charter.
Good fishing boats ply the waters around St. Martin and can be chartered by the hour, half-day, full day, or week. Charters usually include tackle, bait, light lunch, and drinks. Dolphin, kingfish, sailfish, blue marlin, big eye and wahoo are the catches. Sailfish Caraibes, based at Port Lonvilliers (contact Capt. Jean-Pierre Goetz at 81.31.94), has two 33-foot Bertrams equipped with Fenwick rods, Penn International reels, and similar top deep-sea fishing material. Both half-day trips ($400 with open bar) and full-day trips ($700 with open bar and lunch) leave at 6 A.M. Maximum of 11 people a boat.
 
Hotels
 The outstanding beach resorts -- and with the best beaches -- are L'Habitation and La Samanna. L'Habitation has a 60-slip marina and offers water sports facilities, including canoes, snorkeling and water skiing. There are 250 rooms and suites and Le Privilege fitness center with six lighted tennis courts. Double rooms start at $300 and suites at $395 and rates include buffet breakfast. At La Samanna, which overlooks a long white sand beach, snorkeling gear, windsurfing, sailing and water skiing are complimentary. Rooms are from $400. A less expensive choice is the Grand Case Beach Club, within walking distance of the noted cluster of restaurants of Grand Case. Rates begin at $230 for two, with Continental breakfast.
 
Transportation
 From New York on B.W.I.A. (via Antigua), A.L.M., American, Continental and Pan Am; from Miami on Pan Am. Planes land at Queen Juliana Airport in the Dutch sector and visitors transfer to the French side by hotel car or taxi.
 
ST. THOMAS
 
U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS DIVISION OF TOURISM
1270 AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-582-4520
 
Overview
 While all of the United States Virgin Islands offer a wide selection of water sports, St. Thomas is the center for everything from sailing to lounging on the beach. For windsurfing, snorkeling and swimming, Sapphire Bay beach at the east end of the island is recommended. Residents and visitors praise Magens Bay for improving suntans, picnicking and swimming -- and most claim it is the most beautiful beach. It is the only one where admission is charged: 50 cents, 25 cents for children under 12 and 50 cents for parking. Snorkels and masks can be rented for about $6 a day. Lounge chairs, floating mats and other equipment is available from Magens Bay Concession.
The many dive shops offer all-inclusive scuba lessons and a reef dive. Joe Vogel Diving Company (809-775-7610) has a five-hour package for $60 that includes all equipment, two hours of instruction and a half-hour dive. Morning dives are best to see the many varieties of fish.
Second Wind Charters (809-775-6135 or 800-524-2029) offers sailboat charters for $2,200 to $3,100 a week, prorated for day charters. Fully crewed and provisioned charters begin at $3,600 a week. Boats are 38 to 46 feet long. V.I. Power Yacht Charters (809-776-1510 or 800-5224-2015) has 37- to 62-foot powerboats for $3,570 to $9,500 a week. Captains are $85 a day and provisions run $165 a person per week.
Three hotels have not reopened since Hurricane Hugo: Carib Beach, Virgin Isle and Sea Cliff Beach Resort on nearby Water Island.
 
Hotels
 Stouffer Grand Beach Resort (809-775-1510 or 800-468-3571). The resort's sports center provides complimentary windsurfing, Sunfish sailing, snorkeling and scuba instruction to guests. Offshore day and night dives are offered to guests who complete the scuba instruction. Once a week, divers are taken to the Rhone, a sunken 19th-century ship used to film sequences for "The Deep." Other water sports and sailing activities can be arranged. The resort has two restaurants, snack bar, swimming pool and six tennis courts. Chilled towels are supplied to afternoon sunbathers. Winter rates for a single or double room range from $295 to $415 a day.
Sapphire Beach Resort and Marina (809-775-6100 or 800-524-2090) has a full-service dive shop, open daily, where guests and nonguests may take lessons. Complimentary snorkeling equipment, Sunfish sailboats and windsurfers are available for guests. The marina offers boats for deep-sea fishing. Guests get reduced rates, $750 a day for deep-sea fishing or $450 for a half-day. Marlin fishing is $900 a day. The hotel has two restaurants, and all rooms have kitchens. Double rooms from $275 to $365 a day.
Bolongo Bay Beach Resort (809-775-1800 or 800-524-4746) gives guests complimentary Sunfish sailing, paddleboats and snorkel gear, and scuba lessons in the hotel pool. Daily diving trips are available. Guests also get a day sail to St. John, an all-day cruise including a picnic lunch at Honeymoon Bay. The hotel has two restaurants and four tennis courts. From $200 a day for a double room to $375 for a three-bedroom villa that accommodates six people. A 7.5 percent room tax is added to rates on St. Thomas.
 
Transportation
 Airlines that serve St. Thomas include Pan American, Midway Airlines, Eastern, Continental and American. Commuter airlines provide connecting service to other carriers in San Juan.
 
ST. VINCENT
 
ST. VINCENT AND THE GRENADINES TOURIST OFFICE
801 SECOND AVENUE, 21st FLOOR, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-687-4981)
 
Overview
 The Grenadines, part of the nation called St. Vincent and the Grenadines, are some 30 islands and cays stretching south from St. Vincent, home of the group's capital, Kingstown. Bequia, Mustique and Palm are among the larger ones. All the Grenadines have soft white coral sand beaches and clear water, ideal for sailing, diving and snorkeling. Dive sites around St. Vincent include the Garden, a spot with coral terraces conducive to underwater photography; New Guinea Reef, with its black coral, and the Forest, noted for gorgonian corals 6 to 10 feet tall waving in the current. Bequia has seven miles of fringing reefs, many of them virtually undived.
Instruction and equipment are available wherever the diving is good. On St. Vincent, for example, Mariners Watersports and Yacht Charters (809-45-84228) offers all water sports, day trips to Bequia and to the Falls of Baleine on St. Vincent's northwest coast. There are several other water sports outfits. Some hotels provide snorkeling equipment and some have sailboard equipment. On St. Vincent, swimming on the rocky windward coast is not advisable because of rough seas.
The sailing is renowned around the world, and yachts may be chartered from a number of outfits, including Mariners, Frangipani Yacht Services on Bequia and Anchorage Yacht Club on Union. A string of sources for windsurfing equipment and instruction stretches from the Windsurfing International School on St. Vincent to Sunsports on Bequia and Basil's Bar, Mustique. Basil's is also one of the places to rent water skis along with the Plantation House Hotel on Bequia.
 
Hotels
 Among less expensive lodgings on the islands is the 27-room Friendship Bay Resort on Bequia where oceanview rooms for two, with two meals a day, are $175 and oceanfront rooms, $225. In New York, Friendship Bay is represented by I.T.R. (212-545-8469 or 800-223-9815). One of the most exclusive hotels is the Young Island Resort, 200 yards off St. Vincent's south coast. Guests at its cottages and suites pay from $365 a day, with two meals. Two 44-foot yachts are available for guests' use. The resort is represented by Ralph Locke at 914-763-5526 or 800-223-1108), who also acts for the Cotton House.
The Cotton House is the only hotel on Mustique, and it's expensive, but you don't have top spend a great deal to stay on the island. Firefly House (809-45-84621), a private villa overlooking Britannia Bay, charges $80 for a double room with Continental breakfast. The Cotton House rate is about $500 a day for room and three meals.
 
Transportation
 From St. Lucia to St. Vincent on L.I.A.T., Inter-Island Air Services and EC Air-Air Martinique. From Barbados to St. Vincent on L.I.A.T. and EC Air-Air Martinque, and from Grenada on L.I.A.T. Passengers transfer to other islands by boat or small plane. Also from Barbados to Mustique, Canouan and Union on Mustique Airways.
 
TORTOLA
 
BRITISH VIRGIN ISLANDS TOURIST BOARD
370 LEXINGTON AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-696-0400)
 
Overview
 Beaches range from popular hangouts with bars, restaurants and equipment rental to quiet stretches affording solitude. All beaches, including those bordering private property, can be used by the public from the ocean to the highwater mark. Among notable beaches is Cane Garden Bay on the northwest coast, offering swimming and snorkeling as well as bars and restaurants.
Smugglers Cove between Long Bay and West End is quiet, with excellent snorkeling and basic accommodations offered by the couple that run the restaurant there. Each of four guest rooms costs $98 for two (809-495-4234). Elizabeth Beach on the northeast coast is one of Tortola's best kept secrets -- no facilities, just miles of crashing waves, palms and white sands. Brewers Bay offers the island's only campground at the edge of nearly a mile of remote beach and some of the best snorkeling. The campground (809-494-3463) provides 20 two-person tents at $20 a night and tent sites for $7 nightly. Ruins of an old distillery are at the camp's edge.
 
Hotels
 Nestled between steep green hills and nearly a mile of beach, Long Bay Beach Resort has 20 hillside studios and 42 beachfront units with four-poster beds and patios. Seven-night packages from $1,200 a person include breakfasts, some dinners, sports and use of jeeps. There are two restaurants of high local reputation, day sails, diving, tennis. Reservations: 800-729-9599.
The Tortola branch of the world's largest chartering outfit, the Moorings, offers comprehensive marina services, as well a water sports activities package in conjunction with the nearby Treasure Isle Hotel. A seven-night stay at $985 a person includes breakfasts and dinners and access to windsurfers, sunfish, snorkeling and dinghies with outboards. The Moorings, a full-service marina with 80-room hotel, pool and restaurant, arranges crewed and bareboat charters, sailing and scuba lessons, island cruises and day sails. Reservations: 800-334-2435.
The B.V.I.'s largest hotel, Prospect Reef Resort, is a self-contained village on a coral reef offering water sports. On the western edge of Road Town, it has 131 oceanview units on 43 acres. Varied accommodations start at $120. Packages available for diving, charter fishing and day sailing. Reservations: 800-356-8937.
Ramada Nanny Cay Resort and Marina is on a 25-acre islet and has a dive shop with varied packages, board sailing, pools, chandlery and repair yards. Crewed and bareboat charters plus sailing instruction are also offered. Studios cost from $150 a day. Reservations: 800-228-9898.
The Peter Island Resort and Yacht Harbour, renovated after severe damage caused by the hurricane last year, is due to reopen Jan. 5.
 
Transportation
 Flights are available to Beef Island, which is connected to Tortola by a small bridge, from San Juan, Puerto Rico, and St. Thomas, U.S.V.I. Principal carriers are American, Air B.V.I., L.I.A.T. and Eastern Metro. Or by the Bomba Charger, Speedy's or Native Son ferryboats from St. Thomas, a 45-minute ride.
 
TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO
 
TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO TOURIST BOARD
118-35 QUEENS BOULEVARD, FOREST HILLS, N.Y. 11375
(718-575-3909)
 
Overview
 Calls by cruise ships to the two islands and flights to Port-of-Spain, Trinidad, from Europe, which were suspended because of the attempted coup July 27 and the resulting state of emergency, have resumed. Tourism, disrupted by the political crisis, has begun to recover. However, at this writing a curfew remains in effect between 1 and 5 A.M. on Trinidad; there is no curfew on Tobago.
Tobago, rather than the larger island of Trinidad, provides the majority of facilities for snorkeling, diving, water skiing, sailing and other water sports. Its trump card is the Buccoo Bay and Reef, where millions of coral creatures swim in submarine gardens, and coral sparkles in the clear water. The marine life can be viewed in glass-bottom boats. Fine beaches include Castara, Charlotteville, Lambeau, a tiny bathing spot near the chief town, Scarborough, and Pigeon Point.
For scuba divers Tobago has two major dive shops: Tobago Dive Experience, operated by Sean Robinson and Derek Chung, from the Blue Waters Inn at Speyside, and the Crown Point Beach Hotel (809-639-8781); and Tobago Marine Sports, which can be reached at the Crown Reef Hotel, Store Bay (809-639-0291). Dive Experience gives various courses, including one of five days for $285. Its teaching programs are done at the newly opened Grafton Beach Resort (809-639-0191) and Crown Point, while advanced work takes place at Speyside, noted for its manta rays that span some 30 feet.
Marine Sports is run by John Darwent, whose specialties are night diving, deep diving, search and recovery. His dive courses start at $65; five days of open-water instruction cost $180. Both operations also provide snorkeling trips and rent equipment.
Although only a short drive from Port-of-Spain, the capital, the trip to Maracas Bay, Trinidad's most popular bathing resort, offers visitors great views of mountains and tropical forest during a high, winding climb to the North Coast road before the descent to the bay. The tourist board has installed modern facilities for bathers and picnickers. Farther along the same coast road is Tyrico Bay, with surfing on high waves. On the east coast is Manzanilla Beach, which has a picnic area with snack bar, changing rooms and a paved parking area.
Preparations are under way in Trinidad for the Parang season leading up to Christmas when singers, guitarists and tambourine players gather to perform Christmas songs. After the holidays comes the calypso season when steel bands take part in competitions before the Carnival parade of bands taking place next Feb. 11 and 12, the Monday and Tuesday preceding Ash Wednesday. Hotels and guest houses are often heavily booked during this period.
 
Hotels
 The hotels that offer good water sports facilities are on Tobago. One is the new Grafton Beach Resort (809-639-0191 and 809-639-9444), which has 108 air-conditoned rooms and charges $120 for a double room and $30 for a third person sharing. Another is the 29-room Blue Waters Inn, at Speyside (809-660-4341 and 809-660-4077), where rates for two are from $90 to $150; children under 12, $15. Sandy Point Beach Club at Sandy Point (809-639-8533) has 42 rooms with rates of $70 for a double room.
 
Transportation
 From New York and Miami on B.W.I.A., Pan Am and American. An air bridge service between Trinidad and Tobago is operated by B.W.I.A., with several daily flights from 6:15 A.M. to 7:15 P.M.
 
VIRGIN GORDA
 
BRITISH VIRGIN ISLANDS TOURIST BOARD
370 LEXINGTON AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-696-0400)
 
Overview
 The nearly deserted white beaches are enough reason to visit the island, but along with them are good snorkeling, diving and sailing opportunities. Certainly the most popular site is the Baths, a curving beach interrupted by large round boulders that seem to have dropped from the sky by the handful. The clear, blue water washes around the rocks, the tops of which form a rough ceiling and shelter from the blazing sun. The waist-deep pools are safe for wading. Climbing over the smaller rocks leads to the open sea and snorkeling.
Nearby, Spring Bay offers shade, picnic tables and swimming. Both the Baths and Spring Bay are a short walk down narrow trails from a parking area. Novice snorkelers should try Savannah Bay, where they can see an expansive reef while wading through knee-deep water.
The island's annual festival around Easter is a weeklong celebration ending in a day of dancing, parades and music.

Hotels
 North Sound, along the eastern tip, is protected from surge and storm and is teeming with activity from anchored yachts and the Bitter End Yacht Club. The resort, named for being the last point of land before the open waters of the Atlantic, is one-of-a-kind in the area. Guests who stay in one of 50 cottages will have a tough time deciding between the water sports available. Windsurfing and sailing lessons are given at every level; fees range from $50 to $100. Sportfishing and scuba diving are available at extra cost. The Admiral's package (seven nights) includes unlimited use of several types of sailboats, windsurfers and Boston Whalers, daily island excursions, airport transfers, all meals, snorkel fins and free beginners' sailing course, and starts at $2,240 for two people; call 800-872-2392.
Although it's but a short distance from the Bitter End, Biras Creek feels as if it's miles from anyone. Its 100 acres are laced with trails to the beach, which offers guests use of several types of boats, windsurfers and snorkeling gear. There is a fee for water skiing, scuba diving, deep-sea fishing and excursion charters, but water sports lessons are free. There is a freshwater swimming pool and bicycles at each cottage. The 34 private cottages are surrounded by sea grapes and an occasional six-foot iguana. Daily rates for two, from $415. 800-223-1108.
North Sound is accessible only by boat. The taxi ride from Spanish Town to Gun Creek is well worth the time, and both hotels offer boat service from there to their shores. Or, the North Sound Express ferry travels from Trellis Bay, Beef Island (Tortola), to North Sound several times a day.
 
Transportation
 Flights daily from San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Tortola-Beef Island on Air B.V.I., American Eagle and Eastern Metro; from St. Thomas, U.S.V.I., on Air B.V.I and Eastern Metro. Daily ferryboat service from St. Thomas.
