HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SUN;
Growing Pains in the Caribbean

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH; HOWARD W. FRENCH is the Caribbean correspondent of The New York Times.

 BODY:
After years of seeking ever greater numbers of tourists, many Caribbean island nations are debating whether they are becoming victims of their own success.
From less-developed St. Lucia to tourism-dependent Barbados, the more-is-better approach to tourism is being questioned as it conflicts with fundamental issues such as protecting local environments and the islands' economic independence. 
 Some islands have long been or are rapidly becoming saturated with hotels, beach resorts and duty-free shopping centers, which they have relied upon to draw visitors from the United States. While this development succeeded in fueling years of growth, the resulting traffic jams, crowded beaches and jumbles of concrete buildings are now making it more difficult to attract American visitors interested in fitness vacations, wilderness and solitude.
"We still have a core product of sunshine and sea that people want and I think will continue to want," said Jean Holder, director of the Caribbean Tourism Organization, the regional industry's principal research and promotion group. "But many of the established countries are having to work much harder to maintain occupancy rates and the level of interest, and there is certainly a change in our market in relation to the whole 'green' movement."
On the Atlantic island of Bermuda, there has been strong opposition to the construction of a 400-room Ritz Carlton Hotel on the south shore. Opponents of the planned seven-story hotel have warned against breaking with the island's gentle low-rise construction style and building so densely as to create unmanageable traffic jams.
In Barbados, economic reliance on tourism, which brings a half-million visitors to the 166-square-mile island each year, has had other costs. Government engineers have estimated that the island's white sand beaches on its more developed west coast are washing away at the rate of a foot each year. The suspected culprit is untreated sewage, which kills the coral reefs that have long acted as a natural wave barrier.
Barbados, which derives about a third of its income from tourism, is now scrambling to build more sewage treatment plants to supplement the one it already has, and has borrowed $7.3 million from the Inter-American Development Bank to combat the erosion problem.

OTHER islands are beginning to show concern. The United States Virgin Islands, for example, which include some of the most heavily developed areas in the Caribbean, began a $3 million international publicity campaign last summer focusing on images of underwater life, flowering plants and migratory birds to emphasize its commitment to protecting the environment.
Indeed many travel publications have begun grouping islands according to density of development. Islands like New Providence (where Nassau is situated) in the Bahamas, St. Thomas in the United States Virgin Islands, the Dutch side of St. Martin, Barbados and Aruba -- all places that have invested heavily in tourism -- are now frequently described as mass-market destinations, best suited for package tour and cruise visitors, rather than discriminating individual tourists.
An economic model that ranks the islands' degree of tourism "penetration" and predicts its impact on their environments and economies has been devised by Jerome L. McElroy, chairman of the business and economics department at St. Mary's College in Notre Dame,Ind., whose academic specialty is Caribbean tourism and who taught in the Virgin Islands for 10 years. The model uses a variety of data, including population, land area, hotel capacity, visitor arrivals and spending per visitor.
Rather than building more hotels and straining to increase the number of visitors, Professor McElroy asserts that the best way for Caribbean countries to attain sustainable rates of growth and preserve their environments is to find new ways of encouraging guests to stay longer and consume more locally produced goods and services ranging from furniture and fruit to crafts and cultural activities.
"If you want a durable tourism that will remain profitable and won't overrun the island, you have to plan for a lower-density style that will get away from the major international enclave-style hotels," Professor McElroy said in an interview.
Islands that encouraged the growth of Club Med and other all-inclusive resorts, he said, have seen dramatic increases in visitor volume but relatively small gains in their local economies. Most of the earnings, he said, remain with the resort owner and the airline. And relatively few goods and services are supplied locally, he said.
"Each resort has self-contained economic activity with few links outside its own boundaries and little spillover," he said. "Everything from shopping to sailboating is provided at the site."
Moreover, he said, the volume of visitors may mean cumulative environmental damage to the fragile peninsulas and beaches where the big resorts are situated.
According to his studies, a number of islands, including the British Virgin Islands, Antigua, the Caymans, Turks and Caicos and Anguilla, have reached or are near the point where their governments must make major decisions about further growth if they wish to avoid becoming slump-prone and environmentally damaged.
One country where the Government is wrestling with such questions is St. Lucia. On this island, 28 miles long and up to 12 miles wide, forested volcanic peaks rise from the Caribbean to create striking vistas that invite comparison to Tahiti.
Only recently has St. Lucia begun to draw tourists in significant numbers. While the number of arrivals has doubled since 1980, with more than 130,000 last year, and quadrupled receipts from tourism, concern has spread, even among those involved in promoting the island, about the possibility that it could eventually become overrun.
"There is almost a schizophrenia between public discourse and public policy on tourism development," said one St. Lucian tourism official who asked not to be identified. "Everyone goes around saying that they stand firm on protecting the environment and the charm of the island, which they promise will stay green forever. Then they come back from a trip abroad with their eyes opened wide and say they want Singapore- or Hong Kong-style development. And I'm afraid that if we err, it will be on the side of overdevelopment."
With only about 2,000 hotel rooms and large expanses of virgin rain forest and pristine beaches, St. Lucia is still by most measures far from being overrun. But given the political imperative to produce jobs for a rapidly growing population, it is none too soon, advocates of gradual, controlled growth say, to begin planning limits.
Nicholas Thomas, director of the St. Lucia Tourist Board, said, "If we begin destroying the natural beauty here we are really going to be in a crunch because we don't have the experience of some of the other islands in managing things." He has advocated, among other limits, a moratorium on building more all-inclusive resorts until the issues are studied.
Jamaica, one of the region's most popular islands, has been able to avoid the stigma of beachfront saturation by virtue of its size and by its emphasis on attractions away from the beach, from its distinctive culture to its wooded and mountainous interior.
 And although its tourism industry has grown rapidly in the last decade, the Dominican Republic, another large country, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti, has similarly avoided the image of saturation because of its size. To serve growing numbers of tourists and avoid congestion, the country has spread its construction over a variety of regions and established separate, modern airports to ease access.
Smaller Caribbean islands are the most vulnerable. Several of these, including Dominica, Montserrat, Saba, St. Eustatius and St. Vincent, remain for a variety of reasons relatively untouched by tourism. On some, island leaders have been ambivalent about opening doors to the tourist industry; on others, the infrequency of airline connections, or in the case of mountainous Dominica, the lack of white-sand beaches, have been inhibiting factors.
Nowadays, however, these less developed islands are being increasingly sought out, particularly by ecologically aware or active vacationers interested in hiking, sailing and other sports.
For this group of islands, Professor McElroy says, late arrival in the tourism game allows flexibility in planning, the opportunity to learn from the experience of the region around them, and time to decide exactly what sort of tourism they wish to encourage.
While no country seems ready to declare that it has reached a definitive limit with tourism, officials in some islands, like St. Lucia, St. Vincents, Grenada and Dominica, are planning to develop a collaborative marketing plan to advertise themselves as one destination. The aim is to avoid oversaturation and clutter.
Under this scheme, which is similar to one being used by the Bahamas, some Windward Islands will be marketed as resort centers with beach-based activities, while others will be promoted as quiet havens, for yachting and fishing or as centers for climbing and other land-based outdoor activities. Such plans reflect the growing realization that it is no longer desirable, economically or environmentally, to try to be all things to all tourists.

HEADLINE: Toll of Troubled Conversions Is Rising

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A YEAR after the first reports of defaults by sponsors who converted rental buildings into cooperatives, the number of troubled buildings has risen sharply and thousands of middle-income New York City apartment owners are caught in a financial squeeze.
Having assessed the extent of the problem, public officials are questioning the viability of noneviction conversions in which only a minority of the apartments are bought, leaving the rest occupied by rent-regulated tenants who have lifetime tenures guaranteed by state law. 
 Once regarded as the savior of deteriorating rental housing, conversion now is considered the real estate analogue of Wall Street's junk bonds, with some sponsors' having piled debt on debt, which they now cannot sustain.
"Cooperative ownership is not fundamentally flawed, but the conversion process is," said Frederick J. Mehlman, who heads of the Attorney General's Real Estate Finance Bureau, where 28 lawyers have devoted nearly full time this year to sorting through the fallout.
 Most of those affected are people who bought apartments during the real estate boom of the 80's, when conversions spread from the most affluent sections of Manhattan to middle-income neighborhoods across the city, from Brighton Beach in Brooklyn to Kingsbridge in the Bronx.
Since 1981, enough rental buildings have been converted to house almost a million of New York City's 7 million residents.
Only a small minority of these buildings are under financial strain. Indeed, most of the converted buildings, particularly those where more than half the apartments were sold to tenants or to outside buyers, face little or no risk. Nor are financial problems expected in either the long-established or the newly built co-ops, where there are no rental tenants.
But the problems are spreading. Defaults by sponsors were virtually unknown before 1989, and began to emerge last December, when Time Equities, a major converter, reported to New York State that it was behind in mortgage payments, taxes or maintenance charges at 88 co-ops.
Since then, disclosure statements to the Attorney General show that the sponsors of at least 300 buildings -- nearly 10 percent of the number converted during the 80's -- have fallen behind on their obligations to the co-ops and condominiums. Some arrears have been paid, but many remain past due.
The problems have arisen in buildings where sponsors still own large numbers of rent-regulated apartments whose tenants elected not to buy when the buildings were converted. Most of these tenants pay rents that fall far short of the monthly maintenance charges required to cover their apartments' shares of the operating costs of the co-op. These costs typically include payments on the building's underlying mortgage as well as taxes, insurance, utilities and staff wages.
Unable to make up the monthly shortfalls, the sponsors have been defaulting and their obligations have been falling on the tenant-shareholders who own a minority of the apartments in their buildings. Although a few of Manhattan's most fashionable upper-income buildings are caught in such binds, state records show that most of the troubled buildings are in middle-income neighborhoods.
In some of the buildings, lenders have foreclosed on the sponsors' unsold, rent-regulated apartments and are trying to sell them at distressed prices that could undercut the value of the other units. At other buildings, the apartment owners are threatening to foreclose to take over the sponsors' apartments and collect the rents themselves.
Most banks and thrift institutions, fearing problems in the future, are refusing to extend individual mortgage loans in co-ops where a majority of the apartments are occupied by rent regulated tenants, even if the co-ops show no immediate signs of financial strain. That is making it harder for apartment owners to sell in an otherwise weak real estate market.
As a worst case, lawyers say lenders could foreclose on entire co-ops where mortgage payments are in arrears, a devastating move that would take the apartment owners' homes away while leaving them deeply in debt. No co-op building has been taken over in a bank foreclosure since the Great Depression of the 30's.
In a related problem that could threaten rent-regulated tenants, Federal officials presiding over the savings-and-loan bailout have said they may try to evict the renters from apartments that have been taken over from insolvent lenders. Attorney General Robert Abrams, who has promised to fight the evictions in court, said 515 rental apartments in 10 buildings are now at risk and the number is certain to grow.
"This has turned into a disaster," said Claire Shulman, the Borough President of Queens, where 77,000 apartments were converted from rentals to co-ops and condominiums during the 80's. Ms. Shulman, like many other officials, said she had welcomed those conversions, thinking that they would stabilize neighborhoods and bring much-needed investment in building improvements. Now, she said, 14,000 Queens apartment owners are threatened because their sponsors are in default.
"We are small people, and we don't deserve this," said Barbara Rooney, a part-time data processer who, with her husband, Patrick, a fuel-truck coordinator at La Guardia Airport, was among 247 middle-income renters who bought their apartments in Hyde Park Gardens, a complex in Kew Gardens Hills that went co-op in 1986.
The Rooneys' problems are typical of those in troubled co-ops. Five hundred rent-regulated tenants in the complex, which has 747 garden apartments, elected not to buy. Most pay rents below the $500 to $700 a month that is assessed in maintenance on each apartment by the co-op, and some pay less than $300 a month.
ALTHOUGH the shortfall should be covered by the sponsor of the conversion, Herman I. Krauss, he stopped paying maintenance, taxes and mortgage payments more than six months ago and his banks have foreclosed on his unsold rental apartments.
The wave of co-op and condominium conversions during the 80's was unmatched in New York City history. State records show that conversion plans for 3,762 rental buildings with 311,819 apartments were accepted by between January 1981 and last July.
Most were conversions to co-ops, in which buyers became corporate shareholders in their buildings and shared the financial liabilities of their sponsors. A co-op sponsor's debts almost always include an underlying mortgage on the building, which his fellow shareholders help pay off as part of their monthly assessments for maintenance; they also usually include additional layers of bank financing.
Those who bought apartments that were converted to condominiums are less vulnerable because they own title to their apartments instead of corporate shares, but they are not immune to problems. Although there is no underlying mortgage to carry in a condominium building, sponsors may default on common charges on their units for the building's labor, utility and insurance costs. If that happens, the other apartment owners must cover the costs.
Typically, a sponsor in the mid-80's took a loan to buy a rental building for conversion, then used the unsold rental apartments in the building as collateral for other loans. Often, he also offered "wraparound financing" to buyers in the co-op, meaning that he became a lender himself, extending mortgage loans to fellow shareholders.
Some real estate experts say the problems at co-ops resemble those of Wall Street and its corporate clients, who entered the 1990's under too much debt. Some refer to recent co-op conversions as the junk bonds of New York City real estate. Others, though, maintain that the conversions benefited New York, protecting it somewhat from the flight of middle-income professionals during economic downturns.
"The city's dependence on rental housing has always been its fault line," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and urban planning at New York University. "To whatever extent the conversions of the 80's reduced the mobility of the middle-class, it has stabilized New York."
Nor is the outlook for all the troubled conversions entirely bleak. Some lenders, who have foreclosed on recalcitrant sponsors, are offering to transfer ownership of unsold apartments to their rental tenants at rock-bottom prices.
"THE obvious goal is to sell these apartments, and it is the tenants that have the greatest opportunity to benefit," said James Kerr, a spokesman for the Crossland Savings Bank, New York City's largest thrift, which has foreclosed on the unsold rental apartments in more than a dozen buildings. The apartments were used as collateral for $25 million in financing by Time Equities.
Crossland, with little desire to become a landlord, said it would offer its rent-regulated tenants in Time Equities buildings the opportunity to buy their apartments at low prices, but it declined to say how low.
The terms have been spelled out more clearly at Hyde Park Gardens, where the sponsor's apartments have been taken in foreclosure by a consortium of New York lenders, including the Bowery Savings Bank and EAB. In a preliminary offer, which must be approved by the Attorney General, the banks said their rent-regulated tenants could buy their apartments for $4,000 a room, or under $20,000 for a two-bedroom apartment.
Still, because many of the tenants' monthly rents are now below what they would be paying if they bought their apartments, there is no assurance the bail-out plan will work.
Many critics of the current conversion process have been lobbying legislators in Albany for changes. Most important, they say, is to amend the current law that allows sponsors to convert their buildings after selling only 15 percent of the shares or apartments in them.
For more than three years, Mr. Abrams and his staff have been seeking a new law to require that at least 25 percent of the apartments be sold in a conversion. The measure has been passed repeatedly in the Assembly but has so far failed in the Senate. It is to be introduced in each house again early next year.
"A lot of the problems we have seen in recent conversions are being worked out, but there may come a point where not all of them can be," said Mr. Melhlman of the Attorney General's office.
Lawyers say that foreclosing on the underlying mortgage of a co-op would be devastating to its shareholders. Since buyers in a co-op own shares a corporation -- giving them a different legal status from most homeowners -- their shares would be taken away and their apartments would revert to rental units. Although they could stay on as rental tenants, they would also retain responsibility for paying off their individual mortgage loans.
Some real estate lawywers say that such foreclosures, although possible, are at most a remote threat.
"I'm willing to bet it just won't happen," said Stuart Saft of Manhattan, an attorney for several troubled co-ops. He added that one defense available to the co-op shareholders is to seek protection for their buildings under Federal bankruptcy laws, a recourse that would mean added delay and legal expenses in trying to recover money owed by recalcitrant sponsors, but that would prevent lenders from seizing their homes. However, the ongoing operating costs of the building would still have to be carried by the shareholders.
Other complex legal questions have emerged. One is the role of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency charged with disposing of the assets of failed thrift institutions, including several that have financed New York City co-ops and condominiums. The agency, which has been ordered by Congress to seek the highest prices it can for its assets, threatened in September to evict nine rent-regulated tenants who had declined to buy their apartments in an expensive condominium on East 57th Street in Manhattan.
Resolution Trust, which had seized the apartments from insolvent lenders, reasoned that the apartments would be more valuable if they were vacant and that it could invoke Federal authority to bypass state rules. After protests from many New York officials, the agency withdrew its eviction threat temporarily in October and said it would conduct a review of how to handle rent regulated apartments. Two Representatives -- Eliot L. Engel of the Bronx and Yonkers and James H. Scheuer of Queens, the Bronx and Nassau County, both Democrats-- said they will introduce a bill in January that would require Resolution Trust to abide by any state or local law protecting renters from eviction.
LAST week, the Federal agency said through a spokesman in Washington that it was still studying the legal ramifications and might try to evict some New York City renters.
The consequences loom large. Mr. Mehlman said he knew of 515 rent- regulated apartments in 10 co-op and condominium buildings that have already fallen into Federal conservatorship this year because of the failures of the Nassau Federal Savings Bank in Brooklyn, the Ensign Savings Bank of Manhattan and other lenders. The list would grow if other thrifts fail in New York's troubled banking environment.
Real estate experts say the conversion wave of the 80's can be traced to the rent-control laws adopted during World War II and the rent-stabilization laws extended to postwar apartment buildings in 1974. Landlords, limited in how much they could raise rents, struck upon conversion as a way of turning a low-performance investment into a rich source of profits.
In many cases, the conversions also benefited tenants, who were able to buy their apartments at below-market prices and then sell them at a profit.
During the 50's and 60's and most of the 70's, conversions were governed by "eviction plan" rules imposed by the city and New York State. Landlords could convert their rentals to co-ops and evict tenants who did not buy, but they needed to first sell at least 35 percent of their units.
But the rules began to change in 1982 with the advent of state laws allowing "noneviction" conversions. Under this approach, sponsors were compelled to honor the rights of rent-regulated tenants but could convert their buildings by selling only 15 percent of the apartments or co-op shares. Federal tax laws made the conversion business more attractive because of generous real estate deductions, which enticed many investors to buy the occupied rental apartments from converters as long-term tax shelters.
Thus, the experts said, the stage was set in 1982 for the wave of conversions that lasted through the decade, even after changes in the Federal tax code in 1986 pushed most investors out of the market and left sponsors holding thousands of rent-regulated apartments.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Rent-Control Increases
 
Question: I am a rent-controlled tenant in a building that also has rent-stabilized tenants. I am now paying 7.5 percent increases and fuel pass-along costs while rent-stabilized tenants are paying only 9 percent increases on two-year leases. Some tenants in rent-controlled apartments pay more rent than tenants in rent-stabilized apartments, some of which have new sinks, refrigerators and gas ranges. Can anything be done to equalize the rents in our building? . . . Alfred Soled, Long Island City, Queens
 
Answer: No. Even though both forms of rent regulation are administered by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, their rent increases are based on different criteria.
In New York City, a maximum base rent is established for each rent-controlled apartment and owners who show they are providing essential services can raise rents by 7.5 percent each year until the maximum is reached. In the last few years the 7.5 percent increase has been higher than increases set for rent-stabilized apartments by the Rent Guidelines Board.
As part of a plan to put all rent-regulated housing under the same system, rent control is being phased out, with vacated apartments going to rent stabilization.
 
New Windows
 
Question: The management of our Mitchell-Lama complex recently started replacing the windows with ones of a different size. The problem for some tenants is that the old shades, blinds and air-conditioners do not fit. Is the landlord responsible for reimbursing us for the expense of having these things replaced or reinstalled? . . . Diane Christiansen, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. There are no rules in Mitchell-Lama housing that require landlords to reimburse tenants for blinds, shades or fixtures if these no longer fit after new windows have been installed. In Mitchell-Lama units under the jurisdiction of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, if the reinstallation of fixtures or air-conditioners involves no extra expense or effort, the landlord is responsible. Otherwise, the tenant must do it.
Roz Post, a spokesman for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said tenants in city-sponsored Mitchell Lama projects are responsible for replacing their own air-conditioners and other fixtures after window work has been done.
 
Security Deposits
 
Question: I am trying to recover the security deposit my sister made when she rented her apartment. She vacated when it became necessary for her to live in a nursing home. I understand that under such circumstances tenants can break leases without penalty. But what about the security deposit? Is there a law or rule that says it must be returned? . . . Raymond Laughlin, Manhasset, L.I.
 
Answer: No. Samuel Himmelstein, a lawyer who specializes in real estate matters, said there are no statutes that would automatically require a landlord to return a security deposit under the circumstances you have described. Mr. Himmelstein said that a tenant would probably be entitled to a return of the security only if a landlord caused a breach of the lease by failing to maintain an apartment in good condition.
Mr. Himmelstein said that making a strong case for the return of your sister's security deposit would depend on the wording of the lease. The security deposit clause in many leases, he said, states that the landlord has the right to retain the security if the tenant vacates before the end of the lease.

HEADLINE: Stamford Scrambling To Resurrect Office Boom

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
FOR most of the past two decades, Stamford has been a magnet to New York City corporations weary of rising rents and crime rates. Stamford was so desirable that it never created an economic-development office to help lure Fortune 500 companies, like the Olin Corporation, Xerox and GTE, that found their way there.
In the past year, though, Stamford's office boom has been brought up short by overbuilding, the slumping Northeast economy and the city's own high housing costs and growing congestion. To compete for what prospects remain -- like Jersey City and areas of neighboring Westchester County -- the city has begun aggressively courting corporate headquarters and financial services companies now in Manhattan. The campaign's centerpiece, a 16-page advertising supplement that was published in The Wall Street Journal last month, extols Stamford's virtues: economic stability, declining cost of housing and office space, proximity to Manhattan and the lack of a state or municipal income tax, which can mean an automatic raise of up to 12 percent for some employees leaving New York City. "Stamford is late in getting into the game, and has rested on its laurels for a long time," said David E. Anderson, president of the Stamford Partnership, a nonprofit alliance of business, government and community leaders involved in civic action and research. "Two years ago, no one would have dreamt of putting an 16-page insert in The Wall Street Journal." 
 More important, perhaps, is Mayor Thom Serrani's new role as a de facto director of economic development, holding strategy sessions, seminars and pep talks with commercial brokers battered by the city's chronically high office-space vacancy rates.
He has also stepped up his personal contacts with officials from companies considering moves to his city, like Morgan Stanley Group, a securities concern with 4,200 employees. "Until recently," Mr. Serrani said, "Stamford didn't have to sell itself. It was a natural. But because of the economy and the vacancy issues, I feel it's more incumbent upon me to change my role as Mayor.
"My job is to be the city's No. 1 salesman. And that's something I'm spending a lot of time doing."
Local real-estate brokers said that as a prelude to a possible move, Morgan Stanley will soon take an option to buy or lease an 11-acre site north of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad station in downtown Stamford.
Morgan Stanley officials, who have been exploring a move out of Manhattan for months and have looked at several locations in Connecticut, have denied that they have made a decision to move. The company's lease at 1251 Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan expires in 1998.
Neither Mr. Serrani nor a Morgan Stanley spokeswoman, Jeanne D. Andrews, would comment on a story published recently in The Advocate of Stamford that cited anonymous sources who said the company would shortly announce plans to relocate to Stamford.
"A lot of people feel they are very close to an announcement," said Joseph A. Ercolano, vice president of economic development for the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association, a private business-advocacy organization based in Stamford.
If Morgan Stanley does move to Stamford, city officials said, they hope that would spark other corporate relocations. They noted that Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, a brokerage house that employs almost 3,500 people in Manhattan, is reportedly considering a move to property in Greenwich owned by its parent company, Primerica.
Such a migration into Connecticut would be a smaller version of the wave that helped rebuild Stamford in the 1970's and early 1980's from a decrepit manufacturing town into a center for the reinsurance industry, accounting firms and corporate financial services.
That period virtually ended by the mid-1980's, when both residential and commercial real-estate costs rose so high that companies balked at moving to the area. Mergers and acquisitions also forced businesses, like the Singer Company, to leave Stamford.
Office-space vacancy rates in Stamford have been hovering around 25 percent. The glut has been especially troubling for the F. D. Rich Company, which built many of the high-rise towers that have become synonymous with the city's reputation as a new corporate capital. The company, pinched for cash, has been attempting to reorganize.
 
Problems Become Selling Points
 Stamford also has had to fend off efforts by other cities, including some of its Fairfield County neighbors, like Norwalk, to steal away the corporations that arrived 10 and 20 years ago. Although company officials have denied any move is in the works, people familiar with Stamford's real-estate market said a rumor had long been circulating that GTE would move its corporate headquarters to Texas.
The city's problems, however, have turned into selling points, as commercial rentals have fallen to about $25 a square foot from the high of $30 to $40 a square foot.
While still high, Stamford's residential real-estate prices have remained flat over the past 18 months. Many sellers, though, are offering lease options and other creative deals that make owning a home in the area easier. The average price of a single-family house in Stamford is about $295,000.
"The tremendous disparity between Fairfield County and other places doesn't exist anymore," said Richard E. Schwartz, vice president at Prudential Relocation Management in White Plains. "People who just a year or two ago never thought they could afford a house in lower Fairfield County now are finding out that they can."
So far, Stamford's campaign to snare large corporations disenchanted with New York has not yielded any tangible benefits, although Mr. Serrani said he soon expects to make "a major announcement involving more than one company."
No concern on Fortune magazine's list of the nation's 500 largest companieshas moved its headquarters from New York to Stamford since General Signal did so in 1976, although several corporations, like American Brands in 1986, have moved just across the border in Greenwich. Other large companies that have moved to Stamford, like Cadbury Schweppes in 1989, appear on the magazine's roster of the top 500 service companies or have dropped off the Fortune 500 list since their move.
Most city officials and real-estate brokers in the area agreed that Stamford's future lies with attracting smaller companies, like International Masters Publishing, a 150-employee direct-mail company that moved to the city from Los Angeles last year.
"If Morgan is the first to announce, others will follow," Mr. Ercolano said. "But someone has to make a first move."

LENGTH: 1823 words

HEADLINE: Towns Facing Service Cuts Under New Law

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AS local officials begin their annual struggle to balance rising municipal budgets, many say that a revised municipal spending law signed by Gov. Jim Florio last August will result in a substantial reduction in local services.
The law, commonly called the "municipal cap law" because it sets an annual 4.5 percent limit on increases in municipal budgets, was revised to eliminate exemptions from the cap that had been allowed under the prior law. Local officials say the revisions make an already bad law even worse. Limiting increases in municipal budgets, the officials say, contributes only marginally, if at all, to lowering property taxes. 
 Municipal services, they say, account for only a small portion of the total tax dollar paid by residents. Public education and county taxes, which are not limited by the law, account for as much as 75 percent of local tax bills, they say.
In addition, local officials say, eliminating exemptions for rapidly increasing solid-waste disposal and employee health benefit costs will result in cutbacks in other areas and may necessitate employee layoffs.
 State legislators, however, say the limitations are necessary to contain increases in local property taxes and to force local officials to eliminate unnecessary expenses. The elimination of exemptions to the law, they say, was necessary because as much as 50 percent of some municipal budgets had been exempted under the old law.
The budget cap issue arises as state and local officials, faced with an electorate angered by increases in state taxes and the threat of a statewide recession, attempt to achieve a balance between the rising cost of government and antitax sentiment.
"I think the whole cap law is basically a sham," said Robert A. Roth, chief financial officer of Middletown Township, a Monmouth County municipality with 70,000 residents.
"The law is designed to benefit state politicians at the expense of local government," Mr. Roth said. "It gives the impression that the legislators are doing something about taxes when in reality they're not."
Mr. Roth, like many municipal financial officers across the state, said the law failed to address the problem that it was intended to solve -- a steady rise in property taxes.
Inasmuch as the law limits increases in spending for most ordinary municipal services, he said, it only serves to hamstring officials who are faced with spiraling expenses over which they have no control. At the same time, Mr. Roth said, insofar as the law fails to place effective limits on public education expenses and county taxes, which together often account for as much as 75 percent of a municipality's total tax bill, the law does little to prevent municipal property taxes from increasing.
As a result, he said, the law effectively shifts the blame for rising taxes from state legislators and local school board officials to municipal government.
"Let's face it," Mr. Roth said. "The municipality sends out the tax bills, and it's the local tax collector sitting in a municipal office who ends up taking the wrath of the public."
 Mayor Patrick W. Parkinson of Middletown said, for example, that the Middletown Board of Education recently awarded teachers an 8.5 percent raise and clerks a 9.5 percent raise for each of the next three years.
The Board of Education's $70 million annual budget, which is double the municipal budget of $35 million, is not limited by the municipal cap laws, he said.
But with salaries and benefits accounting for 80 percent of the school budget, and with the school budget accounting for almost 60 percent of the total municipal tax bill, Board of Education salaries and benefits account for 48 percent of Middletown's property taxes, Mr. Parkinson said.
At the same time, Mr. Parkinson said, Middletown is now in salary negotiations with other municipal employees, including the police unions.
"When they see the teachers getting 8 and 9 percent, then they want it too," he said. But with a 4.5 percent limit on non-education municipal expenditures, Mr. Parkinson said, it is impossible to give employees a raise in excess of the limit without cutting services somewhere else.
"If the state wants us to adhere to the 4.5 percent, then fine," Mr. Parkinson said. "But keep the playing field level. As it is, we feel that the taxpayers are being taken to the cleaners on this."
The municipal cap law was first enacted in 1976 and provided for a 5 percent limit on almost all non-education municipal expenditures. Over the years, however, certain expenditures were exempted.
Solid-waste disposal costs, liability and health insurance costs and the purchase of police vehicles, for example, were exempted. In all, the original law was amended 46 times. But as a result, by 1990, exempted expenses in some municipalities accounted for almost half the budgets of those municipalities.
 
Exemptions Taken Back
 In August, Gov. Jim Florio signed a revised law that brought all the exemptions back under the spending limitation and reduced the statutory ceiling to 4.5 percent, with a provision allowing the municipalities to apply for an increase to 5 percent. Limits on public education expenses are not included in the law, but are governed by a complex formula contained in the Quality Education Act of 1990.
"This is the only way we can get a true picture of what the municipalities are required to spend," said State Senator Richard Van Wagner, Democrat of Middletown and sponsor of the revised legislation.
"The original cap law was useless," Mr. Van Wagner said. "The Legislature kept excluding things, and when you exclude things, you are in effect mandating property tax increases. We essentially went back to ground zero."
But that, municipal officials say, is just the problem.
After managing their municipalities for years with certain expenses outside the cap, they say, it is impossible for them to now absorb increasing costs for those expenses within the 4.5 percent limitation.
 
'Just Not Going to Work'
 "This is just not going to work," said James Pascale, township administrator of Princeton. "Tipping fees for solid-waste removal have increased several hundredfold in the last several years. And health insurance is not going up 5 percent; it's going up a whole lot more than that."
Both those expenses, he said, which had previously been exempted from caps, must now be included within the spending limit, thereby reducing available capital for other programs or services. "Something has got to give," Mr. Pascale said.
Another anomaly associated with the law, he said, is the fact that municipalities fortunate enough to have a budget surplus are prohibited from spending it without placing a referendum on the ballot requesting authorization.
"A community can have literally millions of dollars in surplus," Mr. Pascale said, "but because of the arbitrariness of the cap law, they can't spend the money, even if they have a high demand for certain municipal services."
But the most troubling aspect for local officials is that by enacting such a restrictive law, the Legislature has essentially pre-empted municipalities from establishing their own spending restraints.
 
'Arrogant and Presumptuous'
 "My opinion is that it's arrogant and presumptuous of the Legislature to think that local officials have no self-control," Mr. Pascale said, adding that "the fact of the matter is they're taxpayers in the community, so they're not going to spend a thin dime more than they have to."
The problems associated with the new law are not limited to sprawling suburban communities like Middletown or those fortunate enough to have surplus funds.
"In the past, the city never had a problem because of the exemptions," said Arthur Bunting Jr., Atlantic City's director of finance and revenue. "But insurance costs and solid-waste disposal costs have doubled and tripled and quadrupled."
What that means, Mr. Bunting said, is that "it's impossible to stay within the caps without reducing staff."
Experts on municipal government agree that many municipalities may have a difficult time operating within the new spending guidelines.
"They've got good reason to be concerned," said John Moran, a legislative analyst for the New Jersey League of Municipalities. "This is the tightest cap law that municipal governments have had to operate under since 1976."
Mr. Moran said, however, that some expenditures still remained outside the cap and could be increased as necessary. They include capital expenditures, amounts required to finance the previous year's deficits, public library support and affordable housing costs.
 
'Escape Clause' Provided
 In addition, experts say, there is an "escape" clause contained in the legislation that allows the state's Local Finance Board in the Department of Community Affairs to make exceptions to the law.
"They can get out from under the caps if they prove a case," said Dr. Ernest Reock, director of the Bureau of Government Research for Rutgers University in New Brunswick.
The law provides, however, that any exception made by the state's Local Finance Board must then be granted to all the state's 567 municipalities, a provision that would constrain the board from making decisions based upon strictly parochial needs.
But even with that provision, Dr. Reock said, he is opposed to the idea of legislative restraints on municipal budgets. "It does hold down expenditures," he said, "but I think that it's a terrible way to do it."
Dr. Reock said legislation establishing strict spending limitations took part of the responsibility for governing a municipality away from local officials. "What this really means is that you don't trust the political process to work within the community," he said.
And that, Dr. Reock said, weakens the concept of home rule in that it diminishes the right of the municipality to tax and spend as it sees fit.
 
Flying 'Flag' of Home Rule
 But Mr. Van Wagner, sponsor of the revised law, disagreed.
"There's no such thing as home rule," he said. "Home rule is a flag that flies when the municipalities want to do what they want to do."
Local officials, he said, would be wise to consider consolidating services and finding other ways to trim expenses. "There's a revolution going on in this state," he said, "and part of the anger is a great frustration with the growth of property taxes."
Municipal officials, however, appear to be well aware of that frustration.
At a recent League of Municipalities convention in Atlantic City, organizers scheduled a seminar on the expected impact of the caps.
As members entered the Grand Ballroom at Convention Hall, which had been curtained in half, it soon became apparent that more space would be needed. The curtains were drawn, and more than 1,000 members filled the hall -- the largest crowd that had assembled in the three days of meetings.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Delaware;
Faculty Broadens University Policy On Harassment

DATELINE: NEWARK, Del.

 BODY:
In the wake of a series of racial and anti-homosexual incidents on campus, the Faculty Senate of the University of Delaware ratified a proposal last week that strengthened the university's policy on sexual, racial and other forms of harassment.
In October, racial and anti-homosexual slurs were written on residence-hall doors, and a black student found her black doll hanging by its neck in her room. 
 In response to the incidents, the Black Students Union and the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual Student Union joined other university groups in a rally to voice their concerns and vowed not to tolerate such acts.
The university's president, David P. Roselle, told the protesters: "We need to be vigilant. We need to be more aware. We need to have better policies."
 
 Additions to List
 Acts prohibited under the old policy included intimidation by threats of violence and personal vilification of students on the basis of their race, sex, sexual orientation, age, religion or disability.
The new policy adds to the list vilification on the basis of national or ethnic origin, veteran's status, creed or color and defines more explicitly what constitutes harassment.
"Basically, we improved the definition of harassment by clarifying it," said Daniel D. Shade, an assistant professor in the Department of Individual and Family Studies and chairman of the faculty's committee on student life. Referring to the characters in the original "Star Trek" television series, Professor Shade said, "McCoy's calling Spock an ugly, pointy-eared Vulcan is an example of personal vilification."
Earlier this semester, Leslie Goldstein, a professor of political science and the Faculty Senate's president, charged the committee on student life with reviewing and clarifying the student handbook's policy statement on harassment. Professor Shade said the recent incidents of harassment on campus based on race and sexual orientation had increased the need for a policy change.
 
Possible Penalties
 Timothy F. Brooks, the dean of students, said there was a concern that the old policy would not pass a legal review, since it "was vague and flawed and could be misinterpreted."
Dean Brooks said harassment violations, heard by administrative hearing officers on a case-by-case basis, could result in probation, suspension or expulsion.
The president of the Delaware Undergraduate Student Congress, Michael E. DiFebbo Jr., said the old policy was ineffective because there was no clear definition of harassment. "It basically said harassment is harassing people," said Mr. DiFebbo, a senior business major from King of Prussia, Pa.
Farley Grubb, an associate professor of economics and a faculty senator who voted against the policy, said, "The new statement is in too much detail and loses control of how harassment is defined."
Professor Grubb added that the new policy would not have any effect on students. "It was an extreme attempt to codify a policy that was not codifiable," he said.

HEADLINE: A Heritage of Giving: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund;
Proud but Suddenly Poor, Elderly Reach Out for Help

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Two months after Esther S., a former accountant and grade-school teacher, came to New York City from the Soviet Union last year, she found herself homeless and contemplating suicide. Lilian F., who lived a privileged life on the Upper East Side for many years, found herself penniless and almost homeless after the death of her husband.
Like countless other elderly men and women who face economic setbacks, failing health and family problems each year, Esther and Lilian reluctantly set aside their pride and turned to charities for assistance. 
 It was an emotionally wrenching step.
"I always used to have my own piece of bread," Esther said through an interpreter. "Here I am at 69, in a strange country with a strange language, where everything is different, abandoned by my daughter, and I still don't know why."
Lilian, describing how she felt about having to ask for help, said: "It was horrendous. It was like I wanted to jump out of the window."
In New York City today, an increasing number of elderly residents find themselves ineligible for government assistance but "still too poor to make it on their own," said Prema Mathai-Davis, the city's Commissioner for the Aging. For many of them, she added, the only option is a private social-service agency.
 
Arguments About Money
 When Esther arrived in this country from her native town in the western Ukraine, she moved in with her daughter and grandchildren in a two-bedroom apartment in Forest Hills.
"Everything was perfect for the first two months," Esther recalled.
She helped with the cleaning and other household chores, tutored her 13-year-old granddaughter in mathematics, and made embroidered items that she sold to supplement the family's income. But there were arguments, mostly about money.
Earlier this year she fell ill with digestive problems and was hospitalized for 10 days.
When she returned to her daughter's apartment, she said, the atmosphere was different. There were arguments that she said were initiated by her daughter's boyfriend over such questions as whether she ate too much of the family's food.
Finally, she said, her daughter kicked her out.
 
A Place to Live
 "It was a cold, rainy day, the end of March," Esther recalled. "For a moment there in the street I got the idea it would be good to be hit by a car."
But a 90-year-old Russian woman passing by convinced Esther to move in with her for a few days. Then Esther got a temporary job as a live-in babysitter on Long Island.
As that job was about to end last May, Esther contacted the Metropolitan New York Coordination Council on Jewish Poverty. The council, which maintains an emergency housing fund with Neediest Cases Fund contributions it receives from the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, got Esther a room in a private shelter and is paying her rent.
"Esther could have gone to a city shelter, but I don't think she would have survived," said Peter Fine, director of special projects for the council.
 
Doing Things for Friends
 At Respite House, on Manhattan's Lower East Side, Esther is one of 14 residents, who are assisted by two full-time social workers.
A petite woman with white hair, dark, questioning eyes, and a strong, husky voice, Esther is the kind of person who needs to be doing things for others. These days she spends most of her time in her room doing needlework, embroidery or alterations for her new friends in the shelter.
At other times, Esther, who knows almost no English, can be found sitting in the smoking corner of the shelter's lounge, conversing in Yiddish with several other residents or in Romanian with a couple who live in the building.
 
Losing Everything
 Further uptown, Lilian lives near Beekman Place, surrounded by the bric-a-brac of better days: Thai prints, Italian Renaissance pottery, an onyx table and crystal figurines.
A native New Yorker, Lilian has youthful skin and a youthful figure that belie her 74 years.
She was married to the senior partner in a Wall Street brokerage and had everything: a 6 1/2-room apartment in a building on East 57th Street, two Cadillacs and yearly trips around the world.
Then, in 1973, her husband died and the bottom fell out of her world. Soon after his death, the firm went out of business.
Lilian lost her apartment and rented a one-bedroom apartment near Beekman Place for herself and her son, who is developmentally disabled.
"I sold the stocks, the antiques, the furniture, the silverware and most of my jewelry, one piece at a time," she recalled.
 
Son Out of Work
 She now lives on Social Security, no longer entertains or goes to the theater and has taken "little jobs," with the Board of Elections and the Census Bureau. But the rent has more than doubled in the last year and there is nothing more to sell, "just bric-a-brac," she said.
Her 54-year-old son has been out of work for more than two years, and their financial situation continued to deteriorate. So did their relationship: Her son refused to leave when she tried to evict him. So the two of them continued to argue.
"I just couldn't manage anymore and needed help," she said in an interview.
 
Rebuilding Self-Esteem
 Lilian turned to the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged, a social-service agency, which also receives Neediest Cases funds through the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. The agency is providing Lilian with a rent supplement until she can find permanent affordable housing.
"I'm trying to help Lilian cope with the terrible assault on her self-esteem," said Doris Solomon, the social worker who now meets regularly with Lilian and her son.
Ms. Solomon has also helped Lilian's son get into a state job training program.
"JASA has been a big help, helping with the rent and easing the tension with my son," Lilian said. "But life is not the way it used to be."

HEADLINE: A Heritage of Giving: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund;
Catholic Charities Fill Gaps Families Can't

BYLINE: By NOAM COHEN

 BODY:
Charles Dickens once observed that the difference between happiness and misery is the difference between being a penny over budget and a penny under budget.
The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, one of seven charities that receive money from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, assist the poor when budgets become unbalanced. 
 Often providing money at times of crisis, the charities can keep a family in its home while a dispute over government benefits is being settled, provide the means for a pregnant teen-ager to see a doctor or tide over the family of a recently laid-off worker with supplies from a food pantry.
As a major social-services contractor of the City of New York, the Catholic Charities send staff workers called homemakers to see families, many of whom have histories of neglected children. Money donated to the Neediest Cases allows the workers the discretion to give diapers or baby formula to families that need them.
 
Food, Diapers and Bunk Beds
 A typical reason families fall behind, said Kenneth Kimball, the director of family and children services, is a father who fails to provide child support.
"We use the money to fill in the gaps when the city can't react fast enough," Mr. Kimball said as he opened a closet on the sixth floor of the charities' offices in the headquarters of the Archdiocese of New York at 1011 First Avenue, near 55th Street.
Inside were packages of food and a three-foot high container of diapers. In Mr. Kimball's office were receipts for bunk beds and cribs.
The importance of the everyday products becomes telling when one realizes that families are hungry and children sleep on the floor, Mr. Kimball said.
 
Part of a Last-Ditch Effort
 And the needs are growing. Father Kevin Sullivan, director of the charities' department of social development, said, "We see people coming to the pantries earlier in the month."
Since most of these families are being monitored by homemakers because a court suspects trouble -- particularly drug abuse by a parent -- the supplies are part of a last-ditch effort to keep a family intact.
Last year, the midtown Manhattan office spent $32,133 for diapers and the like, and much of that money was provided by the Neediest Cases. Similar purchases were made in five other offices from Staten Island to East Harlem.
Founded in 1917, the Catholic Charities spend more than $15 million a year operating hospitals, shelters and nursing homes. Most of that money comes from parishoners' donations.
 
Society's Most Fragile Members
 The Neediest Cases gave the organization $561,442 after last year's drive. That amount was part of $771,911 that the charities spent on direct relief and staff services that assist the poor.
In recent years, the charities have seen more and more resources used to combat the effects of drug addiction and AIDS.
With the goal of smoothing over crises, the charities focus on society's most fragile members: teen-age mothers, illegal aliens, the homeless.
The bulk of the archdiocese's direct assistance is used to care for pregnant women and young mothers and children. Last year, $337,392 went to the charities' Maternity Services Ministry, which operates three shelters in the Bronx and Manhattan.
 
Back to Independent Living
 The newest shelter, which opened in May of 1989 in the Parkchester section of the Bronx, serves 18 women and their newborn children.
There is also a shelter for 19 pregnant homeless women on the Lower East Side and another for 12 women with newborn children in the Bronx.
The goal of the shelters is to lead the women back to independent living with their children, said Sister Una McCormack, executive director of the Catholic Home Bureau, which supervises the Maternity Services Ministry.
"We have been very successful in moving women out to their own apartments," she said. "Thank God, none of their children have gone into foster care."
Sister McCormack said that in some of the shelters, women who have moved into their own apartments return to talk to the current residents.
The people who run the charities say they have not seen a drop in donations from individuals, but know that their services are being particularly taxed when more and more families are facing crises related to the health of the economy.

HEADLINE: Awaiting the Call of the Big Leagues, Young Socialites Party on Their Own

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
On the charity circuit, they are the not-ready-for-prime-time players. They have the evening clothes, the social connections and the philanthropic impulses. But they are not old enough or rich enough for serious galas at $500 to $1,000 a ticket and so, increasingly, they are running benefits on their own, on the cheap.
The juniors, as they are called, have a certain style. No gilded hotel ballrooms for them -- clubs are less expensive, more lively venues. No sit-down dinners -- only old people need to sit down. No society orchestras -- a deejay will do. And forget the fancy decorations -- the crowd is decorative enough. 
 The top ticket price for a junior party is $150, with many events around $100. Guests are mostly in their 20's and 30's, although some powers behind the benefits are in their 40's and musing about moving into the big time.
 
Reluctant Graduates

 
 Alfred (Chappy) Morris, who at 40 still gets invitations to debutante parties and bachelor balls, recently graduated to the list for $1,000 benefits. "I guess that's one way to tell you're a senior," he said.
He and other leaders of the Lobby Gallery Associates of the Whitney Museum have been pondering their status. One of them, Christine Mortimer Biddle, said, "With the economy, a lot of juniors can't afford to be seniors and yet they still want to support the charities."
Invitations to junior parties sometimes list members of the younger generations of old society families like the Rockefellers and the Phippses. But the names of fashion models, designers and musicians also draw juniors. And they love titles, no matter how questionable the lineage.
"You'll find a lot of committees headed by His Royal Highness So-and-So or Princess Whoever," said Polly Onet, who handles junior benefits for Gustavus Ober Associates, a public relations concern.
For Ms. Onet and other juniors, charity parties have become the place "to make connections, professional and social," she said. "With everything that's happening -- crime, AIDS -- people are leery about going to night clubs and staying out till 2 in the morning. They want to dress up, go out at a civil hour and, for $75 or so, meet attractive people."
 
Repaying Debts

 
 Juniors without the time or space to entertain at home pay back social debts with benefit tickets. "They'll buy a $1,000 table, invite 12 friends and that's their entertainment for the year," Ms. Onet said. "It's for a good cause and it's tax deductible."
Anyone who has done time on the charity circuit can remember when juniors amounted to "window dressing," as Lewis Ufland put it. He and other charity-event planners would set aside junior tables for committee members' children because "older people love to look at young people." "In the past, juniors were not treated as grown-ups," Mr. Ufland said. "Now they're doing their own parties and they're being taken seriously."
Juniors emerged as a fund-raising force in the mid-1980's when charity balls blazed and waves of young people got rich on Wall Street. As the decade ended, virtually every cause from the New York Public Library to the Guardian Angels had a cadre of young supporters.
 
'A Tough Year'

 
 Like seniors, juniors are scrambling these days to attract corporate donors and underwriters while holding the line on ticket prices. As Tav Berry, head of the junior committee of the Girl Scouts Council of Greater New York, put it: "Everybody's having a tough year. Asking $300 a couple is not the easiest sell."
Juniors do not deliver the big bucks as seniors do. Juniors' benefits that raise $30,000 are considered blockbusters. Charities see junior committees not only as fund-raising groups but also as training grounds for the next generation of Pat Buckleys and Nan Kempners.
"They have to start somewhere, " said Joanne de Guardiola, chairwomen of the Associates of Memorial Sloan-Kettering.
Mark Gilbertson, chairman of the Winter Ball at the Museum of the City of New York, said his group was grooming "future leaders of the museum, trustees and donors." He added, "A lot of people are from old New York families."
People from new New York families are on the Boys Harbor junior committee, though. For example, a co-chairwoman is Odette Cabrera, whose parents were born in the Dominican Republic and who attended prep school on scholarship.
Her group raised $25,000 at a recent $40-a-ticket black-tie benefit. "We could have charged $100," Ms. Carera said. "But we kept it low so everyone could join in, not just the elite and the affluent."
 
To Some, Older Is Better

 
 Not all juniors stick to their own circuit. Christopher Mason, the songwriter who twits both generations at society parties, prefers going to senior parties and paying junior prices.
He was among a throng of young people who paid $125-a-ticket to dance at a recent Metropolitan Museum of Art benefit after the $900 crowd had had dinner. "Frankly I find it much more interesting to have a good mix of the ages," he said. "I always liked being around old people, anyway."
Junior parties may be "tiresome even though one's getting a deliciously cheaper ticket," he said, adding that one cannot very well social-climb among one's peers.
"All of the juniors at the museum were zeroing in on people like Ivana and Nan Kempner, " Mr. Mason said. "Pat Buckley was surrounded by adoring young men. It was a very funny sight seeing the juniors and the older group mix."

HEADLINE: Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:
The history of American numismatics would be incomplete without mentioning the notes of Norton I, Emperor of the United States and Protector of Mexico.
The Imperial notes were issued from 1871 to 1880 and give testimony to one of the United States' most benevolent rulers. 
 Born in London in 1818, the future emperor accompanied his plebian parents to South Africa in 1820 where his father farmed and opened a ship's chandelry.
With the death of his father in 1843, Joshua Norton was left with a failing chandelry and by 1849 he joined the gold rush, which was heading for San Francisco. But Norton never left for the mines.
Instead he began provisioning the miners from his base in San Francisco. Joshua Norton & Co. bought and resold flour and coal, coffee and tea, liquor, bricks and rice. He took in a partner, but then dissolved the partnership. His warehouse burned down in the fire of 1851 and he rebuilt it.
Norton sold hides to London and speculated in mine stocks and real estate. By 1852, he was a respected member of San Francisco's business community and he was well on his way to becoming a millionaire.
Then he heard a rumor that China had prohibited the export of all rice and so he formed a syndicate to corner the rice market. He signed all the contracts himself and when shipment after shipment of rice was unloaded in San Francisco harbor, Norton was ruined.
His partners vanished and Norton was liable for all payments. He tried to get relief in the courts and failed.
By 1855 his $15,000 of remaining assets were sold to relieve his debts. In the middle of a recession, Norton found no way to recoup his losses. He disappeared.
Mythlike, however, Joshua Norton rose again. In the San Francisco Bulletin of Sept. 17, 1859, Norton proclaimed himself Norton I, Emperor of the United States.
His imperial residence was the Eureka Lodging House on Commercial Street, his trusted counselors and Praetorian Guards were his two dogs, Bummer and Lazarus. The imperial robes were an old donated army coat and navy trousers and boots.
His tall crown was a white beaver hat with a large plume. As one set of clothes wore out, new ones were donated. Gold epaulets appeared on the imperial shoulders and imperial walks were aided by a new cane.
Each day, Norton I wandered the streets of San Francisco, surveying his empire. He rectified all social ills by decree. The Emperor's proclamations appeared from time to time in San Francisco's newspapers, each a studied cure for the nation's ills.
Norton dissolved both the Democratic and Republican parties in the name of peace and he called for an end to the Civil War.
He also called for the abolition of Congress and then abolished it himself. The Emperor attended synagogue each Saturday and a Catholic or Protestant church each Sunday.
His business friends from his more successful years supported his few needs and the British Consul is thought to have paid many of the bills of the imperial household.
But by 1870, Norton's old friends were dying. So on Jan. 15, 1871 the printing firm of Cuddy & Hughes printed the first of a series of notes, which were tendered by The Imperial Government of Norton I.
Those first notes were for $5 each. But the Emperor must have had a difficult time passing them because he immediately started issuing notes for the imperial sum of 50 cents.
Each note promised to pay gold coin to the bearer in the amount of the listed sum plus 7 percent interest. At the maturity date of 1880, the bearer could convert each note into one payable in 1900.
This was probably a wise course as no notes were ever known to be redeemed. Instead they were kept as souvenirs and pasted in cafe windows as advertisements of imperial patronage.
The imperial treasury would generally issue just one or two of the 50 cent notes per day, paying for food and lodging.
By 1878, the bonds were so well received that the interest rate fell to 5 percent and by 1879, Emperor Norton I was issuing notes for $10.
Emperor Norton I died while walking the streets of San Francisco on Jan. 8, 1880. The police had to control the crowds at his funeral and today his notes are quite rare and valuable.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Bouncing Along Above the Low

 BODY:
IN a rough week, the dollar held up pretty well. That means it didn't set another record low, even though there were plenty of reasons for it to do so. The dollar started the week on a note of strength, having pierced the 1.50 level against the German mark. But then Saddam Hussein said he would release all of his hostages, defusing fears of a Gulf war and lessening the dollar's attraction as a safe harbor. The Government reported November employment data, which showed an economy falling even faster than expected with a loss of 267,000 non-farm jobs. And the Federal Reserve eased the Fed funds rate another quarter of a point, to 7.25 percent. The dollar fell under all this weight, but only to 1.4725 against the mark, a smidgen above its latest record low of 1.4705.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
When a Weak Dollar Is Useful

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
World stock markets have not been very kind to American investors this year. But the dollar has.
A sharp fall in the dollar in 1990 has shielded American investors in European markets from sharp losses. In Britain, for example, the dollar's drop against the pound turned a 11.2 percent stock market decline into a gain of 7.47 percent when translated back into dollars, according to the Financial Times World Indices. 
 And now that the dollar has also weakened against the yen, after rising sharply earlier this year, the losses in the Japanese stock market, the sharpest of any major market this year, have been trimmed by 14 percent.
Despite all that, "investing overseas is not a pure currency play," said John Ford, a director at Rowe Price-Fleming International in London, which manages several global mutual funds. "You should not move in and out on a pure currency view."
He is right. A currency forecast, just like any other, can be off base. The dollar was expected to decline this year, but few economists saw it falling to the depths it actually reached; some even thought it would be rising by now. And worrying too much about currency can rob an investor of nice stock gains over time.
Yet the dollar has played a key role in the last several years in overseas returns and it could do so again next year. Indeed, looking at overall returns for foreign markets without acknowledging the dollar component can be deceiving.
So what lies ahead? According to several current forecasts, the dollar will decline further at the beginning of the new year from the new lows that it reached this year against the mark and the Swiss franc. But it is expected to rise again by the end of 1991. If a dollar rally does occur, it would eat into what are already expected to be modest gains in many stock markets.
"It may not be a bad year for stock markets," said Geoffrey Dennis, chief international economist at James Capel Inc. in London. "But a rise in the dollar will really cut into those gains."
Analysts and economists generally agree that the dollar will continue to fall in early 1991 because the American economy appears to be in a recession, the Federal Reserve (as it did Friday) is expected to push interest rates lower, the German central bank is expected to raise interest rates in that country and the Japanese, at the least, will hold them steady. All this spells a lower dollar since higher rates abroad favor other currencies, and world capital will generally flow to growing economies, like Germany's.
But if the American recession is short-lived, the stage could be set for a dollar rally later in the year, say some forecasters, including those at Goldman Sachs, Salomon Brothers and James Capel. Under this scenario, interest rates in the United States would stop falling, the stock market here would rally and foreign capital would flow in to reap the gains in the American market.
James Capel expects the dollar to reach the 1.70 range against the mark by the end of 1991, or a 15 percent increase from current levels, and nearly $1.68 against the British pound, an increase of 16 percent. Goldman Sachs forecasts slightly higher gains.
These increases, mirrored by the dollar's advances against other European currencies, would sharply curtail the gains -- or accentuate the losses -- in the European stock markets. As for the yen, the experts are divided. James Capel thinks the dollar will remain weak against the yen, meaning an investment in Japan could face little currency risk. But Goldman sees the dollar rising about 7 percent, which adds to the risk in this already turbulent market.
There is a haven abroad from this problem. It is Hong Kong, where the currency is closely tied to the dollar and there is almost no currency risk. Rowe Price-Fleming International predicts that Hong Kong and other Southeast Asia markets, excluding Japan, will be the fastest-growing next year. But as good as Hong Kong might be, it is too small a market in which to concentrate investments.
So a diversified investor cannot avoid the currency risk. But focusing on that risk, along with prospects for the foreign stock markets, means fewer surprises.
