HEADLINE: The Tables Have Turned on Gambling

BYLINE: By N.R. KLEINFIELD

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
The cards slapped down on the baize blackjack tables in mind-numbing regularity. The roulette wheels spun, and the slots chattered incessantly, occasionally coughing up cups full of winnings, mostly just eating up dreams. Down at the Copacabana, Barry Manilow was singing. Billboards promised that Joan Rivers would be coming to Caesars. Outside, the air was brittle and the ocean waves were choppy. At Boardwalk Roger's Famous Hot Dogs, hot dogs twirled on their heating rollers, but only one customer came.
A middle-aged man with chiseled features and a thin mustache climbed out of his seat at one of the blackjack tables at Bally's. He gave a wave of disgust. A short-skirted hostess asked him if there was anything he would like. He said, "How about some more chips? They busted me." 
 He paused a moment to talk. "Last year, I used to come twice a month," he said. "If I blew a hundred, two hundred, I racked it up to bad cards. Now, I can't handle that. My car is eating money with these high gas prices. I'm worried about heating oil bills; I've got four bedrooms and a den. No way I stop coming to play the games. But it's once a month now. My wife said she'd get an ax after me if I came more often. My wife has a bit of a temper."
Masses of traffic still rush into Atlantic City, transporting the hopeful. But not as many, and not as often. Gloom has enveloped Atlantic City along with the entire casino industry.
In the past, gaming has been a business that has bragged that recessions couldn't touch it. No matter what bumps the economy hits, casino operators have insisted, people will always find the extra dollars to take a chance at the tables and the slots, the high rollers will still gravitate to the baccarat games. It is a tune that sounds flat these days. Throughout the glitzy gaming halls of Atlantic City, business is dwindling, evident most vividly in the grave turn in the fortunes of Donald Trump. And the problems of Atlantic City have begun to disturb Nevada, too, albeit to a much smaller extent. Depending on what happens with the cost of oil and the sagging economy, the problems could worsen with great rapidity.
"Everybody is getting hurt right now," said Raymond Neidl, a casino analyst with Dillon, Read & Company. "The whole industry is in trouble."
 
Failing a Test
 Earlier in the year, the feeling was that the crucial test for the industry would be midsummer. But July and August were bad; business hasn't improved much in the fall, and with the end of the year typically inconsequential in terms of generating high levels of play, the books are pretty much closed on what has been a despondent 1990 for casinos.
According to figures compiled by the New Jersey Casino Association, the 12 casinos in Atlantic City together lost $4.3 million in the second quarter, which marked the first time that had happened since gambling was allowed here in 1978. They managed to register a profit of $35.2 million in the third quarter, but that was less than half the $83.6 million earned a year ago. Las Vegas, which doesn't report complete numbers for its casinos in the same way Atlantic City does, has been faring better, though quite a few properties in both cities are heavily in debt and not well poised to sustain themselves in a protracted downturn in play.
"Three months from now you'll read that Las Vegas has the same problems that Atlantic City has because there's oversupply," said Jack Galloway, president of TropWorld, a casino in Atlantic City. "There are a lot of operators in Las Vegas who are real worried."
The problem is not so much that there isn't adequate business, but that too much debt has been strapped to many casinos. "The banks are really pulling in their horns now," Mr. Neidl said. "So debt maturations are becoming more important than ever."
Sheila O'Connell, a gaming analyst at Duff & Phelps in Chicago, estimates that Las Vegas casino revenues will grow about 7 percent this year and Atlantic City's will be flat. The last time Atlantic City had any big growth in gaming revenue was 1988, when revenues rose 9.6 percent. Next year she thinks Atlantic City's gambling revenues could fall and, although she is more pessimistic than some, that Las Vegas's might improve by no more than 4 to 6 percent.
Whether any casinos will actually silence their rackety one-armed bandits and close up remains unclear. But many casino operators express bitter disillusionment toward their prospects over the next year, should a bad recession set in.
 
Where It's Darkest
 Without doubt, the mood is darkest for the gambling parlors in Atlantic City. September was the first month since Donald Trump's much-ballyhooed Taj Mahal opened in April that total table drop -- the amount of chips bought at casinos -- fell from the prior year. Every casino in the city suffered a decline. October's drop was up just a little over 1 percent, and was down significantly if the Taj Mahal is not counted.
"The casinos will not be helped unless an actual casino floor is closed," said Harold Vogel, a media and gaming analyst at Merrill Lynch. "But I think the state of New Jersey will do everything to keep people employed. It will not be the first thing they would let happen."
If the casinos can ride out the sour economy, they could gain some curative benefits. "Maybe this pause is good, because it's made everyone look inside their organizations and cut costs," said Al Glasgow, a gaming consultant in Atlantic City who publishes Atlantic City Action, a newsletter tracking the casinos, and who occasionally consults for Donald Trump. "The big question is, 'Can the operators adjust to cut their costs or will they keep spending money to draw customers?' The old dilemma is coming into play for everyone: Is it better to lose market share and make money or is it better to lose money and hold on to market share?"
It is instructive to examine which sort of gambler has accounted for the bulk of the decline here. During the months of July, August and September, according to Mr. Glasgow, the table drop tumbled by some $55 million. Of that, $53 million was in chips paid for by credit. Generally speaking, lower-level gamblers acquire their chips for cash, while high rollers employ credit.
"The person who's a high roller, who gambles discretionary income, has cut back," said Mr. Galloway. "The person who has his own business, who gambles some of his extra income, he's cutting back. That's maybe 20 to 25 percent of the market. On the other hand, the bread-and-butter slot customers, the retired people on fixed income who come every other week for entertainment, are still coming down."
Casino operators worry that they are chasing a dwindling number of high rollers. But it is also vital that they attract enough "grind" play to cushion any losses to big players.
Among casino owners, the man in the deepest trouble is undoubtedly Donald Trump. He and his Trump Organization have been scrambling for most of the year to restructure the heavy debt on his three casinos. The opening of his glitzy Taj Mahal, by far the biggest casino in Atlantic City, has drained business from virtually every other casino in the city, while failing to attract enough business to cover its own debt payments.
Both the Taj Mahal and the Trump Castle had losses in the quarter ended Oct. 31, normally the strongest period of the year, while the Trump Plaza's income detriorated sharply.
 
Shallow Pockets
 Unable to come up with the cash to meet a $47.3 million interest payment due on Nov. 15 on the high-yield "junk bonds" sold to finance the Taj Mahal, Mr. Trump was forced two weeks ago to agree to a short trip to bankruptcy court and to give bondholders 50 percent of the equity in the gambling parlor, though he retains control.
His woes aren't over. On Dec. 15, a payment is due on Trump Castle junk bonds, and it is highly questionable whether he has the money to pay.
Being short millions of dollars in interest payments is not an uncommon malady going around Atlantic City and Las Vegas. The Chicago-based Bally Manufacturing Corporation, which owns three casinos in Nevada and one in Atlantic City, knows the symptoms all too well. Steeped in debt, it reported a third-quarter loss of $84.7 million and missed an $18.4 million payment to its bondholders.
In early October, Robert Mullane, Bally's chief executive, even told the board he would quit if that was what they wanted. They kept him -- for two weeks. By mid-October, he was gone.
Casino operators are confronted with a deft juggling act. They are fearful of deep reductions in marketing expenses for they don't want to lose market share. But they must trim expenses wherever they can.
Many of the casinos are cutting back on chartered bus excursions, trips in which casinos dole out chips and meal vouchers in advance to get people to visit their gaming floors. People who come to town by bus do not bet as much as those who arrive in their own cars. Any number of bus riders, in fact, do nothing more than waltz into the casino that provided them with chips, cash them in, and stroll off to the boardwalk.
All in all, the casinos would dearly love to move their client base more heavily toward people in cars.
According to an analysis done by Mr. Glasgow, the consultant, the number of people bused to Atlantic City in October dropped by nearly 107,000, or 10 percent, from the level of October 1989, before the Taj Mahal had opened. The drop followed a 7 percent decline in September.
At the same time, analysts say, many casinos have been reducing middle management. John Giovenco, president of the Hilton Nevada Corporation, the Hilton Hotels subsidiary that runs four Nevada gaming properties, said that its back-of-the-house personnel has been cut about 6 to 7 percent. Mr. Galloway of TropWorld has required all casino employees to take a week's vacation without pay between Thanksgiving and Christmas. Mr. Galloway himself is down for Dec. 13. His wife and he are talking about going skiing.
 
Save It or Make It?
 Cost cutting will save money. However, casinos still need to build revenues to make money. As Mr. Glasgow put it in a recent newsletter: "The theme of the day for Atlantic City operators is cost containment. However, you only save money by cutting costs -- you must have revenues to make money. It is truly the day of the hands-on operator."
While winnings at the Nevada casinos rose more than 13 percent during the first eight months of the year, there is widespread concern about what will happen if the bad economy heads west. Higher fuel prices are a particular worry, since more than 40 percent of visitors go by plane.
Hotel rooms and casino space have grown enormously in Nevada, and plenty of debt exists. "There are a lot of operations in Las Vegas that are substantially leveraged, which puts a lot of pressure on them to be competitive," said Henry Gluck, chairman of Caesars World Inc., which owns Caesars Palace, long one of the most successful casinos in Las Vegas. "And there's been a lot of capacity added in the last year and a half."
In Las Vegas, the November 1989 opening of the Mirage, which cost about $615 million to build, followed by the Excaliber, the world's largest casino hotel, in June, have injected the city with a tremendous amount of new capacity. Together, the two facilities added 7,000 hotel rooms to the 69,000 already there.
The 3,100-room Mirage, which is next door to Caesars Palace, likes to characterize itself as a resort rather than a hotel, and has tried to lure the young, well-off family crowd who might enjoy such things as bottlenose dolphins and the volcano outside that spews steam and fire into the air. It is a marvel to visit. Throngs have.
As the Mirage celebrates its first anniversary, Steve Wynn, chairman of the parent Golden Nugget Corporation, said that, with revenues of $600 million to $650 million, it has well exceeded his expectations.
But the Mirage has forced other casinos to spend money to keep up. Caesars Palace has refurbished its rooms, though it did not build any new ones as a number of analysts felt it should. "It's more important," Mr. Gluck said, "that people come and play the games than actually stay at the hotel." Caesars, like other casinos, has had to hand out more complimentary rooms and meals, he said. It has also told its three "people movers" to be more aggressive in bringing people in. "They almost act like vacuum cleaners," he said.
Many of the Vegas hotels have chopped their room rates to try to stimulate business. At some hotels, rates have fallen to as low as $35 to $60 a night, from $45 to $100 a year ago, and guests can also often pick up free meal and show tickets. Regular patrons who gamble heavily are usually accorded free rooms.
A big question mark hanging over Las Vegas is the prospect of ground being broken next year on the MGM Grand Hotel & Theme Park. If it opens, as planned, in 1992, it will bring another 5,000 rooms to the city.
In Reno, another large gambling city in Nevada, business has been worse than in Las Vegas. Casino revenues have flattened out, and were down in October. Just weeks ago, the owners of two Reno casinos -- Harold's Club and the Nevada Club -- said their properties were for sale because they couldn't afford the renovations needed to stay competitive.
Still, because Nevada attracts a wide base of customers, gaming analysts expect it to ride out a bad economy.
 
Storms in the East
 Atlantic City faces a murkier future. It has yet to develop as the full-fledged family resort and convention center that Las Vegas has. It is also a tawdry city, riddled with social ills. Most people come to Atlantic City just for the day or the weekend, whereas visitors linger much longer in Las Vegas.
Casino owners hope that what appears to be a warming regulatory attitude will enable it to get some of the treats -- longer gambling hours and permission to offer new games -- it feels it needs to spark future growth. There is the promise that the city will get parimutual horse betting, which exists along with sports betting in Las Vegas, and some additional casino games.
Meanwhile, casino operators cross their fingers.
"While the gaming industry is not recession-proof, it is more recession-proof than most businesses," said Mr. Gluck. "A lot would have to happen for people to stop going to conventions. And when people are under a lot of pressure, they still want to go on vacations and sit down at the tables and take a shot."
 
A LONG SHOT CALLED LAUGHLIN
 Being watched with considerable curiosity among casino operators is a town 90 miles south of Las Vegas that has emerged in the last few years as a hotbed of gambling. This is Laughlin, a dusty town where the rooms are cheap, the food is simple and the gambling is free of assertive electronic gadgetry.
For the most part, this has been a gambling den for the blue-collar crowd. But the town is being transformed at a frenzied pace. Huge new projects have sprung up, intended to draw younger and more affluent customers. The population has gone from 95 in 1984 to more than 5,000.
"It's small and low key and has the ambience of an Old West city," said Sheila O'Connell, a gaming analyst at Duff & Phelps. "Until recently, it was kind of a secret. They're getting great occupancy rates there, but if they keep putting up building after building, it could lose its ambience. The people investing there have to be careful. They don't want to go crazy on growth."
There have been some signs of stretched debt in Laughlin, too. An interest payment was missed a couple of weeks ago on Sam's Town Gold River Hotel & Casino. The owner, a partnership called John Midby & Associates, said it is hopeful that a suitable arrangement will be worked out. The partnership is currently putting up a second casino on a new golf course it built in Laughlin.
Hilton Hotels, which opened a 2,000-room, $190 million resort in Laughlin in August, admitted that it misjudged the depth of the market, and caused occupancy rates to drop throughout Laughlin. John Giovenco, who oversees Hilton's casinos, said that occupancy rates have fallen to 75 percent or so, from 90 percent and up.

 
 
TRIPPING ON THE BONDS
 Want fantastic yields? Don't mind big risks? It's not necessary to catch a bus to Atlantic City or a plane to Vegas. Buy some casino bonds.
The high-yield bonds that have financed many of the gambling parlors have recently been one of the worst-performing groups in the high-yield market. Since the beginning of June, according to Richard Byrne, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, the average prices of casino bonds have fallen more than 32.7 percent.
Yields on some bonds -- such as those of the beleaguered Trump Castle -- have been running as as high as 50 percent, and many are yielding 20 to 30 percent. Yields, of course, don't mean all that much if the issuers don't make the payments, an increasingly common habit among casino owners.
"The average yield for casino bonds is about 35 percent," said Raymond Neidl, an analyst with Dillon, Read. "That tells you something about the interest in them right now."
Though Mr. Byrne acknowledges that many casino bonds seem to be undervalued at their current prices, he thinks that continued softeness in the casino industry will keep those prices from improving for a while.
"I'm not ready to call the bottom of this market yet," he said.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
What Brokers Are Pushing

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
For many investors, picking a mutual fund from the 3,000-plus funds available is like finding a needle in a haystack. So many turn to stockbrokers for guidance. Which funds are they pitching?
Dalbar Financial Services, a Boston-based research firm, asked nearly 500 top-selling stockbrokers for their recommendations among the independent fund groups. These groups account for about 45 percent of the $538 billion invested in stock and bond funds today, according to Avi Nachmany, an analyst with Strategic Insight, mutual fund consultants in New York. They exclude funds sold directly to investors, like Fidelity's, and fund groups, like Merrill Lynch and Shearson, sold through their own brokers. 
 What are the favorites? The top broker pick is the $800 million Oppenheimer Global Fund. Its biggest holdings are in health care, said Ken Oberman, the fund's manager, because "as a country's per capita income rises, a bigger percentage of its gross national product goes to health care." Three favorite drug companies: Astra, in Sweden; Novo-Nordisk, in Denmark, and Schering in Germany. He also likes energy companies, particularly Saga Petroleum, in Norway, and the Moeller Companies, in Denmark.
How well has the fund done? A performance measure devised by Morningstar Inc., Chicago-based mutual funds consultants, ranks funds compared to all others of their type. A 1.0 rank is average and a 1.20 rank means a fund performs 20 percent better than its peers. All the broker favorites have solid ratings, reflecting performance in the past 3, 5 or 10 years (depending on the fund's age). Oppenheimer Global, for example, had a 1.21 rating. Besides performance, however, brokers also look at other factors, such as service provided by the fund group.
 Two funds tied for the No. 2 spot among brokers. One was the $4.9 billion Washington Mutual Investors Fund (ranking: 1.33), sponsored by Capital Research and Management, in Los Angeles, a growth-and-income fund that invests in conservative, dividend-paying stocks. About 15 percent of its holdings are in telecommunications. Two favorites: Southwestern Bell and Pacific Telesis. The fund also invests heavily in banking stocks. Many of its holdings "are undervalued, and well-diversified banks that follow prudent investing standards and will have an above-average return over the next five years," said Stephen E. Bepler, the fund's co-manager. His picks: Banker's Trust and Wells Fargo.
The other No. 2 fund was the $1.2 billion Oppenheimer Equity-Income Fund (1.16). It has moved nearly one-third of its assets into cash. Among its stock holdings (53 percent), manager Susan Wilder likes the electric utilities. She says the group is "boring," but adds, "in the environment I see for the next six to nine months, boring may be beautiful." She likes Texas Utilities and the FPL Group.
Another favorite was the $5.3 billion Investment Company of America (1.20), a Capital Research growth-and-income fund that invests in "large, strong, well-diversified companies," said Peter Langer, the group's senior vice president. Its biggest holdings: Phillip Morris, Merck and I.B.M.
The $2.1 billion American Capital Pace Fund (1.31), sponsored by American Capital Asset Management, in Houston, is betting the biggest chunk of its portfolio on the energy sector. S. Peter Hidalgo 2d, the fund manager, likes Texaco and Schlumberger, a French company, and has nearly doubled his financial services holdings since the beginning of the year, to 6 percent. Two favorites: NCNB, the Charlotte-based banking company, and BancOne, in Columbus.
The $1.45 billion GT Europe Growth Fund (1.45) invests in blue-chip stocks, with its biggest holdings in Britain (23 percent), Germany (20 percent) and France (14 percent). John Legat, the London-based fund manager, says British stocks "have underperformed for some time now and those stocks look relatively undervalued." He expects "a good runup in a select group of stocks in the next six to nine months." Two of his picks: British Gas and Northwest Water.
That said, a few provisos: All the recommended funds have a sales charge because that's how brokers earn their living. And some are quite steep. When there are so many funds without fees around -- the 100% No-Load Mutual Fund Council, a New York City-based trade group, counts 130 funds among its members that have no sales charges and represent $25 billion in assets -- why should anyone pay fees? People who are short on time or energy to manage their investments find them an easy solution. A good broker will do the legwork and monitor performance. You get some handholding, too.
While the commission that brokers earn clearly is a factor in their recommendations, it is not the overriding one. The brokers who survived the shakeout after the 1987 crash are a sturdy lot. "They take a more sophisticated, risk-conscious and long-term point of view," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar. "They're selling funds with good track records, because they recognize that success is measured by keeping clients satisfied, not by this month's sales."
 
JUGGLING THE SHORT-TERM OPTIONS
 People tend to flee to short-term funds when the market gets tough and they are usually good bets because their prices tend to fluctuate less than long-term investments. But there is potential risk. Yields are high, but the principal-only return -- reflecting changes in the value of fund shares, without yield -- can drop. That risk is always there, but short-term investors seem to pay less attention to it because their investments fluctuate less than long-term ones.
What's more, all short-term funds are not alike. Money-market funds are relatively safe investments. But world income funds are riskiest -- and their yields reflect that -- because of the currency plays involved. If you don't choose carefully, "the price movements may be more than you bargained for," said Stephen A. Schoepke, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services. You must decide how nimble you can be and how much risk you can live with.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Europe Can't Heal Britain's Economy

BYLINE: By STEVEN RATTNER; Steven Rattner is a general partner at Lazard Freres & Company.

 BODY:
With a speed astonishing to most Americans, Britain has selected John Major as its new Prime Minister. But changes in Britain's economic policies or in the parlous state of its economy may be much slower in coming.
At the moment, Britain is in the midst of classic stagflation: double-digit inflation, rising unemployment and declining gross national product. And, while Britain's economic forecasters are holding out hope of an orderly recovery, the expectations for that upturn are more often attributed to the natural economic cycle than to any particular policy prescription.
Mr. Major appears likely to reject one popular notion -- that greater economic integration with Europe will somehow smoothly restore Britain's economy to good health. In principle, economic integration is a good thing: classic theory suggests that freer trade should benefit all participants. But economic integration in and of itself is no more likely to cut inflation and increase output in Britain than Massachusetts' could escape its difficulties by unifying with California.
The British fascination with European integration manifests itself in the notion of linking the pound with other European currencies and eventually creating a single currency to supplement or even replace the traditional units of exchange. But such a return to fixed exchange rate policies -- and it was Mr. Major who pushed Mrs. Thatcher into entering the current European exchange rate mechanism -- carries at least as much baggage as benefit.
Because Britain's economy is not competitive with countries like Germany, maintaining the pound's assigned position in the constellation will take high domestic interest rates or direct intervention in foreign exchange markets or both. The first, which amounts to giving the Bundesbank a major voice in British economic policy, almost insures a continued slow domestic economy. That could well prove as politically hazardous for Mr. Major, who must face a general election by June 1992, as it did for Mrs. Thatcher. The latter tactic has been proved in many other countries to be extremely costly and of little efficacy for anything other than correcting short-term imbalances in foreign exchange markets.
When it comes to matters like the poll tax, change will come quickly from Mr. Major -- and the betting is that the tax will be scrapped. Imagine an American leader deciding to abolish the property tax -- which at least bears some relationship to individual wealth -- and to substitute a per capita charge that would not vary regardless of whether one's income was $10,000 or $10 million. It took extraordinary arrogance and insensitivity to believe that such a policy would be politically acceptable. Mr. Major will inevitably move toward raising revenue based on ability to pay.
Peculiarly, Britain's real difficulty is the same root problem Mrs. Thatcher found, albeit to a far lesser degree: an extraordinarily rigid and uncompetitive economy unable to produce goods and services as efficiently as trading partners. Mrs. Thatcher's biggest misjudgment was her belief that five years of monetary discipline would be enough to bring a period of strong economic growth after those policies were relaxed in 1986.
But after relaxation, inflation immediately shot up, to its current peak of more than 10 percent. In response, the Thatcher Government began to increase interest rates in late 1988, ultimately more than doubling the base rate to 15 percent and bringing economic growth to a halt. Now the country is mired in recession. The Confederation of British Industry recently forecast that the economy would contract by 1 percent in 1991. Unemployment is now expected to rise into 1992.
When the British economy was stimulated, the result was not higher domestic output but higher imports and higher inflation. For while productivity jumped in the 1987-88 boomlet, the most recent results on output per head in manufacturing showed only a 0.2 percent increase compared with a year earlier. Meanwhile, average earnings grew by 10.25 percent.
How John Major will address these most important problems remains to be seen. He emphasizes his opposition to inflation and his commitment to a classless society. He surrounds himself with bright young economists like Mervyn King and Gavyn Davies. He emphasizes that he is his own man, not a Thatcher clone or stooge. But success will depend on finding the path to freeing up Britain's economy, not only through strict macroeconomic policies and free markets, but through other avenues like education and training.
It's fine for Britain to welcome Mr. Major as part of a needed change. But it is an economic illusion for Britain to believe that its problems resided with Mrs. Thatcher or the rest of Europe or anywhere but with Britain itself. To proceed on any other foundation risks merely returning Britain to the unappetizing economic state in which Mrs. Thatcher inherited it.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Trading an Ad for a Bucket of Bolts

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
There were lots of things the McDonnell-Douglas Helicopter Company could do with the $16 million worth of nuts, bolts, washers and screws cluttering up its warehouses. It could keep them, at a huge carrying cost. It could sell them to liquidators, for maybe 3 cents on the dollar. Or it could trade them for goods and services.
"We went over every possibility for getting the most out of these excess materials, and trade was by far the best," said Gary Pacific, McDonnell's manager of countertrade. He struck a deal with a so-called reciprocal trade company, which gave him credits to use on hotel rooms, airline tickets, car rentals -- even telecommunications consulting services -- in exchange for the hardware. 
 With recession looming large, more companies are seeking new ways to turn excess capacity or materials into assets. The result is that barter, long common in international trade, is getting popular domestically, too.
Paul E. Suplizio, executive director of the International Reciprocal Trade Association, in Alexandria, Va., guesses that the various forms of barter specialists handled trades worth more than $5 billion this year, and that the number is about to soar. "I'm getting a lot more calls from people who hope that barter will help them move excess inventories during the coming recession," he said.
Some companies are doing the trades themselves. Some are going through barter exchanges that, for a flat annual fee plus a 10 percent per-trade commission, serve as middlemen for companies that want to trade. Others, like McDonnell-Douglas, deal with reciprocal trade companies that will themselves take possession of excess products, pay for them in trade credits, then try to sell them elsewhere for cash.
 There are plenty of reasons to barter even aside from the current economic malaise.
Broadcasters, cruise lines and other companies with high fixed costs but low costs of delivering excess products use barter as a crucial source of financing, particularly when they are starting up. For example, when ESPN Inc. was still a fledgling cable sports channel, Icon International Inc., a New York "barter finance" company, provided it with some expensive broadcasting equipment in exchange for a stream of 30-second commercial time slots.
"We loved the concept of acquiring needed equipment without any out-of-pocket costs," said Robert M. Jeremiah, ESPN's vice president of advertising sales. For its part, Icon was able to resell the blocks of commercial time at such a nice profit that it got a four-fold payback on its investment in equipment, said Lance B. Lundberg, Icon's president.
Manufacturers of tangible goods use barter to keep production on an even keel, so that neither machines nor workers sit idle in sluggish times. "When we've got a mill that can make 11 million cases, but our marketing people think we can only sell 10 million, it's nice to know we can barter any excess," said Robert J. Monusky, manager of advertising services at the James River Corporation, which routinely trades surplus Dixie cups or paper towels for advertising space.

FOR others, barter is a competitive tool. Susan Groenwald, president of the Chicago Barter Corporation, a barter exchange, tells of a pest-control company that landed a huge hotel-chain account by agreeing to take part of its payment in room credits. "To my mind, the most important thing about barter is that it brings new customers," she said.
She gets no argument from Jerry Markbreit, trade and barter manager for the 3M Corporation's advertising services group, which sells advertising space on some 30,000 outdoor billboards. He recently traded space on one of them to a cash-strapped airline in exchange for air-freight credits, which he then "sold" to 3M's traffic division for use in shipping 3M products.
"The traffic department saved about 50 percent on its cost for freight, we got to sell billboards we would otherwise have been stuck with, and most important, we were able to service a customer," Mr. Markbreit said.
When barter is timed right, it can help a supplier, too. Alfred Eisenberg, president of Creative Industries, a Chicago manufacturer of insulated packaging material, trades excess packaging for such perennial needs as advertising space. But his favorite deals are those that let both partners capitalize on each other's slow times. Recently he traded packaging for a new driveway, put in by a contractor during his slow season. "If you plan your needs to coincide with other people's down times, you get really good deals through trade," he said.
 
 
WHY IT DOESN'T ALWAYS WORK
 Barter's contraints are as considerable as its benefits. Among them:
* Desired goods may not be available for trade. That's why the Xerox Corporation, for one, has all but stopped bartering. "We could not find things that we wanted to trade for," said a Xerox spokesman.
* It can cut into cash sales. ESPN Inc. maintains a constant vigil to ensure that ESPN air time is not being bartered to any company that is buying time for cash, or that an ESPN salesman is trying to cultivate.
* It can alienate distributors. The 3M Corporation readily barters space on its billboards, but will not trade any of its tangible products. "We don't want our products showing up somewhere at a discounted price because some liquidator got hold of them," said Jerry Markbreit, 3M's barter specialist.
* It can cause tax problems. Tax laws require companies to pay taxes on the value of credits from a barter exchange at the time the credits are issued, even though the company may not book them as income until they are used. And, the Internal Revenue Service still insists on being paid cash.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gary Pacific, at McDonnell Douglas, swapped spare hardware for a basket of credits. (Penny Ann Dolin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: California Showing Hopeful Signs of Political Regeneration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I think recent events in California might be interpreted differently from "California Tried Democracy, and Look What's Happened Now" (The Week in Review, Nov. 18).
You state that in California "the end of politics has begun" and point out, for example, that Californians rejected 22 of 28 initiatives while passing an initiative that limits legislators' terms and expenses.
You also note that a movement to limit the power of initiatives is growing in California, a movement that one of those 22 failed initiatives attempted to counter -- the one that would have required voters to approve any change in the state's initiative and referendum process.
Upon these and a few other events suggesting governmental gridlock seems to rest your pessimism about California politics.
Yet we might find signs of hope for the regeneration of the political process in California -- and perhaps (just perhaps) a harbinger of change in the country itself.
In the long run, the results -- especially the limited terms of office -- might suggest an invigorating, maybe even vital spirit of regeneration in California politics. Without doubt, some senior lawmakers will have to start looking for a new job. But the space they create as they seek work elsewhere could offer California an opportunity to create a resurgence in representative democracy as new candidates vie for political office without the promise of long-term careers in the Legislature. That Californians were unwilling to pass bond and tax measures in this election might suggest a concern by citizens about fiscal responsibility, about growing state indebtedness and about a possible future economic slowdown.
Perhaps the earlier passage of Proposition 13, which limited property tax increases, and Proposition 103, which was intended to roll back insurance premiums, indicates similar worries about where money goes to work. Californians have passed initiatives that control the growth of government spending or the direction in which tax revenues should flow.
Most important, the burden of success for lawmaking and policy shaping in California may now lie more squarely on the shoulders of each voter -- where it should in a working democracy. What may be needed, rather than pessimism about the demise of politics, is a call for a more involved, educated and informed electorate to detect the shenanigans of initiative salesmen and to think more frequently about the qualities of the men and women they give the power to shape and manage government.
 
NORMAN J. UNRAU
Moraga, Calif., Nov. 20, 1990

HEADLINE: Buying Groups Can Lower Fuel Costs

 BODY:
The informative article "Does a Switch From Oil to Gas Heat Make Sense?" [Oct. 28] fails to describe how Long Islanders who may not have the capital to switch from oil to gas can immediately start saving. Joining a fuel-buying group is the short-term answer to the escalating home-heating-oil prices.
Long Islanders are currently forced to pay wartime prices for home-heating oil. Nassau and Suffolk residents can start saving money immediately by joining a not-for-profit fuel-buying group whose price is tied to their regional wholesale price. The savings from increased economics of scale and decreased marketing costs are passed directly to the consumer.
The New York Public Interest Research Group Inc. Fuel Buyers Groups pools the purchasing power of its more than 12,000 members to negotiate discounts on No. 2 home-heating oil with reputable oil dealers on Long Island and nearby.
Nypirg's analysis shows that spot crude prices have increased about 34 cents a gallon, while wholesale home-heating oil has increased 35 cents a gallon and retail prices 45 cents a gallon between Aug. 19 and Oct. 30. Therefore, today due to the instability in the Middle East, Long Islanders are paying an additional 45 percent on their home-heating-oil bills.
Wholesale has dropped about 10 cents a gallon since its peak on Oct. 12, while retail home-heating oil has not dropped a penny in the same period.
At current price levels, the average consumer can expect to pay an additional $200 to $500 on their home-heating-oil bills this winter.
Nypirg asks oil companies to pass along decreases immediately. However, consumers are now experiencing the "sticky pricing phenomenon."
 
CATHERINE HUGHES
Director
Nypirg Fuel Buyers Group

HEADLINE: The Role of Demand in the Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Hidden Pep in the American Economy" (Oct. 7) argues that the ability of various industries to expand supply determines economic growth. The article gives almost no attention to the role of demand.
In some instances inability to increase supply does limit growth, but I believe lack of demand is the main reason. Ask anyone of our automobile companies or anyone in the steel industry, for example.
Consumption expenditures make up 65 per cent of our gross national product. They provides the gas that fuels our economy. A major reason we have had eight years without a recession is the Federal deficit and the fact that consumers have maintained their buying by borrowing large amounts of money.
Because of the size of our national debt, we must reduce the Federal deficit. But because of the recessionary character of our economy, this must be done without reducing consumer spending.
The important role consumers play is graphically illustrated by what happened before the Great Depression. In the late 1920's, productivity and production increased rapidly. Organized labor was weak, so wage increases were too slow to enable workers to buy the increased output. These conditions led to depression.
The New Deal helped get us out of the depression, but Congress was unwilling to vote enough money to do the job. By 1933, almost 13 million people were unemployed, roughly 25 per cent of the labor force. In 1940, 8 million people still were out of work. We then began to prepare for World War II. Restrictions on spending vanished. Unemployment was rapidly reduced, reaching the almost unbelievable level of 640,000 by 1944.
If Congress passes legislation that seriously reduces consumer spending, and it seems they are determined to do this, we are likely to have a serious depression. Let us hope it doesn't take a war to get us out of it.
 
JOHN C. DAVIS
Santa Fe, N.M., Oct. 20

HEADLINE: Cuomo Supports New Game To Aid City's Police Hiring

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would push for quick passage of New York City's anti-crime plan, but insisted that any new city lottery game created to generate money for the plan not siphon revenues from existing state lotteries.
The compromise plan, unveiled by Mayor David N. Dinkins and Speaker Peter F. Vallone of the New York City Council earlier this week, would result in the hiring of nearly 3,500 new police officers over the next six years. It would rely for financing on a property-tax increase of up to $25 for every homeowner in the city, extension of the city income-tax surcharge and creation of a new city lottery game. 
 While the Mayor has urged passage of the plan during the Legislature's special session here this month, top lawmakers have said the package will be difficult to put together and may have to wait until the Legislature begins a new session in January.
Mr. Cuomo, whom some Dinkins administration officials have criticized for not helping to promote an earlier, more expensive anti-crime plan offered by the Mayor, cast himself today as Mr. Dinkins's chief supporter for speedy passage of a plan.
 
 Do It Quickly, Cuomo Says
 "The timing is critical," the Governor said in a telephone interview. "If you push it off to January, it may get lost in a maze of other problems." The city is scheduled to revise its revenue forecasts then, and some officials fear that worsening economic news could deflate support for speedy approval of the plan.
Still, some top officials here appeared to see less urgency than the Governor did in getting the plan passed right away. "If it gets done, it gets done," said Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat. "If not, we'll do it when we come back in January."
It remains unclear whether the package can be worked out this month. Several upstate lawmakers have expressed concerns that the city lottery could take money away from existing lotteries, whose profits go into a fund for public schools across the state, while lawmakers from throughout New York have insisted on legal guarantees that most of the money be used for hiring police officers.
Given the wide support from city officials for higher property taxes and the extension of the income-tax surcharge, whose rate varies by income level, few state lawmakers here have described the taxes themselves as objectionable.
The Governor's comments on the lottery, which came at a morning news conference in the Capitol, appeared intended to allay fears that the city would be allowed to shift money from the general state education fund to its crime program.
 
 Scratch-Off Lottery Game
 City officials publicly thanked the Governor for his pledge to help secure passage of the anti-crime plan, but appeared noncommittal on guarantees that the state's own lottery revenues would be protected.
"We are confident that we can work out a plan that addresses the city's needs as well as the state's concerns about its own fiscal picture," Mr. Vallone said in a prepared statement. A spokeswoman for Mayor Dinkins, Jennifer Kimball, said it would be "very difficult to analyze" the Governor's lottery plan until Monday.
Under the Governor's proposal, outlined today by the state lottery director, Peter D. Lynch, the city could create a new scratch-off lottery game for the crime plan to market along with an existing scratch game that lottery officials feel is widely underused.
 
 Buffalo Bets Differently
 Buffalo residents, Mr. Lynch noted, spend about twice as much per person on the current scratch game as New York City residents do; they in turn widely outspend Buffalo residents on the Lotto jackpot contests.
Any revenues from the new scratch game could go to the city's crime fund as long as total net revenues from the existing scratch-off game sold in the city remained at its present level of about $25 million annually, Mr. Lynch said. If not, revenues from the new game would have to go to the state. Mr. Lynch said he "could not conceive" of the new scratch game's cutting into revenues for the separate Lotto jackpots.

HEADLINE: Suit Dismissed on Pine Barrens Construction

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 6

 BODY:
In a victory for builders in Suffolk County, a State Supreme Court judge has dismissed an environmental group's lawsuit that sought to block all development within the environmentally sensitive Pine Barrens region of Long Island.
Judge Paul J. Baisley ruled that more than 230 construction projects in the Pine Barrens, 100,000 acres of fragile land crucial in replenishing the Island's underground water supply, would be allowed to go forward without any study of their cumulative environmental impact. 
 The Long Island Pine Barrens Society had tried to block the projects by arguing that state environmental laws required all of the proposed developments be studied together before any could proceed. But in denying the group's request on Wednesday, Judge Baisley said that no specific provision required such study.
Richard L. Amper Jr., executive director of the society, said the ruling had been anticipated and would be appealed. "These matters are never resolved in the lower court, and we'll take it to the Appellate Division," he said. "I would be very surprised if we saw asingle project built as a result of this ruling."
But Walter M. Conlon, a partner in Mars, Sloane & Conlon, a firm representing some of the builders, said the decision was a victory for property owners and meant that development throughout the Pine Barrens could proceed.
"This decision has clarified a very important aspect of the environmental process," he said. "It has cleared the air to enable people to make freer decisions with their property. It means that there is a definition as to how far a municipality has to go with its environmental impact statement." It is not known how many of the 230 projects on Long Island -- where, as elsewhere, the weak economy has hurt development -- will be renewed because of the judge's decision. Some of the projects were in the initial planning stages when the suit was filed; others were ready for permits to break ground.
Under the State Environmental Quality Review Act, builders are required to prepare environmental impact statements of proposed projects. In an earlier case the Pine Barrens Society cited in its legal argument, the State Court of Appeals had ruled that a cumulative impact study had to be done of more than 10 projects in a 295.5-acre section of the Albany Pine Bush. But a cumulative study involving hundreds of projects in three different towns, which is what the Pine Barrenslawsuit had sought, was unprecedented.
Lewis B. Oliver Jr., the lawyer for the environmental group, said that Judge Baisley had misread the Pine Bush decision by construing that there were three criteria to be met to require a cumulative impact statement. Mr. Oliver said there are two criteria -- that the land be environmentally sensitive and that development threaten to endanger it -- and the Pine Barrens met both.
 
A 'Chill' on Development
 "The Pine Barrens Society should have won the case because the judge made all the findings that the court made in the Pine Bush case and more," Mr. Oliver said.
Mr. Conlon said the decision would help the economy in Suffolk County,where building, already suffering because of the weak economy, has been curtailed by the lawsuit. "What this did in the Pine Barrens was create a chill on the preparation of property for ultimate use," in which developers did not want to spend money on preliminary work and banks did not want to commit money, he said.
The Pine Barrens' lawsuit also sought to stop the projects by claiming that the county and town agencies charged with granting permits should have considered publicly acquiring the land, rather than letting it be developed. Again, Judge Baisley ruled that there was no such provision in state environmental law.

HEADLINE: Trash Department Recycling Effort Criticized

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
Public officials and environmental groups assailed the New York City Sanitation Department on Friday for failing to aggressively pursue recycling.
At a City Council hearing, department officials were criticized for poor management, excessive recycling budget cuts, favoring incineration and not supplying information required by the city's 20-month-old recycling law. 
 "The Sanitation Department has simply reneged on its legal and public obligations to pursue recycling," City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said. "The only thing the Department ofSanitation consistently recycles are its excuses."
Steven M. Polan, Sanitation Commissioner, responded that the law had unrealistic timetables and goals. He acknowledged, as he has before, that the program has major problems concerning collection costs and the ability to process recyclables.
Residents are separating about 6 percent of the city's garbage. Twenty-nine of 59 community boards, or almost 2 million households, are involved.
The recycling law, passed in April 1989, calls for separating 25 percent of the city's trash by April 1994. The law was passed to reduce the amount ofgarbage dumped at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island.
The city's financial problems have forced the department to cut its $79 million annual operating budget by about 15 percent and delay until July 1 expanding recycling into 11 community districts in Brooklyn and the Bronx.
Mr. Polan said on Friday that the delay could help the department refocus attention on neighborhoods that have started recycling but are lagging in participation. A delay of more than six months would be "counterproductive," he said.
Sheldon S. Leffler, a City Councilman from Queens and one of the recyclinglaw's authors, said that nearly two years after the program began, an effective management team was still not in place. He said 25 of 70 people in the recycling division had left.
Mr. Polan, who became Commissioner in June, responded that "the fundamental problem is not management; it's economics."
"We have to bring down the cost of this program to make it successful," he said.
The department had expected recycling collection to cost $65 a ton when operating fully in a few years, Mr. Polan said, but if collection did not become more efficient, the cost could be $300 a ton.
One way to reduce costs would be to modify work practices of unionized workers, he said. Council members on Friday criticized those workers for notcooperating with attempts to increase productivity.
Mr. Polan said that because recycling had reduced the amount of garbage left on the street, collection trucks were finishing early. He has proposed extending the collection routes to increase productivity, which will be addressed in ongoing contract talks.
"This is a heck of a state of affairs," said Enoch H. Williams, chairman of the Council's Environmental Protection Committee. "We're paying people and we're not doing anything."
A spokesman for the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, Jim Grossman, said, "They're not back there loafing around."

HEADLINE: STATES TRY TO CUT COST OF INSURANCE FOR MEDICAL CARE

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Eight states, from Florida to Washington, have recently changed their laws in an attempt to encourage private insurers to sell low-cost policies to working Americans who have no health coverage.
The new policies cost less because they provide less coverage and are exempt from laws that all states have requiring insurers to pay for various kinds of care. 
 At least 33 million Americans do not have health insurance, two-thirds of whom are workers or dependents. Insurers, worried about proposals for an insurance system run by the Government, say many owners of small businesses and people who are self-employed might pay for cheaper, less extensive plans.
 
Requirements Raise Costs
 Requirements for health-care coverage vary by state and now often include the services of chiropractors, therapy for alcohol and drug abuse or mental health problems and, in three states, acupuncture treatment. While such treatments can be enormously important to those who need them, they increase the cost of health plans.
The states hope that small employers and working people will buy the less-expensive plans, which cost as little as $60 a month for an individual, or about 25 percent to 40 percent less than policies with broader coverage.
Fewer uninsured patients would mean fewer unpaid bills, for which hospitals and doctors usually compensate by raising prices for other patients. Indeed, the main backer of the stripped-down health plans is the insurance industry, which is trying to placate large employers, who resent having to pay for uninsured patients.
The insurers are worried by the increasing support of employers and labor unions for more Federal regulation of health insurance, as well as for a system run by the Government, which could threaten the private insurance business.
 
Opponents Speak Out
 But the changes in state insurance laws are opposed by consumer advocates who favor national health insurance and those health-care professions whose services would not be paid for under the new insurance.
"Depending on how limited the package is, you can end up with health care being rationed for whole portions of the working population and their families," said Maryann O'Sullivan, executive director of Health Access, a California coalition that advocates a Government-financed health system.
Dr. Terry Rondberg, president of the World Chiropractic Alliance, a professional group, said chiropractors were considering bringing lawsuits challenging the new laws. "The costs that are driving up medical bills come from high technology, neo-natal care and drug rehabilitation programs, not chiropractic care," he said.
The eight states where new laws waiving some of the requirements have recently been enacted are Florida, Illinois, Kansas, Kentucky, Missouri, Rhode Island, Virginia and Washington State. The idea is expected to catch on quickly elsewhere.
"Virtually every state is going to look at this approach in 1991," said Greg Scandlen, director of state research with the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, whose member groups provide coverage to 70 million people.
 
Still Too Costly for Some
 But it remains unclear how many uninsured people will end up obtaining coverage under the new laws. Many small employers and low-income individuals might find even these basic policies unaffordable, particularly because rising overall health costs might quickly wipe out any savings from the stripped-down insurance. The cost also makes it unlikely that the unemployed or those with part-time jobs would buy the policies, although they would be eligible to do so.
The number and kinds of required treatments vary widely by state. In states like Maryland, which requires coverage for 33 types of treatment, insurers say the requirements add 15 to 20 percent to the cost of premiums. In Florida, with 19 requirements, the cost and the potential saving is 5 percent to 7 percent, said Trevor Smith, the assistant state treasurer and assistant insurance commissioner.
Among the most costly requirements are those for treatment of drug abuse, which insurers are required to provide in 13 states, and mental health treatment usually including out-patient care, required in 11 states.
The waiver laws have been in effect only a few weeks in Virginia and Washington, and the six other states are still working on the change, so it is too early to tell what effect they might have.
The changes in Washington are typical of those in the other states. Washington now allows insurers to offer a lower-cost, lower-benefit plan to individuals and groups of fewer than 25 employees who do not have coverage. The new law is vague as to what treatments must be included in the basic coverage, but it says that the plan need not cover treatments like mental health care that the state requires for all larger employers who are not self-insured.
 
One Small Business's Plan
 Jim Weston, who owns Marty's Food Center in Puyallup, Wash., said he pays $226 a month to cover three employees under the new Blue Cross basic-coverage plan. Blue Cross will pay their covered medical expenses, after a $200 annual deductible for the two employees who are unmarried and a $600 deductible for the employee who has a family.
"If this hadn't come along, I doubt I would have been able to afford it," Mr. Weston said. "I pay the whole thing. The employees don't have a lot of bucks or they would have their own health insurance."
Nearly half the nation's uninsured employees work in businesses with fewer than 25 employees. Small businesses in Virginia had been paying $95 to $135 for each employee, on average.
Blue Cross groups say they are absorbing the costs of overhead, like paperwork, and hope to break even on medical costs in the new plans.
 
Differences in Virginia
 In Virginia, the law on basic coverage applies to groups of fewer than 50 who have been without coverage for at least 12 months. It requires that the plan cover 30 days of hospitalization a year, prenatal and obstetrical care and checkup visits to a doctor for children and adults. The Blue Cross version costs about $76 a month in Richmond for a person under age 40, with at least half being picked up by the employer.
The Edwards & Harding Petroleum Company, a gas exploration company with seven employees based in Abingdon in southwestern Virginia, was one of the first to sign up for the basic-coverage plan. "We were shopping around for insurance; we never had it," said Karen Edwards, a vice president of the company. "It fit us perfectly."
Ms. Edwards's company decided to have extra coverage for the care of healthy infants and for the maternity expenses of an employee's spouse. The monthly cost, half of which is paid by the employee, ranges from $60.55 for an unmarried employee under age 40 to $245.40 for an employee, 40 or older, with a family.
Insurers have been urging all state legislatures to waive the requirements and approve other changes to make health coverage more affordable. The 50 state insurance commissioners recommended last week that all states change their laws to slow the growth in rates that has forced many small employers out of the market.
"The problems of small groups are the No. 1 issue that the association needs to be working on," said Jim Long, the North Carolina insurance commissioner, who is the president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners.
 
'First-Priority Issue'
 John Sloan, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, an advocacy group in Washington for small businesses, said the cost of health insurance was also "the first-priority issue with our members." Among small employers, 40 percent do not provide health insurance.
Some experts say eliminating mandates is only one of a number of needed changes. "You need a comprehensive program that tries to deal with the problems of access to health insurance and cost together," said Alain Enthoven, a professor of political economy at the Stanford University Graduate School of Business. He wants to limit Federal tax deductions on employee health benefits, while requiring all employers to pay for coverage, either directly for their employees or through new taxes to pay for the care of people who are not insured.
The insurance industry wants to keep the tax breaks but proposes state laws that would make coverage available to all small businesses regardless of the health of employees. "Getting rid of the mandates by itself is not enough to make coverage affordable to small employers," said Mr. Scandlen of Blue Cross.

HEADLINE: Louisiana Journal;
Trying to Resurrect Shades of the Old South

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BURNSIDE, La.

 BODY:
The avenue of oaks leads from the bank of the Mississippi River to the white Doric columns of the Houmas House plantation, a shaded path through the history of battle and blood, dreams and dust at what was once Louisiana's largest sugar plantation.
But missing from this quintessential Southern scene of wealth derived from sugar cane and the sweat of 1,000 slaves is the curtain of Spanish moss that once draped these elegant trees in extravagant abundance. 
 All over Southern Louisiana, from the silent swamps of the Atchafalaya basin to the green marshes west of Lafayette, the plant that is a symbol of Southern pain and mystery has vanished from its former range.
"It used to hang off the oaks in folds," said Helene Crozat, the manager of the 160-year-old plantation house that is now a tourist stop 25 miles south of Baton Rouge. "Our landscape architect told me that leaded gasoline had an effect on it, and since we went to unleaded gas things were improving. It's hard to tell. There still isn't much moss here."
Although Spanish moss is not nearly as economically important as soybeans or sugar cane, and has been largely ignored by the plant research community, its decline in Louisiana has stirred years of popular speculation about the causes, most of it focused on air pollution. Scientists dispute this, citing a loss of habitat -- the oak trees on which the moss thrives -- and a destructive fungus.
Whatever the reasons, the loss of Spanish moss has compelled people to take unusual action to re-create its allure and re-establish the plant in some of its traditional habitats.
It is now common for movie directors shooting films in Louisiana's bayous to pay thousands of dollars to have boatmen collect moss from the deepest swamps where it still thrives and carefully hang it from cypress and oak. To establish the unsettling and obsessive mood of his 1987 film "Angel Heart," the director Alan Parker had to drape trees with harvested moss. "We go moss gathering for almost everything shot in Cajun country," said Tesa Laviolette, the director of the Louisiana Film Commission, which promotes movie making in the state.
Around the state, it has become routine to see homeowners gingerly tying or placing moss in their trees, hoping to establish new parental lines. Tree surgeons say they are often directed to save moss pulled from sick limbs and hang it on healthy ones. Along St. Charles Avenue in New Orleans, Louisiana's grandest boulevard where trees were once thick with Spanish moss, Allen and Marnie Borne completed the renovation of their historic home by gathering moss in Mississippi and Louisiana and paying two men to hang it in their 40-foot oak. Out back, the Bornes established an above-ground nursery by hanging moss in five crepe myrtle trees.
"We just liked the history of it, the quaintness of it," said Mrs. Borne. "It's the only tree on St. Charles Avenue that has moss. We put sprigs of it on our neighbor's tree, hoping it will catch on there too." The Bornes say it has.
It was not terribly long ago that Spanish moss was valued for more than its visual charms. Between 1900 and 1940, Spanish moss was ginned in Louisiana and other Deep South states into long dark fibers that felt like horsehair and had the strength of cotton cord. In 1936, the peak year of production, 10,000 tons of moss worth $2.5 million were ginned in the South and used to stuff upholstery and repair fishing nets.
Just one moss gin is left. In Labadieville, La., it turns out 100,000 pounds of material a year that fish hatcheries use to collect and preserve eggs from spawning females. Several other businesses in Louisiana collect Spanish moss from the swamps to sell to nurseries and flower shops, which use it to preserve moisture in potted plants and as a decorative bedding in floral arrangements.
 Despite the name, Spanish moss is neither moss nor Spanish. According to Howard William Rickett's authoritative study for the New York Botanical Garden, Tillandsia usneoides is a flowering plant and a member of the Bromeliaceae family, which makes it a distant cousin of the pineapple. Legend has it that Spanish moss (once called gray moss or Florida moss) acquired its name because someone thought it hung like "a Spanish beard."
Spanish moss is an epiphyte: it takes all its nutrition from the air. Botanists say Spanish moss prefers to dwell in live oaks because the craggy bark gives seeds a secure hold, and the long, stout limbs, which never lose their leaves, afford adult plants protection from wind and the drying effects of the sun.
Before the Civil War, Spanish moss was believed to harbor evil spirits and deadly diseases, especially malaria. The same kind of mythology has grown up in Louisiana to help explain the plant's declining ability to thrive in its traditional habitats.
Thousands of Louisiana residents point fingers at the toxic clouds of pollution from the state's mammoth chemical and oil plants. The first signs of the decline of Louisiana's Spanish moss in the mid-1970's coincided with the rapid industrialization of the bayous by the petrochemical industry. Residents who lived close to the new chemical plants also noticed that vegetables in their gardens were weakened by exposure to toxic chemicals and became susceptible to killing diseases.
But a more likely cause of the moss's retreat in Louisiana, say biologists, is Fusarium solani, a fungus that struck Florida, Georgia and South Carolina in the early 1970's. Moss in those states has since recovered.
In 1979, Dr. Ken Whitam, a plant pathologist at Louisiana State University, was summoned to the Tezcuco plantation, another antebellum home down the road from here, to take samples of sick and dying Spanish moss. After analyzing the samples in his laboratory, Dr. Whitam concluded that the fungus had finally reached Louisiana.
"Everybody wants to hear that air pollution is the problem," said Dr. Whitam. "I think that's so much hype. We're losing forest land that used to be this plant's prime habitat. We're losing some of our live oaks, probably from old age. We identified fusariam in moss in this state.
"You know," said Dr. Whitam, "it's been 10 years since we did this work, and I get more calls about Spanish moss than I've ever gotten about my work with soybeans."

(Alan Weiner/The New York Times) (pg. 26)
