HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PULSE: Texas -- A special report;
Slow but Steady Revival After Going Bust in Texas

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Three years ago, with Texas mired in its worst post-World War II recession, Kim Dawson was not sure how long her modeling agency, the state's largest, could survive.
"A lot of good studios closed in 1987 and the photography work had just about dried up," she said, recalling the dreariest months of her career. 
 But like many Texans, Ms. Dawson now sees those days as part of the past. Thanks in part to the added business that came in when the J. C. Penney Company moved its headquarters from New York to the Dallas area, Ms. Dawson's agency is having one of its best years ever.
 
A Renewal of Optimism
 And for Christmas she and her husband are buying expensive art works for each other, something they have not done for a couple of years.
"I may be too optimistic," she said, "but I'd rather feel this way."
Ms. Dawson's optimism is emblematic of a tentative confidence that has emerged in the nation's third most populous state, with consumers' increased spending evident at car dealers, restaurants and department stores. Even the construction industry, which thrived in the oil boom of the early 1980's and sank to perilous depths as oil prices collapsed in the middle of the decade, is again hiring.
The state's recovery has been spotty but growing, aided largely by efforts of state officials and business leaders to diversify the economy. The energy industry now accounts for 10 percent of the state's economic activity, or half the level of a decade ago. The newly ascendant electronics and telecommunications industries, as well as a growing service and retail trade, have contributed to the recovery.
And although Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August has slowed the progress in recent months, many economists say the high oil prices and crumbling consumer confidence that threaten the nation's economy with recession are unlikely to drag Texas down, too. In fact, if oil prices remain high, the state would clearly benefit by next summer.
"We see Texas being one of the four or five strongest states over the next year in employment growth," said Clair Asklund, director of regional research at DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc., an economic research company in Lexington, Mass. "Right now, they have a cost advantage as a result of the hard times they went through in the middle 80's."
Bain & Company, the large corporate consulting firm based in Boston, opened an office in Dallas last month, choosing it over sites in New York and Chicago.
"Dallas was not even on our radar screen," said Mark A. Gottfredson, managing director of the new Dallas office. "But as we started to look around, it looked to us like the Texas economy would do extremely well over the next several years."
 
Help From Government
 Analysts cite several factors for Texas's relative strength in the face of a national recession. Beginning in 1987 the largest banks here, after years of staggering losses and reductions in lending, were bolstered by more than $7 billion in rescue money from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the federally managed fund for insuring deposits in banks. New owners, most from out of state, control eight of the state's nine largest banks.
The construction and real-estate industries, at a standstill since 1986, when the office-building boom collapsed, are showing slow improvement. Foreclosures and bankruptcies are down, too. Also, Texas, California and other border states stand to benefit more than other states if negotiations on a free-trade agreement between the United States and Mexico succeed.
"It's true that we are no longer insulated from the national economy, so we will be affected" if there is a national recession, said Michael Levy, publisher of Texas Monthly magazine. "But so much of what happens in a recession is psychological. The threat of a national recession is nothing to a state that has been through a depression."
Some bankers in the state see a mood of optimism. Timothy P. Hartman, chairman and chief executive of NCNB Texas, the state's largest bank, said his loan officers had noticed an increase in inquiries from owners of small businesses in the last three months.
"These are companies with sales in the $2 million to $10 million range, thinking about how they are going to attack the market in 1993 and '94," Mr. Hartman said. "That attitude was missing up until late August. The Texas economy has been at low tide for probably three years."
After lagging behind most other states in job growth the last five years, Texas has edged nearer to the top. The state added 110,000 jobs from September 1989 to September 1990, according to the Texas Comptroller's Office. The unemployment rate, averaging 6.2 percent for the year through November, seems certain to be the lowest since 1985.
The November figure jumped to 7 percent, from 5.7 percent in October, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Analysts said that manufacturing jobs declined in November, and that, unlike most years, retailers added few workers in anticipation of the Christmas season.
 
 The Oil Industry
A Shrinking Role, But Still Vital

Because Texas is far less dependent on the energy industry than a decade ago, the surge in oil prices that followed the invasion of Kuwait has not been an immediate boon, as it was in 1979 after the Islamic revolution in Iran.
This time around, higher oil prices have slowed job growth and rattled Texas consumers, said Harvey Rosenblum, senior vice president and head of economic research at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas. The health of the telecommunications, retailing and electronics industries that expanded or moved to Texas, like Compaq Computer in Houston and J. C. Penney, are more attuned to the nation's slowing economic pace than the weekly count of oil drilling rigs.
Yet if the price of oil remains above $25 a barrel, and the price of natural gas rises as well, Texas and other energy-producing states like Oklahoma and Louisiana would get a boost from the resulting increase in drilling. Oilmen said the increase would be apparent by the middle of next year.
While a sustained period of high oil prices would deepen a national recession, it would bolster the Southwest's economy.
The Federal Reserve in Dallas estimates that with every $1 increase in the price of oil over a year Texas gains 15,000 jobs while New York State loses 11,000 jobs, as the higher energy prices increase operating costs for businesses, especially manufacturers. The nation as a whole loses 78,000 jobs for every $1 increase, according to the Federal Reserve Bank.
Although many independent oil producers voiced skepticism about the current surge in prices, expecting them to fall as low as $20 a gallon once the Persian Gulf crisis passes, the large oil companies appear confident that the long-term trend is toward rising prices. In the last few weeks, several, like Shell Oil Company and Conoco Inc., have announced major increases for their 1991 spending plans, with most of the money designated for drilling additional wells.
More than half of the industry's spending on drilling last year went to projects outside the United States, but much of the drilling equipment is still made in Texas.
A large drilling-services company based in Dallas, the Halliburton Company, announced a 12 percent increase for its 1991 capital budget, to $442 million. Its chief executive, Thomas H. Cruikshank, said he anticipated rising demand for the company's products.
The number of active drilling rigs in the nation was 1,175 last week, compared with 1,062 a year ago, according to Baker-Hughes Inc.
 
 Signs of Revival
A Budget Surplus And Port Records

Several statistical barometers suggest how far the Texas economy has recovered in the last four years.
Apartment occupancy rates in Houston climbed above 90 percent this year for the first time since 1982 and in Dallas for the first time since 1984. The average monthly rent in Houston last spring was $372, as against $401 in 1982, according to M/PF Research Inc., a private research organization based in Dallas. Monthly rents in Dallas were an average of $459 in the three months that ended in September, as against $430 in the last quarter of 1984.
More than 500,000 new jobs have been created since the Texas economy hit bottom late in 1986. The Houston area added 197,000 jobs during the last four years, after losing 221,900 jobs in the previous five years, according to the Greater Houston Partnership, an economic development agency. The agency expects Houston to add 48,000 more jobs in 1991, mostly in the service sector.
The Texas state government completed the 1990 fiscal year, which ended in August, with a surplus of $767 million, a mirror image of the 1987 deficit of $745 million. Higher oil prices helped to increase tax receipts from oil production and increase money the state received from the mineral rights on vast expanses of state-owned land.
Total advertising published in The Houston Chronicle rose in 1989 for the third consecutive year, to 6.4 million inches. The high mark for the 1980's was 7.4 million inches in 1984.
The total tonnage of shipments through the Port of Houston set records of more than 120 million tons in each of the last two years, exceeding a record 117 million tons that had stood since 1979. The Port of Houston Authority has forecast another record for 1990, at 128 million tons. Rising shipments of imported oil, to refiners with storage tanks along the Houston Ship Channel, have been the biggest factor in the gains.
Since 1986, the amount of outstanding loans from banks has fallen 35 percent, prolonging the economic downturn. But that cutback in credit has apparently run its course. Mr. Rosenblum of the Federal Reserve Bank here said Texas bankers are getting over the shocking losses of 1987 and 1988.
"The banking industry has been about in neutral in terms of the credit it is providing the economy," he said. "It's about to head into first gear."
Moves into the Dallas area of the corporate headquarters of J. C. Penney and the Exxon Corporation, which completed its move last August, and the Southwest telephone operations of the GTE Corporation, have bolstered demand for legal and accounting firms as well as photography, advertising and temporary-employment agencies.
 
 Soft Spots
Feeling Ripples Of U.S. Downturn

Despite these gains, the Texas economy has weak spots, particularly in manufacturing and military activities that were hurt by budget cuts ordered by the Pentagon last summer. The General Dynamics Corporation, which makes the F-16 fighter and is Fort Worth's largest employer, has pared its payroll by 2,000, to 28,000, this year.
The largest employer in Dallas, Texas Instruments Inc., trimmed 1,000 jobs related to military output since last summer. Then, with sales slowing in the semiconductor industry, the company said last month that it would indefinitely freeze salaries for its white-collar workers.
The sharp drop in car sales nationwide in November reverberated in North Texas. The General Motors Corporation closed its plant in Arlington for four weeks, starting Dec. 2, after dealers slashed orders for the Cadillac Brougham and Chevrolet Caprice models assembled there.
High oil prices have also hurt petrochemical plants. The industry, which accounted for much of Houston's growth since 1986, has made little money in the last half of the year.
Then, too, the future for Texas real-estate values, and their effect on dozens of recapitalized, struggling savings institutions remains uncertain. The Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency that is handling sales of properties acquired from failed savings institutions, has had a trying time finding buyers for the thousands of properties it has here.
The state government also faces rising costs, in some cases ordered by Federal courts, of building more prisons and improving schools.
Texas is one of six states with no personal income tax. The state sales tax, at 6.25 percent, has been raised four times since 1983. Several business leaders have said the Legislature should adopt a personal income tax soon, but state officials realize it would be political suicide to propose such a measure. State Treasurer Ann Richards, who will become Governor in January, and the Republican she defeated in November, Clayton Williams, both said they would oppose a state income tax.
Governor-elect Richards said last week that she was confident the Texas economy would continue to grow in 1991, and that the state would not need to broaden the existing tax structure.
 
 Change in Thinking
Willing to Spend, But Cautiously

For now, old feelings about the relationship here between rising oil prices and rising prosperity are slow to die. Steady news reports over the last two months of oil prices near or above $30 a barrel have stirred hopes of better times.
Carl Sewell, a Cadillac and Lexus dealer here, said that Cadillac sales and leases soared in September and October and that he sold or leased every Lexus model that was shipped by its Japanese manufacturer, Toyota.
Mr. Sewell, whose cars sell for $30,000 and up, said many of his customers are cautious, choosing to lease rather than buy. Thirty percent of his current business is in leased vehicles, he said, as against 10 percent a year ago.
"Texans who survived to this point are much more careful with debt," he said, "and we are going to be much more careful with cash."
Texans make up about a third of the 2.5 million people who take some income from oil well production in the United States. Many inherited royalty rights acquired by grandparents who owned land in East Texas at the time of the oilfield boom there in the 1930's or in the Permian Basin fields of West Texas, where wildcatters and major drilling companies first appeared in the 1940's.
Most of the royalty checks had averaged less than $200 a month since oil prices fell from $27 a barrel in January 1986 to below $10 in the following June. But the surge in oil prices after the Iraqi invasion has revived a willingness to spend, although little of the extravagance that accompanied the early 80's boom is evident.
Since early September, more women have bought the $400 skirts and $300 designer jackets displayed in Susanne Stibolt's sportswear shop than at any other time since she opened the store two years ago in Highland Park, a wealthy enclave within Dallas.
Highland Park is populated by lawyers, financiers, oil barons and leaders of the arts, and Mrs. Stibolt said she believes that the higher oil prices explain the brisk business at her shop, Harrison Blair & Company. "It's obvious," she said. "Our clientele includes many people who have oil royalties, and the bigger royalty checks are coming in."
At the same time, most Texans doubt that oil prices will remain above $25 a barrel for long. Indeed, the more prevalent hope is that prices will not fall below $20 after the gulf crisis ends.
"No one is making any great plans based on the belief that oil prices will stay way up there," said Valerie Freeman, president and owner of Wordtemps, a local agency that places more than 1,000 temporary workers. "We're glad here in Texas that oil prices are going up. But we realize that this may not last another week."
A Dallas tax preparer and insurance saleswoman, Ann Whitchurch, said that in October her royalties on wells in the Panhandle produced the largest monthly royalties she had seen in years, $579.
"It was nice to have, but I've done nothing to celebrate, believe me," she said. She added that rising taxes had limited her income from the wells, each of which produce fewer than 10 barrels a day.
"I should get at least one more $500 check," she said, "but then it might go back to $200 a month. I can't depend on it."

HEADLINE: Soviet Drug Testing: Full Disclosure Is The Rule

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Pushing its new openness policy into sports, the Soviet Government has been freely disclosing suspensions and other sanctions against the nation's established athletes who have tested positive for use of forbidden drugs to gain competitive advantage.
"In the old days we would have simply said that athlete doping is alien to Soviet culture, but we live in the real world now," said Vasily V. Gromyko, deputy chairman of Goskomsport, the Soviet sports ministry, which was once notorious for its tight-lipped Cold War competitiveness. 
 Gromyko, a barrel-chested, 58-year-old former state wrestler who is the official Soviet authority on the subject of sports drug abuse, disclosed that 49 athletes had been sanctioned during the first 10 months of unannounced spot checking of athletes under a joint program with United States sports officials and physicians.
 
'Real Controls'
 The program features the sports equivalent of on-site inspection, the verification device at the heart of the burgeoning arms-control treaties between Moscow and Washington.
"Real controls like this are the only way to build trust," Gromyko said. "It is the same as in missile reduction: true trust begins when all secrets are revealed."
The agreement was signed last year, and in their first round of enforcement, Soviet officials have been quite candid, trying to use public disclosure as a caution to their international competitors, publicly disclosing the names of all 49 athletes who tested positive among the 2,500 spot-checked since the beginning of the year.
Offenders established by dual specimen analyses are already being suspended from competition and stripped of their medals, officials said. The offenders were accused of using anabolic steroids and psychotropic drugs illicitly.
 
Body Builders Cited
 Leafing through a computer printout of the drug-testing program, Gromyko said the worst offenders were in body building, an increasingly popular amateur sport here that greatly influences youth. Body builders accounted for 16 of the 49 offenders.
"That is a catastrophic situation," he said, noting those 16 cases turned up among a total of only 63 tests in that single category.
Of the rest, 11 track and field competitors tested positive among 600 whose specimens were analyzed; six weight lifters were found positive among 324 tested, and the rest, including two cyclists and two rowers, were scattered among other sports.
Individual competitors have the most pressure to experiment with drugs, Gromyko said. In five years at his present post, Gromyko said, he has not come upon a single case of drug abuse among Soviet team sports.
For the Soviet public, this new candor about the behavior of some individuals in the once-heroic category of sports celebrities is merely another bit of glasnost disclosure spurring more cynicism than hope amid the society's general discontent and preoccupation with economic survival. There has been virtually no reaction to the ministry's disclosures, with the public more wary than curious about the contradictions of individual enterprise, on the sports field or off.
 
Candor and Cynicism
 "My friends use anabolics, but I am categorically against them," said Nikolai Machkov, the coach of a body-building club here. "Parents are desperate for their kids to stay out of trouble and have something to do, so they are paying money now for the new body-building clubs."
As a historian at the new Lenin Museum in Gorki, Machkov can see firsthand the mix of increased candor and greater cynicism in Soviet life reflected in the sports drug disclosures. He finds that the doctored truths about Lenin are being gradually corrected just as the public is finding less reason to visit and study the archives of the fallen official idol.
"The nation must be told the truth," he said, speaking of the illicit sports drugs as much as Lenin. "For reasons of competitiveness, of course, but most importantly for reasons of good health."
Gromyko praised the cooperation of the Americans. He said that while the Soviet procedure includes unabashed disclosure of offenders, American custom is more discreet. But Soviet officials already receive confidential summaries of American findings that fully meet the standards of disclosure under the agreement, he said.
 
Off-Guard Athletes
 The Soviet ministry has been spot-checking its athletes at the rate of about nine a day at unannounced times and places and not just at competitive meets, he said, to find athletes least on their guard.
The first few exchanges of specialists with the United States have already occurred on an experimental basis to work out procedures. The program provides for physicians, laboratory specialists and training experts to visit the rival nation and conduct drug-ingestion tests at the rate, next year, of up to 100 athletes per country.
Individual competitors are to be of the visitors' choosing at times they secretly select as most promising, with test specimens to be made available within 24 hours of the request and analyzed by the visitors under ideal laboratory conditions, Gromyko said.
"Any time of the year, day or night," he said. "We need the element of surprise." He estimated that anything more than 24 hours' notice to an athlete or coach worked against effective testing.

HEADLINE: Yachting;
San Diego Seeking Little Cup

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
As if having the America's Cup isn't enough, government officials in the San Diego area are going after the Little America's Cup. The trophy has some of the same history as its illustrious namesake. In 1985, the Little America's Cup was lost by United States yachtsmen to Australia and the Australians have successfully defended it twice. This month, San Diego sailors will try to win it back.
The Little America's Cup was established in 1961 by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club of Long Island. Known as the International Catamaran Challenge Trophy, the award of small silver sails isn't as prestigious as the gilded urn of the America's Cup. But the multihull racing it fosters attracts yachting's most advanced designers. 
 Gino Morelli, the multihull designer who was instrumental in creating Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes catamaran in 1988, has designed a twin-hulled sailboat for the Little America's Cup. The 25-foot catamaran has been sent from San Diego to Melbourne, Australia, where it is expected to begin racing next Sunday.
The effort is the brainchild of Brian Bilbray, the San Diego County Supervisor. Bilbray, a multihull sailor, has been closely involved as a county official with plans for the 1992 America's Cup series in San Diego. With the international event stalled in the New York courts for two years, Bilbray embraced the idea of the Little America's Cup as an interim challenge.
 
Playing Waiting Game
 "It was a waiting game," Jeff Stafford, Bilbray's administrative assistant, said of the court impasse. At stake was whether Michael Fay of New Zealand would be awarded the America's Cup for New Zealand, or whether it would go to San Diego. San Diego officials at the time estimated that the event could bring the area as much as $1 billion in revenue. Bilbray argued that the Little America's Cup also had economic potential.
Bilbray persuaded local governments to support a Little America's Cup campaign. If San Diego sailors won the catamaran trophy, it would bring another sailing event to the area, he said. "It is a perfect way to highlight the South Bay as a sailing center and tourist spot," Stafford said.
As the syndicate chairman, Bilbray enlisted the Chula Vista Yacht Club, a club south of San Diego, as a sponsor. He raised $85,000 in support from local municipalities along the South Bay waterfront: Chula Vista, National City, Coronado and Imperial Beach. Another $100,000 came from the Port of San Diego, a state government agency that has committed $8.3 million for the 1992 America's Cup match series.
The local communities raised the money from hotel taxes, a levy designed to further enhance tourism, said Stafford. For the area to reap the cup's benefits, the San Diego team needed to bring the Little America's Cup trophy back from Australia.
An overall budget of $750,000, which also includes corporate and private donations, includes about $160,000 for building Freedom's Wing, the San Diego syndicate's new high-tech boat.
 
Two-Man Crew
 The catamaran, capable of speeds up to 30 knots, has a crew of two Californians: Pete Melvin of Westminster, and Steve Rosenberg of Long Beach, who were former teammates on the ProSail professional multihull circuit. They will begin racing next week against another challenger, a catamaran from La Rochelle, France. The winner of a four-of-seven race series is slated to compete against the Australian defender beginning Jan. 12.
"I think if we get through the French with our noses clean, that will give us the experience we need to race the Australians," Morelli said last week. "We'll have three weeks in Melbourne to get ready for them."
The boats they are racing are C Class catamarans. The multihulls have few design limits: a length of 25 feet; a width of 14 feet, 300 square feet of sail area; and a two-man crew. Yacht designers strive to build the lightest boats to gain a speed advantage. Morelli said his team's design weighs about 400 pounds.
Experience has shown in the Little America's Cup that getting to the starting line is as important as winning the race. In the last event, staged in Melbourne in the winter of 1989, a challenger from the Cabrillo Yacht Club of San Pedro, Calif., was on site but unable to race. The lightweight but fragile catamaran capsized and its rig fell apart during the starting sequence of the match-racing series.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Scranton Baseball Is No Minor Issue

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

DATELINE: SCRANTON , Pa.

 BODY:
IN a city where steel furnaces and rail cars loaded with coal are all but a distant memory, there stands an elegant monument to a long-lost industrial and manufacturing era.
The Royce Hotel in downtown Scranton is built on what was once one of the busiest railway hubs in the region, the Lackawanna Station. 
 The stately six-story building now has only railroad memorabilia to provide a reminder of what was a viable artery from which the Lackawanna, Delaware and Western carried the region's precious resources to cities like Hoboken, N.J., and Buffalo.
Scranton, Wilkes-Barre and the surrounding mountain and valley towns of northeastern Pennsylvania long ago stopped producing coal and steel. Local residents stubbornly refuse to allow an image held by much of the outside world -- that it is a Rust Belt region -- to take hold.
Gains, economic and social, large and small, are held dearly. No better example exists, residents say, than two modern-day products: the Scranton/Wilkes-Barre Red Barons, the Triple A affiliate of the Philadelphia Phillies; and the ball park that houses the team, Lackawanna County Stadium.
"The Red Barons and the ball park are probably one of the most significant economic developments for our local economy in years," said Charlie Gahwiler, a local Scranton businessman and one of the original season ticket holders for Red Barons games.
The Red Barons' primary function is to produce major leaguers for the parent club about two and a half hours to the south. As for the two- years-young 10,600-seat multipurpose ballpark, it is a miniature version of the Phillies' Veterans Stadium, and what it produces cannot be easily measured.
"The stadium was definitely a morale builder for an area that has been through some tough economic times recently," said Pat McKenna, editorial page editor of The Scranton Times-Tribune. Take away that the team and with it the ball park's revenues and it would have "an incredibly chilling effect."
Such words are not the mutterings of a doomsayer, but the very real concern of a lot of people in this region as well as of the close to 200 minor league towns across the United States, Canada, the Dominican Republic and Mexico. Not until next Thursday can such concerns go away. That's when minor league officials will vote on a new Professional Baseball Agreement that would bind them to their major league affiliates. Without the agreement, many clubs may be permanently disenfranchised.
Chances seem likely that the two groups will come to a formal agreement. The executive committee of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues -- the minors' governing board -- unanimously recommended Friday that its membership approve a proposal already ratified by the major league owners. Still, the very idea that minor league baseball might have been wrenched away proved to be very sobering, especially for a region like Scranton/Wilkes- Barre.
Even though the Barons are still contractually bound to the Phillies for another year, they have no formal schedule because of the four-and-a-half-month dispute. The Barons don't even know which teams will be in what had been an eight-club Triple A International League. "There is some concern because this is more than baseball here," Bill Terlecky, the general manager of the Barons, said.
"Coal has been gone for about 30 years," said McKenna. "The downtown area of Scranton, once a retail center, is not in great shape. The ball park, however, generates money. According to the Economic Development Council of Northeastern Pennsylvania, for every dollar spent at Lackawanna Stadium, another $7 is generated for the local economy."
Studies indicate that $69-73 million worth of economic impact would be attributed to the development of the stadium over a 10-year period if the Barons average a quarter of a million fans annually. In the team's first two seasons, the attendance has averaged 500,000.
"The ball park is a catalyst," said Bill Risse, director of community affairs for the county. "It wasn't part of a master plan. but one of a succession of developments, all interdependent on one another. They've given the community a lot of momentum."
The ball park is nestled at the foot of Montage Mountain in Moosic, just south of Scranton and about 18 miles north of Luzerne County's Wilkes-Barre. A ski resort, constructed in the early 1980's, is atop the mountain. A business park that has already attracted J.C. Penney and Prudential is springing up around the base.
The area's momentum now may hinge on Thursday's vote. "If things don't go, then I think you'll see a backlash," Terlecky said.
He is not just talking about the ire of the 14 full-time Barons employees or even the 200 or so part-time concessionaires, parking lot attendants and ushers. Rather, the backlash would be broad-based. For Lackawanna County Stadium, as the name suggests, is a public facility, owned and operated by the county's multipurpose stadium authority.
The county, using bonds and state grants, built the park at a cost of $22 million and started operations with a $13 million debt service to be paid in increments of $1.8 million a year for 20 years. The park primarily depends on the Barons' tickets sales to meet that debt. "In the first season, we hit debt service and we look to be on track this year," said Terlecky.
If ticket sales can't cover that expense, the taxpayers will have to, a fact not lost on politicians. Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, concerned about all five minor league teams in Pennsylvania, had asked the Senate Judiciary Committee to consider holding special hearings. And, said Joe Corcoran, a Lackawanna County commissioner, "we were committed to going to war over this, to the courts, if necessary."
Still, while Terlecky and others wait on Thursday's vote, the general manager said the team was trying to concentrate on the job at hand. Season ticket sales, the backbone of the team ever since 2,200 buyers guaranteed a financial base for the team in 1984, are still brisk. Terlecky expects the usual 4,000 purchasers again for 1991.
"Nobody," said Terlecky, "has turned away."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Free-Agent Signings in the Game of Catch-the-Leader

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
A year ago some of the teams that had watched the Oakland Athletics win their second successive American League West championship took expensive steps to try to reduce the distance between the champions and them.
The Kansas City Royals signed Mark Davis, a Cy Young award-winning relief pitcher, and Storm Davis, a starting pitcher, giving them what they believed was the best staff in the league. The California Angels signed Mark Langston, figuring he would solve the missing link in their pitching. The Seattle Mariners made an unusually bold foray into the free-agent market by signing the first baseman Pete O'Brien. 
 Oakland, however, won again, and the Angels, the Mariners and the Royals finished fourth, fifth and sixth, winding up an aggregate 76 1/2 games behind the Athletics. So much for the aggressive winter moves.
Now come the clubs that finished behind the Cincinnati Reds in the National League West. This is their winter to act aggressively in an effort to succeed the Reds. No matter how much they spend, though, or how much creative trading they do, only one team can win the division championship. And there's no guarantee that any of the aggressive also-rans will catch the Reds.
The Los Angeles Dodgers began the can-you-top-this approach by signing Darryl Strawberry, but the San Francisco Giants leaped in with a frenzy, signing three free agents for a total of $33 million and making two trades.
The division's two new general managers have not deferred to those already in residence. In fact, they made similar acquisitions but in different ways. John Schuerholz, assuming command of the last-place Atlanta Braves, quickly recruited half of a new infield: Sid Bream for first base and Terry Pendleton for third.
Then Joe McIlvaine changed half of the San Diego Padres' infield, obtaining Fred McGriff for first base and Tony Fernandez for shortstop in a trade that caught the attention of everyone and the envy of many other general managers.
McIlvaine is not finished; he seeks another center fielder, perhaps Brett Butler, who is a free-look free agent. But the Braves and the Dodgers like Butler, too, creating what could be an economically spiraling competition. The outcome of the pursuit, if the winner is one of the N.L. West teams, could have an impact on the division race. It could even affect the Giants, who signed Willie McGee and shed Butler.
Most likely Al Rosen, the Giants' general manager, isn't finished bolstering his team's chances either. If he could add another left-handed pitcher -- he has already signed two, Bud Black and Dave Righetti -- the Giants would be even better equipped to neutralize the predominantly left-hand-hitting Dodgers, whom they see as a formidable rival, perhaps even more so than the Reds. (The Dodgers also have signed a starting pitcher, Kevin Gross.)
The defending champions have not added any new players to their winning collection. They lost one, Danny Jackson, as a free agent, but once that left-handed pitcher left, they made sure that another one, Tom Browning, didn't get away.
The Houston Astros have not made any moves. They are debating whether to trade Glenn Davis, their first baseman, who could be a free agent after next season, instead of signing him to a very expensive contract.
If they do trade him, though, they will not keep him in the division. It is well stocked with first basemen, people such as McGriff, Will Clark and Eddie Murray.
 
Jays' Offense a Question Mark
 With two trades and two free-agent signings, Pat Gillick has made nearly as many moves as he had in the previous three and a third years as the Toronto general manager. As interesting as the trades are, however, Gillick has taken a chance on leaving the Blue Jays with too little offense.
Compare the 1990 figures for total bases and on-base percentage of the four stars in the stunning swap with the Padres.
Fred McGriff and Tony Fernandez had a combined 543 total bases to 471 for Joe Carter and Roberto Alomar and a .375 on-base percentage to .314. Unlike such statistics as runs batted in and runs scored, these are individual achievements that have no reliance on other hitters.
Gillick said that the Blue Jays could afford to carry the inexplicably weak bat of Devon White, their new center fielder, but even if the two-for-two were viewed as an even exchange, adding White and subtracting George Bell would leave the Blue Jays short on offense.
 
Rebuilding Time for the Cardinals
 The St. Louis Cardinals have played a bad joke on Joe Torre. Last year, after Whitey Herzog realized the direction the team was heading and quit as manager, the Cardinals lured Torre out of a comfortable broadcasting booth. The dugout doesn't figure to be too comfortable next season.
The Cardinals, who won three division titles in six years in the 80's, are in a state of fatal deterioration. They finished in last place this year, and from that team they have lost Vince Coleman, Terry Pendleton and Ken Dayley as free agents afer trading Willie McGee before he could leave as a free agent. They also will be without John Tudor, their No. 1 pitcher with 12 victories. This is a team in need of serious rebuilding.
The Cardinals are counting on youth for respectability: four players who have a total of three years and 69 days of of major league experience. They are the outfielders Bernard Gilkey, Ray Lankford and Felix Jose and the catcher-turned-third baseman, Todd Zeile.
Gilkey will replace Coleman in left field (although Milt Thompson will be there to platoon if necessary) and Lankford will continue to play center, where he replaced McGee. Jose, acquired from Oakland during the season, will play right.
Zeile, a disappointment offensively as a rookie catcher, will take Pendleton's place at third, where he played for about a month late in the season, then in the instructional league. Tom Pagnozzi moves in as the catcher. Dayley's departure leaves Frank DiPino as the No. 1 left-hander in the bullpen.
If Torre can take the frustration and the headaches he undoubtedly will encounter, someday he could have a good young team. By losing Coleman, Pendleton and Dayley, the Cardinals will have five extra selections early in next June's amateur draft, giving them seven of the first 40 to 45 players chosen.
 
The Patience of Quinn
 On the day he was named baseball executive of the year by The Sporting News, Bob Quinn, the general manager of the World Series champion Cincinnati Reds, talked about the importance of patience in his job and how his previous employer, George Steinbrenner, never understood that.
Unlike the impetuous Steinbrenner, Quinn said, he took his time making deals, checking reports, consulting with scouts, even calling former coaches of the team he was dealing with to learn more about the player he sought.
The next day Quinn contradicted himself, and maybe lost a starting pitcher in the process.
Quinn, a low-key man who occasionally flashes a temper, lashed out at Zane Smith's agent, Joe Sroba, even slamming down the telephone to end their conversation. Then he harshly criticized him publicly, saying Sroba had told him if he offered $10.5 million for Smith they had a deal.
However, as Sroba explained before and after Quinn's tirade and as three other general managers apparently understood, $10.5 million was the minimum offer needed to remain in competition. How the misunderstanding developed is not the point. By reacting heatedly instead of trying to straighten out their differences, Quinn belied his policy of patience.
As for Steinbrenner, he blames Commissioner Fay Vincent for the Yankees' loss of Dave Righetti. "If I were involved, this never would have happened," the ousted managing partner said, again arguing that he should have been permitted to deal with free agents.
Steinbrenner, however, was free to deal with Righetti before he resigned Aug. 20. He knew Righetti was in the last year of his contract. He could have locked him up before the season or before he was locked out.
One of the points Righetti made the night he agreed to take his heart to San Francisco was that the Yankees didn't talk to him all season about a new contract. If Steinbrenner wanted Righetti back so badly, he could have talked to him and negotiated a deal long before the reliever was in a position to get away.
 
 Exhibit No. 1, Collusion 5?
 In a farewell speech to his fellow owners, Charles Bronfman of the Montreal Expos decried the profusion of lucrative multiyear contracts and cited the MacPhail report that five years ago expressed much the same lament, with statistics added for support. Bronfman's mention of the report served as the proverbial red flag waved in front of a bull because it was one of the early pieces of evidence the players presented to support their collusion case.
"We hope it doesn't become the first exhibit in collusion five," said Donald Fehr, head of the players' union. "Obviously, if he cites the MacPhail report, it has potential to put people on edge because that was the event that confirmed that collusion had begun to take place. I don't expect there to be further collusion. If there is, sparked by this suggestion or any other, somebody should remember that there are triple damage provisions in the new agreement."

HEADLINE: The World;
Europeans Begin to Calculate the Price of Pollution

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS

DATELINE: THE HAGUE

 BODY:
IN a Spartan office on the eighth floor of the Netherlands Central Bureau of Statistics, a shy man with the stoop of a bookkeeper rather than the bearing of a firebrand has been quietly plotting a revolution in the way economists look at the environment.
For 30 years, Roefie Hueting has provoked and prodded planners and policymakers, telling them that they are fooling themselves in the way they measure a country's wealth, the welfare of its citizens, the prices of goods and services. And he has devised his own way, a set of new indicators that would arrive at a "green" gross national product, accounting for the harm that economic activity does to the environment. 
 The idea is getting a broader reception in Europe as the environmental debate has heated up, and public opinion now favors more drastic steps to fight pollution.
By ignoring or disguising the cost of economic production to the environment, Mr. Hueting and other dissident economists argue, the gross national product of many countries has been inflated and sometimes grossly distorted. It is absurd, Mr. Hueting contends, that measures to defend nature or to check or clean damage have been tallied as growth.
In his years as a gadfly, the meticulous and persistent Mr. Hueting, economist and jazz pianist, has been an irritant to people on the left and the right. He survived politicians who wanted to close down his department, and he got a reputation as a Don Quixote among economists. Slowly he gained acclaim from his peers. Now governments and international institutions are listening.
The Dutch Government has asked Mr. Hueting to produce an alternative system of national accounting to reflect the damage done to the air, water, soil, and animal and plant life, and to account for the cost of maintaining or restoring them. Planners at the United Nations Environment Program and officials at the World Bank have said that Mr. Hueting's publications got them thinking about the need for "environmental accounting" in recent years.
Mr. Hueting is far from the only economist contending that the habits of more than 50 years of economic accounting -- using the output of goods and services as the only measure of economic and even social success -- are outdated and misleading. Arguments that new rules and premises are needed have gained among researchers in the United States. A bill passed a year ago by Congress directed the Commerce Department to work on a new system of calculating environmental costs and benefits.
In Europe, the idea of "green" accounting has pried its way into more and more government offices. Sweden' Parliament has sent a delegation to the Netherlands for advice on starting a project. France and Norway have started to compile inventories of their natural resources, a first step to linking the state of the environment to economic activity.
Germany, which is farther along, has responded to pressure from its Green Party and is working out a system to correct the "double counting" in its national bookkeeping. In a 1989 study, the economist Christian Leipert showed that between 1970 and 1985, West Germany's spending to preserve or restore nature increased from 5 percent to 10 percent of its gross national product, and was consistently counted as growth. That meant, said Mr. Hueting, that measures simply to check deterioration were recorded as a significant contribution.
"Take a water treatment plant," said Mr. Hueting. "Under the present accounting system, it is booked as a contribution, though it should be entered as cost. It's built to make up for the loss of usable water. It does not generate growth. You can only count that plant as value added if you have first entered the ruined drinking water as a loss." It would be equally misleading to count cleaning smog as growth, he said.
 
Not a Solution
 Redefining such costs and correcting the books is useful, he said , but "it's dangerous if politicians or statisticians present this as the solution, because, as is well known, most environmental destruction is never restored or compensated."
Ultimately, Mr. Hueting and other ecological economists hope that a new framework for national accounts will lead to a fundamental change of national goals and even a redefinition of progress. "Green" accounting will show how far the world has drifted from rational behavior, from activities that are not destructive to the biosphere and therefore to society, they argue.
Applying a "green" G.N.P., Mr. Hueting said, will make polluting products more expensive and consequently will slow growth. But he said this does not have to mean a decline in employment. "Many activities that protect the environment will have to be more labor-intensive," he said. "An economy that protects the environment will create more jobs."
While he says his work is often complex and frustrating, the political climate for his ideas is far more favorable than in the early 1960's. Mr. Hueting and his team of 30 specialists, among them biologists, chemists and physicists, reckon that they need at least two years to come up with a draft for a "green" G.N.P. Even so, the Netherlands seems further along than most nations. The Department for Environmental Statistics, created by Mr. Hueting in 1969, has been collecting data on the environment -- all emissions, concentrations of toxic material, disappearances of plant and animal species and other changes -- over the last two decades. Such an inventory, he said, is a vital prerequisite.The process, he said, involves establishing norms for "sustainable use" of the environment, that is, leaving intact its capacity to regenerate itself.
 
Complex Process
 The next step, he said, is to decide what measures are needed to attain sustainable use. The costs of these measures must then be subtracted from the current G.N.P. to calculate the "green" G.N.P. "It is obviously a very complex process," said Mr. Hueting, "despite the fact that we can apply traditional economic methods."
<> <> Even if governments only use it as a parallel system, he said, it will help to clarify "our mistaken accounting and demonstrate how we are squandering air, water, ground, trees, spaces, silence, as if they were free goods instead of assets that we are losing." It will clarify "that we should abandon the G.N.P. as the main indicator of economic success and not get upset when it drops."
While many researchers in Europe have agreed that income is not a satisfactory measure of quality of life here, they say a new perspective is even more important for developing nations that are in danger of squandering their assets. Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines, which have cut their forests and suffered soil erosion, have asked the Netherlands for technical assistance in environmental accounting. At the United Nations, the Statistical Commission is now revising its System of National Accounts, which it does only once every two decades, and it has agreed to set up guidelines for countries that want to draw up their own "green" G.N.P.'s.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Miami Melting Pot Proves Explosive

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
WITH its periodic civil disruptions, this has become the Old Faithful of American cities. Last week, the latest eruption of looting, mayhem and hatred raised the question of just what it is about this sun-splashed city that begets such uprisings.
Five times in the last 10 years, Miami has been rocked by disorders. While other cities mark the passage of time by elections, natural disasters, or championships won by local sports teams, Miami's calendar is pockmarked by riots named after the neighborhoods where they have occurred: Overtown, Liberty City and, last week, Wynwood. 
 Indeed, the worst of the disturbances is recalled in eerily human terms. The 1980 conflagration that left 18 dead, 400 injured and $100 million in property damage in the predominantly black Liberty City district is simply referred to as "McDuffie," after the black motorcyclist whose death at the hands of the police touched off the rampage.
Compared to McDuffie, the three-hour spree of arson and looting in the largely Puerto Rican neighborhood of Wynwood was a pint-sized affair. Three buildings were set ablaze, and only a handful of others were damaged. And except for two newspaper photographers who were roughed up by youths in the streets, no one was injured.
"What happened this week was, in terms of disturbances of this kind, rather small," said Msgr. Bryan Walsh, director of Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of Miami. "Bigger ones have occurred after soccer games in England."
But if Wynwood's explosion was smaller than McDuffie's, the two were fueled by similar discontents. In each case, rioting followed the accquittal of police officers charged with a killing. In Wynwood, the dead man was 35-year-old Leonardo Mercado, a suspected drug dealer. As in McDuffie, the scene was a neighborhood plagued by poverty, crime, gang activity and drugs. And, once again, police were unprepared for a community's reaction. In each case, spokesmen for a disaffected group complained of being ignored by the city's political and commercial elite.
"We're the invisible community," said Betzaida Ferrer, state director for National Puerto Rican Forum. "And it's sad that this is the only way we have gotten recognition." Xavier Suarez, Miami's Mayor, acknowledged after the disturbance that the problems of the Wynwood area were not being met. He promised to divert more city resources to the area.
Miami's Puerto Ricans, comprising about 4 percent of the population, were not known for such eruptions of mass anger. For that reason, police failed to place their riot squads on alert after the Mercado verdict. But Miami's Puerto Ricans say they are thought of as meek only when they are thought of at all, which is seldom.
"The perception here is that when you speak about Hispanics, you only speak about Cubans," said Emilio Lopez, president of the Borinquen Health Care Center in Wynwood. "When you speak about the poor, you speak about blacks."
Expressions of resentment against the entrepreneurial and politically conservative Cubans, who make up 42 percent of the city's population, were common among the youths on Wynwood streets during the disturbance. In Miami's black neighborhoods, it is also commonly complained that Cubans have gotten more than their share of economic advantages.
"There is a perception among blacks of loss of jobs as a result of the Latinization of the city," said Marvin Dunn, professor of community psychology at Florida International University. Mr. Dunn said that census data have not supported this contention. In fact, he said, black incomes rose significantly during the 1970's, the time when the Cubans were becoming entrenched in Miami. Mr. Dunn and others are awaiting the 1990 census data to see if that trend continued during the 1980's. Still, he says, the "why" of Miami's propensity for civil disturbance remains "a perplexing question."
What is undeniable, though, is Cuban domination of the city's politics. Three of the five members of the Miami City Commission, including the mayor, are of Cuban descent. So are the city manager, the Dade County school superintendent and one of one of the city's four members of the House of Representatives. Blacks, who account for about 25 percent of the population, have one seat on the City Commission
"The political agenda in Miami clearly places the interest and priorities of Cubans first," said Mr. Dunn.
In fact, both the Wynwood disturbance and the McDuffie riot occurred while the city's attention was diverted by events relating to the Cuban community. In 1980 it was the Mariel boatlift. Last week it was a bitter debate between blacks and Cuban politicians who withdrew the city's official welcoming praise of Nelson Mandela last June after Mr. Mandela spoke highly of Fidel Castro.
Perhaps the simplest explanation is that there are riots in Miami because there have been riots in Miami. In a close succession of disorders, the memory of the last rampage can serve as motivation for the next, especially when local officials view social and economic conditions as contributory factors and respond with more money for remedial programs.
"The other people, the black people, this is how they did it, and it worked," Yvette Diaz, 17 years old, told the Associated Press during the riot.
"People in society follow patterns," said Maurice Ferre, Miami's former mayor, who is also Puerto Rican. "Obviously a pattern has been established that when you have been ignored, you respond with civil disturbances."

HEADLINE: The Region;
Are Special Tolls A Way to Thin Out Midtown Traffic?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
THE pleasures of New York City's rush-hour traffic are well known. But to some environmentalists and economists, Manhattan's street snarl is seen as an opportunity as well as a problem. New technology already being used to collect tolls in Texas and Louisiana could be adopted, they say, to limit the number of rush-hour drivers in Manhattan by charging a fee, with results that could help to restore New York City's edge in the national competition for jobs and tax base.
Others, notably New York City's Transportation Commissioner, point out that such restrictions have so far been adopted only in authoritarian Singapore, and argue that such a system would never be accepted in Manhattan. But the idea had enthusiastic backers in the Koch Administration, and pressures from Washington could yet make the concept attractive to Mayor David N. Dinkins. 
 Tough standards adopted in the new Clean Air Act will eventually force New York to take dramatic steps to cut pollution from cars. And new technology for assessing "congestion fees" at rush hour, some believe, would make it practical to meet the air-quality targets with little disruption to commerce, clipping the daily peaks in traffic while actually increasing the total number of vehicles able to use midtown streets.
The potential benefits are so great, advocates such as William Vickrey, an economist at Columbia University, argue, that even rush-hour drivers would be better off: the savings in time would more than offset the fees. But even the most ardent supporters concede that congestion fees will not be workable unless commuters are convinced the fees are more than just another way to separate them from their money.
Each day some three-quarters of a million vehicles inch into the area bounded by Second and Tenth Avenues, 34th and 59th Streets. Once inside, traffic moves like ketchup in a television commercial: speeds average 7 miles an hour daily.
 
More Cars, Less Road

 
 To Gabriel Roth, a former World Bank economist who is an advocate of congestion fees, that makes no more sense than the Soviet practice of deciding who gets the limited supply of sausage by rewarding those who wait longest in lines outside butcher shops. Indeed, it apparently makes less sense: no matter how long the line, the amount of meat available remains the same. But very heavy use reduces a road system's capacity.
As traffic builds, average speed falls -- and the number of vehicle miles traveled each hour eventually falls with it. As average travel time increases, the total number of vehicles that can squeeze through the streets diminishes.
Most vehicles entering Manhattan do pay tolls for the privilege. But as George Haikalis, a New York transportation consultant, notes, commuters perversely receive discounts for regular rush hour use of bridges and tunnels. A 1986 study prepared for the city by Cambridge Systematics, a Massachusetts consulting firm, envisaged a system with more rational incentives: cars entering midtown on weekday mornings would have to display a special license, purchased on a daily, monthly or annual basis.
Such a system has been in use in Singapore since 1975. The daily fee, now about $5, cuts morning traffic by 60 percent. New Yorkers would probably be less responsive: the 1986 study estimates that a $5 fee would cut private auto entries during the morning by a fifth.
Since many of the entry points to midtown are streets rather than bridges or tunnels, toll collection might have proved an expensive headache in the mid-1980's. But electronic collection systems have improved the prospects for unintrusive administration.
Radio-based identification sys-tems built by the Amtech Corporation are used to collect tolls on the North Dallas Tollway and the Crescent City Bridge in New Orleans; by next year an Amtech system will cover the Oklahoma Turnpike. A British system was fully tested in downtown Hong Kong. And Singapore is now converting to electronic collection.
Equipment above or below the road identifies each vehicle by its radio signature, broadcast by a cigarette-pack-sized transmitter in the windshield. Individual accounts are billed with statements that look like phone bills. In Dallas, drivers pay $30 for the identification unit; all other costs are covered with a 5-cent-a-transaction charge. Those driving infrequently in midtown Manhattan could buy one-day stickers, sold at bridge crossings and gas stations.
Hong Kong's system was judged 99.7 percent accurate in a two-year test of some 3,000 vehicles. Amtech equipment used to keep track of tolls on buses entering New York's Lincoln Tunnel is 99.99 percent accurate. It might still be prudent, though, to test the system under battlefield conditions -- say, by trying electronic collection on one of the Hudson River crossings.
 
A Wall of Resistance

 
 But the politics of congestion fees are far more problematic than the technology or economics. Sandford Borins, a political scientist at York University in Ontario, notes that the Hong Kong system was stillborn because drivers viewed it as a backhanded tax. New York's own flirtation with congestion fees offers little reason for optimism.
Ross Sandler, Mayor Koch's Commissioner of Transportation, proposed a fee in 1986 as a way of meeting looming Federal air-quality deadlines. The concept was supported by the Regional Plan Association, a private research group, but ran into a wall of resistance from unions and midtown businesses.
Such opposition frustrates Mr. Vickrey. The small minority of shoppers who drive to midtown, he believes, would happily pay a modest fee in return for an easier ride. And even a modest improvement in traffic that increased the efficiency of delivery trucks would more than offset the charge. But Lucius Riccio, New York's current Commissioner of Transportation, is not convinced. "To affect people's driving behavior," he said, "you would have to charge $10. And at that point you would be restricting certain groups."
One way to make the idea more appealing might be to link the peak-hour congestion fees to a dollar-for-dollar reduction of bridge and tunnel tolls at non-peak hours. Another, advocated by Mr. Haikalis, would be to dedicate the revenues to road and mass-transit improvements. Mr. Haikalis would also use some of the revenue to allow free bus-subway transfers, sharply reducing the costs of subway commuting for car-minded residents of the outer boroughs.
Those revenues could be substantial. If 120,000 vehicles entered midtown during the weekday morning rush (20 percent fewer than now) a $5 tax would generate more than $150 million annually.
Congestion fees would be a hard political sell without support from city and state officials. But the traffic problem has not induced a radical response from City Hall in the past, and there is no sign it will in the future. What eventually might force action, though, is a hard line from environmental regulators.
Amendments to the Clean Air Act will require the metropolitan area to reduce overall emissions of pollutants by 3 percent annually, a goal that Eric A. Goldstein at the Natural Resources Defense Council argues will put New York "under increasing pressure to formally address motor vehicle pollution." And if Federal sanctions -- everything from the loss of subsidies to a ban on construction -- became a credible threat, the politics of congestion fees could change.

HEADLINE: The World;
In South America, Bush Finds Warmth And Restiveness

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
MILITARY revolts in Argentina and Panama, an army massacre of Indians in Guatemala, a major rebel offensive in El Salvador and the murder of a Coca-Cola executive by guerrillas in Bolivia made it an inauspicious week for President Bush to tour Latin America.
The violence was not related to Mr. Bush's visit -- except for a scattering of rioting and minor bombings in Venezuela and Chile -- and it did not spoil the general warmth of his welcome. But the outbursts highlighted the intractable obstacles of militarism, racism, poverty, corruption and ideological polarization that stand in the way of the economic progress Mr. Bush intended to promote. 
 They also served to raise the question of whether any United States President, whatever his ideology, economic program or personal style, can put together a policy that will help heal Latin America's wounds. Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy were beloved in Latin America for the idealism they expressed in pursuing the Good Neighbor Policy and the Alliance for Progress. But whatever successes their programs accomplished did not endure.
George Bush is also popular in Latin America, uncommonly so for a Republican President, and he has proclaimed his own Enterprise for the Americas Initiative. But it remains doubtful that Mr. Bush will have any more success than his predecessors unless Latin Americans manage to create workable economies and democracies for themselves.
Mr. Bush's highly publicized campaign to halt Latin American drug trafficking has failed to make even a dent in the flow of Peruvian, Colombian and Bolivian cocaine into the United States. And the pride of his Latin America policy -- the electoral victory of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro over Nicaragua's Sandinista President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, last February -- has not yet brought that country stability.
Mr. Bush traveled to South America, and to Mexico the week before, talking pesos and dolares. Wherever he went he promoted his enterprise initiative, which he described to the Uruguayan Congress as "an ambitious new plan to increase trade, investment and growth throughout the hemisphere."
 
Pushing Privatization
 "It is a major step," he declared, "in our shared dream for the world's first completely democratic hemisphere." He pushed for the privatization of state enterprises, cutbacks in public subsidies, and reductions in budget deficits in exchange for the Administration's support in encouraging Latin America's commercial creditors to ease interest rates on old debts.
Such free-market thinking is not new, but the emphasis he has placed on economic issues in his Latin America policy is. The last several American Presidents concentrated their energies on the strategic import of political developments in countries like Nicaragua, El Salvador, Panama and Cuba. The facts that Mr. Bush's visits to Argentina and Chile were the first by an American President since Dwight D. Eisenhower, and his visit to Venezuela the first since John F. Kennedy, demonstrate how long it has been since some of the largest and most economically important Latin American countries have figured so importantly in a hemispheric policy initiative from the White House.
Administration officials insist that Mr. Bush has not forgotten Central America, but that he has a far broader view of the importance of Latin America as a whole than did his most recent predecessors. They say he is keenly aware of Mexico's and Venezuela's vast oil potential, the shrinking of Brazil's Amazon rain forests, and the potential consumer market for United States exports that could be built among the more than 400 million people in the region.
As Mr. Bush repeatedly demonstrated in Mexico and South America, he gets on well with Latin Americans, and appears to genuinely enjoy Latin culture. He quickly picked up on the symbolism when Mexico's President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, invited him to his ancestral town of Agualeguas, and he reciprocated by personally removing Mr. Salinas' jacket at a rodeo. Mr. Bush has made some progress toward his policy goals by regularly consulting with Latin American presidents and even coordinating some of his policies with theirs -- most recently in attempts to reinvigorate the stalled peace talks in El Salvador and to assure fair elections in Haiti. Latin American leaders have noticed the attention, and relish it. President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela noted that because Mr. Bush "is a Texan and an oil man, he understands us and our strategic importance better." Argentina's President, Carlos Saul Menem, characterized Mr. Bush's Latin tour as "a fiesta of good neighborliness."
But all the good mutual feelings cannot assure success for Mr. Bush's new policy.
 
Structural Problems
 "President Bush has handled himself extraordinarily well compared to the old track record," said Roberto Eisenmann Jr., publisher of the Panama City daily La Prensa.
"But we have very definite structural problems," he said. "They go back as far as the colonial period, and the long U.S. record in Latin America has created a hostility that will not be easy to overcome."
Mr. Eisenmann predicted that last week's rebellion of police forces in his country would only be repeated, time and again, if Panama did not follow Costa Rica's example and disarm itself. What made the apparent coup attempt less than one year after the United States invasion particularly distressing to Washington was that it took American troops to end the revolt. Many analysts believe that it was that kind of dependency, ingrained during decades of intensive American involvement in the country, that contributed to the need for the invasion in the first place -- by having helped make the Panamanian people reluctant to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega themselves.
Another military uprising, this one in Argentina -- the fourth unsuccessful one since 1987 -- forced President Menem to impose a state of siege and deploy tanks and air force bombers just 48 hours before Mr. Bush's visit. It was easily put down, and did not deter Mr. Bush from keeping to his schedule. But it was a reminder that problems most recently associated with Central America remain problems in South America as well.

HEADLINE: The Region;
The Port Authority Thinks It's Time to Build Again

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
IN their quest for more money for large projects, Port Authority and transit officials are singing a familiar song to Trenton and Albany: public spending, especially now in times of austerity, would help bolster the region's economy by creating thousands of new jobs and spurring billions of dollars in private investment. To pay for these projects, Port Authority officials are seeking authorization to raise bridge and tunnel tolls as well as PATH train fares, and the Metropolitan Transit Authority is seeking capital funds from the state and Federal governments.
Stanley Brezenoff, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, estimates that the agency's proposed $5.4 billion plan would stimulate $3.8 billion in private investments and create 166,000 construction jobs and 20,000 new permanent jobs. 
 But critics of such capital spending said projects like those the agency is planning often take so long to develop and initiate that new jobs and economic benefits are not realized until many years later when the region's fiscal woes have passed.
"These billion-dollar investments have to be justified based on their long-term impact to improve mass transit and not on whether they help put a few thousand people to work in the next few years," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit monitoring group financed by businesses in New York City.
But Mr. Brezenoff argued that his agency's capital plan would provide short-term benefits like jobs and economic growth as well as make the region's airports and marine terminals more competitive in the long term. "If we don't do something to insure that New York is a convenient place to ship goods and to travel to distant lands," Mr. Brezenoff said, "we will become a second-rate town and people will take their business elsewhere." The agency oversees Newark, LaGuardia and John. F. Kennedy airports, bridges, tunnels and PATH rail systems crossing the Hudson, the World Trade Center, the bus terminal and port operations.
The $5.4 billion the Port Authority is seeking would be used to continue major construction projects at all three airports that will ease congestion; finish rehabilitation work on the authority's Hudson River bridges and tunnels, and make improvements at the World Trade Center, which now needs some renovations if it is to attract prospective tenants, Mr. Brezenoff said.
Undertaking major rebuilding programs in times of economic decline, transit officials said, also enables them to finish more projects at less cost because contractors are more competitive in bidding for the work.
But in order for that to happen, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which receives little or no state and Federal subsidies for its capital programs, said it needs to raise the tolls on its bridges and tunnels to $4 from $3, and the fare on its PATH trains to $1.25 from $1, starting next year. The increases, which would pay for the capital program as well as daily operations, must be approved by the Port Authority board and the Governors of New York and New Jersey. A decision is expected sometime next month.
 
Getting 'the Best Deals'

 
 Many local politicians agree with transit officials that an infusion of capital into public transportation facilities would help boost a sagging economy. "We are in a position to get the best deals and the best people to do our infrastructure work at a time when they don't have much else to do," said Ruth Messinger, Manhattan Borough President. "If you put these people to work, you are fueling the local economy by generating taxes that would otherwise not be forthcoming."
 Next year, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which operates operates subways, commuter railroads and many bus routes in the New York City region, will complete a $16-billion, 10-year capital program to overhaul tracks, switches, signals and stations and buy new buses and subway cars. A recent study by the Port Authority found that the program has stimulated $19 billion in economic activity in the region, generated $741 million in tax revenues and created 14,800 jobs.
The transit agency is seeking an estimated $12 billion from the state and Federal governments to fund a new program that transit officials said is necessary to complete the rebuilding effort -- including equipment like new electronic turnstiles for subway stations -- and to maintain New York's mass transit system.
Mortimer Downing, the M.T.A.'s executive director, argued that there would be no delay in starting up capital projects at the M.T.A and the Port Authority. "We won't be starting projects from scratch," Mr. Downing said. "We are talking about projects that have been in the planning for years and that we could get underway in a matter of months."
