HEADLINE: The Nation;
The Deficit Issue Is Back, And Likely to Make a Mess

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
JUST when many people thought Congress had slain the deficit monster after a seemingly endless struggle, the beast reappeared bigger than ever.
Congress is coming to grips with reality and recognizing that the Federal budget deficit will set a record in the current fiscal year, 1991, and will probably rise higher in 1992, despite the five-year "deficit-reduction bill" signed by President Bush on Nov. 5. 
 The new estimates of the deficit issued last week by the Congressional Budget Office were not a surprise to anyone who followed the arcana of the debate that consumed hours and hours and hours toward the end of the 101st Congress. But the numbers were sobering for lawmakers and Bush Administration officials who warmly congratulated one another six weeks ago on their herculean labors to cut the deficit.
Since then, the economy has weakened, the United States military commitment in the Persian Gulf has deepened and the projected costs of the savings and loan bailout have risen. And Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said the latest estimate of the deficit, $253 billion for the current fiscal year, was "a bit optimistic" since it was based on economic assumptions adopted in October.
So Congress and the President are gearing up for another battle, which will begin in earnest when Mr. Bush submits his proposals in early February. "Our best course is to build on this year's agreement, to use it as a foundation and to take advantage of the tough decisions that were made," said Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, chairman of the House Budget Committee. "That agreement does put us on the right course. But I suspect we will have to build upon that agreement additional deficit reduction."
 
Hidden Programs
 The budget is the main vehicle for such domestic policy as the Federal Government has these days. The 1991 budget bill, for example, expanded Medicaid coverage of poor children and provided $18 billion worth of new tax credits over five years for working poor families with children. Those changes would have been trumpeted as a major improvement in social welfare policy had they not been tucked away in a bill to raise taxes and trim spending for dozens of Government programs.
The political and intellectual debate on domestic policy is conducted in the shadow of the deficit. Democrats and Republicans alike have been cramped by their reluctance to raise taxes, and last month's election results will probably fortify their resistance to tax increases. Popular discontent over rising taxes was a factor in most of the 14 states where control of the governor's mansion shifted from one party to another.
The furious annual dance of budget legislation raises a few simple questions: Why can't the President submit more realistic budget proposals? Why can't Congress adhere to its schedule for acting on the budget? Why does Congress defer difficult decisions, then exhaust itself in a spasm of activity on the budget in the closing hours of each year's session? Why can't Democrats and Republicans moderate the partisanship that seems to poison most debates on the budget?
The struggle over the budget dramatizes the difference between real life and civics textbooks. The stakes are simply too high, in political and economic terms, for lobbyists, lawmakers and Federal agency officials to observe Marquis of Queensberry rules in sparring over the budget. No decision is final. No issue is too small to be reopened a week, a month or a year after a decision has been made. A budget bill is supposed to reconcile diverse interests, but there is never really reconciliation, only a brief truce till the fighting resumes.
A Presidential proposal initially dismissed by Congress as unrealistic may be accepted as lawmakers become desperate for savings and revenue. For example, Mr. Reagan's 1982 proposal to charge fees for entrance to national parks was initially hooted down by campers and environmentalists, but Congress eventually approved it, and some of the most popular parks, like Glacier and Yellowstone, now charge fees of $5 to $10 a vehicle.
Allen Schick, a professor of public policy at the University of Maryland who has written several books on the Federal budget process, said that members of Congress "really hoped they had put the budget and deficit problem behind them until after the 1992 elections." But, he said, that hope might evaporate after the 102d Congress convenes on Jan. 3.
"Delay occurs not simply because of legislative gridlock or the big egos involved, but because some people gain from it," Mr. Schick said. "Waiting till the last minute changes the political balance of power in budgeting. The winners are the Congressional Appropriations Committees, which have a stronger voice in dictating what happens on the floor, and the committee chairmen, who determine what goes into the final bills."
Moreover, Mr. Schick said, "Congress perceives that it gains from going to the brink" and packaging tax and spending legislation in an omnibus bill. By signing such legislation, the President acquiesces in measures that he might veto if presented to him separately.
The budget has a different dynamic each year, and 1991 will differ from 1990 in several ways. Congressional leaders say they do not intend to enter another round of "summit negotiations" with the White House. This year's negotiations were excruciatingly difficult, and they riled rank-and-file lawmakers, who complained they had been left out.
 
Self-Discipline
 In theory, the budget should be subject to new discipline because of procedures adopted by Congress to enforce spending limits. There are separate limits on military, international and domestic spending; if a new law threatens to push outlays above the ceiling for any category, there would be automatic across-the-board cuts in that category. Under the law, Congress may consider suspending the enforcement mechanism if there is a recession.
The next round of fiscal fisticuffs may be easier because 1991 is not an election year, but it may be more difficult if the economic slump continues. Defenders of the budget agreement expect to come under pressure from two sides. With the deficit rising to record levels, some Republicans plan to push for further cuts in Federal spending. Just as surely, some Democrats will push for new spending to stimulate the sluggish economy, create jobs and provide assistance to people who cannot find work.
Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said he did not see a need now for increased spending to stimulate the economy, since most forecasters expect a short, shallow recession, not a severe downturn.
"The budget agreement we enacted into law has a life expectancy of two years and, if we are lucky, perhaps three," he said. "It accomplished all that the political system and the economy will let us do in the near term."

HEADLINE: Headliners;
Europe's Farmers Plow a Trade Treaty Under

BYLINE: CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
THIS is not the way it was supposed to work out.
Because of their industrial interests, the United States and the European Community were expected to be on the same side in the trade talks that broke down Friday. Instead, they were at each other's throats. 
 The fights were supposed to come chiefly between developed and developing countries over opening up markets in financial and other service sectors and getting new rules to stop the piracy of patents and copyrights that occurs mainly in third-world countries.
Instead, the five days of a conference intended to wrap up a new agreement on opening up world trade degenerated into a spat between Washington and the Europeans over farm export subsidies.
These are the payments given to farmers to export surplus production at low world prices. The European Community is now subsidizing close to 25 million tons of food exports, and although this plays havoc with world trade, the community refused to meet demands to limit its subsidies. Hence the breakdown in the trade talks.
Washington had a powerful group of allies in 14 food exporting countries, known as the Cairns Group because they were organized in that Australian city. Those countries -- Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Fiji, Hungary, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Thailand and Uruguay -- have seen some of their markets wiped out by the subsidized competition.
Their stakes are illustrated by these numbers: in those 14 countries live about 240 million farmers, compared with 10 million in the European Community and fewer than 2 million in the United States. "For countries like mine," said Marcos Costrioto de Azambuja, leader of the Brazilian trade team, "going through a painful process of economic readjustment, international trade is the indispensable condition for this process to succeed." For the trade negotiations to succeed, the Europeans will have to make some concessions on the export subsidies.
Facing strong political pressure from their own farmers, it was unlikely that the Europeans would cede in the near future, thus throwing the future of the trade liberalization effort into doubt.
This could be dangerous for the world, triggering trade tensions that could lead to creeping protectionism and eventually trade wars. Protection breeds protection. Trade could spiral downward as it did during the 1930's, bringing economic decline and job losses to most countries of the world.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Bush Ventures South

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Those few norteamericanos who think about Latin America at all know that its nations have not been made safe for democracy by the collapse of the Soviet empire, by the two recent U.S. interventions in Nicaragua and Panama, or by the regional trend to free elections and free-market economies.
On his trip to five of those nations, President Bush made more headlines by his remarks on the Middle East than for anything concrete he offered or achieved. Still, if he had his eyes and ears open, he's bound to have come back to Washington with a heightened appreciation of Latin problems. 
 The most recent report of the Inter-American Dialogue, a high-level hemispheric forum, makes clear that the most pressing of these problems are economic. Since 1982, a debt-driven regional depression has cut per capita income in Latin America by more than 10 percent -- 25 percent in Peru and Argentina.
Aggregate foreign debt is $410 billion, nearly $100 billion more than in 1982, and requires a net annual outflow in interest and principal payments of about $25 billion -- or more than 20 percent of Latin American exports. Inflation and hyperinflation cripple the region. Infrastructure and industrial plant have deteriorated from lack of investment. Unemployment is up and wages are down, both drastically; housing, medical care and education have suffered in every country; crime is rampant in some.
In these circumstances, it's not surprising that 180 million Latins, 50 million more than in 1982, are living in poverty; that's two of every five people in the region. Only in Chile and Colombia have living standards risen -- though not by much -- in the last decade.
What can Mr. Bush do about any of this, with the U.S. also in an economic bind that's getting worse? The investment capital that Latin America needs is not readily available here; but Treasury Secretary Brady's debt-relief plan could be more flexible and the U.S. could write off some of its loans to Latin nations. Mr. Bush also might persuade U.S. banks to forgive some Latin debt, and he could influence multilateral lending agencies to be more lenient in debt rescheduling.
Most important, the President could work for -- not just talk about -- freer trade conditions in the U.S. and elsewhere, to open markets for Latin exports. That's doubly needed now, with recession in the U.S. likely to shrink imports.
One reason for Mr. Bush to take such steps is economic -- a more prosperous Latin America would provide badly needed markets for U.S. exports, thus helping to cut the trade deficit. Other reasons, as detailed in the Inter-American Dialogue report, are political and important to the hemisphere.
Sharp income disparities and endemic poverty, for one thing, are not conducive to political stability; the Shining Path in Peru and other insurgencies feed on economic inequity and depression. But free markets are not as immediately effective in reducing poverty as are, say, food subsidies, transfer payments, or public-sector jobs. If restive populations force governments too heavily into such programs, inflation and restricted economic growth would result -- making things worse economically, and probably causing the downfall of democratic governments not yet deeply rooted in Latin society.
Governments that stick to market economies and longer-term investments in health, education, and infrastructure are no doubt on the better road to higher living standards; but they will not quickly relieve Latin poverty. Even at a 5 percent growth rate -- unrealistic in most cases -- the Dialogue report estimates that "30 years or more would be needed to lift the poorest 20 percent of Latin Americans out of poverty." The slow pace of such reform also could bring popular reaction against democratic government and market economies.
The end of the cold war, however, casts a new light on Latin American affairs. Washington's exaggerated fear of Soviet penetration in the region, which brought so much grief to Chile, Guatemala, El Salvador and Nicaragua, is a dead letter; and Fidel Castro's problem in Cuba is no longer to spread revolution but to survive. Without cold war worries, moreover, the U.S. can more freely join with Latin America in coping with problems -- drugs, crime, immigration, trade and environment -- important to both.
Thus, the U.S. has a needed new chance to help build hemispheric stability, cooperation and economic growth, in its own as well as the Latin interest; and Mr. Bush's trip may be a better omen than his misguided intervention in Panama.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: How Iraq Ate and Armed at Our Expense

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Saddam Hussein was a good guy but is now a bad guy. The print media, however, do not explain our Government's flexibility in rewarding good guys while they remain good.
To explain: America's largess of grain can be given to any country of the President's choosing at negotiated interest rates, with as long as three years to pay, under the Commodity Credit Corporation Act.
Under this act, President Nixon enabled Soviet grain buyers to wipe out all of America's emergency wheat reserves in a single month of purchasing (July 1972). A sharp increase in United States food prices followed this gigantic grain on credit move. Mr. Nixon's detente with the Soviet Union had a price.
From 1983 to May 1990, Iraq received $4.3 billion in dollar-denominated credits to buy our grain under this act. The Iraqis got loans from banks, mainly in Italy. The loans were guaranteed by the Commodity Credit Corporation, which gets its funds from the Agriculture Department's $40-billion-plus annual budget, which is funded by the Treasury.
Saddam Hussein was careful never to default on the up-to-three-year loans. But the loans were continuously additive to the much-discussed Federal budget deficit, at least from one accounting year to the next. Getting American grain in this way permitted Mr. Hussein to spend less of Iraq's scarce hard currency on food from year to year and thereby spend more on his military buildup.
Loans from the Commodity Credit Corporation to Iraq were finally cut off by the Department of Agriculture about two months before the invasion of Kuwait, under Senate pressure on human-rights grounds led by Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato and Daniel K. Inouye.
 
BEVERLY KITCHING
Springfield, Ill., Nov. 29, 1990
 
The writer is a professor emeritus of economics at City College of Chicago.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 60; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Campus Life: North Carolina;
Finding It Hard To Say Goodbye To Chapel Hill

DATELINE: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.

 BODY:
Students at the University of North Carolina have long called their town the "Southern part of heaven," but recently many students have decided it is so heavenly that real life can wait.
Although the administration says it discourages students from prolonging their college years, the number of fifth-year seniors and those who remain in Chapel Hill after graduating is rising. 
 Of the entering freshmen in 1984, 19.2 percent graduated in five years, compared with 14.2 percent of those who entered in 1980, according to the university's Office of Institutional Research. And that does not include the students who graduated in four years but remain here.
While some students must extend their college years for financial reasons, and others because they studied abroad and need to complete graduation requirements, most students interviewed said they were staying longer because of the quality of life on campus and in Chapel Hill.
Many also said they were postponing having to look for a job in a tight labor market and dealing with a competitive world in general.
 
Parents Pay
 Christopher Smith of High Point is six hours short of graduating with a major in economics. Mr. Smith could have graduated over the summer had he taken one summer-school session. But he is worried about the tight job market and said he would rather wait a year than apply for jobs he does not want.
"I thought I'd hang around for as long as my parents will pay for it," he said. Tuition for 1990-91 is $1,084 for state residents, $5,752 for nonresidents.
"I love Chapel Hill," Mr. Smith added. "Where else do you want to live? I'm getting used to it."
What he is getting used to is three classes, or nine classroom hours, a week and a bartending job at a local restaurant, with some stints as a drummer for several bands. He spends much of his free time at his fraternity.
 
'Why Leave Chapel Hill?'
 "It was football season," said Kirk Stechmiller, a political science major from Gainesville, Fla., explaining his decision to prolong his college life, which is financed by Federal and state scholarships. His decision to extend his undergraduate studies, he said, was based on a desire to see a few more college football games. The Tar Heels won one of the 11 games they played last year.
"I want to enjoy the college atmosphere here," he said. "Why leave Chapel Hill?"
Jamie Block, who graduated last spring with a degree in English and is pursuing a career as a singer and a songwriter, said: "Chapel Hill is a pre-eminent music area that is pleasant to live in and affordable. Per capita, I don't know anywhere where there are more musicians."
Mr. Block, a native of Westhampton Beach, L.I., released his first album last spring and plays frequently in Chapel Hill's cafes and clubs.
"There are lots of people who get into original music here," he said. "This town has the tradition for taking risks as far as art goes."
Ian Williams, whose weekly humor column in the college newspaper made him a campus celebrity until he graduated last spring, said Chapel Hill was the perfect place to pursue a writing career. He is writing a fictional diary about the life of a college student while auditing classes in women's studies, English and religion.
Besides, said Mr. Williams, a music and psychology major from Arcadia, Calif., Chapel Hill makes him happy, "and if you want to write you have to be happy."
Mr. Williams also enjoys attending social events at his fraternity, where he has alumni status.
 
More Popular With Men
 Sally Kennedy, a senior international studies major from Atlanta, said she thinks men are more likely to remain at the school than women.
"I can think of three guys I know who have decided to stay," she said. "They thought they would have a good time if they stayed and could be with friends."
Susanne Huey, a senior German major from Charlotte, agreed, noting, "Men are so much more likely to prolong their college experience here because of the overabundance of women, whereas women are anxious to get out in the real world and meet men."
The ratio of female to male undergraduates at the university is 3 to 2, according to the Office of Institutional Research.
"Boys are in such a play-stage here," said Happy Hynes, a junior in political science from Charlotte.
Mark Pierce, an English major from Nashua, N.H., said he has taken the semester off to "hang out." He delivers pizzas to support himself. "Chapel Hill is the only place on earth where the waiters have Ph.D.'s and the homeless have master's," Mr. Pierce said.

For students entering in 1980, the comparable statistic was 72.2 percent (not 14.2 percent).

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Japan's Mythical Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
Bill Totten, an American, has lived in Japan since 1969. In 1972, he started a company in Tokyo called Ashisuto to sell American software to Japanese companies. Ashisuto now has sales of about $100 million a year. Earlier this year, Mr. Totten published a book in Japanese about American-Japanese relations called "Don't Blame Japan." Mr. Totten spoke with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times. 
 Q. Japan typically has trade surpluses with the United States in the range of $60 billion. But you have argued that in reality business between the two countries is in balance. What did you mean?
Mr. Totten: The American Government, in compiling its trade figures, uses statistics that exclude the production of American companies outside United States. For instance, I have a $4 million I.B.M. computer in my office in Tokyo. I thought it was American-made when I bought it. But I.B.M. executives in New York chose to manufacture my computer in Japan rather than in the United States. So the fact that I bought that computer in Japan is not included in the trade statistics. It wasn't exported; it was produced overseas.
Another example: I use a Schick razor every morning at my home in Tokyo. Seventy percent of Japanese males use Schick razors. But Schick, which is headquartered in Connecticut, sells razors in Japan that it makes in Hong Kong. So sales of those razors are not included in the trade statistics. They are not American exports.
 If you include the value of all American products sold to the Japanese versus the value of all Japanese products sold in America, you see they're roughly equal in dollar terms. That's why the statistics don't show that our two economies are really in balance.
Q. Critics of that argument say the existence of the trade balance nevertheless means foreign workers are displacing Americans. They also say American companies manufacture in Japan not because they want to but because Japan has been closed to imports. What do you say to the critics?
Mr. Totten: Well, my immediate reaction is that the American Government should talk to Mr. Akers at I.B.M. and ask him why he's not employing Americans to make the computers I buy in Japan. Why is he employing foreigners instead of Americans? Why beat up on the Japanese?
Q. But do you agree that Japan has put restrictions on some of the products America exports, like rice and specialty steel?
Mr. Totten: There are some specific incidents. But the metal thing was back about 10 years ago. And, yes, the rice thing is unfair. But we should remember that the Japanese are our best agricultural customer. We never mention that.
Q. You have been doing business in Japan since the early 1970's. How have you been accepted?
Mr. Totten: It is probably better to be an American doing business in Japan, than to be a Japanese doing business in Japan. Because I am an American, I've got special advantages. I might make a mistake in my manners or in the way I act, but as long as I'm not flaunting it or being deliberately rude, the Japanese are forgiving. They are much more forgiving of the foreigner than they are with each other.
Q. But so many companies complain that Japan is run like a club and Americans just can't get in. Have you found that to be the case?
Mr. Totten: Never. I've never heard of a person who speaks Japanese saying that.
I am fluent in Japanese. My wife and children don't even speak English. I conduct all my business and my home life in Japanese.
But most Americans trying to do business in Japan cannot speak the language at all. These Americans live in Tokyo in the equivalent of the Trump Tower and even though they are middle-level managers, they'll be chauffeured to and from their offices. These Americans will also spend all their time at the American Club or at the Foreign Press Club. They don't associate with the Japanese and they don't live in the Japanese consumer culture. If this is the case, how can they do business effectively?
Q. You have often criticized American software companies for being out of step with the Japanese markets. Is that still true?
Mr. Totten: I've changed my mind about that somewhat. The best-known American software companies -- the biggest ones that are very successful in the United States and other parts of the world -- tend to be arrogant or tend not to make their products fit the needs of the Japanese. They don't take that extra step. But lately, we have been finding a lot of smaller American software companies that are willing to make the effort. The small companies either customize their products for Japan -- which means adapting them to run on Fujitsu and Hitachi mainframes -- or they give us the manuscript and source codes so we can do it for them. They accept a 10 percent royalty. They let us do the pricing. They do everything needed to be successful in Japan. And we have picked up a number of products in the last six months from small American companies that previously didn't do any business overseas. It is our oldest suppliers, the biggest American software companies, that are not making the effort to expand in Japan.
Q. Do you run you business like an American company or a Japanese company?
Mr. Totten: Like a Japanese company. My total income from Ashisuto -- and I'm the founder, own 60 percent of the stock and am president -- is only eight times my average employee's salary. After taxes, my salary last year was only six times that of my average employee. That is typical of Japan.
What's typical in the United States? A ratio of about 93 to 1. And the people with that 93 to 1 ratio are not the company founders. They are the hired guns. Jim Mansey, chairman of Lotus, paid himself $17 million last year and fired 10 percent of his employees in August of this year. You see the difference? Jim Mansey is typical of American companies. That hurts them.
Why do I take only the amount of money I do? Because I run my company for the sake of our customers -- as the Japanese do. I don't run my company for the stockholders. But you know, what I am doing is no different from what I remember it was like in the United States when I grew up in the 1940's and 1950's.
I don't think the chief executive should make all the money. If he does, why would an employee work so hard? And my employees have lifetime employment. That's typical. In Japan employees get a very fair share. That is why they are more productive. And productive employees don't get shoved out the door as soon as profits take a downturn.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 16, 1990, Sunday

An article on the Forum page last Sunday, "Japan's Mythical Trade Surplus," rendered the name of the Lotus Development Corporation's chairman incorrectly. He is Jim P. Manzi.

HEADLINE: From Copland, the Gift of Complexity

BYLINE: By ARTHUR BERGER; Arthur Berger is a composer whose writings include "Aaron Copland," published by Oxford University Press in 1953 and reprinted by Da Capo.

 BODY:
Aaron Copland, who died last Sunday at the age of 90, had a reputation as a mild-mannered person, not at all given to the flares of temperament associated with musical genius. No more severe a test of his tolerance is imaginable than the evenings he spent as host to a certain small group of young composers in the 1930's. I became part of the group when I was brought to one of the gatherings by some classmates at New York University.
These were stormy sessions, highly vocal and rowdy, with sharp disagreements on matters of both musical esthetics and world politics. (I still have a postcard inviting me to a session, with "no polemics" scrawled on it in Copland's hand.) Copland somehow was above it all, and our shared devotion to him as our mentor kept us together for several years, during which time we became known as the Young Composers Group. 
 Having spent the early 1920's studying with Nadia Boulanger in Paris during the heyday of the boisterous Group of Six, Copland was delighted with the idea, and he fancied himself in the role of Erik Satie, who had been the central figure around whom that group revolved. But unlike Satie, Copland did not strongly influence the style of members of his coterie. Perhaps he had something to do with the Americanism of Elie Siegmeister, one member of the group. But one would be hard put to find his influence in the others: Bernard Herrmann, Jerome Moross, Vivian Fine, Henry Brant, Lehman Engel, Israel Citkowitz and Irwin Heilner.
The reason may very well be that Copland's style was too personal, so that while it can be readily imitated -- as is all too evident from the myriad television and Hollywood background scores that have done precisely this -- it does not provide an optimum point from which the composer may go on to a personal style. There are traces of a Coplandesque turn of phrase in some works of Leonard Bernstein, Irving Fine, Harold Shapero and even the early Elliott Carter. But it is hard to think of Copland, as one can so easily think of Schoenberg or the Neo-Classic Stravinsky, as a progenitor of a school.
Copland's influence -- and there surely has been one -- cannot be localized. It lies in the realm of such intangibles as sensitivity to the beauty and transparency of the musical surface, voluminousness that derives from the wide spacing of chords, and virtues like economy of means, honesty and directness.
From his own vantage point as a composer, Copland's highly recognizable musical profile stood him in good stead whenever he decided to shift course for various reasons -- among them always, a determination not to lapse into routine. First there was the abandonment around 1930 of his overt use of jazz in favor of a manner that sublimates it within what, it is now hard to believe, was considered a ferociously far-out austerity. Then there was the shift in the mid-30's -- back, in one sense, to the jazz-inspired period, but using folk songs instead of jazz in a special effort to reach a much larger audience than the limited modern-music audience for which he had been writing.
Finally in 1950 this paradigm of a diatonic composer surprised us all by announcing with his Piano Quartet that he had joined the hitherto enemy camp of the serialists. But through all these metamorphoses Copland's musical personality suffered not the least occlusion.
The transformations did, however, call down on him the wrath of some of his most ardent devotees. I spoke out against his simplification of music, which he undertook largely as a response to the pressures of the Federal Works Progress Administration and the leftist intellectual climate. I soon realized, however, that Copland was not writing down to the public, that he was employing some of the same craft and sensitivity that went into his masterly less accessible works.
At the same time, one of my worst fears has become a reality. The number of performances of the more popular works inevitably has had the effect of shutting the other music out. Indeed, some people are scarcely aware of that music's existence. When they learn about it, chances are they reason that since Copland's more popular works are so good at being what they purport to be, it is doubtful he would be capable of the profundity and complex musical thinking that go into the loftiest serious music. How misguided they are! One of the best ways in which tribute can be paid to this master of American music, our erstwhile dean of composers, is to encourage performers to pay more than token tribute to this relatively neglected portion of his legacy -- works like "Connotations" or even the problematic "Short Symphony."
Those who attacked Copland for his serialism may not be aware why it was appropriate for him to embrace the method in the 50's but not in the 30's. In the earlier period Copland was concerned with developing a distinctly indigenous idiom. At that time serialism transported to our soil maintained the aura of its Viennese origin. By the 50's it was liberated from its national affiliations, and as a neutral technique, it was adopted by Luigi Dallapiccola in Italy and Pierre Boulez in France. Presently Stravinsky joined the company. In all these cases, the Teutonic roots of the method, as in Copland's case, were no longer discernible as such.
Copland's stylistic shifts presented no problem to anyone who understood his personality, and I know of no more insightful analysis of this than the one advanced many years ago by Israel Citkowitz: "All in all, Aaron Copland is a most elusive personality. One could no sooner describe a particular quality than its opposite would appear to counter it. In a less well-balanced personality, these contradictions would create conflict and division. Copland can balance them, and, far from canceling out, these opposites complement each other and work together like well-meshed gears."
Who would ever have expected a Brooklyn-born composer passionately devoted to the New York scene to have so magnificently translated into musical terms the atmosphere of the American West? I remember an evening in August 1949 riding in a car behind one driven quite slowly by Copland on the way to his studio outside of Tanglewood. Suddenly a cow dashed into his headlights.
We rued the death of the poor animal and sympathized with Copland for the ordeal he had to endure at the hands of state troopers. But we were all terribly amused by the irony that this was the closest the composer of "Rodeo" had ever come to a cow.

HEADLINE: The Spirited and Erudite Oration That Could Fail

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
On Friday morning, Jack Valenti will rise before the members of the Federal Communications Commission at a hearing in Washington. Nattily attired, no doubt, with every strand of his silver hair in place, he will launch into a spirited and erudite oration in defense of the Federal regulations that govern the economic relationship between Hollywood's movie studios, which he has represented in the nation's capital for nearly 25 years, and the television networks.
His Texas twang will ring with conviction as he pleads with the commission not to abolish the regulations. If true to voluble form, he will quote philosophers and generals, cite statistics and rail against the power of networks and their corporate parents to dominate the airwaves. 
 Mr. Valenti, 69 years old, head of the Motion Picture Association of America, is widely regarded as one of the most effective lobbyists in Washington. Since being recruited to the motion picture trade in '66 from the White House, where he was a top aide to President Lyndon B. Johnson, he has by all accounts served as a tireless advocate for his constituency.
But on this issue, which centers on whether the networks should be allowed to share more in the often-lucrative proceeds studios receive from the sale of rerun rights to prime-time programs, he and the motion picture association are fighting a defensive action. Most industry executives expect the commission to loosen or eliminate the regulations, known as the Financial Interest and Syndication Rules, which restrict the ability of the networks to share in rerun revenues by strictly limiting their ownership of the shows produced for them by the studios. The commission hears arguments on Friday.
The debate illustrates how diverging business strategies and economic interests of the major studios have reduced Hollywood's clout in Washington. The issue nominally pits the big studios against the networks, but one of the studios, the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, now operates a network. Mr. Valenti has tried to frame the issue in terms of how much power the networks should be given over programming. But the recent acquisition of MCA Inc. by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Corporation of Japan, the fourth acquisition of a major studio by a foreign company in recent years, has shifted attention to whether foreign companies should be free to invest in and profit from businesses that the current regulations leave largely off limits to American networks.
This debate is not the only one in which Mr. Valenti has found his effectiveness stifled. After years of railing against concentration of ownership in the cable television business, Mr. Valenti and the motion picture association suddenly had to curtail their complaints last year when Warner Communications Inc., parent of Warner Brothers studio, merged with Time Inc., a major player in cable.
"When I first came in, I had the easiest job in the world, and I didn't realize it," Mr. Valenti said in a recent interview. "All we were concerned with was television and movies. I worked with a tightly bound group of companies, all with the same interests and motives. Now I've got companies that are moving into different interests and all of a sudden I'm being assaulted by problems and issues that never existed before."
An increasing amount of his time is spent on international trade. Entertainment may be the one business in which the United States retains worldwide dominance, and expanding foreign markets is a top priority for all studios. In Brussels recently, Mr. Valenti urged American trade negotiators to forestall efforts by France to limit imports to the European Community of American films and television shows.
Mr. Valenti is by no means the only person speaking for studios and producers in the current battle with the networks. Robert Daley, the head of Warner Brothers, is the lead negotiator for the studios, and the heads of most of the other studios will also make their case before the F.C.C. But Mr. Valenti has long served as the point man on the issue.
For the better portion of the last decade, he has been telling anyone who would listen that the Financial Interest and Syndication Rules are an essential safeguard for the studios and Hollywood's creative community against what he terms the "all-powerful" networks. If the networks are given greater freedom to own shows, he argues, there will be nothing to stop them from strong-arming producers into caving in on creative disputes and giving up a portion of the financial stake in a show in return for a crack at the network's airwaves
The networks see the situation very differently, of course. They argue that the rules, which were imposed 20 years ago, reflect an outdated view of the entertainment business. The reasoning behind the rules was primarily to prevent ABC, CBS and NBC from forcing producers to give up a portion of their ownership of a show -- a "financial interest" -- in return for the network putting it on the air.
But the networks argue that they no longer dominate broadcasting. On any given night, only about two-thirds of American homes with televisions on are watching one of the three networks, down from 90 percent in 1970. The networks face increasing competition from cable, independent stations and videocassette recorders, not to mention the studios and parent companies. Twentieth Century-Fox's network has become a serious rival on the two nights a week that it broadcasts head-on against ABC, CBS and NBC. Time Warner's HBO is a major force in entertainment. The networks say it is unfair for the studios to be able to compete on their turf without giving them a chance to profit from syndication.

MR. VALENTI won't give. "If this rule is abolished or shrunk, there will be no surcease for the networks," he said, unashamedly describing the matter as one of life and death. "They will own you -- dominate you."
For years, Mr. Valenti's public broadsides and private lobbying were highly effective. He seems to be on a first-name basis with half the members of Congress, many of whom regularly accept invitations to view a new film in the screening room of the motion picture association's headquarters near the White House. He opens the doors of Hollywood's executive suites to legislators hungry for campaign contributions and urges industry executives to become more involved in supporting candidates.
No incident did more to cement his lobbying reputation than his handling of an F.C.C. vote in 1983 to repeal the Financial Interest and Syndication Rules. The networks appeared to have won the day, but Mr. Valenti went right to Congress, skillfully exploited its fears of network economic power, and successfully lobbied for a bill that blocked the commission.
Today, the political winds are blowing against Mr. More than any other factor, the change is attributable to the growth in the foreign ownership of studios. The networks are making political hay by citing the increasing foreign control of Hollywood while the current regulations keep the networks from owning studios or participating in worldwide consolidation of the entertainment industry.
The situation does not seem to have rattled Mr. Valenti, who continues to operate at warp speed, as he has since his youth in Texas. Growing up in Houston, he got his first job at the age of 15, working, fittingly, as an usher in a movie theater. He went on to work in advertising at Humble Oil, to serve as a bomber pilot in World War II and then to get an M.B.A. at Harvard Business School.
HE went back to Houston and started an advertising agency. By the mid-50's, he had gotten to know and admire then-Senator Lyndon Johnson, wrote some speeches for him and became an unofficial adviser. On Nov. 22, 1963, he was riding in the motorcade in Dallas when President Kennedy was assassinated; within hours, the new President had "ordered" him to Washington. There, Mr. Valenti developed a reputation as a fierce loyalist, if not apologist, for his boss, and was widely mocked for a comment made in 1965: "I sleep each night a little better, a little more confidently because Lyndon Johnson is my President."
While at the White House, Mr. Valenti caught the eyes of several of the President's closest friends and advisers, among them Lew Wasserman, who was then and remains today the head of MCA. When the studios found themselves in need of a new head for their trade group in Washington, they quickly offered the job to Mr. Valenti -- after receiving permission from the President. Mr. Valenti, fascinated by the movie business, accepted, and has been at it since.
To the network Mr. Valenti is a constant annoyance, someone they are forced to take seriously even though many of them consider him little more than a loudmouth. But those for whom he works have high praise: "He's been ideal for the job and the job has been ideal for him," said Mr. Wasserman. "People always make fun of him for that thing he said about Johnson. But I once said to someone, and I mean it, that I sleep a little more soundly at night knowing that Jack Valenti is head of the motion picture association."
 
WHERE THE COSBY DOLLARS GO
 The Carsey-Werner Company has made hundreds of millions of dollars selling rerun rights to "The Cosby Show," one of the hit series it produces. But not a dime of the syndication profit has gone to NBC, which broadcasts the show's initial run. NBC has no actual ownership in "Cosby."
The network has made plenty of money on the show because of its high ratings, which translate directly into huge advertising revenues. But in the future, NBC, CBS and ABC want to to share in syndication windfalls.
Current regulations strictly limiting the ability of the networks to own shows or profit from syndication are key to the economics of the television business. Under the system, producers and studios make shows for less than the networks pay to air them -- usually hundreds of thousands of dollars per episode less -- in return for a chance at the windfall.
The studios say they are now willing to give the networks greater opportunities to own shows, within limits. But the networks, sensing that the rules may be abolished by the Federal Communications Commission, have been reluctant to agree to any compromise. The next few months may tell.

HEADLINE: New Haven Sends Needles Into the Battle Against AIDS

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
SONIA LUGO said the drug addicts were already waiting when she and two colleagues drove into the Hill section of New Haven the other day. While her two co-workers, Arthur Stewart and Dominick Maldonado, set up supplies in the back of their blue van, Ms. Lugo said, she walked down the street looking for new clients.
Before long, people began lining up to receive their condoms, hypodermic needles and packets of bleach. Mr. Stewart, meanwhile, counseled each one about ways to avoid contracting or transmitting sexual diseases and where to seek drug treatment. After the people dispersed, the three outreach workers drove to the Fair Haven section and repeated the process. 
 "We're on a rescue mission, all right," Ms. Lugo said recently as she and her colleagues restocked their van outside the office of the New Haven Health Department's AIDS division.
The mission began on Nov. 13, when the city started its needle-exchange program. It is intended to help reduce the spread of the AIDS virus by providing clean needles to intravenous drug users, who transmit the disease by sharing needles. It also aims to curb the city's drug-abuse rate by assisting addicts who wish to enter treatment programs.
 
Assistance From Yale
 Last spring, the legislature granted the pilot project an exemption from the state law that forbids the distribution of hypodermic needles without a prescription. The lawmakers have earmarked $25,000 for the program's supplies, and Yale University donated the van and is providing evaluation services.
New Haven has the highest AIDS rate in the state, with some 75 percent of the city's reported cases related to intravenous drug use, said a report issued by the Mayor's Task Force on AIDS. Dr. Patricia Checko, director of immunology in the AIDS section of the State Health Services Department, said that by October, the city had 341 of 1,825 AIDS cases reported in the state since 1980, followed by Hartford, with 302 cases, and Bridgeport, with 173.
The AIDS rate in the state's three largest cities also surpasses the national average, she said. Figures show 15 AIDS cases for every 100,000 people in the United States, she said, while New Haven has 56 cases for every 100,000 residents, Hartford has 65 cases, and Bridgeport has 29.
The needle-exchange program has received wide support from state and local officials, the New Haven Police Department and Mayor John C. Daniels.
The nation's first government-sponsored needle-exchange program began in New York City in 1988. It immediately ran into a political thicket, with one City Councilman comparing it to genocide of black and Hispanic people, who are a majority of the city's drug abusers. The program never enrolled more than about 300 people and was scrapped earlier this year by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Mayor Daniels said that as a State Senator, he opposed needle-exchange programs for fear they would encourage drug abuse. But he changed his mind, he said, after he was elected Mayor in 1989.
"This disease is running rampant," he said. "The city has one of the highest AIDS rates per capita in the country, and we have to do everything we can to stop it and its devastating effects." He said he has received dozens of phone calls from officials in cities throughout the nation asking about the program.
Opponents say that the pilot project is merely a stopgap that may eventually do more harm than good. Though it may stem the tide of AIDS, they say, the city does not have the resources or the drug-treatment openings to make the program effective.
"If this were a responsible client population, it might work," said Toni Harp, a New Haven Alderwoman and project coordinator for the Homeless Health Care Project at the Hill Health Center in the city. "But with addicts, the need for drugs outweighs any kind of responsibility."
Elaine O'Keefe, the director of the AIDS division of the New Haven Health Department, said that coping with the AIDS crisis is made more difficult by the myths about people who are addicted to drugs and have contracted the virus through needle sharing. She said that interviews with drug abusers over the past four years showed that they would use clean needles if they were available. "The reason drug addicts share needles is because of economics or fear of arrest," she said, "not because they are on a suicide mission or because sharing needles is part of some social ritual."
A new state-financed drug-rehabilitation program is scheduled to begin within the next month in the city, Ms. O'Keefe said, providing services for 75 addicts. She added that the outreach workers for the needle-exchange program are also assisting people through the bureaucratic maze of the drug-treatment system. Of the 100 people who have enrolled in the needle-exchange program so far, she said, 4 have begun drug treatment.
 
'No Stranger to These Streets'
 The program's advocates say that one of its strengths is its outreach workers, all veteran drug-abuse counselors who live in or near the neighborhoods they are trying to reach. They have been doing AIDS-prevention education in these areas for nearly four years.
"We're no strangers to these streets," said Mr. Maldonado, "which is why it's easy for us to pull up our van and strike up a rapport."
Both Mr. Stewart and Ms. Lugo said that they have undergone treatment for drug addiction, and that they are proof that it is possible to change an addict's behavior. Ms. Lugo, who served six months in the women's state prison in Niantic for a drug charge five years ago, said she has since returned as a social worker to talk to inmates about AIDS prevention and the effects of drug abuse.
"If an addict tells me that I have no idea what he's going through, I tell him that I've been there, and I do know the pain," said Ms. Lugo.
The outreach staff members said they have seen their share of friends, colleagues and clients die from AIDS. Because most of the disease's victims in New Haven are poor drug users, said Mr. Maldonado, "there's a growing indifference to the epidemic, which has made our job that much harder."
Given the nature and the urgency of the needle exchange and other AIDS-prevention measures, he and his colleagues often receive phone calls at home or visits from family members of addicts. "There is no way to leave AIDS at the office," he said.
 
Ficticious Names Used
 Four days a week, the team travels to several sites in the city noted for high drug traffic. An identification card is issued to everyone who enrolls in the program, but ficticious names are used to protect the addicts' privacy. Once they receive individual AIDS-prevention counseling and information on drug treatment, addicts are given condoms, five hypodermic needles and a packet of bleach with instructions on how to clean the needles once they are used.
Participants must return their used needles before they receive new ones. The workers place the returned needles in tin vials, which are stored in a plastic container. At the end of the day, the needles are taken to Yale for evaluation and disposal. A counselor is also on call at the AIDS division office to answer questions about treatment programs and other concerns.
Outreach workers are required to interview each participant every three months to determine if there has been a change in behavior. That information, along with the needle-return rates, will be analyzed and assessed by medical and management experts at Yale.
Dr. Don DesJarlais, director of research for the Chemical Dependency Institute at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York and an expert on needle-exchange programs in the United States and Europe, said early research has shown that programs in Amsterdam, London and Tacoma, Wash., reduced needle sharing and the risk of transmitting AIDS without increasing drug use.
"There is absolutely no evidence that these programs have any negative effects," he said. "They are also serving as an excellent referral source for getting people into drug-treatment programs."
Because of New Haven's high percentage of intravenous drug users who have been exposed to the virus, he said, its exchange program will be watched closely by health officials across the country. He added that there are five other similar programs in operation, as well as underground exchanges in several major cities.
But even in the program's early stages, said Ms. Lugo, residents of the city's drug-torn neighborhoods say that the program is having an impact. While canvassing the Hill section recently, she said, she was approached by a well-known drug dealer who cursed her and the program for taking away his customers.
"Let me tell you," she said with a proud smile, "that really made my day."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: DR. LEWIS MANDELL;
Boosting the Image of Financial Planners

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
DR. LEWIS MANDELL, a professor of finance at the University of Connecticut for 11 years, has started a couple of successful businesses and is a consultant to several corporations. Next spring, he will become the first editor of Financial Services Review. Its publisher, J.A.I. Press of Greenwich, said the review, with an initial circulation of 2,000, will attempt to give scientific credibility to the field of financial planning.
Several private organizations certify financial planners, but there are no government or academic standards for the field, said Dr. Mandell. He answered questions about the new journal and financial planning during a recent interview at his office in Storrs. Here are some excerpts from the conversation. 
 Q. Why do you view it as such a big step to launch this journal?
 A. There is no textbook in financial planning that treats it as an application of theory of finance. We need the textbook, we need basic research, we need the journal, and that's what we're doing. Once we have the journal going, the researchers in the field will say, "You know, it's now respectable to do work in financial planning." I predict that in 10 years this will be an academic field.
 Q. What kind of articles will be in the first issue?
 A. There is a very interesting article by Harry Markowitz, who won the Nobel Prize for finance recently. He won by being the first person to look at optimal portfolio construction. He didn't do it for an individual, and it's applied every day now by corporations, mutual funds, and institutional investors. What Markowitz did was he said, "How do we apply this theory to the individual?" We have a very useful methodology that everyone agrees is appropriate.
 Q. What kind of academic panel will be overseeing the Review?
 A. The group that formed has called itself the Academy of Financial Services. You have to call yourselves something, and we all know what we're interested in. But we did not want to have "financial management" in the name of the organization or the journal because of the generally low esteem in which financial planning has been held.
 Q. Why?
 A. Because it has very little basis in science. It's almost like medicine -- if a group of people claim to have a new kind of medicine, but they have no medical training, they have never taken anatomy or biochemistry, I'm not sure how many physicians would want to be associated with them.
 Q. Is there any way of telling if you're getting good financial planning advice?
 A. What you can do is go and get a second opinion, or a third or fourth opinion, and see the degree of variance between them. In choosing a financial planner, it's important to choose someone who has had a good education, who has studied a fair amount in finance.
 Q. How do you choose a planner?
 A. You want to make sure, first of all, that the planner knows finance, that he is not going to give you an absolutely wrong answer on a relatively simple question. Secondly, make sure that person is really up on what is happening in the economy. Can that person talk about what is happening in Hungary, and how the situation in Czechoslovakia is going to impact upon us?
 Q. What recourse do people have if they get bad financial advice?
 A. Really none. They're afforded little protection by law. In fact, I would say they're afforded literally no protection.
A financial planner is supposed to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission as an R.I.A., registered investment adviser. But to do that all you have to do is pay a fee of a couple of hundred dollars and fill out a form. I can say, "I'm a registered investment adviser, registered with the S.E.C." And people say: "Wow, that's super. You're certified by the S.E.C." But there is no certification involved.
The same thing is true of states. There are a few states that make you pass a little exam, but it's really a compliance exam, to make sure you know the laws pertaining to giving advice, not to certify whether you are qualified to give advice.
Anyone can do it. I think even if you're a convicted felon, you can do it from jail.
Q. What about recourse in civil courts?
A. It isn't going to be very long before the lawyers will start to get involved. Anyone who gives advice is expected to know the current state of the art in the field. There have been a lot of lawsuits when pension funds didn't use state-of-the-art finance techniques, and those suits were successful.
 Q. Can you give an example of the type of bad advice you might get from an untrained financial planner?
 A. One of the questions most asked financial planners today is: "I just inherited enough to pay off my mortgage. Should I do it?" They usually will ask about the interest rate on the mortgage, and it might be 10 percent. Then they ask how much you can get for the money in the bank, and the answer might be 8 percent. So the answer appears pretty simple -- you're better off paying off the mortgage. It turns out that answer is wrong, and it's wrong for reasons most financial planners wouldn't know, because they don't study it.
A very contemporary issue in finance is option-pricing theory. Financial planners think an option is something you buy if you want to lose all your money. But suppose you have a 30-year mortgage at a fixed rate of 10 percent. That mortgage has some valuable features, and one of them is that if interest rates go up, the bank cannot charge me more than 10 percent, but if they go down to 8 percent I can refinance. That gives me, in essence, what's called a put option on that, and that's very valuable. To tell someone to give that up is having them give up something that's worth thousands and thousands of dollars.
 Q. What are your own financial planning achievements?
 A. Ever since I've been in the profession, I've been writing books. I have been doing consulting. I'm an inventor with a number of products out there. I have businesses that I have started, and I have other people selling products for me. But that is a very interesting question, and it's a question of what I do with my own assets.
One thing I am not doing is buying Connecticut real estate. We had a fair amount of money in money-market funds, but now we read that the reason some of those funds were paying such high rates is they had a lot of money in junk commercial paper. The first big money-market fund that goes down is going to topple the others. Recently, I bought Connecticut municipal bonds.
 I'm not always my own best financial planner. I'm not always moving my assets around as quickly as I advise people to do so. But things I believe in, I am at least moving in those directions.
 Q. What kind of returns should you expect from investments these days?
 A. Your risk-free rate of return is the Treasury bill, which has been in the range of 7 or 8 percent, which is free of state income taxes. And if you can't do better than that, you really aren't trying.
 In terms of how you allocate your assets, there is an interesting discussion going on among financial planners. Financial planning is not just finance. It's a combination of finance and psychology. If we have a portfolio we're running for a corporation or mutual fund, we will try to invest some of it in liquid assets, and the rest of it, maybe 80 percent, in index funds, depending on how much risk you want to take.
But look at an individual family, and look at how they choose to hold their money. They are not doing it the way we in finance say they should be doing it. Rather, people are earmarking funds for specific purposes and holding funds in vehicles that match those needs.
If I have a kid who's going to college in five years, I probably don't have those funds in a risky investment, because the time is getting close. If the kid was 2, I might be willing to take more of a risk, because I've got more time.
 Q. Will this journal be giving actual financial planning advice?
 A. No. You really can't begin by giving people advice; you have to begin with theory. There is a tremendous amount known in finance and economics and theory, but there is not a great deal of linkage. The people who call themselves financial planners don't necessarily have a great deal of training. Many of them have never had a course in finance, believe it or not.
 Q. Has there been any improvement in the way financial planners are trained?
A. Certification was originally issued by the College of Financial Planning in Denver, which was a proprietary institution founded by a bunch of financial planners. Initially -- and still, in fact -- you send them some money, about $1,500, and they send you some books to study, and you take a test. If you pass the test, you get certification.
But of course, the test reflects the way the industry was set up, around the notions and beliefs of a few people who got together and began doing the certifying. A few years ago, a university in the New York area wanted to start certifying financial planners. There was an antitrust suit against the College of Financial Planning, and the settlement involved the formation of the International Bureau of Standards for Certified Financial Planning.
They represent a bright spot on the horizon, maybe the only bright spot. They have been trying to make financial planning into a respectable field. They have been trying to get colleges and universities around the country to offer the courses needed for financial planning.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Lewis Mandell, a professor at UConn, will become the first editor of Financial Services Review next spring. (Ron Waters for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hard Times Give Subways a Reason to Streamline Service

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is ironic how the New York City Transit Authority reaches for the wrecking ball on transit services at the first sign of recession (news article, Nov. 16) when public transportation is the most economical and environmentally efficient means of moving people.
Instead of proposals that doom round-the-clock buses and trains, which are the lifeblood of New York's 24-hour-a-day existence, the Transit Authority should use the downturn to complete renovation work on the subway system at lower-than-boom-time prices. It should also find ways to streamline its operations and improve services, such as consolidating the myriad local private subsidized bus lines under its operations planning, so that all buses will go where and when the public goes.
Questionable projects pushed during the good years, such as the 63d Street connector to the IND subway lines under Northern Boulevard, could be re-examined. Cheaper proposals to accomplish roughly the same objectives, such as building a transfer station on the new subway alignment under the Queens Boulevard station should be looked at.
The Transit Authority can take its renovation work, integrated bus system and subway improvements and aggressively market its services as recession-proof transportation, compared with the much more costly private automobile and taxis. In view of the Federal Clean Air Act mandate on New York City to cut back on smog, this approach would also be environmentally wise and pay off in the long run, getting more people out of private transportation and into public transit.
 
BRENDAN B. READ
Deputy Chairman, N.Y. Task Force
Committee for Better Transit
Long Island City, Queens, Nov. 23, 1990

HEADLINE: Gulf Analogy: Munich or Vietnam?

BYLINE: By Alexander M. Haig Jr.; Alexander M. Haig Jr., Secretary of State from 1981 to 1982, was Supreme Commander of NATO from 1975 to 1979.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
International conflicts attract historical analogies the way honey attracts bears, because the "lessons learned" from such analogies are supposed to help us avoid past mistakes. The Persian Gulf crisis is no exception, and two analogies in particular -- Munich and Vietnam -- might have something to tell us.
The first, more familiar to older Americans, is Munich -- the story of the disastrous appeasement of Hitler, redeemed later only by horrible loss of life in a terrible war. The second, more familiar to younger Americans, is Vietnam -- the story of disastrous American military involvement, never redeemed despite its costs. 
 Which analogy, Munich or Vietnam, the 1930's or the 1960's, has more to tell us?
Munich symbolized the failure of the international community to defend basic values: freedom, sovereignty, the settlement of conflict without resort to force. Throughout the 1930's, Japan, Italy and Germany successfully challenged those values.
Spurious historical claims, geopolitical "interests," ethnic and racial theories were invoked by aggressors to justify their conquests. Victims included both neighbors, such as Czechoslovakia or Manchuria, and distant lands, such as Ethiopia.
That some of the states conquered were primitive or, in any event, remote from the concerns of the democracies were facts used by the aggressors and their apologists to argue that their actions "did not matter" or did not "affect vital interests." But each conquest strengthened the aggressors until finally vital interests were unambiguously threatened.
Yet, the important difference between 1935 and 1939 was that the military power of the aggressors grew. When war ultimately became the only effective means of resistance, the odds did not favor the defenders of freedom, and the costs in blood and national treasure mounted dramatically.
Saddam Hussein and Iraq fit important parts of this metaphor. His stated reasons for assaulting Kuwait are spurious history, a claim of economic necessity and a vaulting ambition to "lead" the Arabs. These are excuses he can use over and over again to justify further aggression.
Like Nazi Germany, Saddam Hussein's Iraq can only enjoy the benefits of its conquest if the international community acquiesces. Armed with the benefits of aggression, including oil, Iraq will surely be much the stronger, much better able to buy and perfect the weapons of mass destruction that its leader craves.
In short, the appeasement of Saddam Hussein, like that of his forebearers in the 30's, would favor a greater crisis later and enlarge Iraq's capability to prevail in such a crisis. Saudi Arabia, Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, possibly Egypt, surely Israel, would be drawn one by one into either submission or conflict.
After an Iraqi victory in the gulf, it is all too easy to foresee the U.S. and Israel standing together against a hostile Iraq-led Arab world. It is almost as easy to see Israel standing alone against an international coalition intent on forcing it to take actions against its vital interests, the better to avoid a test of strength with Saddam Hussein and the Arabs. In short, a real Munich.
The Munich metaphor, however powerful its appeal, must compete with another striking American memory: Vietnam. The Vietnam metaphor appeals to two very influential groups, the moralists and the pragmatists.
The moralists saw Ho Chi Minh's Vietnam as a victim of imperialism; some also condemned the war as illegal because it had never been declared by Congress. But both will find Iraq hard to fit into these categories.
No one seriously suggests that Saddam Hussein is a misunderstood victim rather than a willful criminal. And as for the legalities, the worst distortion of the Vietnam metaphor is to believe that a declaration of war would have mattered. The Tonkin Gulf Resolution served well until the war went badly. A declaration of war would have been overtaken by the same loss of popular support.
The same would apply in the gulf crisis. Prompt military success or failure, not a Congressional declaration or lack thereof, will determine the decisive level of popular support. Prudent and meticulous consultation, rather than endless uninformed debate and authorizing votes makes far better sense.
It is not misplaced morality or misunderstood legalism that matters most but a far more potent Vietnam metaphor: success or failure. Today, most Americans remember U.S. policy in Southeast Asia as self-defeating. It was a war without clear political purpose or definable military objective.
Most Americans eventually joined this pragmatic group, forcing the U.S. to withdraw. Their question today is, Do we have a gulf policy with clear and justifiable purpose? If we go to war, is there a definable and achievable end?
The President has in fact defined clear purposes: unconditional Iraqi withdrawal; restoration of the legitimate Kuwait Government; protection of American lives, and peace and stability in the gulf.
He has justified these demands on several grounds: the stakes for international peace in the post-cold-war period; the danger that Iraq might lead the gulf and the Middle East into even greater conflict later and the dangers to the international economy of Iraqi domination of the oil supply. And he has said that the conflict can be resolved peacefully if Iraq cares to do so -- that is, resolved in accordance with the Security Council resolutions, not through so-called "partial solutions" that reward Iraq for its aggression.
Some "pragmatists" are troubled by the thought that this leaves no face-saving way for Iraq to get out. But we have no reason to help Saddam Hussein unless we believe that by doing so we avoid something worse, such as war. But if we believe that Saddam Hussein eventually must be rewarded to avoid war, then our current military efforts are essentially a bluff and that bluff will be called. Such a display of strategic ineptitude would certainly bring evil consequences for our friends and interests throughout the region and beyond.
If war comes, is there a definable military objective? Here is where the Vietnam analogy does offer a valid lesson. When purposes are clear, means must serve them. If we are forced to military action, we must know that to expel Iraq from Kuwait and to assure the peace in the gulf, we will have to destroy Iraq's capacity to make war.
We should not accept the fallacy that because we want Iraq out of Kuwait, the war should be confined to Kuwait. Nor should we succumb to a war fought by degrees in the belief, as in Vietnam, that a few good men, big ships and loud noises will frighten the culprits.
War, Clemenceau said, is too serious to be left to the generals. By that he meant that military force must be governed by the ends to which it is applied. The Vietnam codicil is that war is also too serious to be left to the politicians. By that I mean that when ends are set, the military forces available must be used in a professional and decisive way.
Thus, the Munich and Vietnam analogies both have application to the gulf but not exactly as many would use them. The Munich analogy teaches us not that Saddam Hussein is already a Hitler but that we must act now to prevent him from becoming one. The Vietnam analogy instructs us not that we should refrain from using force but that if our purposes are just and clear, we should use it decisively.
Perhaps if this is well understood in Washington, it may be understood well enough in Baghdad for Saddam Hussein or someone else to abandon this aggression without war.

HEADLINE: MOMBASA JOURNAL;
A Port Waits With Open Arms for U.S. Sailors

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOMBASA, Kenya, Dec. 6

 BODY:
This muggy port town, which for centuries shipped decorative elephant tusks to maharajahs and rhino horns to keep the sultans in aphrodisiacs, is awaiting the revival of a more modern kind of trade.
Expectancy hangs along the narrow walks of the Arab old town and the wide boulevards of modern Mombasa: When will the sailors from the United States armada now serving in the Persian Gulf alight for rest and recreation? 
 "I've asked the consulate to inform us," said Daniel O. Owino, the manager of Kenya Breweries, who has seen American aircraft carriers come to Mombasa in the past and is relishing the prospects of stepped-up visits because of the gulf crisis.
"The sailors drink a lot of Tusker premium," he said, referring to one of his company's products. Extra bottling capacity has to be arranged at the brewery to accommodate the 1,000 extra cases a day that he said are consumed when the ships come in.
 
The Logical Spot
 Whether the Navy comes to Mombasa is not yet a certainty but seems a good bet.
"Say the gulf situation ended and the Navy was not needed, they would go home," said the United States consul here, Donald E. Stader. "But if they keep the ships up there, people will be rotated through here. I think you can assume we will get ships."
Geographically, Mombasa is the logical spot for the American ships in the gulf to take a reprieve. North of here, where Islamic conservatism prevails, there is nothing with beer and sex. Southward, economically deprived Dar es Salaam in Tanzania and war-torn Maputo in Mozambique do not carry the same appeal.
For the last decade, Washington has had the right to use Mombasa, the biggest port in eastern Africa north of Durban in South Africa, for the support of military operations and for troop rest and recreation. The agreement signed with Kenya in 1980 was based on the idea that military access to Kenya was useful while Iran and Iraq were at war and the Horn of Africa was a theater of the cold war.
But in the last several years, as the strategic importance of Ethiopia and Somalia dwindled and the Iran-Iraq war wound down, ship visits here have dropped, with only one so far this year after a high of 29 visits in 1985. Thus the appetite for more port calls is high, even in the era of AIDS when African women have found American sailors a little more reluctant.
 
Caution Is the Word
 "The ladies come all the way from Zaire to come and enjoy," Mr. Owino said. "The Americans are big spenders. With the AIDS scare, the girls still come, the men entertain them."
But in fact locals said many of the women who have traveled in the last several years by train from Nairobi, the Kenyan capital, and Uganda and Zaire for American ship arrivals have left disappointed. Before shore leave, the sailors are rigorously briefed about the high incidence of AIDS in Africa and its transmission on the continent by heterosexual sex, Mr. Stader said.
The eagerness for ship visits should not leave the impression that Mombasa, which with about 600,000 people is Kenya's second largest city, is hurting. The opposite is the case. Its equatorial heat seasonally air-conditioned by monsoon winds, its pale, fine sands, its easy mix of Arabs and Africans and its rather exotic history have made Mombasa a haven for package-tour holidaymakers from Europe. While a few days of riots in Nairobi in July deterred some safari-going tourists, Mombasa is a world apart from the highlands, savannah and deserts of Kenya. Mombasa hoteliers report their sprawling establishments along the beachfront have been full all year.
 
Still an Islamic Town
 One of the favorite hangouts for the American sailors when they have come in the past, the waterfront Florida Nightclub, where a large seawater swimming pool extends from the red velour-walled disco, is filled these days with German vacationers.
Until the Portuguese arrived in 1497 and Vasco da Gama cast an imperial eye over the town, Mombasa was a thriving Arab center and slave trading port. The Portuguese used the place as a provisioning station for caravels bound for India and built the now-decrepit Fort Jesus to defend the harbor from Arabs sailing in on dhows from the Red Sea. The Omanis pushed the Portuguese out; then finally the British took over. Now about 60 percent of the population is African, about 30 percent Indian and about 10 percent Arab.
Mombasa remains a predominantly Islamic town, with the sight of women in black chadors common. But it is a moderate kind of Islam -- some call it "the old Beirut type of Islam" -- and on a recent day two young women could be seen stripping off their religious cloaks, revealing T-shirts and bare legs, and stepping into the ocean for a cooling dip.
For the United States, the Mombasa consular office has always been a remote war post. It opened in 1915 during World War I, when Washington was the protecting power for German missionaries in the region. A dozen years later, the office closed but reopened for World War II. It shut down again in 1952 and reopened in 1981 as a backstop for the Iran-Iraq war. The nearly 20 United States Navy personnel stationed at the port left in 1988, but with the present situation in the gulf, the recently arrived Mr. Stader said, the American outpost on the African coast is staying in business.
