HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Way of Betting On a '95 Oil Price

BYLINE: By Matthew L. Wald

 BODY:
WHILE the world pays close attention to daily changes in the price of oil, a deeper question for the oil industry and the economy is the long-term outlook for prices. What will a barrel of oil cost in five years, after the Persian Gulf crisis has presumably been resolved and any war damage has been repaired?
A relatively new financial instrument, the Salomon Phibro Oil Trust, represents a sort of popular projection of the 1995 oil price. Four units of the trust represent one barrel of West Texas Intermediate oil -- or, more practically, the price of one barrel -- in September 1995. At that time, Phibro will acquire four million barrels, auction them and split the proceeds among the holders of the 16 million units. 
 When the trust came on the market on Aug. 24, three weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait, units sold for $4.65 each. On Friday, they closed at $3.25, down 12.5 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.
Philip C. Verleger, the commodities market expert at Charles River Associates, a consulting firm based in Boston, pointed out recently that buyers of the units do not expect a price per barrel of four times the share price (or $13 on Friday); they are expecting a gain, in exchange for the use of their money for the intervening years. Assuming a cost of money of 12 percent, the share price implies a 1995 price in the neighborhood of $24 a barrel. Such a figure, Mr. Verleger said, would be "strikingly low," especially since it represents the price after inflation has taken its toll. Many other oil experts agree, although with global production capacity and inventories rising, a price crash after the crisis is resolved could also be envisioned.
Anyone with a little cash on hand who thinks theprice in mid-decade will be above the mid-$20's could place a bet by buying units of the Phibro trust; if the sale price in 1995 exceeds $24, the buyer's return would exceed 12 percent. An investor who wanted to place the opposite bet, that prices would be even lower, might buy stock in a company that prospers when prices are low, like a refiner and marketer of petroleum products.
In the oil markets, five years is almost forever. In 1981, for example, when oil prices were near record highs after the revolution in Iran, almost no one foresaw the price collapse of 1986. And no one was predicting that year that Iraq would invade Kuwait in 1990, causing oil prices to double in a few weeks.
Before the invasion, oil analysts pointed out that the world's surplus capacity lay almost entirely within OPEC's control and was dwindling as demand rose. This situation was a recipe for significant price increases in the mid-90's, they said.
The chief economist of the Amoco Corporation, Theodore Eck, predicted before the events of the last five months that oil would sell for $25 in the mid-1990's. "I don't see that anything's happened to change that forecast," he said last week.
Independent of Saddam Hussein, he said, the world's largest and third-largest producers (the Soviet Union and the United States) are going through rapid declines in production, and the Persian Gulf (home of the second-largest, Saudi Arabia) still has the great bulk of the known, easy-to-pump oil. "Price is going to continue to be a function of the leading countries in OPEC: Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iran and Iraq," he said. "Thosefour determine what the price is."
Those countries were successfully raising prices before the invasion, he said. And if the crisis over Kuwait has had any effect, it is to raise the revenue requirements of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq; Iran was already hard pressed for money.
At the First Boston Corporation, William Randol, who follows the oil market and oil stocks, said that the recent price shock had helped slow the economies of various nations, depressing demand, but that overall demand was still growing. He predicted a price above $30. Last month, Texaco Inc. predicted prices rising two to three percentage points above inflation; inflation of 4 percent, Mr. Randol said, would yield a price of $27.75 in 1995.
Norman P. Higby Jr., an analyst in Menlo Park, Calif., laid out a different projection. Saudi Arabia, already a partner with Texaco in a joint venture for refining and marketing that covers the Eastern United States, would expand that effort nationwide and provide gasoline cheaply, to gain market share. Others, he said, would have to follow with low product prices to stay competitive, lowering the value of crude. Prices would be volatile, he said, ranging from $15 to the high $20's or $30.
Thomas R. McHale, an energy economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said he saw China becoming an importer instead of an exporter, and Soviet production falling sharply. Outside the Middle East, he asked, "where else do we have any great potential for expansion of oil production?"
His forecast implies a higher price, but he added that many analysts underestimate the long-term capacity of countries facing higher prices to use less. He would not speculate on a 1995 price.
And the completely unforeseen is always a possibility. At Bear, Stearns & Company, William E. Byers, a futures expert, warned that in oil, copper, soybeans or any commodity, projections made by extrapolating current conditions and inflation rates are seldom accurate. His bottom line on 1995 has a ring of sincerity to it. "I have no clue," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Full-Point Cut in Rates Is Urged

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Can the Federal Reserve Board rescue the economy? Many credit market analysts believe it can, but that it will need to push down interest rates by at least a full percentage point, much further than currently forecast.
Over the last two months, as evidence of an economic slowdown grew, the usually cautious Fed has apparently realized that increasingly radical steps may be needed to avert a deep recession. During that span, the central bank lowered the Federal funds rate -- the interest on overnight loans between banks -- three times, to 7.25 percent. It also eliminated a reserve requirement on some commercial bank deposits, which made more money available for lending. 
 The Fed can do more, and probably will. After the extremely weak November employment report on Friday, many economists are expecting that the Fed this week will lower its discount rate, currently at 7 percent, by half a percentage point. The discount rate is what the Fed charges banks for loans. A further drop to 7 percent in the Federal funds rate is also a distinct possibility before the end of the year, they added.
 
Response to Jobs Data
 Last week, credit market participants responded to the employment report and the Fed's easing move by pushing short-term Treasury bill rates to below 7 percent and pushing down yields on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds to 8.14 percent.
But over the next few months, many analysts said, both short- and long-term rates will need to fall another full percentage point in order to turn the economy around.
"We went in to this recession with seemingly neutral interest rates," said Robert J. Barbera, an executive vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers. "We had a bank-induced credit crunch with no rise in interest rates because people changed their minds about what constituted a safe loan. To make lending safe again you will need much lower rates."
The employment report, which showed that 267,000 workers lost jobs last month and that 5.9 percent of the civilian work force was idle, forced economists to recalculate their fourth-quarter growth projections. Based on the first two months of the period, analysts now say the economy could shrink by 2 percent to 5 percent in the quarter.
"My guess is the Fed was shocked by the data," said Alan Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. "Last week, they seemed aware that we were in a recession, but not one that is as sharp and sweeping as the employment data suggest."
 Pressure of Huge Debt
 The huge amounts of debt accumulated by corporations and consumers during the 1980's -- obligations that crimp profitability and limit future spending -- are a large reason why interest rates may have to fall much further to pull the economy out of recession, the analysts said.
"Can monetary policy stimulate the economy?" Marcos Jones, an economist at the Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation, asked in a weekly letter to clients. "The available evidence suggests that it will not do so quickly, especially if the gradual approach to rate reductions prevails."
Three regional banks responded last week to the Fed's most recent easing move by lowering their prime lending rates by a quarter of a percentage point, to 9.75 percent. But large money-center banks, which lend huge amounts of money based on the prime rate, will probably react much more slowly to the Fed's lead than in the past because their balance sheets are in sorry shape. Now, by keeping the prime rate where it is, these banks will be able to increase profits as their borrowing costs decline.
Moreover, it is doubtful that consumers, who account for two-thirds of all economic activity, are in a position to increase their spending much even when prime-based consumer loan rates do fall, Mr. Jones and other analysts said.
 
Unique Conditions
 In contrast to past downturns, the current recession is beginning with consumer balance sheets that are substantially overleveraged, a decline in housing prices that has eroded household wealth and a slowing in income growth.It will take time, and much lower rates, to reverse those trends, the analysts said.
"The reluctance of banks to extend credit is a new nuance that you have to allow for," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "And while the consumer malaise perhaps won't get much worse, it is not improving."
Consumers did not do much to pull up the economy in November, economists estimate. Based on most forecasts, retail sales figures expected on Thursday will show that sales dropped by as much as 1 percent last month, compared with a meager one-tenth of a percentage point increase in October.
Aside from the retail sales report, analysts said, signs of much lower inflation should be apparent in November producer price figures, due out Friday.
In advance of the report, the consensus forecast is calling for an increase of about a tenth of a percentage point in the producer price index.
 
Focus on New York
 Attention in the municipal bond market will be focused on New York City. On Wednesday, the city is expected to sell $1.17 billion worth of tax-free and taxable securities, the largest debt offering in the city's history.
In an effort to market the new securities and dispel investor worries about the city's financial prospects, underwriters and city officials held a two-day conference in late November with prospective investors.
Concerns about the future abound, and investors continue to seek haven in higher quality issues. Nevertheless, many market participants said the market premium currently charged for New York City securities, compared with that for other municipalities with a similar debt rate, makes it likely the sale will go well.
Late last week, outstanding New York City issues were offered at a price to yield around 8.6 percent, a full percentage point higher than other A-rated credits.
Ratings of A from Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A- from the Standard & Poor's Coroporation are expected.
"With all the recession talk, the market is in pretty good shape," one municipal-bond trader said. "And with yields on outstanding city paper at those levels, I don't think they will have that big of a problem."

HEADLINE: Cut by Fed In Discount Rate Seen

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
As part of its next step to ease credit conditions, the Federal Reserve Board will probably lower the discount rate, the interest rate that banks pay when they borrow from the central bank.
In interviews last week, Fed officials said a consistent monetary policy would require a reduction of the discount rate, which has remained at 7 percent for almost two years, if the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other for loans, continues to be driven down by the Fed. 
 "We would be reluctant to move the funds rate under the discount rate," said a top official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. He reflected current thinking at the central bank that the Fed would lose a dimension of control over interest rates if banks could borrow more cheaply from each other than from the central bank.
 
Threats to the Economy
 On Friday, in recognition of the weakness in the economy, the Fed allowed its target for the Federal funds rate to fall to 7.25 percent from 7.5 percent. It was the third time in the last two months and the fourth time since July that the funds rate had been lowered.
The prevailing view of economists is that the threat of recession has become so serious that further drops in the funds rate are likely soon. This would put more pressure on the Fed to cut the discount rate, a move that would be viewed in the financial markets as a signal of a significant easing of monetary policy.
"The markets would interpret it as a very clear statement of a very aggressive Fed policy," said Robert H. Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank in New York.
 
Full-Point Cut Urged
 Indeed, many credit market analysts believe the Fed will need to push down interest rates even more than currently forecast, possibly by as much as a full percentage point over the next few months, to rescue the economy. [Page D7.]
Almost all current statistics show that the economy has slipped into a recession. The most recent gloomy news came Friday when the Government reported that 267,000 jobs had been lost in November and that the civilian unemployment rate had climbed to 5.9 percent, its highest level in more than three years.
With this year's budget deficit expected to exceed $250 billion, the largest ever, measures like tax cuts and spending increases that have been used to counteract past recessions are virtually out of the question now. This means that encouraging more bank loans, by lowering interest rates, is the only tool the Government has to turn the economy around.
If banks increase their lending, consumers and businesses have more money to spend and invest, and that should lead to economic growth. But changes in interest rates take six to nine months to work their way through the economy. So steps taken by the Federal Reserve now could have little effect on economic conditions in the first half of next year, but they might help by summer.
Eventually, the Fed's actions should make some borrowing less expensive for consumers, lowering the rate for home mortgages and automobile loans, for example. But credit card rates are less influenced by the markets and probably will fall little if it all.
Until last week, the Fed's easing had not affected commercial interest rates; the prime rate remained stuck at 10 percent. But on Friday, a few regional banks reduced this rate, the benchmark for many commercial and personal loans, to 9.75 percent, and others may follow this week.
In addition to cutting the Federal funds rate, the central bank took an unusual step last week to improve bank profits and reduced the amount that banks were required to hold in reserve in cash or interest-free accounts. This was a move to provide banks with more money to lend.
The reserve requirement, the Federal funds rate and the discount rate are the only three elements of the Fed's monetary policy.
 
Symbolic Reduction
 The effect of a reduction in the discount rate would be more symbolic than direct. Few banks now are using the discount window, the term the markets use for borrowing from the central bank, and instead are borrowing from other commercial banks.
Changes in the Federal funds rate are accomplished by the Fed's buying or selling Government securities in the open market, and the change is not announced. But a change in the discount rate must be accompanied by a statement of the central bank's policy and an announcement of the vote by which the Federal Reserve Board decided to act.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, prefers to act discreetly and views a change in the discount rate as a blunt instrument that should be avoided. The rate was last changed in February 1989, when it was raised to 7 percent from 6.5 percent.
Still, if the Federal funds rate comes down further, a step most economists view as inevitable in light of the poor economic conditions, it would probably force the Fed to reduce the discount rate as well.
 
'An Unstable Situation'
 The last time the Federal funds rate dropped below the discount rate was for a brief period in 1980. At the time, Henry C. Wallich, then a member of the Federal Reserve Board and a highly respected economist, said: "When the Federal funds rate falls below the discount rate, there is no clear definition of where the Federal funds rate should be because it's no longer supported by the discount rate. On a given day, it could fall to zero. So if you don't lower the discount rate, you get quite an unstable situation."
Normally, when the discount rate is changed, it is done by at least half a percentage point. Albert M. Wojnilower, a senior economist at the First Boston Corporation, said that if the central bank reduced the rate by a full point, it would be unmistakable evidence of a drastic change in policy.

HEADLINE: Hawkish Coalition Is Forming

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
As President Bush prepares for talks with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq, an unusual coalition of liberal Democrats and moderate-to-conservative Republicans is urging the Administration to make the elimination of Iraq's weapons ability an explicit goal of American policy in the Persian Gulf.
The group, which calls itself the Committee for Peace and Security in the Gulf, has scheduled a news conference on Monday where it plans to argue that the United States should be willing to use force if necessary to see that Iraq's chemical, biological and potential nuclear weapons ability is dismantled or destroyed. 
 Formation of the coalition comes at a time of increasing partisan division over the Administration's conduct of gulf policy, particularly the issue of whether the United States should take military action within the next few months to force Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait.
A majority of Congressional Democrats, including such traditional party conservatives as Sam Nunn of Georgia, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, have argued that the Administration should allow more time for economic sanctions to persuade Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, to leave Kuwait voluntarily.
 
Divisions in the Party
 But the willingness of some Democrats to join a coalition that advocates use of force to disarm Mr. Hussein underscores what may be even more significant divisions in the party itself. Members of the new group include prominent liberals like Tony Coelho, the former House Democratic Whip; Ann Lewis, a former political director of the Democratic National Committee, and Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat who serves on the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
Among the Republicans are Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, a senior member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee; former Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci and such vocal Reagan Administration conservatives as Jeane J. Kirkpatrick.
"For someone who has been very vocal in the past about criticizing Administration policy on intervention overseas, I think it is important to speak out when I support it," Mrs. Lewis said. "That is not to say that this is a blanket endorsement of every aspect of Administration strategy."
Richard Perle, a conservative Democrat who served as an Assistant Secretary of Defnese in the Reagan Administration, said the purpose of the coalitin was not to deal with partisan politics.
"The cold war is over, and what constitutes an appropriate position for liberals is going to change," Mr. Perle said.

HEADLINE: Planting a Seed for Trade Wars

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 9

 BODY:
If the European Community does not eventually compromise on the farm trade issue that caused the collapse of the international trade talks here last week, there could be a painful return to the kind of trade warfare that aggravated the economic crises of the 1930's.
 Some officials still hold out hopes that the liberalization effort can be salvaged early next year when governments cool off and take a new look at the impasse over farm subsidies. 
 But for now, the European Community's refusal to dismantle the policies that protect the continent's farmers has paralyzed a four-year effort by 107 nations to expand free-trade initiatives into the 21st century under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the body that regulates world trade.
 
Danger of Unemployment
 The round of talks that failed were the first since World War II to be conducted at a time of such economic weakness. Government officials on both sides of the issue were bound to be far more concerned with the immediate danger of unemployment in their countries than with the promise of future benefits from expanded world trade.
President Bush may again seek to impress upon European leaders the importance the United States attaches to the trade liberalization effort. But American officials make it clear that progress will not come until the Europeans change their position on agriculture and are willing to commit to limitations on their export subsidies.
"We will not be making the telephone calls this time, but rather waiting for others to call us," said Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative.
Europe could choose not to seek a resolution of issues that remain in dispute, acting instead to become predominantly a regional economic and political power. It could adopt ever more adversarial relations with North America, which is in the process of forming its own trade bloc, and with countries of East Asia and the Pacific, where Japan is the pre-eminent economic force.
 
'A Protectionist Era'
 "The dynamics of a protectionist era could be about to begin," said C. Ford Runge, a professor at the University of Minnesota Center for International Food and Agricultural Policy.
In any new world of adversarial blocs and trade wars, the GATT trading system, which has been responsible for a 20-fold increase in trade over four decades, will atrophy.
 So far, there has been little evidence of compromise from the European Community's top leaders.
It had been expected that Chancellor Helmut Kohl, after an election victory in the newly unified Germany, would support the curbs on the community's agricultural subsidies that food exporters outside of Europe had long awaited.
 
German Assertiveness
 But the Germans did not send a high-level delegation to the meeting in Brussels, and officials who were there went out of their way to demonstrate German assertiveness and independence from Washington.
"We are not the 51st state," said Walter Kittel, Secretary of State in the Agriculture Ministry. Otto Schlecht, Secretary of State in the Economics Ministry added, "We are not ready to kowtow."
As the world's third-largest exporter, Germany has much to gain from freer world trade. But rising joblessness is a more immediate worry for Mr. Kohl.
The chancellor also sets high stock in his relationship with President Francois Mitterrand of France, the country that most strongly supports the Europeans' existing farm policy. France is the leading food exporter in Europe, but its farmers receive generous Government support.
 
Little Room to Maneuver
 Mr. Mitterrand has little room to maneuver. His political position has been undermined by student riots in Paris and by violent demonstrations of farmers.
The position supported by the United States in Brussels called for industrialized nations to permit greater access for agricultural and textile products in their markets. In return, developing coutries would open their markets in insurance, banking, accounting, engineering and other services and accept stronger rules against piracy of patents and copyrights.
Under some of the changes contemplated in financial services, for example, a country like Brazil would open its market to foreign insurance companies. Under the intellectual property negotiations, Thailand would be required to take stronger measures against the piracy of American films.
In addition, there would be further cuts in world tariff levels and improved procedures for settling trade disputes.
Essentially what the non-European food-exporting countries want are limits on what this year is expected to be nearly 25,000 tons of subsidized food shipped by Europeans to international markets.
 
Farmers Serve Notice
 While the big food exporters sought access to Europe and other international markets that have been captured by the countries with generous subsidy programs, some 10 million European farmers served notice of the immediate and unpleasant consequences that would reslut if their political leaders gave in to such international demands.
The trade conference started with a demonstration by 30,000 farmers from across the 12-nation European Community, and their message carried through to the final session when European trade negotiators refused to entertain any agricultural proposals acceptable to the United States and other leading food exporters.
The impact of the European farm policies is to depress world prices, hurting not only American farmers but those in Canada, Australia, Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, Indonesia, the Philippines and many other exporting countries.
Despite the breakdown in the final session of the talks, some gains were made.
"Some real good things happened here," said William Brock, a former United States trade representative. "Many developing countries have shown an enormous willingness to be more forthcoming -- from Mexico and Brazil to Thailand and Malaysia. These are really important changes that must be seized upon and responded to."

HEADLINE: Bangladesh Army Chief Ousts Some Commanders

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAKA, Bangladesh, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Military officers reported to be loyal to the deposed President, H. M. Ershad, were being moved out of their commands today as the army chief apparently sought to head off any armed intervention in politics, Bangladeshis close to the armed forces said.
In an atmosphere of increasing tension over the fate of Mr. Ershad, who seized power in a 1982 coup and ruled the country until being forced to resign on Dec. 5 under popular pressure, the American Ambassador to Bangladesh, William B. Milam, met today with the army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Mohammad Noor Uddin Khan. 
 A statement issued by the United States Embassy here afterward said Mr. Milam had praised the army for its "positive and responsible" role in the political crisis that culminated in Mr. Ershad's resignation.
The Ambassador also told the army chief that this attitude would continue.
 
Threat of Aid Loss
 From the beginning of the student-led democracy movement that led to Mr. Ershad's downfall, foreign embassies here have assumed almost mythological importance because of real or perceived messages from diplomats to the Ershad Government implicitly threatening the loss of aid to a country dependent on assistance.
When all newspapers stopped publishing here at the end of November, the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corporation news programs became the "bulletin boards" of the protest movement, Bangladeshis of all political opinions say.
Today Mr. Ershad gave his first recent interview, to the B.B.C., in which he said he expected to lead his Jatiya Party into the coming election.
He scoffed at suggestions that he would go into exile. "Why?" he asked the B.B.C. "It's my country. What have I done wrong?"
At the same time, student leaders and others were continuing to call for Mr. Ershad's execution.
Dhaka was awash with rumors today that the military has split in two over the fate of Mr. Ershad, a former general who had a significant enough following in the army to cause alarm among politicians whose main goal is to see that free and fair elections are held here within the next three months.
Helicopters droned overhead this morning as area commanders assembled here for strategy sessions. It was becoming apparent tonight that at least two major intelligence officers who had supported Mr. Ershad were transferred. Questions remained about other units and commanders who might be called on to support a military maneuver on behalf of the deposed President.
Mr. Ershad's fate may split the fragile alliance that stands to gain the most from the fall of his Government.
Today Sheik Hasina Wazed, the leader of the Awami League, Bangladesh's oldest political party, unexpectedly told a group of foreign correspondents that if Mr. Ershad left the country, it would be a relief to Bangladeshis.
Her opponent for more than a decade, Khaleda Zia, leader of the Bangladesh National Party, was today demanding that a special judicial inquiry be set up to try the former President.
 
Caution Is Urged
 Sheik Hasina said the subject of a trial was a "very complicated question." She said that the established legal procedures should take their own course, and that the politicians should move "very cautiously, very calculatedly" to avoid antagonizing the army.
"We shouldn't behave so that with any excuse a military dictator could come again," she said.
Dhaka remained relatively quiet today, with the gap growing between the millions of poor people who want to return to whatever work they can find, and the students roaming the streets with political banners.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Issue of Job Quotas Sure to Affect Debate on Civil Rights in the 90's

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Few issues reverberate in American politics like race. And not many charges are more serious than accusing a candidate of practicing racial politics.
In recent days, some leading Democrats have been accusing top Republicans, including the next chairman of the Republican National Committee, of doing just that. 
 The subject is quotas: employment policies that, some Republicans charge, unfairly guarantee minority workers or women a certain proportion of jobs. In campaigns in California and North Carolina this year, Republican candidates hammered Democrats as proponents of quotas, charges the Democrats angrily denied.
The issue is expected to be at the heart of the renewed debate over civil rights legislation when Congress returns in January. Democratic leaders say they will quickly reintroduce the civil rights bill that President Bush vetoed this year.
And the prospective Republican National Committee chairman, William J. Bennett, has declared that he considers quotas and affirmative action policies a worthy subject of debate, which, to some Democrats, means that they will be part of the campaign dialogue of 1992.
 Politicians, like generals, are seared by the last war. Much of the heat of this debate stems from the Democrats' experience with Willie Horton, the black convicted murderer and rapist whose case was a focal point of George Bush's 1988 campaign against Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.
Republicans said they used the Horton case to highlight Mr. Dukakis's liberal crime policies, including the furlough program that put Mr. Horton back on the streets. Democrats said it was a patent appeal to racial fears. The only agreement was on its impact: Willie Horton was devastating to Mr. Dukakis.
Democrats remember, just as they remember the beating they took that year over Mr. Dukakis's veto of a bill requiring schoolchildren to recite the Pledge of Allegiance. The pledge experience made them react in 1989 with great care to the issue of whether a law or a Constitutional amendment would be the best way to ban burning of the flag.
The Horton experience helps frame their response to the quota issue of 1990. It helps explain why Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, chose to lambaste the Republicans in a major speech last week as "seeking a successor to the Willie Horton issue."
Some Democrats say the Republicans are simply seeking another "wedge issue," the term often used for an issue intended to split Democrats from their party. They say that quotas are a classic straw man, since the bill Mr. Bush vetoed explicitly denied any effort "to require or encourage quotas." Republican strategists, the Democrats charge, are simply fomenting an angry new politics of resentment for the recessionary 1990's.
Republican leaders counter that Democrats cry racism because they fear a debate on the merits of some affirmative action policies. "People who want some kind of quota or some kind of set-aside based on your racial background should be forced to debate in public their vision of America," argues Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip. The civil rights bill of 1990 might not have imposed quotas, some Republicans say, but it would have inevitably led to them.
Republican Party leaders bristle at the charge that they are playing racial politics. Mr. Bennett declined to be interviewed last week, but Charles Black, who advised Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina in his successful re-election campaign and who is the chief spokesman for the Republican National Committee, argues that the quota issue is a way of making an ideological -- not a racial -- point.
"The thing about quotas is it reminds people that Democrats are elitist social engineers," Mr. Black said.
But Democrats assert that the racial component was obvious in the way the issue was handled in Mr. Helms's campaign against Harvey Gantt, a black Democrat. A television commercial for Mr. Helms showed white hands crumpling a rejection letter, while an announcer intoned: "You needed that job, and you were the best qualified. But it had to go to a minority because of a racial quota."
 
Comfortable or Not?
 Mr. Gingrich, when asked to assess the commercial at a meeting with reporters this week, said, "I wasn't comfortable or uncomfortable with the ad." He went on to say he had never seen it. When pressed, he said that if he ran such an ad, "I would make clear that I oppose quotas explicitly because I favor an integrated America."
Mr. Bennett, chosen by Mr. Bush last month to serve as the Republican chairman, has a long interest in this issue. In 1979, he wrote a book critical of affirmative action policies called "Counting by Race: Equality from the Founding Fathers to Bakke and Weber." His co-author was Terry Eastland, who went on to become the chief spokesman for the Justice Department in the Reagan Administration.
This debate is likely to intensify as Congress returns to the civil rights bill next year. President Bush based his opposition to the 1990 bill largely on the assertion that it would have led employers to impose hiring and promotion quotas to avoid lawsuits. This argument infuriates backers of the legislation, who say it would simply restore the law to what it was before several recent Supreme Court rulings made discrimination suits harder for plaintiffs to bring and easier for employers to defend.
"This is not a quota bill," said Ralph Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. "The Democratic Party opposes quotas, the Republican Party opposes quotas and the leadership conference does not support quotas." Rigid quotas applied without regard to qualifications, he said, are very different from such affirmative action remedies as goals in hiring.
 Moreover, supporters of the legislation say there is a broad bipartisan consensus behind it in Congress, and a broad public consensus. The House approved the measure, 273 to 154, in October, with 34 Republicans voting for it. The measure showed its greatest strength in the Senate when it failed by one vote to get the two-thirds necessary to override President Bush's veto. Eleven Republicans were among the 66 Senators voting to override the veto.
Although some campaigns this year featured attacks on the civil rights measure, Mr. Neas said, "These campaigns were the exceptions to the rule. Progressive Democrats and Republicans campaigned aggressively in support of the civil rights act of 1990, and they were the beneficiary of it."
Still, many Democrats assert that the quotas issue is especially potent when the economy is bad. "What you're talking about basically is the politics of resentment," said Mandy Grunwald, the media consultant for the Gantt campaign.
Some Democrats worry that their party is particularly vulnerable. "A fundamental reason why Democrats are potentially vulnerable to attacks on issues like affirmative action and race quotas is the perception that the Democratic Party has overlooked the needs and values of average Americans," Frederick Yang, an analyst with the polling firm of Peter D. Hart Research Associates, which polls for Democrats, wrote recently in the newsletter "The Polling Report."
Democrats, particularly in the South, often have been dependent on a fragile biracial coalition -- overwhelming black support and enough of the white vote to push them over 50 percent -- for victory in recent years. Such an environment, coupled with the economic downturn and their memories of Willie Horton, make Democrats take the quotas issue very seriously.

HEADLINE: Group Will Buy Mexico's Phone Company

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The Mexican Government said yesterday that it would sell control of its national telephone company to a consortium made up of Grupo Carso of Mexico, the Southwestern Bell Corporation and France Telecom.
The $1.76 billion deal follows a long bidding process, and is among the biggest and most complex transactions in a series of recent sales of telephone companies by governments around the world. The selection of a consortium that includes a large American corporation also signals the Mexican Government's new willingness to open strategic industries to American business interests after seven decades of sometimes open hostility. 
 Southwestern Bell, which has its headquarters in St. Louis, also joins the ranks of regional Bell companies that have made large overseas investments in the expectation of higher profits than they might earn through additional spending on their local telephone networks.
The Mexican Government is selling a 20.4 percent stake in Telefonos de Mexico that carries a majority of the company's voting rights. Also included in the price is an option for Southwestern Bell to buy from the Mexican Government another 5 percent stake in the company, known as Telmex, that carries no voting rights.
Grupo Carso will pay $859.6 million for 10.4 percent of the stock, thereby meeting a stipulation imposed by the Government that Mexican individuals or companies control a majority of the winning consortium. France Telecom will pay $412.2 million for 5 percent, and Southwestern Bell will pay $485.8 million for another 5 percent, plus the 5 percent option.
An all-Mexican consortium, Grupo Gentor, made an unsuccessful $700 million bid for the 10.4 percent stake that Grupo Carso won. Gentor includes the wealthy and influential backers of two of Mexico's biggest conglomerates, Vitro and Grupo Industrial Alfa.
The Mexican Government also turned down a third bid, for $1.69 billion, from a consortium of Accival Casa de Bolsa, a Mexican company; the GTE Corporation, and Telefonica de Espana.
Sixteen companies, including a dozen foreign concerns, were approved by the Mexican Government in October as potential bidders. What prompted such strong international interest was Mexico's fast-growing economy and the strong prospects for expansion in a country with only one local telephone line for every 17 residents. By comparison, the United States has a local telephone line for every two people.
"There is a large pent-up demand for telephone service, and it's just not available," said Royce S. Caldwell, Southwestern Bell's senior vice president for corporate development.
 
Binding Obligation
 The buyers assume a binding obligation to update Mexico's antiquated telephone network, which is notorious for delays of more than a year to install new phone lines. Telmex also lacks adequate local, regional and international trunk lines to handle all the calls.
In Mexico, as in much of Latin America, people still place many long-distance and international calls from the phone company's neighborhood office, handing the desired number to an operator and then waiting on a nearby bench until a connection is made. Upon obtaining a connection, which can take an hour or more in rural areas, the operator sends the caller to a booth and begins timing the call, sometimes with a stopwatch.
Mexican regulators have estimated that Telmex will have to invest $1 billion a year until the late 1990's to meet the service goals set out as part of the company's sale, and that reinvested profits would supply no more than 70 percent of this amount. Service requirements set by the Government include a doubling within four years in the number of household phone lines, to 10 million, and a reduction in installation time to 6 months, from 18.
 
Annual Borrowing to Rise
 Telmex will increase its annual borrowing to pay for the extra investment, and the consortium controlling it will not guarantee the extra debt, Mr. Caldwell said. If Telmex does not reach the service goals, the Government will impose fines that were set as part of the transaction.
Mr. Caldwell said in a telephone interview from Mexico City that Grupo Carso executives called him at home in St. Louis Friday evening and he joined other Southwestern Bell executives the next morning on an American Airlines flight to Mexico to put finishing touches on the deal.
All seven of the regional Bell companies formed by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984 are investing abroad. They have taken a particular interest in the state-owned telephone companies now being sold. The governments seek to bring in foreign expertise for their local phone operations and to raise money to pay off foreign debts.
In June, Ameritech, the Bell Atlantic Corporation and two New Zealand companies successfully bid $2.4 billion to buy New Zealand's national phone company. An agreement for Bell Atlantic to buy half of Argentina's telephone company fell through in October.
The BellSouth Corporation, the Nynex Corporation, the Pacific Telesis Group and U S West Inc. all have large stakes in cellular telephone or cable television operations overseas, and Southwestern Bell publishes telephone directories in Australia and Israel.
As many as 25 countries are considering the sale of all or part of their national telephone companies over the next four years, Mr. Caldwell said.
 
Investments Criticized
 Critics have suggested that the regional Bell companies should spend more on high-quality digital switches and high-capacity fiber-optic lines instead of investing abroad. Mr. Caldwell said his company's Mexican venture would not hurt telephone users in the five states -- Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri and Kansas -- that Southwestern Bell now serves. "We will spend whatever amount is necessary to spend in Texas and Oklahoma and our other states to provide the level of service we've always been willing to provide," he added.
Little information on investment banking fees was available late yesterday. Salomon Brothers Inc. advised Southwestern Bell. Wasserstein, Perella & Company advised France Telecom. Grupo Carso, which is involved in mining, paper products, consumer goods and insurance, has its own investment banking arm and did not retain outside advice. Goldman, Sachs & Company and Banco Internacional S.N.V. of Mexico advised the Mexican Government.
The deal came as one of Telmex's most profitable businesses, receiving and distributing calls from the United States, has become part of a growing international dispute.
The United States sends more than twice as many calls to Mexico as it receives, because calls are easier to make from the United States and because Telmex charges several times as much for a call as American carriers.
 
Compensation for Calls
 American carriers paid $534 million to Telmex last year to compensate it for handling the extra calls, more than the combined amount paid to any four other telephone companies around the world. The Federal Communications Commission has been putting pressure on foreign telephone monopolies to reduce the highly profitable fees that they charge for the extra calls, and Mr. Caldwell said the consortium buying Telmex would be likely to do so.
The consortium will also try to raise local telephone rates and lower long-distance and international rates, so that the rates will more closely reflect the cost of providing service, Mr. Caldwell said.
The Mexican Government retains a 36 percent non-voting stake in Telmex. The 5 percent of Telmex for which Southwestern Bell has an option would come out of the Government's stake, Grupo Carso is acquiring an option on a stake of another one-tenth of 1 percent, and the Government has pledged to sell 4 percent to Telmex employees.
The Mexican Government has said that it will sell the rest of its stake in one or more deals over the next several years. The remaining 44 percent is traded on stock exchanges around the world.

HEADLINE: The Hole in Hollywood's Pocket

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
While many American industries are retrenching in the face of a recession, Hollywood is on a spending spree. The studios are paying unprecedented prices for scripts, stars, directors and other talent required to produce feature films.
The theatrical, video and pay television businesses have exploded abroad, setting off bidding wars among the studios for the handful of talent believed to have the greatest global appeal. Artists involved in action films, which consistently play well worldwide, have seen the most spectacular increases.
 
High Industry Benchmarks
And rates like the following are beginning to serve as benchmarks for the entire industry: 
 Arnold Schwarzenegger was paid $10 million for starring in "Total Recall" and will earn $12 million from Carolco Pictures for "The Terminator II."
*"The Godfather, Part III," which stars Al Pacino, will cost Paramount Pictures at least $55 million.
*The screenwriter Shane Black earned less than $750,000 for "Lethal Weapon," one industry executive said, but he received $1.7 million from Warner Brothers for his latest script, "The Last Boy Scout."
*The screenwriter Joe Esterhaus received $3 million for a screenplay for Carolco Pictures' "Basic Instinct," and Irwin Winkler earned $1 million to produce the film, even though both left the project by mutual agreement shortly after production began.
Though there are myriad reasons behind the rise in fees, many Hollywood executives seem to agree that Carolco Pictures, a small Hollywood studio, is partly responsible. In the last few years, Carolco has carved out a niche making big-budget films with international appeal at a time when foreign markets were growing rapidly. It paid actors like Sylvester Stallone, Mr. Schwarzenegger and Mel Gibson enormous fees, recouping its investment by selling the films around the world.
Now, other studios have difficulty hiring these actors for substantially less money, even to appear in films in other genres like comedy that do not travel as well abroad.
And once the fees of actors increase, so do those of the other artists working on their films. Technical experts like cameramen and editors can charge more. "It is an industry where everyone looks at what everyone else makes," said Tom Hansen, an entertainment lawyer at Hansen, Jacobson & Teller in Los Angeles. "That creates a type of momentum."
 
Driving Down Profit Margins
 The escalation in fees is starting to drive down the profit margins of movies. If the trend continues, companies with deep pockets -- like the Sony Corporation, which bought Columbia Pictures last year, and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, which has agreed to buy MCA Inc. -- are in the best position to pay for talent. But the fear among some executives in the entertainment business is that those companies might only aggravate the problem because they are capable of overspending and are willing to do so if it gives them a competitive edge.
"We are going in for tougher times in the movie business," said David Londoner, a media analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company. "The competitive bidding war has thrown everything out of wack."
As one top executive at a major studio put it: "It's like a herd of elephants going down Main Street with each one's trunk hooked into the next one's tail. What they don't know is that the lead elephant is blind and has no idea what he's doing."
 
Changing Hollywood's Economics
 Higher costs are indeed changing Hollywood's economics. Last year, production costs for an average film rose 30 percent, to $23.5 million, while advertising costs jumped 10 percent, to $7.8 million.
One industry executive, who insisted on not being named, estimated that production costs have continued to grow this year, but not as strikingly as in 1989, while advertising costs have shot up much more sharply as studios have looked to protect their heavy investments in production.
Peter Dekom, a leading Hollywood lawyer and a partner at Bloom Dekom & Hergott, said he believed that the rates of return for films had already declined this year. And Mr. Londoner said he believed that the average profit margin of studios could fall 20 percent in the next few years, to about 9 percent.
 
Artists Demand Pay Up Front
 Eroding profitability has not been lost on actors and producers. Rather than settling for a modest advance and a cut of the profits, more artists have started demanding all of their pay up front -- an arrangement that further diminishes studios' profit potential. "No one is willing to gamble on real profits coming from these movies," said Dale Pollock, president at A& M Films, a production company owned by Polygram. "So most talent wants its money first."
An independent film producer, Lee Rich, said that "when stars get more, an Oscar-nominated cinematographer who earned $6,000 a week two years ago may make close to $12,000 today."
The problem is compounded when studios feel compelled to spend more to promote the films to increase the chances that their investment will pay off. The Walt Disney Company, for example, spent $46 million to make "Dick Tracy" and $54 million to promote it. Historically, studios have spent about one-fourth of their total budget on advertising.
Studios, of course, might keep a lid on their costs by staying out of the action film and big-budget categories. The trouble, said Tom Pollock, the chairman of Universal, is that these movies are "the big locomotives that drive the other films." He continued, "You get better terms from your theater owners if you can offer them such films."
 
Effect of Foreign Financing
 Foreign investors have helped provide financing for this spending frenzy. At Columbia Pictures, for example, Sony has put in place the particularly aggressive management team of Jon Peters and Peter Guber, who produced high-budget films like "Batman" for Warner Brothers. Eager for a big hit to give their new studio an aura of success, the team reportedly paid unprecedented prices for talent to make "Hook," a new film based on the pirate captain in "Peter Pan."
Studios rarely pay principals more than 30 percent of a film's proceeds, movie industry executives said. But Columbia is reportedly paying the director Steven Spielberg and the actors Dustin Hoffman and Robin Williams a total of 40 percent of all the money "Hook" takes in.
"Up until Columbia got into the fray, we argued that Carolco could pay Sylvester Stallone $12 million, but we could offer $7 million and say that a star was likely to make more money from a film's profits because we could distribute it better," said one executive who insisted on not being identified. "Columbia has made it harder for us to make that argument."
Mr. Guber, Mr. Peters and Columbia declined to comment.
 
Spending as a Measure of Success
 At some level, the ability to spend has itself become a measure of success. Largo Entertainment, an independent production company, recently attracted Japanese financing, permitting it to pay top dollar for actors and directors. In describing the ability of Largo's president, Larry Gordon, to make high-budget films, one entertainment lawyer said, "Larry can really play with the big boys."
Some studios can more easily justify paying higher prices for talent these days because, with the consolidation of the media industry and the rise of integrated entertainment conglomerates that distribute movies, books, recordings, television programming and magazines, they have more outlets through which to recoup their investments.
For example, the box office success of "Presumed Innocent," based on Scott Turow's best-selling book and released by Warner Brothers last summer, may have helped stimulate paperback sales of the book and of "The Burden of Proof," the author's second novel. Both books were published by Time Warner's book division.
Sometimes studio executives may believe there are indirect benefits from spending heavily to give a film high visibility. For Disney, the high cost of "Dick Tracy" may have reduced profit margins, but the movie's box-office revenues made the studio the industry leader in market share for the summer, a factor that one executive at a rival studio said helped persuade a group of Japanese institutional investors to invest $600 million in Disney.
 
Indications of Disenchantment
 Already, some industry executives say they are undertaking cost control measures. Many of them were spooked this summer when a glut of action films eroded the profitability of individual releases, and audiences, perhaps tiring of the format, gravitated toward films like Paramount Pictures' "Ghost," Disney's "Pretty Woman" and New Line Cinema's "Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles." Despite their relatively low budgets, the three are the highest-grossing films of the year.
Frank Mancuso, the chairman of Paramount Pictures, said his studio was moving away from high-budget films. "Now that everyone is doing it, we don't want to," he said.
In an indication of this disenchantment, Paramount recently broke its production deal with the producers Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer, who had produced a series of expensive hits but, more recently, some disappointments, including "Days of Thunder."
But the results of any spending cuts may not show up for several years. Budgets have been set for films that will be produced this year and next. But their costs will not be capitalized until the films are released, and that will not be for two years or so.

HEADLINE: Suspense for News as Tribune Board Meets

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
With The Daily News still hemorrhaging money on the 46th day of a bitter strike, there is an air of suspense about what might happen at tomorrow's quarterly board meeting of the newspaper's corporate parent, the Tribune Company of Chicago.
The strike, which erupted on Oct. 25 after 10 months of fruitless contract talks, has taken a great financial toll on the otherwise robust company, far more than the tens of millions of dollars Tribune executives say they anticipated when they began girding for a climactic clash with their New York City unions nearly a year ago. 
 As a result, some Wall Street investment analysts have speculated that the TribuneCompany's 14-member board might well decide tomorrow to cut the company's losses and close the paper.
In the last week, union leaders had eagerly seized on this notion, hoping that the specter of a shutdown would help force a settlement favorable to them, or possibly a sale of the paper.
 
Tough Management Style
 Those hopes seemed buoyed by the announcement last week of plans for a meeting in Washington at the invitation of the Federal Government's top labor mediator.
In many ways, a shutdown of The News, a fixture on the New York newspaper scene for 71 years, would be consistent with the pragmatic, hard-nosed management styleof the parent company and its combative chief executive, Charles T. Brumback, who took over that post four months ago.
But several Tribune officials familiar with Mr. Brumback's long-range strategy said that while he had underestimated the costs of the strike -- especially the extent to which violence, intimidation and pro-union sentiments would cut into circulation -- the company decided long ago to wage a war of attrition with the unions in which it was prepared to gamble many millions of dollars.
This view -- which several company officials offered in recent days on condition of anonymity -- suggests that the fate of the paper might not be decided until mid-1991, and would hinge on two factors: the success of the publisher, James Hoge, in bringing circulation and advertising at least back to the break-even point, and revenue projections for the fourth quarter of 1991.
"Charlie Brumback has always looked at this thing in long-range terms," a Tribune Company official familiar with Mr. Brumback's thinking said on Friday.
The company, he said, had maintained the same "hard-nosed position" at the bargaining table since the beginning of the year. "The unions don't like it and they've tested us as much as anybody's been tested," he said. "But that's not the question. The question is, who's got the staying power?"
For the moment, the company's record of success in the strike has been mixed. Although The News has continued to publish, and for less than half of its pre-strike labor costs, its circulation -- sustained by a ragtag force of hawkers and private home-subscription contractors -- has fallen to less than half its pre-strike level of 1.09 million copies a day. Most of its major advertisers have fled.
These losses, combined with more than $25 million management is believed to have spent on strike-related costs like security, legal expenses and pre-strike preparations, could raise the tide of red ink at the paper to close to $100 million for the year, many outside financial analysts believe.
 
Union Publicity Effort
 At the same time, union leaders -- whom The News recently sued for $150 million, accusing them of conspiring to terrorize vendors and nonunion workers -- have gained the sympathy of many local political and religious leaders, including John Cardinal O'Connor, head of the New York Archdiocese.
The Cardinal, who has sharply criticized The News's use of permanent replacement workers and what he has called its exploitation of homeless people in its hawker program, is scheduled to join the Rev. Jesse Jackson today at a pro-union rally outside News headquarters on East 42d Street. And tomorrow, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, has scheduled a one-day labor subcommittee hearing in Manhattan to discuss the practice of hiring permanent replacement workers to break strikes.
If the Tribune Company decides to close The News and attribute it to the unions, the shutdown could be accomplished for perhaps $150 million, including pension liability and other benefits, outside newspaper investment analysts say.
 
Waiting Till Spring?
 But there is wide agreement on Wall Street that the stock of the tightly managed, $2.4 billion Tribune Company will prosper in the long run whether The News survives or not. Indeed, company stock, down since last year, has been on the rise since the strike began.
One possibility, a financial analyst at the Tribune Company said, is that the board will put off a decision on The News's fate until spring, just before the annual company meeting in April. The crucial factors then, he suggested, would be the price of Tribune Company stock at that time, and whether Mr. Hoge has managed to bring The News to a break-even point by luring back enough advertisers and achieving a "provable" paid circulation of perhaps 575,000 copies a day.
"Their general view is that if they see progress at The News, they'll stick with it," the Tribune analyst said. "They think they they can outlast people who have to buy Christmas presents for their kids."
If all goes well over the coming months -- a big "if," the analyst acknowledged -- Mr. Brumback would ultimately announce a $300 million plan to build a new printing plant equipped with color presses, a production feature considered essential to The News's survival.
 
Accepting Big Losses
 Asked about the likelihood of that series of events, Joseph A. Hayes, the Tribune Company's vice president for corporate affairs, and John T. Sloan, The News's chief spokesman, declined to comment, other than to reaffirm that the company was committed to remaining in New York.
But the Tribune analyst said he believed that a huge financial loss at The News this year is unlikely to faze Mr. Brumback or his top associates.
"I think they're willing to accept a $100 million loss without batting an eye," the analyst said. "The Tribune Company has written off the fourth quarter for this year -- they've just written it off. The thinking is that if they're going to take a hit, now's the time to do it because we're going into recession."
Noting that the company's stock has been rising, the Tribune Company official familiar with Mr. Brumback's thinking said, "I don't think the investors want to see us cutting and running just yet."

HEADLINE: How a 9-Year-Old Boy Rode A Dark Horse to Success

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The star of the movie is a mere lad of 9, and the story line has been criticized as implausible and excessively sentimental. But "Home Alone" has overcome those obstacles and others, becoming the first blockbuster hit of the holiday film season and making its young leading man an instant favorite of American children and a potential millionaire.
Playing Kevin McCallister, who is accidentally left behind when his parents, four siblings and many assorted relatives leave for Paris from their home in suburban Chicago on a Christmas vacation, young Macaulay Culkin lives out a universal childhood fantasy. He gorges on ice cream, stays up late watching television and fends off a pair of bumbling burglars, a comedic formula that has proved immensely alluring to the young and not-so-young. 
 Released in mid-November by 20th Century Fox, "Home Alone" has already earned $80 million. With many moviegoers returning to theaters with friends or family members to see the comedy three or four times, the movie is expected by many in the film industry to gross $100 million by Christmas and to end up with a total box office take of $150 million or more, making it a sleeper hit almost in a class with "Ghost," the most successful movie of 1990, with receipts of $200 million.
 
Where Concept Prevails
 "We weren't on anybody's list of upcoming films for the holiday, not even in the longshot dark-horse column," said John Hughes, who produced and wrote the movie. "But I felt that the concept, the idea of a kid taking care of himself, was the most important thing."
The runaway success of "Home Alone" comes as especially welcome news to Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation, the parent company of 20th Century Fox. Having spent hundreds of millions of dollars to set up a fourth television network even as it was expanding into newspapers, book publishing and magazines, the News Corporation finds that the revenue it needs to stay afloat is smaller than expected because of a worldwide economic downturn.
Mr. Murdoch has been trying to negotiate an agreement with his creditors to defer repayment of about $5 billion in debt due in the next three years. With that in mind, "Home Alone" comes as a windfall that reduces some mounting financial pressure.
 
A Falling Out
 Originally, Mr. Hughes was planning to make "Home Alone" for Warner Brothers. That studio, though, pulled out just before filming was to begin in a disagreement over production costs, which Mr. Hughes estimated came to $18 million.
"We were three weeks away from the start, and it was a question of the budget," Mr. Hughes said in a telephone interview from Chicago, where he is directing a movie called "Curly Sue" for Warner Brothers. "To me, this was always an A picture, and I didn't want to see it treated as a B kiddie title."
Many of the 18 films Mr. Hughes has directed, produced or written in the last seven years, including the hits "Planes, Trains and Automobiles," "The Breakfast Club" and "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," were made for Paramount Pictures or Universal Studios. But Joe Roth, the head of movie operations for 20th Century Fox, had told Mr. Hughes early on that he would be happy to take on "Home Alone" if it ran into problems with Warner Brothers, Mr. Hughes said.
"I knew I had to go somewhere where I could get it made right away," Mr. Hughes said. "I had a cast and crew that were waiting and didn't know what was going on."
 
Timing, Timing, Timing
 The success of "Home Alone" also demonstrates the importance of knowing the right time to release a movie. 20th Century Fox had intended to open "Home Alone" on Thanksgiving weekend, but changed its plans when it was announced that Disney's "Three Men and a Little Lady," a sequel to the 1987 hit "Three Men and a Baby," would do the same.
"When 'Three Men' moved into that slot, we knew there was no way we could possibly compete head to head," said Tom Sherak, head of marketing at 20th Century Fox. "We decided to move everything up a week."
By doing so, "Home Alone" opened against Sylvester Stallone's "Rocky V" on Nov. 16 and racked up $17 million, a record gross for a nonholiday fall weekend. A sneak preview at about 1,000 theaters the weekend before the official release date was also said to be essential to the strategy: 5 percent of the preview audience members came to see the movie again on the opening weekend with friends, which convinced studio executives that they had a smash hit.
With that strong opening, "Home Alone," which received mixed critical reviews, was able to hold off "Three Men and a Little Lady" when it opened. Though "Three Men" earned a strong $13.8 million in its opening weekend, the box office take for "Home Alone" for the same period rose 23 percent, to a remarkable $21 million.
 
The Film That Wouldn't Leave
 "Home Alone" promises to further complicate a holiday film release schedule that is already one of the most crowded in recent years. The 1,300 theaters that had expected "Home Alone" to play for 3 or 4 weeks are now looking forward to a run of 10 to 12 weeks; these theaters are to be joined by 700 others by Christmas, which may make it even more difficult for other films to find a perch.
Studio executives are also waiting to see if "Home Alone" will siphon business away from a pair of comedies that have story lines relying on children and that are expected to be hits. "Kindergarten Cop," starring Arnold Schwarzenegger as a detective who goes undercover as a kindergarten teacher, and "Looking Who's Talking Too," with the voices of Bruce Willis and Roseanne Barr in a sequel to the 1989 hit that grossed $140 million, are to open this month.
"Home Alone" is rated PG, which means not only that children who are the age of its star and even younger may see the movie, but also that Fox can advertise it on Saturday morning cartoon programs catering to that audience. In contrast, both "Kindergarten Cop" and "Look Who's Talking Too" carry a more restrictive PG-13 rating, limiting their ability to advertise to children.
One early beneficiary of the movie's success is its star, who by appealing to adults and children and showing the ability to carry a film has suddenly become a hot property.
 
Alone at Home Again?
 He is reportedly to receive $1 million for his next film, "I Am Woman." Mr. Hughes added that "a sequel about the next chapter in Kevin's life makes sense creatively" and that he and 20th Century Fox are discussing the possibility. He also acknowledged that the child, whose contract does not oblige him to appear in a sequel, stands to make a lot more money the second time around. His salary for acting in "Home Alone" was reportedly in the low six figures.
"It's phenomenal that we're talking about these numbers in connection with a 10-year-old boy," Paul Feldsher, Macaulay Culkin's agent said of this Manhattan fifth grader who has been acting since he was 4 years old. "But when you look at the commerce of it all, it makes perfect sense. He's an actor in a hit film, and everyone associated with a hit picture tends to do better the next time around."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Macaulay Culkin as Kevin McCallister in "Home Alone," the holiday season's blockbuster hit. (20th Century Fos)

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Will There Be War?

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
President Bush insists that there can be no negotiation with Iraq and that the threat of war remains high. When Saddam Hussein decided to release his hostages, Mr. Bush said a peaceful solution was no closer. With Americans out of the way, he said, it would in fact be easier to make war on Iraq.
But negotiation has already started. There is every reason to think it will go on. And that makes war distinctly less likely. 
 Think about Secretary of State Baker's meeting with Saddam Hussein in Baghdad, whenever it is finally scheduled. Is Mr. Baker going to come back saying the meeting was a total failure? That war is now the only option?
If Saddam Hussein were intransigent, refusing to talk about withdrawal from Kuwait, then Mr. Baker might well come back with such a message. And President Bush would then have more public support for war.
But the Iraqi dictator knows all that. He has already shown that he can read American feelings and can move to avoid danger to himself. One reason he decided to release the hostages was surely to remove one casus belli. In meeting Mr. Baker he will be quite aware that to avoid war he has to give ground on Kuwait.
It seems to me likely, therefore, that Saddam Hussein will tell Secretary Baker that Iraq is withdrawing from Kuwait -- but that he needs assurances on some points. For example, he could announce a withdrawal in stages:
"Stage one has already begun, Mr. Secretary. Our troops began pulling out at 5 this morning. But it will take time, and there are security problems. Before finally leaving, we need to know when American forces will leave Saudi Arabia, who will maintain security in Kuwait and when sanctions on us will end."
If Saddam Hussein makes that kind of statement, is Mr. Baker going to refuse a discussion? Is he going to come out of the meeting and say that Iraq has not met the demand for unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait so there must be war?
The truth is that there would not be much American support for a war in such a scenario. Nor would there be much if Saddam Hussein did what many think he may do: withdraw from all of Kuwait except two islands at Iraq's outlet to the Persian Gulf and Kuwait's portion of a disputed oilfield.
Secretary Baker was asked yesterday on the ABC News program "This Week With David Brinkley" whether it would be credible to threaten war over the islands and oilfield. He answered yes, "to say anything else would be to reward an aggressor."
But the real world is not like that, and Mr. Baker knows it. Americans are deeply divided over the possibility of war with Iraq as it is. Can one imagine President Bush trying to take the country into war over the islands and oilfield?
There are other ways to deal with the border questions. The United Nations could keep sanctions on Iraq's oil exports until its withdrawal was complete. Or the border issues could be put, by mutual consent, to a legal tribunal of some kind.
Those are matters for diplomacy, and of course there will be diplomacy -- not just Mr. Baker looking Saddam Hussein in the eye and delivering an ultimatum. In fact the diplomacy has started. Last week Mr. Baker gave assurance that American forces would not attack Iraq if it left Kuwait. This week he emphasized that Iraq and Kuwait can discuss their differences, on such issues as the border, after Iraqi withdrawal.
"We are already involved in the negotiation process," former Secretary of State Cyrus Vance told The Boston Globe.
Mr. Vance called for an international conference on the Middle East to discuss security arrangements for the region after this crisis ends. He said it should consider, among other things, Iraq's nuclear capacity, arms sales to all countries in the region and the Palestinian question.
The conference idea is a prickly one for the Bush Administration because of Israeli objections to international consideration of the Palestinian question. But the United States has a strong interest in reducing instability in the Middle East, and Mr. Baker has already said that security must be dealt with after the crisis. If the promise of a future conference would help to end the crisis, would Americans prefer war?
President Bush no doubt feels he must keep the pressure on by making warlike noises. But if Iraq does withdraw, even with conditions, he will surely want to give priority to rebuilding Kuwait -- and leave the rest to diplomacy.

HEADLINE: Regulate Banks: Less, and More

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has put forth a seemingly crazy idea: sweeping deregulation of commercial banks. The last time Washington set out to deregulate financial institutions, it brought on the monumental savings and loan scandal.
But in fact there's nothing crazy about the Administration's bank plan. It is prudent and courageous. Prudent because current regulations make banks financially shaky and unable to survive foreign competition. Courageous because the Administration is sure to be ridiculed by members of Congress quick to stir up distaste for anything that smacks of another S.& L. bailout.
 
 Two laws, each more than 50 years old, stifle commercial banks. The McFadden-Douglas Act prevents banks from opening branches across the nation. And the Glass-Steagall Act forbids banks to underwrite and trade securities. Both laws are supposed to keep banks safe. In fact, they do the opposite.
The key to lowering financial risk is diversification: by investing in many different regions, industries and financial instruments, banks could insulate themselves. By forbidding such diversification, the two laws destabilize bank earnings.
A glaring example is the fate of S.& L.'s in the Southwest, dragged down by the collapse of the real estate market. If they had been allowed to operate branches in thriving Northwest states and not been forced to invest so heavily in real estate, they would still be alive.
The banking laws create another mortal problem. U.S. banks are losing customers to foreign banks which are permitted to offer a panoply of services, ranging from insurance to securities trading. Deregulation is necessary for American banks to survive. But it cannot proceed until Congress makes sure that failing banks can't gamble with federally insured deposits. That's what created the S.& L. debacle, and it remains possible under current law.
The Treasury Department is reviewing several promising options. The essential ingredients are clear. First, the Government needs to set high capital standards, above current levels. Next, as bank losses mount -- and capital slips below specified targets -- regulators would be required to intervene. Failing banks would be prevented from extending new loans, paying dividends or otherwise squandering funds needed to reimburse depositors.
Mandatory intervention was missing during the 1980's as bankrupt S.& L.'s were permitted to get deeper and deeper into trouble. What Congress ought to have learned from that searing episode is that the response cannot be left to the discretion of politically sensitive regulators.
Even if Congress agrees to these safeguards, many details must be resolved. The Treasury Department is grappling with proposals to improve accounting standards, introduce risk-adjusted fees for deposit insurance and set up barriers against misuse of federally insured deposits.
Beyond such details, the overriding need is to free U.S. banks to diversify investments and compete against foreign rivals. Economists have shown this can be done without endangering the taxpayer. Now the Administration has wisely turned policy into proposals. Congress would be wise to accept.
