HEADLINE: G.O.P. Senate Leader in Albany Is Showing New Swagger

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Ralph J. Marino, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate, is not known for making bold statements. He can exasperate Democratic leaders by revealing so little about a negotiating position that they question whether he has one. Reporters jockey to shove their tape recorders close to his mouth so they can catch his virtually inaudible utterances.
But in the wake of an impressive victory for the Republican majority in the Senate in the Nov. 6 election, his words, if not his voice, have resounded with uncharacteristicbravado. "The Marino era," he mumbled in a recent interview, "has begun." 
The statement served as both a declaration and a confession. Mr. Marino, a Nassau County lawyer, has been the majority leader for two years. But only now is he feeling confident enough to exert the power wielded by his venerable predecessor, Warren M. Anderson of Binghamton.
 
'Marino's Maulers'
 His new swagger stems from his ability to expand his Republican majority despite the most vigorous Democratic effort in decades to loosen the Republicans' 25-year grip on the Senate. Republican Senators returned toAlbany last week sporting lapel buttons that declared themselves "Marino's Maulers."
Beginning in January, the Republicans will control 35 of the 61 seats in the Senate. The party's majority during this year's legislative session was 34, but two Republican Senators were struggling with fatal illnesses and could not be relied on to make it to Albany. Mr. Marino had to count noses before every vote.
Not only did the Republicans increase their majority, but they also did it by running determinedly against tax increases and the fiscal policies of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Significantly for the future of state politics, Mr. Marino now feels that he hasbeen handed a mandate.
Perhaps seeing the writing on the wall, Mr. Cuomo proposed shortly before Election Day to fill a $1 billion gap in the current state budget purely by cutting spending without raising taxes.
 
'Too Much Spending'
 "We in the Republican Senate have proven the case that there was too much spending in New York State, and the Governor now is trying to get in the mainstream with us," Mr. Marino said. "As long as he does that, we'll get along just fine. But if there's an effort to go back to the old ways, if there's more spending, everyone will hear from me very clearly, for a change."
The state's leading Democrats, Mr. Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, argue that such posturing is more than a bit disingenuous.
After all, the 62-year-old Mr. Marino has not yet sworn to oppose tax increases in next year's budget, which could have a $3 billion gap. And Mr. Marino was a partner with Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Miller in negotiating this year's budget agreement, which included the largest tax increase in state history.
Whatever happened in the past, Mr. Marino and members of his Republican conference in the Senate said the election results have given them new resolve to resist tax increases. "I feel bolstered by it, I feel energized by it," Mr. Marino said.
 
Opposition to Payroll Tax
 The Senate leader has become more assertive in other matters as well. He was quick to oppose the payroll tax proposed by Mayor David N. Dinkins to finance an ambitious anti-crime package for New York City, sending Mr. Dinkins and the City Council back to the drawing board.
And after his party was embarrassed by the gubernatorial candidacy of Pierre A. Rinfret, who leveled blistering attacks on the Senate Republicans, Mr. Marino suggested bluntly that the state Republican chairman, J. Patrick Barrett, should step down.
Some Republicans believe that Mr. Marino is now positioned to become a party leader whose influence could rival that of his close political associate, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
The majority leader, who keeps a jar of elephant-shaped animal crackers on his desk, is more conservative than the Rockefeller wing of the state Republican Party but is less ideologically zealous than many upstate legislators. For instance, he has voted in favor of abortion rights but against Medicaid financing of abortions.
 
'Control Is Important'
 Both Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Miller said they did not expect to see much change this year in Mr. Marino's low-key style. But they do think he will be a more dominant force in controlling his own Republican conference.
"That will be helpful to Ralph and to all of us because control is important to the way we work," Mr. Cuomo said. "One of the problems with Ralph in his first year was that he couldn't deliver his conference. It made us hostage to all the disparate points of view and that made it hard to govern."
Mr. Marino said he proved he could deliver votes in his first year as majority leader, when he pushed through a budget agreement that included $1 billion in tax increases. But for reasons he said he could not understand, the perception has lingered that he is led by the State Senate's Republican members.
That impression may have been created by the way Mr. Marino won the majority leader's job in 1988. To tap the resentment of legislators who were weary of Mr. Anderson's autocratic style, Mr. Marino promised greater democracy in his house.
But the perception has also been advanced by Mr. Marino's personality. He is so reserved that he is often misjudged as a pushover.
"It's always extraordinary to me how little he gets away with saying," said Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine. "We're never able to flush out his position."
In a now legendary negotiating session on the state budget last spring, Mr. Cuomo orally pummeled Mr. Marino almost until sunrise. The Senator offended the sensibilities of some of his colleagues by doing little to defend himself against the abuse. But he also refused to cave in to the Democrats' demands.
 
'He Can Dig In'
 "The fact that he's quiet does not mean he's not resolute," Mr. Miller, the Assembly Speaker, said. "He can dig in and really be tough without raising his voice."
Mr. Marino's political instincts were steeled in the rough-and-tumble world of Nassau County Republican politics. A Rochester native whose parents were tailors, he moved to his wife's home in Oyster Bay after graduating from Syracuse University and Fordham Law School.
He served on the school board and town board and lost an election for town supervisor before winning election to the Senate in 1968. There, he developed an interest in criminal-justice issues, serving as chairman of the Committee on Crime and Correction for more than a decade.
Those skeptical of Mr. Marino's abilities point out that he remains a relative novice on the state budget, which is expected to dominate the action in Albany during the next two years.
"He doesn't like this stuff," said one legislative aide. "On the whole, he's probably going to swallow whatever is handed out."
Mr. Marino said that was not so. In the Marino era, he said, the Senate will be less reactive to the Governor's initiatives. "This gives me an opportunity to become a little more positive, a little more creative," he said. "We'll be laying out our own agenda."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "The Marino era has begun," said Ralph J. Marino, a Republican who has been the majority leader of the New York State Senate for two years. Beginning in January, his party will control 35 of the 61 Senate seats. (David Jennings for The New York Times) (pg. B6)

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Iran's Leader Uses Gulf Crisis to Consolidate Power and Reduce Isolation

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Taking advantage of the Persian Gulf crisis, President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran has isolated the radical foes of his policies, improved relations with Arab governments in the gulf and expanded political and economic ties with Western Europe.
Throughout the crisis Iran has tried a balancing act, condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the American military presence in the region. 
 It has largely adhered to the international embargo against Iraq -- although there is smuggling of food and other goods across the border -- while vigorously pursuing peace talks with Baghdad to resolve issues remaining from the war the two countries fought from 1980 to 1988. Soon after the United States and its allies sent large forces to Saudi Arabia to confront Iraq, Baghdad agreed to make peace with Iran, largely on Teheran's terms. The two nations agreed to withdraw their forces from conquered territory and exchange prisoners.
 
'The Second Republic'
 The country is now entering what one Saudi official calls "the second republic" under the stewardship of President Rafsanjani. After the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini two years ago, Iran seems in the view of many Iranian affairs experts to look upon the crisis as an opportunity to signal the world that the President's pragmatic policies are becoming firmly established, replacing the country's decade-long militancy and isolation.
Internally, President Rafsanjani has teamed up with Iran's Shiite Muslim spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, in a steady campaign to drastically reduce the influence of important opponents, including the former Interior Minister, Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, and Ayatollah Sadegh Khalkhali, a member of Parliament who was known as "the hanging judge" when he headed the country's revolutionary courts under Ayatollah Khomeini.
Mr. Rafsanjani's foes are being removed from policy making positions from which they inveighed against President Rafsanjani's declared intentions to attract foreign capital and improve ties with the West.
President Rafsanjani's professed intentions to revive and privatize the economy have been helped by an impressive increase in oil revenues. As oil prices soared, several Iranian oil experts predicted that the country's oil income would be nearly $20 billion this year, an increase of almost $7 billion over pre-crisis calculations.
 
Hostages and Frozen Funds
 In the realm of foreign policy there are no indications of an imminent improvement of Iranian-American relations, which hinge on the fate of the American hostages still held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian militias and a settlement of Iran's claims to $10 billion in funds frozen in American banks. After an initial effort earlier this year by Iran, which resulted in the release of three American hostages, progress on these issues seems to have stopped and is unlikely to resume before the gulf crisis ends, Arab diplomats here say.
But Iranian diplomacy has quietly succeeded in getting the European Community to lift all economic sanctions in October and encouraged Britain to resume diplomatic ties.
These moves are attracting Western financial aid and investment, most notably from France, whose companies have started work on rebuilding Iran's main oil shipping terminal at Kharg Island. The French Peugot company recently concluded a deal to assemble cars in Teheran.
"It is clear that the growing consensus around the country is to put the economic house in order and get Iranian money and expertise abroad to come back home," said Shireen T. Hunter, deputy director of the Middle East program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.
Within the gulf region, Iran is in the midst of an intensive diplomatic campaign to repair its relations with Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Saudi Arabia, ties that were damaged by those countries' support of Iraq in the eight-year war with Iran.
"Before the crisis all the gulf states were aligned with Iraq," said Shahram Chubin, a political analyst with the Strategic Studies Center in Geneva. "Now that Iraq is the major threat to all of them, Iran is emerging as a natural counterweight."
 
Regional Security System
 Speaking at a news conference here on Friday, the Iranian Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, confirmed this notion by hinting that Iran had discussed with several Arab countries in the gulf the idea of setting up "a regional security system" to prevent a recurrence of episodes such as the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the arrival of foreign troops, adding that the proposal has met with "positive signals."
Just before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, Iran had resumed diplomatic relations with that country. And over the last two months, Saudi and Iranian envoys have exchanged visits to resolve the thorny issue of the pilgrimage of Iranian Muslims to Mecca, which has been suspended for three years since clashes with Saudi security forces in which 400 Iranians died.
Inside Iran, the most significant developments in the last few months took place in October, when several Iranian leaders teamed up in a cunning maneuver to marginalize opponents.
President Rafsanjani, with the support of Ayatollah Khamenei, swiftly eliminated four of his most hard-line adversaries from the political scene by challenging their right to re-election to the Council of Experts on the grounds that they were not sufficiently knowledgeable in Islamic jurisprudence. The council passes judgment on all laws and on appointments of senior Government officials.
 
A Humiliating Test
 The militants who were disqualified after failing to pass a humiliating examination on Islamic law included the Deputy Speaker of Parliament, Mehdi Karrubi, and a former State Prosecutor, Mohammad Mussawi Khoeniha, as well as Mr. Mohtashemi and Ayatollah Khalkhali.
President Rafsanjani has made attempts to widen the scale of public tolerance at the expense of hard-liners.
A week ago the President, who holds the religious rank of hojatolislam, called for greater sexual permissiveness, invoking the existing right in Islam of "temporary marriages," which could last as little as a day, for young men and widowed or divorced women, in order "to clear the path for intrinsic needs of the youth to be satisfied in a correct, legal and orderly manner."
Religious hard-liners struck back with demonstrations demanding greater vigilance in public morality. The episode recalls several instances in which Mr. Rafsanjani floated proposals to allow women to wear makeup and encourage the return of music and singing, stirring hard-line opposition.
 
Little Help for Iraq
 Mr. Rafsanjani and Ayatollah Khamenei seem to have decided that while they will continue to talk peace with Iraq, they will not help it in any substantial way to break the embargo.
According to several officials of Arab gulf nations, Iran has turned a blind eye to the smuggling of sheep into Iraq. But these infractions of the embargo by Iran "are nothing major," in the words of one Arab Cabinet officer in the gulf who spoke on condition that he not be identified.
Yet experts agree Iran is still far from the point where it would consider better ties with the United States, and they say it strongly objects to a lengthy stay of American forces in the gulf.
Iran's reactions to the invasion of Kuwait emcompass a number of conflicting interests.
For one thing, there is a feeling of solidarity inside Iran, a non-Arab country with a Shiite Muslim population, toward the Arab Shiites who constitute a majority of the population in Iraq and who may suffer heavy losses in life during a war.
Also, Iran is not certain of the ability of the United States to contain the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, and therefore is reluctant to undertake any further actions that may antagonize him.
"What they really want is for Saddam to be weakened but not destroyed," Mrs. Hunter said. "They want Iraq contained, not obliterated."
Therefore, Iran has strongly condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait while vigorously pursuing its peace settlement with Baghdad.
Another motivation for the evident ambivalence toward Iraq is a dominant sentiment among even the pragmatic leadership of President Rafsanjani's Government that the United States is still a force seeking to dominate the gulf region's oil resources to the detriment of Iran and Iraq.
For that reason, Iraq is still looked upon by many Iranian strategists as a potential ally against pro-Western Arab nations led by Saudi Arabia.
 
A Reversal of Roles
 Still, the cumulative changes in Iran's foreign and domestic policies constitute what many commentators believe to be a reversal of roles in the gulf region between Iraq and Iran.
"Saddam Hussein, who started out as a pragmatist, is becoming an ideologue," said Baqer Moin, an Iranian author and commentator who lives in London. "His early speeches after the invasion of Kuwait look like copies of Khomeini's lexicon."
He noted that it is Mr. Hussein who is now calling for holy war against the Americans and their allies while Mr. Rafsanjani is pursuing expanded ties to the West and the gulf Arabs.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Continued Gloom Predicted In Outlook for Ad Spending

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
THE outlook for advertising spending in the United States for 1991 is gloomier than expected, said Robert J. Coen, a senior vice president and the director of forecasting at McCann-Erickson.
Speaking in New York yesterday to media executives and securities analysts at the 18th annual media outlook conference sponsored by Paine Webber Inc., Mr. Coen said total ad spending in the United States next year would increase by only 4.6 percent, to $136 billion. That would be the lowest growth rate in nearly two decades. 
 Earlier this year, Mr. Coen predicted that 1991 spending would increase by 7.5 percent, but he tempered that yesterday because of the worsening economy and uncertainty over the Middle East.
This bad news follows a lackluster 1990 for the industry. Ad spending had been expected to rise 6.2 percent this year, but Mr. Coen said expenditures increased just 4.9 percent, to $130 billion.
In his semiannual report on media outlook, Mr. Coen said spending might "pick up gradually" in the second half of next year. But he does not expect "significant improvement" until 1992, when the Olympic Games should result in a big lift. Mr. Coen expects this upward trend to continue for the remainder of the 1990's.
There is one bright spot: Spending in Europe and other foreign countries is expected to increase by 7.5 percent, to $156 billion, next year. With United States spending added to that, Mr. Coen said in his report, total worldwide ad expenditures should rise by 6.1 percent next year, to $292 billion. Worldwide spending is expected to rise at even faster rates for the remainder of this decade, he said.
The countries that saw the biggest rises in spending this year were Spain, with a 12 percent increase, and France, with 11 percent. In addition, spending in Japan, Italy and the Netherlands increased by about 9 percent.
This should be especially good news for Madison Avenue's largest agencies, most of which now earn 40 percent or more of their revenues from operations in European and other foriegn countries.
In other domestic trends, Mr. Coen said that spending by national advertisers next year is expected to be stronger than from local advertisers, increasing by 5.7 percent, to $78 billion. At the same time, local spending will rise only 3.1 percent, to $58 billion.
In broadcasting, cable and syndicated television will benefit the most from national ad spending, with Mr. Coen predicting double-digit growth continuing. This year, national advertising for cable rose 15 percent, and it rose 25 percent for syndication.
The outlook for network television is again bleak. In 1990, spending by national advertisers increased only 5 percent, and Mr. Coen said that spending would continue to be sluggish for most of next year.
Magazines, which had a dismal 1990, with ad pages dwindling at many major publications, is expected to recover somewhat next year, Mr. Coen said.
But there will not be much relief for newspapers, he said. National advertising is expected to be weaker in 1991 and local advertising will rise just 2 percent.

HEADLINE: Insurers Called Stable

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
A company that has been rating insurance companies for 90 years today told Senate investigators that the industry was not heading for the same financial troubles that befell savings and loan associations.
"We would not support the dire conclusions which have been reached regarding the potential insolvencies of several large and prominent insurers," said Michael Albanese, an analyst with the A. M. Best Company.
Mr. Albanese testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, whose chairman, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum contends the insurance industry is showing some of the same warning signs that preceded the collapse of scores of savings and loans.
"Like past S.& L. regulation, current insurance regulation in most states is not equipped to detect or prevent another financial debacle for millions of Americans," the Ohio Democrat said.
Mr. Albanese, whose company rates 1,500 life and health insurers and 2,300 property-casualty concerns, told the subcommittee that Best does "not agree that the insurance industry as a whole at this point in time is on the brink of financial crisis analogous to that of the savings and loan industry."
Senator Metzenbaum contends that state regulators and generally accepted accounting practices allow insurers to conceal their true financial situation by valuing such bonds and real estate at purchase price, rather than at present value.

HEADLINE: Unable to Work, He Gets Help From the Neediest Cases Fund

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
William J. Jagacki peered at the framed photographs of his family on the bedroom wall yesterday morning and pointed to the snapshots of his wife, himself and his stepdaughter. He then stopped, unable to identify the baby in the last photo.
"It's Kelly?" he softly said to his wife, Margaret. She patiently corrected him, telling him the right name. 
 "My memory isn't so good any more," said Mr. Jagacki, 37 years old, who has epilepsy. "I can't remember names and dates so well."
Mr. Jagacki, an unemployed butcher, stands a trim 6 foot 4 inches and appears robust and muscular. He loves to go fishing, makes his own rods and reels and has caught several dozen bluefish in the last two weeks. Yet he will not venture to the beach -- a block away from his apartment in Far Rockaway -- unless his wife or a friend goes with him.
 
Epileptic Seizures Continue
 It has been about three years since Mr. Jagacki began fainting and having convulsions. A year ago, he lost his job in a supermarket after having a seizure behind the dairy counter, in front of customers. Over the summer, he had a seizure while wading in the ocean and almost drowned. A few weeks ago, he had a seizure on a bus. He takes 700 milligrams a day of the medication Dilantin, but his seizures continue, averaging two a week.
The illness, Mr. Jagacki said, has ended the middle-class existence he once enjoyed. For him, there is no longer a car, a savings account or nights out on the town. And if the Community Service Society of New York was not helping him, the Jagackis would be without a home.
Last spring, a few months after he lost his job, the couple fell behind in their rent and received eviction notices and orders to appear in court.
When the Jagackis called for help, the Community Service Society of New York responded quickly. In April, a social worker from the agency maneuvered through the welfare system on the couple's behalf to help them get back payments of $1,750. The charity then offered to provide the couple with a monthly check for $250 -- half of their rent -- until they began receiving more substantial disability benefit checks from the Government.
The money that has allowed the Jagackis to keep their two-room apartment comes in part from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The Community Service Society is one of seven charities that receive money from the fund.
The Neediest Cases 79th annual appeal began last month and already $1,442,117.55 has been received. The New York Times pays for the campaign's overhead, and all of the money is to be used by the charities to provide direct assistance for the sick and the needy.
The Jagackis said that they would have been forced to move into a friend's house or to a shelter without the help of the Community Service Society. And they are pleased to be living in their snug apartment, decorated with Elvis Presley posters and plaques of Jesus.
Mr. Jagacki said that he is not sure about his future, that every seizure deadens his memory a little bit more and that he does not know whether he will work again.
"This summer, I asked the guy next door, a contractor, if he could use me," Mr. Jagacki said. "He told me that he always had work for a big, strong guy like me. An hour into my first day, he drove me back home. I had a seizure."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances in U.S. After Retreating Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced in New York after falling overseas yesterday as the Federal Reserve took no apparent steps to push interest rates lower.
Foreign exchange traders went into yesterday's session fearing that the Fed, which relaxed its monetary policy on Friday, would again nudge rates downward. 
 Mike Faust, a foreign exchange analyst with MMS International in Chicago, said the market worried that the nation's central bank would lower the discount rate or take some other aggressive action.
However, "it never materialized," Mr. Faust said. "The dollar got a temporary reprieve."
On Friday, the Fed announced it was injecting $1.5 billion into the banking system, a move designed to encourage banks to make funds more available and to allow interest rates to fall. The Fed acted after the Labor Department issued an employment report that showed the economy continued to weaken in November.
The dollar, which is supported by higher interest rates, fell sharply after the Fed's move. When no further steps were taken yesterday, the United States currency moved higher.
Mr. Faust said that despite the dollar's rise, the outlook for the dollar remained negative. If the economy continues to weaken, the Fed may be forced to relax its policy further.
The dollar gained ground against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 132.15 yen, up from 130.70 yen late Friday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 130.55 Japanese yen from 132.17 yen at Friday's close, and in London, it was quoted at 130.55 yen.
The British pound was also brought lower by interest rate concerns. The market expects the new Government in Britain to lower rates.
Sterling fell to $1.9442 in New York, from $1.9535 late Friday, and in London, the pound fell to $1.9450, from $1.9510 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Accounting Education Broadened

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
THE career outlook for young accountants will depend upon their quality, so much that the the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has decreed that new members starting in the year 2000 must have 150 credit hours of education.
That means 30 hours of graduate training in addition to the equivalent of the usual 120 hours or so of undergraduate study. Universities across the country have been planning changes in their accounting curriculums in response to the institute's position, and some have already begun new programs. One such program is at the University of Southern California, in Los Angeles. 
 The dean of its accounting school, Dr. Michael A. Diamond, went to New York last week bearing a study guide of the new accounting program that will start next month.
"I believe we are one of the first, possibly the first, to start a program this spring to meet the eventual new requirements," he said. The aim is to provide better and more broadly trained accountants as well as to encourage larger numbers of undergraduates or graduates to specialize in accounting, especially minorities."
He said the changes had come about because leading accounting firms had complained for years about the quality of young accountants, as well as declining interest in the profession.
The program at U.S.C. begins in January with a new required course for undergraduates called "Core Concepts of Accounting Information." Dr. Diamond said it consisted of teaching modules that could be altered as professional needs changed.
Because of contentions that accounting is boring, the new course will use a variety of dramatic approaches, with videotapes, group study, role playing and mock stockholder meetings.
All new candidates for a bachelor of science degree in accounting, usually about 600 at any period, will take the eight-hour, two-semester course. Other new courses will be added.
As for the five-year program envisioned by the accounting institute, Dr. Diamond agrees that "many students will exit after four years."
Some will work for corporations, management consulting firms or the Government, and others might work for major accounting firms that will give them additional training and send them to obtain master's degrees, possibly at evening sessions. Dr. Rick Elam, a vice president of the accounting institute, calls accountants "ambidextrous," in that they can find jobs in many managerial areas. Accountants generally must take continuing professional training to keep state licenses, he said.
Dr. Diamond reports that more candidates for master of business administration degrees are taking additional accounting courses beyond those required -- an indication that more business students realize the helpfulness of more accounting knowledge, along with a broader education.
Dr. Diamond could be an example. A history major at the University of California at Berkeley, he later obtained a master's degree in accounting and a doctorate at the University of California at Los Angeles. He worked for a major accounting firm and taught accounting at a college in Washington before joining U.S.C.
Last week he conceded that "right now the need for young accountants is in a down cycle and there is not a notable increase in hiring." Demand will come back strongly once the economy improves, he said.
The real problem is increasing the quality of graduates, he said. Accounting education has hardly changed in the last 50 years. "It is too narrow, too centered on rules, too focused on preparation for the C.P.A. exam, too inclined to force students to memorize rather than analyze." he said.
He said that accounting's body of knowledge has "expanded tremendously" in the last 20 years. Use of computers and globalization of business have spurred the need for more broadly educated accountants, as well as the proliferation of services offered by accounting firms, like management consulting, tax advice, compensation surveys and other services.
As if updating programs is not enough of a problem, universities have a hard time finding well-qualified professors. They have to offer high salaries in two areas that are especially short, engineering and accounting, according to the American Council on Education.
To attract young accountants with doctorates, leading universities offer $70,000 for the typical nine months' work, plus perquisites like extra pay for research done in the summer. Full-time professors of accounting can command $150,000 at some universities.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Japanese Leaders See Support for U.S. Stand in Gulf Ebbing

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 10

 BODY:
While in public Japan continues to back American policies in the Persian Gulf, business leaders, Government officials and politicians say privately that the support is ebbing away amid concern that the United States is overlooking the possibility of a compromise with Iraq.
Businessmen in particular say there is a growing consensus that their interests will suffer in a war and that the United States is not sensitive enough to the possibility that fighting, along with Arab casualties, would alienate the Arabs from the West for generations to come. 
 "The sentiment of business leaders is that the United States shouldn't be holding a gun to the head of Saddam Hussein," said Kazuo Nukuzawa, managing director of Keidanren, the largest and most influential business trade association. "There are a lot of other ways to influence his behavior."
The apparent growing reluctance among Japanese to endorse the American hard-line goals was seen as lessening the chance that Japan would increase the $2 billion it has pledged to assist the American-led military buildup in the gulf.
 
Little of Money Disbursed
 Of the original $2 billion, only about $100 million has been disbursed, but Japanese officials said nearly $1 billion was in the pipeline in the form of equipment, cash payments to the United States and payment for transportation of equipment in chartered ships and planes.
Japan also pledged another $2 billion in economic aid for Jordan, Egypt and Turkey, but less than a third has been disbursed.
Most has been held up for discussions on the kind of projects to be aided and how the aid is to fit in with the overall economic development of these countries.
President Saddam Hussein's decision last week to release all the hostages, including nearly 300 Japanese, is considered likely to reinforce the Japanese aversion to the use of force against Baghdad, various specialists say.
Responding to Mr. Hussein's move, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said again that Japan demanded an unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait, which was overrun in early August.
 
Concern Over Economic Effect
 But in Japan the activities of big trading and industrial companies are often more influential than what the Prime Minister says or does, and the indications are that their concerns about the economic effect of war are rising.
As if to illustrate this point, the president of a large Japanese energy company who is close to Mr. Kaifu and several other leaders of the governing party said in an interview that he had been on the telephone all day on Friday with contacts in Iraq to try to suggest a possible compromise.
"Unless some sort of negotiations take place, Saddam Hussein will not get out of Kuwait," the president said, asking not to be identified. "It would be best if some sort of inter-Arab solution were to be found, giving Saddam some concessions on territory or oil prices or freedom of waterways."
Japanese officials say that for now they do not feel huge pressure to change the Government's policy in Iraq, but they acknowledge that this could change. The United States has ruled out any concessions, including allowing Iraqi control over Kuwaiti oilfields or oil production or pricing.
No opinion polls have surveyed what the Japanese think about the American threat to use force against Iraq, although politicians say they are haunted by the fact that polls last month showed overwhelming opposition to Japanese troops taking part in any such use of force.
 
Desire for Compromise
 A well-placed official in the governing Liberal Democratic Party of Mr. Kaifu said party members in Parliament were growing concerned that a possible compromise was being overlooked, although they were afraid of speaking out because of pressure from the United States.
Another factor in the growing concern has been a sudden spate of articles in popular and scholarly journals in recent weeks criticizing American policy in the Persian Gulf as wrong-headed, short-sighted and insensitive.
In addition, newspapers have quoted Japanese hostages in Iraq and hostages released and returned to Japan as openly criticizing the Japanese Government for what they say is subservience to Washington.
"The American method of taking short cuts, behaving in an impatient way and pushing for direct reaction is making more and more people worry," said Shigeki Koyama, president of the Japanese Institute of Middle East Economics. "People are beginning to feel that more calm, realistic measures are necessary."
Mr. Koyama and many other critical Middle East specialists, many of them longtime champions of Arab positions, are often seen on television and contributing to journals.
"More and more respectability is being given to opinions against the United States," said Takeshi Sasaki, a professor of political science at Tokyo University. "A very strong counterreaction has started in leading journals that are always very sensitive to shifts in public opinion."
 
Questions Often Raised
 A senior Foreign Ministry official involved in the gulf said that so far the Japanese public and business people were officially supportive, but he said he was concerned about the questions raised on the Middle East whenever he gave speeches on the subject.
"I lecture on this all the time," said the senior official, Yukio Okamoto. "The business people say: 'You know, so what if Saddam Hussein gets hold of the oilfields? He has to sell his oil somewhere.' And they say, 'Don't you know that the Arabs will make a deal among themselves in the end?' "
Mr. Okamoto said many Japanese suffered from what he called a disease of relativism that makes them reluctant to criticize other nations' behavior as immoral, even in extremes. "There are no examples in our history of Japan standing up for one value against another value."
Another theme being mentioned increasingly in the press and in private discussions is that the American policies are the result of pressure from Israel. Businessmen and many other Japanese also speak about the "Jewish lobby" in the United States as a factor in American policy.
"The United States is not looking at this in a balanced way," said a leading banking executive, also asking not to be identified. "The real reason behind America's involvement is the relationship with Israel. Who benefits from this? Only Israel. It is not balanced to see the Middle East through the eyes of one small country."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Questions About First Chicago

BYLINE: By Eric N. Berg

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
WITH the shares of the First Chicago Corporation down more than 40 percent this year, some people might rate the stock of the big bank holding company a "buy." After all, if First Chicago traded at $35 a share in the last year on the strength of its leading market position in the Middle West, then at its current price below $20, the stock is surely a bargain.
That, at least, might be an argument on behalf of the company. But to hear most Wall Street analysts tell it, First Chicago is anything but a buy and should probably be sold short in anticipation of further price declines. 
 Most investors doubted that First Chicago shares would fall as far as they have. Now, with concerns deepening about the bank's real estate loan portfolio, the prevailing view among market professionals is that the stock could sink to the low teens. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, First Chicago closed at $19.75, up 62.5 cents.
"There is more bad news to be digested," said Richard Mueller, an analyst at Duff & Phelps Inc.
To be sure, not all analysts are bearish. Stephen Berman, who follows First Chicago for County NatWest Securities, has created what he considers a worst-case scenario in which 35 percent of First Chicago's real estate loans become uncollectible.His analysis shows First Chicago shares still rising to $30 a share in the next year. In view of the fact that the stock also pays a $2 dividend (10 percent), Mr. Berman rates First Chicago a buy.
But the potential for big real estate problems has most analysts nervous. What they are concerned about is not the roughly 16 percent of First Chicago's $4.5 billion in commercial real estate loans that have already experienced some degree of difficulty. Presumably, First Chicago has already established loan-loss reserves. Rather, the issue is what lies ahead.
Through its American National Bank subsidiary, First Chicago has made hundreds of millions of dollars in realty loans in the Midwest. American National has already said that more than $60 million of these loans are troubled, and some fear fear that the Midwest, which so far has held up well economically, will be the next to fall victim to the nationwide recession.
"Vacancy rates are already ticking up in Chicago," Mr. Mueller, of Duff & Phelps, said. "And once employment growth here shows, you will see even more upticks."
Analysts also note that as one of the largest issuers of Mastercard and Visa credit cards in thecountry, with $6.4 billion in receivables, First Chicago will see more defaults on card accounts as more people become strapped to pay bills. So far, the bank has reported no big increase in losses.
First Chicago also has a $3.6 billion portfolio of loans to highly leveraged companies. Although only $108 million of these loans were reported to be troubled on Sept. 30, highly leveraged loans are generally the first to suffer in a recession.
There are also uncertainties about the company's ability to control its overhead. First Chicago's "non-interest expense" rose 12 percent in the first nine months of this year, to $1.2 billion, while revenues rose only 3 percent, to $1.8 billion.
According to Norman Jaffe, a banking analyst at Fox Pitt Kelton Inc., First Chicago officials are trying to address this problem, but he stopped short of predicting broad layoffs.
Lisabeth Weiner, a First Chicago spokeswoman, said that the company was reviewing operations, but that so far only a small number of the bank's 17,250 employees had been laid off.
Complicating matters for holders of the stock is that First Chicago recently reinstated its dividend reinvestment plan, under which shareholders can buy newly issued shares at a 4 percent discount from market. That has left some Wall Street analysts puzzled because the move, while providing fresh capital for the company, could reduce earnings per share and send the stock price lower still.
But according to Ms. Weiner, the dividend reinvestment plan should be only mildly dilutive, if at all, and is less generous than many other plans.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Quayle, in Sharp Attack, Accuses Some Democrats of 'Playing Politics' on the Gulf

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 10

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle charged today that some Congressional Democrats holding hearings on the deployment of American troops to the Persian Gulf were "playing politics" and undermining the United States' position in the crisis.
"A Congress solidly united behind the President would strengthen our chances for peace," the Vice President said. "But that would require Congress to resist the temptation to use the current hearings on the gulf for partisan political advantage." 
 In a speech here before a meeting of the Republican Governors' Association, the Vice President used what one aide, David Beckwith, said was the strongest language to date in criticizing some Congressional Democrats.
 
Partisanship and Statesmanship
 In hearings over the past two weeks, several of the Democratic Party's more conservative voices have argued that the Bush Administration should allow time for economic sanctions against Iraq to work, getting President Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait voluntarily rather than using force to dislodge him.
But Mr. Quayle said today: "Despite the efforts of some in Congress, the fact of the matter is that the American people support the President. Once again, the American people are ahead of their Congress.
"Unfortunately, by portraying themselves as the party of peace, and the Administration as the party of war, some Congressional Democrats -- but by no means all Congressional Democrats -- seem to have placed partisanship above statesmanship."
He specifically cited the Senate Armed Services and Foreign Relations Committees, which both led off their hearings with witnesses critical of the President's actions. Mr. Quayle acknowledged that the hearings had also heard "clear, candid and convincing" testimony from Administration architects of the policy, but he said President Hussein had made it clear that the Congressional hearings were useful in what the Vice President called his "political war against the United States."
 
Democrats' Response
 "Saddam has even gone so far as to heap praise on the Congress," Mr. Quayle said. "Saddam's purpose in all this is perfectly clear. He hopes to encourage Congress to deprive the Bush Administration of its option to use force."
Democrats involved in the hearings said Mr. Quayle's criticisms were misplaced. "The first partisan statement has just come from Vice President Quayle," said Senator John Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat who is a member of the Foreign Relations Committee. "I know of no one who has suggested that the threat of force should not be real and unmistakable. Whether it's now or later, Saddam Hussein faces the same ultimate day of reckoning. But many of us are fighting to guarantee that we maintain consensus in this country so that should shooting start, the policy does not fall apart."
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat who is also on the Foreign Relations Committee, said, "The fact that a member of Congress has genuine concerns about the Adminstration's policy does not mean he is being partisan, particularly about a policy that would put the nation at war," and added, "For what it's worth, I note that the hostages are coming out."
 
'Real Comfortable in That Role'
 The tough, partisan comments by Vice President seemed consistent with the role he has played in other recent confrontations between the Administration and Congress. In the tax debate this fall, it was Mr. Quayle who often fiercely challenged Democratic criticism of the President.
"He looks real comfortable in that role," said William Lucas, director for liaison services in the Justice Department.
Mr. Quayle asserted that the Administration was determined to resolve the gulf crisis peacefully, but that the Iraqi leader did not seem to understand that the United States and its allies were also determined to end his aggression. The Vice President said the coming mission to Baghdad by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would show that determination. "We are committed," he said. "The coalition is committed. The world is committed."
The Republican governors gathered here in a time of confusion for many of them after midterm elections that slightly thinned their ranks or gave some of them tougher races than they expected. Before the election there were 28 Democratic governors and 22 Republicans; on Nov. 6 the voters elected 28 Democrats, 19 Republicans and 2 independents (both former Republicans). The race in Arizona will be decided by a runoff, since neither candidate won a clear majority.
All in all, said Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri, the governors' association's departing chairman, it was not a bad midterm election, given earlier predictions that the Republicans would lose four or five governorships.

HEADLINE: Giving New Purpose To the Space Program

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Ever since the lunar explorations of Apollo two decades ago, a general perception of the American civilian space program has been that of a giant spaceship in a decaying orbit: still capable of some brilliant flourishes, but directionless and drifting lower with diminishing ground support.
 Nothing, not even the Challenger tragedy in 1986, could change its course and reinvigorate it with a new sense of purpose. 
 But the White House, Congressional leaders, scientists and some of the space agency's harshest critics believe the program has now been shown the way back to steady orbit with a more promising future. In their view, the committee assessing the future of the civilian space program, in its report today, has done nothing less than lay out a realistic blueprint for the post-shuttle, post-cold-war era of space exploration.
 
 Facing the Facts
 In what could be a historic turning point, the committee confronted facts that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had long refused to face and identified the two major stumbling blocks to fundamental change -- the unreliable space shuttle and the poorly conceived Freedom space station. The committee recommended a gradual phasing out of the first and a sweeping redesign of the second.
 The shuttles would be largely replaced by a fleet of heavy-lift rockets, for robotic operations and later for human flight. The space station would be stripped to a more modest size and given a more narrowly defined objective: studies in the life sciences. It so happens that more powerful rockets and experience in the effects of long-duration flight on human physiology would be essential prerequisites for reaching goals set by President Bush last year, a return of astronauts to the Moon to establish permanent outposts and the eventual flight of humans to Mars, perhaps by 2019.
Unlike many Government reports, this one is not so likely to sink out of sight, because it strikes chords pleasing to a wide range of interests.
A senior White House official said some of the committee's recommendations could be incorporated in the 1992 budget that is being prepared for submission to Congress in late January. NASA officials will be asked to confer with the Office of Management and Budget within 30 days.
 
'Go as You Pay' Effort
 President Bush should like what he sees because the committee endorses his view that the long-term "magnet of the manned space program is the planet Mars" and favors a "go as you pay" effort to get there that might not be so frightening to fiscal conservatives. And Vice President Dan Quayle, who directs the National Space Council, has already praised the committee's findings and is expected by his associates to take a forceful hand in seeing that many of the recommendations are carried out. He may try to use the space issue as a means of gaining greater political visibility.
The report is likely to strike a responsive note in Congress, at least on the point of redesigning the space station to reduce costs, whose estimated cost had risen as high as $35 billion for the decade. The appropriations committees had already told NASA to come up with a less expensive concept or have it scrapped altogether. At the same time, the budget-conscious Congress eliminated almost every cent requested for the kinds of long-range technology development being recommended by the committee.
Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, said the changes were needed to restore confidence in NASA and added that the Science, Technology and Space subcommittee, which he heads, would conduct hearings in the next session. Representative Bill Green, a Manhattan Republican who is a frequent critic of NASA operations, agreed with the proposed changes in the space station and the call for greater emphasis on scientific research by NASA, but cautioned that the advisory committee's underlying assumption of that NASA's appropriations would grow 10 percent a year over the decade, after taking inflation into account, "seems difficult to attain."
The most exuberant response so far has come from scientists, who cannot believe their possible good fortune. "This could be the dawn of a second golden age," said Dr. Bruce C. Murray, a planetary scientist at the California Institute of Technology who has been especially critical of the space program's emphasis on the shuttles and space station at the expense of scientific exploration.
 
 'Realistic' Recommendations
 John E. Pike, a space policy analyst for the Federation of American Scientists in Washington, had high expectations that many of the changes would come about. Unlike other recent examinations of space policy, he said, "This is a realistic set of recommendations rather than a pie-in-the-sky wish list."
NASA officials, if not elated, were at least relieved that the advisory committee had not proposed a major overhaul of the agency's organization, as some had feared. The agency's leaders said they were pleased with the report's general tone and would take the recommendations seriously.
"There may be some initial resentment at NASA," said Dr. John M. Logsdon, a space policy expert at George Washington University and frequent advisor to the agency. "But there's so much common sense in the report that NASA will finally fall behind it as the best way to get White House and Congressional support."
If the recommendations are adopted, it will be the beginning of the end for the shuttle program. The military is no longer interested in using the shuttle, commercial payloads were barred after the Challenger accident and now NASA is even being told to find something less expensive and more reliable for its own operations. Shuttles will still be needed through the end of the decade, the committee concluded, but less and less so. A proposed fifth shuttle would not be built, with the money saved going to the heavy-lift boosters.
The committee also recognized another ending for the space program: the end of its cold war connection.
"Clearly times have changed," said Norman R. Augustine, head of the committee and chairman of the Martin Marietta Corporation. "The heavy driver for the space program used to be competition with the Soviets. Today, there is not that clear competition, but the fundamental values of exploration that drive us. They are less tangible, but no less important."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Prices Increase

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The credit market rally continued yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell further.
The bulk of the gains were achieved during overseas trading, but the positive momentum generated by the weak November employment data released Friday continued to swirl even after activity shifted to American financial markets. 
 Even with yesterday's gains, traders said it would probably be difficult for the market to improve significantly this week.
"The unfortunate thing for us is that the employment number was so bad," one government bond trader said.
The Fed, reacting to the employment data, lowered its target on the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market on Friday, to 7.25 percent. But it made no announcement yesterday that it has decided to lower its discount rate, currently at 7 percent.
In spite of the Fed's failure to make that move, "there is a constant thought that at any point the Fed could lower the discount rate," said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
While a cut in the discount rate would have more of a psychological than practical effect on the economy, most market participants said they expect the Fed would follow a half-point reduction in the discount rate by cutting the funds rate again, to 7 percent.
"The market is still expecting a lot from the Fed," the bond trader said.
 
Drop in Short-Term Rates
 The steep drop in short-term rates that occurred last week was visible in the results of yesterday's weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 6.86 percent, down sharply from the average rate of 7.06 percent at last week's sale.
Meanwhile, six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 6.74 percent, compared with an average rate of 6.96 percent a week ago.
The rates are the lowest on three-month and six-month bills since auctions held in July, 1988.
Traders said that participation at the bill sale was good, but with rates now under 7 percent, Mr. Held and others said that investors seeking higher yields are now extending out the maturity spectrum, particularly into 30-year Treasury bonds.
"We are close to where appreciation in the bond is outperforming cash this year," Mr. Held said. "When you have an asset that is rising like that, there is a tendency on the part of money managers to get it on their books."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered late yesterday at a price of 106 31/32, up 5/8 a point, to yield 8.12 percent, compared with 8.17 percent late Friday. Barring any shooting in the Middle East, dealers said yields on the benchmark issue could soon slide below 8 percent.
Among Treasury notes, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 21/32, up 13/32, to yield 7.95 percent. And the 7 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 6/32, up 2/ 32, to yield 7.26 percent.
Participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market began what looks to be an active week by pricing a number of issues yesterday, including $266.79 million worth of securities for the Jacksonville Electric Authority.
Underwriters from Lehman Brothers acted as lead managers for the negotiated sale. The offering consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1996 to 2005 and a term bond that matures in 2007.
At pricing, yields on the serial bonds range from 6.05 percent in 1996 to 6.50 percent in 2000 and 6.80 percent in 2005. The term bond was priced to yield 6.85 percent.
Ratings of AA were expected from both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt securities, prices of widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 point, dealers said.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues were unchanged on the day, according to participants.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Weicker Nominates 3 For Social-Service Jobs

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Governor-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced three more nominations for his emerging independent administration today, including a Democrat to head the Department of Aging, a Republican to be in charge of economic development and a private businessman to oversee public housing.
The nominations, which must be approved by the Democrat-controlled General Assembly, are Mr. Weicker's first in the areas of social policy. The nominees gave little indication yesterday of their positions on major issues facing the state, and Mr. Weicker stressed even as the group was introduced at a State Capitol news conference that there would be little money in the deficit-ridden state budget for expensive new initiatives. 
 The nominees are State Representative Edith G. Prague as Commissioner of Aging, Joseph J. McGee as Commissioner of Economic Development and Henry S. Scherer Jr. as Commissioner of Housing.
Mr. Weicker, a former Republican, will take office next month as Connecticut's first independent governor since the 1850's. He has already nominated two Democrats to the top posts in his budget office and two Republicans to be his chiefs of staff.
 
A Diverse Group
 He said that all three nominees introduced today were longtime personal friends, but that they had little else common. "What stands out in this group is that it's very diverse," he said, adding that "since we don't have money, we need creativity and we need brains."
Mrs. Prague, a 65-year-old Democrat from Columbia, was among the first members of the General Assembly to endorse Mr. Weicker for governor earlier this year.
Mr. McGee, 44, is a Republican bank executive from Fairfield who briefly ran for governor himself earlier this year. He served as staff director in the 1970's for United States Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Fairfield.
Mr. Scherer, 59, is the chief executive of an East Hartford company that makes reinforced steel. He met Mr. Weicker in the early 1950's when they both attended Yale University. Of the three nominees, only Mr. Scherer, a registered Republican, said he would join A Connecticut Party, the party Mr. Weicker organized this spring around his candidacy.
 
Problems Ahead
 If approved by the General Assembly, the three commissioners will face daunting challenges, ranging from the state's slumping economy, which has battered cities like Bridgeport and Hartford, to the rising price of heating oil, which has affected thousands of elderly residents on fixed incomes.
Public housing, clustered in the state's poor cities, is also becoming a burden on local budgets in some communities. Hartford's City Manager, Eugene Shipman, suggested recently that the city's public housing projects be razed and new public housing distributed equally in rich and poor communities.
Asked about Mr. Shipman's proposal, Mr. Scherer said he needed to familiarize himself more with the issues. Mrs. Prague said she had avoided thinking about the grim realities she will face if appointed.
"I'm so excited today, I don't want to get depressed thinking about that," she said.
Mr. McGee said the focus of his agency would be "jobs, jobs, jobs," to help combat the recession that he said had already begun in Connecticut.

HEADLINE: Civic Groups to Sue, Urging Alternative to West Side Highway Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Charging that government officials had unlawfully ignored alternatives to rebuilding the West Side Highway as it stands, a coalition of civic groups in New York City announced yesterday that they will sue to force consideration of other approaches.
The groups, including the Municipal Art Society, the Parks Council and People for Westpride, will argue that a failure by city and state officials to review alternatives to the existing viaduct, which runs from 59th to 72d Street, violates Federal laws that require environmental reviews and protect parkland.At stake is the future of the Hudson River waterfront where Donald J. Trump dreams of building his enormous Trump City complex, but which the civic groups envision as a riverfront park, with development further east.
 
A Break With Dinkins
 The lawsuit, to be filed today in Federal Court in Manhattan, would also mark a rupture in relations between Mayor David N. Dinkins and a number of the civic leaders who had earlier cheered his pronouncements on city planning and community involvement in land-use issues. 
 "The honeymoon is over," said Kent L.Barwick, president of the art society. "The great disappointment is to find ourselves in court so soon after the nuptials.
"Here was a fine place for the new administration to fulfill its responsibilities instead of responding to highway engineers or bureaucrats in Albany. The fact that they didn't is not only disappointing. When it rises to the level it has here, it is unlawful."
The society and the Parks Council have successfully challenged city projects in court before, most notably in 1987, when they opposed a large development on the site of the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle. That suit forced the withdrawal and subsequent redesign of the proposal.In the West Side Highway project, government officials have been proceeding with an $85 million plan to rehabilitate and realign the existing elevated structure. Contractors' bids are due next month.
Private planners and environmentalists have urged for some time that the highway be lowered to ground level in the area of the former railroad yards north of 59th Street and that its course be shifted inland. That would create room for a 25-acre park along the river's edge. The road would run at grade level from 59th Street to 68th Street and then begin rising to meet the Henry Hudson Parkway at 72d Street.
In October, the Municipal Art Society, the Parks Council and the Westpride group believed they had an agreement with City Hall under which their proposal would be studied by a special committee for two months.
But Mr. Barwick said that a week after the agreement for a study was reached, Barbara J. Fife, Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development, called to say "that the city decided not to go through with the study."
Ms. Fife said yesterday: "It was not my impression that we had an agreement. It was my impression that there were several issues outstanding."
City officials argued yesterday, as they have in the past, that it would not be practical to delay the rehabilitation of the existing highway.
 
Assessing the Costs
 "The road is in a very, very bad state of disrepair," Ms. Fife said. "It would be misleading to indicate that we had a whole lot of time to let that condition continue. It would have been misleading to indicate that we had the capital money to build a replacement road. The road that is now out for bids is not being replaced with any city money."
The alternatives, Ms. Fife said, were "either to keep repairing the road, at the expense of almost everything else in the city, or set 90,000 cars a day on the streets of the West Side."
An engineering study conducted for the civic groups concluded that building costs for the alternative plan might range from $50 million to $75 million.
"The critical and somewhat startling finding," said Linda Davidoff, executive director of the Parks Council, "was that it was not only reasonable but cheaper than what the state had proposed to spend on repairing the highway."
Daniel Gutman, an environmental consultant to the Westpride group, said that only 30 percent of the cost of the current project would go toward structural repair, with the rest being spent on the realignment and expansion of the highway.
Philip K. Howard, vice president of the Municipal Art Society, said, "All we're asking them to do is some planning, to look at alternatives -- things they should do anyway."
An alternative highway would completely disrupt the Trump Organization's plans for the railyard site: a 150-story skyscraper and more than a dozen other high-rise buildings, a shopping center and parkland.

HEADLINE: Miami Journal;
Months of Regrets by All But Not a Single Apology

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Saying you're sorry is difficult for friends, sib lings and lovers. It can be especially hard for politicians, whose constituents will analyze every word and every sentiment, expressed or held silent. It can be virtually impossible for a politician who feels he has nothing to apologize for in the first place.
The politics of apologies are on display in this sunny city as stiff-necked and prideful representatives of two of Miami's major ethnic groups, blacks and Cubans, argue over the way Nelson Mandela was treated when he visited here five months ago. 
 A group of blacks, stung by what they considered the snubbing of Mr. Mandela by local politicians, is demanding that the political leaders apologize. Until they do, the black group has asked national black organizations not to hold meetings or conventions in the Miami area.
Calls for the boycott began after the Miami City Commission rescinded a proclamation welcoming Mr. Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress. The commissioners were angered by comments the South African nationalist had made praising President Fidel Castro of Cuba; Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the leader of Libya, and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, for their support of the battle against racial separation in South Africa.
 "There is nothing wrong with saying they disagree with him," H. T. Smith, the spokesman for the local group, Boycott Miami: Coalition for Progress, said of the commissioners. But he added, "Notwithstanding their personal feelings about Mr. Mandela's views, they have the responsibility as a result of their jobs to provide a minimal level of respect."
Local politicians, Mr. Smith said, have to realize how much hurt was caused among blacks. After an apology is given, Mr. Smith said, he wants to talk with business leaders about increasing opportunities for blacks in the tourism industry. Although blacks make up 20.5 percent of Dade County's population, they hold only 5.1 percent of the tourism jobs.
Ten black organizations have canceled gatherings that were to be held in Miami. The Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau estimates the cancellations will cost the economy about $5.4 million over the next several years, a small portion of the $245 million generated each year by conventions.
The National Organization for Women and the American Civil Liberties Union recently announced their support for the boycott.
On Nov. 29, one of the local politicians, Mayor Stephen Clark of Dade County, apologized but said he had nothing to do with any snubs.
"I'm the one who got snubbed," Mr. Clark said. "Here I am, the Mayor of two million people, and I wasn't invited to go to the airport. I wasn't invited to go to the podium. I wasn't asked to issue any proclamations."
Two other Mayors, Alex Daoud of Miami Beach and Xavier Suarez, Miami's Cuban-born Mayor, have steadfastly refused to say they are sorry, even though both admit Mr. Mandela's visit was not handled well.
The dispute further tears at the social fabric of a city where ethnic and racial resentments are continually bubbling to the surface.
"I was at a meeting and there was heated discussions with some Latin friends of mine over the Mandela incident," said Georgia Ayers, a social worker who is black. "One Latin man said he was insulted that Mandela would come into his living room and express such views. That really ticked me off. I consider his living room to be in Cuba."
"There are some people who are glad that black conventions are not coming to Miami," said Leslie Pantin, a Cuban who owns a public relations firm. Blacks must realize, he said, how much hurt was caused among Cubans by Mr. Mandela's remarks about President Castro.
Mr. Suarez came close to apologizing at a Nov. 29 news conference, in which he expressed regret about the handling of the visit. But Mr. Suarez stressed the word "regret" and said he was not apologizing.
Mr. Smith said that wasn't good enough.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Nationwide Banks Urged

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
A group of economists urged the Treasury today to allow banks to open branches nationwide, saying such a move would help restore health to the troubled industry.
"Nationwide branching would allow banks to capture the full benefits of diversification," said the group, known as the Shadow Financial Regulatory Committee. "It also would permit mergers that would help the banking system return to financial health."
Banks have only limited rights now to open branches beyond their home states. Typically, they must stay within their own region.
The economists say such constraints are responsible for the high rate of United States bank failures. They said such limits caused many failures in Texas when oil and real estate prices fell, and in the Midwest when farm incomes declined.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Sees $250 Million Budget Gap

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Having cut services to close a budget gap of nearly $400 million in the current fiscal year, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that because of expected cuts in state aid and projected tax shortfalls, New York City faced a new gap of $250 million and would have to trim still more.
Mr. Dinkins had warned that the state cuts might cost the city as much as $185 million, but he had not suggested how far the total budget could be pushed out of balance. Budget Director Philip R. Michael said possible further reductions in sales-tax receipts could push the gap to $300 million. 
 Mr. Michael said that at least half of the new gap would have to be closed through cuts in spending for workers or materials, with the rest to come from expected modest miscellaneous revenue increases or bond refinancings. But city officials said that making a $250 million adjustment over the remaining seven months of the fiscal year would be difficult.
 
'Further Action' and 'More Pain'
 At the same time, the city is struggling to make cuts to help close a gap of at least $1.3 billion for the 1992 fiscal year, which starts on July 1. That gap is the deficit the city says will remain out of a previous estimate of at least $1.6 billion, after accounting for the annual effect of the cuts already made.
In disclosing the new gap, Mr. Dinkins echoed the comments of fiscal monitors who suggested in recent weeks that the current budget was, at best, precariously balanced, despite the earlier cuts. The Mayor said the city would take "further action, albeit that that action is harsh," and plugging the new hole would bring "more pain."
Mr. Dinkins said he had not decided where the additional cuts would be made. But he said that a $40 million program of contingencies outlined last month -- including the closing of six fire companies, layoffs of teachers, cuts in garbage collection, reduced money for centers for the elderly and cuts in parks maintenance -- would be among the first options considered.
The Mayor made his comments as reporters at City Hall questioned him about a meeting he and top aides had yesterday morning with the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the Wall Street rating agency. Two months ago, the agency placed the city's bonds on a negative credit watch, a warning that it might lower the rating and thus force the city to pay more in interest.
With the city preparing to issue $1.3 billion in long-term bonds tomorrow, Standard & Poor's is to issue a statement on the city's credit today. Mr. Dinkins, who canceled two planned appearances to meet with the agency, acknowledged that "the question is whether or not they just leave us as we are" or lower the rating.
Given either possibility, it did Mr. Dinkins no harm to put out his latest bad news swiftly, though he did so in a matter-of-fact tone that seemed to bespeak how routine such periodic pronouncements have become at City Hall.
The announcement also kept up pressure on the city's municipal unions, which are negotiating new contracts, and on the State Legislature, whose approval is needed for the use of pension funds to finance part of Mr. Dinkins's 5.5 percent pay raise for teachers. The raise has drawn harsh criticism from fiscal monitors.
 
'An Enormous Hit'
 First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said the new gap was "an enormous hit," that "is going to be very difficult and very painful to be sure."
While Mr. Dinkins did not commit himself to cutting all of the specific programs that had already been identified as contingencies, Mr. Steisel said, "Generally speaking, the list would be implemented."
"There may be some fine tuning," he said. He said the city expected to outline the cuts next week, and to provide greater detail in January, when it will also announce its plans for closing next year's gap.
For next year, Mr. Michael has ordered most agencies to outline how they would cut up to 17.5 percent of their budgets, if need be. City officials have warned that thousands of layoffs or other severe service cuts might be needed, and agencies are now negotiating specific proposals.
 
$100 Million in State Cuts
 Of the new $250 million gap, Mr. Steisel said the city expected about $100 million to be caused by cuts in the state budget planned by the Cuomo administration, including money for education, Medicaid and unrestricted aid, with the remaining $150 million caused by more revenue shortfalls.
Mr. Michael said that $50 million of the shortfall was in sales-tax receipts, which had generally kept up with expectations because of inflation, but which have softened since the Persian Gulf crisis began. He said sales taxes might also slip $50 million more.
The remaining $100 million was in shortfalls in taxes related to real-estate transactions, Mr. Michael said.
Among the extra revenues that might help offset such declines, Mr. Michael said, is $25 million earmarked to begin Mr. Dinkins's broad anti-crime plan. If the State Legislature approves the special taxes that the city is seeking to finance the plan, the $25 million would no longer be needed, and could go toward balancing the budget.
Mr. Michael said he planned to maintain the city's general reserve fund at $150 million, as a cushion against possible further problems.
