HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
SHAMIR BARS DEAL WITH THE 'ENEMY'

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel said in a speech in New York City last night that his country would not acquiesce in any "move to appease Saddam Hussein at the expense of Israel."
In advance of his meeting with President Bush in Washington today, Mr. Shamir made it clear that Israel would reject any move in the United Nations or elsewhere to put pressure on it to give up some of its occupied Arab lands. Some governments have argued that this, by raising the Palestinian issue, might allow Iraq a chance to pull out of Kuwait in a face-saving manner. 
 Alluding to the discussions going on at the United Nations Security Council in which some governments are seeking language for a resolution calling for an international conference on Arab-Israeli issues, Mr. Shamir said: "The well-known argument will be that Israel should make a contribution, ostensibly for the sake of world peace."
 
No Munich for Israel
 "Let me, therefore, state at the very outset: Israel in 1990 is not Czechoslovakia of 1938," he went on. "We shall not acquiesce to any deal with enemies who wish to destroy us."
He was referring to the Munich agreement of 1938 in which Britain and France acceded to Hitler's demand that Czechoslovakia turn over the Sudetenland to Germany. The Government in Prague acquiesced and several months later Czechoslavakia was totally occupied by Germany. World War II broke out in September 1939 when Germany invaded Poland.
In a reference to the Bush Administration's stated position on the issue, Mr. Shamir added, "We trust the American Government's determined stand not to permit Saddam Hussein to link the gulf crisis with the Arab-Israeli conflict and the Palestinian issue."
Mr. Shamir spoke at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan, where he received the $100,000 Defender of Jerusalem Award -- formerly known as the Jabotinsky Award -- given annually by the Jabotinsky Foundation, which is named after Vladimir Jabotinsky (1880-1940), a Russian-born right-wing Zionist leader and author.
The award went to Mr. Shamir "in recognitiion of his lifetime commitment to the defense of Jewish rights and to the safety and security of Israel."
 
A Signal From Shamir
 Officials familiar with Mr. Shamir's thinking said that he was signaling that Israel would not accept even a hint that, after an eventual settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis, there might be some sort of after-the-fact linkage with the Arab-Israeli confrontation.
They suggested that the signal indicated that Israel would not acquiesce in any regional settlement involving it and the Arabs if such a settlement were to be in any way a quid pro quo for a settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis.
In a reference to the United Nations, Mr. Shamir contended that "free and democratic states continue to cater to the pressures and threats of a group of dictatorial governments" led by the Palestine Liberation Organization.
"Enemies of freedom, democracy and basic human rights cannot be prophets of progress," he went on. "Nor can the U.N. open a new chapter as long as dictatorships like Libya and Iraq can sit in the Security Council, while Israel is the one U.N. member excluded" from it.
 
180,000 Soviet Jews in '90
 Mr. Shamir also noted the influx of Soviet Jews into Israel and the economic burden it puts on the country. He is expected to ask Mr. Bush for more economic aid to Israel to ease the absorption of the new immigrants.
Mr. Shamir said that by the end of 1990, the total number of Soviet immigrants "could arrive at a figure of 180,000 for the year," which he said "equals the number of all the Russian Jews who came to Israel in the 20 years from 1968 to 1988."
Indeed, he said: "There is now a realistic expectation that we may increase our population by one million in the next three to five years. This is equivalent to the United States' absorbing 60 million immigrants in three to five years."
While praising the influx as "nothing short of a miracle," he said, "it is a mammoth undertaking to receive them and absorb them, to house, educate and provide jobs for hundreds of thousands of people."
 
$40 Billion in 4 Years
 "The estimated cost for all this in the next three or four years is around $40 billion," he said. "To provide such a vast sum will require the joint effort, the aggregate strength and the collective thinking and ingenuity of the entire Jewish people," both those in Israel and elsewhere.
He went on to express what he called "our people's profound gratitude to successive U.S. Administrations for their invaluable assistnce in our efforts and struggle for the repatriation in Israel of our brethren from the Soviet Union."
Mr. Shamir did not allude specifically to the possibility of additional United States Government aid, but he observed that, "Everyone, Jew or gentile, who stands up for the right of the Jewish people, for the justice of our cause, who has fought for the repatriation of our brethren from the Soviet Union, who has recognized the uniqueness of Jerusalem as the united capital of our state, contributes to the modern miracle of Israel."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, left, with Marvin Lender, national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, before Mr. Shamir addressed the group at a luncheon yesterday at Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan. (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MOSCOW ASKS U.S. FOR FOOD SUPPLIES; BAKER HINTS AT AID

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
For the first time, the Soviet Union publicly asked the United States today for food supplies to help it overcome shortages in major cities. In response, the Bush Administration indicated it would provide some kind of aid.
Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze made the appeal in response to a reporter's question at the start of two days of talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. Mr. Baker, at the same exchange with the press, said the Bush Administration intended to be "very forthcoming." 
 Mr. Shevardnadze was in Houston, Mr. Baker's hometown, to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis and how to overcome the remaining obstacles to a treaty limiting strategic nuclear weapons. President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hope to sign the treaty at their next summit meeting, which is expected to take place early next year.
 
Touchy Issue for the U.S.
 Food aid for the Soviet Union has become a touchy issue for the Administration, which has resisted joining Germany and other nations in giving outright grants to the Soviet Union. The Administration has said that aid is really not needed because there are no production shortages, only a breakdown in the distribution system.
But Mr. Baker, in his comments today, suggested that the Administration might be rethinking its policy on grants given the highly publicized shortages of food in major Soviet cities. He declined to specify how or when aid might be offered, but the President can provide help any time by executive order, as he did after the earthquake in Soviet Armenia in December 1988.
In addition to outright grants, the Administration could also make it easier for the Soviets to buy grain and other food by extending credits, currently barred by law.
 
Bush Considering a Waiver
 But Mr. Baker still would not say when the Bush Administration would waive the long-standing barriers to extending credits to Moscow erected because of its once-restrictive emigration policies. A waiver would open the way for the Soviets to obtain easy credits to buy American food to ease the shortages. President Bush said last week that a waiver was under serious consideration.
The National Conference on Soviet Jewry, an umbrella group of American organizations, has said it would support a waiver. And Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel said on Sunday that he favored lifting the barrier for a year or more.
"I think it's time to do it in order to help them," he said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
Although Germany, other Western nations and private relief groups like CARE have begun sending food and other aid to the Soviet Union, the Bush Administration has taken the view up to now that the shortages are largely a distribution problem that would not be remedied by simply dumping more food into the system.
 
Soviets 'Would Appreciate' Aid
 Pressed on why the United States did not set up its own distribution system to see that any aid is properly channeled, as the Germans have done, Administration officials said that the Soviets had not asked for help.
But today Mr. Shevardnadze asked.
As Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze were preparing to begin their discussions at the Houstonian Hotel, the Soviet minister was asked whether the time was not ripe for the United States to offer some aid, in the form of medical supplies or loan guarantees, so Moscow could buy food on easy terms.
"We would appreciate it," Mr. Shevardnadze answered.
Asked what kind of aid the Soviets would like most, Mr. Shevardnadze said: "Probably some food supplies -- that is the most acute problem -- and, of course, efficient economic cooperation."
Mr. Baker was then asked for his response. He drew a clear distinction between emergency food and medical aid, which the Administration could provide on humanitarian grounds, and trade credits allowing the Soviets to buy American food themselves.
The position of the Bush Administration has long been that the Soviet Parliament must first approve a law enshrining free emigration before it will waive the Jackson-Vanik amendment and other legal restrictions against preferential trade credits for the Soviet Union. The amendment is named after the late Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, and Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio.
 
Bush Said to Be Willing
 "The President is considering this question," Mr. Baker said. "He has also expressed an interest and, indeed, a willingness to be of assistance to the Soviet Union as they make this transition from one system to another -- a transition that's not simple. It's something that hasn't been done before.
"So the United States," Mr. Baker continued, "would want to be of assistance in ways that we can be. Now there are legal restrictions having to do with 40 or 45 years of history of the cold war. But as far as humanitarian assistance, medical assistance, food assistance, and that sort of thing, I know the President will be very forthcoming with respect to that kind of help."
That Mr. Shevardnadze would make a somewhat embarrassing public appeal for American food aid is a measure of both the desperate condition of the Soviet economy and the degree of cooperation that now characterizes United States-Soviet relations. The Soviet Ambassador to France, Yuri V. Dubinin, made a similar appeal in Paris last week.
The Soviets may be hoping that if they can line up enough foreign commitments of food aid, Soviet citizens will take note of it and stop hoarding, which has caused many of the distribution-related shortages. By all accounts there is no famine in the Soviet Union today. Rather, the economy, caught in the transition between central planning and a free market, is experiencing widespread chaos and shortages, prompted by breakdowns in food deliveries, hoarding, black marketeering and corruption.
 
U.S. Course Unclear
 But the seeming change in American thinking on this issue is no less striking. It is a measure of how much the Bush Administration wants to see Mr. Gorbachev's Government remain in power and keep the Soviet Union intact at a time when its cooperation has been essential in forging an international coalition to confront Iraq. Turmoil in the Soviet Union could spill over into Eastern Europe and also erase the possibility of the United States and the Soviets signing their first treaty reducing strategic nuclear arms.
How the Administration intends to proceed was not immediately clear. For several weeks it has been talking to the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association about the possibility of arranging an emergency shipment of medical supplies to the Soviet Union, which is suffering a shortage because of faulty production.
 
Emigration Bill Bogged Down
 President Bush said on Nov. 30 that he was considering waiving the Jackson-Vanik amendment for one year, even though the emigration bill is still bogged down in the Soviet Parliament. That would make the cash-strapped Soviets eligible for Commodity Credit Corporation loans to buy American food on easy terms.
Mr. Shevardnadze is to meet with Mr. Bush at the White House on Wednesday, and some clearer indication of how the Administration plans to proceed could come then.
During a break from their talks today, Mr. Baker took Mr. Shevardnadze on a tour of the Johnson Space Center here. Mr. Shevardnadze said during the visit that he expected Washington and Moscow to make "good progress" in their long effort to settle the Afghan conflict.
Reports from Pakistan suggest that the United States and the Soviet Union may issue a joint declaration this week extricating themselves from the 12-year civil war in Afghanistan, and leave the country to find a solution on its own.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Freeing the Hostages

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
No, it was not Saddam Hussein who freed the hostages held in Iraq. It was George Bush. His instrument was not the United Nations or economic pressure. It was the threat that if they were not released, American armed power would be used to destroy their jailer.
Let's understand that now, before history is rewritten by Saddam Hussein's allies and apologists. Already stories are being broadcast about how King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat talked him into it. 
 Seems they looked deep into his eyes and told him that for the sake of peace he must release the hostages. Saddam Hussein clapped his forehead and said, "Boys, I never thought of that; I will do it."
The gilding of Saddam Hussein will begin any day now -- "He's not such a bad fellow, you have to understand him." It already has started with Saddam Hussein's terrorist twin, Hafez al-Assad of Syria.
We are told by liberals and conservatives that we should actually thank Mr. Assad for making Lebanon his colony. All those Lebanese he slaughtered, all those years? Well, what were they doing standing there in the way of Syrian shells, silly people.
Mr. Bush himself, while opposing Saddam Hussein, gives Mr. Assad respectability. Consistency -- who needs it? So before the process of turning Saddam Hussein into a teddy bear begins, let's learn the lesson of the hostage release.
President Bush said American goals in the Persian Gulf were to reject aggression, liberate Kuwait, restore the royal family -- and free the hostages.
Somehow the objectives of stopping one more Arab-against-Arab foray or restoring the oil princelings of Kuwait to full use of their bank accounts did not fire the American imagination or psyche.
The only one of those goals that moved Americans was liberating the hostages. About that Mr. Bush neither blustered nor wimped. He assembled a powerful American force of troops, tanks, planes and ships. He made sure publicly and through every back channel that Saddam Hussein knew he would pay if the hostages were not freed, not just with his face but his whole head.
For Saddam Hussein the hostages became a vivid danger instead of an asset. Their release would bring him two connected benefits. One was to remove the certainty of the use of American power to release them. The second was to stoke U.S. Congressional and public opposition to use of force to "punish" aggression by restoring the Kuwaiti royal family.
Still -- if Mr. Bush had done what other Presidents did about the hostage-taking, just wail, the hostages would still be in Iraq. So when the toasts are raised about the hostages, save one for the President.
But he made an initial mistake from which he has not recovered, and which can be Saddam Hussein's salvation. Mr. Bush did not give Americans the one overriding reason for using force, other than the hostages. The one other goal Americans might have accepted if put to them and Congress was the destruction of the chemical power, nuclear potential and missile capability of a dictator for whom terrorism, aggression and expansionism are the very breath and bread of life.
So after kidnapping thousands of foreigners, costing the world hundreds of billions of dollars, virtually wiping out Kuwait as a national entity, Saddam Hussein will have paid no price, zero. Eventually he will offer to retire from Kuwait, on the understanding, which probably will be accepted by Washington and the Arab world, that he then "negotiate" with his Arab brothers about getting an oilfield and two gulf islands from Kuwait.
Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the other oil states will then pour billions into Iraq, just as they did before the invasion of Kuwait. Syria will allow the West to replace the bankrupt Soviet Union as its arms supplier.
The U.S. will make a big noise about keeping a coalition "presence" in the area. But never again will the Arab nations muster to oppose Saddam Hussein. He will not need to send his tanks to control the oil supply of the gulf and thus the world. He can do it by telephone.
If the Bush Administration is unwilling to ask the American public and Congress to act now to prevent Saddam Hussein's control of the gulf and consequent domination of the Arab Middle East, there is no point keeping American troops in the desert to watch him enjoy his cost-free triumph. And while we give Mr. Bush deserved praise for rescuing the hostages, Saddam Hussein can put up his boots, and also raise a toast -- to himself.

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Look Who's Coming!

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
Following is a copy of the memo prepared for President Bush on the eve of one of his infrequent appearances in Washington:
 I. Airport arrival: The customary red carpet from Air Force One to the President's local transportation vehicle will be dispensed with at the instance of Richard Darman, budget director, citing the following justifications: 
 1. Since the President will be arriving on native soil it would seem unpatriotic, hence politically unwise, to allow carpeting of any color whatever to be placed between his feet and the American earth or its modern equivalents such as asphalt, concrete, oil slicks, cigarette butts, discarded beer cans and so forth.
 2. The President will be arriving in a country that has great trouble paying its bills. By avoiding the expense of red carpeting, the President can, without preaching, illustrate his belief that the destitute should never lavish their last penny on frills, especially if the penny be borrowed.
 3. Because carpeting is historically associated with Islamic culture, using it for the President's arrival in a capital with unique problems in the Middle East would be diplomatically unsound, since (a) Arab states might take offense at having this cultural symbol trod underfoot in a place like Washington, and (b) Israel might interpret purchase of the necessary carpeting as a sly scheme for subsidizing its Arab enemies.
 Two other customary airport ceremonies will be abandoned for this visit at the direction of John Sununu, White House adviser in charge of being photographed looking over the President's shoulder all over the world:
 1. The playing of "The Star-Spangled Banner" followed by the host nation's anthem will be dropped since the host country's anthem in this case is also "The Star-Spangled Banner." Consecutive renditions of this anthem ("even longer than it sounds," Mark Twain said of it) would not be "sound-bite friendly," and might renew the television industry's agitation for a new national anthem that can be played from start to finish in 10 seconds.
 2. The customary greeting of the President by the host country's head of state will be dispensed with, since this would require the President to talk to himself in public, which might be politically unsound. The idea that the President be greeted by John Sununu was dismissed after Mr. Sununu noted that it would be impossible for him to be photographed looking over the President's shoulder if he had to come around front to do the greeting.
 II. Arrival in Washington: Helicopter transport will carry the President from airport to White House. During this trip he will cross the infamous Beltway. Despite the altitude, he could recognize that he had passed inside the Beltway if he were to glance down and see the hordes of unreal people swarming below.
 This bleak mass of unreality always depresses the President. ("How nice it is to be out where the real people are -- outside of Washington, D.C.," he said recently on a visit to Nebraska.) To help the President avoid the sight, thick curtains will be drawn across the helicopter windows before intra-Beltway incursion takes place.
 During this blackout period he will be briefed on the time zone he has entered (Eastern standard), the name of the country (the United States of America), its numerical status (still Number One), the identity of its leader (George Bush of Yale, C.I.A., Skull and Bones, and U.S. Naval Aviation), the names of everyone important whom he should recognize (James Baker) and photographs of same to help him do so.
 III. Situational briefing: Immediately upon entering the White House, the President will go to the Situational Briefing Room to be briefed on the status of all pertinent situations as they have developed since his last visit to Washington. Situations to be briefed upon are as follows:
 Collapse of the domestic coalition behind his Persian Gulf policy; onset of a nationwide economic recession; the unchecked reign of murder and drug abuse; the rise in illegitimate births, homelessness and AIDS; deepening of the racial divide between whites and blacks; continuing rise of the budget deficit despite new taxes; a fresh budget nightmare created by adding the new multibillion-dollar military bill for Persian Gulf policy to staggering savings and loan bailout costs; the Japanese purchase of Hollywood . . .
 IV. Medical: At bedtime the President will suggest that another trip outside Washington may be just what the doctor would like to order, eh, Doc?

HEADLINE: Deposit Insurance Victimizes the Taxpayer;
Use Treasury Securities

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As you argue in "A Better Way to Protect Deposits" (editorial, Nov. 26), we must stop allowing savings and loan institutions and banks to take risks with Government-insured deposits. The equity stakes of stockholders are too trivial (often zero) to deter excessive risk taking at the expense of taxpayers. A big enough increase in required capital ratios is not conceivable. 
 I propose a requirement that insured deposits be backed by safe assets, mainly Treasury securities, segregated and dedicated to the redemption of those deposits. Let banks -- and savings and loans, if they survive separately -- also offer uninsured higher-yield deposits under usual regulation and supervision. Make clear that taxpayers will not bail out insolvent institutions, no matter how big, or their uninsured depositors.
No ceiling on deposit insurance per account or per depositor would be necessary. The $100,000 ceiling has been made virtually meaningless by the ingenuity of sophisticated depositors and their brokers, and by decisions of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation to rescue all depositors of institutions deemed too big to let fail or depositors in insolvent institutions acquired with hefty Federal subsidies.
Given this history of discretionary liberality with taxpayers funds, the F.D.I.C.'s strict treatment of the unsophisticated charities and other large depositors at Harlem's Freedom Bank is outrageous.
The Treasury is reported to be preparing proposals for further deregulation of banks. But until deposit insurance is reformed, it would be foolhardy to expand the scope of bank activities.
 
JAMES TOBIN
New Haven, Nov. 28, 1990
 
The writer retired as Sterling Professor of Economics at Yale University.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Industry Outlook Viewed as Gloomy

BYLINE: By JEREMY GERARD

 BODY:
A subdued, almost confessional atmosphere pervaded yesterday's start of Paine Webber's annual conference on the outlook for the media, a weeklong meeting in New York.
Top executives in the communications industries invariably began this year's prognostications by apologizing for last year's, citing recession, the crisis in the Persian Gulf, strikes at newspaper printing plants and other factors for declines in growth. 
 "Last year, I was further off the mark in my projections than I had been in all of the seven previous years combined," David F. Poltrack, CBS senior vice president for planning and research, told about 100 media analysts and industry executives. He had projected an increase in revenues for the three major broadcast networks of 8 to 9 percent; the true figure, he said, would more likely be around 2 percent. He predicted the same 2 percent for next year.
 
Underestimation by CBS
 While ABC and NBC overestimated their ratings for this television season, forcing them to offer advertisers extra time, Mr. Poltrack added, CBS underestimated, and thus would end the year in a stronger position, free of make-good obligations. ABC is owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc. and the National Broadcasting Company is a General Electric Company unit.
Still, Mr. Poltrack said, short-term advertising purchases would be down throughout the industry in the fourth quarter. Most startling, he added, was that the share of the prime-time audience belonging to the three major networks was eroding faster than industry projections, to 64.4 percent from 68.1 percent this season. By 1995, he said, the three-network share in prime time will probably drop to the middle-50's, with Fox, independent stations, cable and public television taking the rest.
 
Profitability Drop Seen
 William G. Moll, the vice president and general manager of the NBC flagship station, Channel 4 in New York, said that while local stations would continue to be profitable, the rate of profitablility would probably drop from around 15 percent five years ago to around 3 or 4 percent. "Belt-tightening and staff downsizing will continue," Mr. Moll added. "We're doing it with fewer and fewer."
The outlook for cable television, on the other hand, could not be brighter -- especially for basic channels -- said Marshal Cohen, the executive vice president of MTV Networks, a unit of Viacom Inc. "Advertiser-supported basic cable has never been better," he said, because the channels have two revenue sources -- subscribers and advertisers -- and a low-cost product. There was also a consensus among the cable executives that Congress would again fail to pass cable regulation legislation.
But that forecast was the only gleam of light offered by the assembled executives.
 
'Culling of the Flock'
 "It is cold outside today in our business," said Donald M. Elliman Jr., the executive vice president for marketing and group publisher for Time Warner Inc. There has been a flood of magazines in the marketplace, and the resulting "selective agony" would mean a "culling of the flock," he said. But the survivors, he added, mostly personality, life style, fashion and entertainment magazines, would emerge stronger and healthier, saying that " '91 will not be a year for the faint-hearted."
William T. Kerr, the president of The New York Times Company's magazine group, said that "trendy high-fliers," like 7 Days, Smart and Spy, had not ended the year as they began it: 7 Days failed; Smart, struggling to survive, is scheduled to reappear later this month as Smart for Men, while Spy went through a restructuring.
Magazines directed toward highly targeted, specialized, upscale readers, he said, would do well.
"Let us pray," said Jack Butcher, the circulation director of The Tampa (Fla.) Tribune as he began his presentation, drawing the only laugh of the day. He added that the biggest growth areas for newspapers would be in small suburban dailies, although the major dailies in Atlanta and Los Angeles were also doing extremely well.
He said that newspapers were read most frequently by people middle-aged and older, and that the increase of that group in the next decade could be a boon to newspapers.
Profit margins for the papers will continue to shrink, said Gordon Medenica, vice president for corporate planning at the Times Company, because of "a large base of fixed costs," as well as the economic factors that have affected all of the industries.
"Ninety-one will be a difficult year for the industry," he said later, as if summing up for everyone, "But we will remain profitable."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 15, 1990, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Media Business pages on Tuesday about a media outlook conference misstated a prediction by William G. Moll, vice president and general manager of WNBC- TV. He said that in 1991 television station revenues, not profitability, would rise 3 to 5 percent over last year, and that profitability would increase slightly more.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Chief Is Named By Peabody Holding

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
The Peabody Holding Company, the nation's largest coal producer, yesterday named Irl F. Engelhardt president and chief executive.
Mr. Engelhardt, who is 44 years old, succeeds Robert H. Quenon, 62, who has been named chairman and is scheduled to retire in August. Mr. Quenon is a longtime coal executive who has been with Peabody since 1977. 
 Peabody, based in St. Louis, was acquired this year by Hanson Industries P.L.C., the British conglomerate. "Hanson is an interesting and fun company," Mr. Engelhardt said yesterday. "They have put their touch on Peabody, focusing keenly on strong earnings and have looked at the way our organization is shaped and made sure we de-layered it." As a result of the streamlining, Peabody has trimmed the number of employees.
Peabody can now "make fast decisions and move rapidly," Mr. Engelhardt said.
"By and large," he said about Hanson, "as long as we can meet our earnings projection and stay within the financial controls, they tend to let us run our business reasonably free of day-to-day involvement."
Right now, he said, the company "is looking carefully at the impact of a recession, as to whether it will have an impact on our utility customers." He said he thought the country might escape a serious recession "if we don't talk ourselves into one."
Mr. Engelhardt received a degree in accounting from the University of Illinois at Urbana in 1968 and an M.B.A. from Southern Illinois University in 1971. From 1968 to 1972 he managed the audit and tax divisions of a regional accounting firm in Champaign, Ill. From 1972 to 1979 he worked in the consulting division of Arthur Andersen.
"Peabody was one of my clients," he said, "and I got to know the company."
He joined the coal producer in 1979. Most recently he has been president of Peabody Development, a unit that manages coal marketing, purchases and other functions for Peabody.
The company he will now head mined 9 percent of the coal produced in the United States last year. It operates both surface and underground mines and has a presence in all major American coal fields.
Hanson, the parent, owns several diverse American businesses, including Jacuzzi, Endicott Johnson, Kaiser Cement and Gold Fields Mining.

HEADLINE: Armand Hammer Dies at 92; Executive Forged Soviet Ties

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Company who long sought peace between the United States and the Soviet Union and financed research for a cancer cure, died at his home last night in Los Angeles. He was 92 years old.
The cause of death was not immediately reported. Frank Ashley, a spokesman for Occidental Petroleum, said Mr. Hammer "died after a brief illness." 
 Dr. Hammer, who built and led Occidental Petroleum for 33 years, at one time or another headed successful businesses in fields ranging from art to bourbon whiskey.
Dr. Hammer, who was trained as a physician but never set up a medical practice, was also a noted philanthropist and art collector who hobnobbed with the high and mighty, including members of the British royal family and generations of Soviet leaders.
Dr. Hammer bequeathed his art collection to a new museum he opened in Los Angeles on Nov. 28 in a zebra-striped building that adjoins the headquarters of Occidental Petroleum, where he was chairman and chief executive officer.
Last summer, the heirs of Dr. Hammer's late wife, Frances, who died last year at 87, filed a lawsuit contending that Dr. Hammer had tricked her into signing away her part of their collection, valued at $400 million. Dr. Hammer called the charges scurrilous.
Dr. Hammer had planned to celebrate his own bar mitzvah tonight, like much of what he did, in public. Dr. Hammer, who was raised in a non-observant family, planned to link the ceremony to a fund-raising dinner at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. The dinner was to benefit two organizations, the Pacific Jewish Center and the Jerusalem College of Technology.
Over the years, he was variously president and chairman of the Mutual Broadcasting System and president of such diverse companies as the J. W. Dant Distilling Company and the A. Hammer Pencil Company of New York, London and Moscow.
"I am first and foremost a catalyst -- I bring people and situations together," Dr. Hammer once said in discussing his long business career.
A short and forceful man with a quick smile appraising eyes,he became involved in American-Soviet trade very early, in 1921, and maintained ties with the Soviet Union for more than 60 years, with a hiatus during Stalin's ascendancy.
Dr. Hammer wrote in 1985 that his involvement with the Soviet Union reflected a belief "that nuclear war must be avoided and that the chances for peace can best be preserved by building the bonds of culture and commerce."
In the mid-1950's, already a multimillionaire, he invested in Occidental, then a small and struggling company. By 1986, after he had headed it for 29 years, he could boast that it had become "the eighth-biggest energy concern in the United States and the 12th-biggest industrial corporation," with gross revenues of about $16 billion that year.
As a businessman Dr. Hammer was inventive, daring and energetic. His talents brought him so much money that he said he could not count it, and he prolonged his business career into his nineties.
"I love business," he once said. "I love my work. I can't wait to start a new day."
 
His Motives Were Questioned
 Although he profited spectacularly from his dealings with the Soviet Union, his motives were sometimes questioned. He wrote in his best-selling autobiography, "Hammer," that his Russian-born father, Julius Hammer, was recruited, while a Connecticut steelworker, into the Socialist Labor Party. It was the leading Marxist party in the United States in the last quarter of the 19th century and a forerunner of the American Communist Party -- of which, Dr. Hammer wrote, his father was a founding member in 1919.
Some people contended that Dr. Hammer's early success in trading with the Soviet Union was nourished by Julius Hammer's connections in the Moscow Government. There were also insinuations that Dr. Hammer shared his father's political sympathies, a view he denied.
Nonetheless, Dr. Hammer sometimes expressed views of the Soviet Union that, coming from an American millionaire, seemed strikingly uncritical. In an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times in 1987, he and a co-author wrote that "to some extent, the Soviet Union lacks the delicate balance present in our society between technological achievements and human values."
In "Hammer," which came out in 1987, Dr. Hammer wrote that he had met with the Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev many times, finding him "a man of great humanism and vast warmth."
Appraising the book in The New York Times Book Review, Ted Morgan contended that Dr. Hammer, "in order to maintain his 'most favored person' position with the Russians, becomes disturbingly sycophantic."
Mr. Morgan also contended that "Dr. Hammer presents himself as the architect of world peace, instrumental in arranging the 1985 Geneva summit between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan" while "in fact, he is more like an enthusiastic amateur trying to break into the major leagues, a George Plimpton of international relations."
Dr. Hammer was also involved in United States politics. A lifelong Democrat, he was convicted in 1976 of making illegal campaign contributions totaling $54,000 to President Richard M. Nixon's 1972 re-election campaign, fined $3,000 and put on one year's probation. Years later Dr. Hammer contended that he should not have pleaded guilty and that he had been the victim of misdeeds by an associate, He was pardoned by
Despite the controversy Dr. Hammer sometimes aroused, he retained the friendship and esteem of many famous people. Two former presidents, Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter, endorsed his autobiography. Mr. Ford said Mr. Hammer was "a unique individual in the business and geopolitical world." Mr. Carter said he had "a unique standing in both the United States and the Soviet Union."
 
Art, Cattle, a Park And a Boeing 727
 Over the years, Dr. Hammer's various holdings, interests and possessions were staggeringly diverse. There was his own plane, a Boeing 727, in addition to the art galleries: the Hammer Galleries Inc. and Knoedler & Company, in New York City. He had on his desk in Los Angeles inscribed pictures of important people from Lenin to President Ronald Reagan. For a while, he owned Campobello Island, the Roosevelt family's retreat; he gave it to the United States and Canada in 1962 as an international park.
His purchases included champion Aberdeen Angus cattle and a costly Leonardo da Vinci manuscript, as well as the Hooker Chemical Company. During the nine years he spent in the Soviet Union, beginning in 1921, he invested in art works that he called treasures of the Romanovs -- the family of the Czars of Russia from 1613 until the Revolution in 1917.
Dr. Hammer gave away a great deal of the money that he made. "I have a seven-figure income and give away 90 percent of it," he said in 1980. He headed the Armand Hammer Foundation, which gave millions of dollars a year to charitable causes.
Some instances of his largesse were the $5 million that he gave to Columbia University in 1977; the 1,000 lithographs by Daumier that he gave to the Corcoran Gallery of Art in 1983, and the gift of $1 million to the Metropolitan Museum that was announced in 1986. Its purpose was to help renovate its arms and armor galleries at the museum. In recognition of his patronage of the arts, Dr. Hammer was chosen in 1987 to receive a National Medal for the Arts.
In 1988 he announced plans to build a $30 million cultural center and museum in Los Angeles for his art collections. The New York Times critic, John Russell, wrote at the time that "the collections are particularly strong in European Old Master paintings and drawings. Among the masters represented are Raphael, Correggio, Ingres, Rubens, Rembrandt, Watteau, Fragonard, Tiepolo, Boucher, Cezanne,Gauguin, Renoir and van Gogh."
Mr. Russell said Dr. Hammer's $250 million valuation of the collections was conservative.
Dr. Hammer also had what Mr. Russell called a remarkable collection of European Old Master drawings, which he gave it to the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
That same year Dr. Hammer initiated an ambitious, four-year campaign to raise $500 million from private sources for cancer research. The drive officially got under way in October 1988, but in its first few weeks only about $13 million in private funds was donated.
Dr. Hammer's role in the campaign stirred much praise and some misgivings. Some cancer researchers and specialists voiced concern that it might lead to too much money being put into research involving the body's immune defense system, a field in which he was particularly interested.
Named for Hero Or Socialist Symbol? Dr. Hammer was born on the Lower East Side of Manhattan on May 21, 1898, the son of Julius Hammer and Rose Robinson Hammer. In "Hammer," Dr. Hammer wrote that his father named him Armand "after Armand Duval, the romantic hero in Dumas's 'La Dame aux Camelias,' although others suggested he obviously had in mind the symbol of the Socialist Labor Party -- an arm and a hammer."
Dr. Hammer's business career began when he was a medical student at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. In "Hammer," he wrote that his father, who had become a physician and a pharmaceuticals manufacturer, was in poor health and called on him to take over his business. The young Hammer did so and, while continuing his studies, prospered mightily. "Average income in the United States in 1919 was about $625 a year," he wrote, while "my personal income was over $1 million net."
When he graduated from medical school in 1921, he had six months to wait before beginning his internship. But other events intervened. There was a typhus epidemic, along with other problems, in the Soviet Union at the time, four years after the revolution; and he decided to go there, thinking he would work as a doctor. When he arrived, he found that the major problem was starvation, not typhus. Then, he wrote, "there came to me the single proposition which most dramatically changed my life" -- the idea, which he swiftly acted on, of trading American grain for furs and other goods from the Soviet Union.
Before long, Dr. Hammer attracted the attention of Lenin, who needed foreign investment and who gave the young American a concession for asbestos in the Urals. Dr. Hammer wrote in "Hammer" that the concession was not as successful as he himself had hoped, but it was the start of a profitable trading relationship. He soon became the representative of three dozen American companies.
 
Enter Stalin, Exit Hammer
 In 1925, he asked for a pencil concession. He received it, and with the aid of experts and technology from Germany, he produced $2.5 million worth of pencils in his first year. y 1930, he was employing 1,000 workers and producing nearly 500,000 pencils a day.
But Stalin came into power, and, he wrote, it was clear "that Stalin was not a man with whom you could do business." Mainly for that reason, he wrote, he left the Soviet Union.
In the decades that followed, Dr. Hammer made money in a variety of fields, including the sale of art that he had acquired in the Soviet Union, the production of beer and whiskey barrels and the operation of a number of distilleries. After greatly expanding sales at J. W. Dant Bonded Bourbon, he sold the distillery for $6.5 million and moved to California in 1955, thinking he would retire.
But unlimited leisure bored him, and he began investing in Occidental, which then had assets of less than $100,000. He found the oil business, he wrote years later, "more exciting, more interesting, more complex, riskier and more rewarding than any other business I had encountered."
In the late 1950's, he also invested in the Mutual Broadcasting System, and he ran that company for a time himself. But he sold out, for a profit of $1.3 million, he later recalled, partly because he was "much more excited about Occidental."
As chairman and chief executive of Occidental, he hired oil-industry experts, much as he had hired pencil-making experts 30 years before. The company grew, and by 1967 its assets were more than $1 billion.
In 1966, after years of intricate negotiations, Occidental Petroleum was awarded two oil concessions in Libya. Within two years, it was exporting more than 200,000 barrels of oil a day.
In 1973, Dr. Hammer's luck seemed to turn sour. Libya's radical new Government put pressure on Occidental, by then the country's largest single oil producer, and later that year, it turned over 51 percent of the company to the Government for $135 million. Occidental also agreed to higher taxes and a 30 percent price increase.
The move by Occidental, which soon led to similar accommodations by other oil producers in Libya, has been described as changing the world economy. It was the first time that an oil-producing country had dictated oil prices, and it set the stage for the dramatic increase in influence of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Nevertheless, Occidental continued to prosper, moving into oil production in Peru and the North Sea, among other areas.
 
New Troubles In the 1970's
 In the 1970's, Dr. Hammer's free-wheeling business style brought him different kinds of trouble. A successful battle by the Mead Corporation, an Ohio-based forest products company, to resist a takeover by Occidental turned up information that prompted Federal and state investigations into Dr. Hammer's and Occidental's activities.
According to informants close to the takeover attempt, Occidental abandoned the move after investigators began looking into Dr. Hammer's art dealings. One allegation that was bruited about, although he contended it was only "a lot of gossip," was that he had made an improper payment of $100,000 in the early 1970's to the Soviet Minister of Culture, Yekaterina A. Furtseva, to facilitate an art exchange.
His involvement with the Soviet Union continued into the 1980's. After the nuclear power plant leak in 1986 at Chernobyl, he dispatched an international group of physicians to deliver medicine and medical care. In that same year, after he had conferred with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, works of art that he had collected went on display in Soviet cities.
Also in 1986, the Soviet authorities permitted Dr. Hammer to take an ailing Jewish scientist, David Goldfarb, from a hospital in Moscow and fly him and his wife to the United States.
Even in his 90's Dr. Hammer remained prominent in Occidental's management and continued to personify the company. Through the decades, he was also variously a director of numerous organizations and business concerns, including banks and companies in the petroleum industry and other fields.
In 1986 he became affiliated with the Church & Dwight Company, which makes Arm & Hammer, the baking soda brand, when Occidental bought a stake in the company. It was not the first time Dr. Hammer had sought the company. He once told an interviewer that he was often asked if he owned Arm & Hammer. "A few years ago," he said, "I offered to buy it so I could say yes. But the owners didn't want to sell."
It was announced in 1987 that Dr. Hammer was donating a substantial collection of his personal papers, including documents involving Soviet leaders, to the Library of Congress.
He was awarded a Soviet decoration, the Order of Friendship Among Peoples, and others from several other nations.
Dr. Hammer was married three times, the first time in 1927 to a Russian singer, Olga von Root, by whom he had a son, his only child, Julian. The marriage ended in divorce, as did his second marriage, to Angela Carey Zevely in 1934. In 1956, he married Frances Barrett, a painter, of Beverly Hills, Calif. Mrs. Hammer, who often accompanied her husband on international business trips, died in December, 1989, from pneumonia, following surgery for a broken hip.
In addition to his son, Julian, he is survived by a grandson, Michael A. Hammer; a granddaughter, Casey Hammer, and two great-grandchildren.,

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Martin Ritt, Director, Dead at 76; Maker of Socially Conscious Films

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Martin Ritt, a director admired for making films that explored moral choices and reflected concern for racially and economically oppressed people, died on Saturday in Santa Monica Hospital Medical Center in California. He was 76 years old and lived in Pacific Palisades, Calif.
The film maker died of heart disease, a family spokesman said. 
 Beginning in 1957, Mr. Ritt directed and occasionally co-produced 25 diverse films, including "Edge of the City," "The Long Hot Summer," "Hud," "The Spy Who Came In From the Cold," "Sounder," "Pete 'n' Tillie," "Norma Rae," "Murphy's Romance," "Nuts" and "Stanley and Iris."
Most of his films were quietly moving studies of human relationships, punctuated by periodic hits that gave the husky, tough-minded director freedom to deal with social issues and the alienation of outsiders.
 
'The Human Condition'
 Critics argued that his idealism made some of his work sentimental and susceptible to sugar-coated themes and happily-ever-after endings. In rebuttal, he said in 1986 that "most of my pictures are concerned with the human condition."
Speaking in the gravelly rhythms of the Lower East Side of Manhattan, where he grew up, he added, "I'm also very committed to assuming responsibility for one's actions." The concern, he said, was rooted in part in his experience of being blacklisted in the 1950's for past Communist ties. He bitterly skewered the era in his 1976 film "The Front."
Mr. Ritt was known as an actor's director who enhanced many careers and was widely admired, although he was nominated for an Academy Award only once, in 1963 for "Hud," an incisive character drama that won Oscars for Patricia Neal, Melvyn Douglas and the cinematographer James Wong Howe.
"I make the kind of films that not too many people get to make in this town, though sometimes I've had to take the risk myself," he said in 1986. To make both "Sounder," a 1972 tale of black sharecroppers during the Depression, and "Norma Rae," a 1979 story about a struggle to unionize a cotton mill in the South, he said, he and most of the principals worked for far less than their normal salaries, in exchange for a percentage of any profits, which were ultimately considerable.
 
An Unobtrusive Hand
 Mr. Ritt directed his camera the way he directed actors, with restraint, favoring a linear, sequential technique and eschewing flashy camera angles and shots and editing. "I don't use the zoom unless that's the only way I can get into a scene," he once said. "The audience shouldn't be aware of the director's work until the movie's over."
Martin Ritt was born to immigrant parents in Manhattan on March 2, 1914. He graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx and Elon College in North Carolina, where he was a running guard and a boxer. He began studying law at St. John's University, but he met and befriended Elia Kazan and joined him in New York's Group Theater, where he acted in "Golden Boy" and other socially conscious Depression-era plays.
He served in the Air Force in World War II, appearing in the service's stage and film drama "Winged Victory." After the war, he acted in live television plays but increasingly stressed directing. He was then blacklisted for five years and eked out a living by teaching at the Actors Studio.
He began film directing in 1957 with "Edge of the City," a powerfully realistic waterfront drama with racial overtones and starring John Cassavetes and Sidney Poitier.
Mr. Ritt is survived by his wife, Adele; a daughter, Martina Werner, a film producer, of Los Angeles, and a son, Michael, of Alaska.

HEADLINE: Seoul Begins Talks on Soviet Trade

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 11

 BODY:
In a bold drive to line up with several more prosperous Western nations helping the Soviet Union, South Korea has started talks with Moscow that officials here say could lead to several billion dollars in trade, investment and aid in the next five years.
On Thursday, President Roh Tae Woo is to become the first leader of South Korea to visit the Soviet Union, a trip scheduled less than three months after the two countries established diplomatic relations, formally ending a long period of hostility dating from the Korean War 40 years ago. 
 The trip, announced last week, is seen as overshadowing the third round of talks between senior leaders of North and South Korea, to begin Wednesday in Seoul amid signs of a stalemate over steps to reduce tensions.
The North Korean delegation arrived this morning, a relief for those South Korean officials who worried that the talks would be called off by Pyongyang out of pique over Seoul's new cooperation with its longtime patron.
 
Political Stature Is Goal
 The South Korean strategy seems to be to gain political stature and turn to its own advantage Moscow's economic problems, particularly the restiveness of disgruntled and desperate Soviet consumers.
For example, Mr. Roh is going to Moscow with the heads of 20 major companies said to be interested in joint ventures in the Soviet Union to produce televisions, soap, shoes, refrigerators and dozens of other goods that Koreans have proven they know how to make.
"I think trade and investment could reach several billion dollars in the next five years," said Koo Bon Yong, Secretary for Economic Affairs to President Roh. "We want to expand trade and start as many mutually profitable investments as possible, for both political and economic reasons."
No one believes that South Korea's relatively small economy is strong enough to rescue the Soviet economy, but with the United States economically strapped and Japan staying on the sidelines because of a territorial dispute with Moscow, South Korea could fill some of the gaps.
 
Isolating the North
 Indeed, diplomats say a web of cooperative ventures, including possible joint development of natural resources, could have far-reaching political ramifications. It would strengthen Mr. Roh's attempt, for instance, to improve ties with China and what was once the Soviet bloc, further isolating North Korea.
The Soviet-Korean talks have in fact begun to alarm Japanese businessmen, who are avoiding joint ventures out of fear of Russian economic instability and because of their Government's insistence on first resolving the territorial matter.
Mr. Roh, in Moscow, is expected to meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and sign four separate treaties to encourage trade, scientific cooperation and South Korean investment.
Moreover, officials said that South Korea, which only 15 years ago was receiving economic aid from the United States, is ready to provide hundreds of millions of dollars in credits to let Moscow import commodities and, eventually, the factory equipment to produce the commodities itself.
 
Insurance and Credit
 Mr. Koo, the economic adviser, said Seoul was considering establishing a Government insurance fund for companies that want to export but worry about being paid quickly, plus a line of credit of several hundred million dollars to the Russians for consumer items and manufactured goods.
"As Korean exports increase, we may need more such mechanisms," said Mr. Koo. He added that trade between South Korea and the Soviet Union is expected to be about a billion dollars this year, more than three times what it was a year ago.
South Koreans assert their country may be ideally positioned, even more than Japan, Europe or the United States, to provide middle- and low-level production technology that has made its economy a model for development.
"Korean businessmen have a gung-ho spirit," said a South Korean diplomat. "These guys are coming along with us to Moscow because, frankly, we want to see how they negotiate with the Russians. Eventually, if there is a financing problem, we'll consider how to help solve it."
 
3 Joint Ventures
 Three joint ventures have already started. The Jindo Fur Company this fall began a joint manufacturing operation in Moscow to make and sell fur coats. The Hyundai Group is engaged in another joint venture to produce timber in the eastern Soviet Union.
And the Samsung Business Group, after being rebuffed with a proposal to put up a hotel in Moscow, is negotiating to refurbish an existing hotel and run it under a management contract. The group is also negotiating to export videotape recorder parts and components to be assembled in the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Massachusetts Prices Bonds With a Top Yield of 7.80%

 BODY:
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts priced $526 million in general obligation bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Initial pricing produced a maximum yield of 7.80 percent for an issue that is due to mature in 2007.
About $475 million of the financing consists of just two maturities, a bond due in 2007 and a bond issue due 2010, which was priced to yield 7.75 percent. For shorter maturities, the yields are 7.50 percent for an issue due in 1998, 7.55 percent in 1999 and 7.60 percent in 2000.
Investors are also offered capital appreciation bonds, which are zero-coupon bonds that pay no interest, but if held to maturity will yield 7.70 percent. An issue due in 2004 is offered at a price of $348.54 for $1,000 in bonds and a bond due in 2005 is priced at $323.18 for $1,000 in bonds.
Underwriters said the financing was rated Baa by Moody's Investors Service, BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and A by Fitch Investors Service Inc.
Moody's said its Baa rating "reflected the as yet uncertain effect of the commonwealth's efforts to restore financial control, high debt load, poor liquidity, and the adverse impact of a continuing economic downturn."
The rating agency noted that the state's net tax-supported debt, including this issue, is $10.6 billion. Last year Massachusetts spent an estimated $873.8 million in debt service payments, and the projected figure for the fiscal year 1992 is $1.065 billion, not including this issue of general obligation bonds.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
First Interstate Sale Suggested

 BODY:
Marvin Davis, the investor and oilman, said yesterday in a letter to directors of the First Interstate Bancorp that the Los Angeles-based bank holding company should "either achieve the operating economies that are long overdue or consider the sale of the bank to another banking institution."
In the letter, which Mr. Davis distributed as a news release, Mr. Davis said he was distressed by the company's "deteriorating financial condition" and declines in its stock in recent months. 
 Mr. Davis did not disclose his family's stake in First Interstate, but analysts said the position must be less than 5 percent because any investments that size or larger must be reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
"We take Mr. Davis's concerns seriously as we do the concerns of all our shareholders," said Simon Barker-Benfield, a spokesman for First Interstate. He said that under the management team that took control of the company this year, First Interstate had "returned to profitabilty and made a dramatic improvement" in its capital position.
First Interstate earned $155.4 million in the third quarter, up from a loss of nearly $15.6 million a year earlier. A sale of new shares earlier this year plus profits earned since the end of 1989 have raised the company's equity capital to more than $2.3 billion in the third quarter, compared with $1.97 billion in the first quarter.
First Interstate's stock closed at $25.125 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, up 37.5 cents, and well above its low of $15.625 in the third quarter.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
New Chip Method May Be Put Off

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Advances in manufacturing computer chips promise to allow the existing technique to be used for many more years than was previously thought possible, postponing or maybe eliminating entirely the need for costly new technologies, semiconductor industry experts say. The advances seem to raise questions about the urgency of efforts to develop a competing technology, to which Congress has allocated $60 million for the current fiscal year and to which Japanese companies are also devoting money.
For years, experts have been predicting that the existing process for etching microscopic circuit patterns on silicon wafers was about to become outmoded. The process, known as optical lithography, uses light to shrink a chip-circuitry pattern onto a wafer of silicon.
 
Like a Very Sharp Pencil
 But as circuits continue to be made smaller in an effort to place more computing power on each chip, they are getting as small as the wavelength of light. Trying to make such intricate circuits with light is like trying to paint a thin line with a wide brush. 
 That prospect has led to worried calls for the creation of a large Government-industry program to develop an exotic and costly new technology known as X-ray lithography. By comparison to light, X-rays, which have a far shorter wavelength, are like a very sharp pencil, and can therefore be used to develop the smaller circuits necessary for future generations of chips.
But now, a growing number of experts say optical lithography should be able to carry the semiconductor industry at least until the turn of the century and possibly beyond, relieving the pressure to develop X-ray lithography or other new technologies like one that uses electron beams to write patterns.
"The window for using X-rays keeps getting pushed out," said Thomas E. Seidel, vice president for manufacturing equipment and materials for Sematech, the consortium working on advanced semiconductor manufacturing techniques.
Being able to stay with the existing technology could have enormous economic implications for semiconductor companies. A chip production plant using X-ray lithography promises to cost at least $500 million, at least $200 million more than an equivalent plant using optical lithography, some experts say.
 
Welcome News in U.S.
 That would be welcome news for American semiconductor companies, which by and large are smaller than their Japanese rivals and would have trouble affording X-ray lithography factories.
Also, there is concern that the Japanese companies are outspending the United States on X-ray lithography. There are more than a dozen programs in Japan, both individual company efforts and consortiums.
In the United States, I.B.M. is the only company with a major program in X-rays, although A.T.& T. is doing some work and Motorola is working with I.B.M. Much of the rest of the work is being done at national laboratories and universities with the $60 million in financing from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.
Still, how advances in optical lithography will affect the competitive picture is not entirely clear. Japanese companies now lead in producing and using the current generation of optical lithography equipment, so anything that prolongs use of that equipment could help them as well.
 
Technique Applied by Japanese
 The latest developments in optical lithography are being introduced here this week at the International Electron Devices Meeting. Researchers from several Japanese companies are discussing a new technique, known as phase shifting, that promises to extend the usefulness of optical lithography for at least several years.
Scientists from Fujitsu, for instance, used the technique to manufacture a 64-megabit dynamic random access memory chip using their existing lithography equipment. Such a chip can store 64 million pieces of data, 16 times more than the most advanced chip now on the market, which is the four-megabit D-RAM. It was previously thought that existing lithography equipment could not make chips more complex than a 16-megabit D-RAM.
"This is a very exciting result because it may push optical lithography another generation," said Steven J. Hillenius, a semiconductor expert at A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories.
The sudden flurry of activity in phase-shifting technology by the Japanese electrified some American researchers. The technique was first proposed by Mark Levenson of I.B.M. about 10 years ago, but has not been applied until now.
 
'Caught Off Guard'
 "We have pretty much been caught off guard by it," said Rick Sivan, manager of advanced technology development at Motorola Inc. in Austin, Tex., referring to American companies. "My worry is we probably have not put enough effort in it."
But some experts say X-ray lithography will still be needed. They say that while phase shifting looks promising in the laboratory, it might be difficult to use in mass production.
Moreover, as optical lithography is pushed to make more and more intricate chips, it will become increasingly expensive. At some point, X-ray technology will triumph because of basic physics.
"Eventually, the economics is going to make it inescapable that you're going to have to go to shorter wavelengths," said Paul M. Horn, director of silicon technology at I.B.M.'s T. J. Watson Research Center. I.B.M. has been the most active in pursuing X-ray lithography.
 
Hedging Their Bets
 However, some detractors who have raised questions about the need for X-ray lithography any time soon say it is the technology of the future -- and always will be.
"Most people can't demonstrate there's any reason for doing it other than that the Japanese are doing it," said G. Dan Hutcheson, president of VLSI Research, a San Jose market research firm that specializes in semiconductor manufacturing equipment.
But he and some others said even Japanese companies, despite participating in several highly publicized cooperative efforts to develop X-ray lithography, were merely hedging their bets while concentrating their best efforts on optical lithography.
 
'It's Not Useful'
 "X-ray technology is very interesting to develop, but it's not useful," said Kenji Nakagawa, the section manager at Fujitsu Ltd. who was presenting the company's paper on phase-shifting technology at this week's conference. Mr. Nakagawa, who worked on X-ray development two years ago but shifted to optical lithography, said he was offering a personal opinion that might not represent his company's.
Optical lithography has already proved more resilient than expected, partly because so much effort is being put into it that it becomes a moving target for other technologies to catch.
"Everybody's waiting for this heavyweight champ to retire,' said Martin E. Lepselter, president of Lepton Inc., a Murray Hill, N.J., company that makes electron-beam equipment. "He doesn't want to retire. He keeps batting down everyone that gets in the ring with him."
Optical lithography is a process similar to one in which light is used to enlarge a photograph from a negative, only in this case it is used to shrink an image. The pattern of the circuit is made on a mask, which is like a photographic negative. Light shines through lenses and the mask, and the pattern is reproduced, in smaller size, on a silicon wafer that is coated with photosensitive materials.
Currently, the most advanced chips have circuits a little less than one micron wide. A micron is a millionth of a meter and about one one-hundredth the thickness of a human hair.
That is approaching the wavelength of the light use to make such circuits, which is about 0.4 micron. X-rays, by contrast, have wavelengths of about 0.001 micron.
 
Lenses and Chemicals Improved
 About 10 years ago, some chip designers thought optical lithography would prove unable to make circuits with features smaller than 0.8 micron, the size of the circuits in the four-megabit D-RAM, which is just coming to market. As little as two years ago, people said new technologies would be needed when circuit widths reached 0.5 micron, the size needed for the 16-megabit D-RAM, which should make its debut in two or three years.
Those predictions proved unfounded, in part because lenses and photosensitive chemicals were improved.
Now, two alternative approaches promise to allow optical lithography to move down to 0.35 micron, the size needed to make the 64-megabit D-RAM, which should begin appearing by about 1995. If these approaches are combined, optical lithography might be able to produce circuits of 0.2 micron, enough for the 256-megabit D-RAM that is expected to reach the market late in the decade.
It is even possible, some say, that optical lithography will be able to reach 0.1 micron, enough for a one-billion-bit chip that would appear after the year 2000.
 
Shorter Wavelengths
 One of the new approaches is to use shorter wavelengths of light. Some newer machines use lasers or other approaches to produce invisible ultraviolet light with a wavelength of 0.25 micron. There is research under way toward using light with a wavelength of 0.19 micron. American companies lead in the development of such low wavelength light, which is difficult to produce.
The other approach, phase shifting, might allow conventional lithography equipment, with 0.4 micron light, to make circuits with features smaller than that.
To use the paint brush analogy, it would seem impossible to paint a green stripe 0.2 micron wide using a brush that is 0.4 micron wide. But that brush could be used to paint two wide stripes side by side that overlap by 0.2 micron. One stripe would be painted blue and the other yellow. Where they overlap would be a green stripe 0.2 micron wide.
That is exactly how phase shifting works, except it uses two phases of light rather than colors of paint.
In conventional lithography, the mask has transparent areas and opaque areas, like a photographic negative. But the light going through the transparent areas bends slightly, so that the image formed on the silicon wafer is slightly blurry. When the circuit features are large, this blurring is not noticeable, but it becomes a problem as circuit elements become as small as the wavelength of the light.
With phase shifting, masks have two different transparent areas, rather than transparent and opaque areas. One of the transparent areas is thicker than the other.
Light moving through glass slows down, so light moving through the thicker glass will go more slowly than the light going through the thin glass. If the thicknesses are precisely set, the light going through the thicker glass will emerge 180 degrees out of phase with the light going through the thinner glass.
Because the light bends as it travels through the mask, light from the two different mask regions overlaps slightly where they hit the wafer. But because the light beams are out of phase, the peaks of one are canceled by the valleys of the other and a very narrow dark spot emerges. The bending of light is turned from a problem into a way of making tiny dark patterns on the chip.
The main drawback of phase shifting is that it is very difficult to manufacture and test the masks.
 
A BETTER WAY TO MAKE COMPUTER CHIPS
 
Computer chips are made by printing tiny patterns of circuitry into silicon with light, in a procedure called optical lithography. But as circuits have become smaller and smaller, chip makers have needed to develop ways to make lithography more precise, including a method called phase-shifting.
 
CONVENTIONAL LITHOGRAPHY
 
In conventional procedures, a mask is covered with chrome in some places to block light. Light shines through the holes in the mask onto a silicon wafer treated with light-sensitive material. But because light waves bend as they pass through the mask, it is hard to achieve a sharp edge between the exposed and unexposed areas on the silicon wafer.
 
"PHASE-SHIFTED" LITHOGRAPHY
 
Phase-shifting uses a mask that varies in thickness. Light waves passing through the thicker parts of the mask emerge "out of phase" with light passing through the thinner parts. Where the two phases of light overlap they are canceled out, as the two waves exactly oppose each other. This produces a sharper dark pattern on the wafer.
 
Source: Motorola

Photo: The GCA Autostep 200 Advanced Lithography System is used to produce microscopic circuit patterns on a silicon wafer. Experts say this technique of producing computer chips, known as optical lithography, may be used until the end of the century, relieving the pressure to develop X-ray lithography or other new technologies.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Strengthens on Plans For Talks to Halt Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened against leading currencies yesterday, largely on news that a group of industrialized nations planned to meet to halt its decline.
Foreign exchange dealers were warmed by news that the so-called Group of Seven -- the United States, Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- would meet in January to discuss the dollar's recent decline. 
 "People are presuming -- with a capital 'P' -- that the outcome will be possibly an attempt to stabilize the dollar," said Robert Hatcher, corporate foreign exchange dealer for Barclays Bank P.L.C.
 
Weak Mark Also Helped
 Analysts said the dollar was also supported by a weakening of the mark after Germany's central bank announced that it was not planning to raise interest rates on Thursday. Traders had speculated that the Bundesbank would tighten its credit policy, which could have lifted the mark against foreign currencies.
The two events combined to bounce the dollar off earlier lows, analysts said.
Within two hours yesterday morning, the dollar jumped in value from 1.4680 German marks to 1.4810. Much of those gains were sustained, with the dollar closing up 1.4784 German marks, compared with 1.4725 late Monday.
"Basically the situation with the dollar was pretty much a complete turnaround from the morning," Mr. Hatcher said.
 
Dollar Up Against Yen
 The dollar also gained against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 132.40 yen, up from 132.15 yen late Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 131.75 yen, from 130.55 at the Monday close. In London, it was quoted at a rate of 131.95 yen.
The British pound weakened to $1.9380 in New York, compared with $1.9442 at the Monday close. In London, it fell to $1.9400, from $1.9450 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the late Monday prices, included: 1.2650 Swiss francs, up from 1.2615; 5.0190 French francs, up from 5.0050; 1,114.00 Italian lire, up from 1,112.25, and 1.1606 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1572.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with those of late Monday, included: 1.4790 German marks, up from 1.4708; 2.2665 Swiss francs, up from 1.2610; 5.0230 French francs, up from 4.9980; 1.6683 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6585; 1,110.07 Italian lire, up from 1,109.75, and 1.1591 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1566.
Silver rose on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $4.067 an ounce, up 1.7 cents. Silver also rose in London to a late bid price of $4.06 an ounce, from $4.05 bid late Monday.

SECTION: Section D; Page 20; Column 1; National Desk
