HEADLINE: Armand Hammer Dies at 92; Industrialist and Philanthropist Forged Soviet Links

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation who long sought peace between the United States and the Soviet Union and financed research for a cancer cure, died at his home in Los Angeles Monday night. He was 92 years old.
The cause of death was not disclosed but associates said he had been suffering from kidney problems. Frank Ashley, a spokesman for Occidental, said the death occurred after "a brief illness." 
 Dr. Hammer, who at one time or another headed successful businesses in fields ranging from art to bourbon whisky, built and led Occidental for 33 years. Ray R. Irani, the company's president and chief operating officer, immediately succeeded Dr. Hammer as chairman and chief executive officer.
Dr. Hammer, who was trained as a physician but never set up a medical practice, was also a noted philanthropist and art collector who hobnobbed with the high and mighty, including members of the British royal family and generations of Soviet leaders.
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union sent condolences to the Hammer family and said in a statement that Dr. Hammer helped forge Soviet-American relations. He "was associated with one of the most remarkable pages of our relationship," Mr. Gorbachev added. "He met with Lenin and was very close in many ways to the Soviet Union, and to Russia."
Experts in different fields that Dr. Hammer was active in gave varying appraisals of him in interviews yesterday.
Daniel Yergin, an author and the president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm. said Dr. Hammer's life straddled "the whole history" of the 20th century. "He was virtually the only one who could tell Mikhail Gorbachev firsthand what Lenin was like, Gorbachev having been born" seven years after Lenin died.
 
'A Very Minor Figure' In U.S.-Soviet Relations
 Richard Pipes, the Baird Professor of History at Harvard and a specialist in modern Russian history, said that, "in terms of U.S.S.R. internal developments and U.S.-Soviet relations, he was a very minor figure."
"I don't think he was a man who in any way sympathized with the regime," Mr. Pipes added. "He basically entered into relations with the Soviet Government in the early period and again later purely for making a profit and enhancing his stature."
Michael Kimmelman, chief art critic of The New York Times, said Dr. Hammer "was as aggressive and wily in his dealings in the art world as he seems to have been in other aspects of his life."
"He was a dealer, collector and impresario of art," Mr. Kimmelman added, "but it's not clear whether in the end he served his own interests best by building a monument to his own collection in the form of the Armand Hammer museum in Los Angeles instead of donating the works to another museum that could have edited the wheat from the chaff and therefore made the best case for Hammer's taste."
Dr. Hammer bequeathed his art collection to the new museum, which was opened in Los Angeles on Nov. 28 in a zebra-striped building that adjoins the headquarters of Occidental.
Last summer, the heirs of Dr. Hammer's late wife, Frances, who died last year at 87, filed a lawsuit contending that Dr. Hammer had tricked her into signing away her part of their collection, valued at $400 million. Dr. Hammer called the charges scurrilous.
 
From a Bar Mitzvah To a Memorial Service
 Dr. Hammer had planned to celebrate his own belated bar mitzvah last night, like much of what he did, in public. Dr. Hammer, who was raised in a non-observant family, planned to link the ceremony to a fund-raising dinner at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. The dinner was to benefit two organizations, the Pacific Jewish Center and the Jerusalem College of Technology.
The ceremony was changed into a memorial service. "We're going to go ahead with the event," a spokesman, Howard Bragman, said. "It's really the wish of Dr. Hammer that this event continue because it was important to him."
Funeral arrangements were pending. Dr. Hammer will be entombed in the private Hammer family mausoleum at Westwood Village Cemetery, just a few hundred yards from Occidental's headquarters.
Over the years, Dr. Hammer was variously president and chairman of the Mutual Broadcasting System and president of such diverse companies as the J. W. Dant Distilling Company and the A. Hammer Pencil Company of New York, London and Moscow. "I am first and foremost a catalyst, I bring people and situations together," Dr. Hammer once said in discussing his long business career.
A short and forceful man with a quick smile and appraising eyes, he became involved in American-Soviet trade very early, in 1921, and maintained ties with the Soviet Union for more than 60 years, with a hiatus during Stalin's ascendancy.
Dr. Hammer wrote in 1985 that his involvement with the Soviet Union reflected a belief "that nuclear war must be avoided and that the chances for peace can best be preserved by building the bonds of culture and commerce."
 
Small and Struggling Occidental Transformed
 In the mid-1950's, already a multimillionaire, he invested in Occidental, then a small and struggling company. By 1986, after he had headed it for 29 years, he could boast that it had become "the eighth-biggest energy concern in the United States and the 12th-biggest industrial corporation," with gross revenues of about $16 billion that year.
As a businessman Dr. Hammer was inventive, daring and energetic. His talents brought him so much money that he said he could not count it, and he prolonged his business career into his 90's. "I love business," he once said. "I love my work. I can't wait to start a new day."
Although he profited spectacularly from his dealings with the Soviet Union, his motives were sometimes questioned. He wrote in his best-selling autobiography, "Hammer," that his Russian-born father, Julius Hammer, was recruited, while a Connecticut steelworker, into the Socialist Labor Party. It was the leading Marxist party in the United States in the last quarter of the 19th century and a forerunner of the American Communist Party, of which, Dr. Hammer wrote, his father was a founding member in 1919.
Some people contended that Dr. Hammer's early success in trading with the Soviet Union was nourished by Julius Hammer's connections in the Moscow Government. There were also insinuations that Dr. Hammer shared his father's political sympathies, a view he denied.
Nonetheless, Dr. Hammer sometimes expressed views of the Soviet Union that coming from an American millionaire seemed strikingly uncritical. In an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times in 1987, he and a co-author wrote that, "to some extent, the Soviet Union lacks the delicate balance present in our society between technological achievements and human values."
In "Hammer," which came out in 1987, Dr. Hammer wrote that he had met with Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, many times, finding him "a man of great humanism and vast warmth."
Appraising the book in The New York Times Book Review, Ted Morgan contended that Dr. Hammer, "in order to maintain his 'most favored person' position with the Russians, becomes disturbingly sycophantic."
 
'Enthusiastic Amateur' On International Ties
 Mr. Morgan also contended that "Dr. Hammer presents himself as the architect of world peace, instrumental in arranging the 1985 Geneva summit between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan" while "in fact, he is more like an enthusiastic amateur trying to break into the major leagues, a George Plimpton of international relations."
Dr. Hammer was also involved in United States politics. A lifelong Democrat, he was convicted in 1976 of making illegal campaign contributions totaling $54,000 to President Richard M. Nixon's 1972 re-election campaign, fined $3,000 and put on one year's probation. Years later Dr. Hammer contended that he should not have pleaded guilty and that he had been the victim of misdeeds by an associate. He was pardoned by President Bush in August 1989.
Despite the controversy Dr. Hammer sometimes aroused, he retained the friendship and esteem of many famous people. Two former Presidents, Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter, endorsed his autobiography. Mr. Ford said Mr. Hammer was "a unique individual in the business and geopolitical world." Mr. Carter said he had "a unique standing in both the United States and the Soviet Union."
Over the years, Dr. Hammer's various holdings, interests and possessions were staggeringly diverse. There was his own plane, a Boeing 727, in addition to art galleries: Hammer Galleries Inc. and Knoedler & Company, in New York City. He had on his desk in Los Angeles inscribed pictures of important people from Lenin to President Reagan. For a while, he owned Campobello Island, the Roosevelt family's retreat; he gave it to the United States and Canada in 1962 as an international park.
 
Leonardo Manuscript And Prize Cattle Bought
 His purchases included champion Aberdeen Angus cattle and a costly Leonardo da Vinci manuscript, as well as the Hooker Chemical Company. During the nine years he spent in the Soviet Union, beginning in 1921, he invested in art works that he called treasures of the Romanovs, the family of the Czars of Russia from 1613 until the revolution in 1917.
Dr. Hammer gave away a great deal of the money that he made. "I have a seven-figure income and give away 90 percent of it," he said in 1980. He headed the Armand Hammer Foundation, which gave millions of dollars a year to charitable causes.
Some instances of his largesse were the $5 million that he gave to Columbia University in 1977; the 1,000 lithographs by Daumier that he gave to the Corcoran Gallery of Art in 1983, and the gift of $1 million to the Metropolitan Museum that was announced in 1986. Its purpose was to help renovate its arms and armor galleries at the museum. In recognition of his patronage of the arts, Dr. Hammer was chosen in 1987 to receive a National Medal for the Arts.
In 1988 he announced plans to build a $30 million cultural center and museum in Los Angeles for his art collections. The New York Times critic, John Russell, wrote at the time that "the collections are particularly strong in European Old Master paintings and drawings. Among the masters represented are Raphael, Correggio, Ingres, Rubens, Rembrandt, Watteau, Fragonard, Tiepolo, Boucher, Cezanne, Gauguin, Renoir and van Gogh."
Mr. Russell said Dr. Hammer's $250 million valuation of the collections was conservative.
Dr. Hammer also had what Mr. Russell called a remarkable collection of European Old Master drawings, which he gave to the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
 
Praise and Misgivings On Cancer Research Aid
 That same year Dr. Hammer initiated an ambitious four-year campaign to raise $500 million from private sources for cancer research. The drive officially got under way in October 1988, but in its first few weeks only about $13 million in private funds was donated. Dr. Hammer's role in the campaign stirred much praise and some misgivings. Some cancer researchers and specialists voiced concern that it might lead to too much money being put into research involving the body's immune defense system, a field in which he was particularly interested.
Dr. Hammer was born on the Lower East Side of Manhattan on May 21, 1898, the son of Julius Hammer and Rose Robinson Hammer. In "Hammer," Dr. Hammer wrote that his father named him Armand "after Armand Duval, the romantic hero in Dumas's 'La Dame aux Camelias,' although others suggested he obviously had in mind the symbol of the Socialist Labor Party -- an arm and a hammer."
Dr. Hammer's business career began when he was a medical student at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. In "Hammer," he wrote that his father, who had become a physician and a pharmaceuticals manufacturer, was in poor health and called on him to take over his business. The young Hammer did so and, while continuing his studies, prospered mightily. "Average income in the United States in 1919 was about $625 a year," he wrote, while "my personal income was over $1 million net."
 
Starvation, Not Typhus, Soviet Problem in 20's
 When he graduated from medical school in 1921, he had six months to wait before beginning his internship. But other events intervened. There was a typhus epidemic, along with other problems, in the Soviet Union at the time, four years after the revolution, and he decided to go there, thinking he would work as a doctor. When he arrived, he found that the major problem was starvation, not typhus. Then, he wrote, "there came to me the single proposition which most dramatically changed my life" -- the idea, which he swiftly acted on, of trading American grain for furs and other goods from the Soviet Union.
Before long, Dr. Hammer attracted the attention of Lenin, who needed foreign investment and who gave the young American a concession for asbestos in the Urals. Dr. Hammer wrote in "Hammer" that the concession was not as successful as he himself had hoped, but it was the start of a profitable trading relationship. He soon became the representative of three dozen American companies.
In 1925, he asked for a pencil concession. He received it, and with the aid of experts and technology from Germany, he produced $2.5 million worth of pencils in his first year. By 1930, he was employing 1,000 workers and producing nearly 500,000 pencils a day.
But Stalin came into power, and, he wrote, it was clear "that Stalin was not a man with whom you could do business." Mainly for that reason, he wrote, he left the Soviet Union.
In the decades that followed, Dr. Hammer made money in a variety of fields, including the sale of art that he had acquired in the Soviet Union, the production of beer and whisky barrels and the operation of a number of distilleries. After greatly expanding sales at J. W. Dant Bonded Bourbon, he sold the distillery for $6.5 million and moved to California in 1955, thinking he would retire.
 
Bored by Life of Leisure, Excited by Oil Business
 But unlimited leisure bored him, and he began investing in Occidental, which then had assets of less than $100,000. He found the oil business, he wrote years later, "more exciting, more interesting, more complex, riskier and more rewarding than any other business I had encountered."
In the late 1950's, he also invested in the Mutual Broadcasting System, and he ran that company for a time himself. But he sold out, for a profit of $1.3 million, he later recalled, partly because he was "much more excited about Occidental."
As chairman and chief executive of Occidental, he hired oil-industry experts, much as he had hired pencil-making experts 30 years before. The company grew, and by 1967 its assets amounted to more than $1 billion.
In 1966, after years of intricate negotiations, Occidental was awarded two oil concessions in Libya. Within two years it was exporting more than 200,000 barrels of oil a day.
In 1973, Dr. Hammer's luck seemed to turn sour. Libya's radical new Government put pressure on Occidental, by then the country's largest single oil producer, and later that year it turned over 51 percent of the company to the Government for $135 million. Occidental also agreed to higher taxes and a 30 percent price increase.
The move by Occidental, which soon led to similar accommodations by other oil producers in Libya, has been described as changing the world economy. It was the first time that an oil-producing country had dictated oil prices, and it set the stage for the dramatic increase in influence of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Nevertheless, Occidental continued to prosper, moving into oil production in Peru and the North Sea, among other areas.
 
Free-Wheeling Style Brings Business Fights
 In the 1970's, Dr. Hammer's free-wheeling business style brought him different kinds of trouble. A successful battle by the Mead Corporation, an Ohio-based forest products company, to resist a takeover by Occidental turned up information that prompted Federal and state investigations into the activities of Dr. Hammer and Occidental.
According to people close to the takeover attempt, Occidental abandoned the move after investigators began looking into Dr. Hammer's art dealings. One allegation that was bruited about, although he contended it was only "a lot of gossip," was that he had made an improper payment of $100,000 in the early 1970's to the Soviet Minister of Culture, Yekaterina A. Furtseva, to facilitate an art exchange.
His involvement with the Soviet Union continued into the 1980's. After the nuclear power plant leak in 1986 at Chernobyl, he dispatched an international group of physicians to deliver medicine and medical care. In that same year, after he had conferred with Mr. Gorbachev, works of art that he had collected went on display in Soviet cities.
Also in 1986, the Soviet authorities permitted Dr. Hammer to take an ailing Jewish scientist, David Goldfarb, from a hospital in Moscow and fly him and his wife to the United States.
Even in his 90's Dr. Hammer remained prominent in Occidental's management and continued to personify the company. Through the decades, he was also variously a director of numerous organizations and business concerns, including banks and companies in the petroleum industry and other fields.
 
Bids Made to Acquire Arm & Hammer Brand
 In 1986 he became affiliated with the Church & Dwight Company, which makes Arm & Hammer, the baking soda brand, when Occidental bought a stake in the company. It was not the first time Dr. Hammer had sought the company. He once told an interviewer that he was often asked if he owned Arm & Hammer. "A few years ago," he said, "I offered to buy it so I could say yes. But the owners didn't want to sell."
It was announced in 1987 that Dr. Hammer was donating a substantial collection of his personal papers, including documents involving Soviet leaders, to the Library of Congress.
He was awarded a Soviet decoration, the Order of Friendship Among Peoples, and others from several other nations.
Dr. Hammer was married three times, the first time in 1927 to a Russian singer, Olga von Root, by whom he had a son, his only child, Julian. The marriage ended in divorce, as did his second marriage, to Angela Carey Zevely in 1934. In 1956, he married Frances Barrett, a painter, of Beverly Hills, Calif. Mrs. Hammer, who often accompanied her husband on international business trips, died in December 1989, from pneumonia, following surgery for a broken hip.
In addition to his son, Julian, he is survived by a grandson, Michael A. Hammer; a granddaughter, Casey Hammer, and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
More Declines in Treasury Yields

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Treasury bond yields continued their seemingly inexorable downward march toward 8 percent yesterday, helped by a decline in oil prices and a softening in a key short-term interest rate.
"There is a very firm tone to the bond market, even though at this point it is overbought," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "It just doesn't give up." 
 By late yesterday, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 107 5/8, up 22/32, to yield 8.06 percent, down from 8.12 percent late Monday. That is the benchmark issue's lowest yield since early January.
Although the drop in oil prices helped, a number of traders said market participants seemed to attach a great deal of significance to a drop in the rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market.
The funds rate slipped below 7 percent for a period yesterday, well under the 7.25 percent level that is seen as the Federal Reserve Board's target for the rate, which is what banks charge each other for overnight loans. On Friday, the central bank indicated that it had lowered the closely watched rate to 7.25 that day.
 
Excess of Reserves
 Analysts said that because of technical factors, the banking system had an excess of reserves, and that this, rather than a change in Fed policy, had caused the drop in the funds rate.
Indeed, the Fed indicated to market participants yesterday that it was not moving the funds rate lower when it entered the Treasury securities market near midday to drain reserves from the banking system. At that time, the funds rate was at 7 percent.
"There is a lot of technical noise in the funds market right now," said James Fralick, a principal and senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "I don't think the Fed chose this time to signify an easing move."
In Mr. Fralick's view, the Fed is more likely to approve another quarter-point cut in the funds rate when members of its policy-making Open Market Committee meet in Washington next week.
"The Fed's draining operation was clearly a rate protest move," one government-bond trader said. "But the fact that funds didn't go back up to 7.25 percent after they came in helped the market later in the day."
By late in the day the funds rate was trading at around 7 1/16 percent.
 
Lending Shown to Slow
 Credit market participants may also have been encouraged by a report from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that showed bank lending continued to contract in the third quarter.
According to the F.D.I.C. report, net loans and leases at all commercial banks rose by 4.1 percent in the 12 months ended Oct. 31, down from a 4.4 percent increase in the period covering the second quarter of 1989 to the second quarter of 1990. Bank lending had increased at a 6 percent rate for each of the previous three years.
"Bank-loan growth will probably remain weak in 1991, and continued tight credit conditions could significantly limit economic growth," analysts at MMS International, an economic information service, noted in their daily market commentary.
Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America, said that "if only monetary policy is going to be used to bring us out of recession, interest rates are going to need to fall a lot more before a lot of outstanding debt gets refinanced" and banks start lending again.
 
Note Prices Rise
 Treasury bond prices were not the only beneficiaries of the day's events. In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 104 in late trading, up 11/32, to yield 7.9 percent. And the 7 3/8 percent two-year notes rose by 2/32, to a late price of 100 1/4, to yield 7.23 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates also fell. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.81 percent, down four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bills were offered at a late rate of 6.7 percent, down one basis point.
During the afternoon, the Treasury said that after its Dec. 19 auction it would discontinue its offerings of four-year notes. Instead, it will offer five-year notes on a monthly basis. These securities are currently sold on a quarterly basis.
The moves "will produce a much more rational pattern of debt service payments each quarter," said Louis v. B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm. "From a debt management perspective, this step is long overdue."
 
Active Corporate Market
 In other developments, the continued slide in interest rates produced another huge spurt of activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market, as eight companies offered a total of $1.54 billion worth of new securiites.
Among the issuers was the Province of Saskatchewan, which sold $300 million worth of 30-year debentures through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9 3/8 percent securities, which mature Dec. 15, 2020, were priced at $99.33 to yield 9.443 percent, 1.36 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The Ford Motor Credit Corporation offered $200 million of seven-year notes through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 9 3/8 percent notes were priced at $99.686, to yield 9.437 percent, 1.56 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent seven-year notes.
The issue is rated AA-3 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 of a point.

HEADLINE: New Occidental Chief Expected to Shift Focus

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11

 BODY:
In the 33 years he headed the company, Armand Hammer shaped the Occidental Petroleum Corporation in his own image, pushing the company into diverse interests, giving it a worldwide reach and making its course difficult to predict.
With Dr. Hammer's death on Monday night at the age of 92, Occidental, the nation's 16th-largest industrial company, now faces a period of reassessment. Analysts expect Ray R. Irani, who has succeeded Dr. Hammer as chairman and chief executive officer, to try to focus Occidental more closely on its core oil and chemical businesses and to reduce the company's debt load, possibly by selling some divisions. 
 Analysts and investors speculated that Mr. Irani might sell the company's 51 percent interest in IBP Inc., a meatpacking concern, for as much as $1 billion. The company's coal operations and its natural gas transmission business are also considered candidates for sale.
 
Dividend Cut Called Possible
 Analysts said Mr. Irani might also cut the company's dividend, although he has previously said that he would not favor such a move.
Reflecting a belief that any changes would benefit the company's flagging stock price, shares of both Occidental and IBP rose in heavy trading after the news of Dr. Hammer's death. [Obituary, page D20.]
Occidental's shares rose $1.875 on the New York Stock Exchange today, to $22.625. The issue was the most active of the day, with 8.1 million shares changing hands. Occidental shares have long been considered a laggard on Wall Street, and despite a general rise in oil stocks the stock had fallen from $30 earlier this year.
IBP's stock rose $2.625 to close at $19 a share.
"Ray Irani is not likely to be a whole lot different from Armand Hammer in his approach to the company," said Peter Hunsberger, an analyst with John S. Herold Inc., a petroleum research firm in Greenwich, Conn. "Yet it is new blood and he may be more interested in some of the restructuring ideas that Armand Hammer was not very interested in."
Mr. Irani said through a spokesman today that it "is not an appropriate time to discuss corporate matters." But analysts said they thought he would be inclined to turn Occidental, which last year had revenues of $20.1 billion and a net income of $285 million, into a smaller but more profitable company.
"Under Armand Hammer the company just grew and grew and the stock has gone nowhere," said Warren Shimmerlik, an independent oil analyst in New York. "Irani has the opportunity to change the company, make it smaller instead of larger, to get the debt down and free up cash flow so more funds can be invested internally to increase their returns."
 
Reluctant to Cede Authority
 Like many strong-willed executives, Dr. Hammer long seemed reluctant to cede any authority over what he regarded as his company (he owned well under 1 percent of Occidental's shares). He went through a series of top executives during the 1970's and early 80's, many of whom left in frustration. But Mr. Irani, a 55-year-old chemist who had been president of the Olin Corporation, served faithfully and apparently amicably under Dr. Hammer as president beginning in 1984. After Dr. Hammer temporarily fell ill earlier this year, Dr. Hammer publicly stated that Mr. Irani would succeed him should he retire or die.
Mr. Irani has been running the company on a day-to-day basis in recent years. Dr. Hammer spent considerable time in recent years on the building of the Armand Hammer Museum of Art adjacent to the company's headquarters here. Dr. Hammer spent at least $50 million of Occidental's money on the museum, which opened last month.
Dr. Hammer was also increasingly active in financing efforts to find a cure for cancer, and until the final months of his life he continued to fly around the world arranging oil deals and meeting foreign leaders.
 
'Left in Very Strong Hands'
 "The company is left in very strong hands with Irani and his team," said Eugene L. Nowak, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds.
Mr. Irani's major role has been to guide the company's expansion in the chemicals business. Chemicals, a notoriously cyclical industry, last year accounted for more than a quarter of the company's sales and the vast majority of its operating profit. This year, a slowing economy and higher oil prices have pushed earnings from the chemicals segments down sharply. Analysts said earnings from chemicals could remain depressed for another year but should eventually rebound.
The downturn in chemicals this year has been largely offset by an improvement in the company's oil and gas segment. Occidental explores for oil and owns and operates fields around the world. The sharp increase in oil prices following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait helped push oil and gas earnings up fivefold in the third quarter as earnings from chemicals fell sharply.
 
Oil Outlook Viewed as Good
 While the company's earnings from oil will depend to a large extent on oil prices, analysts say the outlook is good. The company should get a boost next year from the completion of work to rebuild the Piper Alpha oil rig in the North Sea, which was severely damaged by a fire in 1988. Occidental has a 36.5 percent interest in the Piper oilfield.
Mr. Nowak said he was projecting earnings for the entire company next year of $1.30 to $1.40 a share, up modestly from the $1.20 he is projecting this year.
The company's coal and natural gas transmission businesses have been lackluster performers. And Occidental has previously indicated that it might be willing to sell its stake in IBP, though it has recently suggested it might want to wait a year or two until it begins seeing the results of an expansion plan at the meatpacker.
 
Valued at $30 to $40 a Share
 Analysts said Occidental's assets, if sold separately, should be worth between $30 and $40 a share. John S. Herold Inc., the research firm, estimated the company's asset value at $33 a share after accounting for the company's $10 billion in debt.
Of the businesses that analysts say are most likely to be sold, Herold said the company's gas transmission segment could be worth $2.25 billion and the stake in IBP $700 million. Many analysts say the IBP stake could be worth $1 billion if a sale includes the assumption of IBP debt.

HEADLINE: SOVIETS ARE URGED TO CHANGE FASTER

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
With the Bush Administration on the verge of giving emergency economic aid to the Soviet Union, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d prodded Moscow today to use this assistance to speed up economic changes, not as a cushion to avoid them.
Mr. Baker and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, conducted a joint news conference at the Houstonian Hotel, where they have been holding two days of talks on a variety of issues, from arms control to the Persian Gulf. 
 Administration officials said it was highly likely that President Bush would announce on Wednesday that he is waiving the Jackson-Vanik trade restrictions, so that the Soviets will be free to buy American food on easy credit from the Commodity Credit Corporation. It is also likely that Mr. Bush will announce a provision of emergency medical assistance to the Soviets, after he meets at the White House on Wednesday with Mr. Shevardnadze, officials said.
On Monday, Mr. Shevardnadze made a public appeal for food and other economic assistance from Washington, and while Mr. Baker confirmed that this would be forthcoming, he added that he and the Soviet foreign minister discussed the importance of "blending" any short-term emergency assistance "with efforts to promote medium or long-term economic reform in the Soviet Union."
 
'A Vibrant Economy'
 With Mr. Shevardnadze sitting next to him, Mr. Baker added that while he did not want to "minimize the current possible short-term needs of the Soviet Union, it is a country with tremendous resource potential and capabilities, and the right market reform can tap this potential in a manner to give that country a vibrant economy."
Mr. Baker said he and Mr. Shevardnadze were in full agreement that any American emergency aid "should be transitional" -- meaning, he indicated, that it should be a bridge to a free-market Soviet economy not a crutch for maintaining the current half-way economic liberalization.
On regional issues, Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze announced that in order to help promote a settlement of the Angolan civil war, Mr. Shevardnadze would meet on Wednesday in Washington, for the first time, with Jonas Savimbi, head of Unita, an American-backed guerrilla organization that has been fighting to topple the pro-Soviet Angolan government.
Mr. Baker, for his part, will be meeting with Pedro Van Dunem, the Angolan foreign minister.
 
Outline of Angola Accord
 Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze said in a joint statement that they would "outline their concept of a settlement, including a cease-fire agreement; free participation of Unita and other parties in the political process in Angola in the framework of multiparty democracy; the conduct of free and fair elections and the termination of deliveries of all lethal materials to Angola" once there is a cease-fire.
The two ministers said they made progress on resolving the myriad technical issues still holding up a treaty limiting strategic nuclear weapons, but had more work to do. They were also having to spend a great deal of time haggling over loose ends from the conventional arms reduction treaty they signed in Paris last month, officials said.
Because the Soviets withdrew so many tanks and artillery pieces from Europe before the conventional arms treaty went into effect, they will not be destroying as much armor as originally projected. Some leading Senators have warned the Administration that unless they can get some ironclad assurances from Moscow about how these thousands of tanks and artillery pieces, now behind the Ural Mountains, will be, in effect, neutralized, if they are not going to be destroyed, the Senate is not likely to ratify the treaty.
 
U.S. on Gulf Position Backed
 On the Persian Gulf, Mr. Shevardnadze endorsed the American position that Iraq should agree to receive Mr. Baker in Baghdad at an early date, as the Americans have been demanding, as opposed to the Jan. 12 date offered by the Iraqis, which is only three days before the expiration of the United Nations Security Council deadline for Iraqi troops to be out of Kuwait.
"It is very important that the goodwill grace period that expires on Jan. 14 is taken up with very active diplomatic and political efforts," said Mr. Shevardnadze. "The sooner contacts begin between the Iraqi leadership and the United States, the better it would be."

HEADLINE: Many Incorrect Charges Found On Adjustable-Rate Mortgages

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
As many as one of every four Americans who bought homes with adjustable-rate mortgages may be paying either too much or too little each month because of bank errors in calculating interest rates, according to a report by the General Acounting Office.
The miscalculations were discovered in routine audits of mortgages issued by failed savings and loan associations that have been taken over by Federal regulators. But bankers concede that some adjustable loans, which have complex terms, are also being incorrectly adjusted by solvent institutions.
 
Overcharges Put at $8 Billion
 The extent of the problem is disputed. John Geddes, a former Federal mortgage banking auditor who has been the chief whistle-blower on the errors, estimates that 30 to 35 percent of the country's 12 million outstanding adjustable-rate mortgages, which include home equity loans, are billed incorrectly, with half the borrowers charged too much and the rest too little. 
 He says the net overcharges are about $8 billion, but says he has not estimated the undercharges. It is also unknown how many of these loans have already been paid off. Mr. Geddes's estimate is based on his review of 7,000 adjustable mortgages taken over by the Government in the savings bailout.
Experts cited in an October report of the accounting office, the investigative arm of Congress, put the error rate at 20 to 25 percent of these mortgages, but some banking industry officials contend that the rate is considerably less than that. Chase, for instance, audited its adjustable mortgages last year and found almost no errors.
The size of the errors varies, with most considered to be small. But Shirley and Gordon Wynn of Miami received a $1,463.99 refund from the Coral Gables Federal Savings and Loan in September after pointing out to the bank that charges on their adjustable home mortgage since 1987 had been based on an interest rate of 10.875 percent instead of the correct rate of 10.375 percent. The Wynns' monthly mortgage payment is now $797.75, instead of $812.34.
It is unclear whether financial institutions are liable for making refunds to overcharged borrowers, although the first lawsuits challenging lenders on the issue are now being brought by borrowers.
But a big concern to members of Congress who are beginning to look into the problem is the additional cost of the Federal savings and loan bailout if such refunds have to be made.
The Federal regulators' role in the problem is also expected to be discussed at Congressional hearings to be held on the miscalculations. Documents from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which took over thousands of mortgages from failed savings banks whose deposits it insured, show that the corporation knew as early as the summer of 1988 that many mortgages in its portfolio were being billed incorrectly.
People working for the agency say they were told not to notify overcharged borrowers, and to keep billing at the wrong interest rates. "I don't believe that most of the errors were intentional," Mr. Geddes said, "but what I did find is that once the errors were found, a lot of savings and loans, and the F.S.L.I.C. for certain, would do nothing to fix them."
Federal regulators overseeing the portfolio would not comment on that practice, arguing that they would first like to finish a formal audit of these mortgages.
The miscalculations came to light in the summer of 1989, when Mr. Geddes alerted Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana to the large percentage of errors in the mortgages taken over by the F.S.L.I.C., where he was employed.
 
Lugar Sought Review
 Late last year, the Senator asked several Government banking agencies to review reports of a growing mortgage bookkeeping problem, and was told there was none.
"They all wrote back, 'We don't see any problems,' " said Steven Fischer, the Senator's aide for banking issues.
Still, after the release of the G.A.O. report, which was requested by Senator Lugar, the F.D.I.C. began an audit of its Chicago office mortgage portfolio, where Mr. Geddes and others who confirm his story worked.
Arthur Lorentzen, an assistant director in the F.D.I.C.'s Division of Liquidation, originally said the review of a sample of the Chicago portfolio would be finished by the second week in December. But on Thursday he said his office would review the audit and postpone an announcement of the results indefinitely.
"Because of the publicity about all this we've decided to go back and refigure them," he said in an interview. "There's a lot more to it than meets the eye," he said of the audit process.
 
Human Mistakes
 In most cases, Mr. Geddes and others familiar with the process said, the errors have resulted from human mistakes at failed savings institutions, many of which were small operations, unfamiliar with the complexity of adjustable-rate mortgages. Often, they computed adjustable mortgages by hand. The G.A.O. report suggest that the problem may be greatest in the Middle West, where banks are smaller and adjustable-rate mortgages are less common than on the coasts.
Unlike fixed-rate mortgages, whose rates are fixed for the duration of the mortgage, adjustable-rate mortgages have interest rates that rise and fall with a designated index of prevailing interest rates. The rates are usually low for the first year, and are then adjusted every six months or every year after that.
The rate consists of an index like the interest rate on Treasury bills plus a fixed margin of two or three percentage points. Changes are usually "capped," and the rate may not rise more than two percentage points in any adjustment period and six percentage points over the life of the loan.
In some cases, the problems are caused by computer glitches, as indicated by an audit of a sample of 96 adjustable-rate mortgages from a failed savings institution, the Victor Federal Savings and Loan of Muskogee, Okla., The audit, conducted for the F.S.L.I.C. by the Bennington Group, a San Diego consulting firm, found that the bank's computer system contained logic errors. The bank, among other things, rounded rates upward instead of downward and "pulled" the index on the wrong date.
Victor ended up undercharging borrowers by $130,000, said Bernard Lomax, an executive at the consulting firm.
 
Poor Record-Keeping
 Mr. Geddes and other former F.S.L.I.C. workers say errors also resulted from the poor recordkeeping at failed savings and loans. Federal bank receivers had unusual or hard-to-locate interest indexes, or were missing documentation, or did not match the agency's computer programs.
Some mortgages in the F.S.L.I.C portfolio, have never been adjusted, according to Betty Skatchke, a former loan officer who was in charge of adjustable loans and the corporation's Chicago office. For mortgages taken out in a time of rising interest rates, this would result in serious undercharges.
 
A Subtraction Mistake
 She also recalled a large commercial loan in which a four percentage point interest margin was subtracted instead of added to the index rate, leaving the business paying at an interest rate of a little more than 3 percent instead of more than 10 percent.
"We were told that if there were errors we were not to touch them," Ms. Skatchke said. "The bottom line statement was, 'We must be consistent in our errors.' "
Indeed, agency documents show that the Chicago office of the F.S.L.I.C. sought the first of 13 legal opinions about the Federal Government's potential liability for overcharges by failed banks in August 1988.
 
Checking the Rate
 Homeowners can check their own mortgages by finding the index and the margin for their loans in their loan agreement. The agreement should specify the date on which the mortgage rate changes. The bank bases the new interest rate on the rate at which the index was trading 45 days before that change date. That index rate is published in newspapers. To arrive at the new interest rate, add the margin to the index rate and then check that the mortgage cap was not exceeded.
Mortgage consulting services will also provide audits, for a $40 or $50 fee, for consumers who want to check whether lenders are charging them correctly. These firms also sell mortgage-checking kits for $3 to $15 that contain tables on interest rates over several years and on several indexes.
Mr. Lorentzen said the F.D.I.C. would probably credit any overcharges it finds to the borrower's principal balance. Some interpretations of the Federal Truth in Lending Act maintain that the borrower may be entitled to cash, but the G.A.O. report noted that the issue probably would be left to the courts to decide.
 
Delays Cited
 Still, some mortgage holders have found the Government unresponsive to their requests for refunds or their inquiries. Evelyn McGuire, a Paducah, Ky., apartment landlord and real estate agent, is still waiting for Federal regulators to untangle three adjustable-rate mortgages they took over from the First Federal Savings and Loan of Paducah, which failed in 1988.
The $120,000 mortgages started out in 1986 with identical payments and balances, Mrs. McGuire said, but they have since wandered off in different directions. Now, she is waiting for the F.D.I.C. to explain why she has three different monthly payments, three different loan balances and two different payment schedules. On top of that, Mrs. McGuire added, the F.D.I.C. got the index wrong at the change date last September.
"I'm in the real estate business and I know how to check the numbers," Mrs. McGuire said in an interview. "So I wrote and asked them to document how they got that number, but they have never answered, they do not return my phone calls. So I pay it every month, but I tell them I'm paying under protest."
And not all homeowners received refunds from their banks as easily as the Wynns. Class action suits charging violations of the Truth in Lending Act, enacted to protect borrowers against such things as interest-rate fluctuations, were brought in September against four small Indiana savings and loans, with Mr. Geddes acting as a researcher for Henry Price, the lead attorney for the plaintiffs. Mr. Price, of Indianapolis, is seeking refunds of the overcharges plus undetermined damages under the Federal law.
It is unclear how the courts would treat any of these cases. The G.A.O. report cites the opinion of Federal regulators that the Truth in Lending Law "probably does not" require lenders to repay overcharges in any form, but legal opinions sought by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation held the opposite view. Borrowers who were undercharged, however, are not believed to be liable for making up the difference.

HEADLINE: Florio Plans Wide Improvements for Newark Airport Area

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The Florio administration has developed plans for more than $1.7 billion in construction projects in and around Newark Airport, including miles of new construction along the New Jersey Turnpike and a rail connection between the city of Newark and the airport.
Officials say the plans are intended to take advantage of growth at Newark Airport to generate thousands of publicly financed construction jobs at a time of recession, and permanent jobs to help bring the unemployed of the inner cites into the workforce. 
 But to pay for the project his aides and appointees have designed, Gov. Jim Florio will have to approve toll increases on the New Jersey Turnpike and Hudson River crossings. In a season of anti-tax fervor in New Jersey, Mr. Florio is relying on the authorities to make the case for toll increases before he supports them.
 
Parts of the Strategy
 Among the major pieces of the administration strategy for the Newark Airport area are these:
*More than $635 million in new construction along the New Jersey Turnpike, including adding a new lane in both directions from exits 11 to 14, improvements of the "southern mixing bowl" between exits 14 and 15E, and improved access to the the airport at exit 13A.
*More than $900 million in improvements by the Port Authority to the airport and the ports of Newark and Elizabeth, including a new $378 million "people mover" to transport air passengers from parking lots to terminals.
*A train link between the airport and the city; the plan favored by many officials in Trenton and supported this week by Mayor Sharpe James, would use $60 million in Port Authority funds to build a new station alongthe Northeast corridor tracks next to the airport, and use Amtrak or New Jersey Transit trains to connect the airport to Newark and New York City.
*More than $187 million in State Department of Transporation improvements to routes leading to the city, the airport and the port, including routes 1, 9, 21 and Doremus Avenue.
In an announcement scheduled for Wednesday, the Transportation Commissioner, Thomas Downs, is expected to disclose the recommendations of the Governor's Transportation Executive Council for the northeast section of the state, including much of the plans for the Newark Airport area.
The council, which includes representatives of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and a variety of state agencies, has directed that spending by the Turnpike Authority, which has $1.3 billion in its coffers, be coordinated with construction plans of the Port Authority in the airport area. The State Department of Transportation plans to draw money from its transporation trust fund to pay for the Newark area improvements.
Ever since taking office last January, Mr. Florio has tried to gain control over the spending by the independent authorities, and to use their expenditures to pay for construction projects and transportation goals that the financially strapped state agencies cannot afford.
The Newark plan shifts the focus of development in northern New Jersey from the Hudson Waterfront, the priority under Gov. Thomas H. Kean, to creating jobs south of Newark, one of the state's poorest areas.
Carl Van Horn, a top policy adviser to the Governor, said the decision to concentrate much of the available state and authority funds in the Newark Airport area grew out of projections by the Port Authority that Newark Airport will grow to rival Kennedy International Airport in the number of passengers it handles by the year 2000.
 
'Gateway of Trade With Europe'
 In addition, Mr. Van Horn said, the proximity of the ports of Elizabeth and Newark, highway and train lines, and the available workers in Newark and other poor cities, make it possible for the area to benefit dramatically from expected increases in trade from Europe through the 1990's.
"The major goal is to establish the port, the airport and the city as a major gateway of trade with Europe," said Carl Van Horn, a top aide to the governor on transportation issues. "These plans could provide job opportunities to a part of the state that has suffered greatly over the past decade."
But the plans confront the Governor with a political problem. The turnpike funds would come from money raised in a 1985 $2 billion bond issue, $1.3 billion of which has gone unspent. To pay for the bonds, the turnpike leadership has told Trenton, will require a toll increase that would likely exceed 60 percent.
In addition, the Port Authority, whose new chairman, Richard Leone, was apppointed by Mr. Florio, has asked for $1 increases in tolls at Hudson river crossings as well as 25 cent increases in PATH fares. Increases in Port Authority tolls require the approval of both the governors of New York and New Jersey. Unless the authority is granted the increases, the authority has said, its plans for improvements to the Newark Airport and Port would be severely curtailed.
 
Wrath From Motorists
 Aides say Mr. Florio heavily favors the construction projects, but they point out that after a year in which the Governor suffered mightily for raising taxes, the last thing he needs is more wrath from motorists.
Before Mr. Florio decides to approve the toll increases, politicians here say, he will wait to see what reaction the authorities draw from the public in New Jersey for their proposals.
Although the Port Authority's plans for the airport and port were announced several weeks ago, the turnpike has yet to announce what it plans to do with the unspent $1.3 billion of its 1985 bond issue. According to one official, even if the Turnpike Authority would return the entire $1.3 billion to the bond market, it would ask the Governor to approve a toll increase of more than 25 percent.
If a toll increase were approved, the authority estimates that construction could begin on the turnpike widening sometime next spring.
 
'1950's Liberal Logic'
 As for the rail link between the city of Newark and the airport, officials say there is a growing consensus among agencies and city officials that the most practical of several proposals would be the use of existing rail lines and the construction of a new station next to Conrail's abandoned 97-acre Waverly Yard.
One critic of the Florio administration, George Sternlieb, an economist and retired professor at Rutgers University, said the ideas of shifting the limited public money into the Newark area and raising tolls were ill-conceived.
"This has a certain amount of 1950's liberal logic to it, but it flies in the face of the market," Mr. Sternlieb said. "Its the same old rhetoric: let's pump money into the older central cities, lets breathe life, if not into corpses, into lifeless areas."
"The real issue is that you have a very frail economy," Mr. Sternlieb said of the proposed toll increases. "Do you really want to add more of a tax burden now?"

HEADLINE: Wary G.O.P. Governors Discuss Taxes

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 11

 BODY:
Republican governors ended a two-day meeting here today, still bruised from party setbacks in the elections and saying the party had to address core economic and tax issues to avoid bigger problems in 1992.
"We dodged a bullet last month," said Richard Wirthlin, a Republican poll taker, "and in 1992 the issues you will all face are budgeting and taxes. That's clear, and there is nowhere for any of you to hide." 
 Mr. Wirthlin and others noted that, as midterm elections go, the party had not done as badly as it had in other elections over the last 20 years when there were Republicans in the White House.
Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri, the departing chairman of the Republican Governors' Association, said the net loss of one governorship, eight House seats and one Senate seat made it basically "a break-even year," particularly since greater losses had been predicted.
 
Arizona Still Undecided
 The lineup of governors in 1991 will be 28 Democrats, 19 Republicans and 2 independents, both of whom are former Republicans. The race for governor in Arizona is to be decided in a January runoff.
But even as Governor Ashcroft and others tried to wring an upbeat message from the elections, some here were not so sanguine. Publicly and privately, they wrestled with the messages and strategies the party should use to avoid more defeats.
Gov. Michael Castle of Delaware said that in the midterm elections the party had failed in its mission to blame the Democratic-controlled Congress for the budget and tax debacles. What was needed, he said, was the outspokenness, combativeness and energy of the next party chairman, William J. Bennett.
"He makes an impact and he can crystallize issues," Governor Castle said after Mr. Bennett appeared before the group.
 
Differing on a Debate
 Some called for a bracing debate between the party's conservative and pragmatic wings, but others disagreed with such a strategy.
"Those kinds of debates are irrelevant to the whole world," said Governor-elect James Edgar of Illinois. "I'm more concerned with keeping our budget in balance and managing our fiscal problems than I am about any new paradigm."
But Mr. Bennett, speaking with reporters after addressing the group of 16 Republican governors and governors-elect, said he thought debate was good. "Debate is what you have in a brain-live party," he said.
In his speech to the group, Mr. Bennett urged the governors to devise ways of addressing the country's "most vexing problem, the position of the poor."
"Let's stop talking past one another," he said, "and let's set up a way to provide for a rigorous analysis of what works and what doesn't work in providing the conditions for upward mobility for the poor."
 
Meetings With Quayle
 On the troubling issues of taxes and budgets, the governors sought to send a message to President Bush in meetings with Vice President Dan Quayle, who addressed the group.
Gov. Carroll Campbell of South Carolina, who will become the chairman of the group for the coming year, would not say what the governors said to Mr. Quayle, but he did offer his own advice on the position the party ought to take on taxes. In an implicit criticism of the Bush Administration, he said the party should not build a tax policy around the capital gains tax and little else, nor make hard-and-fast statements against tax increases.
"I don't make Sherman-esque statements and say I will never do this or never do that," said Governor Campbell. "I may have to do just that for the good of my state later."
Mr. Quayle, meeting with reporters early today after his meetings with the governors, said he did not see future tax debates revolving solely around the capital gains tax.
"It will be more inclusive," he said. "We have learned some political lessons about how to handle the capital gains tax. Any growth package in the future would be more inclusive."
 
Linking Taxes and Services
 Mr. Wirthlin and Robert M. Teeter, President Bush's poll taker, appeared to echo Governor Campbell on the other taxation issue when they told the governors to talk to voters about providing better services for the taxes paid.
"It's true, nobody likes tax increases," said Mr. Wirthlin, "but people want value for their tax dollar. You have to do things to highlight that you are giving them value for every tax dollar you collect."
He said that if the Republican Party found that it had to advocate tax increases the governors and the party should look carefully at what taxes can get voter support and which cannot. He said that recent polling had shown that many voters with low incomes would prefer an increase in the sales tax to one in the income tax, if some higher tax was unavoidable.
"They are cynical and don't believe that the upper income brackets actually end up paying their share of income tax increases," said Mr. Wirthlin. "So if you have to, look at all kinds of taxes."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Plans More Job Cuts For This Year

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Taking a stern fiscal stance on the eve of a major sale of New York City bonds, the Dinkins administration said yesterday that the city would have to cut another 7,000 to 10,000 jobs -- about half of them through layoffs -- to help close a $250 million budget gap in the current fiscal year.
City officials said the job reductions were necessary because of expected cuts in state aid and projected shortfalls in tax revenue that have thrown the budget out of balance again, just weeks after Mayor David N. Dinkins announced that the city would not be able to fill 5,000 jobs and would lay off at least 556 workers. 
 Altogether, officials said, perhaps 15,000 jobs would be cut by the end of the fiscal year, June 30, and another 5,000 in the following year, when the city faces a projected gap of at least $1.3 billion between revenues and spending.
 
Quicker Timetable
 City officials had earlier said that they envisioned cutting as many as 20,000 jobs over the next 18 months, and they said yesterday's announcement amounted to accelerating that pace to save more money now.
Barry L. Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which is negotiating a new contract with the city, said the administration had made the announcement now to appease the Wall Street credit-rating agencies. The agencies have been reviewing the city's ratings in anticipation of its plan to borrow money through the sale of $1.2 billion in bonds today. If the ratings are lowered -- indicating that Wall Street considers the city's bonds to be a riskier investment -- the city ends up paying higher interest on money it borrows.
"The Mayor has spent a good deal of time with the rating agencies and this is a way of placating the financial community's avarice," Mr. Feinstein said. He said Mr. Dinkins had been overly gloomy about layoff projections in the past and was wrong now, too. "The Mayor has a thing about self-immolation," he said.
But Budget Director Philip R. Michael said the latest orders to cut, given to city agencies yesterday morning, had been made in recognition of the city's changing fiscal condition. "There comes a time when you've got to pin down these things," he said. "If we weren't selling bonds this week, might this have happened a week later? That's certainly possible."
Told that labor leaders had complained that they had not been consulted about the moves, Mr. Michael said, "What else is new?"
Mr. Michael said he believed the rating agencies "were very interested in expense reductions" by the city.
An official at one rating service, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "It doesn't take a rocket scientist" to see that additional layoffs are a likely option.
Mr. Michael outlined the plans to reporters after one credit rating agency, Standard & Poor's, affirmed its A- rating on the city's bonds, while keeping them on the "negative credit watch" it imposed in October.
 
Plans for Deeper Cuts
 A second rating agency, Moody's Investors Service, was still reviewing its rating, and met with Mayor Dinkins, Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and other senior officials at City Hall yesterday afternoon for a final review, in which city officials argued for mantaining the agency's A rating. Moody's is expected to make a statement today.
In recent months, in recognition of New York City's troubled economy and fiscal condition, city bonds have already been trading below their stated ratings.
In a reflection of the persistence of the fiscal problems, Mr. Michael said most agencies had been told to outline cuts amounting to 17.5 percent of their budgets in the coming fiscal year. Earlier, they had been told to prepare cuts of 10 percent and contingency plans to cut 7.5 percent more if conditions worsened.
Of those reductions, Mr. Michael said, Mr. Dinkins had ordered that cuts of 10 percent should be achieved by reducing spending for wages and benefits, to spur agencies to shrink the city work force.
 
Cuts in Education
 Mr. Michael did not say precisely where layoffs could come, but said they would be spread among agencies. The expected state cuts in aid to education could force the Board of Education to lay off "more than a couple of thousand" workers.
In its statement affirming its current rating, Standard and Poor's said it "expects the city to take all necessary actions to achieve fiscal balance." But it added that "in light of the contracting economy, that challenge will be more difficult to meet than in prior years."
It said that maintaining the current rating "depends upon formulation of a plan that reflects the uncertainty of the economic environment and balances achievable revenue assumptions with necessary service reductions."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
500 GULF HOSTAGES FLOWN TO SAFETY

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Nearly 500 Western and Japanese hostages left Kuwait and Iraq today on chartered planes, but only one American emerged from hiding in Kuwait to board one of the three Boeing 707's sent there for what had been described as a final evacuation effort.
Two chartered British planes picked up 240 British and other Western nationals in Kuwait, along with the single American, who declined to identify himself. The evacuees were joined in Baghdad by 72 Britons who had been returned in recent days by Iraqi authorities from military and industrial installations where they were held as so-called human shields. 
 Another 8 Americans, gathered from strategic sites in Iraq, boarded the American evacuation flight to Frankfurt tonight. Seven Americans were on a British charter from Kuwait to London, and 6 got themselves out by driving in cars to Saudi Arabia from Kuwait.
[Both flights landed at their destinations on Tuesday evening, The Associated Press reported.]
The State Department in Washington said as many as 309 Americans had chosen to stay in Kuwait and 200 in Iraq. These included 294 children, 100 women and 115 men with dual citizenship. Another 30 are unaccounted for.
State Department officials say they believe that 268 Americans have left Iraq and Kuwait since the latest hostage exodus began over the weekend.
Originally, the State Department said there were about 750 Americans who were believed to be in Kuwait and Iraq. But now the estimate is that there may have been 807 Americans in the two countries.
 
No More Held as Shields
 A United States Embassy official here said she was satisifed that no more Americans were being held at Iraqi installations.
Separately, 159 Japanese hostages boarded an Iraqi Airways charter to Bangkok. Fourteen of them had been diplomats in Kuwait.
Despite the poor turnout for the American charter flight to Kuwait, which returned to Baghdad carrying one Irishman and two Canadians, United States officials here and in Washington said a final charter flight has been scheduled for Thursday.
"We don't know many people are in deep hiding," said Jeanette Pinot, a United States consular officer who was ushering Americans onto the plane at Saddam International Airport. "But I think it's going to be a trickle from now on." A State Department doctor who arrived today from Cairo accompanied the Americans to Frankfurt.
 
'Continue to Assist'
 The deputy chief of the American Embassy in Baghdad, Joseph C. Wilson 4th, added, "We will not get big planeloads, I don't believe, but we will continue to assist any American held against their will."
Mr. Wilson, who has supervised the consular effort that has assisted more than 2,500 Americans trapped in Kuwait since the invasion by Iraq on Aug. 2, said the flights this week will conclude a complex and successful evacuation effort.
After he moved through the line of hostages shaking hands and saying goodbye to some of those who have lived for months in safe haven here at the residence of the United States Ambassador, April Glaspie, Mr. Wilson told reporters, "I swear to God that I hope this is the last time in my generation and my childrens' generation that we ever face the specter of people being taken against their will."
At the American Embassy in Kuwait, Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell; his deputy, Barbara Bodine, and two other diplomats remained behind after the departure of 6 of their colleagues and about 12 other Americans who had taken refuge there.
 
Christmas Carols at Embassy
 An Irishman who was in hiding within sight of the embassy compound in Kuwait said Mr. Howell and his group of holdouts played Christmas carols over loudspeakers two nights ago as Iraqi soldiers maintained their cordon around the United States mission, which is still without electricity and basic services.
Iraqi military authorities have told the last of the diplomats that anyone who steps outside of the compound will not be able to return. United States officials say the status of the embassy after it is abandoned, which is scheduled to happen on Thursday, will be that it is "open" but not staffed, "whatever that means," a Western official here said.
Although it is hard to come up with exact figures in the turmoil associated with the hasty exodus, State Department officials said that they believed 268 Americans had left so far. These included those who departed today and on Sunday, plus those who departed with John Connally, the former United States Treasury Secretary, on Saturday.
In Washington, the State Department said that the 30 Americans who remain unaccounted for may include some who are still in "deep hiding," and still others who may possess false identity papers protecting economic assets, businesses and property in Kuwait.
 
Missing Americans Sought
 The Voice of America was reported on Monday to be broadcasting appeals for information from four Americans who have not been heard from since August, a United States official here said.
A number of hostages speculated that some Americans and other Westerners still are missing, and some may have perished during any of the hundreds of sometimes harrowing and desperate attempts to escape through the Kuwaiti desert toSaudi Arabia.
The combination of intense August heat and random shootings by Iraqi soldiers may also have claimed lives, the returning hostages said.
Of those Americans who remained, a State Department official said: "It's people where the family chooses to stay -- a Kuwaiti husband has an American wife, or Kuwaiti husband and wife have an American kid. They'd have to break up the family to go. Some are Arab-Americans, some are dual nationals -- people whose homes, family ties and maybe business interests are there and who consider themselves more Iraqi than American.
"We've got these people everywhere," he added. "Beirut, Monrovia, everywhere."
 
Briton Posed as Romanian
 Several British hostages arrived from Kuwait saying they passed themselves off as citizens of such countries as Romania and Spain.
Leonard and Maureen Baker of Southampton, England, said they stayed in their home near Schuwaikh Port in Kuwait and fended off inquiring Iraqis with Romanian identity documents. They said they witnessed the "commercial looting" of the city and its port by the Iraqi Army, which used "thousands of trucks from Baghdad."
Mr. Baker said he saw goal posts disappear from the soccer fields and cranes used to hoist heavy equipment, construction huts, cars and the inventory of port warehouses onto 16-wheel trucks for transport to Iraq.
Mr. Baker, a service engineer for Volvo Penta, said that in Kuwait's marinas thousands of yachts, fishing boats and pleasure craft were burned or sunk by the Iraqi military to prevent flight by sea. The Bakers lost their 26-foot boat.
One of the last Americans to board today's flight, Mike Nickerman of Grand Island, Neb., spent four months in idle but safe haven at the residence of Miss Glaspie, the American Ambassador to Iraq, who was out of the country at the time of the invasion.
Mr. Nickerman, who had been working on a construction site near the Syrian border on Aug. 2, said the lesson he had learned from his experience was never to hesitate in the face of danger. He criticized his own caution and unwillingness to escape Iraq at the outset of the crisis.
"I learned if something looks like trouble, I'm going to get out while I have the chance," Mr. Nickerman said.
 
 
 
MORE IRAQI TROOPS IN KUWAIT
 WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Iraq has placed 20,000 more troops in and around Kuwait in the past week, expanding the Iraqi armed force in the area to more than half a million soldiers, Pentagon officials said today.
Last week, the Pentagon said Iraq had sent 480,000 troops to Kuwait and southern Iraq. That represented an increase of 30,000 from the week before.
Mr. Williams described the latest additions to the Iraqi force as "a rounding out of existing brigades" committed to the occupation of Kuwait, rather than the arrival of newly activated brigades.
The United States buildup is also continuing. A Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said today that an additional 10,000 American troops had arrived in the gulf since last week, increasing the total American force there to 260,000.

Mr. Wilson said, "We will continue to assist any American held against their will." (Associated Press) (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: Like Growing Number of Companies, I.B.M. Is Building Child-Care Centers

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

 BODY:
Like an increasing number of corporations that are frustrated by the shortage of good child care for their employees, the International Business Machines Corporation has decided to take a more active role and build its own centers.
The company announced yesterday that it would spend $3 million next year to build five child-care centers near its offices and plants around the country to serve 530 preschool children. 
 It said it would spend an additional $500,000 in communities that have large populations of I.B.M. workers to improve existing day-care centers and to recruit and train people who care for children in their homes. The company does not plan to operate the centers; that will be done by companies specializing in child care. Nor will I.B.M. give employees direct financial assistance for child care.
 
'Lousy Choices'
 "Companies are frustrated because employees have lousy choices," said Dana Friedman, co-president of the Families and Work Institute, a nonprofit research organization based in New York that advises companies on child care.
"A number of companies like I.B.M. that said they would not build child-care centers, that they are not in the business of child care, are reconsidering," Dr. Friedman said. "They have milked other options, and now they realize they have to roll up their sleeves and be in it in a bigger way."
Dr. Friedman added that it was highly unusual for a corporation to build five child-care centers. "I don't know of any company that has built more than two or three," she said.
The new projects represent the largest expenditure to date of the $22 million fund that I.B.M. established a year ago to increase the availability of child-care services for its employees. The money, to be distributed over a five years, represents the largest financial commitment by any American corporation for child care.
Since 1984, I.B.M.'s child-care assistance for its 216,000 employees in the United States has consisted of a referral service. But I.B.M. found that that was strained by the limited supply and poor quality of child care in many American communities.
 
'A Long-Term Investment'
 J. T. Childs Jr., the director of the company's Work/Life Program, noted that the number of male employees at I.B.M. had declined by 20 percent over the last 30 years while the number of female employees had tripled, so child care had become a vital program to keep women in the work force.
He described the company's decision as "a long-term investment in our economic and competitive health."
Barbara Reisman, executive director of the Child Care Action Campaign, a national advocacy organization, said the I.B.M. announcement "confirms what we have been saying, that the quality of child care is not what it should be, and that companies can help to do something about it."
But Dr. Edward F. Zigler, a child psychologist and director of Yale University's Bush Center in Child Development and Social Policy, said that while I.B.M. "is to be commended for doing something to make the work place more family friendly," such corporate initiatives "are not the solution" to the lack of adequate child care in the United States.
 
Limited Assistance Now
 Dr. Zigler, a founder of the Head Start program, said, "The Reagan Administration's solution was for the private sector to take this on." But, he said, only 6,000 of nearly six million employers now provide some form of child-care assistance.
"And what will happen when a company falls on hard times?" Dr. Zigler asked. "It will close a child-care center, not an assembly plant."
Mr. Childs said that Work/Family Directions of Boston, I.B.M.'s child-care consultant, would choose experienced child-care companies to operate the centers. "We are not in the child-care business," he said.
Fees at each center will be set by the operator, he said. But since the new centers will not be encumbered by mortgages, he said, "It will be easier for them to operate and establish reasonable fees."
In addition to the new centers, I.B.M. will finance programs to recruit and train people to care for small groups of children in their homes. The company will also provide money to help scores of child-care centers around the country meet the quality standards established by the National Association for the Education of Young Children, the largest group of early-childhood educators in the nation.
Of the $3.5 million, I.B.M. has allocated for construction, nearly half has been designated for two new day-care centers at large office parks in Charlotte and Raleigh, N.C., a state that I.B.M. officials said has an especially severe shortage of good child-care services.
Other new centers are to be built near I.B.M. plants and offices in Rochester, Minn.; Gaithersburg, Md., and Southlake, Tex.
 
'Help the Community'
 Mr. Childs said that although I.B.M. is primarily building child-care centers to help its employees, at least half of the enrollment at most centers will be open to the public. "We are trying to help the community while helping our own people," he said.
Several of I.B.M.'s new centers will be in collaboration with other corporations. For example, in an office park in Charlotte, owned by University Research Park, I.B.M., the American Express Company, Duke Power Company and Research Park will share the costs of building and providing money to start up a $2 million child-care center that will serve nearly 200 children, including mildly sick youngsters. I.B.M. will contribute $500,000 of the total.
In Katonah, N.Y., in Westchester County, near I.B.M.'s headquarters and other offices, the company will be joined by Pepsi-Cola in financing the $600,000 relocation and expansion of a center that provides care for both pre-school and school-age children. I.B.M.'s share will be $430,000.
And in Southlake, Tex., about 20 miles from Dallas, I.B.M. and Maguire Thomas Partners, a real estate developer, will convert an unoccupied building in an office complex into a day-care center for infants and pre-school children. I.B.M. will provide $500,000 of the $800,000 total cost.
Dr. Friedman said I.B.M.'s collaboration with other corporations "could be a catalyst" for other companies to join forces in providing child-care assistance. "Smaller companies can spend less money but still work together and make a dent," she said. "I.B.M. is providing new models, new thinking. It often takes one employer to stand up and say, 'Let's go for it, let's figure out how to do it.' "
