HEADLINE: U.S. Treasury Charges Discrimination by Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 11

 BODY:
In a tough new report on the slow opening of Japan's financial markets, the United States Treasury Department said today that foreign banks and securities firms were still blocked from competing on equal terms because of legal and informal hurdles, despite Tokyo's emergence as a major financial center.
The Treasury study conceded that some of the blatant discrimination against foreigners, such as a lack of seats on the Tokyo stock exchange, have been eliminated in recent years. But in a slight shift of focus in Washington's efforts to open Japan's financial markets, it added that some of the worst impediments faced by foreign firms were informal barriers, or unwritten business and government practices. 
 An example of this sort of barrier has cropped up recently in what is becoming one of the most closely watched confrontations between an American securities house and Japanese ways in years.
Salomon Brothers Inc. appeared to have staged a coup recently in breaking the lock grip that big Japanese brokerage houses have on underwriting the yen securities of Japanese companies. It won the mandate to be the lead manager on two big offerings of convertible bonds in the Euromarkets for Oji Paper and Fujisawa Pharmaceutical.
 
'Like Exporting AIDS'
 But just 10 days later, Japan's biggest broker, Nomura Securities, protested vehemently against what it described as the unsound way Salomon planned to trade the bonds after they were issued, a complex technique that is common in the more innovative New York markets. The yen-denominated securities were going to be swapped into dollars, combined with options and sold to American insurance companies as private placements instead of publicly listed securities.
"It's like exporting AIDS from Wall Street," Tadashi Takubo, an executive managing director at Nomura, was quoted as saying in the Japan Economic Journal, the country's leading business newspaper. "We have to protect the soundness of the Tokyo market from the U.S. threat."
Asked about the story, Fujisawa Pharmaceutical said yesterday that it had not decided who would underwrite its convertible bonds and Oji Paper said it would neither confirm nor deny the reports.
But Salomon officials insisted the Big Four securities houses had intimidated the companies into backing away from using an American lead underwriter, in spite of the better terms Salomon was offering.
 
Importance of Cultural Factors
 "We offer good technology and some good market opportunities, but how a Japanese company comes to a decision on its underwriter is the critical question at the end of the day," said Kunihiko Kumagai, a managing director at Salomon Brothers. "The cultural, or invisible factors can be the most important part of doing business."
He added, "We need to learn a lot more about how to persuade a Japanese company."
Earlier this year, Salomon sailed into another controversy when it stunned the Big Four by underwriting some dollar-denominated bonds for Mitsui Toatsu, a big chemical company. Shortly afterward the Japanese newspapers were filled with complaints from the big Japanese brokerage houses on how Salomon's program trading was behind a steep slide in share prices.
The report issued today is a so-called national treatment study, intended to determine whether American financial institutions are permitted to compete on an equal footing with Japan's own banks and securities firms within Japan. The latest report, the fourth in the last decade, repeats the conclusion that Japan still restricts the operating ability of foreign bankers and investment bankers.
According to Treasury estimates, foreign banks have actually been losing ground here.
Foreign banks' share of total lending has tumbled from 3.5 percent in March 1983 to 1.7 percent at the end of last year. By contrast, Japanese banks have taken more than 25 percent of the lucrative California banking market.
No Japanese bank has been acquired by a foreign bank and foreign banks must pay much higher rates to borrow yen and acquire funds to operate in Japan, the report says.
Specifically, the Treasury contends that despite several important openings since 1986, keiretsu, or big groupings of industrial companies and banks, exclude foreign banks. Relatively inexpensive short-term loans from the Bank of Japan are difficult for foreigners to obtain. Japan's short-term money markets remain underdeveloped. And many regulations continue to be delivered orally or in ways that are difficult for foreign banks to obtain and cary out.
On the securities side, the report argues that foreign firms are still excluded from the underwriting business. They are still not free to trade in foreign currencies. New financial products are accepted here only after substantial delays. And foreign firms still face major obstacles in breaking into the lucrative business of managing pension funds and investment trusts.

HEADLINE: Colleges Basing Aid on Race Risk Loss of Federal Funds

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
The Department of Education has decided to begin prohibiting colleges and universities that receive Federal funds from offering scholarships designated for minority students.
Michael L. Williams, the Education Department's Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights, said yesterday that "race-exclusive" scholarships, or those based on ethnic origin, were discriminatory and therefore illegal. 
 College administrators and scholarship fund directors reacted with alarm, saying the decision could reverse decades of efforts to increase the enrollment of members of racial and ethnic minorities who have been historically underrepresented in colleges.
"We were shocked by this decision," said Richard F. Rosser, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, which represents 815 institutions. "We have been making enormous efforts to increase the numbers of minority students in our colleges and universities, and this has necessarily required a great deal of financial aid."
Neither Mr. Rosser nor anyone else contacted yesterday could say how many institutions, or what percentage of total financial aid to minority students, might be affected by the new enforcement policy. But the practice of setting aside money to attract qualified minority students and make college more affordable for them has been widespread for at least 20 years.
Scholarships based strictly on financial need often benefit minority students, and they would not be affected. Nor would scholarships awarded to individual students by private foundations and groups. Groups like the United Negro College Fund, which raises money for historically black colleges but does not stipulate that the revenue be used for minority students only, would also seem to be exempt.
Word of the department's policy reached college administrators and scholarship fund directors after the department sent a letter on Dec. 4 to organizers of the Fiesta Bowl in Tempe, Ariz. The organizers, under fire for the State of Arizona's policy against a holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., had proposed to set up a scholarship fund in Dr. King's memory for the two universities whose teams play in the annual football game. The department's letter cautioned that a scholarship earmarked for minority students would be illegal.
Mr. Williams said his position should not be seen as an assault on minority scholarships or an attempt to curb the numbers of black and Hispanic college students. Rather, he said, he wants his office to have a consistent approach to "race-exclusive" financial aid.
He said the issue was one of seven areas on which the Office of Civil Rights would concentrate as part of a new national enforcement strategy. A memorandum outlining that strategy was circulated in the department yesterday, and will be described at a press conference in Washington today.
It is not clear whether Mr. Williams's initiative has the specific approval of the Bush Administration. Mr. Williams has been preparing the overall enforcement strategy since his appointment in June.
Explaining his position, Mr. Williams said yesterday that institutions receiving money from the Department of Education may not provide or deny financial aid or other benefits on the basis of race, color or national origin. He cited the 1978 Supreme Court decision in Bakke v. University of California at Davis, which held that a state institution could not have fixed quotas for certain racial or ethnic groups, although race could be taken into account in affirmative action programs to remedy past discrimination.
Mr. Williams also cited a 1976 lawsuit, Flanagan v. President and Directors of Georgetown College. In that case, he said, a Federal district court found that the civil rights law had been violated by the college's practice of allocating 60 percent of its financial aid for minority students.
Race-based scholarships may be appropriate within certain narrow limits, Mr. Williams said. For example, exceptions would be allowed at colleges in which past racial or ethnic discrimination had been established. He added that race could be a factor in determining whether a student should receive special financial help, but not the essential factor.
For more than a decade, he said, the Education Department has been inconsistent on the issue of race and financial aid. "We owe colleges and universities a good-faith and legally honest review of the law," he went on. "Quite frankly, we have not done that in the past."
In mid-November, the Fiesta Bowl organizers offered to award $100,000 minority scholarships to each of the two universities fielding football teams in the New Year's Day game, and to name the scholarships in honor of Dr. King. This year's teams are the Universities of Louisville and Alabama.
Last week the Education Department's Office for Civil Rights reviewed the Fiesta Bowl scholarship plan on its own initiative. In the department's Dec. 4 letter, sent by fax to John Junker, the bowl's executive director, Mr. Williams applauded the attempt to provide educational opportunities for minority students. But he added, "You should be aware of certain civil rights obligations," and said colleges failing to comply with provisions of the Civil Rights Act risked losing all Federal revenue.
The letter suggested that the scholarship aid be used to benefit students who are "economically disadvantaged, educationally disadvantaged or from single-parent families."
Brent DeRaad, a Fiesta Bowl spokesman, said bowl officials would follow all Federal regulations. While the fund will be named for Dr. King, he said, the scholarship will not designate race as a criterion for qualification.
"We will let the universities allocate the money as they see fit," Mr. DeRaad said.
Nonetheless, Mr. DeRaad said bowl officials would do all they could to suggest that the scholarships be used for financially needy students.
Richard J. Wood, president of Earlham College in Richmond, Ind., who is co-chairman of the Task Force for Minority Opportunities of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, called Mr. Williams's decision "outrageous," and said it was "the continuation of the kind of thinking" of the Reagan Administration and its Education Secretary, William J. Bennett.

HEADLINE: BUSH BACKS MOVE FOR LIMITING TERMS OF U.S. LAWMAKERS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
President Bush has decided to push for a constitutional amendment to limit the number of terms for members of Congress, his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, said today.
Doing so as he prepares for his re-election campaign will put Mr. Bush squarely and publicly on the side of an idea that is as widely popular among voters as it is wildly unpopular among members of Congress, including many Republican lawmakers. And state lawmakers are not enamored of the idea either. 
 These are the people whose votes would be needed to make the idea a reality. But even though passage of such an amendment is unlikely, there is little risk for Mr. Bush in associating himself with this movement.
 
Evolution of an Issue
 Politically, the move fits nicely with the growing effort by the White House to depict Congress as the source of most of the nation's problems.
"The reality that incumbency breeds a very different attitude is now sensed by the public," Mr. Sununu said.
Mr. Bush has previously said he supports limiting lawmakers' terms, just as the terms of the President and many governors are limited. Vice President Quayle campaigned heavily on the issue during the midterm elections.
But Mr. Sununu's comment today, at a National Press Club luncheon, was the first public indication that the White House plans to work to keep the issue alive -- indeed, draw even more attention to it -- as the Presidential election approaches.
The movement to limit terms, many politicians say, has begun to take on a life of its own, somewhat reminiscent of the way the revolt against taxes gathered momentum a decade ago.
 
Democrats Are Opposed
 Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill are against a constitutional amendment limiting Congressional terms, and have said they would oppose it. Some Democrats have characterized the proposal as a "Republican front," intended to accomplish what the Republicans cannot do at the ballot box: regain control of Congress.
But many incumbent Republicans also oppose the amendment. A spokeswoman for Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican leader of the House, said, "He doesn't think it needs to be done."
President Bush, as Ronald Reagan did before him, has embraced a number of other controversial proposals for constitutional amendments, and none have been enacted. They include measures to curb abortion, to require a balanced budget and to give the President power to veto individual budget items.
Mr. Bush made a public push for an amendment to ban flag burning, which the Supreme Court has ruled is protected by the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech. But Democrats, led by Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said such a measure would amount to tampering with the First Amendment, and the measure died on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Sununu made his comment in a luncheon speech in which he also defended himself from the view, prevalent in Washington, that his abrasive style has offended too many people, including Congressional leaders of his own party.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, recently called him the "chief of chaff," and Senator Trent Lott has said he was mystified when Mr. Sununu described the Senator's role in the budget process as "insignficant," even though the Mississippi Republican was involved in the budget negotiations.
 
Another Dig at Congress
 Mr. Sununu took the opportunity today to try to fault Congress for the nation's economic troubles, saying the problems would not be so deep if the Federal budget had been settled six months sooner. Congressional leaders roundly reject blame for the delay.
Mr. Sununu, who as Governor of New Hampshire in 1988 was instrumental in helping Mr. Bush defeat Mr. Dole for the Republcian Presidential nomination, said reports of clashes with members of Congress and others were "based on fiction, not fact." But later he said that his outbursts had been orchestrated to achieve political effect.
"I guarantee you that, contrary to the legend, any strong statements on my part are both controlled, deliberate and designed to achieve an effect," he told the audience. "There is no random outburst. It all is designed for a purpose. And I think the efficiency of the result is underscored by what we've been able to achieve."
 
His Personality an Issue
 The entire day, from the lunchtime speech to an evening show on cable television, seemed to have been an effort by Mr. Sununu to counteract a wave of recent criticism and negative press coverage that painted him as a liability to the President.
Just hours after his appearance at the press club, Mr. Sununu went on Cable News Network, where Larry King, the interviewer, asked Mr. Sununu about his role in the budget negotiations with Congress, his relationships with Republicans with whom he disagrees and the crisis in the Persian Gulf.
Mr. Sununu said, "Oh, not at all," when asked by Mr. King whether President Bush had ever called him on the carpet.
"See," Mr. Sununu said, "I only have a constituency of one to keep happy; that's the President."
 
A Freudian Slip?
 In discussing the issue of limiting terms, Mr. Sununu made a remark at the press club luncheon that was apparently a slip of the tongue. Mr. Sununu said Mr. Bush would "press for a term-limitation amendment that deals with the problems associated with perpetuating the life of those who are elected to govern people."
"I think that's more than a Freudian slip," said Jeff Biggs, chief spokesman for Speaker Foley, who opposes term limits. "That's his true wish."
As the crowd began to laugh at Mr. Sununu's remark, and some people began to applaud, Mr. Sununu corrected himself to say, "The public life of those who are elected to govern people."
In elections this year, voters in California, Oklahoma and Colorado, approved measures limiting the terms of state officeholders -- measures that seemed to give voters a way of expressing their frustration with goverment.
The Colorado measure also seeks to limit the terms of members of Congress, but the constitutionality of state action to limit the tenure of Federal office holders is far from clear.
 
Many Favor 12 Years
 White House officials said Mr. Sununu was not referring to any specific proposal in his speech today. Most proponents of term limits have tended to favor a tenure of 12 years, that is, six terms for members of the House and two terms for senators. But any number of variations are possible, and there would be a number of crucial questions, including how current members would be affected.
The 22d Amendment to the Constitution, limiting the President to two terms, was approved by the 80th Congress in 1947. It won ratification by the required three-fourths of the states in 1951. No amendment has taken longer to ratify.
The 22d Amendment was a reaction, initiated by Republicans, against Franklin D. Roosevelt's decision to break the tradition that a President serve no more than two terms. Roosevelt was elected four times and died in office.
There was an effort to repeal the amendment during Dwight D. Eisenhower's second term, but nothing came of it, and the two-term limit now seems sacrosanct. President Reagan said he opposes both the limit on the President and a limit on lawmakers, but he made no serious effort to repeal the 22d Amendment.
Mr. Foley, who was first elected to the House in 1964, has spoken out repeatedly against the idea of limiting Congressional terms. He, and other opponents, argue that it would deprive voters of the right to choose their own representatives. Most members, they add, serve less than 12 years anyway, and some of the most effective and seasoned legislators would be affected.

HEADLINE: The Budget Cuts: Still Real, Still Right

 BODY:
In October, after months of rancorous debate, Congress passed a budget bill that promised to cut the deficit by nearly $500 billion. Now the Congressional Budget Office reports that, even so, the deficit will rise to record levels this year and next. That has prompted wide cynicism among people who conclude that, once again, Congress must have been trading in mere budget gimmicks. 
 Such cynicism is ill founded. Yes, the level of the deficit will rise beyond previous expectations but for reasons beyond Congress's control -- namely, the skyrocketing costs of the S.& L. bailout and the oncoming recession. But those facts in no way diminish the impact of the budget agreement. Because of the agreement, the deficit will still be $500 billion lower, which is all Congress promised.
In fact, the Congressional Budget Office report can be interpreted as vindicating Congress. Anticipating bad economic news, it purposely held down the first year's cuts for fear of pushing a sluggish economy into recession.
Critics have misinterpreted other parts of the report. Borrowing money to pay off depositors at failed thrifts does not affect capital markets and therefore does not hurt the economy. Cutting programs or raising taxes to pay for the S.& L. bailout is unwarranted.
Nor should Congress react to the rise in deficits caused by recession. Tax revenues will fall; expenditures for unemployment compensation and welfare will rise. These changes are welcome because they will alleviate misery and mitigate the downturn. If Congress tried to keep the deficit steady by further cutting programs or raising taxes, it would worsen the slide. That would drive up unemployment, as well as the deficit. And that's precisely why the budget cuts were "back-loaded," falling more heavily in later years.
The purpose of deficit reduction is to reduce the amount the Government siphons from private borrowers and therefore from capital formation. But that's not an important danger in this climate, when the economy is receding and corporations aren't borrowing. The budget agreement will restrain Federal borrowing best when that restraint is needed most: when the economy returns to capacity. And nothing in the Congressional Budget Office report says otherwise.

HEADLINE: The Daily News Wins Backing In Chicago

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The board of The Daily News's parent, the Tribune Company, met here today, and afterward the publisher of the paper, James Hoge, said The News would continue to publish as long as it showed progress in overcoming the seven-week-old strike by 9 of its 10 unions.
Mr. Hoge cited as progress what he called an increase to a circulation of 580,000. Before the strike began on Oct. 25, The News's circulation was 1.09 million. It has also lost most of its advertising as a result of the strike. 
 The meeting of the Tribune Company's 14-member board at the company's headquarters on Michigan Avenue was closed, but afterward Mr. Hoge told reporters that the board had considered all the options for the future of the paper, including its possible sale or closing.
 
'We Are Making Progress'
 But the only option supported, Mr. Hoge said, was "plowing ahead as long as we can show that we are making progress."
"It is the opinion of everybody involved in this effort that we are making progress," the publisher added.
In a statement issued after the meeting, Mr. Hoge said the board "expressed continued strong support of Daily News management." As the board met in the morning, about 100 pickets, including some Guild members from The News and some union members from Chicago, marched outside the headquarters chanting, "Settle or sell."
Jerry Minkkinen, the executive director of the Newspaper Guild in Chicago, said the pickets hoped the board members "would talk some sense into Charlie Brumback." Charles T. Brumback is the chief executive of the Tribune Company.
Mr. Hoge is not a member of the board but appeared at its request to report on the status of The News, a Tribune Company spokeswoman, Martha Lindeman, said.
In his statement, Mr. Hoge said he told the board that circulation had increased "despite continued violent intimidation against newsstand dealers and small retail store owners."
The circulation increases had been achieved, he said, by raising the number of dealers and street hawkers selling the paper. The total of such outlets, Mr. Hoge said, now approaches half of the 12,000 outlets that sold the News before the strike.
Mr. Hoge said that at the same time the company continues to try to publish and increase its circulation, that it will "make every effort to achieve fair and reasonable collective-bargaining settlements with the assistance of the Federal mediation service." Representatives of The News and the striking unions are to meet Wednesday in Washington with the head of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, Bernard DeLury.
Both sides have expressed hope that the meeting, the first involving management, all of the striking unions and an outside mediator, will lead to a breakthrough in negotiations, which have been stalled for 11 months.
In New York City, the 52-year-old Federal law that allowed The News to fill the jobs of striking workers with permanent nonunion employees came under new attack today.
 
Accusations of Intimidation
 Representatives of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins and three union representatives asserted that the practice not only hinders collective bargaining, but also is a factor in strike-related violence.
The News has accused its nine striking unions of conspiring to terrorize news vendors and nonunion employees through violence and intimidation. Unions leaders have denied the accusation, and senior police officials said last month that they had found no evidence of a centrally coordinated effort.
Governor Cuomo's Labor Commissioner, Thomas F. Hartnett, told a Senate subcommittee hearing in lower Manhattan today that the use of permanent replacements -- a practice he called "the industrial equivalent of capital punishment" -- causes "bitterness and hostility that leads to violence."
Eric J. Schmertz, Mayor Dinkins's Labor Relations Commissioner, agreed. "It is not illogical to conclude," he said, that workers who find themselves permanently replaced "may resort to unlawful action and commit acts or threats of violence because the economic burden on them becomes too severe."
 
Law to Outlaw Replacements
 Mr. Schmertz and Mr. Hartnett were among six witnesses who testified at the hearing, which was conducted by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, and Representative Major R. Owens, Democrat of Brooklyn. Mr. Metzenbaum has introduced legislation to outlaw the use of permanent replacements.
The News declined to send a representative to testify, a fact Senator Metzenbaum said, "I particularly regret."
Since Mr. Reagan's action, according to a study last June by the General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress, there has been a sharp increase in employers' use of permanent replacements. The study found that in 1989, the practice was used in 30 percent of strikes, up from 23 percent in 1985.
 
Cardinal Speaks Out
 Mr. Hartnett told Senator Metzenbaum that he was convinced that the practice permanently destroys "any vestige of equality" at the bargaining table.
The Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, John Cardinal O'Connor, saying he spoke as "the proud son of a lifelong union man," said that he could see no clear moral justification for using permanent replacement workers. The Cardinal told the hearing that had The News not been armed with "the weapon of permanent replacement," the seemingly minor labor squabble that helped prompt the strike "would have fizzled out very quickly."
The other witnesses at the hearing yesterday were George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council; Theodore W. Kheel, legal adviser to the striking unions, and Otilio Mighty, a striking driver.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 14, 1990, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the strike at The Daily News referred incompletely to the newspaper's response to a Congressional hearing in New York City on Tuesday about the hiring of workers to replace strikers. While the paper did not send a representative to testify, it did submit a detailed written statement of its position.

HEADLINE: Clarke to Be Renamed as Comptroller

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
President Bush decided today to reappoint Robert L. Clarke as the nation's top regulator of nationally chartered banks, taking the advice of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady over the objection of the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu.
The nomination of Mr. Clarke as Comptroller of the Currency had been recommended weeks ago by Mr. Brady. It had been considered a foregone conclusion, especially since the office is a division of the Treasury Department, until Mr. Sununu stepped in earlier this month. He raised concerns that tough regulation of the banking community was contributing to the current credit crunch, reflecting views he had heard from bankers in New England. 
 Mr. Clarke's five-year term expired on Dec. 2, but he has remained in the post while the President considered the reappointment. Democrats in Congress have come to Mr. Clarke's defense, and he is not expected to face a hostile renomination hearing.
Senior bank officials and lobbyists said that while Mr. Clarke would probably be reappointed, the White House wanted to send a signal to regulators to be sensitive to the difficulties bankers face as real estate values plummet in many parts of the nation.
"At the very least, it's a shot across the bow," said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, when reports of Mr. Sununu's objections came to light last week.
Mr. Clarke, who earlier this year told a Congressional panel that the industry had termed him "the regulator from hell," appeared responsive to Mr. Sununu's concerns.
"This is an extremely difficult time for lenders, borrowers and bank regulators," he said in a statement. "However, we can work through the current problems if lenders assume their responsibility to make loans and take reasonable risks, and if regulators follow a responsive, balanced approach that takes into account their regulatory responsibilities, current economic conditions and the very significant national interest in not unnecessarily depressing credit availability."
 
 'Time for Common Sense'
 "In short," he added, "I believe that now is a time for the application of common sense, a time when neither lenders nor regulators should overreact or be unresponsive."
Mr. Clarke, a 48-year-old Houston lawyer, came to Washington in 1985 at the request of his friend and fellow Texan, James A. Baker 3d, who was then President Ronald Reagan's Treasury Secretary. As Comptroller of the Currency, he regulates more than 4,200 nationally chartered banks, which hold about two-thirds of the assets of the commercial banking system.
A Treasury official who insisted on anonymity said Mr. Clarke's nomination had also been opposed by several large Republican contributors, who had asked Mr. Sununu to intervene.
 
Complaints From Bankers
 Difficulties between Mr. Sununu and Mr. Clarke began more than a year ago, the official said, when examiners from the Comptroller's office began looking at troubled real estate loans from the Northeast. Mr. Sununu, a former Governor of New Hampshire, then began receiving complaints from local bankers that the examinations were too tough, the official said. Mr. Sununu passed those complaints on to Mr. Clarke.
When a group of senior bank regulators met with President Bush last month about the state of the economy and the nation's banks, Mr. Sununu again raised concerns based on anecdotal information that too stringent regulation was causing credit tightening. Without naming the company or its bank, Mr. Sununu told the regulators that he knew of a New Hampshire institution that had paid its loans on time but was still having trouble getting financing.
At the meeting, the regulators were strongly defended by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, who by several accounts told the President that a softening economy required the regulators to be vigilant against improper lending practices.

HEADLINE: 4 Billion Loss Seen by F.D.I.C.

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The nation's senior bank regulator said today that the Federal fund that insures deposits would probably lose $4 billion or more this year.
The prediction, by L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, appeared to be another sign of the deterioration of the bank insurance system. It came less than three months after he had said that the fund would probably lose about $3 billion, a revision that itself was only a few months old. A loss of $4 billion for the year would put the fund at about $9 billion, only about $7 billion of which is readily available in cash. 
Mr. Seidman said that as a result, if the insurance fund was not reorganized, the F.D.I.C. might experience what he called "problems with liquidity" in 1991 that would require the agency to borrow money to bail out institutions that failed.
"It isn't a concern at the moment," he said. "It might become a concern during 1991 if the pace of failures increases."
 
Overhaul to Be Proposed
 With the insurance fund now at its lowest level in relation to deposits in its 56-year history, the Bush Administration is planning to propose an overhaul of the banking system that includes a reorganization of the bank insurance fund.
 Banks now contribute to the fund by paying a flat fee based on their size. Working with regulators at the F.D.I.C., Administration officials are preparing proposals to tie the payments to banks' financial health instead.
 The latest estimate on losses for the insurance fund includes banks that the F.D.I.C. knows with reasonable certainty would be closed by early next year. It came with a report by the F.D.I.C. that earnings for the third quarter for the nation's 12,399 federally insured banks were down 29 percent from the quarter before, to $3.75 billion.
 Unlike most businesses that are seasonal and compare quarterly results on a year-to-year basis, banks look at successive quarterly reports for trends. For the third quarter of last year, banks reported losses of $744 million, much of which was attributed to many banks adding to reserves to cover losses from loans to developing countries.
 Today's report also contained a host of other discouraging news about the banking industry.
 "Over all, the outlook for the fourth quarter has to be bleak," Mr. Seidman said. He said that real estate problems, particularly in the Northeast, continue to hurt many banks. The F.D.I.C. quarterly report showed that the larger banks -- those with more than $1 billion in assets -- were having the greatest troubles with poor earnings and low asset quality.
 
Consumer Delinquencies Rise
 There was a sharp increase in delinquent consumer loans, with a 10.4 percent increase in the third quarter. The delinquency rate for consumer loans was 20 percent higher in the first three quarters of 1990 than in the period last year.
 The F.D.I.C. also reported, for the first time, on the financial health of 479 savings banks, which are community-based lenders that hold about 10 percentof the nation's insured deposits. The F.D.I.C. said that these institutions posted losses of $771 million in the third quarter, $1.2 billion in the first nine months, and that one in every three had been losing money.
 On Monday, Lawrence Lindsey, an economic adviser to the White House, said that there was a "good chance" that a large bank in New England would fail soon. Mr. Seidman did not cite that today as the primary reason for his increase in estimating the loss to the bank insurance fund. Rather, he attributed the increased losses to two factors: greater-than-anticipated losses at the banks the F.D.I.C. expects to fail and additional bank failures generally.
 "It more than anything else reflects deteriorating values and therefore, increasing losses on failures," he said.
 
Lack of Working Capital
 Mr. Seidman said in an interview that the possible cash shortage might occur
 because of a lack of working capital that would be needed to take over failed banks. He said the bank insurance fund now had about $7 billion in cash. The rest of the fund consists of restricted funds or assets that are not immediately marketable.
 Mr. Seidman emphasized that any additional expenditures for deposit insurance would not be borne by taxpayers -- as is the case with the multibillion-dollar bailout of the savings and loan industry -- but by banks. Next month the F.D.I.C. will be considering another increase in the premiums paid by banks. Premiums are already scheduled to increase from 12 cents to 19.5 cents for every $100 in deposits in January.
 There was also bad news today for the savings and loan industry. Its chief regulator, T. Timothy Ryan Jr., told a House panel that new figures to be released on Thursday would show that significantly fewer savings institutions were profitable in the third quarter than the second quarter.
 "I'm concerned about it," Mr. Ryan told a House task force on the bailout of the savings and loan industry. "Deterioration in economic conditions, especially in real estate, is adversely affecting the propsects for recovery of many institutions."
 
New Accounting Rule
 The F.D.I.C. today also adopted a new accounting rule for banks that was the subject of intense lobbying by the banking industry and is expected to have a significant impact on the Government's ability to clean up the savings and loan debacle.
 The new rule covers the treatment of purchase mortgage servicing rights, which are increasingly finding their way into the portfolios of banks that buy failed savings institutions.
 Such rights are contracts bought or held by banks and savings associations under which the institution handles a portfolio of mortgages -- processing the monthly payments, distributing the proceeds among investors and handling foreclosures.
 The agency ruled that up to 50 percent of a bank's regulatory capital could consist of purchase mortgage servicing rights. It had no previous standard, but considered the treatment of such rights on a case-by-case basis.
 The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates nationally chartered banks, is reconsidering its standard for such rights. It now permits up to 25 percent of such rights to constitute capital.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Office Space Slumping In Chicago

BYLINE: By Cheryl Kent

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
SAPLINGS are being planted at the corners of a vacant downtown block that has become a symbol of Chicago's deflated building boom. With trees in place, the site will presumably look less forlorn until the city's slumping property market improves.
The Block 37 project, as it is known, is on hold. The land is across the street from the Richard J. Daley Plaza and one block from City Hall. It is to be the site of a $350 million office and retail project. 
 The development team consists of a consortium of Chicago's largest and most powerful developers, including Metropolitan Structures, JMB Realty and the Levy Organization. "We can't start without tenants, and we don't have them now," said Bernard Weissbourd, chairman of Metropolitan Structures.
With financing dried up and major tenants hard to find, developers in Chicago are postponing groundbreakings. Sixteen projects amounting to 21 million square feet are on hold. Among these is a 125-story building proposed by Miglin-Beitler Inc., a Chicago development concern. The building was to succeed the Sears Tower as the tallest building in the world, but so far no financing for the project has been obtained.
The office vacancy rate here reached 14.5 percent in October, the highest it has been since 1974, according to Coldwell Banker Commercial Real Estate Services in Chicago. The rate rose three percentage points since June as five million square feet of office space came on the market.
Although a total of 8.4 million square feet is now under construction, none of those projects is scheduled for completion this year, leading to expectations that vacancy rates will not rise in the fourth quarter.
Chicago is no worse off than other cities. The Real Estate Research Corporation's report on emerging trends in real estate in 1991 ranked Chicago fifth in the perceptions of business people about the prospects of real estate markets' attracting developers, investors and lenders. Los Angeles ranked third and New York 12th.
All the cities in the ranking, based on 112 interviews with real estate experts, have slipped. For 1990, Chicago had a rating of 6.7; for 1991 it is 5.4. New York's 1990 rating was 6.2; 1991's is 3.8.
Among the projects that are under way in Chicago is a 50-story office building by the Prime Group at 77 West Wacker Drive. It represents a kind of deal that is not available any longer; the tower is being financed by Swiss and Japanese banks, a development partnership of the Prime and the Kemper Investors Life Insurance Company.
Commercial brokers say that the deals that brought pension funds, insurance companies, foreign investors and commercial banks, sometimes in combinations, into joint ventures with developers on new projects can no longer be made.
One by one, these sources of financing are drying up. Jolts to Japan's stock market have made investors from that country pull back from American real estate. Pension funds and insurance companies have been disappointed by their returns on real estate and are becoming cautious about investing more.
Because of the savings and loan crisis, Federal banking regulators are concerned about the heavy commitments of banks in real estate loans. Some developers say that new underwriting requirements imposed on commercial banks by regulators are the immediate cause of the halt in construction.
"The real estate industry is out of capital," said Richard Hanson, president of Stein & Company of Chicago, which has developed several downtown office towers. "You need lots of equity now, and I'm talking about 40 to 50 percent. We have been put into a regulated recession by changes in the underwriting."
Many new buildings that have come on the market recently are only slowly being leased. Lincoln Properties' 1.3-million-square-foot building at 311 South Wacker Drive opened in May and is only 25 percent leased. The cleared sites for the project's second and third phases have been landscaped and paved over for parking.
"Projects like this exert a continued downward pressure on rents," said Richard Kateley, president of the Real Estate Research Corporation. "Tenants have multiple options for low rents, so they can bargain."
Asking rents for prime space range from $22 to $32 a square foot a year. Deals are actually being made at rents ranging from $16 to $27 a square foot, the reseach corporation said.
Chicago experienced intensive development over the last 10 years, partly because of its low vacancy rates, which stood at just 4 percent in 1980. Since 1987 Chicago has added nearly 11 million square feet to its inventory of office space. Of a total of just over 100 million square feet downtown, 15 million square feet is now unoccupied.
Predictions vary as to how long the downturn will last. With two million square feet absorbed annually, estimates are that it will be at least four to five years before significant new construction starts again.

HEADLINE: Cityspire, Music at Its Peak

BYLINE: By Monroe Price; Monroe Price is dean of Yeshiva University's Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law.

 BODY:
Cityspire, that lipstick-like 72-story edifice on West 56th Street near Seventh Avenue, has been accused of emitting a high-pitched whistle that distracts New Yorkers from Ninth to Third Avenues. The sound apparently is created by wind blowing over louvers on its dome, about 800 feet above the ground.
In our city, beset by so many ills caused by the onslaught of modernity, this novel "crime" has immediately been taken as evidence of yet another generation of insults to the senses: inhumanely gigantic buildings that are now heard as well as seen. 
 The first, predictable reaction of bureaucrats was to "arrest" the building for speaking out of turn -- to issue a summons against its surprised developer, Ian Bruce Eichner. This is far too unimaginative a response to a sound that, admittedly, can make the neighbors crazed on a blustery day.
Before New York officialdom levies an $880 fine for violating the noise control code -- before it requires the architect to alter the dome -- the community should attempt to understand what the building is trying to say. (After all, don't suburbanites interpret creaks in the attic at night?) Maybe we need a linguist who has deciphered the eerie songs of whales or the chit-chat of dolphins.
Is Cityspire's whistle a lonely call for companionship to Citibank's far-off tower in Long Island City, a sirenlike wooing of the World Trade Center, a fraternal nod to the Empire State Building, which has seen more towering days?
Maybe it is a cry of sympathy for Cityspire's lower floors, which worry about the real estate recession. Or an echo of the winds of fortune that rise and fall through increasingly vacated acres of Financial District office buildings.
As we come to appreciate Cityspire's whistle, perhaps we will not condemn it so readily. As with graffiti and other detritus of today's world, desperate New Yorkers may even come to value it as an art form. One day, the Municipal Art Society might even oppose construction modifications that would alter a building's sounds -- a step in the direction of landmarking the music of the architectural spheres.
Let's not, just yet, think of Cityspire's wail as another sign of environmental doom: the aural equivalent of global warming. Let's not explain the sound, as one newspaper did, by likening it to the result of bursts of air across the neck of a soda bottle.
To enrich, rather than impoverish, our urban lives, we might think of Cityspire's sound not as a whistle but as the voice of a mythical Wind -- Zephyr or Boreas or Eurus -- as it expresses itself in the Aeolian cave of the gods, as a kind of monologue in the sky. Or, more simply, as winter's cold heights humming an up-to-date version of "The Tin Roof Blues."

HEADLINE: Florida Authority Tax-Free Bonds

 BODY:
The Orlando-Orange County Expressway Authority for the State of Florida is offering $385 million in tax-exempt, junior-lien revenue bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.
Yields range from 6.20 percent for an issue due 1997 to 6.50 percent in 2000, 6.75 percent in 2003, 6.85 percent in 2010 and 6.95 percent in 2016.

HEADLINE: 6 States Accuse GMAC on Escrow

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Attorneys general in six states have filed suit against the GMAC Mortgage Corporation, accusing the lender of overcharging consumers by millions of dollars in excessive escrow payments.
The action seeks to bar the Detroit-based lender, part of the financial services operations of the General Motors Corporation, from building big cushions into escrow accounts and to force GMAC to recalculate the way it determines escrow payments. GMAC holds 400,000 mortgages nationwide.
Attorneys general in New York, California, Iowa, Massachusetts, Minnesota and Texas filed suit yesterday in Federal court in Manhattan.
The six states acted because the Federal Government has not enforced its own laws against the practice, Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York said. Mr. Abrams said that if the suit was successful, homeowners could receive millions of dollars in refunds.
Officials from GMAC declined to comment on the suit.
In April, the attorneys general released a study critical of the practice by mortgage lenders of requiring excess funds in escrow accounts.
"When we released the report of the illegal escrow practices of GMAC and other lenders, we urged the Federal Government to enforce its own statutory limits on escrow payments," Mr. Abrams said. "So far, it has taken no action." That has prompted suits like this one "at great cost to the states," Mr. Abrams added.
The study said consumers were being overcharged $2 billion to $4 billion by the nation's mortgage lenders.
Lenders maintain escrow accounts to make payments for property taxes, insurance and other items that borrowers must pay. Extra money in escrow accounts hurts consumers but is a bonanza for lenders, who pay a low rate of interest or nothing for use of the funds, regulators say. About two-thirds of the nation's home mortgages involve escrow accounts.
Federal law limits lenders to a two-month "cushion" in escrow -- enough money to make payments for two months. The cushion allows lenders to make tax and insurance payments even if the consumer's monthly payment is late.
"Our report estimated that the 'excess cushion' averages about $150 per homeowner," Attorney General Tom Miller of Iowa said. "That means we think lenders are holding several billion dollars that should be in the hands of their customers."
The report called on the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, Jack Kemp, to tighten enforcement of the law. The attorneys general said inaction by the agency had led them to file the suit.
The study focused on big lenders that operate nationwide. A survey of four of the largest -- Citibank, GMAC Mortgage, the Fleet Mortgage Corporation and the Lomas Financial Group -- "indicated that lenders may be holding excessive and illegal cushions in more than 70 percent of escrow accounts."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Quiet Trading And Gold Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower against foreign currencies yesterday in what traders said was one of the quietest trading days of the year.
Gold prices were mixed.
With currency trading thinned by the pre-holiday season, the dollar eased largely on technical factors, mostly ignoring the day's few external influences. 
 "A lot of people are already sidelined for the holidays," said Gabriele Schmitt, vice president for the Bank of New York. "We had absolutely no indicators come out today."
Traders said the British pound showed signs of strength after the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont, said British interest rates would remain at their current level and not be lowered.
Sterling strengthened to $1.9502 in New York from late Tuesday's $1.9380, and in London, the pound rose to $1.9435, from $1.9400 late Tuesday.
But traders said the market shrugged off an early-day rumor that Iraq would withdraw its troops from Kuwait before the Jan. 15 deadline imposed in a resolution passed last month by the United Nations. The rumor later proved to be untrue.
The resolution permits the use of military force against Iraq if the country remains in occupied Kuwait beyond the mid-January deadline.
"People are pretty happy to stay square and not really get involved that much," said Renato Strauss, currency trader at Bank Julius Baer & Co. "I had one of the lowest volume days of the year."
The dollar lost ground against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 131.45 yen, from 132.40 late Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 131.88 Japanese yen from 131.75 yen at Tuesday's close, and later in London it was quoted at 131.75 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's prices, included: 1.4756 German marks, down from 1.4784; 1.2610 Swiss francs, down from 1.2650; 5.0120 French francs, down from 5.0190; 1,112.00 Italian lire, down from 1,114.00, and 1.1606 Canadian dollars, unchanged.
Gold rose in New York, closing up 70 cents a troy ounce, to $372.70, on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $371.45 a troy ounce, down 55 cents from late Tuesday.
Silver fell on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $4.026 a troy ounce, down 4.1 cents. It also fell in London to a late bid price of $4.03 a troy ounce, from $4.06 bid late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: In Urals City, the Communist Apparatus Ends but Not the Communist Power

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SVERDLOVSK, U.S.S.R.

 BODY:
Until recently, the ornate green building at the corner of Pushkin and Lenin Streets housed an intimidating organization called the Sverdlovsk People's Control Committee.
The committee, part of a nationwide citizens' network run by the Communist Party to inspect the work of government and industrial enterprises, was abolished last summer by the democratic reformers who have swept into office in the Russian Republic. 
 Today the wood-paneled office suite is occupied by a new power, the Ural Regional Association of International Trade Cooperation, a commercial export agency. Within days of its creation in September, the association was awarded a priority government license to help market $2 billion worth of surplus production of local manufacturers.
And the general director of this lucky new venture? He is Vladimir K. Gaffner, who before becoming a trade middleman was chairman of the Sverdlovsk People's Control Committee.
 
Little Changing of Guard
 Eight months after Sverdlovsk voted out the Communist old guard in its first contested City Council elections, this Urals industrial stronghold is discovering -- along with many other cities -- that real power has not changed hands, and in some cases has not even changed desks.
The new City Council has inherited much of the public discontent over empty grocery stores, inflation and rising street crime. But local officials and journalists say the quality of life in the city still depends largely on an unelected elite that controls the flow of money, privilege and influence.
This interlocking directorate includes the military-industrial complex, the unelected executive bureaucracy, the police agencies and the adaptable Communist Party, which is now parlaying its great wealth into commercial power.
"People blame the new democrats for everything," said Sergei Plotnikov, a local reporter who has long specialized in law enforcement issues. "But power still belongs to all these mafias."
 
Center of Arms Industry
 Sverdlovsk, a city of 1.35 million people, is the heart of the Soviet heavy machinery industry, a category that includes tanks, rockets and other military hardware as well as excavators, rolling mills and oil derricks.
The Mayor estimates that nearly a third of the workforce makes weapons. The gray stone building housing the military industrial ministries, known locally as the "Pentagon," fills an entire city block.
Access to the city is controlled not by the City Council but by the military and K.G.B., which until recently had never admitted an American reporter. Recently the city has begun opening to foreigners as local industry desperately seeks Western investment.
Two of the leading rivals in current Soviet politics are products of Sverdlovsk.
President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian Republic began as the Communist Party boss of Sverdlovsk province. He remains a popular hero here, the exemplar of a nationwide democratic insurgency that helped oust the Communists in the city elections.
 
Ryzhkov's Legacy Lives
 Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, the Soviet Prime Minister, ran this city's gigantic Uralmash machine tool plant. He is regarded now as a feckless politician and an emblem of the past.
Yet Mr. Ryzhkov's legacy lives on on Sverdlovsk, perhaps larger than Mr. Yeltsin's.
The Uralmash plant, for example, which turns out giant machines for mining and processing industries -- with a sideline in tank components -- rules the largest of several urban fiefs that has been virtually untouched by the election of a new City Council.
The Uralmash neighborhood at the northern edge of Sverdlovsk is a sprawling, company-maintained micro-city of 180,000 residents. The company provides cheap apartments, kindergartens and food packets for its workers and for a whole community of doctors, teachers and clerks who serve them.
The company pays all its taxes to Moscow, which decides how much to share with the city.
 
'We Have Our Own City'
 "Why do we need them?" Anatoly S. Osintsev, deputy general director of Uralmash, said when asked the enterprise's relationship with the City Council. "We have our own city -- 180,000 people. Isn't that a city? It's all on our budget."
Even such an elementary city service as police protection is in large part beyond the control of the local government.
This fall salesmen from Interpass Ltd., an Irvington, N.Y., police equipment company, arrived here to peddle handcuffs and body armor to the local police.
Their customer, it turned out, was not the Sverdlovsk City Council. It was a consortium of factories that had pooled some of their foreign currency earnings and bypassed the government to fight crime.
The City Council, elected in March, is nominally responsible for making sure the state stores are stocked with ample food and consumer goods for the population, but there, too, the city is dependent on its industry.
 
State Stores Barren
 In the past Sverdlovsk lived better than other parts of the country, because the central Government in Moscow took pains to feed its military-industrial workers. But the central distribution system has broken down as farm regions hoard food for themselves, and state stores here have become as barren as those in Moscow.
The Mayor of Sverdlovsk, Yuri Y. Samarin, said the city has little to trade with farm regions for food because most of its industry produces heavy equipment for the state.
The city has tried to stimulate small enterprises, and has legalized several free-market stores that sell Finnish boots, children's clothes from China and Western beer and cigarettes at high prices.
But many would-be entrepreneurs have fallen prey to organized crime or been crushed by state and industrial trading organizations that are not eager for competition.
 
Impatient With Democracy
 As in other cities where newcomers are in the majority, the failure to put food in the stores has made the public impatient with the tedious business of democracy.
"They pass a lot of pretty laws, but nothing changes," said a student at the Urals Polytechnical Institute, where the alumni include both Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Ryzhkov.
Sergei L. Nazarov, who works for a commercial publishing enterprise, said many citizens believed that the new city councilmen had already been seduced by the perks of the job.
"You know the Arab fable about a dragon sitting on a pile of gold?" he asked. "A young man goes out and slays the dragon, and when he sits on top of the pile of gold he himself turns into a dragon.
"That is us. The pile of gold is privileges."
 
Public Expectations Faulted
 Mr. Samarin, a former engineer at a rocket factory who was chosen as Mayor with backing from the democratic insurgents, said the public expected too much from a city government that is inexperienced and has little leverage.
"There has been far too much talk about perestroika, while all the while the old administrative system is allowed to live on," he said. "This is where the disappointment comes from."
The most effective tool the city has had so far has been a kind of blackmail, using the threat of worker unrest to extract concessions from the authorities in Moscow.
This fall the city sent an appeal to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Mr. Ryzhkov threatening to withhold marketable commodities like nickel from the defense industry unless the food situation improved.
 
Moscow Increases Deliveries
 "There was a threat of deep social unrest in the city, and we were forced to make a decision to appeal to the Government," the Mayor said. "We said, 'Give us what we are entitled to, since we cannot feed ourselves, or we will be forced to appeal to work collectives to take part of their output to be used in barter deals.' "
Mr. Ryzhkov agreed to increase deliveries from the central food fund, and also issued an order letting Sverdlovsk companies sell a certain portion of their goods abroad to raise money for consumer supplies.
The Communists, reduced in the elections to a minority in the City Council, have been adapting to defeat by tightening their grip on other levers of power.
The party still has an entrenched presence in the government apparatus, the city and provincial executive committees that can cut a citizen's red tape or tie him up in a bureaucratic straitjacket. Theoretically these agencies are the working arms of the elected councils, but in practice they are often the only ones with the connections to get anything done.
 
Party Goes Commercial
 In Sverdlovsk, as elsewhere in the Soviet Union, the party is shoring up its position by pumping its wealth into commercial joint ventures, small businesses and trading organizations.
The party owns the best hotel in town, which it puts at the disposal of factories and visiting trade delegations. It has the best computers and printing services, and its 22-story office tower dominates the skyline.
Stanislav V. Yachevsky, a city councilman, sees Communists exploiting this period of confusion to build comfortable new niches for themselves.
"Then when the structure begins to fall apart, they will have a way to retreat," he said. "They will be powerful again, but it will be commercial power rather than ideological. It is a great danger."
Mr. Plotnikov, the journalist, agreed, saying: "The party is the fifth column in the market economy. They serve a purpose, but the harm outweighs the good. Even the most honest of them has bad habits in his blood."

LENGTH: 476 words

HEADLINE: G.M. and Ford Wary on '91; Gulf Outcome Called a Key

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 12

 BODY:
The clouded economic outlook is forcing the nation's two biggest auto makers to hedge their bets for 1991, with sales projections trimmed and the level of dividend payments perhaps in question.
A crucial issue for the economy and Detroit, top executives of General Motors and Ford agreed today in year-end news conferences, will be the outcome of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. 
 Philip E. Benton Jr., president of the Ford Motor Company, said the company's $3 annual dividend might not be sustainable next year if the economy continued to be weak and war broke out in the Middle East.
For its part, the General Motors Corporation is forecasting industrywide domestic car and truck sales of about 13.5 million units for 1991, said Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, down about 5 percent from the 14.2 million to 14.3 million vehicles expected to be sold this year.
The company's forecast assumes there will not be armed conflict in the Middle East, Mr. Stempel said. Otherwise, the total could be lower. Lloyd E. Reuss, G.M.'s president, said several assembly plants in the United States would be temporarily idled in 1991 for extensive retooling for model changes. He added that some assembly line speeds would be slowed and workers laid off to match production with lower sales.
Mr. Stempel declined to speculate on whether G.M.'s cash dividend on common stock was secure at its current rate, but he said the No. 1 auto maker "is financially strong."
Mr. Benton's statement is the first from a top Ford executive suggesting that finances might be tight for the No. 2 auto maker in the industry's downturn.
The Chrysler Corporation, the weakest of the three, last week declared its regular quarterly dividend. A spokesman said Chrysler's forecast is for industry sales of 13.8 million cars and trucks in 1991 but added that the number could dip below 13 million or climb to 14 million, depending on the severity of the downturn.
The shares of the Big Three have been trading at relatively weak prices and high dividend yields for several months because investors believe that dividend cuts are possible, analysts say. General Motors and Chrysler posted losses for the third quarter, and Ford reported a steep drop in profits.
"Ford's statement confirms what the stock market has already been thinking," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch. "It doesn't come as a shock."
Until recently, Ford executives have said that cost-cutting and restructuring would allow the company to make money and maintain its dividend even in a recession. Ford is planning on 1991 industry sales of about 13.5 million vehicles.
"If hostilities break out, oil prices may again skyrocket and the outlook for the economy and the auto industry would be quite different," said Harold A. Poling, Ford's chairman, in a statement.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Great Western

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 12

 BODY:
The Great Western Financial Corporation, an operator of savings and loan associations, will close its Great Western Real Estate subsidiary and abandon the real estate brokerage business. Combined with layoffs announced last month, the shutdown will put 1,506 people out of work -- 241 staff members and 1,265 full-time real estate agents. The real estate company, based in Yorba Linda, Calif., had $50 million in gross sales commissions last year.

HEADLINE: White Men Get Better Deals on Cars, Study Finds

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Research on scores of car dealerships here has found that salespeople who bargain with customers over the price of a new car make significantly lower final offers to white men than to women or blacks.
The findings, by a research group established by the American Bar Association, were based on more than 550 visits to dealerships in the Chicago area by researchers who posed as middle-class car buyers. The researchers sought to follow a set of carefully rehearsed negotiating tactics to extract the best final offers from the salespeople. 
 Ian Ayres, an assistant professor at the Northwestern University School of Law who wrote the study, said the results raised questions about whether civil-rights laws were adequate to protect black and women consumers against discrimination.
 
Unregulated Markets
 "The civil rights laws of the 1960's picked out only a handful of markets -- employment, housing and public accommodations -- and left virtually unregulated much larger markets for retail goods and services," said Mr. Ayres, who is a lawyer and an economist. "It was important to determine whether discrimination has an effect in these markets as well."
The researchers noted that the pattern persisted regardless of the race and sex of the salesperson.
The research, described by experts as the first to test for racial or sexual discrimination in new car sales, was commissioned by the American Bar Foundation, an organization founded by the bar. It is an independent, nonprofit organization based in Chicago that conducts research on the law, legal institutions and the legal professions.
A spokesman for the National Automobile Dealers Association, Allan Wilbur, who had not seen the research, said he could not comment on it but said the association believed that all customers should be treated the same, regardless of race or sex.
Mr. Ayres based his conclusions on two related surveys.
The results of the first study, which took place about 18 months ago, will be the subject of an article in the February issue of the Harvard Law Review.
 
90 Dealers in Study
 In that survey, three white male researchers divided among them 90 car dealers and then visited the concerns, trying to negotiate the best possible offer on the price of a new car. At about the same time, each of those dealers was also visited by one of three other testers -- a white female, a black male and a black female -- who bargained over the same car.
When the results of the first study of some 165 visits were tabulated, the white men were found to have received final offers that averaged about $11,362 on a new automobile with a dealer sticker price of about $13,465. The researchers said the dealer's cost of the car, which included air conditioning and power steering, was about $11,000. The make and model of the car were not disclosed.
By contrast, the white female researcher was given an average final price of about $11,504, a price containing a markup that was was about 40 percent higher than that offered to white men. The black male was given an average price of $11,783, containing more than double the markup than that offered to the white men. The black woman was given an average price of $12,237, with three times the markup.
Mr. Ayres noted in his study that discrimination appeared to be a factor even in the dealer's initial offer, before any negotiations had begun. When the researchers asked the salesperson for the first, best offer, they quoted an average price of about $11,818 for white males, $11,829 for the white female, $12,534 for the black male, and $13,169 for the black female.
A more comprehensive follow-up study, completed more recently, involved 36 testers, including five black males, eight black females, six white females and 17 white males. The testers made more than 400 visits to some 200 showrooms and bargained over nine models of cars.
That study showed similar disparities in the dealers' treatment of the testers, Mr. Ayres said, except that this time the highest final quotes were given to black men.
 
'A Closer Look'
 "When car bargaining ends up hurting those people in society who have already been traditionally disadvantaged, I think we need to take a closer look at the process," said Mr. Ayres.
As in tests for bias in housing, with individuals posing as buyers to determine whether real estate agents discriminated on the basis of race in the sale or rental of houses and apartments, the aim of the new research was to measure discrimination, rather than investigate its cause.
But in trying to interpret his findings, Mr. Ayres suggested that the results might reflect dealers' beliefs about how much they can get from various groups of people, rather than outright or intentional bigotry.
He said there might be a shared and perhaps even subconscious assumption among many salespeople that blacks and women are less knowledgeable or adept at the bargaining process than are white males, and that they therefore are more willing to accept an offer that gives the dealer a higher markup.
Mr. Ayres describes this process as the sellers' "search for suckers," an attempt to concentrate profits in sales to a relatively few customers who will pay the higher markups.
 
Access to Data Is Key
 "The reason a larger proportion of blacks or women are more willing to pay a higher markup does not suggest they are inferior," said Mr. Ayres. Rather, there is an inference they may have less access to information about the automobile bargaining process, or have done less comparison shopping.
He cited a survey of consumers last spring by the Consumer Federation of America as finding that 37 percent did not know that the price of a new car was negotiable. When the responses were broken down by race, Mr. Ayres said, 61 percent of blacks said they did not know they could bargain over price, compared to 31 percent of whites.
Pamela Karlan, professor of law at the University of Virginia and a specialist in sex discrimination and civil rights matters, said she was not surprised by the findings. "You see it happening all the time in housing cases, even though housing is supposedly regulated," she said. "And the courts have held that stereotyping people on the basis of sex or race is intentional discrimination," she added, even though it was not based on bigotry.
Although bigotry may be a factor as well, its effect is harder to divine, Mr. Ayres said. In fact, the researchers in the Northwestern study often received the worst offer from salespeople of the same race and sex.
 
Changes in Marketplace
 Mr. Wilbur, of the car dealers' association, which represents 20,000 of the nation's dealers, said the industry was trying to do a better job of dealing with what he called the changing nature of the marketplace, in which consumers, including a growing number of women, are better informed and are demanding better service.
To that end, he said the trade group next year would begin a sales certification program aimed at setting standards for showroom sales staffs. Among other things, it will include courses on ethics, contract law and sales psychology, he said.
Remar Sutton, a former automobile dealer and the author of a 1981 book entitled "Don't Get Taken Every Time," said the new study's findings underscored the central strategy of automobile sales: the weaker the person, the stronger the profit.
The salesperson will not give the same deal to most women or blacks that will be offered to whites, he said, because there is an unstated assumption that white males have more bargaining experience. "It's not racism, except to the extent that if you are a salesman, you learn over time you can make a lot more money off poor blacks and some women," said Mr. Sutton, who writes a booklet aimed at educating consumers on the purchase and financing of automobiles.
The researchers who conducted the survey were schooled in a uniform strategy, with questions and behavior part of the design of the study. They were dressed casually, but neatly, as college-educated, urban professionals from 24 to 28 years of age. They were told to say, if asked, that they lived in an upscale Chicago neighborhood. They also told the salesperson that they intended to finance the purchase themselves.
Mr. Ayres said those who believe they are the victims of racial discrimination in a retail transaction can bring civil lawsuits under civil rights laws outlawing racial bias in contracting. Those laws were enacted after the Civil War. But he said there were no statutes to protect women from discrimination in retail sales.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ian Ayres of Northwestern University headed the research group in whose study car dealers often discriminated against women and blacks, making better final offers to white men. (Tim Wright for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE TRADE DECISION;
Bush's Move Unlikely to Mean Quick Trade Surge

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
President Bush's major step today toward normalizing commercial relations with the Soviet Union will increase American farm exports, but is unlikely in the short term to lead to a big surge in two-way trade.
The two countries will sell each other about $3.6 billion worth of goods this year -- little more than what the United States exchanges with Haiti. 
 The immediate impact of the decision today will be to give the Soviets Agriculture Department and Export-Import Bank credits to buy more American food and industrial products.
Moscow is expected to seek $1 billion in food credits during the current fiscal year, which ends next Sept. 30, according to Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter.
 
A Threat by the Soviets
 The Soviets had threatened that if the credits were withheld they would swing more of their purchases to the European Community and other food suppliers already offering generous credit terms.
Moscow can get up to $300 million of credits from the Export-Import Bank. The Stevenson Amendment to the 1974 Trade Act says Federal agencies may not lend or guarantee more than that in loans to finance exports to the Soviet Union unless Congress certifies that the Soviet Union has ended its limits on emigration. The Administration is considered likely to seek repeal of the amendment next year.
Companies like Upjohn, which is planning Soviet pharmaceutical plants, or International Business Machines, which is planning to sell tens of thousands of personal computers, are understood to be among those seeking the Export-Import Bank credits.
"There's a great deal of demand from the Soviet Union and a lot of big, medium and small companies that want to do business there," said John D. Macomber, Export-Import Bank president.
He predicted in an interview that the bank -- which, like similar institutions in other industrial countries, gives loans to finance exports -- would sign its first deal "within the next month."
 
Lower Duties Will Result
 Early next year, the President is expected to send to Congress the trade agreement the two countries concluded earlier this year, which sets the economic framework for their enterprises to establish deeper footholds in each other's markets. Under that agreement, normalization of trade relations between the two nations can take place only after the Soviet Parliament passes a law codifying free movement of people into and out of the country.
Once Congress assents, sharply lower duties would be charged on Soviet imports. This could help the Soviets sell more goods in the United States.
All Soviet products sold here -- including vodka, caviar, anhydrous ammonia, fiberboard, porcelain statues and other products -- would enter the United States at the most favored nation tariff rates, the lowest level granted to any country.
Duties on Soviet imports now are as much as 10 times higher as those on goods from other countries. On vodka, for example, the change could mean a consumer saving of as much as $1.25 a bottle.
 
'Only Good Things' Expected
 That trade will increase is almost certain. "The Soviet Union is the biggest untapped market in the world," said Margaret Chapman, director of the trade forum of the American Committee on U.S. Soviet-Relations, a Washington-based public policy organization representing business and academic interests.
"Only good things will come from this decision," she added.
But whether Soviet-American trade takes off depends in large measure on what happens to the Soviet economy, now going through a series of painful changes.
To support Soviet restructuring efforts, President Bush proposed a "special association" of the Soviet Union with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to give Moscow access to the economic and financial expertise of these institutions.
This could mean a special status for the Soviets in the institution, which would put Moscow somewhere between full membership and nonmembership, according to the White House.
The two giant credit organizations advise countries on ways to improve economic performance, conditioning their loans on the countries' willingness to take the counsel.
 
Help From the I.M.F.
 The White House said that under the plan the I.M.F. would provide technical assistance on financial, exchange rate, tax reform and banking policies while the World Bank would advise on revamping broad sectors of the economy, such as transportation and energy.
Sometime later the Soviets will probably seek full membership in the institutions, which count 154 other nations as members and have combined assets of nearly $400 billion.
The Soviet Union was vice chairman of the 1944 Bretton Woods conference, at which the two organizations were created. Stalin then pulled out as the cold war began.
Officials of the two organizations said the proposals would be taken up shortly in their executive boards.
Because of large food exports, the United States runs a big trade surplus with the Soviet Union.
Most of what the United States buys from the Soviets is raw materials. The biggest import is fuel oil, followed by anhydrous ammonia used to make fertilizer, palladium and such products as fur skins, vodka, caviar, woven cotton fabric and crabs cooked in their shells.
