HEADLINE: Official Sees Consistency in Scholarship Rule

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
As an undergraduate and a law student at the University of Southern California in the late 1970's, Michael L. Williams challenged the university to increase its number of minority students.
But as head of the civil rights office in the Education Department, Mr. Williams is telling colleges and universities that if they give out scholarships based on race, except in narrow instances, they will be violating the law. 
 The 37-year-old Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights sees no inconsistency in the actions.
"You have to go back to the position that we took at Southern Cal," he said today. "We said the university needed to look at a lot of other variables besides the S.A.T. in selecting students. We urged them to look at economic disadvantage, whether students overcome large obstacles, et cetera. We did not urge them to say we will admit 15 black students a year."
 
A Fresh Wind in June
 Mr. Williams, a domestic policy analyst in George Bush's Presidential campaign in 1988, is a former Justice Department official. He was considered a fresh wind in a moribund agency when he took over the Education Department office in June.
Civil rights and education groups were cautiously optimistic that he would be sympathetic to their concerns, particularly because he emphasized the law-enforcement aspects of his office. He sought redress for anti-Asian admissions practices uncovered in a 30-month investigation at the University of California at Los Angeles. He also completed an investigation at Harvard University, concluding that there was no anti-Asian bias in admissions procedures there.
The Office of Civil Rights is responsible for enforcing Federal laws that prohibit discrimination based on race, sex, national original, handicap or age in all education programs or activities that receive Federal money.
In his confirmation hearings Mr. Williams said that his office could support education goals that the governors and the President have set for the nation by insuring that grouping students by ability was not carried out in discriminatory fashion and that children whose first language is not English were not disproportionately placed in special education programs. These are concerns of education and civil rights groups.
But Mr. Williams draws his educational philosophy from the early roots of the civil rights struggle and its search not for racially balanced schools or busing but for equal education opportunities for blacks.
Mr. Williams said today that the reaction to his policy prohibiting scholarships based on race was "maybe a bit of unnecessary frustration and anxiety." He added that he was not worried that without such scholarships universities and colleges would not increase the number of minority students in their institutions.
"There are a lot of forces out there that will force universities to do the right thing," Mr. Williams said. "We can get minority students into schools without saying that the only way you can get in is that there are five seats allocated here for you."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Effort Sells Bonds, But at a Price

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
After its most intensive marketing and lobbying campaign in years, New York City was able to sell almost $1.3 billion in long-term bonds yesterday, but the price to the city was high. It was the first such sale since the city's financial situation sharply deteriorated in the last few months.
Yields to investors ranged up to 8.5 percent for the longer-term tax-exempt bonds, under prices worked out in negotiations between city officials and a team of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. 
 Over the last few days, Mayor David N. Dinkins and a parade of city officials and business leaders met with representatives of bond rating agencies in a tense but successful effort to convince them that the administration was on top of the city's worsening finances and that the city's credit rating should not be lowered.
 
Lower Rates Than Expected
 But to attract investors the bonds sold at yields far higher than those of most other comparably rated bonds, or even higher than most bonds that have lower but still investment-grade ratings. That cost the city tens of millions of dollars in higher interest costs.
Underwriters said that once the ratings were reaffirmed -- A from Moody's Investors Service and A- from Standard & Poor's, which are medium- to high-investment-grade ratings -- there was strong interest by both institutional and individual investors. The bond offering was the largest in memory by the city, which is the largest single borrower in the municipal credit markets.
Bradford Higgins, a managing director at First Boston, said the tax-exempt bonds, totaling $950 million, had lower rates than many traders had expected.
Because of the strong interest in the bonds, the city was able to reduce yields yesterday evening. Late in the day, the city increased its offering of taxable bonds from about $200 million worth to $332 million because it had received several large orders.
The highest yield for these was almost 11 percent.
"Keeping the rating helped a lot," he said. "We are very pleased with the reception we have gotten. Compared to where New York City was a month ago you have got to view this as a vote of confidence."
The cost of borrowing has increased sharply since the the city last sold long-term bonds in September. For example, yesterday preliminary yields were 8.45 percent on bonds maturing in 15 years, an increase of 0.60 of a percentage point over the yields of similar bonds sold in September.
But during the same period, interest rates, including yields on municipal bonds, fell. An index of bonds compiled by the Delphis Hanover Corporation shows that on, average, yields on 15-year bonds rated A declined by 0.45 of a percentage point. So, in effect, the extra cost to the city is 1.05 percentage points more than for similar city bonds offered only four months ago.
This translates into more money to be paid to bondholders by the city over the life of the bonds. Each percentage point on the $1.1 billion in bonds translates into about $11 million in interest costs a year. So if the entire offering had consisted of 15-year bonds, the city would be paying $165 million more in interest than it would have on identical bonds sold four months earlier.
Last night Ms. Holtzman put the overall cost to the city of the tax-exempt borrowing at 8.35 percent, up from 7.9 percent in September.
The city is paying even higher costs than the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, which has been struggling with financial problems and whose bonds have lower ratings. On Tuesday when Massachusetts sold $526 million in bonds, the top yield was 7.8 percent on 17-year bonds. Similar New York City bonds were yielding about 8.5 percent. The Massachusetts bonds were rated only Baa by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
 
Meetings to Raise Confidence
 But rather than focusing on the high costs of the borrowing, city officials pointed to their intensive campaign to drum up demand for the city's bonds by lobbying institutional investors and rating agency officials and by using an investment vehicle the city had never used before, a zero-coupon bond, which was marketed as the New York CitySaver. The bond pays no yearly interest but sells at a deep discount. For instance, a few hundred dollars will buy a typical bond that will be worth $5,000 in the year 2005.
Deputy Mayor Sally Piniero-Hernandez said that in recent weeks Mayor Dinkins and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman met with officials from each rating agency at least three times.
She said officials from both rating agencies were given helicopter tours of development sites and an intensive round of briefings.
"We told them pick any commissioner you like, and we will have them meet with you," she said. As a result they met with Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, and the Human Resources Administrator, Barbara Sabol.
 
'Marketplace Has Been Churning'
 Mark Page, a deputy city budget director, said uncertainty in the marketplace about the city had contributed to the high yields, as was the city's plan to hold more bond sales over the next few years.
"The marketplace has been churning over New York," he said. Now that the rating agencies have reaffirmed their ratings, he said, demand for New York bonds might increase.
The city is to sell $1 billion in bonds in February, but city officials said they were re-examining their schedule of borrowing.
One investor who has not been deterred is James Gammon, who manages municipal bond investments for the of Loews Corporation. Acting, in part, on the advice of former Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who is now a consultant, Mr. Gammon began buying large quantities of New York City bonds in October on behalf of Loews and related entities as city bond prices fell.
With a portpolio of $350 million in city bonds, Loews quickly became the largest single holder of city bonds. Yesterday Mr. Gammon was said to be placing orders for more bonds.
"When the bonds got beat up, we started to buy," he said. "The bonds are selling like the city is going out of business. City bonds are a terrific bargain."
